Manx: Nagh vel daa sparroo er nyn greck son farling? as cha duitt annane oc marroo er y thalloo fegooish oardagh yn Ayr eu.

English: 30 But the very hairs of your head are all numbered.
Manx: Agh ta eer renaigyn nyn ghing ooilley er nyn earroo.

English: 31 Fear ye not therefore, ye are of more value than many sparrows.
Manx: Ny bee-jee shiuish er-y-fa shen ayns aggle, ta ny smoo dy ve soit jiu na jeh ymmodee sperriu.

English: 32 Whosoever therefore shall confess me before men, him will I confess also before my Father which is in heaven.
Manx: Quoi-erbee er-y-fa shen ghoys rhyms kiongoyrt rish deiney, goyms rishyn myrgeddin kiongoyrt rish my Ayr t’ayns niau.

English: 33 But whosoever shall deny me before men, him will I also deny before my Father which is in heaven.
Manx: Agh quoi-erbee obbys mish kiongoyrt rish deiney, eshyn nee’ms myrgeddin y obbal kiongoyrt rish my Ayr t’ayns niau.

English: 34 Think not that I am come to send peace on earth: I came not to send peace, but a sword.
Manx: Ny smooinee-jee dy daink mish dy chur lhiam shee gys y thalloo: cha daink mee dy chur lhiam shee, agh cliwe.

English: 35 For I am come to set a man at variance against his father, and the daughter against her mother, and the daughter in law against her mother in law.
Manx: Son ta mish er-jeet dy scarrey dooinney veih e ayr, as yn inneen veih e moir, as y ven-chlewn veih e moir ’sy leigh.

English: 36 And a man’s foes shall be they of his own household.
Manx: As noidjyn dooinney vees adsyn jeh’n lught-thie echey hene.

English: 37 He that loveth father or mother more than me is not worthy of me: and he that loveth son or daughter more than me is not worthy of me.
Manx: Eshyn ta ny s’graihee er ayr ny moir na orryms, cha vel Eh feeu jee’m: as eshyn ta ny s’graihee er mac ny inneen na orryms, cha vel Eh feeu jee’m.

English: 38 And he that taketh not his cross, and followeth after me, is not worthy of me.
Manx: As eshyn nagh jean e chrosh y ymmyrkey as geiyrt orryms, cha vel Eh feeu jee’m.

English: 39 He that findeth his life shall lose it: and he that loseth his life for my sake shall find it.
Manx: Eshyn nee e vioys y hauail, caillee Eh eh: agh eshyn chaillys e vioys er my ghraih’s, nee Eh eh y hauail.

English: 40 ¶He that receiveth you receiveth me, and he that receiveth me receiveth him that sent me.
Manx: Eshyn ta soiaghey jiuish, t’eh soiaghey jee’ms; as eshyn ta soiaghey jee’ms, t’eh soiaghey jehsyn t’er my choyrt.

English: 41 He that receiveth a prophet in the name of a prophet shall receive a prophet’s reward; and he that receiveth a righteous man in the name of a righteous man shall receive a righteous man’s reward.
Manx: Eshyn ta cur oltaghey-bea da phadeyr ayns ennym phadeyr, yiow Eh leagh phadeyr; as eshyn ta cur oltaghey-bea da dooinney cairagh, ayns ennym dooinney cairagh, yiow Eh leagh dooinney cairagh.

English: 42 And whosoever shall give to drink unto one of these little ones a cup of cold water only in the name of a disciple, verily I say unto you, he shall in no wise lose his reward.
Manx: As quoi-erbee ver cappan dy ushtey feayr da annane jeh’n vooinjer veggey shoh dy iu, ayns ennym annane jeusyn ta sheer geiyrt orryms, dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, nagh jean Eh er aght erbee e leagh y choall.
CAB. XI.

English: And it came to pass, when Jesus had made an end of commanding his twelve disciples, he departed thence to teach and to preach in their cities.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, tra va Yeesey erreish saaraghyn y choyrt da e ghaa ostyl jeig, dy jagh Eh veih shen dy ynsaghey as dy phreacheil ayns ny ard-valjyn oc.

English: 2 Now when John had heard in the prison the works of Christ, he sent two of his disciples,
Manx: Nish tra va Ean er chlashtyn ayns y phryssoon jeh obbraghyn Chreest, hug Eh jees jeusyn v’er ny ve sheer marish er chaghteraght huggey,

English: 3 And said unto him, Art thou he that should come, or do we look for another?
Manx: Dy ghra rish, Nee uss Eh * va dy heet, ny vel shin dy yeeaghyn son fer elley?
*Yn Messias.

English: 4 Jesus answered and said unto them, Go and shew John again those things which ye do hear and see:
Manx: Dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh roo, Immee-jee as soilshee-jee da Ean ny reddyn ta shiu dy chlashtyn as dy akin:

English: 5 The blind receive their sight, and the lame walk, the lepers are cleansed, and the deaf hear, the dead are raised up, and the poor have the gospel preached to them.
Manx: Ta ny doail geddyn nyn soilshey, as ny croobee shooyll, ny louraanee er nyn ghlenney, ny beuyr clashtyn, ny merriu er nyn mioghey, as [yn] sushtal er ny phreacheil da ny boghtyn.

English: 6 And blessed is he, whosoever shall not be offended in me.
Manx: As bannit ta eshyn nagh gow oyr dy huittym ersooyl [veih’n Chredjue] er y choontey aym’s.

English: 7 ¶And as they departed, Jesus began to say unto the multitudes concerning John, What went ye out into the wilderness to see? A reed shaken with the wind?
Manx: As myr v’ad goll roue, ren Yeesey toshiaght dy ghra rish y pobble mychione Ean, Cre hie shiu magh gys yn aasagh dy akin? Cuirtlagh criht lesh y gheay?

English: 8 But what went ye out for to see? A man clothed in soft raiment? behold, they that wear soft clothing are in kings’ houses.
Manx: Agh cre hie shiu magh dy akin? Dooinney coamrit ayns sheedey? Cur-my-ner, t’adsyn ta ceau sheedey ayns thieyn reeaghyn.

English: 9 But what went ye out for to see? A prophet? yea, I say unto you, and more than a prophet.
Manx: Agh cre hie shiu magh dy akin? Phadeyr? dy jarroo, ta mee gra riu, as fer syrjey na phadeyr.

English: 10 For this is he, of whom it is written, Behold, I send my messenger before thy face, which shall prepare thy way before thee.
Manx: Son shoh Eh jeh te scruit, Cur-my-ner, ta mee cur my haghter magh royd, dy yannoo aarloo dty raad er dty hon.

English: 11 Verily I say unto you, Among them that are born of women there hath not risen a greater than John the Baptist: notwithstanding he that is least in the kingdom of heaven is greater than he.
Manx: Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, nyn mastey ocsyn t’er ve ruggit jeh mraane, cha vel fer syrjey na Ean Bashtey er n’irree seose: ny-yeih ta’n fer * sloo t’ayns reeriaght niau ny syrjey na eshyn.
* Yn fer-ynsee sloo jeh’n sushtal.

English: 12 And from the days of John the Baptist until now the kingdom of heaven suffereth violence, and the violent take it by force.
Manx: As er dy laghyn Ean Bashtey derrey nish, ta sleih chionney stiagh gys reeriaght niau, as t’adsyn ta cheet lesh jeeanid cosney stiagh ayn.

English: 13 For all the prophets and the law prophesied until John.
Manx: Son ren ooilley ny phadeyryn as y leigh phadeyrys derrey Ean.

English: 14 And if ye will receive it, this is Elias, which was for to come.
Manx: As my ta shiu booiagh y chlashtyn eh, shoh Elias va ry hoi cheet.

English: 15 He that hath ears to hear, let him hear.
Manx: Eshyn ta cleashyn echey dy chlashtyn, lig da clashtyn.

English: 16 ¶But whereunto shall I liken this generation? It is like unto children sitting in the markets, and calling unto their fellows,
Manx: Agh cre gys nee’m yn cheeloghe shoh y hoyllaghey? T’ad goll rish cloan ta nyn soie ayns ny margaghyn, as geamagh da ny sheshaghyn oc,

English: 17 And saying, We have piped unto you, and ye have not danced; we have mourned unto you, and ye have not lamented.
Manx: As gra, Ta shin er n’yannoo bingys diu, as cha vel shiu er ghonsin: ta shin er n’yannoo kiaull hrimshagh diu, as cha vel shiu er cheaney.

English: 18 For John came neither eating nor drinking, and they say, He hath a devil.
Manx: Son cha daink Ean, gee ny giu, as t’ad gra, Ta drogh-spyrryd ayn.

English: 19 The Son of man came eating and drinking, and they say, Behold a man gluttonous, and a winebibber, a friend of publicans and sinners. But wisdom is justified of her children.
Manx: Haink yn Mac dooinney gee as giu, as t’ad gra, Cur-my-ner dooinney jollyssagh, as iuder-feeney, carrey dy phublicanee as dy pheccee: agh ta creenaght er ny heyrey liorish e cloan hene.

English: 20 ¶Then began he to upbraid the cities wherein most of his mighty works were done, because they repented not:
Manx: Eisht ren Eh toshiaght dy gheddyn foill da ny ard-valjyn, ayndoo va’n chooid smoo jeh e obbraghyn yindyssagh er nyn yannoo, er-yn-oyr nagh ghow ad arrys.

English: 21 Woe unto thee, Chorazin! woe unto thee, Bethsaida! for if the mighty works, which were done in you, had been done in Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago in sackcloth and ashes.
Manx: Smerg dhyts Chorazin, smerg dhyts Vethsaida: son dy beagh ny obbraghyn yindyssagh er ny ve jeant ayns Tyre as Sidon t’er ve jeant ayn-diuish, veagh ad er ghoaill arrys foddey er dy henney ayns aanrit-sack as leoai.

English: 22 But I say unto you, It shall be more tolerable for Tyre and Sidon at the day of judgment, than for you.
Manx: Agh ta mee gra riu, Dy bee kerraghey s’eddrymmee er ny choyrt er Tyre as Sidon ec laa ny briwnys, na vees er ny choyrt erriuish.

English: 23 And thou, Capernaum, which art exalted unto heaven, shalt be brought down to hell: for if the mighty works, which have been done in thee, had been done in Sodom, it would have remained until this day.
Manx: As uss Capernaum, ta dt’ooashley roshtin gys niau, bee oo er dy [sic: dty] hilgey sheese gys niurin: son dy beagh ny obbraghyn yindyssagh er ve jeant ayns Sodom, t’er ve jeant aynyds, veagh eh er ve er-mayrn gys y laa t’ayn jiu.

English: 24 But I say unto you, That it shall be more tolerable for the land of Sodom in the day of judgment, than for thee.
Manx: Agh ta mee gra riu, dy bee kerraghey s’eddrymmee er er [sic] ny choyrt er thalloo Sodom ec laa ny briwnys, na vees orts.

English: 25 ¶At that time Jesus answered and said, I thank thee, O Father, Lord of heaven and earth, because thou hast hid these things from the wise and prudent, and hast revealed them unto babes.
Manx: Ec y traa shen dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh, Ta mee cur booise dhyt, O Ayr, Hiarn niau as thalloo, er-yn-oyr dy vel oo er chieltyn ny reddyn shoh vowsyn ta creeney as tushtagh, as dy vel oo er hoilshaghey ad da oikanyn.

English: 26 Even so, Father: for so it seemed good in thy sight.
Manx: Shen dy jarroo myr te, Ayr, son shen myr ve mie ayns dty hilley’s.

English: 27 All things are delivered unto me of my Father: and no man knoweth the Son, but the Father; neither knoweth any man the Father, save the Son, and he to whomsoever the Son will reveal him.
Manx: Ta dy chooilley nhee er ny livrey dooys liorish my Ayr: as cha nione da dooinney erbee yn Mac, agh yn Ayr: cha-moo shione da dooinney erbee yn Ayr, agh y Mac, as eshyn da nee yn Mac Eh y hoilshaghey.

English: 28 ¶Come unto me, all ye that labour and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest.
Manx: Tar-jee hym’s ooilley shiuish ta laboraght as ta laadit dy trome, as nee’ms shiu y ooraghey.

English: 29 Take my yoke upon you, and learn of me; for I am meek and lowly in heart: and ye shall find rest unto your souls.
Manx: Gow-jee my whing erriu, as ynsee-jee voym’s, son ta mee meen as imlee ayns spyrryd: as yiow shiu fea da nyn anmeenyn.

English: 30 For my yoke is easy, and my burden is light.
Manx: Son ta my whing aashagh, as my errey eddrym.
CAB. XII.

English: At that time Jesus went on the sabbath day through the corn; and his disciples were an hungred, and began to pluck the ears of corn and to eat.
Manx: Ec y traa shen hie Yeesey trooid arroo er y doonaght, as v’adsyn va sheer geiyrt er accryssagh, as ren ad toshiaght dy phluckey jeeasyn jeh’n arroo, as dy ee.

English: 2 But when the Pharisees saw it, they said unto him, Behold, thy disciples do that which is not lawful to do upon the sabbath day.
Manx: Agh tra honnick ny Phariseeyn ad, dooyrt ad rish, Cur-my-ner, ta’n vooinjer ta kinjagh geiyrt orts jannoo red nagh vel lowit dy ve jeant er y doonaght.

English: 3 But he said unto them, Have ye not read what David did, when he was an hungred, and they that were with him;
Manx: Agh dooyrt eshyn roo, Nagh vel shiuish er lhaih cre ren David, tra v’eh hene as e heshaght accryssagh,

English: 4 How he entered into the house of God, and did eat the shewbread, which was not lawful for him to eat, neither for them which were with him, but only for the priests?
Manx: Kys hie Eh stiagh ayns thie Yee, as die Eh yn arran casherick, nagh row lowit dasyn ny da’n vooinjer va marish dy ee, agh da ny saggyrtyn ny lomarcan?

English: 5 Or have ye not read in the law, how that on the sabbath days the priests in the temple profane the sabbath, and are blameless?
Manx: Ny, nagh vel shiu er lhaih ayns y leigh, kys er laghyn y doonaght ta ny saggyrtyn ayns y chiamble brishey’n doonaght, as foast cha vel peccah er ny choyrt nyn lieh?

English: 6 But I say unto you, That in this place is one greater than the temple.
Manx: Agh ta mish gra riu, dy vel ayns shoh fer syrjey na’n chiamble.

English: 7 But if ye had known what this meaneth, I will have mercy, and not sacrifice, ye would not have condemned the guiltless.
Manx: Agh dy beagh fys er ve eauish cre ta dy ve toiggit liorish y raa shoh, Ta mee ny s’booie er myghin na oural, cha beagh shiu er gheyrey yn vooinjer neu-chyndagh.

English: 8 For the Son of man is Lord even of the sabbath day.
Manx: Son ta Mac y dooinney ny Hiarn er y doonaght hene.

English: 9 And when he was departed thence, he went into their synagogue:
Manx: As tra v’eh er gholl veih shen, hie Eh stiagh ayns y cheeill oc.

English: 10 ¶And, behold, there was a man which had his hand withered. And they asked him, saying, Is it lawful to heal on the sabbath days? that they might accuse him.
Manx: As cur-my-ner, va dooinney ayns shen va’n laue echey er shyrgaghey: as, dy voddagh oyr y ve oc dy loayrt noi Yeesey, dênee ad jeh, gra, Vel eh lowal dy lheihys er laghyn y doonaght?

English: 11 And he said unto them, What man shall there be among you, that shall have one sheep, and if it fall into a pit on the sabbath day, will he not lay hold on it, and lift it out?
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Quoi’n dooinney ny mastey eu, vees un cheyrrey echey, as my huittys ee ayns jeeg er y doonaght, nagh daare Eh greme urree, as nagh drog Eh ass ee?

English: 12 How much then is a man better than a sheep? Wherefore it is lawful to do well on the sabbath days.
Manx: Nagh vel dooinney eisht foddey shaare na keyrrey? Shen-y-fa te lowal dy yannoo mie er y doonaght.

English: 13 Then saith he to the man, Stretch forth thine hand. And he stretched it forth; and it was restored whole, like as the other.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Eh rish y dooinney, Sheeyn magh dty laue: as heeyn Eh magh ee; as va’n laue echey er ny lheihys myr y laue elley.

English: 14 ¶Then the Pharisees went out, and held a council against him, how they might destroy him.
Manx: Eisht hie ny Phariseeyn magh, as hug ad nyn goyrle dy cheilley noi, mychione yn aght oddagh ad Eh y stroie.

English: 15 But when Jesus knew it, he withdrew himself from thence: and great multitudes followed him, and he healed them all;
Manx: Agh tra va fys ec Yeesey er, jimmee Eh veih shen: as deiyr earrooyn mooarey dy leih er, as ren Eh ad ooilley y lheihys,

English: 16 And charged them that they should not make him known:
Manx: As hug Eh currym daue, gyn ad dy vrah Eh:

English: 17 That it might be fulfilled which was spoken by Esaias the prophet, saying,
Manx: Dy voddagh ve cooilleenit ny va loayrit liorish Esaias y phadeyr, gra,

English: 18 Behold my servant, whom I have chosen; my beloved, in whom my soul is well pleased: I will put my spirit upon him, and he shall shew judgment to the Gentiles.
Manx: Cur-my-ner, my harvaant ta mee er ny reih, my er-ghraihagh [sic] jeh ta mee dy mooar soiaghey ayns m’annym: nee yn spyrryd aym vaghey ayn, as soilshee Eh briwnys da ny Ashoonyn.

English: 19 He shall not strive, nor cry; neither shall any man hear his voice in the streets.
Manx: Cha bee Eh streeu, ny geamagh, cha-moo chlinnys annane erbee e choraa ayns ny straadjyn.

English: 20 A bruised reed shall he not break, and smoking flax shall he not quench, till he send forth judgment unto victory.
Manx: Cuirtlagh vroojit cha jean Eh y vrishey, as lieen vees jaagh jeh, cha jean Eh y vooghey, derrey ver Eh magh briwnys lesh barriaght.

English: 21 And in his name shall the Gentiles trust.
Manx: As ayns yn ennym echey, nee ny Ashoonyn-quaagh treishteil.

English: 22 ¶Then was brought unto him one possessed with a devil, blind, and dumb: and he healed him, insomuch that the blind and dumb both spake and saw.
Manx: Eisht hoie ad kiongoyrt rish dooinney va drogh-spyrryd ayn, as v’eh doal as balloo: as lhaanee Eh Eh, ayns wheesh as dy ren eshyn va doal as balloo chammah loayrt as fakin.

English: 23 And all the people were amazed, and said, Is not this the son of David?
Manx: As ghow ooilley’n pobble yindyss, as dooyrt ad, Nagh nee shoh mac Ghavid?

English: 24 But when the Pharisees heard it, they said, This fellow doth not cast out devils, but by Beelzebub the prince of the devils.
Manx: Agh tra cheayll ny Phariseeyn jeh, dooyrt ad, Cha vel Eh shoh tilgey magh drogh-spyrrydyn, agh liorish Beelzebub prince ny drogh-spyrrydyn.

English: 25 And Jesus knew their thoughts, and said unto them, Every kingdom divided against itself is brought to desolation; and every city or house divided against itself shall not stand:
Manx: As va fys ec Yeesey er ny smooinaghtyn oc, as dooyrt Eh roo, Ta dy chooilley reeriaght ta girree magh ny oi hene er ny choyrt mow: as cha vod ard-valley ny thie erbee ta girree magh n’oi hene, shassoo.

English: 26 And if Satan cast out Satan, he is divided against himself; how shall then his kingdom stand?
Manx: As my ta’n Jouyl tilgey magh Jouyl, t’eh girree magh n’oi hene; kys eisht oddys y reeriaght echey shassoo.

English: 27 And if I by Beelzebub cast out devils, by whom do your children cast them out? therefore they shall be your judges.
Manx: As my ta mish liorish Beelzebub tilgey magh drogh-spyrrydyn, quoi liorish ta nyn gloan hene dyn tilgey ad magh? adsyn er-y-fa shen vees ny briwnyn eu.

English: 28 But if I cast out devils by the Spirit of God, then the kingdom of God is come unto you.
Manx: Agh my ta mish geiyrt magh drogh-spyrrydyn liorish Spyrryd Yee, eisht ta reeriaght Yee er jeet hiu.

English: 29 Or else how can one enter into a strong man’s house, and spoil his goods, except he first bind the strong man? and then he will spoil his house.
Manx: Er nonney, kys oddys fer goll stiagh ayns thie dooinney lajer, as e chooid y ghoaill liorish roosteraght, mannagh gainle Eh hoshiaght yn dooinney lajer? as eisht nee Eh e hie y roostey.

English: 30 He that is not with me is against me; and he that gathereth not with me scattereth abroad.
Manx: Eshyn nagh vel lhiam, t’eh m’oi: as eshyn nagh vel chymsaghey marym, t’eh skeayley.

English: 31 ¶Wherefore I say unto you, All manner of sin and blasphemy shall be forgiven unto men: but the blasphemy against the Holy Ghost shall not be forgiven unto men.
Manx: Shen-y-fa ta mee gra riu, Bee dy chooilley pheccah as raa mollaghtagh er ny leih da deiney: agh goan mollaghtagh noi’n Spyrryd Noo cha bee er nyn leih da deiney.

English: 32 And whosoever speaketh a word against the Son of man, it shall be forgiven him: but whosoever speaketh against the Holy Ghost, it shall not be forgiven him, neither in this world, neither in the world to come.
Manx: As quoi-erbee loarys fockle noi yn Mac dooinney, bee eh er ny leih da: agh quoi-erbee loayrys noi yn Spyrryd Noo, cha bee eh er ny leih da, edyr ayns y theihll shoh, ny ayns y theihll ta ry heet.

English: 33 Either make the tree good, and his fruit good; or else make the tree corrupt, and his fruit corrupt: for the tree is known by his fruit.
Manx: Edyr jean-jee yn billey mie, as e vess mie; er nonney jean-jee yn billey olk, as e vess olk: son liorish e vess, ta enney er ny choyrt er y villey.

English: 34 O generation of vipers, how can ye, being evil, speak good things? for out of the abundance of the heart the mouth speaketh.
Manx: O heeloghe dy ard-nieughyn, kys oddys shiuish, ta olk, reddyn mie y loayrt? son magh veih stoyr y chree ta’n beeal loayrt.

English: 35 A good man out of the good treasure of the heart bringeth forth good things: and an evil man out of the evil treasure bringeth forth evil things.
Manx: Ta dooinney mie ass stoyr mie yn chree echey, cur magh reddyn mie: as drogh ghooinney ass y drogh stoyr, cur magh drogh reddyn.

English: 36 But I say unto you, That every idle word that men shall speak, they shall give account thereof in the day of judgment.
Manx: Agh ta mee gra riu, Dy chooilley ockle neu-chooie nee deiney y loayrt, dy der ad coontey er y hon ec laa ny briwnys.

English: 37 For by thy words thou shalt be justified, and by thy words thou shalt be condemned.
Manx: Son liorish dty ghoan vees oo er dy [sic: dty] heyrey, as liorish dty ghoan bee oo er dy [sic: dty] gheyrey.

English: 38 ¶Then certain of the scribes and of the Pharisees answered, saying, Master, we would see a sign from thee.
Manx: Eisht dreggyr shiartance jeh ny scruderyn as jeh ny Phariseeyn, gra, Vainshtyr, baillin cowrey y akin woid.

English: 39 But he answered and said unto them, An evil and adulterous generation seeketh after a sign; and there shall no sign be given to it, but the sign of the prophet Jonas:
Manx: Agh dreggyr eshyn, as dooyrt Eh roo, She sheeloghe olk as oainjyragh ta shirrey cowrey, as cha bee cowrey erbee er ny chur daue, agh cowrey yn phadeyr Jonas.

English: 40 For as Jonas was three days and three nights in the whale's belly; so shall the Son of man be three days and three nights in the heart of the earth.
Manx: Son ’naght myr va Jonas tree laa as tree oieghyn ayns bolg y whale: myr shen bee Mac y dooinney tree laa as tree oieghyn ayns cree’n thallooin.

English: 41 The men of Nineveh shall rise in judgment with this generation, and shall condemn it: because they repented at the preaching of Jonas; and, behold, a greater than Jonas is here.
Manx: Nee deiney Nineveh girree seose ayns briwnys, as y cheeloghe shoh y gheyrey, er-yn-oyr dy ghow ad arrys ec preacheil Jonas, as cur-my-ner, ta fer syrjey na Jonas ayns shoh.

English: 42 The queen of the south shall rise up in the judgment with this generation, and shall condemn it: for she came from the uttermost parts of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon; and, behold, a greater than Solomon is here.
Manx: Nee ben-reïn y jass girree seose ayns briwnys noi yn cheeloghee [sic: cheeloghe] shoh, as ad y gheyrey: son haink ish veih ny ardjyn sodjey er y thalloo, dy eaishtagh rish creenaght Solomon, as cur-my-ner, ta fer syrjey na Solomon ayns shoh.

English: 43 When the unclean spirit is gone out of a man, he walketh through dry places, seeking rest, and findeth none.
Manx: Tra ta’n spyrryd neu-ghlen er gholl ass dooinney, t’eh shooyl trooid ynnydyn chyrmey, shirrey fea, as cha vel Eh dy gheddyn eh.

English: 44 Then he saith, I will return into my house from whence I came out; and when he is come, he findeth it empty, swept, and garnished.
Manx: Eisht t’eh gra, Chyndaa-ym gys my hie, ass haink mee; as tra t’eh cheet, t’eh dy gheddyn eh follym, sceabit, as soit magh dy stoamey.

English: 45 Then goeth he, and taketh with himself seven other spirits more wicked than himself, and they enter in and dwell there: and the last state of that man is worse than the first. Even so shall it be also unto this wicked generation.
Manx: Eisht t’eh goll, as cur lesh marish shiaght spyrrydyn elley ta ny smessey na Eh hene, as t’ad goll stiagh as vaghey ayns shen: as ta’n jerrey ny smessey da’n dooinney shen na’n toshiaght. As shoh myr nee eh taghyrt da’n drogh heeloghe shoh.

English: 46 ¶While he yet talked to the people, behold, his mother and his brethren stood without, desiring to speak with him.
Manx: Choud as v’eh foast loayrt rish y pobble, cur-my-ner, va e voir as e vraaraghyn nyn shassoo mooie, shirrey loayrt rish.

English: 47 Then one said unto him, Behold, thy mother and thy brethren stand without, desiring to speak with thee.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt fer rish, Cur-my-ner, ta dty voir as dty vraaraghyn nyn shassoo mooie, as t’ad booiagh loayrt rhyt.

English: 48 But he answered and said unto him that told him, Who is my mother? and who are my brethren?
Manx: Agh dreggyr eshyn yn fer dinsh shoh da, gra, Quoi my voir? as quoi my vraaraghyn?

English: 49 And he stretched forth his hand toward his disciples, and said, Behold my mother and my brethren
Manx: As heeyn Eh magh e laue hucsyn va sheer geiyrt er, as dooyrt Eh, Cur-my-ner my voir, as my vrarraghyn [sic: vraaraghyn].

English: 50 For whosoever shall do the will of my Father which is in heaven, the same is my brother, and sister, and mother.
Manx: Son quoi-erbee nee aigney my Ayr t’ayns niau, Eh shen my vraar, as my huyr, as my voir.
CAB. XIII.

English: The same day went Jesus out of the house, and sat by the sea side.
Manx: Yn laa cheddin hie Yeesey magh ass y thie, as hoie Eh sheese rish oirr ny marrey.

English: 2 And great multitudes were gathered together unto him, so that he went into a ship, and sat; and the whole multitude stood on the shore.
Manx: As va earrooyn mooarrey [sic] dy leih er nyn jaglym cooidjagh huggey, myr shen dy jagh Eh seose ayns lhong, as hoie Eh, as va ooilley’n pobble nyn shassoo er y traie.

English: 3 And he spake many things unto them in parables, saying, Behold, a sower went forth to sow;
Manx: As loayr Eh ymmodee reddyn roo ayns coraaghyn-dorraghey, gra, Cur-my-ner, hie corryder magh dy chuirr.

English: 4 And when he sowed, some seeds fell by the way side, and the fowls came and devoured them up:
Manx: As myr v’eh cuirr, huit paart jeh’n rass rish oirr y raad, as haink ny eeanlee as die ad seose eh.

English: 5 Some fell upon stony places, where they had not much earth: and forthwith they sprung up, because they had no deepness of earth:
Manx: Huit paart ayns ynnydyn claghagh, raad nagh row cooid-vooar dy ooir echey: as chelleeragh daase eh, er-y-fa nagh row diunit thallooin echey:

English: 6 And when the sun was up, they were scorched; and because they had no root, they withered away.
Manx: As ghow niart ny greïney yn soo ass, as er-yn-oyr nagh row eh er ghoaill fraue, hie eh naardey.

English: 7 And some fell among thorns; and the thorns sprung up, and choked them:
Manx: As huit paart mastey drineyn: as daase ny drineyn seose as phloogh ad eh.

English: 8 But other fell into good ground, and brought forth fruit, some an hundredfold, some sixtyfold, some thirtyfold.
Manx: Agh huit cooid elley jeh ayns thalloo mie, as dymmyrk eh mess, paart keead-filley, paart three-feed-filley, as paart jeih fillaghyn as feed.

English: 9 Who hath ears to hear, let him hear.
Manx: Eshyn ta cleashyn echey dy chlashtyn, lig da clashtyn.

English: 10 And the disciples came, and said unto him, Why speakest thou unto them in parables?
Manx: As haink y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er, as dooyrt ad rish, Cre’n-fa t’ow loayrt roo ayns coraaghyn-dorraghey?

English: 11 He answered and said unto them, Because it is given unto you to know the mysteries of the kingdom of heaven, but to them it is not given.
Manx: Dreggyr eshyn as dooyrt Eh roo, Er-yn-oyr dy vel eh er ny choyrt diuish folliaghtyn reeriaght niau y hoiggal, agh dauesyn cha vel eh er ny choyrt.

English: 12 For whosoever hath, to him shall be given, and he shall have more abundance: but whosoever hath not, from him shall be taken away even that he hath.
Manx: Son quoi-erbee ta echey, dasyn vees er ny choyrt, as bee towse smoo echey: agh quoi-erbee nagh vel echey, veihsyn vees, shen ny ta echey, er ny ghoaill ersooyl.

English: 13 Therefore speak I to them in parables: because they seeing see not; and hearing they hear not, neither do they understand.
Manx: Shen-y-fa ta mee loayrt roo ayns coraaghyn-dorraghey: er-yn-oyr fakin, nagh vel ad fakin: as clashtyn, nagh vel ad clashtyn, cha-moo t’ad toiggal.

English: 14 And in them is fulfilled the prophecy of Esaias, which saith, By hearing ye shall hear, and shall not understand; and seeing ye shall see, and shall not perceive:
Manx: As ayndoosyn ta cooilleenit phadeyrys Esaias, ta gra, Liorish clashtyn nee shiu clashtyn, as cha jean shiu toiggal: as fakin, nee shiu fakin, as cha gronnee shiu.

English: 15 For this people's heart is waxed gross, and their ears are dull of hearing, and their eyes they have closed; lest at any time they should see with their eyes and hear with their ears, and should understand with their heart, and should be converted, and I should heal them.
Manx: Son ta cree yn pobble shoh er n’aase roauyr, as ta ny cleashyn oc moal dy chlashtyn, as ny sooyllyn oc t’ad er n’yeigh; er aggle dy vaikagh ad lesh nyn sooyllyn, as dy glinnagh ad lesh nyn gleashyn, as dy doiggagh ad lesh nyn gree, as dy beagh ad er nyn jyndaa, as dy jinnin ad y lheihys.

English: 16 But blessed are your eyes, for they see: and your ears, for they hear.
Manx: Agh bannit ta ny sooyllyn eauish, son t’ad fakin; as ny cleashyn eu, son t’ad clashtyn.

English: 17 For verily I say unto you, That many prophets and righteous men have desired to see those things which ye see, and have not seen them; and to hear those things which ye hear, and have not heard them.
Manx: Son dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy vel ymmodee phadeyryn as deiney cairagh er ve aignagh dy akin ny reddyn ta shiuish dy akin, agh cha vel ad er vakin ad: as dy chlashtyn ny reddyn ta shiu dy chlashtyn, agh cha vel ad er chlashtyn ad.

English: 18 ¶Hear ye therefore the parable of the sower.
Manx: Clasht-jee er-y-fa shen coraa-dorraghey yn chorryder.

English: 19 When any one heareth the word of the kingdom, and understandeth it not, then cometh the wicked one, and catcheth away that which was sown in his heart. This is he which received seed by the way side.
Manx: Fer erbee dy vel clashtyn goo yn reeriaght, as nagh vel dy hoiggal eh, ta’n drogh-er cheet, as tayrtyn lesh shen ny va cuirt ayns e chree: shoh Eh ghow yn rass rish oirr y raad.

English: 20 But he that received the seed into stony places, the same is he that heareth the word, and anon with joy receiveth it;
Manx: Agh eshyn ghow yn rass ayns ynnydyn claghagh, yn fer ta clashtyn yn goo, as ayns y tullogh lesh boggey dy ghoaill eh:

English: 21 Yet hath he not root in himself, but dureth for a while: for when tribulation or persecution ariseth because of the word, by and by he is offended.
Manx: Foast cha vel fraue echey ayn hene, agh t’eh cummal rish son tammylt: agh tra ta seaghyn ny tranlaase cheet er, er coontey’n ghoo, chelleeragh ta e chredjue failleil.

English: 22 He also that received seed among the thorns is he that heareth the word; and the care of this world, and the deceitfulness of riches, choke the word, and he becometh unfruitful.
Manx: Eshyn myrgeddin ghow yn rass mastey ny drineyn, yn fer ta clashtyn y goo: as ta kiarrail y theihll shoh, as moalteraght berchys plooghey’n goo, as t’eh cheet dy ve neu-vessoil.

English: 23 But he that received seed into the good ground is he that heareth the word, and understandeth it; which also beareth fruit, and bringeth forth, some an hundredfold, some sixty, some thirty.
Manx: Agh eshyn ghow yn rass ayns thalloo mie, yn fer ta clashtyn y goo as dy hoiggal eh, as t’eh tilgey mess as gymmyrkey, paart keead-filley, paart three-feed, as paart jeih fillaghyn as feed.

English: 24 ¶Another parable put he forth unto them, saying, The kingdom of heaven is likened unto a man which sowed good seed in his field:
Manx: Coraa-dorraghey elley loayr Eh roo, gra, Ta reeriaght niau er ny hoyllaghey gys dooinney chuirr rass mie ayns e vagher:

English: 25 But while men slept, his enemy came and sowed tares among the wheat, and went his way.
Manx: Agh choud as va sleih nyn gadley, haink e noid as chuirr Eh coggyl mastey’n churnaght, as jimmee Eh roish.

English: 26 But when the blade was sprung up, and brought forth fruit, then appeared the tares also.
Manx: Agh tra va’n chass er n’aase, as er gholl my yeish, eisht haink y coggyl rish myrgeddin.

English: 27 So the servants of the householder came and said unto him, Sir, didst not thou sow good seed in thy field? from whence then hath it tares?
Manx: Er shen haink fir-vooinjerey yn far-thie, as dooyrt ad rish, Vainshtyr, nagh chuirr uss rass mie ayns dty vagher? cre woish eisht ta’n coggyl t’ayn?

English: 28 He said unto them, An enemy hath done this. The servants said unto him, Wilt thou then that we go and gather them up?
Manx: Dooyrt eshyn roo, Noid t’er n’yannoo shoh. Dooyrt ny fir-vooinjerey rish, Naiylt eisht shin dy gholl as dy heigh ass eh?

English: 29 But he said, Nay; lest while ye gather up the tares, ye root up also the wheat with them.
Manx: As dooyrt eshyn, Ny jean-jee; er aggle ayns teigh yn coggyl, dy dayrn shiu yn churnaght as ny fraueyn marish.

English: 30 Let both grow together until the harvest: and in the time of harvest I will say to the reapers, Gather ye together first the tares, and bind them in bundles to burn them: but gather the wheat into my barn.
Manx: Lig-jee daue ny neesht gaase cooidjagh derrey’n fouyr: as ayns earish yn ouyr jir-yms rish ny beayneeyn, Chymsee-jee cooidjagh hoshiaght yn coggyl ayns bunneeyn ry hoi y lostey; agh chaglee-jee yn churnaght stiagh ayns my hoalt.

English: 31 ¶Another parable put he forth unto them, saying, The kingdom of heaven is like to a grain of mustard seed, which a man took, and sowed in his field:
Manx: Coraa-dorraghey elley loayr Eh roo, gra, Ta reeriaght niau goll-rish greine dy rass mustard, ren dooinney y ghoaill as y chuirr ayns e vagher.

English: 32 Which indeed is the least of all seeds: but when it is grown, it is the greatest among herbs, and becometh a tree, so that the birds of the air come and lodge in the branches thereof.
Manx: As ga dy nee eh sloo jeh dy chooilley rass: foast tra te er n’aase, eh smoo ta mastey lossyreeyn, as te cheet dy ve ny villey; myr shen dy vel eeanlee’n aer cheet as goaill fastee ayns ny banglaneyn echey.

English: 33 ¶Another parable spake he unto them; The kingdom of heaven is like unto leaven, which a woman took, and hid in three measures of meal, till the whole was leavened.
Manx: Coraa-dorraghey elley loayr Eh roo, Ta reeriaght niau goll-rish soorit ren ben y ghoaill as y ollaghey ayns three towesyn dy veinn, derrey ve ooilley soor.

English: 34 All these things spake Jesus unto the multitude in parables; and without a parable spake he not unto them:
Manx: Ooilley ny reddyn shoh loayr Yeesey rish y pobble ayns coraaghyn-dorraghey, as fegooish coraa-dorraghey, cha loayr Eh roo:

English: 35 That it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophet, saying, I will open my mouth in parables; I will utter things which have been kept secret from the foundation of the world.
Manx: Dy voddagh shen ve cooilleenit va loayrit liorish y phadeyr, gra, Foshlym my veeal dy loayrt coraaghyn-dorraghey, soilshee-ym magh reddyn t’er ve follit er dy hoshiaght y theihll.

English: 36 Then Jesus sent the multitude away, and went into the house: and his disciples came unto him, saying, Declare unto us the parable of the tares of the field.
Manx: Eisht hug Yeesey yn cheshaght ersooyl, as hie Eh stiagh ayns y thie: as haink huggey adsyn va sheer marish, gra, Soilshee dooin coraa-dorraghey coggyl yn vagher.

English: 37 He answered and said unto them, He that soweth the good seed is the Son of man;
Manx: Dreggyr eshyn as dooyrt Eh roo, Eshyn chuirr yn rass mie, yn Mac dooinney:

English: 38 The field is the world; the good seed are the children of the kingdom; but the tares are the children of the wicked one;
Manx: Yn magher y seihll: yn rass mie cloan y reeriaght: agh yn coggyl cloan y drogh-er:

English: 39 The enemy that sowed them is the devil; the harvest is the end of the world; and the reapers are the angels.
Manx: Yn noid chuirr ad yn Jouyl: yn fouyr jerrey’n theihll: as ny beayneeyn ny ainlyn.

English: 40 As therefore the tares are gathered and burned in the fire; so shall it be in the end of this world.
Manx: Myr er-y-fa shen ta’n coggyl er ny haglym as er ny lostey ayns yn aile; myr shen vees eh ec jerrey’n theihll.

English: 41 The Son of man shall send forth his angels, and they shall gather out of his kingdom all things that offend, and them which do iniquity;
Manx: Ver yn Mac dooinney magh e ainlyn, as teighee ad ass e reeriaght dy chooilley nhee ta tayrn sleih gys peccah, as adsyn ta cur rish yn olk;

English: 42 And shall cast them into a furnace of fire: there shall be wailing and gnashing of teeth.
Manx: As tilgee ad ad ayns coirrey ailagh: ayns shen vees keaney as snaggeraght feeacklyn.

English: 43 Then shall the righteous shine forth as the sun in the kingdom of their Father. Who hath ears to hear, let him hear.
Manx: Eisht nee yn chloan chairagh soilshean magh myr y ghrian, ayns reeriaght nyn Ayrey. Eshyn ta cleashyn echey dy chlashtyn, lig da clashtyn.

English: 44 ¶Again, the kingdom of heaven is like unto treasure hid in a field; the which when a man hath found, he hideth, and for joy thereof goeth and selleth all that he hath, and buyeth that field.
Manx: Reesht ta reeriaght niau goll-rish berchys va follit ayns magher: yn verchys cheddin tra ta dooinney dy gheddyn magh, t’eh dy choodaghey eh, as ayns boggey jeh t’eh goll as creck ooilley ny t’echey, as kionnaghey’n magher shen.

English: 45 ¶Again, the kingdom of heaven is like unto a merchant man, seeking goodly pearls:
Manx: Reesht ta reeriaght niau goll-rish merchand va shirrey pearlyn mie:

English: 46 Who, when he had found one pearl of great price, went and sold all that he had, and bought it.
Manx: As tra v’eh er gheddyn un phearl dy phrice vooar, hie Eh as chreck Eh ooilley ny v’echey, as chionnee Eh eh.

English: 47 ¶Again, the kingdom of heaven is like unto a net, that was cast into the sea, and gathered of every kind:
Manx: Reesht ta reeriaght niau goll-rish lieen va tilgit magh ’sy cheayn, as ghow jeh dy chooilley horch dy eeast.

English: 48 Which, when it was full, they drew to shore, and sat down, and gathered the good into vessels, but cast the bad away.
Manx: As tra ve laane, hayrn ad eh gys thalloo, as hoie ad sheese, as haue ad yn eeast mie ayns siyn, agh cheau ad yn drogh eeast ersooyl.

English: 49 So shall it be at the end of the world: the angels shall come forth, and sever the wicked from among the just,
Manx: Myr shen vees eh ec jerrey’n theihll: hig ny ainlyn magh as scarree ad y vee-chrauee veih mastey’n chloan chairagh;

English: 50 And shall cast them into the furnace of fire: there shall be wailing and gnashing of teeth.
Manx: As tilgee ad ad ayns coirrey dy aile: ayns shen vees keaney as snaggeraght feeacklyn.

English: 51 Jesus saith unto them, Have ye understood all these things? They say unto him, Yea, Lord.
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey roo, Vel shiu er hoiggal ooilley ny reddyn shoh? Dooyrt adsyn rish, Ta shin, Hiarn.

English: 52 Then said he unto them, Therefore every scribe which is instructed unto the kingdom of heaven is like unto a man that is an householder, which bringeth forth out of his treasure things new and old.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Eh roo, Shen-y-fa ta dy chooilley scrudere ta ynsit gys reeriaght niau, goll-rish dooinney ta ny ar-thie, ta cur magh ass y stoyr reddyn noa as shen.

English: 53 ¶And it came to pass, that when Jesus had finished these parables, he departed thence.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, tra va Yeesey erreish ny coraaghyn-dorraghey shoh y loayrt, dy jimmee Eh veih shen.

English: 54 And when he was come into his own country, he taught them in their synagogue, insomuch that they were astonished, and said, Whence hath this man this wisdom, and these mighty works?
Manx: As tra v’eh er jeet gys e heer hene, dynsee Eh ad ayns ny kialteenyn oc, ayns wheesh as dy row ad atchimagh, as dy dooyrt ad, Cre-woish ta creenaght as mirrillyn y dooinney shoh?

English: 55 Is not this the carpenter’s son? is not his mother called Mary? and his brethren, James, and Joses, and Simon, and Judas?
Manx: Nagh nee shoh mac y seyr? Nagh vel e voir enmyssit Moirrey, as e vraaraghyn Jamys as Joses, as Simon, as Judas?

English: 56 And his sisters, are they not all with us? Whence then hath this man all these things?
Manx: As nagh vel ny shairaghyn echey ooilley mârin? cre-woish eisht ta ooilley ny reddyn t’ec y dooinney shoh?

English: 57 And they were offended in him. But Jesus said unto them, A prophet is not without honour, save in his own country, and in his own house.
Manx: As v’ad jymmoosagh rish. Agh dooyrt Yeesey roo, Cha vel phadeyr fegooish ooashley, cheu-mooie jeh ayns e heer hene, as ayns e hie hene.

English: 58 And he did not many mighty works there because of their unbelief.
Manx: As cha nimmey mirril dobbree Eh ayns shen, kyndagh rish y vee-chredjue oc.
CAB. XIV.

English: At that time Herod the tetrarch heard of the fame of Jesus,
Manx: Ec y traa shen cheayll Herod yn Tetrarch jeh goo Yeesey,

English: 2 And said unto his servants, This is John the Baptist; he is risen from the dead; and therefore mighty works do shew forth themselves in him.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish e harvaantyn, Shoh Ean Bashtey, t’eh er n’irree veih ny merriu, as er-yn-oyr shen ta mirrillyn er nyn obbraghey liorish.

English: 3 ¶For Herod had laid hold on John, and bound him, and put him in prison for Herodias’ sake, his brother Philip's wife.
Manx: Son va Herod er ghoaill Ean, as er chiangley, as er hilgey Eh ayns pryssoon, kyndagh rish Herodias ben e vraar Philip.

English: 4 For John said unto him, It is not lawful for thee to have her.
Manx: Son va Ean er gra rish, Cha vel eh lowit dhyt, ee y ve ayd son ben.

English: 5 And when he would have put him to death, he feared the multitude, because they counted him as a prophet.
Manx: As tra ballish v’er choyrt Eh gy baase, v’eh ayns aggle roish y pobble, er-y-fa dy row ad dy ghoaill Eh son phadeyr.

English: 6 But when Herod's birthday was kept, the daughter of Herodias danced before them, and pleased Herod.
Manx: Agh er y laa v’er ny reaylley corrym rish y laa ruggyr Herod, ghonse inneen Herodias ayns yn enish oc, as ghow Herod laane boggey jee.

English: 7 Whereupon he promised with an oath to give her whatsoever she would ask.
Manx: Er shen yiall eh lesh loo, dy jinnagh Eh jee red erbee dy shirragh ee.

English: 8 And she, being before instructed of her mother, said, Give me here John Baptist’s head in a charger.
Manx: As dooyrt ish, myr va e moir er chur roie, Cur dou ayns shoh kione Ean Bashtey er claare.

English: 9 And the king was sorry: nevertheless for the oath's sake, and them which sat with him at meat, he commanded it to be given her.
Manx: As huit y ree ayns trimshey: ny-yeih er coontey yn loo, as y vooinjer v’ec gien marish, hug Eh saarey eh dy ve er ny choyrt jee.

English: 10 And he sent, and beheaded John in the prison.
Manx: As hug Eh fys yn kione dy v’er ny ghoaill jeh Ean ayns y phryssoon.

English: 11 And his head was brought in a charger, and given to the damsel: and she brought it to her mother.
Manx: As va’n kione er ny choyrt er claare, as livreit dys y ven-aeg, as hug ish lheie eh gys e moir.

English: 12 And his disciples came, and took up the body, and buried it, and went and told Jesus.
Manx: As haink y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er, as hrog ad y corp, as doanluck ad eh, as hie ad as dinsh ad da Yeesey.

English: 13 ¶When Jesus heard of it, he departed thence by ship into a desert place apart: and when the people had heard thereof, they followed him on foot out of the cities.
Manx: Tra cheayll Yeesey jeh, jimmee Eh veih shen ayns lhong gys ynnyd-faasagh er lheh: as tra cheayll y pobble jeh, deiyr ad er rish nyn gosh ass ny ard-valjyn.

English: 14 And Jesus went forth, and saw a great multitude, and was moved with compassion toward them, and he healed their sick.
Manx: As hie Yeesey magh, as honnick Eh chaglym mooar dy leih, as v’eh er ny veiyghey lesh chymmey orroo, as laanee Eh adsyn va ching.

English: 15 ¶And when it was evening, his disciples came to him, saying, This is a desert place, and the time is now past; send the multitude away, that they may go into the villages, and buy themselves victuals.
Manx: As tra va’n fastyr ayn, haink huggey adsyn va sheer geiyrt er, gra, She boayl faasagh shoh, as ta’n traa nish er gholl shiaghey; lig y raad da’n cheshaght, dy vod ad goll roue gys ny baljyn beggey, as beaghey y chionnaghey daue hene.

English: 16 But Jesus said unto them, They need not depart; give ye them to eat.
Manx: Agh dooyrt Yeesey roo, Cha lhias daue goll roue, cur-jee shiuish beaghey daue.

English: 17 And they say unto him, We have here but five loaves, and two fishes.
Manx: As dooyrt ad rish, Cha vel ain ayns shoh agh queig bwilleenyn, as daa eeast.

English: 18 He said, Bring them hither to me.
Manx: Dooyrt eshyn, Cur-jee lhieu ad ayns shoh hym’s.

English: 19 And he commanded the multitude to sit down on the grass, and took the five loaves, and the two fishes, and looking up to heaven, he blessed, and brake, and gave the loaves to his disciples, and the disciples to the multitude.
Manx: As hug Eh saarey da’n pobble dy hoie sheese er y faiyr, as ghow Eh ny queig bwilleenyn as y daa eeast, as yeeagh Eh seose gys niau, as vannee Eh, as vrish Eh, as hug Eh ny bwilleenyn dauesyn va sheer marish, as hug adsyn ad da’n pobble.

English: 20 And they did all eat, and were filled: and they took up of the fragments that remained twelve baskets full.
Manx: As ren ad ooilley gee, as v’ad er nyn yannoo magh: as hrog ad jeh’n fooillagh daag ad, laane da vasket jeig.

English: 21 And they that had eaten were about five thousand men, beside women and children.
Manx: As v’adsyn v’er n’ee queig thousane dooinney, cheu-mooie jeh mraane as cloan.

English: 22 ¶And straightway Jesus constrained his disciples to get into a ship, and to go before him unto the other side, while he sent the multitudes away.
Manx: As chelleeragh hug Yeesey er y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er luingys y ghoaill, as ad dy gholl roish gys y cheu elley, choud as v’eh cur y pobble ersooyl.

English: 23 And when he had sent the multitudes away, he went up into a mountain apart to pray: and when the evening was come, he was there alone.
Manx: As tra v’eh er chur yn pobble ersooyl, hie Eh hene er lheh seose er slieau, dy ghoaill padjer: as tra va’n fastyr er-jeet, v’eh ayns shen ny lomarcan.

English: 24 But the ship was now in the midst of the sea, tossed with waves: for the wind was contrary.
Manx: Agh va’n lhong nish ayns main ny marrey, eiyrit noon as noal lesh ny tonnyn: son va’n gheay nyn oi oc.

English: 25 And in the fourth watch of the night Jesus went unto them, walking on the sea.
Manx: As ayns y chiarroo ghoostey jeh’n oie, haink Yeesey huc, shooyl er y cheayn.

English: 26 And when the disciples saw him walking on the sea, they were troubled, saying, It is a spirit; and they cried out for fear.
Manx: As tra honnick adsyn va sheer marish Eh shooyl er y cheayn, v’ad seaghnit, gra, She scaan t’ayn; as v’ad ayns aggle, as deïe ad.

English: 27 But straightway Jesus spake unto them, saying, Be of good cheer; it is I; be not afraid.
Manx: Agh chelleeragh loayr Yeesey roo, gra, Bee-jee dy yien mie, she mish t’ayn, ny gow-jee aggle.

English: 28 And Peter answered him and said, Lord, if it be thou, bid me come unto thee on the water.
Manx: As dreggyr Peddyr Eh, gra, Hiarn, My she oo t’ayn, oardee dooys cheet hood er yn ushtey.

English: 29 And he said, Come. And when Peter was come down out of the ship, he walked on the water, to go to Jesus.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Tarr. As tra va Peddyr er jeet neose ass y lhong, hooyl Eh er yn ushtey, dy heet gys Yeesey.

English: 30 But when he saw the wind boisterous, he was afraid; and beginning to sink, he cried, saying, Lord, save me.
Manx: Agh tra dennee Eh dy row yn gheay lajer, ghow Eh aggle: as myr v’eh er-gerrey dy ve baiht, dyllee Eh, gra, Hiarn, saue mee.

English: 31 And immediately Jesus stretched forth his hand, and caught him, and said unto him, O thou of little faith, wherefore didst thou doubt?
Manx: As ayns y tullogh, heeyn Yeesey magh e laue, as haar Eh Eh, as dooyrt Eh rish, O ghooinney faase-chredjuagh, cre’n-fa vow ayns imnea?

English: 32 And when they were come into the ship, the wind ceased.
Manx: As tra v’ad er gholl seose ayns y lhong, ghow yn gheay fea.

English: 33 Then they that were in the ship came and worshipped him, saying, Of a truth thou art the Son of God.
Manx: Eisht haink adsyn v’ayns y lhong, as hug ad ooashley da, gra, Ayns firrinys oo Mac Yee.

English: 34 ¶And when they were gone over, they came into the land of Gennesaret.
Manx: As tra v’ad er gholl harrish, haink ad gys cheer Gennesaret.

English: 35 And when the men of that place had knowledge of him, they sent out into all that country round about, and brought unto him all that were diseased;
Manx: As tra hoig yn vooinjer va vaghey ayns shen quoi v’eh, hug ad fys magh gys ooilley’n cheer mygeayrt, as hug ad lhieu huggey ooilley adsyn va doghanit,

English: 36 And besought him that they might only touch the hem of his garment: and as many as touched were made perfectly whole.
Manx: As ghuee ad er, ad ny lomarcan dy vennalt rish oirr e gharmad: as whilleen as venn rish, v’ad er nyn lheihys.
CAB. XV.

English: Then came to Jesus scribes and Pharisees, which were of Jerusalem, saying,
Manx: Eisht haink gys Yeesey scruderyn as Phariseeyn veih Jerusalem, gra,

English: 2 Why do thy disciples transgress the tradition of the elders? for they wash not their hands when they eat bread.
Manx: Cre’n-fa t’adsyn ta sheer geiyrt orts brishey oardaghyn y chanstyr? son cha vel ad niee nyn laueyn, tra t’ad gee arran.

English: 3 But he answered and said unto them, Why do ye also transgress the commandment of God by your tradition?
Manx: Agh dreggyr eshyn, as dooyrt Eh roo, Cre’n-oyr ta shiuish brishey saarey Yee liorish ny oardaghyn eu?

English: 4 For God commanded, saying, Honour thy father and mother: and, He that curseth father or mother, let him die the death.
Manx: Son hug Jee saarey, gra, Cur arrym da dt’ayr as da dty voir: as, Eshyn ta gueeaghyn da ayr as moir, lig Eh ve kerrit lesh baase.

English: 5 But ye say, Whosoever shall say to his father or his mother, It is a gift, by whatsoever thou mightest be profited by me;
Manx: Agh ta shiuish gra, Quoi-erbee jir rish ayr ny moir, Yn feaysley shen oddagh uss jerkal rish voym’s, te gioot er ny hebbal da Jee,

English: 6 And honour not his father or his mother, he shall be free. Thus have ye made the commandment of God of none effect by your tradition.
Manx: As nagh lhias da cooney choyrt da e ayr ny e voir. Ta shiu myr shoh jannoo saarey Yee gyn vree liorish ny oardaghyn eu.

English: 7 Ye hypocrites, well did Esaias prophesy of you, saying,
Manx: Chrauee-oalsey, s’mie ren Esaias phadeyrys jiu, gra.

English: 8 This people draweth nigh unto me with their mouth, and honoureth me with their lips; but their heart is far from me.
Manx: Ta’n pobble shoh tayrn ergerrey dou lesh nyn meeal, as cur ooashley dou lesh nyn meyllyn: agh ta’n cree oc foddey voym.

English: 9 But in vain they do worship me, teaching for doctrines the commandments of men.
Manx: Agh ayns fardail t’ad cur ooashley dou, gynsaghey son y goo ayms, oardaghyn dei

English: 10 ¶And he called the multitude, and said unto them, Hear, and understand:
Manx: As deïe Eh er y pobble, as dooyrt Eh roo, Eaisht-jee as toig-jee.

English: 11 Not that which goeth into the mouth defileth a man; but that which cometh out of the mouth, this defileth a man.
Manx: Cha nee shen ta goll stiagh ayns y veeal, ta jannoo dooinney neu-ghlen: agh ny ta cheet magh ass y veeal, shen ta jannoo dooinney neu-ghlen.

English: 12 Then came his disciples, and said unto him, Knowest thou that the Pharisees were offended, after they heard this saying?
Manx: Eisht haink huggey yn vooinjer va sheer marish, as dooyrt ad rish, Nagh vel fys ayd dy row ny Phariseeyn jymmoosagh, tra cheayll ad y raa shoh?

English: 13 But he answered and said, Every plant, which my heavenly Father hath not planted, shall be rooted up.
Manx: Agh dreggyr eshyn, as dooyrt Eh, Bee dy chooilley villey, nagh vel my Ayr flaunyssagh er hoiaghey, er ny ghoaill ass ny fraueyn.

English: 14 Let them alone: they be blind leaders of the blind. And if the blind lead the blind, both shall fall into the ditch.
Manx: Lig-jee daue: she leeideilee doal ta kione y vooinjer ghoal ad. As my ta’n doal shooyl kione y doal, tuittee ad ny neesht ayns y jeeg.

English: 15 Then answered Peter and said unto him, Declare unto us this parable.
Manx: Eisht dreggyr Peddyr, as dooyrt Eh rish, Soilshee dooinyn yn coraa-dorraghey shoh.

English: 16 And Jesus said, Are ye also yet without understanding?
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey rish, Vel shiuish neesht foast fegooish tushtey?

English: 17 Do not ye yet understand, that whatsoever entereth in at the mouth goeth into the belly, and is cast out into the draught?
Manx: Nagh vel shiu foast toiggal, cre-erbee ta goit stiagh ayns y veeal, dy vel eh goll sheese ayns y volg, as goll magh trooid y chorp?

English: 18 But those things which proceed out of the mouth come forth from the heart; and they defile the man.
Manx: Agh ta ny reddyn ta cheet magh ass y veeal, cheet veih’n chree, as t’ad shen jannoo dooinney neu-ghlen.

English: 19 For out of the heart proceed evil thoughts, murders, adulteries, fornications, thefts, false witness, blasphemies:
Manx: Son magh veih’n chree ta cheet drogh smooinaghtyn, dunverys, brishey-poosey, maarderys, maarlys, feanish foalsey, goan mollaghtagh.

English: 20 These are the things which defile a man: but to eat with unwashen hands defileth not a man.
Manx: Ad shoh ny reddyn ta sollaghey dooinney: agh dy ee lesh laueyn nagh vel neeit, cha vel shen jannoo dooinney neu-ghlen.

English: 21 ¶Then Jesus went thence, and departed into the coasts of Tyre and Sidon.
Manx: Eisht hie Yeesey veih shen, as jimmee Eh gys ardjyn Tyre as Sidon.

English: 22 And, behold, a woman of Canaan came out of the same coasts, and cried unto him, saying, Have mercy on me, O Lord, thou son of David; my daughter is grievously vexed with a devil.
Manx: As cur-my-ner, va ben va ny Canaanite haink magh ass ny ardjyn shen, geamagh as gra, Jean myghin orrym, O Hiarn, vac Ghavid; smooar ta m’inneen er ny torchaghey lesh drogh-spyrryd.

English: 23 But he answered her not a word. And his disciples came and besought him, saying, Send her away; for she crieth after us.
Manx: Agh cha dug Eh fockle dy ansoor jee. As haink y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er, as ghuee ad er, gra, Lig y raad jee, son t’ee geamagh nyn yei.

English: 24 But he answered and said, I am not sent but unto the lost sheep of the house of Israel.
Manx: Agh dreggyr eshyn as dooyrt Eh, Cha vel mish er my choyrt, agh gys kirree cailjey thie Israel.

English: 25 Then came she and worshipped him, saying, Lord, help me.
Manx: Eisht haink ee as hug ee ooashley da, gra, Hiarn, cooin lhiam.

English: 26 But he answered and said, It is not meet to take the children’s bread, and to cast it to dogs.
Manx: Agh dreggyr Eh, as dooyrt Eh, Cha vel eh cooie arran y chloan y ghoaill, as y hilgey gys moddee.

English: 27 And she said, Truth, Lord: yet the dogs eat of the crumbs which fall from their masters’ table.
Manx: Spheer shen, dooyrt ish, Hiarn: foast ta ny moddee gee jeh’n vrooilliagh ta tuittym jeh boayrd nyn mainshtyr.

English: 28 Then Jesus answered and said unto her, O woman, great is thy faith: be it unto thee even as thou wilt. And her daughter was made whole from that very hour.
Manx: Er shen dansoor Yeesey as dooyrt Eh ree, O ven, mooar ta dty chredjue: yn aghin t’ow dy yeearree dy row ayd. As va’n inneen eck er ny lheihys veih’n oor cheddin.

English: 29 And Jesus departed from thence, and came nigh unto the sea of Galilee; and went up into a mountain, and sat down there.
Manx: As jimmee Yeesey veih shen, as haink Eh ergerrey da faarkey Ghalilee, as hie Eh seose er slieau as hoie Eh ayns shen.

English: 30 And great multitudes came unto him, having with them those that were lame, blind, dumb, maimed, and many others, and cast them down at Jesus’ feet; and he healed them:
Manx: As haink earrooyn mooarrey [sic] dy leih huggey, as nyn mast’ oc va croobee, doail, balloo, baccee, as ymmodee elley, as hug ad ad nyn lhie ec cassyn Yeesey, as ren Eh ad y lheihys:

English: 31 Insomuch that the multitude wondered, when they saw the dumb to speak, the maimed to be whole, the lame to walk, and the blind to see: and they glorified the God of Israel.
Manx: Ayns wheesh as dy ghow ooilley’n pobble yindyss, tra honnick ad ny balloo loayrt, ny baccee slaane, ny croobee shooyl, as ny doail fakin: as hug ad gloyr da Jee Israel.

English: 32 ¶Then Jesus called his disciples unto him, and said, I have compassion on the multitude, because they continue with me now three days, and have nothing to eat: and I will not send them away fasting, lest they faint in the way.
Manx: Eisht deïe Yeesey er y vooinjer hene va kinjagh marish, as dooyrt Eh, Ta chymmey aym er y pobble, er-yn-oyr dy vel ad er ny ve mârym nish tree laa, as cha vel veg y vee oc: as cha derrym ad ersooyl nyn drostey, er aggle dy der ad naardey er y raad.

English: 33 And his disciples say unto him, Whence should we have so much bread in the wilderness, as to fill so great a multitude?
Manx: Dooyrt adsyn va sheer geiyrt er rish, Cre-woish oddys mad wheesh dy arran y gheddyn ayns yn aasagh, as nee leid y chaglym mooar shoh dy leih y yannoo magh?

English: 34 And Jesus saith unto them, How many loaves have ye? And they said, Seven, and a few little fishes.
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey roo, Cre-woad bwilleen t’eu? Dooyrt adsyn, shiaght, as beggan dy eeastyn beggey.

English: 35 And he commanded the multitude to sit down on the ground.
Manx: As doardee Eh da’n pobble soie sheese er y thalloo.

English: 36 And he took the seven loaves and the fishes, and gave thanks, and brake them, and gave to his disciples, and the disciples to the multitude.
Manx: As ghow Eh ny shiaght bwilleenyn as ny eeastyn, as hug Eh booise, as vrish Eh, as hug Eh ad dauseyn va sheer geiyrt er, as hug adsyn ad da’n pobble.

English: 37 And they did all eat, and were filled: and they took up of the broken meat that was left seven baskets full.
Manx: As ren ad ooilley gee, as v’ad er nyn yannoo magh: as hrog ad jeh’n fooilliagh va er-mayrn laane shiaght basketyn.

English: 38 And they that did eat were four thousand men, beside women and children.
Manx: As v’adsyn ren gee, kiare thousane dooinney, cheu-mooie jeh mraane as cloan.

English: 39 And he sent away the multitude, and took ship, and came into the coasts of Magdala.
Manx: As hug Eh ersooyl yn pobble, as ghow Eh luingys, as haink Eh gys ardjyn Magdala.
CAB. XVI.

English: 16 The Pharisees also with the Sadducees came, and tempting desired him that he would shew them a sign from heaven.
Manx: As haink ny Phariseeyn as ny Saduceeyn dy violaghey Eh, as hir ad er Eh dy yeeaghyn cowrey ennagh daue veih niau.

English: 2 He answered and said unto them, When it is evening, ye say, It will be fair weather: for the sky is red.
Manx: Dreggyr eshyn as dooyrt Eh roo, Tra ta’n fastyr ayn, ta shiuish gra, Bee emshir aalin ayn: son dy vel jirgid ’syn aer.

English: 3 And in the morning, It will be foul weather to day: for the sky is red and lowering. O ye hypocrites, ye can discern the face of the sky; but can ye not discern the signs of the times?
Manx: As ayns y voghrey, Bee emshir vroghe ayn jiu; son ta’n aer jiarg as bodjallagh. Chrauee-oalsey, ta toiggal eu kys dy chur tastey da neeal yn aer, as nagh vod shiu tastey choyrt da cowraghyn ny earishyn?

English: 4 A wicked and adulterous generation seeketh after a sign; and there shall no sign be given unto it, but the sign of the prophet Jonas. And he left them, and departed.
Manx: She sheeloghe mee-chrauee as maardyragh ta shirrey cowrey, as cha bee cowrey er ny chur daue, agh cowrey’n phadeyr Jonas. As daag Eh ad, as jimmee Eh roish.

English: 5 And when his disciples were come to the other side, they had forgotten to take bread.
Manx: As tra v’adsyn va kinjagh geiyrt er er-jeet gys y cheu elley, v’ad er yarrood arran y chur lhieu.

English: 6 ¶Then Jesus said unto them, Take heed and beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and of the Sadducees.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Yeesey roo, Cur-jee twoaie as gow-jee tastey jeh soorit ny Phariseeyn, as ny Sadduceeyn.

English: 7 And they reasoned among themselves, saying, It is because we have taken no bread.
Manx: As loayr ad eddyr ad hene, gra, Ta shoh er-yn-oyr nagh dug shin lhien arran.

English: 8 Which when Jesus perceived, he said unto them, O ye of little faith, why reason ye among yourselves, because ye have brought no bread?
Manx: Tra hoig Yeesey shoh, dooyrt Eh roo, Gheiney faase-chredjuagh, cre’n-fa ta shiu imneagh ayndiu hene er-yn-oyr nagh dug shiu lhieu arran?

English: 9 Do ye not yet understand, neither remember the five loaves of the five thousand, and how many baskets ye took up?
Manx: Nagh vel shiu foast toiggal, as nagh vel cooinaghtyn eu er ny queig bwilleenyn ren magh ny queig thousaneyn, as cre whilleen basket d’ooilliagh v’eu?

English: 10 Neither the seven loaves of the four thousand, and how many baskets ye took up?
Manx: Ny er ny shiaght bwilleenyn ren magh ny kiare thousaneyn, as cre-woad basket hrog shiu?

English: 11 How is it that ye do not understand that I spake it not to you concerning bread, that ye should beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and of the Sadducees?
Manx: Kys te nagh vel shiu goaill eu hene, nagh nee mychione arran loayr mee riu agh shiu dy chur twoaie jeh soorit ny Phariseeyn as ny Sadduceeyn?

English: 12 Then understood they how that he bade them not beware of the leaven of bread, but of the doctrine of the Pharisees and of the Sadducees.
Manx: Eisht hoig ad nagh doardee Eh daue ad dy chur twoaie jeh soorit yn arran, agh jeh ny va ny Phariseeyn as ny Sadduceeyn dy ynsaghey.

English: 13 ¶When Jesus came into the coasts of Caesarea Philippi, he asked his disciples, saying, Whom do men say that I the Son of man am?
Manx: Tra va Yeesey er-jeet gys ardjyn Cesarea Philippi, dênee Eh jeusyn va sheer geiyrt er, gra, Cre ta deiney dy ghra my my-chiones, Mac y dooinney, quoi mee?

English: 14 And they said, Some say that thou art John the Baptist: some, Elias; and others, Jeremias, or one of the prophets.
Manx: Dooyrt adsyn, Ta paart gra dy nee Ean-bashtey oo, as paart Elias, as ta feallagh elley gra dy nee Jeremias oo, ny annane jeh ny phadeyryn.

English: 15 He saith unto them, But whom say ye that I am?
Manx: Dooyrt eshyn roo, Agh quoi ta shiuish dy ghra mee?

English: 16 And Simon Peter answered and said, Thou art the Christ, the Son of the living God.
Manx: Dreggyr Simon Peddyr as dooyrt Eh, Oo yn Creest, Mac y Jee bio.

English: 17 And Jesus answered and said unto him, Blessed art thou, Simon Barjona: for flesh and blood hath not revealed it unto thee, but my Father which is in heaven.
Manx: Dansoor Yeesey as dooyrt Eh rish, Bannit t’ow uss, Simon Bar-jona: son cha nee feill as fuill t’er hoilshaghey shoh dhyts, agh my Ayr t’ayns niau.

English: 18 And I say also unto thee, That thou art Peter, and upon this rock I will build my church; and the gates of hell shall not prevail against it.
Manx: As ta mee myrgeddin gra rhyt, Dy nee uss Peddyr, as dy nee er y chreg shoh hroggym’s m’agglish: as cha vow giattyn niurin yn varriaght urree.

English: 19 And I will give unto thee the keys of the kingdom of heaven: and whatsoever thou shalt bind on earth shall be bound in heaven: and whatsoever thou shalt loose on earth shall be loosed in heaven.
Manx: As verrym’s dhyts ogheryn reeriaght niau: as cre-erbee chianglyss oo er y thalloo, bee eh kainlt ayns niau: as cre-erbee eayslyss oo er y thalloo, bee eh feayslit ayns niau.

English: 20 Then charged he his disciples that they should tell no man that he was Jesus the Christ.
Manx: Eisht hug Eh currym dauesyn va kinjagh geiyrt er, gyn ad dy insh da dooinney erbee, dy nee eshyn va Yeesey yn Creest.

English: 21 ¶From that time forth began Jesus to shew unto his disciples, how that he must go unto Jerusalem, and suffer many things of the elders and chief priests and scribes, and be killed, and be raised again the third day.
Manx: Veih’n traa shen magh ren Yeesey toshiaght dy hoilshaghey dauesyn va kinjagh geiyrt er, kys dy beign da goll seose gys Jerusalem, ymmodee dy reddyn y hurranse veih’n chanstyr, as ny ard-saggyrtyn, as ny scruderyn, as dy beagh Eh er ny choyrt gy baase, agh dy nirragh Eh reesht kione y tress laa.

English: 22 Then Peter took him, and began to rebuke him, saying, Be it far from thee, Lord: this shall not be unto thee.
Manx: Eisht ghow Peddyr Eh, as ren Eh toshiaght dy chur oghsan da, gra, Foddey dy row eh woid, Hiarn, leid shoh dy haghyrt dhyt.

English: 23 But he turned, and said unto Peter, Get thee behind me, Satan: thou art an offence unto me: for thou savourest not the things that be of God, but those that be of men.
Manx: Agh hyndaa eshyn, as dooyrt Eh rish Peddyr, Ass my enish Noid-anmey, t’ow cur ribbeh ayns my raad: son cha vel ennaghtyn ayd jeh ny reddyn ta bentyn rish Jee, agh jeh ny reddyn ta bentyn rish deiney.

English: 24 ¶Then said Jesus unto his disciples, If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Yeesey roosyn va sheer marish, My ta dooinney erbee booiagh geiyrt orrym’s, lig da Eh hene y obbal, as e chrosh y hroggal, as geiyrt orrym.

English: 25 For whosoever will save his life shall lose it: and whosoever will lose his life for my sake shall find it.
Manx: Son quoi-erbee ballish e vioys y hauail, caillee Eh eh: as quoi-erbee chaillys e vioys er my ghraih’s, sauee Eh eh.

English: 26 For what is a man profited, if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own soul? or what shall a man give in exchange for his soul?
Manx: Son cre’n vondeish t’ec dooinney, my chosnys Eh yn seihll ooilley, as e annym hene y choall? ny cre nee dooinney y choyrt ayns coonrey son e annym?

English: 27 For the Son of man shall come in the glory of his Father with his angels; and then he shall reward every man according to his works.
Manx: Son hig Mac y dooinney ayns gloyr e Ayrey, as e ainlyn casherick marish: as ec y traa shen cooilleenee Eh da dy chooilley ghooinney cordail rish e obbraghyn.

English: 28 Verily I say unto you, There be some standing here, which shall not taste of death, till they see the Son of man coming in his kingdom.
Manx: Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Dy vel paart nyn shassoo ayns shoh, nagh jean blashtyn er y baase, derrey hee ad Mac y dooinney cheet ayns e reeriaght.
CAB. XVII.

English: And after six days Jesus taketh Peter, James, and John his brother, and bringeth them up into an high mountain apart,
Manx: As ec kione shey laa, ghow Yeesey Peddyr, as Jamys, as Ean e vraar, as hug Eh lesh ad er-lheh seose er slieau ard,

English: 2 And was transfigured before them: and his face did shine as the sun, and his raiment was white as the light.
Manx: As va’n cummey echey er ny chaghlaa kiongoyrt roo, as ren yn eddin echey soilshean myr y ghrian, as va’n coamrey echey gial myr y soilshey.

English: 3 And, behold, there appeared unto them Moses and Elias talking with him.
Manx: As cur-my-ner, honnick ad Moses as Elias ayns yn enish echey, as v’ad taggloo rish.

English: 4 Then answered Peter, and said unto Jesus, Lord, it is good for us to be here: if thou wilt, let us make here three tabernacles; one for thee, and one for Moses, and one for Elias.
Manx: Eisht dreggyr Peddyr as dooyrt Eh rish Yeesey, Hiarn, te mie er ny son ainyn dy ve ayns shoh: my she dt’aigneys eh, lig dooin three cabbaneyn y yannoo; cabbane er dty hon’s, as cabbane son Moses, as cabbane son Elias.

English: 5 While he yet spake, behold, a bright cloud overshadowed them: and behold a voice out of the cloud, which said, This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased; hear ye him.
Manx: Choud as v’eh foast loayrt, cur-my-ner, ren bodjal sollys scadoo y hilgey harrystoo: as cur-my-ner, coraa ass y vodjal, dooyrt, Shoh my Vac graihagh, jeh ta mee dy mooar soiaghey; eaisht-jee rish.

English: 6 And when the disciples heard it, they fell on their face, and were sore afraid.
Manx: As tra cheayll ny ostyllyn eh, huit ad sheese lesh nyn eddinyn gys y thalloo, as v’ad feer agglagh.

English: 7 And Jesus came and touched them, and said, Arise, and be not afraid.
Manx: As haink Yeesey as venn Eh roo, as dooyrt Eh, Irree-jee seose, as ny gow[-]jee aggle.

English: 8 And when they had lifted up their eyes, they saw no man, save Jesus only.
Manx: As tra hrog ad seose nyn sooyllyn, cha vaik ad annane erbee, agh Yeesey ny lomarcan.

English: 9 And as they came down from the mountain, Jesus charged them, saying, Tell the vision to no man, until the Son of man be risen again from the dead.
Manx: As myr v’ad cheet neose jeh’n clieau, hug Yeesey currym daue, gra, Ny insh-jee yn ashlish da annane erbee, derrey vees yn Mac dooinney er n’irree veih ny merriu.

English: 10 And his disciples asked him, saying, Why then say the scribes that Elias must first come?
Manx: As dênee e ostyllyn jeh, gra, Cre’n-oyr ta ny scruderyn gra, dy vel Elias dy heet hoshiaght?

English: 11 And Jesus answered and said unto them, Elias truly shall first come, and restore all things.
Manx: Dansoor Yeesey as dooyrt Eh roo, Hig Elias hoshiaght, as lhiassee Eh dy chooilley nhee:

English: 12 But I say unto you, That Elias is come already, and they knew him not, but have done unto him whatsoever they listed. Likewise shall also the Son of man suffer of them.
Manx: Agh ta mish gra riu, dy vel Elias er jeet hannah, as cha dug ad enney er, agh t’ad er ghellal rish lurg nyn aigney hene: as er yn aght cheddin ghellys ad myrgeddin rish yn Mac dooinney.

English: 13 Then the disciples understood that he spake unto them of John the Baptist.
Manx: Eisht hoig e ostyllyn dy nee mychione Ean Bashtey v’eh loayrt roo.

English: 14 ¶And when they were come to the multitude, there came to him a certain man, kneeling down to him, and saying,
Manx: As tra v’ad er jeet gys y cheshaght, haink huggey dooinney dy row, as huit Eh sheese er e ghlioonyn, gra,

English: 15 Lord, have mercy on my son: for he is lunatick, and sore vexed: for ofttimes he falleth into the fire, and oft into the water.
Manx: Hiarn, jean chymmey er my vac, son t’eh eddrym ayns e cheeal rish caghlaa ny haist, as dy mooar seaghnit: son dy mennick t’eh tuittym ayns yn aile, as dy mennick ayns yn ushtey.

English: 16 And I brought him to thy disciples, and they could not cure him.
Manx: As hug mee lhiam Eh gys dty ostyllyn, as cha yiarg ad Eh y lheihys.

English: 17 Then Jesus answered and said, O faithless and perverse generation, how long shall I be with you? how long shall I suffer you? bring him hither to me.
Manx: Dansoor Yeesey as dooyrt Eh, O heeloghe vee-chredjuagh as roonagh, caid ta mish dy ve mêriu? caid ta mee dy hurranse diu? cur lhiat Eh hym’s ayns shoh.

English: 18 And Jesus rebuked the devil; and he departed out of him: and the child was cured from that very hour.
Manx: As vaggyr Yeesey er y drogh-spyrryd, as hie Eh magh ass: as va’n liannoo er ny lheihys veih’n oor shen.

English: 19 Then came the disciples to Jesus apart, and said, Why could not we cast him out?
Manx: Eisht haink e ostyllyn gys Yeesey er-lheh, as dooyrt ad, Cre liorish nagh voddagh shinyn Eh y hilgey ass?

English: 20 And Jesus said unto them, Because of your unbelief: for verily I say unto you, If ye have faith as a grain of mustard seed, ye shall say unto this mountain, Remove hence to yonder place; and it shall remove; and nothing shall be impossible unto you.
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey roo, Kyndagh rish y vee-chredjue eu: son dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, My ta credjue eu myr greine dy rass mustard, jir shiu rish y slieau shoh, Scugh ass shoh noon ayns shid, as nee eh scughey; as cha bee nhee erbee neu-phossible diu.

English: 21 Howbeit this kind goeth not out but by prayer and fasting.
Manx: Ny-yeih cha vel y sorch shoh dy ghrogh-spyrrydyn er nyn eiyrt magh, agh liorish padjer as trostey.

English: 22 ¶And while they abode in Galilee, Jesus said unto them, The Son of man shall be betrayed into the hands of men:
Manx: As choud as v’ad ayns Galilee, dooyrt Yeesey roo, Bee Mac y dooinney er ny vrah gys laueyn deiney:

English: 23 And they shall kill him, and the third day he shall be raised again. And they were exceeding sorry.
Manx: As ver ad Eh gy baase, as y tress laa nee Eh girree reesht: as v’ad feer trimshagh.

English: 24 ¶And when they were come to Capernaum, they that received tribute money came to Peter, and said, Doth not your master pay tribute?
Manx: As tra v’ad erjeet gys Capernaum, haink y vooinjer va troggal argid y cheesh gys Peddyr, gra, Nagh vel y mainshtyr eauish geeck y cheesh?

English: 25 He saith, Yes. And when he was come into the house, Jesus prevented him, saying, What thinkest thou, Simon? of whom do the kings of the earth take custom or tribute? of their own children, or of strangers?
Manx: Dooyrt eshyn, dy row. As tra v’eh er jeet stiagh ayns y thie, loayr Yeesey rishyn hoshiaght, gra, Cre t’ow dy smooinaghtyn, Simon? quoi jeh ta reeaghyn y thallooin troggal custom ny keesh? jeh nyn gloan hene, ny jeh joarreeyn?

English: 26 Peter saith unto him, Of strangers. Jesus saith unto him, Then are the children free.
Manx: Dooyrt Peddyr rish, Jeh joarreeyn. Dooyrt Yeesey rishyn, Eisht cha vel veg er y chloan dy eeck.

English: 27 Notwithstanding, lest we should offend them, go thou to the sea, and cast an hook, and take up the fish that first cometh up; and when thou hast opened his mouth, thou shalt find a piece of money: that take, and give unto them for me and thee.
Manx: Ny-yeih, son nagh bee commys er ny chur hooin, gow uss gys y cheayn, as tilg magh dooan, as trog y chied eeast hig hood: as tra vees oo er vosley’n beeal echey, yiow peesh dy argid ayn; shen gow, as cur daue er my hon’s as er dty hon hene.
CAB. XVIII.

English: At the same time came the disciples unto Jesus, saying, Who is the greatest in the kingdom of heaven?
Manx: Ec y traa cheddin kaink [sic: haink] y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er Yeesey huggey, gra, Quoi syrjey ayns reeriaght niau?

English: 2 And Jesus called a little child unto him, and set him in the midst of them,
Manx: As deïe Yeesey er liannoo beg, as hoie Eh Eh kiongoyrt roo,

English: 3 And said, Verily I say unto you, Except ye be converted, and become as little children, ye shall not enter into the kingdom of heaven.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Mannagh jean shiu chyndaa, as cheet dy ve myr cloan veggey, cha jed shiu stiagh ayns reeriaght niau.

English: 4 Whosoever therefore shall humble himself as this little child, the same is greatest in the kingdom of heaven.
Manx: Quoi-erbee er-y-fa shen nee Eh hene y injillaghey myr y liannoo beg shoh, Eh syrjey ta ayns reeriaght niau.

English: 5 And whoso shall receive one such little child in my name receiveth me.
Manx: As quoi-erbee nee soiaghey jeh leid y liannoo beg shoh ayns yn ennym aym’s, t’eh jannoo soiaghey jeem’s.

English: 6 But whoso shall offend one of these little ones which believe in me, it were better for him that a millstone were hanged about his neck, and that he were drowned in the depth of the sea.
Manx: Agh quoi-erbee ver oyr da annane jeh’n vooinjer veggey shoh ta credjal aynyms dy huittym [veih’n Chredjue,] veagh eh ny baare da dy beagh clagh-wyllin er ve croghit mysh e wannal, as Eh dy ve baiht ayns diunit ny marrey.

English: 7 ¶Woe unto the world because of offences! for it must needs be that offences come; but woe to that man by whom the offence cometh
Manx: Smerg da’n seihll, er coontey oyryn peccah: son shegin da nyn leid y ve ayn; agh smerg da’n dooinney liorish ta sleih er nyn dayrn gys peccah.

English: 8 Wherefore if thy hand or thy foot offend thee, cut them off, and cast them from thee: it is better for thee to enter into life halt or maimed, rather than having two hands or two feet to be cast into everlasting fire.
Manx: Shen-y-fa my ta dty laue ny dty chass hene dy dty hayrn gys yn olk, giare jeed as tilg woid ad: te ny share dhyt goll stiagh ayns bea croobagh ny baccagh, na daa laue ny daa chass y ve ayd, as oo dy ve tilgit ayns yn aile dy bragh farraghtyn.

English: 9 And if thine eye offend thee, pluck it out, and cast it from thee: it is better for thee to enter into life with one eye, rather than having two eyes to be cast into hell fire.
Manx: As my ta dty hooyl dy dty hayrn gys peccagh, pluck assyd as tilg woid ee: te ny share dhyt goll stiagh ayns bea lesh un hooyl, na daa hooyl y ve ayd, as oo dy ve tilgit ayns aile niurin.

English: 10 Take heed that ye despise not one of these little ones; for I say unto you, That in heaven their angels do always behold the face of my Father which is in heaven.
Manx: Cur-jee twoaie nagh soie shiu beg jeh annane jeh’n vooinjer veggey shoh; son ta mee gra riu, dy vel ny ainlyn ocsyn ayns niau, kinjagh cur-my-ner eddin yn Ayr ayms t’ayns niau.

English: 11 For the Son of man is come to save that which was lost.
Manx: Son ta Mac y dooinney er-jeet dy hauail shen ny va callit.

English: 12 How think ye? if a man have an hundred sheep, and one of them be gone astray, doth he not leave the ninety and nine, and goeth into the mountains, and seeketh that which is gone astray?
Manx: Cre ta shiu dy smooinaghtyn? My ta keead keyrrey ec dooinney, as annane jeu v’er gholl er-shaghryn, nagh vel Eh faagail yn chiare-feed as yn nuyh-jeig, as goll gys ny sleityn, as shirrey yn cheyrrey hie er-shaghryn?

English: 13 And if so be that he find it, verily I say unto you, he rejoiceth more of that sheep, than of the ninety and nine which went not astray.
Manx: As my she shen dy vel Eh dy gheddyn ee, dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy vel Eh goaill ny smoo dy voggey jeh’n cheyrrey shen, ny jeh’n chiare-feed as yn nuyh-jeig, nagh jagh er-shaghryn.

English: 14 Even so it is not the will of your Father which is in heaven, that one of these little ones should perish.
Manx: Er yn aght cheddin, cha nee aigney nyn Ayr t’ayns niau eh, annane jeh’n vooinjer veggey shoh dy hierraghtyn.

English: 15 ¶Moreover if thy brother shall trespass against thee, go and tell him his fault between thee and him alone: if he shall hear thee, thou hast gained thy brother.
Manx: Myrgeddin my nee dty vraar aggair dhyt, immee as insh da e oill eddyr uss as eshyn nyn lomarcan: my eaishtys Eh rhyt, t’ow er chosney dty vraar.

English: 16 But if he will not hear thee, then take with thee one or two more, that in the mouth of two or three witnesses every word may be established.
Manx: Agh mannagh n’eaisht Eh rhyt, eisht gow mayrt annane ny jees elley, ayns beeal ghaa ny three dy eanishyn dy vod dy chooilley ockle ve jeant mie.

English: 17 And if he shall neglect to hear them, tell it unto the church: but if he neglect to hear the church, let him be unto thee as an heathen man and a publican.
Manx: As mannagh der Eh geill dauesyn, insh eh da’n agglish: agh mannagh der Eh geill da’n agglish, jeeagh er myr fer jeh ny ashoonyn-quaagh as myr publican.

English: 18 Verily I say unto you, Whatsoever ye shall bind on earth shall be bound in heaven: and whatsoever ye shall loose on earth shall be loosed in heaven.
Manx: Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Cre-erbee nee shiu y chiangley er y thalloo, bee eh kainlt ayns niau: as cre-erbee nee shiu y eaysley er y thalloo, bee eh feayslit ayns niau.

English: 19 Again I say unto you, That if two of you shall agree on earth as touching any thing that they shall ask, it shall be done for them of my Father which is in heaven.
Manx: Reesht ta mee gra riu, my nee jees jiuish coardail er y thalloo, my-chione nhee erbee dy jean ad aghin er y hon, bee nyn aghin er ny chooilleeney liorish my Ayr t’ayns niau.

English: 20 For where two or three are gathered together in my name, there am I in the midst of them.
