Manx: Son raad ta ghaa ny three er nyn jaglym cooidjagh ayns m’ennyms, ayns shen ta mish nyn mastey.

English: Then came Peter to him, and said, Lord, how oft shall my brother sin against me, and I forgive him? till seven times?
Manx: 21¶ Eisht haink Peddyr huggey, as dooyrt Eh, Hiarn, cre cha mennick as ta orryms leih da my vraar, tra vees Eh jannoo peccah m’oi? choud as shiaght keayrtyn?

English: 22 Jesus saith unto him, I say not unto thee, Until seven times: but, Until seventy times seven.
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey rish, Cha vel mish gra rhyt, Choud as shiaght keayrtyn: agh choud as three-feed as jeih keayrtyn shiaght.

English: 23 ¶Therefore is the kingdom of heaven likened unto a certain king, which would take account of his servants.
Manx: Shen-y-fa ta reeriaght niau er ny hoyllaghey gys ree dy row, ballish coontey ’ghoaill jeh e harvaantyn.

English: 24 And when he had begun to reckon, one was brought unto him, which owed him ten thousand talents.
Manx: As tra v’eh er n’yannoo toshiaght dy choontey, haink fer huggey va lhiastyn jeih thousane talent.

English: 25 But forasmuch as he had not to pay, his lord commanded him to be sold, and his wife, and children, and all that he had, and payment to be made.
Manx: Agh son wheesh as nagh row echey dy eeck, hug e Hiarn saarey Eh hene dy ve creckit, as e ven as e chloan, as ooilley ny v’echey, as y feeaghyn dy ve eeckit.

English: 26 The servant therefore fell down, and worshipped him, saying, Lord, have patience with me, and I will pay thee all.
Manx: Huit y charvaant er-y-fa shen sheese, as ghuee Eh er, gra, Cur daill dou, Hiarn, as nee’m ooilley y eeck dhyt.

English: 27 Then the lord of that servant was moved with compassion, and loosed him, and forgave him the debt.
Manx: Eisht va chiarn y charvaant shen er ny veiyghey lesh chymmey, as ren Eh feaysley er, as leih Eh da ny v’eh dy lhiastyn.

English: 28 But the same servant went out, and found one of his fellowservants, which owed him an hundred pence: and he laid hands on him, and took him by the throat, saying, Pay me that thou owest.
Manx: Agh hie yn charvaant cheddin magh, as hooar Eh fer jeh e heshaghyn-harvaant [sic] va lhiastyn da keead ping: as haare Eh greme er, as ghow Eh Eh er y scoarnagh, gra, Eeck shen ny t’ow dy lhiastyn.

English: 29 And his fellowservant fell down at his feet, and besought him, saying, Have patience with me, and I will pay thee all.
Manx: As huit e heshey-harvaant sheese ec y chassyn, as ghuee Eh er, gra, Cur daill dou, as nee’m ooilley y eeck dhyt.

English: 30 And he would not: but went and cast him into prison, till he should pay the debt.
Manx: Agh cha row Eh booiagh: agh hie Eh as hilg Eh Eh ayns pryssoon, derrey eeckagh Eh ny v’eh dy lhiastyn.

English: 31 So when his fellowservants saw what was done, they were very sorry, and came and told unto their lord all that was done.
Manx: Myr shen tra honnick e heshaghyn-harvaant [sic] kys hie Eh er, ghow ad dy holk rish, as haink ad as dinsh ad da nyn jiarn ooilley ny va jeant.

English: 32 Then his lord, after that he had called him, said unto him, O thou wicked servant, I forgave thee all that debt, because thou desiredst me:
Manx: Eisht deïe e Hiarn er, as dooyrt Eh rish, O ghrogh harvaant, leih mish dhyts ooilley ny vow dy lhiastyn, er-y-fa dy ren oo aghin hym:

English: 33 Shouldest not thou also have had compassion on thy fellowservant, even as I had pity on thee?
Manx: As nagh lhisagh uss myrgeddin v’er n’yannoo chymmey er dty heshey-harvaant, myr va chymmey ayms orts?

English: 34 And his lord was wroth, and delivered him to the tormentors, till he should pay all that was due unto him.
Manx: As va e hiarn jymmoosagh, as livrey Eh Eh hucsyn va goaill kerraghey, derrey eeckagh Eh ooilley ny v’eh dy lhiastyn.

English: 35 So likewise shall my heavenly Father do also unto you, if ye from your hearts forgive not every one his brother their trespasses.
Manx: Myr shen myrgeddin nee my Ayr flaunyssagh riuish, mannagh leih shiu veih nyn greeaghyn dy chooilley ghooinney da e vraar e loghtyn.
CAB. XIX.

English: And it came to pass, that when Jesus had finished these sayings, he departed from Galilee, and came into the coasts of Judaea beyond Jordan;
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, tra va Yeesey erreish ny goan shoh y loayrt, dy jimmee Eh veih Galilee, as dy daink Eh gys ardjyn Yudea, er cheu elley dy Yordan:

English: 2 And great multitudes followed him; and he healed them there.
Manx: As deiyr earrooyn mooarey dy leih er, ren Eh ad y lheihys ayns shen.

English: 3 ¶The Pharisees also came unto him, tempting him, and saying unto him, Is it lawful for a man to put away his wife for every cause?
Manx: Haink ny Phariseeyn huggey myrgeddin dy violaghey Eh, as dooyrt ad rish, Vel eh lowal da dooinney e ven y chur er sooyl son dy chooilley oyr?

English: 4 And he answered and said unto them, Have ye not read, that he which made them at the beginning made them male and female,
Manx: Dreggyr eshyn, as dooyrt Eh roo, Nagh vel shiu er lhaih, eshyn chroo ad ec y toshiaght, dy chroo Eh ad fyrrynagh as bwoirrynagh?

English: 5 And said, For this cause shall a man leave father and mother, and shall cleave to his wife: and they twain shall be one flesh?
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Er yn oyr shoh nee dooinney faagail e ayr as e voir, as liannee Eh gys e ven: as bee ad ny neesht un eill.

English: 6 Wherefore they are no more twain, but one flesh. What therefore God hath joined together, let not man put asunder.
Manx: Shen-y-fa cha vel ad ny sodjey jees, agh un eill. Cre-erbee er-y-fa shen ta Jee er chur cooidjagh, ny lig da dooinney erbee y chur veih my chielley.

English: 7 They say unto him, Why did Moses then command to give a writing of divorcement, and to put her away?
Manx: Dooyrt adsyn rish, Cre’n-oyr eisht doardee Moses screeuyn scarree y choyrt, as y ven y chur ersooyl?

English: 8 He saith unto them, Moses because of the hardness of your hearts suffered you to put away your wives: but from the beginning it was not so.
Manx: Dooyrt eshyn roo, kyndagh rish creoghys nyn greeaghyn, lhow Moses diu nyn mraane y chur ersooyl: agh cha row eh myr shen er dyn toshiaght.

English: 9 And I say unto you, Whosoever shall put away his wife, except it be for fornication, and shall marry another, committeth adultery: and whoso marrieth her which is put away doth commit adultery.
Manx: As ta mish gra riu, Quoi-erbee scarrys rish e ven, cheu-mooie jeh son maarderys, as phoosys ben elley, t’eh brishey poosey: as quoi-erbee phoosys ish ta scarrit, t’eh brishey poosey.

English: 10 ¶His disciples say unto him, If the case of the man be so with his wife, it is not good to marry.
Manx: Dooyrt y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er rish, My she shoh yn stayd ta dooinney as ben ayn, cha vel eh mie dy phoosey.

English: 11 But he said unto them, All men cannot receive this saying, save they to whom it is given.
Manx: Agh dooyrt eshyn roo, cha nee dy chooilley ghooinney oddys shen y ghoaill er,* agh adsyn ny lomarcan daue te er ny choyrt.
* Eh hene y reaylley veih poosey.

English: 12 For there are some eunuchs, which were so born from their mother’s womb: and there are some eunuchs, which were made eunuchs of men: and there be eunuchs, which have made themselves eunuchs for the kingdom of heaven’s sake. He that is able to receive it, let him receive it.
Manx: Son ta deiney gennish ayn, rug myr shen veih breïn nyn maarey: as ta deiney gennish ayn, v’er nyn yannoo gennish liorish deiney: as ta deiney gennish ayn, t’er n’yannoo ad hene gennish er graih reeriaght niau. Eshyn ta abyl shoh y ghoaill er, lig Eh eh y ghoaill er.

English: 13 ¶Then were there brought unto him little children, that he should put his hands on them, and pray: and the disciples rebuked them.
Manx: Eisht hug ad lhieu huggey cloan veggey, dy voddagh Eh e laueyn y chur orroo, as padjer y ghoaill: as hug y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er oghsan daue.

English: 14 But Jesus said, Suffer little children, and forbid them not, to come unto me: for of such is the kingdom of heaven.
Manx: Agh dooyrt Yeesey, Sur-jee cloan aegey, as ny jean-jee nyn lhiettal ad dy heet hyms: son jeh nyn leid ta reeriaght niau.

English: 15 And he laid his hands on them, and departed thence.
Manx: As hug Eh e laueyn orroo, as jimmee Eh veih shen.

English: 16 ¶And, behold, one came and said unto him, Good Master, what good thing shall I do, that I may have eternal life?
Manx: As cur-my-ner, haink fer huggey, as dooyrt Eh rish, Vainshtyr vie, cre’n red mie neem’s, dy vod yn vea veayn y ve aym?

English: 17 And he said unto him, Why callest thou me good? there is none good but one, that is, God: but if thou wilt enter into life, keep the commandments.
Manx: As dooyrt eshyn rish, Cre’n-fa t’ow genmys mee mie? cha vel annane erbee mie, agh annane, ta shen dy ghra Jee: agh my sailts goll stiagh ayns bea, freill ny annaghyn.

English: 18 He saith unto him, Which? Jesus said, Thou shalt do no murder, Thou shalt not commit adultery, Thou shalt not steal, Thou shalt not bear false witness,
Manx: Dooyrt eshyn rish, Cre ny annaghyn? Dooyrt Yeesey, Cha jean oo dunverys, Cha brish oo poosey, Cha jean oo geid, Cha nymmyrk oo feanish foalsey,

English: 19 Honour thy father and thy mother: and, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself.
Manx: Cur arrym da dt’ayr as da dty voir: as, Ver oo graih da dty naboo myr dhyt hene.

English: 20 The young man saith unto him, All these things have I kept from my youth up: what lack I yet?
Manx: Dooyrt y dooinney aeg rish, Ooilley ny annaghyn shoh ta mee er vreaylley veih my aegid: cre sodjey t’orrym dy yannoo?

English: 21 Jesus said unto him, If thou wilt be perfect, go and sell that thou hast, and give to the poor, and thou shalt have treasure in heaven: and come and follow me.
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey rish, My bailt ve dy firrinagh mie, immee, as creck as cur ny t’ayd da ny boghtyn, as bee berchys ayd ayns niau; as tar as eiyr orryms.

English: 22 But when the young man heard that saying, he went away sorrowful: for he had great possessions.
Manx: Agh tra cheayll y dooinney aeg yn raa shen, hie Eh ersooyl dy trimshagh: son va cummallyn mooarey echey.

English: 23 ¶Then said Jesus unto his disciples, Verily I say unto you, That a rich man shall hardly enter into the kingdom of heaven.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Yeesey roosyn va sheer geiyrt er, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy-goan hed dooinney berchagh stiagh ayns reeriaght niau.

English: 24 And again I say unto you, It is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle, than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of God.
Manx: As reesht ta mee gra riu, Te ny sassey da camel goll trooid croae snaidey, na da dooinney berchagh dy gholl stiagh ayns reeriaght Yee.

English: 25 When his disciples heard it, they were exceedingly amazed, saying, Who then can be saved?
Manx: Tra cheayll y vooinjer va sheer marish shoh, v’ad erskyn towse atchimagh, gra, Quoi eisht oddys ve er ny hauail?

English: 26 But Jesus beheld them, and said unto them, With men this is impossible; but with God all things are possible.
Manx: Agh yeeagh Yeesey orroo, as dooyrt Eh roo, Da deiney ta shoh neu-phossible, agh da Jee ta dy chooilley nhee possible.

English: 27 ¶Then answered Peter and said unto him, Behold, we have forsaken all, and followed thee; what shall we have therefore?
Manx: Eisht dreggyr Peddyr, as dooyrt Eh rish, Cur-my-ner, ta shinyn er dreigeil ooilley, as er n’eiyrt orts; cre vees ainyn er-y-fa shen.

English: 28 And Jesus said unto them, Verily I say unto you, That ye which have followed me, in the regeneration when the Son of man shall sit in the throne of his glory, ye also shall sit upon twelve thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel.
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey roo, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, ec y yiennaghtyn reesht, tra Mac y dooinney soie er stoyl-reeoil e ghloyr, dy jean shiuish myrgeddin t’er n’eiyrt orryms soie er daa stoyl-reeoil yeig, briwnys daa heeloghe yeig Israel.

English: 29 And every one that hath forsaken houses, or brethren, or sisters, or father, or mother, or wife, or children, or lands, for my name’s sake, shall receive an hundredfold, and shall inherit everlasting life.
Manx: As dy chooilley annane t’er hreigeil thieyn, ny braaraghyn, ny shairaghyn, ny ayr, ny moir, ny ben, ny cloan, ny thalloo, er graih m’ennyms, kead-filley, as eiraght ayns y vea veayn.

English: 30 But many that are first shall be last; and the last shall be first.
Manx: Agh bee ymmodee jeusyn ta hoshiaght, er-jerrey; as jeusyn ta er-jerrey hoshiaght.
CAB. XX.

English: For the kingdom of heaven is like unto a man that is an householder, which went out early in the morning to hire labourers into his vineyard.
Manx: Son ta reeriaght niau casley rish dooinney va ny ar-thie, hie magh dy moghey dy ailley labreeyn son e gharey-feeney.

English: 2 And when he had agreed with the labourers for a penny a day, he sent them into his vineyard.
Manx: As tra v’eh er choardail rish ny labreeyn son ping ’sy laa, hug Eh ad stiagh ayns e gharey-feeney.

English: 3 And he went out about the third hour, and saw others standing idle in the marketplace,
Manx: As hie Eh magh mysh y tress oor, as honnick eh feallagh elley ny[n] [1] shassoo nyn daaue ayns ynnyd y vargee,
Notes: [1] This (apparent) error, occurring in the same phrase in v. 6, is reproduced from the 1748 Noo Mian, and is reproduced again in this passage in the 1765 Prayer Book (ny shassoo replaced by shassoo in the 1772 Bible and the 1777 Prayer Book). There is one similar example in the Apocrypha: hooar ad ny shassoo ayns shen Osias as shanstyryn… (Judith 19.6). Er ny son occurs quite frequently, but the expected er nyn son at least 10 times more so.

English: 4 And said unto them; Go ye also into the vineyard, and whatsoever is right I will give you. And they went their way.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Gow-jee shiuish myrgeddin stiagh ayns y gharey-feeney, as verryms diu cre-erbee ta cair. As hie ad rymboo.

English: 5 Again he went out about the sixth and ninth hour, and did likewise.
Manx: Reesht hie Eh magh mysh y cheyoo as yn nuyhoo oor, as ren Eh er yn aght cheddin.

English: 6 And about the eleventh hour he went out, and found others standing idle, and saith unto them, Why stand ye here all the day idle?
Manx: As mysh yn un oor jeig, hie Eh magh, as hooar Eh feallagh elley ny[n] shassoo nyn daaue, as dooyrt Eh roo, Cre’n-fa ta shiu nyn shassoo ayns shoh fey laa nyn daaue?

English: 7 They say unto him, Because no man hath hired us. He saith unto them, Go ye also into the vineyard; and whatsoever is right, that shall ye receive.
Manx: Dooyrt adsyn rish, Er-yn-oyr nagh vel dooinney erbee er vailley shin. Dooyrt eshyn roo, Gow-jee shiu[i]sh myrgeddin stiagh ayns y gharey-feeney, as yiow shiu cre-erbee ta cair.

English: 8 So when even was come, the lord of the vineyard saith unto his steward, Call the labourers, and give them their hire, beginning from the last unto the first.
Manx: Myr shen tra va’n fastyr er jeet, dooyrt chiarn y gharey-feeney rish y stiurt echey, Eïe er ny labreeyn, as cur daue nyn vail, goaill toshiaght veih yn vooinjer s’jerree gys y chied eallagh.

English: 9 And when they came that were hired about the eleventh hour, they received every man a penny.
Manx: As tra haink feallagh yn un oor-jeig, hooar ad dy chooilley ghooinney ping.

English: 10 But when the first came, they supposed that they should have received more; and they likewise received every man a penny.
Manx: Agh tra haink y chied eallagh, heill ad dy voghe ad ny smoo, as hooar adsyn myrgeddin dy chooilley ghooinney ping.

English: 11 And when they had received it, they murmured against the goodman of the house,
Manx: As tra v’ad er ghoaill eh, loayr ad dy jymmoosagh rish yn far-thie,

English: 12 Saying, These last have wrought but one hour, and thou hast made them equal unto us, which have borne the burden and heat of the day.
Manx: Gra, Cha vel yn vooinjer s’jerree shoh er n’obbraghey agh un oor, as t’ow er n’yannoo ad corrym rooinyn t’er n’ymmyrkey errey as chiass y laa.

English: 13 But he answered one of them, and said, Friend, I do thee no wrong: didst not thou agree with me for a penny?
Manx: Agh dreggyr eshyn fer jeu, gra, Heshey vie, cha vel mish jannoo aggair dhyt: nagh choard uss rhym’s son ping?

English: 14 Take that thine is, and go thy way: I will give unto this last, even as unto thee.
Manx: Trog shen ny ta lhiat, as immee royd: m’aigney’s eh dy choyrt da’n fer s’jerree shoh, myr ta mee er chur dhyts.

English: 15 Is it not lawful for me to do what I will with mine own? Is thine eye evil, because I am good?
Manx: Nagh vel eh lowal dou dy yannoo cre saillym rish my chooid hene? vel dty hooyl’s olk, er-y-fa dy vel mish mie?

English: 16 So the last shall be first, and the first last: for many be called, but few chosen.
Manx: Myr shen bee adsyn ta er-jerrey hoshiaght, as adsyn ta hoshiaght er-jerrey: son ta ymmodee er nyn eam, agh beggan er nyn reih.

English: 17 ¶And Jesus going up to Jerusalem took the twelve disciples apart in the way, and said unto them,
Manx: As myr va Yeesey goll seose gys Jerusalem, ghow Eh yn daa ostyl yeig dy-lhiattee er y raad, as dooyrt Eh roo,

English: 18 Behold, we go up to Jerusalem; and the Son of man shall be betrayed unto the chief priests and unto the scribes, and they shall condemn him to death,
Manx: Cur-my-ner, ta shin goll seose gys Jerusalem, as bee Mac y dooinney er ny vrah gys ny ard-saggyrtyn, as gys ny scruderyn, as deyree ad Eh gy baase,

English: 19 And shall deliver him to the Gentiles to mock, and to scourge, and to crucify him: and the third day he shall rise again.
Manx: As livreyee ad Eh hucsyn jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaah [sic: quaagh], dy chraidey mysh, as dy chustey, as dy chrossey Eh: as er y tress laa nee Eh girree reesht.

English: 20 ¶Then came to him the mother of Zebedees children with her sons, worshipping him, and desiring a certain thing of him.
Manx: Eisht haink huggey moir cloan Zebedee, as e meck mâree, cur ooashley da, as shirrey aghin er.

English: 21 And he said unto her, What wilt thou? She saith unto him, Grant that these my two sons may sit, the one on thy right hand, and the other on the left, in thy kingdom.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh ree, Cre bailt? Dooyrt ish rish, Lhow da my ghaa vac dy hoie, yn derrey yeh er dty laue yesh, as y jeh elley er dty laue chiare ayns dty reeriaght.

English: 22 But Jesus answered and said, Ye know not what ye ask. Are ye able to drink of the cup that I shall drink of, and to be baptized with the baptism that I am baptized with? They say unto him, We are able.
Manx: Agh dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh, Cha s’eu cre ta shiu dy yeearree. Vel shiu abyl giu jeh’n cappan ta mish giu jeh, as v’er nyn mashtey lesh y bashtey ta mish bashtit lesh? Dooyrt adsyn rish, Ta shin abyl.

English: 23 And he saith unto them, Ye shall drink indeed of my cup, and be baptized with the baptism that I am baptized with: but to sit on my right hand, and on my left, is not mine to give, but it shall be given to them for whom it is prepared of my Father.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Iuee shiu dy jarroo jeh my chappan, as bee shiu er nyn mashtey lesh y bashtey ta mish bashtit lesh: agh dy hoie er my laue yesh as er my laue chiare, cha vel shen lhiam’s dy choyrt, agh ny lomarcan dauesyn er nyn son te kiarit liorish my Ayr.

English: 24 And when the ten heard it, they were moved with indignation against the two brethren.
Manx: As tra cheayll yn jeih shoh, v’ad feer jymmoosagh rish y daa vraar.

English: 25 But Jesus called them unto him, and said, Ye know that the princes of the Gentiles exercise dominion over them, and they that are great exercise authority upon them.
Manx: Agh deïe Yeesey orroo huggey, as dooyrt Eh, Ta fys eu dy vel prinsyn ny Ashoonyn-quaagh gymmyrkey reill harrystoo, as ta ny deiney mooarey gymmyrkey torrity nyn mastey.

English: 26 But it shall not be so among you: but whosoever will be great among you, let him be your minister;
Manx: Agh cha bee eh myr shen nyn mastey eauish: agh quoi-erbee eauish ballish ve mooar, lig Eh ve ry hoi shirveish erriu.

English: 27 And whosoever will be chief among you, let him be your servant:
Manx: As quoi-erbee syrjey ballish y ve nyn mast’ eu, lig Eh ve yn charvaant eu.

English: 28 Even as the Son of man came not to be ministered unto, but to minister, and to give his life a ransom for many.
Manx: Myr nagh daink yn Mac dooinney dy ve shirveishit, agh dy hirveish, as dy chur e vioys ny lhiassaghey son ymmodee.

English: 29 And as they departed from Jericho, a great multitude followed him.
Manx: As tra v’ad er n’immeeaght veih Jericho, deiyr earrooyn mooarey dy leih er.

English: 30 ¶And, behold, two blind men sitting by the way side, when they heard that Jesus passed by, cried out, saying, Have mercy on us, O Lord, thou son of David.
Manx: As cur-my-ner, va daa ghooinney doal nyn soie rish oirr yn raad, as tra cheayll ad dy row Yeesey goll shiaghey, deïe ad, gra, Jean myghin orrin, O Hiarn, vac Ghavid.

English: 31 And the multitude rebuked them, because they should hold their peace: but they cried the more, saying, Have mercy on us, O Lord, thou son of David.
Manx: As va’n pobble cur oghsan daue, dy voddagh ad nyn jengey ’chummal: agh deïe adsyn wheesh shen smoo, gra, Jean myghin orrin, O Hiarn, vac Ghavid.

English: 32 And Jesus stood still, and called them, and said, What will ye that I shall do unto you?
Manx: As hass Yeesey, as deïe Eh orroo, as dooyrt Eh, Cre bailliu mee dy yannoo er ny son eu?

English: 33 They say unto him, Lord, that our eyes may be opened.
Manx: Dooyrt adsyn rish, Hiarn, dy vod ny sooyllyn ain v’er nyn vosley.

English: 34 So Jesus had compassion on them, and touched their eyes: and immediately their eyes received sight, and they followed him.
Manx: Myr shen va chymmey ec Yeesey orroo, as venn Eh rish ny sooyllyn oc: as chelleeragh hooar ny sooyllyn oc nyn soilshey, as deiyr ad er.
CAB. XXI.

English: And when they drew nigh unto Jerusalem, and were come to Bethphage, unto the mount of Olives, then sent Jesus two disciples,
Manx: As tra v’ad tayrn er-gerrey da Jerusalem, as dy row ad er jeet gys Bethphage, gys cronck ny Oliveyn, hug Yeesey jees jeusyn va kinjagh geiyrt er, er chaghteraght,

English: 2 Saying unto them, Go into the village over against you, and straightway ye shall find an ass tied, and a colt with her: loose them, and bring them unto me.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Immee-jee gys y balley-beg ta shiu dy akin, as chelleeragh yiow shiu assyl kainlt as lhie mâree: feayshyl-jee as cur-jee lhieu ad hym’s.

English: 3 And if any man say ought unto you, ye shall say, The Lord hath need of them; and straightway he will send them.
Manx: As my loayrys dooinney erbee veg riu, abbyr-jee shiuish, Ta feme ec y Chiarn orroo; as chelleeragh lhiggee Eh yn raad daue.

English: 4 All this was done, that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophet, saying,
Manx: Va ooilley shoh jeant, dy voddagh shen ve cooilleenit va loayrit liorish y phadeyr, gra,

English: 5 Tell ye the daughter of Sion, Behold, thy King cometh unto thee, meek, and sitting upon an ass, and a colt the foal of an ass.
Manx: Insh-jee da inneen Sion, Cur-my-ner, ta dty ree cheet hood dy imlee, as ny hoie er assyl, as er lhie sharragh assyl.

English: 6 And the disciples went, and did as Jesus commanded them,
Manx: As hie adsyn rymboo, as ren ad myr va Yeesey er n’oardaghey daue.

English: 7 And brought the ass, and the colt, and put on them their clothes, and they set him thereon.
Manx: As hug ad lhieu yn assyl as y lhie, as hug ad orroo nyn eaddagh, as hug ad eshyn ny hoie er yn eadagh.

English: 8 And a very great multitude spread their garments in the way; others cut down branches from the trees, and strawed them in the way.
Manx: As ren earrooyn mooarey dy leih skeayley nyn gharmadyn er y raad; yiare feallagh elley banglaneyn jeh ny biljyn, as skeayll ad ad er y raad.

English: 9 And the multitudes that went before, and that followed, cried, saying, Hosanna to the son of David: Blessed is he that cometh in the name of the Lord; Hosanna in the highest.
Manx: As deïe yn pobble hie roish, as adsyn haink ny yei, gra, Hosanna gys mac Ghavid: bannit ta eshyn ta cheet ayns ennym y Chiarn, Hosanna ayns yn yrjid.

English: 10 And when he was come into Jerusalem, all the city was moved, saying, Who is this?
Manx: As tra v’eh er jeet gys Jerusalem, va ooilley’n ard-valley seaghnit, gra, Quoi Eh shoh?

English: 11 And the multitude said, This is Jesus the prophet of Nazareth of Galilee.
Manx: Dooyrt y pobble, Shoh Yeesey yn phadeyr, ta veih Nazareth ayns Galilee.

English: 12 ¶And Jesus went into the temple of God, and cast out all them that sold and bought in the temple, and overthrew the tables of the moneychangers, and the seats of them that sold doves,
Manx: As hie Yeesey stiagh ayns chiamble Yee, as deiyr Eh magh ooilley adsyn va creck as kionnaghey ayns y chiamble, as hilg Eh harrish ny buird ocsyn va caghlaa argid, as ny stuill ocsyn va creck calmaneyn.

English: 13 And said unto them, It is written, My house shall be called the house of prayer; but ye have made it a den of thieves.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Te scruit, Bee my hie’s enmyssit thie yn phadjer, agh ta shiuish er n’yannoo eh ny ooig dy vaarlee.

English: 14 And the blind and the lame came to him in the temple; and he healed them.
Manx: As haink ny doail as ny croobee huggey gys y chiamble, as ren Eh ad y lheihys.

English: 15 And when the chief priests and scribes saw the wonderful things that he did, and the children crying in the temple, and saying, Hosanna to the son of David; they were sore displeased,
Manx: As tra honnick ny ard-saggyrtyn as ny scruderyn ny reddyn yindyssagh v’eh dy yannoo, as y chloan geamagh ayns y chiamble, as gra, Hosannah gys mac Ghavid; v’ad feer jymmoosagh,

English: 16 And said unto him, Hearest thou what these say? And Jesus saith unto them, Yea; have ye never read, Out of the mouth of babes and sucklings thou hast perfected praise?
Manx: As dooyrt ad rish, Vel oo clashtyn cre t’ad shoh dy ghra? Dooyrt Yeesey roo, Ta mee; nagh lhaih shiuish rieau, Magh ass beïll oikanyn as cloan er y cheeagh t’ow er gheddyn moylley firrinagh?

English: 17 And he left them, and went out of the city into Bethany; and he lodged there.
Manx: As daag Eh ad, as hie Eh magh ass yn ard-valley gys Bethany, as ghow Eh aight ayns shen.

English: 18 ¶Now in the morning as he returned into the city, he hungered.
Manx: Nish ayns y voghrey, myr v’eh goll reesht gys yn ard-valley, v’eh accryssagh.

English: 19 And when he saw a fig tree in the way, he came to it, and found nothing thereon, but leaves only, and said unto it, Let no fruit grow on thee henceforward for ever. And presently the fig tree withered away.
Manx: As tra honnick Eh billey-figgagh er y raad, haink Eh huggey, as cha dooar Eh nhee erbee er, agh ynrycan dooillagyn, as dooyrt Eh rish, Nar aase mess erbee orts veih shoh magh er son dy bragh. As chelleeragh ren y billey figgagh fioghey ersooyl.

English: 20 And when the disciples saw it, they marvelled, saying, How soon is the fig tree withered away
Manx: As tra honnick yn vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er shoh, ghow ad yindyss, gra, Cre cha leah as ta’n billey figgagh er fioghey ersooyl?

English: 21 Jesus answered and said unto them, Verily I say unto you, If ye have faith, and doubt not, ye shall not only do this which is done to the fig tree, but also if ye shall say unto this mountain, Be thou removed, and be thou cast into the sea; it shall be done.
Manx: Dreggyr Yeesey, as dooyrt Eh roo, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, My vees credjue eu, as mannagh jean shiu dooteil, nee shiu cha nee ynrycan shoh ta jeant rish y billey-figgagh, agh my jir shiu rish y slieau shoh, Bee er dy [sic: dty] scughey, as er dy [sic: dty] hilgey ayns y cheayn; bee eh er ny yannoo.

English: 22 And all things, whatsoever ye shall ask in prayer, believing, ye shall receive.
Manx: As dy chooilley nee cre-erbee nee shiu y hirrey ayns padjer, my vees eh lesh credjue, nee shiu y gheddyn eh.

English: 23 ¶And when he was come into the temple, the chief priests and the elders of the people came unto him as he was teaching, and said, By what authority doest thou these things? and who gave thee this authority?
Manx: As tra v’eh er jeet stiagh ayns y chiamble, haink ny ard-saggyrtyn as shanstyr yn pobble huggey myr v’eh gynsaghey, gra, Cre’n phooar t’ayds dy yannoo ny reddyn shoh? as quoi hug yn phooar shoh dhyt?

English: 24 And Jesus answered and said unto them, I also will ask you one thing, which if ye tell me, I in like wise will tell you by what authority I do these things.
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh roo, Fênyms jiuish un red, as my inshys shiu dou eh, inshyms myrgeddin diuish, cre’n phooar t’aym dy yannoo ny reddyn shoh.

English: 25 The baptism of John, whence was it? from heaven, or of men? And they reasoned with themselves, saying, If we shall say, From heaven; he will say unto us, Why did ye not then believe him?
Manx: Bashtey Ean, cre-woish ve? veih niau, ny veih deiney? As loayr ad nyn mast’ oc hene, gra, My jir mad, Veih niau; jir eshyn rooin, Cre’n-fa eisht nagh chred shiu eh?

English: 26 But if we shall say, Of men; we fear the people; for all hold John as a prophet.
Manx: Agh my jir mad, Veih deiney; ta aggle ain roish y pobble; son ta dy chooilley ghooinney goaill Ean son phadeyr.

English: 27 And they answered Jesus, and said, We cannot tell. And he said unto them, Neither tell I you by what authority I do these things.
Manx: As dreggyr ad Yeesey, as dooyrt ad, Cha vel shin abyl insh. As dooyrt Eh roo, Chamoo inshyms diuish, cre’n phooar t’aym, dy yannoo ny reddyn shoh?

English: 28 ¶But what think ye? A certain man had two sons; and he came to the first, and said, Son, go work to day in my vineyard.
Manx: Agh cre ta shiu dy smooinaghtyn? Va dooinney dy row as daa vac echey, as haink Eh gys y chied vac, as dooyrt Eh, Vac, gow as obbree jiu ayns my gharey-feeney.

English: 29 He answered and said, I will not: but afterward he repented, and went.
Manx: Dreggyr eshyn, as dooyrt Eh, cha jem: agh ny lurg shen ghow Eh arrys, as hie Eh.

English: 30 And he came to the second, and said likewise. And he answered and said, I go, sir: and went not.
Manx: As haink Eh gys yn nah vac, as loayr Eh rish myrgeddin. As dreggyr eshyn, as dooyrt Eh, hem, vainshtyr; as cha jagh Eh.

English: 31 Whether of them twain did the will of his father? They say unto him, The first. Jesus saith unto them, Verily I say unto you, That the publicans and the harlots go into the kingdom of God before you.
Manx: Quoi jeu shoh ny neesht ren aigney e ayrey? Dooyrt adsyn rish, yn chied vac. Dooyrt Yeesey roo, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy jed ny publicanee as ny streebaghyn stiagh ayns reeriaght Yee reue-ish.

English: 32 For John came unto you in the way of righteousness, and ye believed him not: but the publicans and the harlots believed him: and ye, when ye had seen it, repented not afterward, that ye might believe him.
Manx: Son haink Ean hiuish ayns raad y chairys, as cha chred shiu Eh: agh chred ny publicanee as ny streebaghyn Eh. As tra honnick shiuish shoh, cha ghow shiu arrys ny lurg shen, dy voddagh shiu Eh y chredjal.

English: 33 ¶Hear another parable: There was a certain householder, which planted a vineyard, and hedged it round about, and digged a winepress in it, and built a tower, and let it out to husbandmen, and went into a far country:
Manx: Eaisht-jee rish coraa-dorraghey elley: Va far-thie dy row ren garey-feeney y hoiaghey, as ren Eh cley y mysh, as chleigh Eh press-feeney ayn, as hrog Eh toor, as hoie Eh eh rish fir-hie, as hie Eh gys cheer foddey.

English: 34 And when the time of the fruit drew near, he sent his servants to the husbandmen, that they might receive the fruits of it.
Manx: As tra va earish ny mess tayrn er-gerrey, hug Eh e ir-mooinjerey [sic] gys ny fir-hie, dy voddagh ad geddyn jeh’n mess echey.

English: 35 And the husbandmen took his servants, and beat one, and killed another, and stoned another.
Manx: As ghow ny fir-hie e ir-mooinjerey [sic], as woail ad fer, as varr ad fer elley, as chlagh ad fer elley.

English: 36 Again, he sent other servants more than the first: and they did unto them likewise.
Manx: Reesht hug Eh magh sharvaantyn elley ny sliee na’n chied eallagh: as ghell ad roosyn er yn aght cheddin.

English: 37 But last of all he sent unto them his son, saying, They will reverence my son.
Manx: Agh er-jerrey ooilley hug Eh huc e vac, gra, Bee ad arrymagh da my vac.

English: 38 But when the husbandmen saw the son, they said among themselves, This is the heir; come, let us kill him, and let us seize on his inheritance.
Manx: Agh tra honnick ny fir-hie yn mac, dooyrt ad nyn mast’ oc hene, Shoh’n eirey, tar-jee, lig dooin Eh y varroo, as bee’n eiraght echey lhien hene.

English: 39 And they caught him, and cast him out of the vineyard, and slew him.
Manx: As ghow ad Eh, as hilg ad Eh magh ass y gharey-feeney, as varr ad Eh.

English: 40 When the lord therefore of the vineyard cometh, what will he do unto those husbandmen?
Manx: Tra hig er-y-fa shen Chiarn y gharey-feeney, Cre nee Eh rish ny fir-hie shen?

English: 41 They say unto him, He will miserably destroy those wicked men, and will let out his vineyard unto other husbandmen, which shall render him the fruits in their seasons.
Manx: Dooyrt adsyn rish, stroie-ee Eh fegooish myghin ny drogh gheiney shen, as soie-ee Eh yn garey-feeney rish fir-hie elley, livrey-ys ny messyn da ayns nyn imbaghyn.

English: 42 Jesus saith unto them, Did ye never read in the scriptures, The stone which the builders rejected, the same is become the head of the corner: this is the Lord’s doing, and it is marvellous in our eyes?
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey roo, Nagh lhaih shiuish rieau ayns goo Yee, Yn chlagh ren adsyn va troggal y thie y vee-lowal, ta’n chlagh cheddin er-jeet dy ve yn ard chlagh chorneilagh: shoh jannoo yn Chiarn, as te yindyssagh ayns ny sooyllyn ainyn?

English: 43 Therefore say I unto you, The kingdom of God shall be taken from you, and given to a nation bringing forth the fruits thereof.
Manx: Shen-y-fa ta mish gra riu, Dy bee reeriaght Yee er ny ghoaill veuish, as er ny choyrt da ashoon ymmyrkys magh yn mess echey.

English: 44 And whosoever shall fall on this stone shall be broken: but on whomsoever it shall fall, it will grind him to powder.
Manx: As quoi-erbee huittys er y chlagh shen, bee Eh er ny vroo: agh quoi-erbee huittys y chlagh shen er, nee ee cha meen as joan jeh.

English: 45 And when the chief priests and Pharisees had heard his parables, they perceived that he spake of them.
Manx: As tra va ny ard-saggyrtyn as ny Phariseeyn erreish ny coraaghyn-dorraghey echey y chlashtyn, dennee ad dy nee jeusyn v’eh loayrt.

English: 46 But when they sought to lay hands on him, they feared the multitude, because they took him for a prophet.
Manx: Agh tra v’ad aignagh dy ghoaill Eh, ghow ad aggle roish y pobble, er-yn-oyr dy row ad jeeaghyn er dy ve ny adeyr.
CAB. XXII.

English: And Jesus answered and spake unto them again by parables, and said,
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey as loayr Eh roo reesht liorish coraaghyn-dorraghey, gra,

English: 2 The kingdom of heaven is like unto a certain king, which made a marriage for his son,
Manx: Ta reeriaght niau er ny hoyllaghey gys ree dy row, ren bannish son e vac,

English: 3 And sent forth his servants to call them that were bidden to the wedding: and they would not come.
Manx: As hug Eh magh e harvaantyn dy eamagh orroosyn va cuirt gys y vannish: as cha bailliu cheet.

English: 4 Again, he sent forth other servants, saying, Tell them which are bidden, Behold, I have prepared my dinner: my oxen and my fatlings are killed, and all things are ready: come unto the marriage.
Manx: Reesht hug Eh magh sharvaantyn elley, gra, Abbyr-jee roosyn ta cuirt, Cur-my-ner, ta mee er n’aarlaghey my yinnair: ta my ghew as my veiyn beiyht marroo, as dy chooilley nhee aarloo; tar-jee gys y vannish.

English: 5 But they made light of it, and went their ways, one to his farm, another to his merchandise:
Manx: Agh hoie adsyn beg jeh, as hie ad rymboo, fer gys e valley, as fer elley gys y dellal echey:

English: 6 And the remnant took his servants, and entreated them spitefully, and slew them.
Manx: As ghow yn chooid elley ny sharvaantyn echey, as ghell ad dy roonagh roo, as varr ad ad.

English: 7 But when the king heard thereof, he was wroth: and he sent forth his armies, and destroyed those murderers, and burned up their city.
Manx: Agh tra cheayll y ree jeh, v’eh jymmoosagh: as hug Eh magh e heshaghtyn-caggee, as stroie Eh ny dunveryn shen, as losht Eh yn ard-valley oc.

English: 8 Then saith he to his servants, The wedding is ready, but they which were bidden were not worthy.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Eh rish e harvaantyn, Ta’n vannish aarloo, agh y vooinjer va cuirt cha row ad feeu.

English: 9 Go ye therefore into the highways, and as many as ye shall find, bid to the marriage.
Manx: Gow-jee magh er-y-fa shen gys ny raadjyn mooarey, as whilleen as yiow shiu, cuir-jee gys y vannish.

English: 10 So those servants went out into the highways, and gathered together all as many as they found, both bad and good: and the wedding was furnished with guests.
Manx: As hie ny sharvaantyn shen magh gys ny raadjyn mooarey, as ren ad whilleen as haink nyn raad y haglym cooidjagh, chammah sie as mie: as va thie ny banshey er ny lhieeney lesh goaldee.

English: 11 ¶And when the king came in to see the guests, he saw there a man which had not on a wedding garment:
Manx: As tra haink y ree stiagh dy akin ny goaldee, honnick Eh dooinney ayns shen nagh row garmad-banshey er:

English: 12 And he saith unto him, Friend, how camest thou in hither not having a wedding garment? And he was speechless.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish, Charrey, kys haink uss stiagh ayns shoh, fegooish garmad-banshey? as cha row fockle echey dy ghra.

English: 13 Then said the king to the servants, Bind him hand and foot, and take him away, and cast him into outer darkness, there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt y ree rish ny sharvaantyn, Kiangle-jee Eh laue as cass, as gow-jee Eh ersooyl, as tilg-jee Eh ayns y dorraghys sodjey mooie: ayns vees keaney as snaggeraght feeacklyn.

English: 14 For many are called, but few are chosen.
Manx: Son ta ymmodee er nyn eam, agh beggan er nyn reih.

English: 15 ¶Then went the Pharisees, and took counsel how they might entangle him in his talk.
Manx: Eisht hie ny Phariseeyn, as hug ad nyn goyrle dy cheilley, kys oddagh ad Eh y hayrn ayns ribbeh liorish e ocklyn.

English: 16 And they sent out unto him their disciples with the Herodians, saying, Master, we know that thou art true, and teachest the way of God in truth, neither carest thou for any man: for thou regardest not the person of men.
Manx: As hug ad magh huggey shiartance jeusyn v’ad hene er n’ynsaghey marish ny Herodianee, gra, Vainshtyr, ta fys ain dy vel oo firrinagh, as dy vel oo gynsaghey raad Yee ayns firrinys, cha-moo t’ow ayns imnea roish dooinney erbee: son cha vel oo soiaghey jeh persoon deiney.

English: 17 Tell us therefore, What thinkest thou? Is it lawful to give tribute unto Caesar, or not?
Manx: Insh dooin er-y-fa shen, Cre t’ow dy smooinaghtyn, Vel eh lowal keesh y choyrt da Cesar mannagh vel?

English: 18 But Jesus perceived their wickedness, and said, Why tempt ye me, ye hypocrites?
Manx: Agh dennee Yeesey yn foalsaght oc, as dooyrt Eh, Cre’n-fa ta shiu shirrey dy my ghoaill ayns ribbeh, chrauee-oalsey?

English: 19 Shew me the tribute money. And they brought unto him a penny.
Manx: Jeeagh-jee dou argid y cheesh: as hug ad lhieu huggey ping.

English: 20 And he saith unto them, Whose is this image and superscription?
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Quoi gys ta’n jalloo as y screeu shoh bentyn?

English: 21 They say unto him, Caesar's. Then saith he unto them, Render therefore unto Caesar the things which are Caesar's; and unto God the things that are God's.
Manx: Dooyrt adsyn rish, gys Cesar. Eisht dooyrt Eh roo, Eek-jee er-y-fa shen da Cesar, ny reddyn ta lesh Cesar: as da Jee, ny reddyn ta lesh Jee.

English: 22 When they had heard these words, they marvelled, and left him, and went their way.
Manx: Tra cheayll ad shoh, ghow ad yindyss, as daag ad Eh, as hie ad rymboo.

English: 23 ¶The same day came to him the Sadducees, which say that there is no resurrection, and asked him,
Manx: Yn laa cheddin haink huggey ny Sadduceeyn, ta gra nagh vel irree-seose-reesht dy ve ayn, as dênee ad jeh,

English: 24 Saying, Master, Moses said, If a man die, having no children, his brother shall marry his wife, and raise up seed unto his brother.
Manx: Gra, Vainshtyr, ta Moses er ghra, My ta dooinney geddyn baase, fegooish cloan, dy vel e vraar dy phoosey’n ven echey, as dy hroggal seose sluight gys e vraar.

English: 25 Now there were with us seven brethren: and the first, when he had married a wife, deceased, and, having no issue, left his wife unto his brother:
Manx: Nish boyn dooinyn shiaght braaraghyn, as hooar y chied vraar, tra v’eh er phoosey ben, baase fegooish cloan, as daag Eh e ven da’n nah vraar.

English: 26 Likewise the second also, and the third, unto the seventh.
Manx: As hooar y nah vraar myrgeddin baase, as y tress, gys y chiaghtoo.

English: 27 And last of all the woman died also.
Manx: As er-jerrey ooilley hooar y ven baase myrgeddin.

English: 28 Therefore in the resurrection whose wife shall she be of the seven? for they all had her.
Manx: Shen-y-fa ec yn irree-reesht, quoi jeh’n chiaght vees ee echey son ben, son v’ee son ben daue ooilley.

English: 29 Jesus answered and said unto them, Ye do err, not knowing the scriptures, nor the power of God.
Manx: Dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh roo, Ta shiu fo marranys, as cha vel toiggal eu jeh goo, ny jeh pooar Yee.

English: 30 For in the resurrection they neither marry, nor are given in marriage, but are as the angels of God in heaven.
Manx: Son ec yn irree-reesht, cha vel ad poosey, ny er nyn goyrt ayns poosey; agh t’ad myr ainlyn Yee t’ayns niau.

English: 31 But as touching the resurrection of the dead, have ye not read that which was spoken unto you by God, saying,
Manx: Agh mychione irree-seose-reesht ny merriu, nagh vel shiu er lhaih shen va loayrit riu liorish Jee, gra,

English: 32 I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob? God is not the God of the dead, but of the living.
Manx: Mish Jee Abraham, as Jee Isaac, as Jee Yacob? cha vel Jee ny Yee jeh ny merriu, agh jeh ny bio.

English: 33 And when the multitude heard this, they were astonished at his doctrine.
Manx: As tra cheayll yn pobble shoh, ghow ad yindyss jeh’n ynsagh echey.

English: 34 ¶But when the Pharisees had heard that he had put the Sadducees to silence, they were gathered together.
Manx: Agh tra va ny Phariseeyn er chlashtyn dy row Eh er chur ny Sadduceeyn ve nyn dost, v’ad er nyn jaglym cooidjagh.

English: 35 Then one of them, which was a lawyer, asked him a question, tempting him, and saying,
Manx: As dênee fer jeu va ny er-ynsee jeh’n leigh, question jeh, er-chee y violaghey Eh, gra,

English: 36 Master, which is the great commandment in the law?
Manx: Vainshtyr, cre yn ard anney ayns y leigh?

English: 37 Jesus said unto him, Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind.
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey rish, Ver oo graih da’n Chiarn dty Yee lesh ooilley dty chree, as lesh ooilley dt’annym, as lesh ooilley dt’aigney.

English: 38 This is the first and great commandment.
Manx: Shoh yn chied as yn ard anney.

English: 39 And the second is like unto it, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself.
Manx: As ta’n nah anney casley rish, Ver oo graih da dty nahoo myr dhyt hene.

English: 40 On these two commandments hang all the law and the prophets.
Manx: Yn daa anney shoh bun y leigh as ny phadeyryn.

English: 41 ¶While the Pharisees were gathered together, Jesus asked them,
Manx: Choud as va ny Phariseeyn er nyn jaglym cooidjagh, dênee Yeesey jeu,

English: 42 Saying, What think ye of Christ? whose son is he? They say unto him, The son of David.
Manx: Gra, Cre ta shiu dy smooinaghtyn jeh Creest? quoi da mac Eh? Dooyrt adsyn rish, Mac Ghavid.

English: 43 He saith unto them, How then doth David in spirit call him Lord, saying,
Manx: Dooyrt eshyn roo, Kys eisht dy vel David liorish yn spyrryd genmyss Eh ny Hiarn, gra,

English: 44 The Lord said unto my Lord, Sit thou on my right hand, till I make thine enemies thy footstool?
Manx: Dooyrt y Chiarn rish my Hiarn’s, Soie uss er my laue yesh, derrey verrym dty noidjyn son stoyl fo dty chassyn?

English: 45 If David then call him Lord, how is he his son?
Manx: My ta David eisht genmyss Eh ny Hiarn, kys t’eh yn mac echey?

English: 46 And no man was able to answer him a word, neither durst any man from that day forth ask him any more questions.
Manx: As cha row dooinney erbee abyl fockle dy ansoor y chur da, cha-moo by-loys da dooinney erbee (veih’n laa shen magh) question erbee sodjey y ênaght jeh.
CAB. XXIII.

English: Then spake Jesus to the multitude, and to his disciples,
Manx: Eisht loayr Yeesey rish y pobble, as roosyn va sheer geiyrt er,

English: 2 Saying The scribes and the Pharisees sit in Moses’ seat:
Manx: Gra, Ta ny scruderyn as ny Phariseeyn nyn soie ayns stoyl Voses.

English: 3 All therefore whatsoever they bid you observe, that observe and do; but do not ye after their works: for they say, and do not.
Manx: Ooilley er-y-fa shen cre-erbee nee ad y oardaghey diu dy reaylley, freil-jee, as jean-jee eh; agh ny jean-jee lurg ny obbraghyn oc: son t’ad gra, as cha vel ad jannoo.

English: 4 For they bind heavy burdens and grievous to be borne, and lay them on men’s shoulders; but they themselves will not move them with one of their fingers.
Manx: Son t’ad kiangley erraghyn tromey as doillee dy ve er nyn ymmyrkey, as dyn goyrt ad er geayltyn deiney, agh cha gleashee adsyn ad hene ad lesh annane jeh ny meïr oc.

English: 5 But all their works they do for to be seen of men: they make broad their phylacteries, and enlarge the borders of their garments,
Manx: Agh ooilley nyn obbraghyn t’ad dy yannoo dy ve er nyn vakin liorish deiney: t’ad jannoo liane ny * phylactereeyn oc, as cur chemmallyn mooarey er nyn gharmadyn.
* Peeshyn dy chracknyn orroo va scruit raaghyn dy leigh Yee.

English: 6 And love the uppermost rooms at feasts, and the chief seats in the synagogues,
Manx: As shynney lhieu ny ard ynnydyn-soie y ve oc ec cuirraghyn, as ny ard stuill ayns ny kialteenyn,

English: 7 And greetings in the markets, and to be called of men, Rabbi, Rabbi.
Manx: As sleih dy vannaghey daue ayns ny margaghyn, as dy ve enmyssit liorish deiney, Rabbi, Rabbi.

English: 8 But be not ye called Rabbi: for one is your Master, even Christ; and all ye are brethren.
Manx: Agh ny bee[-]jee shiuish enmyssit Rabbi: son ta un vainshtyr eu, ta shen dy ghra, Creest, as ta shiuish ooilley nyn mraaraghyn.

English: 9 And call no man your father upon the earth: for one is your Father, which is in heaven.
Manx: As ny enmyss-jee dooinney erbee yn ayr eu er y thalloo: son ta un er ny Ayr diu ta ayns niau.

English: 10 Neither be ye called masters: for one is your Master, even Christ.
Manx: Cha-moo bee-jee enmyssit mainshtyryn, son ta un er nyn Mainshtyr, ta shen dy ghra, Creest.

English: 11 But he that is greatest among you shall be your servant.
Manx: Agh y fer syrjey nyn mast’ eu, bee Eh diu ny harvaant.

English: 12 And whosoever shall exalt himself shall be abased; and he that shall humble himself shall be exalted.
Manx: As quoi-erbee nee Eh hene y hoiaghey seose, bee Eh er ny injillaghey, as eshyn nee Eh hene y injillaghey, bee Eh er ny hoiaghey seose.

English: 13 ¶But woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! for ye shut up the kingdom of heaven against men: for ye neither go in yourselves, neither suffer ye them that are entering to go in.
Manx: Agh smerg diuish scruderyn as Phariseeyn, chrauee-oalsey; son ta shiu jeigh seose reeriaght niau noi deiney: son cha vel shiu goll stiagh shiu hene, as ta shiu dyn lhiettal adsyn ta aarloo dy gholl stiagh.

English: 14 Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! for ye devour widows’ houses, and for a pretence make long prayer: therefore ye shall receive the greater damnation.
Manx: Smerg diu scruderyn as Phariseeyn, chrauee-oalsey; son ta shiu cur mow thieyn mraane-treoghe, as lhiggey erriu dy bee shiu foddey ec padjer; shen-y-fa ta kerraghey strimmey nyn gouyr.

English: 15 Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! for ye compass sea and land to make one proselyte, and when he is made, ye make him twofold more the child of hell than yourselves.
Manx: Smerg diu scruderyn as Phariseeyn, chrauee-oalsey; son ta shiu goll mygeayrt keayn as thalloo, dy hayrn un yoarree gys y chredjue, as tra t’eh er jyndaa hiu, ta shiu dy yannoo Eh ny liannoo dy niurin gha wheesh riu hene.

English: 16 Woe unto you, ye blind guides, which say, Whosoever shall swear by the temple, it is nothing; but whosoever shall swear by the gold of the temple, he is a debtor.
Manx: Smerg diu leeideilee doal, ta gra, Quoi-erbee looys liorish y chiamble, nagh vel eh veg: agh quoi-erbee looys liorish airh y chiamble, dy negin da coontey choyrt.

English: 17 Ye fools and blind: for whether is greater, the gold, or the temple that sanctifieth the gold?
Manx: Mee-cheealagh as doal: son quoi smoo ta dy ve soit jeh, yn airh, ny’n chiamble ta casherickey yn airh?

English: 18 And, Whosoever shall swear by the altar, it is nothing; but whosoever sweareth by the gift that is upon it, he is guilty.
Manx: As quoi-erbee looys liorish yn altar, nagh vel eh veg: agh quoi-erbee looys liorish y gioot t’er yn altar, dy vel er coontey choyrt.

English: 19 Ye fools and blind: for whether is greater, the gift, or the altar that sanctifieth the gift?
Manx: Mee-cheealagh as doal: son quoi smoo ta dy ve soit jeh, yn gioot, ny’n altar ta casherickey yn gioot?

English: 20 Whoso therefore shall swear by the altar, sweareth by it, and by all things thereon.
Manx: Quoi-erbee er-y-fa shen looys liorish yn altar, t’eh loo liorish yn altar hene, as liorish dy chooilley nhee ta er.

English: 21 And whoso shall swear by the temple, sweareth by it, and by him that dwelleth therein.
Manx: As quoi-erbee looys liorish y chiamble, t’eh loo liorish y chiamble, as liorishyn ta vaghey ayn.

English: 22 And he that shall swear by heaven, sweareth by the throne of God, and by him that sitteth thereon.
Manx: As eshyn nee loo liorish niau, t’eh loo liorish stoyl-reeoil Yee, as liorishyn ta ny hoie er.

English: 23 Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! for ye pay tithe of mint and anise and cummin, and have omitted the weightier matters of the law, judgment, mercy, and faith: these ought ye to have done, and not to leave the other undone.
Manx: Smerg diu scruderyn as Phariseeyn, chrauee-oalsey; son ta shiu geeck jaghee jeh myndey, anise as cummin, agh cha vel shiu er chooilleeney currymyn s’ymmyrchee jeh’n leigh, cairys, myghin, as firrinys: ad shoh lhisagh shiu v’er n’yannoo, fegooish y chooid elley y aagail gyn jannoo.

English: 24 Ye blind guides, which strain at a gnat, and swallow a camel.
Manx: Leeideilee doal, ta carwhillag snemmey erriu, agh sluggee shiu camel.

English: 25 Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! for ye make clean the outside of the cup and of the platter, but within they are full of extortion and excess.
Manx: Smerg diu scruderyn as Phariseeyn, chrauee-oalsey; son ta shiu glenney yn cappan as y claare er cheu-mooie, agh cheu-sthie t’ad laane dy hranlaase as dy neu-heeltys.

English: 26 Thou blind Pharisee, cleanse first that which is within the cup and platter, that the outside of them may be clean also.
Manx: Pharisee doal, glen hoshiaght shen ny ta cheu-sthie jeh’n chappan as jeh’n chlaare, dy vod yn cheu-mooie oc ve glen myrgeddin.

English: 27 Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! for ye are like unto whited sepulchres, which indeed appear beautiful outward, but are within full of dead men’s bones, and of all uncleanness.
Manx: Smerg diu scruderyn as Phariseeyn, chrauee-oalsey; son ta shiu goll-rish oaiaghyn t’er nyn yiallaghey, ta dy jarroo jeeaghyn aalin er cheu-mooie, agh cheu-sthie t’ad laane dy chraueyn ny merriu, as jeh dy chooilley vroid.

English: 28 Even so ye also outwardly appear righteous unto men, but within ye are full of hypocrisy and iniquity.
Manx: Shen myr ta shiuish neesht er cheu-mooie cairagh ayns shilley deiney, agh cheu-sthie ta shiu laane dy chraueeaght-oalsey as dy vee-chairys.

English: 29 Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! because ye build the tombs of the prophets, and garnish the sepulchres of the righteous,
Manx: Smerg diu scruderyn as Phariseeyn, chrauee-oalsey; er-y-fa dy vel shiu troggal oaiaghyn ny phadeyryn, as soiaghey magh lhiaghtyn ny deiney cairagh.

English: 30 And say, If we had been in the days of our fathers, we would not have been partakers with them in the blood of the prophets.
Manx: As gra, Dy beagh shinyn er ve ayns laghyn nyn ayraghyn, cha beagh shin er ve nyn baarteeasyn maroosyn ayns fuill ny phadeyryn.

English: 31 Wherefore ye be witnesses unto yourselves, that ye are the children of them which killed the prophets.
Manx: Shen-y-fa ta shiu nyn veanishyn diu hene, dy nee yn chloan ocsyn shiu ren ny phadeyryn y varroo.

English: 32 Fill ye up then the measure of your fathers.
Manx: Lhieen-jee seose eisht towse nyn ayraghyn.

English: 33 Ye serpents, ye generation of vipers, how can ye escape the damnation of hell?
Manx: Shiuish ard-nieughyn, sheeloghe dy ard-nieughyn, kys oddys shiu kerraghey niurin y scapail?

English: 34 ¶Wherefore, behold, I send unto you prophets, and wise men, and scribes: and some of them ye shall kill and crucify; and some of them shall ye scourge in your synagogues, and persecute them from city to city:
Manx: Shen-y-fa, cur-my-ner, ta mish coyrt hiu phadeyryn, as deiney creeney, as screeuderyn; as paart jeu nee shiu y varroo as y chrossey, as paart jeu nee shiu y chustey ayns ny quaiyllyn eu, as tranlaase y yannoo orroo veih ard-valley gys ard-valley:

English: 35 That upon you may come all the righteous blood shed upon the earth, from the blood of righteous Abel unto the blood of Zacharias son of Barachias, whom ye slew between the temple and the altar.
Manx: Dy vod ooilley yn uill chairagh hie er deayrtey er y thalloo tuittym erriu, veih fuill Abel cairagh, gys fuill Zecharias, mac Barachias, Eh ren shiu y varroo eddyr y chiamble as yn altar.

English: 36 Verily I say unto you, All these things shall come upon this generation.
Manx: Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Dy jig dy chooilley nhee jeu shoh er y cheeloghe shoh.

English: 37 O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, thou that killest the prophets, and stonest them which are sent unto thee, how often would I have gathered thy children together, even as a hen gathereth her chickens under her wings, and ye would not!
Manx: O Yerusalem, Yerusalem, uss ta marroo ny phadeyryn, as dyn glaghey adsyn t’er nyn goyrt er chag[h]teraght hood, cre cha mennick as va mish booiagh v’er haglym dty chloan cooidjagh, ’naght myr ta kiark goaill stiagh e hein fo my skainyn, as cha nee yn aigney eu ve!

English: 38 Behold, your house is left unto you desolate.
Manx: Cur-my-ner, ta’n thie eu faagit diu treigit.

English: 39 For I say unto you, Ye shall not see me henceforth, till ye shall say, Blessed is he that cometh in the name of the Lord.
Manx: Son ta mee gra riu, Nagh vaik shiu mish ny yei shoh, derrey jir shiu, Bannit ta eshyn ta cheet ayns ennym y Chiarn.
CAB. XXIV.

English: And Jesus went out, and departed from the temple; and his disciples came to him for to shew him the buildings of the temple.
Manx: As hie Yeesey magh as jimmee Eh veih’n chiamble; as haink y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er huggey dy chur shilley da jeh stooamit y chiamble.

English: 2 And Jesus said unto them, See ye not all these things? verily I say unto you, There shall not be left here one stone upon another, that shall not be thrown down.
Manx: As dooyrt Yeesey roo, Nagh vaik shiu ooilley ny reddyn shoh? dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Nagh bee faagit un chlagh er clagh elley, nagh bee er ny hilgey sheese.

English: 3 ¶And as he sat upon the mount of Olives, the disciples came unto him privately, saying, Tell us, when shall these things be? and what shall be the sign of thy coming, and of the end of the world?
Manx: As myr v’eh ny hoie er cronck ny Oliveyn, haink y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er huggey er-lheh, gra, Insh dooin, cooin vees ny reddyn shoh? as cre’n cowrey vees jeh’n cheet ayd, as jeh jerrey’n theihll?

English: 4 And Jesus answered and said unto them, Take heed that no man deceive you.
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh roo, Cur-jee twoaie nagh moll dooinney erbee shiu.

English: 5 For many shall come in my name, saying, I am Christ; and shall deceive many.
Manx: Son hig ymmodee ayns m’ennyms[,] gra, Mish Creest: as nee ad ymmodee y volley.

English: 6 And ye shall hear of wars and rumours of wars: see that ye be not troubled: for all these things must come to pass, but the end is not yet.
Manx: As clinnee shiu jeh caggaghyn, as jeh imraaghyn dy chaggaghyn: jeeagh nagh bee shiu seaghnit: son shegin da dy chooilley nhee jeu shoh cheet gys kione, agh cha bee yn jerrey foast.

English: 7 For nation shall rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom: and there shall be famines, and pestilences, and earthquakes, in divers places.
Manx: Son irree ashoon noi ashoon, as reeriaght noi reeriaght: as bee gennaghyn, as crampyn, as craaghyn-thallooin ayns ymmodee ynnydyn.

English: 8 All these are the beginning of sorrows.
Manx: Bee ooilley shoh toshiaght trimshey.

English: 9 Then shall they deliver you up to be afflicted, and shall kill you: and ye shall be hated of all nations for my name's sake.
Manx: Eisht livreyee ad shiu seose dy ve seaghnit, as marree ad shiu: as bee feoh ec dy chooilley ashoon erriu er coontey yn ennym aym’s.

English: 10 And then shall many be offended, and shall betray one another, and shall hate one another.
Manx: As eisht gowee ymmodee oyr dy huittym [veih’n Chredjue,] as brahee ad, as ver ad feoh yn derrey yeh da’n jeh elley.

English: 11 And many false prophets shall rise, and shall deceive many.
Manx: As nee ymmodee phadeyryn foalsey girree seose, as ymmodee y volley.

English: 12 And because iniquity shall abound, the love of many shall wax cold.
Manx: As er-yn-oyr dy jean olkys bishaghey, nee graih ymmodee feayraghey.

English: 13 But he that shall endure unto the end, the same shall be saved.
Manx: Agh bee eshyn, nee tannaghtyn firrinagh gys y jerrey, er ny hauail.

English: 14 And this gospel of the kingdom shall be preached in all the world for a witness unto all nations; and then shall the end come.
Manx: As bee sushtal yn reeriaght er ny phreacheil ayns ooilley’n seihll, son feanish da dy chooilley ashoon, as eisht nee yn jerrey cheet.

English: 15 When ye therefore shall see the abomination of desolation, spoken of by Daniel the prophet, stand in the holy place, (whoso readeth, let him understand:)
Manx: Tra hee shiu er-y-fa shen eajeeid yn traartys, ta loayrit jeh liorish Daniel yn phadeyr, ny hassoo ayns yn ynnyd casherick, (eshyn ta lhaih, lig da tastey ghoaill)

English: 16 Then let them which be in Judaea flee into the mountains:
Manx: Eisht lig dauesyn t’ayns Judea, roih gys ny sleityn.

English: 17 Let him which is on the housetop not come down to take any thing out of his house:
Manx: Eshyn t’er mullagh y thie, ny lig da cheet neose dy ghoaill nhee erbee ass e hie:

English: 18 Neither let him which is in the field return back to take his clothes.
Manx: As ny lig dasyn t’ayns y vagher chyndaa back, dy chur lesh e eaddagh.

English: 19 And woe unto them that are with child, and to them that give suck in those days
Manx: As smerg dauesyn ta torragh, as dauesyn ta cur keeagh ayns ny laghyn shen.

English: 20 But pray ye that your flight be not in the winter, neither on the sabbath day:
Manx: Agh guee-jee shiu nagh bee yn roih eu er-chea ayns y yeurey, ny er y doonaght.

English: 21 For then shall be great tribulation, such as was not since the beginning of the world to this time, no, nor ever shall be.
Manx: Son bee seaghyn mooar ec y traa shen, leid as nagh row er dy hoshiaght y theihll gys yn earish shoh, as leid as nagh bee arragh dy bragh.

English: 22 And except those days should be shortened, there should no flesh be saved: but for the elect’s sake those days shall be shortened.
Manx: As mannagh beagh ny laghyn shen dy-leah ec kione, cha beagh feill erbee er ny hauail: agh er graih yn chloan reiht, bee ny laghyn shen dy-leah ec kione.

English: 23 Then if any man shall say unto you, Lo, here is Christ, or there; believe it not.
Manx: Eisht my jir dooinney erbee riu, Cur-my-ner, ta Creest ayns shoh, ny ayns shid; ny creid[-]jee eh.

English: 24 For there shall arise false Christs, and false prophets, and shall shew great signs and wonders; insomuch that, if it were possible, they shall deceive the very elect.
Manx: Son nee Creestyn foalsey, as phadeyryn foalsey girree, as cowraghyn mooarey as yindyssyn y hoilshaghey, ayns wheesh as dy mollagh ad (dy beagh eh possible) yn eer chloan reiht.

English: 25 Behold, I have told you before.
Manx: Cur-my-ner, ta mish er n’insh diu ro-laue.

English: 26 Wherefore if they shall say unto you, Behold, he is in the desert; go not forth: behold, he is in the secret chambers; believe it not.
Manx: Shen-y-fa my jir ad riu, T’eh ayns yn aasagh, ny gow-jee magh: cur-my-ner, t’eh ayns ny shamyryn follit, ny creid-jee eh.

English: 27 For as the lightning cometh out of the east, and shineth even unto the west; so shall also the coming of the Son of man be.
Manx: Son myr ta’n tendeil cheet ass y shar, as cur soilshey choud as gys y sheear: myr shen myrgeddin vees cheet yn Mac dooinney.

English: 28 For wheresoever the carcase is, there will the eagles be gathered together.
Manx: Son raad erbee dy bee yn corp, ayns shen vees ny urlee er nyn jaglym cooidjagh.

English: 29 ¶Immediately after the tribulation of those days shall the sun be darkened, and the moon shall not give her light, and the stars shall fall from heaven, and the powers of the heavens shall be shaken:
Manx: Chelleeragh lurg seaghyn ny laghyn shen, aasee yn ghrian dorraghey, cha der yn aist e soilshey, as tuittee rollaageyn yn aer, as bee pooaraghyn yn aer er nyn graa.

English: 30 And then shall appear the sign of the Son of man in heaven: and then shall all the tribes of the earth mourn, and they shall see the Son of man coming in the clouds of heaven with power and great glory.
Manx: As eisht bee cowrey jeh’n Mac dooinney er ny akin ayns yn aer: as ec y traa shen nee ooilley sheelogheyn y thallooin dobberan, as hee ad yn Mac dooinney cheet ayns bodjallyn yn aer, lesh pooar as gloyr vooar.

English: 31 And he shall send his angels with a great sound of a trumpet, and they shall gather together his elect from the four winds, from one end of heaven to the other.
Manx: As ver Eh magh e ainlyn lesh feiyr mooar cayrn, as nee ad e chloan reiht y haglym cooidjagh veih ny kiare geayghyn, veih’n derrey chione jeh’n aer gys y chione elley.

English: 32 Now learn a parable of the fig tree; When his branch is yet tender, and putteth forth leaves, ye know that summer is nigh:
Manx: Ynsee-jee eisht coraa-dorraghey jeh’n billey figgagh: tra ta’n banglane echey foast oor, as cur magh duillagyn, ta fys eu dy vel y sourey er-gerrey.

English: 33 So likewise ye, when ye shall see all these things, know that it is near, even at the doors.
Manx: Myr shen myrgeddin shiuish, tra hee shiu ooilley ny reddyn shoh, toig-gee [sic: ‑jee] dy vel eh ergerrey, dy jarroo ec ny dorryssyn.

English: 34 Verily I say unto you, This generation shall not pass, till all these things be fulfilled.
Manx: Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, roish my vow yn cheeloghe shoh baase, dy bee dy chooilley nhee jeu shoh cooilleenit.

English: 35 Heaven and earth shall pass away, but my words shall not pass away.
Manx: Nee niau as thalloo cherraghtyn, agh my ghoan’s cha jean cherraghtyn.

English: 36 ¶But of that day and hour knoweth no man, no, not the angels of heaven, but my Father only.
Manx: Agh er y laa as yn oor shen, cha vel fys ec dooinney erbee, ny ec ainlyn niau, agh ec my Ayr ny lomarcan.

English: 37 But as the days of Noe were, so shall also the coming of the Son of man be.
Manx: Agh myr va laghyn Noe, myr shen myrgeddin vees cheet yn Mac dooinney.

English: 38 For as in the days that were before the flood they were eating and drinking, marrying and giving in marriage, until the day that Noe entered into the ark,
Manx: Son myr ayns ny laghyn va roish y thooilley, v’ad gee as giu, poosey as coyrt ayns poosey, derrey’n laa hie Noe stiagh ayns yn arg,

English: 39 And knew not until the flood came, and took them all away; so shall also the coming of the Son of man be.
Manx: As cha dug ad tastey, derrey haink y thooilley as ghow eh ad ooilley ersooyl; myr shen myrgeddin vees cheet yn Mac dooinney.

English: 40 Then shall two be in the field; the one shall be taken, and the other left.
Manx: Shen y traa vees jees ayns y vagher, bee yn derrey yeh goit, as y jeh elley faagit.

English: 41 Two women shall be grinding at the mill; the one shall be taken, and the other left.
Manx: Bee daa ven blieh ec y wyllyn, yn derrey yeh goit, as y jeh elley faagit.

English: 42 ¶Watch therefore: for ye know not what hour your Lord doth come.
Manx: Bee-jee er nyn dwoaie er-y-fa shen, son cha vel fys eu er oor cheet nyn Jiarn.

English: 43 But know this, that if the goodman of the house had known in what watch the thief would come, he would have watched, and would not have suffered his house to be broken up.
Manx: Agh shoh toig-jee, dy beagh fys er ve ec mainshtyr y thie cre’n oor veagh y maarlagh er jeet, veagh Eh er e arrey, as cha beagh Eh er lhiggey da e hie y vrishey stiagh.

English: 44 Therefore be ye also ready: for in such an hour as ye think not the Son of man cometh.
Manx: Shen-y-fa bee-jee shiuish myrgeddin arrloo [sic]: son ec leid yn oor as nagh vel shiu smooinaghtyn er, hig yn Mac dooinney.

English: 45 Who then is a faithful and wise servant, whom his lord hath made ruler over his household, to give them meat in due season?
Manx: Quoi eisht yn charvaant firrinagh as creeney, ta e Hiarn er n’yannoo ny er-reil er e hie, dy chur daue nyn meaghey ayns traa cooie?

English: 46 Blessed is that servant, whom his lord when he cometh shall find so doing.
Manx: Bannit ta’n charvaant shen, yiow e Hiarn jannoo myr shen, ec y cheet echey.

English: 47 Verily I say unto you, That he shall make him ruler over all his goods.
Manx: Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy livrey Eh dys y churrym echey ooilley e chooid.

English: 48 But and if that evil servant shall say in his heart, My lord delayeth his coming;
Manx: Agh my jir y drogh harvaant shen ayns e chree, Ta my Hiarn lhiggey-shiaghey yn cheet echey,

English: 49 And shall begin to smite his fellowservants, and to eat and drink with the drunken;
Manx: As toshiaght y yannoo dy woalley e heshaghyn-harvaant [sic], as dy ee as dy iu marish y vooinjer veshtal:

English: 50 The lord of that servant shall come in a day when he looketh not for him, and in an hour that he is not aware of,
Manx: Hig Chiarn y charvaant shen ec laa nagh bee Eh jeeaghyn er y hon, as ayns oor nagh bee Eh twoaiagh jeh;

English: 51 And shall cut him asunder, and appoint him his portion with the hypocrites: there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
Manx: As giaree Eh Eh veih my chielley, as pointee Eh e chronney marish ny crauee-oalsey: ayns shen vees keaney as snaggeraght feeacklyn.
CAB. XXV.

English: Then shall the kingdom of heaven be likened unto ten virgins, which took their lamps, and went forth to meet the bridegroom.
Manx: Eisht bee reeriaght niau er ny hoyllaghey gys jeih moidynyn, ghow ny lampyn oc, as hie magh quail y dooinney phoosee [sic].

English: 2 And five of them were wise, and five were foolish.
Manx: As va queig jeu creeney, as queig ommijagh.

English: 3 They that were foolish took their lamps, and took no oil with them:
Manx: Hug adsyn va ommijagh lhieu ny lampyn oc, agh cha dug ad lhieu ooil mâroo:

English: 4 But the wise took oil in their vessels with their lamps.
Manx: Agh hug y vooinjer chreeney lhieu ooil ayns ny siyn oc marish nyn lampyn.

English: 5 While the bridegroom tarried, they all slumbered and slept.
Manx: Choud as v’ad feeau er y dooinney phoosee, huit ad ooilley er saveenagh as cadley.

English: 6 And at midnight there was a cry made, Behold, the bridegroom cometh; go ye out to meet him.
Manx: As ec main-oie va eam er ny choyrt, Cur-my-ner, ta’n dooinney-phoosee cheet, gow-jee magh ny whail.

English: 7 Then all those virgins arose, and trimmed their lamps.
Manx: Eisht dirree ooilley ny moidynyn shen, as hooar ad aarloo nyn lampyn.

English: 8 And the foolish said unto the wise, Give us of your oil; for our lamps are gone out.
Manx: As dooyrt y vooinjer ommijagh roosyn va creeney, Cur-jee dooinyn jeh’n ooil eauish, son ta lampyn ain goll ass.

English: 9 But the wise answered, saying, Not so; lest there be not enough for us and you: but go ye rather to them that sell, and buy for yourselves.
Manx: Agh dreggyr y vooinjer chreeney, gra, Cha jean; er aggle nagh bee dy liooar ain dooin hene as diuish neesht: te ny share diu roih dys y vooinjer ta creck, as kionnaghey er nyn son hene.

English: 10 And while they went to buy, the bridegroom came; and they that were ready went in with him to the marriage: and the door was shut.
Manx: As choud as v’ad goll dy chionnaghey, haink y dooinney-phoosee, as hie yn vooinjer va aarloo stiagh marish gys y vannish, as va’n dorrys jeight.

English: 11 Afterward came also the other virgins, saying, Lord, Lord, open to us.
Manx: Ny lurg shen haink ny moidynyn elley, gra, Hiarn, Hiarn, foshil dooin.

English: 12 But he answered and said, Verily I say unto you, I know you not.
Manx: Agh dreggyr eshyn as dooyrt Eh, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, nagh voddym goaill riu.

English: 13 Watch therefore, for ye know neither the day nor the hour wherein the Son of man cometh.
Manx: Bee-jee er nyn dwoaie er-y-fa shen, son cha vel fys eu er y laa ny’n oor, nee yn Mac dooinney cheet.

English: 14 ¶For the kingdom of heaven is as a man travelling into a far country, who called his own servants, and delivered unto them his goods.
Manx: Son ta reeriaght niau myr dooinney va goll er troailt gys cheer foddey, deïe er e harvaantyn hene, as livrey Eh daue e chooid:

English: 15 And unto one he gave five talents, to another two, and to another one; to every man according to his several ability; and straightway took his journey.
Manx: As da fer jeu hug Eh queig talentyn, da fer elley jees, as da fer elley annane, da dy chooilley ghooinney lurg roshtyn e hushtey, as chelleeragh ghow Eh e yurnah.

English: 16 Then he that had received the five talents went and traded with the same, and made them other five talents.
Manx: Eisht hie yn fer v’er gheddyn ny queig talentyn, as ren Eh dellal lhieu, as chosne Eh queig talentyn elley.

English: 17 And likewise he that had received two, he also gained other two.
Manx: As myr shen eshyn v’er gheddyn jees, chosne eshyn myrgeddin jees elley.

English: 18 But he that had received one went and digged in the earth, and hid his lord's money.
Manx: Agh y fer v’er gheddyn annane, hie Eh as chley Eh ayns y thalloo, as dollee Eh argid e hiarn.

English: 19 After a long time the lord of those servants cometh, and reckoneth with them.
Manx: Agh lurg foddey dy earish haink chiarn ny sharvaantyn shen, as ren Eh coontey roo.

English: 20 And so he that had received five talents came and brought other five talents, saying, Lord, thou deliveredst unto me five talents: behold, I have gained beside them five talents more.
Manx: As haink eshyn v’er gheddyn ny queig talentyn, as hug Eh lesh queig talentyn elley, gra, Hiarn, livrey uss dooys queig talentyn: cur-my-ner, ta mee er chosney queig talentyn elley mârroo.

English: 21 His lord said unto him, Well done, thou good and faithful servant: thou hast been faithful over a few things, I will make thee ruler over many things: enter thou into the joy of thy lord.
Manx: Dooyrt e hiarn rish, S’mie t’ow er n’yannoo, harvaant vie as firrinagh; t’ow er ny ve firrinagh ayns y veggan, livreyms mooarane gys dty churrym: gow stiagh gys boggey dty hiarn.

English: 22 He also that had received two talents came and said, Lord, thou deliveredst unto me two talents: behold, I have gained two other talents beside them.
Manx: Haink eshyn myrgeddin v’er gheddyn yn daa halent, as dooyrt eh, Hiarn, livrey uss dooys daa halent: cur-my-ner, ta mee er chosney daa halent elley mâroo.

English: 23 His lord said unto him, Well done, good and faithful servant; thou hast been faithful over a few things, I will make thee ruler over many things: enter thou into the joy of thy lord.
Manx: Dooyrt e hiarn rish, S’mie t’ow er n’yannoo, harvaant vie as firrinagh: t’ow er ny ve firrinagh ayns y veggan, livreyms mooarane gys dty churrym: gow stiagh gys boggey dty hiarn.

English: 24 Then he which had received the one talent came and said, Lord, I knew thee that thou art an hard man, reaping where thou hast not sown, and gathering where thou hast not strawed:
Manx: Agh y fer v’er gheddyn yn un talent, haink Eh as dooyrt eh, Hiarn, va fys aym’s dy nee dooinney creoi oo; buinn raad nagh ren oo cuirr, as chaglym raad nagh ren oo skeayley:

English: 25 And I was afraid, and went and hid thy talent in the earth: lo, there thou hast that is thine.
Manx: As ghow mee aggle, as hie mee as dollee mee dty halent ayns y thalloo: cur-my-ner, shen y raad ta dty chooid.

English: 26 His lord answered and said unto him, Thou wicked and slothful servant, thou knewest that I reap where I sowed not, and gather where I have not strawed:
Manx: Dreggyr e hiarn, as dooyrt Eh rish, Harvaant vee-chairagh as neu-harroogh, va fys ayds dy row mish buinn raad nagh ren mee cuirr, as chaglym raad nagh ren mee skeayley:

English: 27 Thou oughtest therefore to have put my money to the exchangers, and then at my coming I should have received mine own with usury.
Manx: Lhisagh oo er-y-fa shen v’er chur my argid dauesyn ta jannoo vondeish liorish argid y yeeasaght, as eisht ec y cheet aym, oddin v’er gheddyn my chooid hene lesh bishaghey.

English: 28 Take therefore the talent from him, and give it unto him which hath ten talents.
Manx: Gow-jee er-y-fa shen yn talent veih, as cur-jee eh dasyn ta jeih talentyn echey.

English: 29 For unto every one that hath shall be given, and he shall have abundance: but from him that hath not shall be taken away even that which he hath.
Manx: Son da dy chooilley annane ta echey, vees er ny choyrt, as bee towse smoo echey: agh veihsyn nagh vel echey vees er ny ghoaill ersooyl shen ny ta echey.

English: 30 And cast ye the unprofitable servant into outer darkness: there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
Manx: As tilg-jee yn charvaant neu-harroogh ayns y dorraghys sodjey mooie: ayns shen vees keaney as snaggeraght feeacklyn.

English: 31 ¶When the Son of man shall come in his glory, and all the holy angels with him, then shall he sit upon the throne of his glory:
Manx: Tra hig yn Mac dooinney ayns e ghloyr, as ooilley e ainlyn casherick marish, shen y traa hoieys Eh er stoyl-reeoil e ghloyr.

English: 32 And before him shall be gathered all nations: and he shall separate them one from another, as a shepherd divideth his sheep from the goats:
Manx: As kiongoyrt rish vees dy chooilley ashoon er nyn jaglym; as scarree Eh ad veih my chielley, myr ta bochilley cur scarrey eddyr e chirree as ny goair:

English: 33 And he shall set the sheep on his right hand, but the goats on the left.
Manx: As soie-ee Eh ny kirree er e laue yesh, agh ny goair er e laue chiare.

English: 34 Then shall the King say unto them on his right hand, Come, ye blessed of my Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world:
Manx: Eisht jir y Ree roosyn er e laue yesh, Tar-jee my chloan bannit jeh my Ayr, gow-jee myr eiraght yn reeriaght ta kiarit diu er ny son eu er dy hoshiaght y theihll.

English: 35 For I was an hungred, and ye gave me meat: I was thirsty, and ye gave me drink: I was a stranger, and ye took me in:
Manx: Son va mee accryssagh, as hug shiu beaghey dou: va mee paagh, as hug shiu jough dou: va mee my yoarree, as ghow shiu stiagh mee:

English: 36 Naked, and ye clothed me: I was sick, and ye visited me: I was in prison, and ye came unto me.
Manx: Rooisht, as ren shiu my choamrey: va mee ching, as haink shiu dy my yeeaghyn: va mee ayns pryssoon, as haink shiu hym.

English: 37 Then shall the righteous answer him, saying, Lord, when saw we thee an hungred, and fed thee? or thirsty, and gave thee drink?
Manx: Eisht nee yn chloan chairagh Eh y reggyrt, gra, Hiarn, cooin honnick shin oo accryssagh, as dy dug shin beaghey dhyt? ny paagh, as dy dug shin jough dhyt?

English: 38 When saw we thee a stranger, and took thee in? or naked, and clothed thee?
Manx: Cooin honnick shin oo dy [sic: dty] yoarree, as dy ghow shin stiagh oo? ny rooisht as dy ren shin dty choamrey?

English: 39 Or when saw we thee sick, or in prison, and came unto thee?
Manx: Ny cooin honnick shin oo ching, ny ayns pryssoon, as dy daink shin dy dty yeeaghyn?

English: 40 And the King shall answer and say unto them, Verily I say unto you, Inasmuch as ye have done it unto one of the least of these my brethren, ye have done it unto me.
Manx: As freggyr-ee yn Ree, as jir Eh roo, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Ayns wheesh as dy vel shiu er n’yannoo eh son y fer sloo jeu shoh jeu shoh my vraaraghyn, ta shiu er n’yannoo eh er my hon’s.

English: 41 Then shall he say also unto them on the left hand, Depart from me, ye cursed, into everlasting fire, prepared for the devil and his angels:
Manx: Eisht jir Eh roosyn myrgeddin er y laue chiare, Immee-jee voym, chloan chursit gys yn aile dy bragh farraghtyn, kiarit son y drogh-spyrryd as e ainlyn.

English: 42 For I was an hungred, and ye gave me no meat: I was thirsty, and ye gave me no drink:
Manx: Son va mee accryssagh, as cha dug shiu beaghey dou: va mee paagh, as cha dug shiu jough dou:

English: 43 I was a stranger, and ye took me not in: naked, and ye clothed me not: sick, and in prison, and ye visited me not.
Manx: Va mee my yoarree, as cha ghow shiu stiagh mee: rooisht, as cha ren shiu my choamrey: ching, as ayns pryssoon, as cha daink shiu dy my yeeaghyn.

English: 44 Then shall they also answer him, saying, Lord, when saw we thee an hungred, or athirst, or a stranger, or naked, or sick, or in prison, and did not minister unto thee?
Manx: Eisht nee adsyn myrgeddin Eh y reggyrt, gra, Hiarn, cooin honnick shin oo accryssagh, ny paagh, ny dy [sic: dty] yoarree, ny rooisht, ny ching, ny ayns pryssoon, as nagh chooin shin lhiat?

English: 45 Then shall he answer them, saying, Verily I say unto you, Inasmuch as ye did it not to one of the least of these, ye did it not to me.
Manx: Eisht nee Eh nyn vreggyrt ad, gra, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Ayns wheesh as nagh ren shiu eh son annane jeh’n vooinjer sloo jeu shoh, cha ren shiu eh er my hon’s.

English: 46 And these shall go away into everlasting punishment: but the righteous into life eternal.
Manx: As hed ad shoh ersooyl gys y kerraghey dy bragh farraghtyn: agh y chloan chairagh gys y vea veayn.
CAB. XXVI.

English: And it came to pass, when Jesus had finished all these sayings, he said unto his disciples,
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, tra va Yeesey erreish ooilley ny goan shoh y loayrt, dy dooyrt Eh roosyn va sheer geiyrt er,

English: 2 Ye know that after two days is the feast of the passover, and the Son of man is betrayed to be crucified.
