Manx: Ta fys eu lurg daa laa dy vel feailley ny caisht dy ve ayn, as dy vel yn Mac dooinney er ny vrah dy ve er ny chrossey.

English: 3 Then assembled together the chief priests, and the scribes, and the elders of the people, unto the palace of the high priest, who was called Caiaphas,
Manx: Eisht va ny ard-saggyrtyn as ny scruderyn as shanstyr y pobble er nyn jaglym cooidjagh gys thie yn ard-saggyrt va enmyssit Caiaphas,

English: 4 And consulted that they might take Jesus by subtilty, and kill him.
Manx: As hug ad nyn goyrle dy-cheilley, mychione Yeesey y ghoaill dy follit, as y choyrt Eh gy baase.

English: 5 But they said, Not on the feast day, lest there be an uproar among the people.
Manx: Agh dooyrt ad, cha nee er laa yn eailley, er aggle dy bee irree-magh ayn mastey yn pobble.

English: 6 ¶Now when Jesus was in Bethany, in the house of Simon the leper,
Manx: Nish tra va Yeesey ayns Bethany, ayns thie Simon yn louraane,

English: 7 There came unto him a woman having an alabaster box of very precious ointment, and poured it on his head, as he sat at meat.
Manx: Haink huggey ben as box alabaster dy ooill feer deyr eck, as gheayrt ee eh er y chione echey, myr v’eh ny hoie ec bee.

English: 8 But when his disciples saw it, they had indignation, saying, To what purpose is this waste?
Manx: Agh tra honnick y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er shoh, v’ad jymmo[o]sagh, gra, Cre’n-fa va’n jummal shoh jeant?

English: 9 For this ointment might have been sold for much, and given to the poor.
Manx: Son oddagh yn ooill shoh v’er ny ve creckit son mooarane, as er ny choyrt da ny boghtyn.

English: 10 When Jesus understood it, he said unto them, Why trouble ye the woman? for she hath wrought a good work upon me.
Manx: Tra hoig Yeesey shoh, dooyrt Eh roo, Kys dy vel shiu boirey yn ven? son t’ee er n’obbraghey obbyr vie orrym’s.

English: 11 For ye have the poor always with you; but me ye have not always.
Manx: Son ta ny boghtyn eu kinjagh mêriu, agh mish cha vel eu kinjagh.

English: 12 For in that she hath poured this ointment on my body, she did it for my burial.
Manx: Son liorish dy vel ee er gheayrtey yn ooill shoh er my chorp, t’ee er n’yannoo eh gouyr my oanluckey.

English: 13 Verily I say unto you, Wheresoever this gospel shall be preached in the whole world, there shall also this, that this woman hath done, be told for a memorial of her.
Manx: Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Raad erbee dy bee yn sushtal shoh er ny phreacheil ayns ooilley’n theihll, bee shoh myrgeddin ta’n ven shoh er n’yannoo, er ny insh son cooinaghtyn jee.

English: 14 ¶Then one of the twelve, called Judas Iscariot, went unto the chief priests,
Manx: Eisht hie fer jeh’n daa ostyl yeig, va enmyssit Yuaase Iscariot, gys ny ard saggyrtyn,

English: 15 And said unto them, What will ye give me, and I will deliver him unto you? And they covenanted with him for thirty pieces of silver.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Cre ver shiu dooys, as livrey’m Eh hiu? As ren ad conaant rish son jeih peeshyn as feed dy argid.

English: 16 And from that time he sought opportunity to betray him.
Manx: As veih’n traa shen v’eh shirrey caa dy vrah eh.

English: 17 ¶Now the first day of the feast of unleavened bread the disciples came to Jesus, saying unto him, Where wilt thou that we prepare for thee to eat the passover?
Manx: Nish er y chied laa jeh feailley yn arran millish, haink y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er Yeesey huggey, as dooyrt ad rish, Cre’n raad sailt shin dy yannoo aarloo er dy [sic: dty] hon dy ee yn Eayn caisht?

English: 18 And he said, Go into the city to such a man, and say unto him, The Master saith, My time is at hand; I will keep the passover at thy house with my disciples.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Gow-jee gys yn ard-valley gys leid y dooinney shen, as abyr-jee rish, Ta’n mainshtyr gra, Ta my hraa ec laue, freill-ym y chaisht ec dty hie’s marish y vooinjer ta sheer geiyrt orrym.

English: 19 And the disciples did as Jesus had appointed them; and they made ready the passover.
Manx: As ren adsyn myr va Yeesey er n’oardaghey daue, as daarlee ad yn Eayn caisht.

English: 20 Now when the even was come, he sat down with the twelve.
Manx: Nish tra va’n fastyr er-jeet, hoie Eh sheese marish yn daa ostyl yeig.

English: 21 And as they did eat, he said, Verily I say unto you, that one of you shall betray me.
Manx: As myr v’ad gee, dooyrt Eh, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy jean annane eauish mish y vrah.

English: 22 And they were exceeding sorrowful, and began every one of them to say unto him, Lord, is it I?
Manx: As v’ad feer trimshagh, as ren ad toshiaght dy chooilley annane oc dy ghra rish, Hiarn, nee orryms t’ow cheet?

English: 23 And he answered and said, He that dippeth his hand with me in the dish, the same shall betray me.
Manx: As dansoor eshyn, gra, Eshyn ta thummey e laue mârym ayns y chlaare, Eh shen nee mee y vrah.

English: 24 The Son of man goeth as it is written of him: but woe unto that man by whom the Son of man is betrayed! it had been good for that man if he had not been born.
Manx: Ta’n Mac dooinney goll, myr te scruit jeh: agh smerg da’n dooinney shen liorish vees yn Mac dooinney er ny vrah: veagh eh er ny ve mie son y dooinney shen, mannagh beagh Eh jeet er y theihll.

English: 25 Then Judas, which betrayed him, answered and said, Master, is it I? He said unto him, Thou hast said.
Manx: Eisht dansoor Yuaase, ren y vrah Eh, as dooyrt Eh, Vainshtyr, nee mish Eh? Dooyrt eshyn rish, T’ow er ghra eh.

English: 26 ¶And as they were eating, Jesus took bread, and blessed it, and brake it, and gave it to the disciples, and said, Take, eat; this is my body.
Manx: As myr v’ad gee, ghow Yeesey arran, as vannee Eh as vrish Eh eh, as hug Eh eh da ny ostyllyn, gra, Gow-jee, ee-jee, shoh my chorp’s.

English: 27 And he took the cup, and gave thanks, and gave it to them, saying, Drink ye all of it;
Manx: As ghow Eh yn cappan, as hug Eh booise, as hug Eh eh daue, gra, Iu-jee ooilley jeh shoh.

English: 28 For this is my blood of the new testament, which is shed for many for the remission of sins.
Manx: Son shoh my uill’s jeh’n conaant noa, t’er ny gheayrtey son ymmodee son leih peccaghyn.

English: 29 But I say unto you, I will not drink henceforth of this fruit of the vine, until that day when I drink it new with you in my Father's kingdom.
Manx: Agh ta mee gra riu, Nagh niu-ym maghey shoh jeh mess y villey-feeney, derrey’n laa iu-ym eh as yn noa mêriu ayns reeriaght my Ayrey.

English: 30 And when they had sung an hymn, they went out into the mount of Olives.
Manx: As tra v’ad er ghoaill arrane spyrrydoil, hie ad magh gys cronck ny Oliveyn.

English: 31 Then saith Jesus unto them, All ye shall be offended because of me this night: for it is written, I will smite the shepherd, and the sheep of the flock shall be scattered abroad.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Yeesey roo, Failee yn credjue eauish ooilley noght kyndagh rhym’s: son te scruit, Bwoaillym’s yn bochilley, as bee kirree yn chioltane er nyn skeayley.

English: 32 But after I am risen again, I will go before you into Galilee.
Manx: Agh erreish dou v’er n’irree reesht, hem reue gys Galilee.

English: 33 Peter answered and said unto him, Though all men shall be offended because of thee, yet will I never be offended.
Manx: Dansoor Peddyr as dooyrt Eh rish, Ga dy vaill credjue dy chooilley ghooinney kyndagh rhyts, cha vaill my chredjue’s dy bragh.

English: 34 Jesus said unto him, Verily I say unto thee, That this night, before the cock crow, thou shalt deny me thrice.
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey rish, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra rhyt, yn oie noght roish my gerr yn kellagh, dy nob uss mish three keayrtyn.

English: 35 Peter said unto him, Though I should die with thee, yet will I not deny thee. Likewise also said all the disciples.
Manx: Dooyrt Peddyr rish, Dy beïn dy gholl gy baase mârt, cha nobbin oo. As er yn aght cheddin loayr ooilley ny ostyllyn.

English: 36 ¶Then cometh Jesus with them unto a place called Gethsemane, and saith unto the disciples, Sit ye here, while I go and pray yonder.
Manx: Eisht haink Yeesey mâroo gys ynnyd va enmyssit Gethsemane, as dooyrt Eh rish ny ostyllyn, Soie-jee shiuish ayns shoh, choud as hem’s gys padjer ayns shid.

English: 37 And he took with him Peter and the two sons of Zebedee, and began to be sorrowful and very heavy.
Manx: As ghow Eh marish Peddyr, as daa vac Zebedee, as ren Eh toshiaght dy ve trimshagh as trome-chreeagh.

English: 38 Then saith he unto them, My soul is exceeding sorrowful, even unto death: tarry ye here, and watch with me.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Eh roo, Ta my annym feer trimshagh, dy jarroo gys y baase: fuirree-jee ayns shoh as jean-jee watchal mârym.

English: 39 And he went a little farther, and fell on his face, and prayed, saying, O my Father, if it be possible, let this cup pass from me: nevertheless not as I will, but as thou wilt.
Manx: As hie Eh red beg sodjey, as huit Eh sheese er e eddin, as ghow Eh padjer, as dooyrt Eh, O my Ayr, my te possible, lig da’n cappan shoh goll shiagh-ym: ny-yeih cha nee m’aigney’s, agh dt’aigneys dy row jeant.

English: 40 And he cometh unto the disciples, and findeth them asleep, and saith unto Peter, What, could ye not watch with me one hour?
Manx: As haink Eh gys ny ostyllyn, as hooar Eh ad nyn gadley, as dooyrt eh rish Peddyr, Kys ta shoh, nagh row shiu abyl watchal mârym un oor?

English: 41 Watch and pray, that ye enter not into temptation: the spirit indeed is willing, but the flesh is weak.
Manx: Bee-jee er nyn dwoaie as guee-jee, nagh duit shiu ayns miolagh: ta’n spyrryd dy jarroo arryltagh, agh ta’n eill annoon.

English: 42 He went away again the second time, and prayed, saying, O my Father, if this cup may not pass away from me, except I drink it, thy will be done.
Manx: Hie Eh roish reesht yn nah cheayrt, as ghow Eh padjer, gra, O my Ayr, mannagh vod y cappan shoh goll shiagh-ym, fegooish mee dy iu eh, dt’aigney's dy row jeant.

English: 43 And he came and found them asleep again: for their eyes were heavy.
Manx: As haink Eh as hooar Eh ad nyn gadley reesht: son va ny sooyllyn oc trome.

English: 44 And he left them, and went away again, and prayed the third time, saying the same words.
Manx: As daag Eh ad, as hie Eh roish reesht, as ghow Eh padjer yn tress cheayrt, gra ny goan cheddin.

English: 45 Then cometh he to his disciples, and saith unto them, Sleep on now, and take your rest: behold, the hour is at hand, and the Son of man is betrayed into the hands of sinners.
Manx: Eisht haink Eh gys e ostyllyn, as dooyrt Eh roo, Caidle-jee nish, as gow-jee nyn vea; cur-my-ner, ta’n oor tayrn er-gerrey, as ta’n Mac dooinney er ny vrah gys laueyn peccee.

English: 46 Rise, let us be going: behold, he is at hand that doth betray me.
Manx: Irree-jee, as lig dooin goll: cur-my-ner, te eshyn er-gerrey dooin ta dy my vrah.

English: 47 ¶And while he yet spake, lo, Judas, one of the twelve, came, and with him a great multitude with swords and staves, from the chief priests and elders of the people.
Manx: As choud as v’eh foast loayrt, cur-my-ner, haink Yuaase, fer jeh’n daa ostyl yeig, as va sheshaght vooar marish lesh cliwnyn as luirg, veih ny ard-saggyrtyn as shanstyr yn pobble.

English: 48 Now he that betrayed him gave them a sign, saying, Whomsoever I shall kiss, that same is he: hold him fast.
Manx: Nish hug eshyn v’er vrah Eh, cowrey daue, gra, Quoi-erbee verrym’s paag da, shen Eh, cum-jee Eh dy shickyr.

English: 49 And forthwith he came to Jesus, and said, Hail, master; and kissed him.
Manx: As chelleeragh haink Eh gys Yeesey, as dooyrt Eh, Dy vannee dhyt Vainshtyr; as phaag Eh Eh.

English: 50 And Jesus said unto him, Friend, wherefore art thou come? Then came they, and laid hands on Jesus and took him.
Manx: As dooyrt Yeesey rish, Charrey, cre’n-fa t’ow er-jeet? Eisht haink ad as hug ad nyn laueyn er Yeesey, as ghow ad Eh.

English: 51 And, behold, one of them which were with Jesus stretched out his hand, and drew his sword, and struck a servant of the high priest’s, and smote off his ear.
Manx: As cur-my-ner, heeyn fer jeusyn va marish Yeesey magh e laue, as hayrn Eh e chliwe, as woail Eh fer-mooinjerey yn ard-saggyrt, as yiare Eh yn chleash jeh.

English: 52 Then said Jesus unto him, Put up again thy sword into his place: for all they that take the sword shall perish with the sword.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Yeesey rish, Cur seose dty chliwe reesht ayns e ynnyd: son nee adsyn ooilley ta goaill y chliwe, cherraghtyn liorish y chliwe.

English: 53 Thinkest thou that I cannot now pray to my Father, and he shall presently give me more than twelve legions of angels?
Manx: Vel uss goaill as laue nagh voddym’s nish guee gys my Ayr, as yinnagh Eh chelleeragh hym er-skyn daa legion jeig dy ainlyn?

English: 54 But how then shall the scriptures be fulfilled, that thus it must be?
Manx: Agh kys eisht vees ny scripturyn er nyn gooilleeney, dy nee shoh myr te dy ve?

English: 55 In that same hour said Jesus to the multitudes, Are ye come out as against a thief with swords and staves for to take me? I sat daily with you teaching in the temple, and ye laid no hold on me.
Manx: Ayns yn oor cheddin dooyrt Yeesey rish y pobble, Vel shiu er-jeet magh myr noi maarlagh, lesh cliwnyn as luirg dy my ghoaill? Hoie-mee [sic: Hoie mee] mêriu gagh laa gynsaghey ayns y chiamble, as cha ren shiu my ghoaill.

English: 56 But all this was done, that the scriptures of the prophets might be fulfilled. Then all the disciples forsook him, and fled.
Manx: Agh va ooilley shoh jeant, dy voddagh scripturyn ny phadeyryn ve cooilleenit. Eisht ren ooilley ny ostyllyn Eh y hreigeil as cosney rowe.

English: 57 ¶And they that had laid hold on Jesus led him away to Caiaphas the high priest, where the scribes and the elders were assembled.
Manx: As leeid y vooinjer v’er ghoaill Yeesey Eh ersooyl gys Caiaphas yn ard-saggyrt, raad va ny scruderyn as y chanstyr er nyn jaglym cooidjagh.

English: 58 But Peter followed him afar off unto the high priest’s palace, and went in, and sat with the servants, to see the end.
Manx: Agh deiyr Peddyr er foddey ny yei, gys thie yn ard-saggyrt, as hie Eh stiagh, as hoie Eh marish ny sharvaantyn dy yeeaghyn cre veagh y jerrey.

English: 59 Now the chief priests, and elders, and all the council, sought false witness against Jesus, to put him to death;
Manx: Nish va ny ard-saggyrtyn as y chanstyr as ooilley’n choonceil, shirrey feanish foalsey noi Yeesey dy choyrt Eh gy baase.

English: 60 But found none: yea, though many false witnesses came, yet found they none. At the last came two false witnesses,
Manx: Agh cha dooar ad veg: ga dy daink ymmodee feanishyn foalsey, foast cha dooar ad veg. Ec y jerrey haink daa eanish foalsey,

English: 61 And said, This fellow said, I am able to destroy the temple of God, and to build it in three days.
Manx: As dooyrt ad, T’eh shoh er ghra, Ta mish abyl chiamble Yee y lieggal, as y hroggal eh reesht ayns three laa.

English: 62 And the high priest arose, and said unto him, Answerest thou nothing? what is it which these witness against thee?
Manx: As dirree yn ard-saggyrt seose, as dooyrt Eh rish, Nagh vel oo cur ansoor? Cre t’ad shoh dy hoilshaghey dt’oi?

English: 63 But Jesus held his peace, And the high priest answered and said unto him, I adjure thee by the living God, that thou tell us whether thou be the Christ, the Son of God.
Manx: Agh chum Yeesey e hengey. As dreggyr yn ard-saggyrt as dooyrt Eh rish, Ta mee cur currym ort liorish yn Jee bio, oo dy insh dooin, nee oo yn Creest Mac Yee?

English: 64 Jesus saith unto him, Thou hast said: nevertheless I say unto you, Hereafter shall ye see the Son of man sitting on the right hand of power, and coming in the clouds of heaven.
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey rish, T’ow uss er ghra eh: ny-yeih ta mish gra riu, Ny lurg shoh hee shiu yn Mac dooinney ny hoie er laue yesh yn phooar, as cheet ayns bodjallyn yn aer.

English: 65 Then the high priest rent his clothes, saying, He hath spoken blasphemy; what further need have we of witnesses? behold, now ye have heard his blasphemy.
Manx: Eisht raip yn ard-saggyrt e eaddagh, gra, T’eh er loayrt goan mollaghtagh, cre’n feme sodjey t’ain er feanishyn? cur-my-ner, nish ta shiu er chlashtyn e ghoan mollaghtagh.

English: 66 What think ye? They answered and said, He is guilty of death.
Manx: Cre ta shiu dy smooinaghtyn? Dansoor ad as dooyrt ad, T’eh toilchin dy ve er ny choyrt gy baase.

English: 67 Then did they spit in his face, and buffeted him; and others smote him with the palms of their hands,
Manx: Eisht chew ad shellaghyn ayns e eddin, as woail ad Eh, as woail feallagh elley Eh lesh bassyn nyn laueyn.

English: 68 Saying, Prophesy unto us, thou Christ, Who is he that smote thee?
Manx: Gra, Jean phadeyrys dooin, uss yn Creest, quoi ta dy dty woalley?

English: 69 ¶Now Peter sat without in the palace: and a damsel came unto him, saying, Thou also wast with Jesus of Galilee.
Manx: Nish va Peddyr ny hoie cheu-moie jeh’n cheshaght ayns y hall: as haink ben-aeg huggey, gra, V’ow uss myrgeddin marish Yeesey dy Ghalilee.

English: 70 But he denied before them all, saying, I know not what thou sayest.
Manx: Agh dobb Eh kiongoyrt roo ooilley, gra, Cha s’aym cre t’ow dy ghra.

English: 71 And when he was gone out into the porch, another maid saw him, and said unto them that were there, This fellow was also with Jesus of Nazareth.
Manx: As tra v’eh er gholl magh ayns y phorch, honnick ben-aeg elley Eh, as dooyrt ee roosyn v’ayns shen, V’eh shoh myrgeddin marish Yeesey dy Nazareth.

English: 72 And again he denied with an oath, I do not know the man.
Manx: As reesht dobb Eh lesh loo, Cha nione dou yn dooinney.

English: 73 And after a while came unto him they that stood by, and said to Peter, Surely thou also art one of them; for thy speech bewrayeth thee.
Manx: As tammylt ny lurg shen haink huggey yn vooinjer va nyn shassoo liorish, as dooyrt ad rish Peddyr, Shickyr she fer jeu oo, son ta dty ghlare dy dty vrah.

English: 74 Then began he to curse and to swear, saying, I know not the man. And immediately the cock crew.
Manx: Eisht ren Eh toshiaght dy ghweeaghyn as dy loo, gra, Cha nione dou yn dooinney. As chelleeragh gherr yn kellagh.

English: 75 And Peter remembered the word of Jesus, which said unto him, Before the cock crow, thou shalt deny me thrice. And he went out, and wept bitterly.
Manx: As chooinee Peddyr er ny goan va Yeesey er ghra rish, Roish my gerr y kellagh, obbee uss mish three keayrtyn. As hie Eh magh as cheayn eh dy sharroo.
CAB. XXVII.

English: When the morning was come, all the chief priests and elders of the people took counsel against Jesus to put him to death:
Manx: Tra va’n moghrey er-jeet, hug ooilley ny ard-saggyrtyn as shanstyr yn pobble nyn goyrle dy cheilley, dy choyrt Eh gy baase.

English: 2 And when they had bound him, they led him away, and delivered him to Pontius Pilate the governor.
Manx: As erreish daue v’er chiangley Eh, leeid ad Eh ersooyl, as livrey ad Eh gys Pontius Pilate yn kiannoort.

English: 3 ¶Then Judas, which had betrayed him, when he saw that he was condemned, repented himself, and brought again the thirty pieces of silver to the chief priests and elders,
Manx: Tra honnick eisht Yuaase ren y vrah Eh, dy row Eh er ny gheyrey, ghow Eh arrys, as hug Eh lesh reesht ny jeih peeshyn-as-feed dy argid gys ny ard-saggyrtyn as y chanstyr,

English: 4 Saying, I have sinned in that I have betrayed the innocent blood. And they said, What is that to us? see thou to that.
Manx: Gra, Ta mee er n’yannoo peccah, ayns dy vel mee er vrah yn uill neu-chyndagh. As dooyrt adsyn, Cre ta shen dooinyn? jeeagh uss da shen.

English: 5 And he cast down the pieces of silver in the temple, and departed, and went and hanged himself.
Manx: As hilg Eh sheese ny peeshyn argid ayns y chiamble, as jimmee Eh roish, as hie Eh as ren Eh Eh hene y chroghey.

English: 6 And the chief priests took the silver pieces, and said, It is not lawful for to put them into the treasury, because it is the price of blood.
Manx: As ghow ny ard-saggyrtyn ny peeshyn argid as dooyrt ad, Cha vel eh lowal dy choyrt ad mastey tashtaghyn y chiamble, er-yn-oyr dy nee leagh foalley eh.

English: 7 And they took counsel, and bought with them the potter’s field, to bury strangers in.
Manx: As ghow ad coyrle, as chionnee ad lhieu magher fer-ny-craie, dy oanluckey joarreeyn ayn.

English: 8 Wherefore that field was called, The field of blood, unto this day.
Manx: Shen-y-fa va’n magher shen enmyssit magher foalley gys y laa t’ayn jiu.

English: 9 Then was fulfilled that which was spoken by Jeremy the prophet, saying, And they took the thirty pieces of silver, the price of him that was valued, whom they of the children of Israel did value;
Manx: (Shen y traa va cooilleenit ny va loayrit liorish Jeremy yn phadeyr, gra, As ghow ad ny jeih peeshyn as feed dy argid, yn phrice echyssyn v’er ny phriceil, Eh ren adsyn jeh cloan Israel y phriceil:

English: 10 And gave them for the potter's field, as the Lord appointed me.
Manx: As hug ad ad son magher fer-ny-craie, myr va’n Chiarn er n’oardaghey dooys.)

English: 11 And Jesus stood before the governor: and the governor asked him, saying, Art thou the King of the Jews? And Jesus said unto him, Thou sayest.
Manx: As hass Yeesey kiongoyrt y chiannoort, as dênee yn kiannoort jeh, gra, Nee uss ree ny Hewnyn? As dooyrt Yeesey rish, T’ow uss dy ghra eh.

English: 12 And when he was accused of the chief priests and elders, he answered nothing.
Manx: As tra v’eh er ny chassid liorish ny ard-saggyrtyn as y chanstyr, cha dug Eh ansoor erbee daue.

English: 13 Then said Pilate unto him, Hearest thou not how many things they witness against thee?
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Pilate rish, Nagh vel oo clashtyn cre whilleen red t’ad shoh dy hoilshaghey dt’oi?

English: 14 And he answered him to never a word; insomuch that the governor marvelled greatly.
Manx: As cha dug Eh un ockle dy ansoor da, ayns wheesh as dy ghow yn kiannoort yindyss mooar.

English: 15 Now at that feast the governor was wont to release unto the people a prisoner, whom they would.
Manx: Nish ec y eailley shen va’n kiannoort cliaghtey feaysley daue pryssoonagh erbee dy bailloo.

English: 16 And they had then a notable prisoner, called Barabbas.
Manx: As va oc ec y traa shen ard phryssoonagh va enmyssit Barabbas.

English: 17 Therefore when they were gathered together, Pilate said unto them, Whom will ye that I release unto you? Barabbas, or Jesus which is called Christ?
Manx: Shen-y-fa tra v’ad er nyn jaglym cooidjagh, dooyrt Pilate roo, Quoi sailliu mee dy eaysley diu? Barabbas, ny Yeesey, ta enmyssit Creest?

English: 18 For he knew that for envy they had delivered him.
Manx: Son va fyss echey dy nee ayns goanlys v’ad er ny livrey Eh seose.

English: 19 When he was set down on the judgment seat, his wife sent unto him, saying, Have thou nothing to do with that just man: for I have suffered many things this day in a dream because of him.
Manx: Tra v’eh erreish soie sheese er stoyl y vriwnys, hug e ven fys huggey, gra, Ny bee veg ayds dy yannoo rish y dooinney cairagh shen: son ta mish er hurranse ymmodee dy reddyn jiu ayns my chadley, kyndagh rish.

English: 20 But the chief priests and elders persuaded the multitude that they should ask Barabbas, and destroy Jesus.
Manx: Agh choyrlee ny ard-saggyrtyn as y chanstyr yn pobble ad dy yannoo aghin son Barabbas, as Yeesey y choyrt gy baase.

English: 21 The governor answered and said unto them, Whether of the twain will ye that I release unto you? They said, Barabbas.
Manx: Dansoor y kiannoort as dooyrt Eh roo, Quoi jeh’n jees sailliu mee dy eaysley diu? Dooyrt adsyn, Barabbas.

English: 22 Pilate saith unto them, What shall I do then with Jesus which is called Christ? They all say unto him, Let him be crucified.
Manx: Dooyrt Pilate roo, Cre nee’m eisht rish Yeesey, ta enmyssit Creest? Dooyrt ad ooilley rish, Lhig da v’er ny chrossey.

English: 23 And the governor said, Why, what evil hath he done? But they cried out the more, saying, Let him be crucified.
Manx: As dooyrt y kiannoort, Cre’n-oyr, cre t’eh er n’yannoo dy holk? Agh deïe adsyn ny smoo, gra, Lig da v’er ny chrossey.

English: 24 ¶When Pilate saw that he could prevail nothing, but that rather a tumult was made, he took water, and washed his hands before the multitude, saying, I am innocent of the blood of this just person: see ye to it.
Manx: Tra honnick Pilate nagh row geill er ny chur da, agh dy row ad aarloo dy irree magh, ghow Eh ushtey, as nee Eh e laueyn kiongoyrt rish y pobble, gra, Ta mish neu-chyndagh jeh fuill yn persoon cairagh shen, jeeagh-jee shiuish da.

English: 25 Then answered all the people, and said, His blood be on us, and on our children.
Manx: Eisht dansoor ooilley’n pobble, gra, Yn uill echey dy row orrinyn, as er nyn gloan.

English: 26 ¶Then released he Barabbas unto them: and when he had scourged Jesus, he delivered him to be crucified.
Manx: Eisht deaysle Eh Barabbas daue; as tra v’eh er chustey Yeesey, livrey Eh Eh dy ve er ny chrossey.

English: 27 Then the soldiers of the governor took Jesus into the common hall, and gathered unto him the whole band of soldiers.
Manx: Eisht hug sidooryn y chiannoort lhieu Yeesey gys hall y vriwnys, as deïe ad er y slane sheshaght jeh ny sidooryn.

English: 28 And they stripped him, and put on him a scarlet robe.
Manx: As rooisht ad Eh, as hug ad er coamrey scarleod.

English: 29 ¶And when they had platted a crown of thorns, they put it upon his head, and a reed in his right hand: and they bowed the knee before him, and mocked him, saying, Hail, King of the Jews
Manx: As tra v’ad er fee attey dy ghrineyn, hug ad eh er y chione echey, as cuirtliagh ayns y laue yesh echey: as chroym ad nyn ghlioonyn kiongoyrt rish, as chraid ad mysh, gra, Dy vannee, Ree ny Hewnyn.

English: 30 And they spit upon him, and took the reed, and smote him on the head.
Manx: As chew ad shellaghyn er, as ghow ad y chuirtliagh, as woail ad Eh er y chione.

English: 31 And after that they had mocked him, they took the robe off from him, and put his own raiment on him, and led him away to crucify him.
Manx: As erreish daue v’er chraidey mysh, ghow ad yn coymrey reeoil jeh, as hug ad e gharmad hene er, as leeid ad Eh ersooyl dy chrossey Eh.

English: 32 And as they came out, they found a man of Cyrene, Simon by name: him they compelled to bear his cross.
Manx: As myr haink ad magh, hooar ad dooinney jeh Cyrene, va enmyssit Simon: eshyn ren ad y eaginaghey dy ymmyrkey e chrosh.

English: 33 And when they were come unto a place called Golgotha, that is to say, a place of a skull,
Manx: As tra v’ad er jeet gys ynnyd ta enmyssit Golgotha, ta shen dy ghra, ynnyd bollag,

English: 34 They gave him vinegar to drink mingled with gall: and when he had tasted thereof, he would not drink.
Manx: Hug ad da vinegar dy iu, as gall ny-chione: as tra v’eh er vlashtyn eh, cha ballish giu.

English: 35 And they crucified him, and parted his garments, casting lots: that it might be fulfilled which was spoken by the prophet, They parted my garments among them, and upon my vesture did they cast lots.
Manx: As ren ad Eh y chrossey, as reynn ad e gharmadyn, tilgey lottyn: dy voddagh shen ve cooilleenit va loayrit liorish y phadeyr, Reynn ad my gharmadyn nyn mast’ oc, as er my chooat ren ad lottyn y hilgey.

English: 36 And sitting down they watched him there;
Manx: As hoie ad sheese as watch ad Eh ayns shen.

English: 37 And set up over his head his accusation written, THIS IS JESUS THE KING OF THE JEWS.
Manx: As hoie ad harrish e chione oyr e vaaish scruit, SHOH YEESEY REE NY HEWNYN.

English: 38 Then were there two thieves crucified with him, one on the right hand, and another on the left.
Manx: Eisht va daa vaarlagh er ny chrossey marish: yn derrey yeh er y laue yesh, as y jeh elley er y laue chiare.

English: 39 ¶And they that passed by reviled him, wagging their heads,
Manx: As doltooan y vooinjer va goll shiaghey Eh, craa nyn ging,

English: 40 And saying, Thou that destroyest the temple, and buildest it in three days, save thyself. If thou be the Son of God, come down from the cross.
Manx: As gra, Uss ta lieggal y chiamble, as dy hroggal eh reesht ayns tree laa, saue oo hene: my she Mac Yee oo, tar neose jeh’n chrosh.

English: 41 Likewise also the chief priests mocking him, with the scribes and elders, said,
Manx: Myr shen myrgeddin ren ny ard-saggyrtyn craidey mysh, marish ny scruderyn as y chanstyr, as dooyrt ad,

English: 42 He saved others; himself he cannot save. If he be the King of Israel, let him now come down from the cross, and we will believe him.
Manx: Haue Eh feallagh elley, Eh hene cha vod Eh hauail: my she ree Israel Eh, lig da cheet neose jeh’n chrosh, as nee mad credjal ayn.

English: 43 He trusted in God; let him deliver him now, if he will have him: for he said, I am the Son of God.
Manx: Hreisht Eh ayns Jee; lig da Eh y livrey nish my sallish Eh: son dooyrt Eh, She Mac Yee mee.

English: 44 The thieves also, which were crucified with him, cast the same in his teeth.
Manx: Hilg ny maarlee myrgeddin v’er nyn grossey marish yn leid cheddin er.

English: 45 Now from the sixth hour there was darkness over all the land unto the ninth hour.
Manx: Nish veih yn cheyoo oor, va dorraghys harrish ooilley’n cheer, gys yn nuyoo oor.

English: 46 And about the ninth hour Jesus cried with a loud voice, saying, Eli, Eli, lama sabachthani? that is to say, My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?
Manx: As mygeayrt yn nuyoo oor, deïe Yeesey lesh ard choraa, gra, Eli, Eli, lama sabacthani? ta shen dy ghra, My Yee, My Yee, cre’n fa t’ow er my hreigeil?

English: 47 Some of them that stood there, when they heard that, said, This man calleth for Elias.
Manx: Dooyrt paart jeusyn va nyn shassoo ayns shen, tra cheayll ad shen, Ta’n dooinney shoh geamagh er Elias.

English: 48 And straightway one of them ran, and took a spunge, and filled it with vinegar, and put it on a reed, and gave him to drink.
Manx: As chelleeragh roih fer jeu, as ghow Eh spunge, as lhieen Eh eh lesh vinegar, as hug Eh eh er cuirtliagh, as heeyn Eh eh huggey dy iu.

English: 49 The rest said, Let be, let us see whether Elias will come to save him.
Manx: Dooyrt y vooinjer elley, Faag-jee eh, hee mad jig Elias dy hauail Eh.

English: 50 ¶Jesus, when he had cried again with a loud voice, yielded up the ghost.
Manx: Tra va Yeesey er n’eamagh reesht lesh ard choraa, phaart Eh.

English: 51 And, behold, the veil of the temple was rent in twain from the top to the bottom; and the earth did quake, and the rocks rent;
Manx: As cur-my-ner, va’n coodaghey va eddyr y chiamble as yn ynnyd casherick rapit veih my chielley, veih’n vullagh gys y laare; as ren y thalloo craa, as ny creggyn scoltey,

English: 52 And the graves were opened; and many bodies of the saints which slept arose,
Manx: As va ny oaiaghyn er nyn vosley, as ren ymmodee jeh kirp ny nooghyn va nyn gadley, girree seose,

English: 53 And came out of the graves after his resurrection, and went into the holy city, and appeared unto many.
Manx: As cheet ass ny hoaiaghyn oc, lurg yn irree-seose-reesht echey, as goll stiagh ayns yn ard-valley casherick, as ad hene y hoilshaghey da ymmodee.

English: 54 Now when the centurion, and they that were with him, watching Jesus, saw the earthquake, and those things that were done, they feared greatly, saying, Truly this was the Son of God.
Manx: Nish tra honnick yn captan-keead, as adsyn va marish watchal Yeesey, yn craa-thallooin, as ny reddyn v’er jeet gy kione, ghow ad aggle mooar, gra, Dy firrinagh shoh va Mac Yee.

English: 55 And many women were there beholding afar off, which followed Jesus from Galilee, ministering unto him:
Manx: As va ymmodee mraane ayns shen (va dy akin Eh foddey vow) va er n’eiyrt er Yeesey veih Galilee, as er hirveish er.

English: 56 Among which was Mary Magdalene, and Mary the mother of James and Joses, and the mother of Zebedees children.
Manx: Nyn mast’ oc va Moirrey Malaine, as Moirrey moir James as Joses, as moir cloan Zebedee.

English: 57 When the even was come, there came a rich man of Arimathaea, named Joseph, who also himself was Jesus’ disciple:
Manx: Tra va’n fastyr er jeet, haink dooinney berchagh jeh Arimathea, va enmyssit Joseph, va myrgeddin Eh hene er chredjal ayns Yeesey.

English: 58 He went to Pilate, and begged the body of Jesus. Then Pilate commanded the body to be delivered.
Manx: Hie Eh shoh gys Pilate, as ren Eh aghin son corp Yeesey: eisht hug Pilate saarey yn corp dy ve er ny livrey.

English: 59 And when Joseph had taken the body, he wrapped it in a clean linen cloth,
Manx: As tra va Joseph er ghoaill yn corp, hoïll Eh eh ayns aanrit glen,

English: 60 And laid it in his own new tomb, which he had hewn out in the rock: and he rolled a great stone to the door of the sepulchre, and departed.
Manx: As doanluck Eh eh ayns yn oaie noa echey hene, v’eh er ny chley ayns creg: as rowll Eh clagh vooar er beeal yn oaie, as jimmee Eh roish.

English: 61 And there was Mary Magdalene, and the other Mary, sitting over against the sepulchre.
Manx: As va Moirrey Malaine, as Moirrey elley, nyn soie jeeragh er yn oaie.

English: 62 ¶Now the next day, that followed the day of the preparation, the chief priests and Pharisees came together unto Pilate,
Manx: Nish yn nah laa lurg laa yn aarlaghey, haink ny ard-saggyrtyn as ny Phariseeyn cooidjagh gys Pilate,

English: 63 Saying, Sir, we remember that that deceiver said, while he was yet alive, After three days I will rise again.
Manx: Gra, Vainshtyr, ta cooinaghtyn ain dy dooyrt yn moltere shen, choud as v’eh foast bio, Lurg three laa neem’s girree reesht.

English: 64 Command therefore that the sepulchre be made sure until the third day, lest his disciples come by night, and steal him away, and say unto the people, He is risen from the dead: so the last error shall be worse than the first.
Manx: Cur saarey er-y-fa shen yn oaie dy ve jeant shickyr, derrey yn tress laa, er aggle dy jig yn vooinjer t’er ve sheer geiyrt er ayns yn oie, as dy geid ad Eh ersooyl, as dy jir ad rish yn pobble, T’eh er n’irree veih ny merriu: myr shen bee’n molteraght s’jerree ny smessey na’n chied volteraght.

English: 65 Pilate said unto them, Ye have a watch: go your way, make it as sure as ye can.
Manx: Dooyrt Pilate roo, Ta watch eu, immee-jee reue, jean-jee cha shickyr jeh as oddys shiu.

English: 66 So they went, and made the sepulchre sure, sealing the stone, and setting a watch.
Manx: Myr shen hie ad as ren ad yn oaie shickyr, sealal y chlagh, as soiaghey watch.
CAB. XXVIII.

English: In the end of the sabbath, as it began to dawn toward the first day of the week, came Mary Magdalene and the other Mary to see the sepulchre.
Manx: Tra va’n doonaght ec kione, as y laa toshiaght soilshaghey er y chied laa jeh’n chaghtin, haink Moirrey Malaine, as Moirrey elley dy voddagh ad yn oaie y akin.

English: 2 And, behold, there was a great earthquake: for the angel of the Lord descended from heaven, and came and rolled back the stone from the door, and sat upon it.
Manx: As cur-my-ner, va craa-thallooin mooar ayn; son va ainle y Chiarn er jeet neose veih niau, as er jeet as er rowlal back y chlagh jeh beeal yn oaie, as er hoie er.

English: 3 His countenance was like lightning, and his raiment white as snow:
Manx: Va’n eddin echey goll-rish y tendeil, as e choamrey gial myr y sniaghtey.

English: 4 And for fear of him the keepers did shake, and became as dead men.
Manx: As ayns aggle roish, ren y vooinjer va watchal craa, as haink ad dy ve myr deiney marroo.

English: 5 And the angel answered and said unto the women, Fear not ye: for I know that ye seek Jesus, which was crucified.
Manx: As dreggyr yn ainle, as dooyrt Eh rish ny mraane; Ny gow-jee aggle: son ta fys aym dy vel shiu shirrey Yeesey, v’er ny chrossey.

English: 6 He is not here: for he is risen, as he said. Come, see the place where the Lord lay.
Manx: Cha vel Eh ayns shoh, son t’eh er n’irree, myr dooyrt Eh hene: tar-jee, jeeagh-jee er yn ynnyd raad va’n Chiarn oanluckit.

English: 7 And go quickly, and tell his disciples that he is risen from the dead; and, behold, he goeth before you into Galilee; there shall ye see him: lo, I have told you.
Manx: As immee-jee dy tappee, as insh-jee dauseyn va sheer geiyrt er, dy vel Eh er n’irree veih ny merriu; as cur-my-ner, t’eh goll reue gys Galilee, ayns shen hee shiu Eh; cur-my-ner, ta mish er n’insh diu.

English: 8 And they departed quickly from the sepulchre with fear and great joy; and did run to bring his disciples word.
Manx: As jimmee ad dy tappee veih’n oaie lesh aggle as boggey mooar, as roih ad dy chur lhieu yn naight gys e ostyllyn.

English: 9 ¶And as they went to tell his disciples, behold, Jesus met them, saying, All hail. And they came and held him by the feet, and worshipped him.
Manx: As myr v’ad goll dy insh eh da e ostyllyn, cur-my-ner, haink Yeesey nyn guail, gra, Dy vannee diu. As haink ad, as chum ad Eh er y chassyn, as hug ad ooashley da.

English: 10 Then said Jesus unto them, Be not afraid: go tell my brethren that they go into Galilee, and there shall they see me.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Yeesey roo, Ny gow-jee aggle: immee-jee as abbyr-jee rish my vraaraghyn ad dy gholl gys Galilee, as ayns shen hee ad mee.

English: 11 ¶Now when they were going, behold, some of the watch came into the city, and shewed unto the chief priests all the things that were done.
Manx: Nish tra v’ad goll, cur-my-ner, haink paart jeh’n watch gys yn ard-valley, as hoilshee ad da ny ard-saggyrtyn ooilley ny reddyn v’er jeet gy kione:

English: 12 And when they were assembled with the elders, and had taken counsel, they gave large money unto the soldiers,
Manx: As tra v’adsyn as y chanstyr er nyn jaglym cooidjagh, as er chur nyn goyrle dy-cheilley, hug ad sim mooar dy argid da ny sidooryn,

English: 13 Saying, Say ye, His disciples came by night, and stole him away while we slept.
Manx: Gra, Abbyr-jee shiuish, Haink e ostyllyn ayns yn oie, as gheid ad Eh ersooyl choud as va shin nyn gadley.

English: 14 And if this come to the governor’s ears, we will persuade him, and secure you.
Manx: As my chlinnys y kiannoort jeh, ver mainyn er credjal dy vel eh firrinagh, as freillee mad shiuish sauchey.

English: 15 So they took the money, and did as they were taught: and this saying is commonly reported among the Jews until this day.
Manx: Myr shen ghow ad yn argid, as ren ad myr v’er ny chur roue: as ta’n raa shoh dy cadjin er ny insh magh mastey ny Hewnyn gys y laa t’ayn jiu.

English: 16 ¶Then the eleven disciples went away into Galilee, into a mountain where Jesus had appointed them.
Manx: Eisht hie yn un ostyl yeig roue gys Galilee, gys slieau raad va Yeesey er n’oardaghey daue.

English: 17 And when they saw him, they worshipped him: but some doubted.
Manx: As tra honnick ad Eh, hug ad ooashley da: agh va paart imneagh ayns nyn gredjue.

English: 18 And Jesus came and spake unto them, saying, All power is given unto me in heaven and in earth.
Manx: As haink Yeesey, as loayr Eh roo, gra, Ta dy chooilley phooar er ny chur dou ayns niau as er y thalloo.

English: 19 ¶Go ye therefore, and teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost:
Manx: Immee-jee er-y-fa shen as ynsee-jee dy chooilley ashoon, as bashtee-jee ad ayns ennym yn Ayr, as y Vac, as y spyrryd Noo:

English: 20 Teaching them to observe all things whatsoever I have commanded you: and, lo, I am with you alway, even unto the end of the world. Amen.
Manx: Gynsaghey daue dy reaylley dy chooilley nhee cre-erbee ta mish er chur ayns saarey diu: as cur-my-ner, Ta mish mêriu kinjagh, gys eer jerrey’n theihll.
Amen.
Yn Sushtal scruit liorish yn Noo MARK
CAB. I.

English: The beginning of the gospel of Jesus Christ, the Son of God;
Manx: Toshiaght sushtal Yeesey Creest, Mac Yee;

English: 2 As it is written in the prophets, Behold, I send my messenger before thy face, which shall prepare thy way before thee.
Manx: Myr te scruit ayns ny phadeyryn; Cur-my-ner, ta mee cur my haghter roish dt’eddin, dy yannoo aarloo dty raad royd.

English: The voice of one crying in the wilderness, Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make his paths straight.
Manx: Coraa fer geamagh ayns yn aasagh, Jean-jee aarloo raad y Chiarn, jean-jee ny cassanyn eckey kiart.

English: 4 John did baptize in the wilderness, and preach the baptism of repentance for the remission of sins.
Manx: Ren Ean bashtey ayns yn aasagh, as preacheil bashtey arrys, son leih peccaghyn.

English: 5 And there went out unto him all the land of Judaea, and they of Jerusalem, and were all baptized of him in the river of Jordan, confessing their sins.
Manx: As hie magh huggey ooilley cheer Yudea as fir-vaghee Yerusalem, as v’ad ooilley er nyn mashtey liorish ayns awin Yordan, goaill-rish nyn beccaghyn.

English: 6 And John was clothed with camel's hair, and with a girdle of a skin about his loins; and he did eat locusts and wild honey;
Manx: As va Ean coamrit lesh clooie chamel, as lesh cryss dy chrackan mysh ny meeghyn echey: as v’eh gee locustyn as mill feïe:

English: 7 And preached, saying, There cometh one mightier than I after me, the latchet of whose shoes I am not worthy to stoop down and unloose.
Manx: As ren Eh preacheil, gra, Ta fer s’pooaral na mish cheet my yei, kiangley ny braagyn echey cha vel mee feeu dy chroymmey sheese as dy eaysley.

English: 8 I indeed have baptized you with water: but he shall baptize you with the Holy Ghost.
Manx: Ta mish dy jarroo er vashtey shiu lesh ushtey: agh bashtee eshyn shiu lesh y Spyrryd Noo.

English: 9 And it came to pass in those days, that Jesus came from Nazareth of Galilee, and was baptized of John in Jordan.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione ayns ny laghyn shen, dy daink Yeesey veih Nazareth dy Ghalilee, as v’eh er ny vashtey liorish Ean ayns Jordan.

English: 10 And straightway coming up out of the water, he saw the heavens opened, and the Spirit like a dove descending upon him:
Manx: As chelleeragh haink Eh seose ass yn ushtey, as honnick Eh ny niaughyn foshlit, as y Spyrryd goll-rish calmane cheet neose er.

English: 11 And there came a voice from heaven, saying, Thou art my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased.
Manx: As haink coraa veih niau, gra, Oo my Vac graihagh, jeed ta mee dy mooar soiaghey.

English: 12 And immediately the spirit driveth him into the wilderness.
Manx: As chelleeragh deiyr y spyrryd Eh gys yn aasagh.

English: 13 And he was there in the wilderness forty days, tempted of Satan; and was with the wild beasts; and the angels ministered unto him.
Manx: As v’eh ayns shen ayns yn aasagh da-eed laa er ny violaghey liorish y drogh-spyrryd, as v’eh marish ny beïyn feïe, as ren ny ainlyn tendeil er.

English: 14 Now after that John was put in prison, Jesus came into Galilee, preaching the gospel of the kingdom of God,
Manx: Nish erreish da Ean v’er ny chur ayns pryssoon, haink Yeesey gys Galilee, preacheil sushtal reeriaght Yee,

English: 15 And saying, The time is fulfilled, and the kingdom of God is at hand: repent ye, and believe the gospel.
Manx: As gra, Ta’n traa cooilleenit, as ta reeriaght Yee ec laue: gow-jee arrys, as cred-jee yn sushtal.

English: 16 Now as he walked by the sea of Galilee, he saw Simon and Andrew his brother casting a net into the sea: for they were fishers.
Manx: Nish myr v’eh shooyl liorish faarkey Ghalilee, honnick Eh Simon as Andreays e vraar, tilgey magh lieen ayns y cheayn: (son v’ad nyn eeastairyn)

English: 17 And Jesus said unto them, Come ye after me, and I will make you to become fishers of men.
Manx: As dooyrt Yeesey roo, Tar-jee as eiyr-jee orryms, as neem’s shiu nyn eeastairyn dy gheiney.

English: 18 And straightway they forsook their nets, and followed him.
Manx: As chelleeragh hreig ad nyn lieenteenyn, as deiyr ad er.

English: 19 And when he had gone a little farther thence, he saw James the son of Zebedee, and John his brother, who also were in the ship mending their nets.
Manx: As tra v’eh er gholl red beg sodjey veih shen, honnick Eh Jamys mac Zebedee, as Ean e vraar, va myrgeddin ayns y lhong karraghey nyn lieenteenyn.

English: 20 And straightway he called them: and they left their father Zebedee in the ship with the hired servants, and went after him.
Manx: As chelleeragh deïe Eh orroo: as daag ad nyn ayr Zebedee ayns y lhong marish ny sharvaantyn faïlt, as hie ad geiyrt er.

English: 21 And they went into Capernaum; and straightway on the sabbath day he entered into the synagogue, and taught.
Manx: As hie ad stiagh ayns Capernaum, as chelleeragh er laa’n doonaght, hie Eh stiagh ayns y cheeill, as dynsee Eh.

English: 22 And they were astonished at his doctrine: for he taught them as one that had authority, and not as the scribes.
Manx: As ghow ad yindyss mooar jeh’n ynsagh echey: son v’eh gynsaghey ad myr fer va pooar echey, as cha nee myr ny scruderyn.

English: 23 And there was in their synagogue a man with an unclean spirit; and he cried out,
Manx: As va ayns y cheeill oc dooinney va spyrryd neu-ghlen ayn, as deïe Eh,

English: 24 Saying, Let us alone; what have we to do with thee, thou Jesus of Nazareth? art thou come to destroy us? I know thee who thou art, the Holy One of God.
Manx: Gra, Faag shin, cre’n eïe t’ayd orrin, Yeesey dy Nazareth? vel oo er jeet dy nyn stroie? Ta fys aym quoi oo, yn fer casherick dy Yee.

English: 25 And Jesus rebuked him, saying, Hold thy peace, and come out of him.
Manx: As hug Yeesey oghsan da, gra, Cum dty hengey, as tar magh ass.

English: 26 And when the unclean spirit had torn him, and cried with a loud voice, he came out of him.
Manx: As tra va’n spyrryd neu-ghlen er heih Eh noon as noal, as er n’eamagh lesh ard choraa, haink Eh magh ass.

English: 27 And they were all amazed, insomuch that they questioned among themselves, saying, What thing is this? what new doctrine is this? for with authority commandeth he even the unclean spirits, and they do obey him.
Manx: As v’ad ooilley atchimagh, ayns wheesh as dy row ad resooney nyn mast’ oc hene, gra, Cre’n red shoh? Cre’n ynsagh noa shoh? son t’eh dy pooaral cur saarey da ny eer spyrrydyn neu-ghlen, as t’ad cur biallys da.

English: 28 And immediately his fame spread abroad throughout all the region round about Galilee.
Manx: As chelleeragh hie yn goo echey magh trooid ooilley’n cheer mygeayrt Galilee.

English: 29 And forthwith, when they were come out of the synagogue, they entered into the house of Simon and Andrew, with James and John.
Manx: As cha lea as v’ad er jeet magh ass y cheeill, hie ad stiagh ayns thie Simon as Andreays, marish Jamys as Ean.

English: 30 But Simon’s wife's mother lay sick of a fever, and anon they tell him of her.
Manx: Agh va moir ben Simon ny lhie ching jeh’n chiassaghey, as my daink ny voddey dinsh ad da kys v’ee.

English: 31 And he came and took her by the hand, and lifted her up; and immediately the fever left her, and she ministered unto them.
Manx: As haink Eh as ghow Eh ee er y laue, as hrogg Eh ee seose; as chelleeragh daag y chiassaghey ee, as ren ee shirveish orroo.

English: 32 And at even, when the sun did set, they brought unto him all that were diseased, and them that were possessed with devils.
Manx: As ayns yn astyr, ec lhie ny greïney, hug ad lhieu huggey dy chooilley annane va doghanit, as adsyn va drogh-spyrrydyn ayndoo.

English: 33 And all the city was gathered together at the door.
Manx: As va ooilley’n ard-valley er nyn jaglym cooidjagh ec y dorrys.

English: 34 And he healed many that were sick of divers diseases, and cast out many devils; and suffered not the devils to speak, because they knew him.
Manx: As laanee Eh ymmodee va ching jeh caghlaaghyn dy ghoghanyn, as hilg Eh magh ymmodee drogh-spyrrydyn, as cha hur Eh da ny drogh-spyrrydyn dy loayrt, er-y-fa dy row enney oc er.

English: 35 And in the morning, rising up a great while before day, he went out, and departed into a solitary place, and there prayed.
Manx: As laa ny vairagh dirree Eh seose foddey roish y laa, as hie Eh magh, as jimmee Eh gys boayl er-lheh, as ayns shen ghow Eh padjer.

English: 36 And Simon and they that were with him followed after him.
Manx: As deiyr Simon er, as adsyn va marish.

English: 37 And when they had found him, they said unto him, All men seek for thee.
Manx: As tra v’ad er gheddyn Eh, dooyrt ad rish, Ta dy chooilley ghooinney fênaght er dty hon.

English: 38 And he said unto them, Let us go into the next towns, that I may preach there also: for therefore came I forth.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Lig dooin goll gys ny baljyn sniessey dooin, dy voddym preacheil ayndoo shen myrgeddin: son er-yn-oyr shen haink mee gys y theihll.

English: 39 And he preached in their synagogues throughout all Galilee, and cast out devils.
Manx: As ren Eh preacheil ayns ny kialteenyn oc trooid ooilley Galilee, as hilg Eh magh drogh-spyrrydyn.

English: 40 And there came a leper to him, beseeching him, and kneeling down to him, and saying unto him, If thou wilt, thou canst make me clean.
Manx: As haink louraane huggey, guee er, as gliooney sheese huggey, as gra rish, My she dt’aigney eh, foddee oo mish y yannoo glen.

English: 41 And Jesus, moved with compassion, put forth his hand, and touched him, and saith unto him, I will; be thou clean.
Manx: As va Yeesey er ny veiyghey lesh chymmey, as heeyn Eh magh e laue, as venn Eh rish, as dooyrt Eh, M’aigneys eh, bee er dty ghlenney.

English: 42 And as soon as he had spoken, immediately the leprosy departed from him, and he was cleansed.
Manx: As cha lea as loayr Eh, chelleeragh daag y louraanys Eh, as v’eh er ny ghlenney.

English: 43 And he straitly charged him, and forthwith sent him away;
Manx: As hug Eh currym gyere da, as ayns y tullogh hug Eh Eh ersooyl;

English: 44 And saith unto him, See thou say nothing to any man: but go thy way, shew thyself to the priest, and offer for thy cleansing those things which Moses commanded, for a testimony unto them.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish, Jeeagh nagh loayr oo veg rish dooinney erbee: agh immee royd, soilshee oo hene da’n taggyrt, as cheb son dty ghlenney ny reddyn shen ta Moses er ny haarey, dy ve son feanish daue.

English: 45 But he went out, and began to publish it much, and to blaze abroad the matter, insomuch that Jesus could no more openly enter into the city, but was without in desert places: and they came to him from every quarter.
Manx: Agh hie Eh magh, as ren eh toshiaght dy loayrt dy foshlit, as dy hoilshaghey magh yn naight, ayns wheesh as nagh dod Yeesey goll ny smoo dy foshlit gys yn ard-valley, agh v’eh mooie ayns ynnydyn faasagh: as haink ad huggey veih dy chooilley ard.
CAB. II.

English: And again he entered into Capernaum after some days; and it was noised that he was in the house.
Manx: As laghyn ny lurg shen, hie Eh reesht gys Capernaum, as ve er ny insh magh dy row Eh ayns y thie.

English: 2 And straightway many were gathered together, insomuch that there was no room to receive them, no, not so much as about the door: and he preached the word unto them.
Manx: As chelleeragh va ymmodee er nyn jaglym cooidjagh, ayns wheesh as nagh row room dy ghoaill ad, wheesh as mygeayrt y dorrys: as ren Eh yn goo y phreacheil daue.

English: 3 And they come unto him, bringing one sick of the palsy, which was borne of four.
Manx: As haink ad huggey, cur lhieu fer va ching jeh’n chingys-craa, v’er ny hroggal stiagh liorish kiare dy leih.

English: 24 And when they could not come nigh unto him for the press, they uncovered the roof where he was: and when they had broken it up, they let down the bed wherein the sick of the palsy lay.
Manx: As tra nagh dod ad cheet ergerrey da kyndagh rish y chennid, rooisht ad kione y thie raad v’eh: as erreish daue v’er vosley stiagh ny hrooid, lig ad sheese y lhiabbee ayn va’n ching jeh’n chingys-craa ny lhie.

English: 5 When Jesus saw their faith, he said unto the sick of the palsy, Son, thy sins be forgiven thee.
Manx: Tra hug Yeesey tastey da’n chredjue oc, dooyrt Eh rishyn va ching jeh’n chingys-craa, Vac, ta dty pheccaghyn er nyn leih dhyt.

English: 6 But there was certain of the scribes sitting there, and reasoning in their hearts,
Manx: Agh va shiartance jeh ny scruderyn nyn soie ayns shen, as v’ad resooney ayns nyn greeaghyn.

English: 7 Why doth this man thus speak blasphemies? who can forgive sins but God only?
Manx: Cre’n-fa ta’n dooinney shoh loayrt goan mollaghtagh? quoi oddys peccaghyn y leih, agh Jee ny lomarcan?

English: 8 And immediately when Jesus perceived in his spirit that they so reasoned within themselves, he said unto them, Why reason ye these things in your hearts?
Manx: As chelleeragh tra dennee Yeesey ayns e spyrryd dy row ad myr shoh resooney cheu-sthie jeu hene, dooyrt Eh roo, Cre’n-fa ta shiu smooinaghtyn er ny reddyn shoh ayns nyn greeaghyn?

English: 9 Whether is it easier to say to the sick of the palsy, Thy sins be forgiven thee; or to say, Arise, and take up thy bed, and walk?
Manx: Quoi sassey eh dy ghra rishyn ta ching jeh’n chingys-craa, Ta dty pheccaghyn er nyn leih dhyt: ny dy ghra, Irree, as trog seose dty lhiabbee, as jean shooyl?

English: 10 But that ye may know that the Son of man hath power on earth to forgive sins, (he saith to the sick of the palsy,)
Manx: Agh dy vod fys y ve eu dy vel pooar ec yn Mac dooinney er y thalloo dy leih peccaghyn, (t’eh gra rishyn ta ching jeh’n chingys-craa)

English: 11 I say unto thee, Arise, and take up thy bed, and go thy way into thine house.
Manx: Ta mee gra rhyt, Irree, as trog seose dty lhiabbee, as gow royd gys dty hie.

English: 12 And immediately he arose, took up the bed, and went forth before them all; insomuch that they were all amazed, and glorified God, saying, We never saw it on this fashion.
Manx: As chelleeragh dirree Eh, hrog Eh e lhiabbee, as hie Eh magh kiongoyrt roo ooilley, ayns wheesh as dy row ad ooilley atchimagh, as dy ren ad Jee y ghloyraghey, gra, Cha vaik shin eh rieau er yn aght shoh.

English: 13 And he went forth again by the sea side; and all the multitude resorted unto him, and he taught them.
Manx: As hie Eh magh reesht rish oirr ny marrey, as haink ooilley yn pobble huggey, as dynsee Eh ad.

English: 14 And as he passed by, he saw Levi the son of Alphaeus sitting at the receipt of custom, and said unto him, Follow me. And he arose and followed him.
Manx: As myr v’eh goll shiaghey, honnick Eh Levi mac Alpheus ny hoie ec boayrd y cheesh, as dooyrt Eh rish, Eiyr orryms. As dirree Eh as deiyr Eh er.

English: 15 And it came to pass, that, as Jesus sat at meat in his house, many publicans and sinners sat also together with Jesus and his disciples: for there were many, and they followed him.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, myr va Yeesey ny hoie ec bee ayns e hie, dy ren myrgeddin ymmodee publicanee as peccee soie sheese marish Yeesey as e heshaght: son va ymmodee ayn v’er n’eiyrt er.

English: 16 And when the scribes and Pharisees saw him eat with publicans and sinners, they said unto his disciples, How is it that he eateth and drinketh with publicans and sinners?
Manx: As tra honnick ny scruderyn as ny Phariseeyn Eh gee marish publicanee as peccee, dooyrt ad roosyn va kinjagh marish, Kys dy vel Eh gee as giu marish publicanee as peccee?

English: 17 When Jesus heard it, he saith unto them, They that are whole have no need of the physician, but they that are sick: I came not to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance.
Manx: Tra cheayll Yeesey shoh, dooyrt Eh roo, Cha vel feme ocsyn ta slaane er y lhee, agh ec sleih chingey: Cha daink mish dy eamagh er y vooinjer chairagh, agh er peccee gys arrys.

English: 18 And the disciples of John and of the Pharisees used to fast: and they come and say unto him, Why do the disciples of John and of the Pharisees fast, but thy disciples fast not?
Manx: As va’n vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er Ean as er ny Phariseeyn oallagh er trostey; as haink ad as dooyrt ad rish, Kys dy vel y vooinjer ta sheer geiyrt er Ean as er ny Phariseeyn trostey, agh cha vel adsyn t’ow uss er n’ynsaghey trostey?

English: 19 And Jesus said unto them, Can the children of the bridechamber fast, while the bridegroom is with them? as long as they have the bridegroom with them, they cannot fast.
Manx: As dooyrt Yeesey roo, Vod cloan y chamyr-phoosee trostey, choud as ta’n dooinney-phoosee mâroo? choud as ta’n dooinney-phoosee mâroo, cha vod ad trostey.

English: 20 But the days will come, when the bridegroom shall be taken away from them, and then shall they fast in those days.
Manx: Agh hig ny laghyn, tra vees y dooinney-phoosee er ny ghoaill ersooyl vow, as eisht nee ad trostey ayns ny laghyn shen.

English: 21 No man also seweth a piece of new cloth on an old garment: else the new piece that filled it up taketh away from the old, and the rent is made worse.
Manx: As cha vel dooinney erbee whaalley peesh dy eaddagh lajer er shen gharmad: er nonney ta’n pheesh goaill y laane ass y chen gharmad, as te rapit ny smessey na ve.

English: 22 And no man putteth new wine into old bottles: else the new wine doth burst the bottles, and the wine is spilled, and the bottles will be marred: but new wine must be put into new bottles.
Manx: Cha moo ta dooinney erbee cur feeyn noa ayns shen voteïlyn*, er-nonney ta’n feeyn noa brishey ny boteïlyn, as ta’n feeyn deayrtit, as bee ny boteïlyn dy choayll orroo: agh shegin da feeyn noa v’er ny chur ayns boteïlyn noa.
*Liare.

English: 23 And it came to pass, that he went through the corn fields on the sabbath day; and his disciples began, as they went, to pluck the ears of corn.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, dy jagh Eh trooid ny magheryn arroo er laa’n doonaght, as ren y vooinjer va sheer marish toshiaght, myr v’ad goll, dy phluckey jeeassyn jeh’n arroo.

English: 24 And the Pharisees said unto him, Behold, why do they on the sabbath day that which is not lawful?
Manx: As dooyrt ny Phariseeyn rish, Cur-my-ner, cre’n-fa t’ad er laa’n doonaght jannoo shen nagh vel lowit.

English: 25 And he said unto them, Have ye never read what David did, when he had need, and was an hungred, he, and they that were with him?
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Nagh lhaih shiuish rieau, cre ren David, tra v’eh ayns feme as accryssagh, Eh hene as y vooinjer va marish?

English: 26 How he went into the house of God in the days of Abiathar the high priest, and did eat the shewbread, which is not lawful to eat but for the priests, and gave also to them which were with him?
Manx: Kys hie Eh stiagh ayns thie Yee, ayns laghyn Abiathar yn ard-saggyrt, as die Eh yn arran casherick, nagh row lowit dy ve eeit, agh liorish ny saggyrtyn, as hug Eh eh myrgeddin dauesyn va marish?

English: 27 And he said unto them, The sabbath was made for man, and not man for the sabbath:
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Va’n doonaght er ny yannoo son dooinney, as cha nee dooinney son y doonaght:

English: 28 Therefore the Son of man is Lord also of the sabbath.
Manx: Shen-y-fa ta’n Mac dooinney ny Hiarn myrgeddin er y doonaght.
CAB. III.

English: And he entered again into the synagogue; and there was a man there which had a withered hand.
Manx: As hie Eh reesht stiagh ayns y cheeill, as va dooinney ayns shen va’n laue echey er shyrgaghey.

English: 2 And they watched him, whether he would heal him on the sabbath day; that they might accuse him.
Manx: As hug ad tastey da, dy yeeaghyn jinnagh Eh Eh y lheihys er laa’n doonaght, dy voddagh oyr y ve oc dy loayrt noi.

English: 3 And he saith unto the man which had the withered hand, Stand forth.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish y dooinney va’n laue echey er shyrgaghey, Shass magh.

English: 4 And he saith unto them, Is it lawful to do good on the sabbath days, or to do evil? to save life, or to kill? But they held their peace.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Vel eh lowal dy yannoo mie er laghyn y doonaght, ny dy yannoo dy holk? dy hauail bioys, ny dy varroo? agh chum ad nyn jengey.

English: 5 And when he had looked round about on them with anger, being grieved for the hardness of their hearts, he saith unto the man, Stretch forth thine hand. And he stretched it out: and his hand was restored whole as the other.
Manx: As tra v’eh er yeeaghyn mygeayrt orroo lesh corree, v’eh trimshagh son creoghys ny creeaghyn oc, as dooyrt Eh rish y dooinney, Sheeyn magh dty laue: as heeyn Eh ee magh; as va e laue er ny lheihys myr y laue elley.

English: 6 And the Pharisees went forth, and straightway took counsel with the Herodians against him, how they might destroy him.
Manx: As hie ny Phariseeyn magh, as chelleeragh ghow ad hene as ny Herodianee coyrle noi, kys oddagh ad Eh y stroie.

English: 7 But Jesus withdrew himself with his disciples to the sea: and a great multitude from Galilee followed him, and from Judaea,
Manx: Agh hie Yeesee [sic: Yeesey] dy lhiattee gys y cheayn marish y vooinjer va sheer marish: as deiyr earrooyn mooarey dy leih er veih Galilee, as veih Judea,

English: 8 And from Jerusalem, and from Idumaea, and from beyond Jordan; and they about Tyre and Sidon, a great multitude, when they had heard what great things he did, came unto him.
Manx: As veih Jerusalem, as veih Idumea, as veih’n cheu elley dy Yordan, as adsyn mygeayrt Tyre as Sidon, earroo mooar, tra cheayll ad cre ny reddyn mooarey v’eh er n’yannoo, haink ad huggey.

English: 9 And he spake to his disciples, that a small ship should wait on him because of the multitude, lest they should throng him.
Manx: As loayr Eh roosyn va sheer geiyrt er, lhong veg dy ve aarloo er y hon, kyndagh rish y pobble, son nagh jinnagh ad chionney stiagh er.

English: 10 For he had healed many; insomuch that they pressed upon him for to touch him, as many as had plagues.
Manx: Son v’eh er laanaghey ymmodee, ayns wheesh as dy row ad chionney stiagh huggey, dy vennaylt rish, whilleen as va dourinagh.

English: 11 And unclean spirits, when they saw him, fell down before him, and cried, saying, Thou art the Son of God.
Manx: As ny spyrrydyn neu-ghlen, tra honnick ad Eh, huit ad sheese kiongoyrt rish, as deïe ad, gra, She Mac Yee oo.

English: 12 And he straitly charged them that they should not make him known.
Manx: As hug Eh currym gyere daue, gyn ad dy insh magh quoi v’eh.

English: 13 And he goeth up into a mountain, and calleth unto him whom he would: and they came unto him.
Manx: As hie Eh seose er slieau, as deïe Eh er y vooinjer ballish: as haink ad huggey.

English: 14 And he ordained twelve, that they should be with him, and that he might send them forth to preach,
Manx: As doardee Eh ghaa yeig dy ve marish, dy voddagh Eh nyn goyrt ad magh dy phreacheil:

English: 15 And to have power to heal sicknesses, and to cast out devils:
Manx: As dy voddagh pooar y ve oc dy lheihys chingyssyn, as dy hilgey magh drogh-spyrrydyn.

English: 16 And Simon he surnamed Peter;
Manx: As Simon lhennoo Eh Peddyr.

English: 17 And James the son of Zebedee, and John the brother of James; and he surnamed them Boanerges, which is, The sons of thunder:
Manx: As Jamys mac Zebedee, as Ean braar Jamys (as lhennoo Eh adsyn Boanerges, ta shen dy ghra, Meck yn taarnagh)

English: 18 And Andrew, and Philip, and Bartholomew, and Matthew, and Thomas, and James the son of Alphaeus, and Thaddaeus, and Simon the Canaanite,
Manx: As Andreays, as Philip, as Bartholomew, as Mian, as Thomase, as Jamys mac Alpheus, as Thaddeus, as Simon yn Canaanite,

English: 19 And Judas Iscariot, which also betrayed him: and they went into an house.
Manx: As Yuaase Iscariot, ren myrgeddin Eh y vrah: as haink ad rymboo thie.

English: 20 And the multitude cometh together again, so that they could not so much as eat bread.
Manx: As va’n pobble er nyn jaglym cooidjagh reesht, myr shen nagh dod ad wheesh as arran y ee.

English: 21 And when his friends heard of it, they went out to lay hold on him: for they said, He is beside himself.
Manx: As tra cheayll e gheiney-mooinjerey jeh, hie ad magh dy ghoaill Eh: son dooyrt ad, T’eh ass e cheeal.

English: 22 ¶And the scribes which came down from Jerusalem said, He hath Beelzebub, and by the prince of the devils casteth he out devils.
Manx: As dooyrt ny scruderyn haink neose veih Jerusalem, Ta Beelzebub echey, as liorish prince ny drogh-spyrrydyn t’eh tilgey magh drogh-spyrrydyn.

English: 23 And he called them unto him, and said unto them in parables, How can Satan cast out Satan?
Manx: As deïe Eh orroo huggey, as dooyrt Eh roo ayns coraaghyn-dorraghey, Kys oddys Jouyl tilgey magh Jouyl?

English: 24 And if a kingdom be divided against itself, that kingdom cannot stand.
Manx: As my ta reeriaght girree magh ny oi hene, cha vod y reeriaght shen shassoo.

English: 25 And if a house be divided against itself, that house cannot stand.
Manx: As my ta thie girree magh ny oi hene, cha vod y thie shen shassoo.

English: 26 And if Satan rise up against himself, and be divided, he cannot stand, but hath an end.
Manx: As my ta’n Jouyl girree magh, as my t’eh ny oi hene, cha vod Eh shassoo, agh ta e phooar ec kione.

English: 27 No man can enter into a strong man’s house, and spoil his goods, except he will first bind the strong man; and then he will spoil his house.
Manx: Cha vod dooinney erbee goll stiagh ayns thie dooinney lajer as e chooid y ghoaill liorish roosteraght, mannagh gainle Eh hoshiaght yn dooinney lajer, as eisht nee Eh e hie y roostey.

English: 28 Verily I say unto you, All sins shall be forgiven unto the sons of men, and blasphemies wherewith soever they shall blaspheme:
Manx: Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Bee dy chooilley pheccah er ny leih da meck gheiney, as ny goan mollaghtagh lioroo nee ad loayrt dy mollaghtagh:

English: 26 But he that shall blaspheme against the Holy Ghost hath never forgiveness, but is in danger of eternal damnation.
Manx: Agh eshyn loayrys dy mollaghtagh noi yn Spyrryd Noo, cha bee dy bragh leih ny chouyr, agh t’eh ayns dangere coayl-anmey dy bragh beayn:

English: 30 Because they said, He hath an unclean spirit.
Manx: Er-yn-oyr dy dooyrt ad, Ta spyrryd neu-ghlen echey.

English: 31 ¶There came then his brethren and his mother, and, standing without, sent unto him, calling him.
Manx: Eisht haink e vraaraghyn as e voir, as duirree ad mooie, as hug ad fys huggey dy heet dy loayrt roo.

English: 32 And the multitude sat about him, and they said unto him, Behold, thy mother and thy brethren without seek for thee.
Manx: As va’n pobble nyn soie mygeayrt y mysh, as dooyrt ad rish, Cur-my-ner, ta dty voir as dty vraaraghyn mooie fênaght er dty hon.

English: 33 And he answered them, saying, Who is my mother, or my brethren?
Manx: As dreggyr Eh ad, gra, Quoi my voir, ny my vraaraghyn?

English: 34 And he looked round about on them which sat about him, and said, Behold my mother and my brethren
Manx: As yeeagh Eh mygeayrt orroosyn va nyn soie mygeayrt y mysh, as dooyrt Eh, Cur-jee-my-ner my voir as my vraaraghyn.

English: 35 For whosoever shall do the will of God, the same is my brother, and my sister, and mother.
Manx: Son quoi-erbee nee aigney Yee, she eshyn my vraar, as my huyr, as my voir.
CAB. IV.

English: And he began again to teach by the sea side: and there was gathered unto him a great multitude, so that he entered into a ship, and sat in the sea; and the whole multitude was by the sea on the land.
Manx: As ren Eh toshiaght reesht dy ynsaghey rish oirr ny marrey: as va earroo mooar dy leih er nyn jaglym cooidjagh huggey, myr shen dy jagh Eh seose ayns lhong, as hoie Eh er y cheayn, as va ooilley’n pobble liorish y cheayn, er y thalloo.

English: 2 And he taught them many things by parables, and said unto them in his doctrine,
Manx: As dynsee Eh daue ymmodee dy reddyn liorish coraaghyn-dorraghey, as dooyrt Eh roo ayns e ynsagh,

English: 3 Hearken; Behold, there went out a sower to sow:
Manx: Clasht-jee, Cur-my-ner, hie corryder magh dy chuirr:

English: 4 And it came to pass, as he sowed, some fell by the way side, and the fowls of the air came and devoured it up.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione myr v’eh cuirr dy huit paart jeh’n rass rish oirr y raad, as haink eeanlee yn aer, as diee ad seose eh.

English: 5 And some fell on stony ground, where it had not much earth; and immediately it sprang up, because it had no depth of earth:
Manx: As huit paart er thalloo claghagh, raad nagh row cooid vooar dy ooir echey, as chelleeragh daase eh, er-yn-oyr nagh row diunit thallooin echey.

English: 6 But when the sun was up, it was scorched; and because it had no root, it withered away.
Manx: As ghow niart ny greïney yn soo ass, as er-yn-oyr nagh row eh er ghoaill fraue, hie eh naardey.

English: 7 And some fell among thorns, and the thorns grew up, and choked it, and it yielded no fruit.
Manx: As huit paart mastey drineyn, as daase ny drineyn seose, as hoght ad eh, as cha dymmyrk eh mess.

English: 8 And other fell on good ground, and did yield fruit that sprang up and increased; and brought forth, some thirty, and some sixty, and some an hundred.
Manx: Agh huit cooid elley jeh ayns thalloo mie, as hug eh magh mess ren gaase seose as bishaghey, as dymmyrk eh paart jeih fillaghyn as feed, as paart three-feed, as paart keead-filley.

English: 9 And he said unto them, He that hath ears to hear, let him hear.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Eshyn ta cleashyn echey dy chlashtyn, lig da clashtyn.

English: 10 And when he was alone, they that were about him with the twelve asked of him the parable.
Manx: As tra v’eh ny lomarcan, dênee yn vooinjer va mygeayrt y mysh marish yn daa ostyl yeig jeh mychione y coraa-dorraghey.

English: 11 And he said unto them, Unto you it is given to know the mystery of the kingdom of God: but unto them that are without, all these things are done in parables:
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Diuish te er ny choyrt dy hoiggal folliaght reeriaght Yee: agh dauesyn ta mooie, ta dy chooilley nhee jeant ayns coraaghyn-dorraghey:

English: 12 That seeing they may see, and not perceive; and hearing they may hear, and not understand; lest at any time they should be converted, and their sins should be forgiven them.
Manx: Fakin dy voddagh ad fakin, as gyn tastey choyrt, as clashtyn dy voddagh ad clashtyn as gyn tushtey ghoaill; er aggle ec traa erbee dy beagh ad er nyn jyndaa, as dy beagh nyn beccaghyn er nyn leih daue.

English: 13 And he said unto them, Know ye not this parable? and how then will ye know all parables?
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Nagh vel toiggal eu jeh’n choraa-dorraghey shoh? as kys eisht nee shiu dy chooilley choraa-dorraghey y hoiggal?

English: 14 ¶The sower soweth the word.
Manx: Ta’n corryder cuirr yn goo.

English: 15 And these are they by the way side, where the word is sown; but when they have heard, Satan cometh immediately, and taketh away the word that was sown in their hearts.
Manx: As ad shoh yn voinjer [sic] ta er oirr y raad, raad ta’n goo cuirt, agh tra t’ad er chlashtyn, ta’n drogh-spyrryd cheet chelleeragh, as goaill ersooyl yn goo va cuirt ayns nyn greeaghyn.

English: 16 And these are they likewise which are sown on stony ground; who, when they have heard the word, immediately receive it with gladness;
Manx: As ad shoh neesht yn vooinjer ta cuirt ayns thalloo claghagh, ta, erreish daue v’er chlashtyn y goo, chelleeragh dy ghoaill eh lesh gennalys:

English: 17 And have no root in themselves, and so endure but for a time: afterward, when affliction or persecution ariseth for the word's sake, immediately they are offended.
Manx: As cha vel fraue oc ayndoo hene, as myr shen cha vel ad cummal rish agh son earish: ny lurg shen tra ta seaghyn ny tranlaase cheet orroo er coontey’n ghoo, chelleeragh ta nyn gredjue faileil.

English: 18 And these are they which are sown among thorns; such as hear the word,
Manx: As ad shoh yn vooinjer ta cuirt mastey drineyn: leid as ta clashtyn y goo,

English: 19 And the cares of this world, and the deceitfulness of riches, and the lusts of other things entering in, choke the word, and it becometh unfruitful.
Manx: As ta kiarrail y theihll shoh, as molteraght berchys, as saynt reddyn elley goll stiagh, as plooghey’n goo, as te cheet dy ve neu-vessoil.

English: 20 And these are they which are sown on good ground; such as hear the word, and receive it, and bring forth fruit, some thirtyfold, some sixty, and some an hundred.
Manx: As ad shoh yn vooinjer ta cuirt ayns thalloo mie, leid as ta clashtyn y goo, as ta dy ghoaill eh, as gymmyrkey magh mess, paart jeih fillaghyn as feed, paart three-feed, as paart keead-filley.

English: 21 ¶And he said unto them, Is a candle brought to be put under a bushel, or under a bed? and not to be set on a candlestick?
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Vel kainle dy ve er ny choyrt fo saagh, ny fo lhiabbee? as nagh vel ee dy ve er ny choyrt ayns kainlere?

English: 22 For there is nothing hid, which shall not be manifested; neither was any thing kept secret, but that it should come abroad.
Manx: Son cha vel nhee erbee kellit, nagh bee er ny hoilshaghey: ny nhee erbee freilt follit, agh dy vod eh cheet magh.

English: 23 If any man have ears to hear, let him hear.
Manx: My ta cleashyn ec dooinney erbee dy chlashtyn, lig da clashtyn.

English: 24 And he said unto them, Take heed what ye hear: with what measure ye mete, it shall be measured to you: and unto you that hear shall more be given.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Cur-jee tastey da ny ta shiu dy chlashtyn: lesh y towse ta shiu towse, bee eh er ny howse diu; as diuish ta clashtyn, bee ny smoo er ny choyrt.

English: 25 For he that hath, to him shall be given: and he that hath not, from him shall be taken even that which he hath.
Manx: Son eshyn ta echey, dasyn vees er ny choyrt: as eshyn nagh vel echey, veihsyn vees er ny ghoaill shen hene ny ta echey.

English: 26 ¶And he said, So is the kingdom of God, as if a man should cast seed into the ground;
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Shoh myr ta reeriaght Yee, myr dy dilgagh dooinney rass ayns y thalloo,

English: 27 And should sleep, and rise night and day, and the seed should spring and grow up, he knoweth not how.
Manx: As Eh dy chadley, as dy irree oie as laa; as y rass dy heet er y hoshiaght as dy aase seose, gyn yss da.

English: For the earth bringeth forth fruit of herself; first the blade, then the ear, after that the full corn in the ear.
Manx: 28. Son ta’n thalloo cur magh mess jee hene, hoshiaght yn chass, eisht yn jeease, ny lurg shen yn arroo creen ayns y jeease.

English: 29 But when the fruit is brought forth, immediately he putteth in the sickle, because the harvest is come.
Manx: Agh tra ta’n mess er greenaghey, chelleeragh t’eh cur magh yn corran, er-yn-oyr dy vel y fouyr er-jeet.

English: 30 ¶And he said, Whereunto shall we liken the kingdom of God? or with what comparison shall we compare it?
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Cre gys nee mad reeriaght Yee y hoyllaghey? ny lesh cre’n co-chaslys nee mad y hoiaghey magh eh?

English: 31 It is like a grain of mustard seed, which, when it is sown in the earth, is less than all the seeds that be in the earth:
Manx: Te goll-rish greine dy rass mustard, ta ny sloo, tra te cuirt ayns y thalloo, na dy chooilley rass ta ayns y thalloo.

English: 32 But when it is sown, it groweth up, and becometh greater than all herbs, and shooteth out great branches; so that the fowls of the air may lodge under the shadow of it.
Manx: Agh tra te cuirt, te gaase seose, as cheet dy ve ny smoo na ooilley ny lossyreeyn, as cur magh banglaneyn mooarey; myr shen dy vod eeanlee yn aer fastee y ghoaill fo’n scadoo echey.

English: 33 And with many such parables spake he the word unto them, as they were able to hear it.
Manx: As lesh ymmodee dy leid ny coraaghyn-dorraghey loayr Eh yn goo roo, myr v’ad abyl y chlashtyn eh.

English: 34 But without a parable spake he not unto them: and when they were alone, he expounded all things to his disciples.
Manx: Agh fegooish coraa-dorraghey cha loayr Eh roo: as tra v’ad nyn lomarcan, hoilshee Eh dy chooilley nhee dauesyn va sheer geiyrt er.

English: And the same day, when the even was come, he saith unto them, Let us pass over unto the other side.
Manx: [35] As y laa cheddin tra va’n fastyr er jeet, dooyrt Eh roo, Lig dooin goll harrish gys y cheu elley.

English: 36 And when they had sent away the multitude, they took him even as he was in the ship. And there were also with him other little ships.
Manx: As tra v’ad er chur ersooyl yn pobble, hug ad lhieu Eh myr v’eh ayns y lhong, as va myrgeddin lhongyn beggey elley marish.

English: 37 And there arose a great storm of wind, and the waves beat into the ship, so that it was now full.
Manx: As dirree sterrym mooar dy gheay, as va ny tonnyn er nyn geau stiagh ayns y lhong, myr shen dy row ee nish laane.

English: 38 And he was in the hinder part of the ship, asleep on a pillow: and they awake him, and say unto him, Master, carest thou not that we perish?
Manx: As ve eshyn ayns jerrey ny luingey ny chadley er pillow: as ghooisht ad Eh, as dooyrt ad rish, Vainshtyr, nagh vel oo dy ghoaill eh gys dty chree dy bee mad callit?

English: 39 And he arose, and rebuked the wind, and said unto the sea, Peace, be still. And the wind ceased, and there was a great calm.
Manx: As dirree Eh, as smaghtee Eh yn gheay, as dooyrt Eh rish y faarkey, Gow fea, bee kuine: as ghow yn gheay fea, as va kuiney vooar ayn.

English: 40 And he said unto them, Why are ye so fearful? how is it that ye have no faith?
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Cre’n-fa ta shiu cha agglagh? kys te nagh vel credjue eu?

English: 41 And they feared exceedingly, and said one to another, What manner of man is this, that even the wind and the sea obey him?
Manx: As v’ad feer agglagh, as dooyrt ad yn derrey yesh [sic: yeh] rish y jeh elley, Cre’n monney dy ghooinney Eh shoh, dy vel y gheay hene as y faarkey cur biallys da?
CAB. V.

English: And they came over unto the other side of the sea, into the country of the Gadarenes.
Manx: As haink ad harrish gys y cheu elley jeh’n cheayn, gys cheer ny Gadarenee.

English: 2 And when he was come out of the ship, immediately there met him out of the tombs a man with an unclean spirit,
Manx: As tra v’eh er jeet ass y lhong, chelleeragh haink ny whail veih mastey ny hoaiaghyn, dooinney va spyrryd neu-ghlen ayn,

English: 3 Who had his dwelling among the tombs; and no man could bind him, no, not with chains:
Manx: Va’n ynnyd-vaghee echey er ve mastey ny hoaiaghyn, as cha voddagh dooinney erbee y chiangley Eh, eer lesh geulaghyn:

English: 4 Because that he had been often bound with fetters and chains, and the chains had been plucked asunder by him, and the fetters broken in pieces: neither could any man tame him.
Manx: Er-y-fa dy row Eh dy mennick er ny ve kainlt lesh yiarnyn as geulaghyn, as va ny geulaghyn er ny ve tayrnit veih my-chielley liorish, as ny yiarnyn brisht ayns peeshyn: as cha dod dooinney erbee Eh y smaghtaghey.

English: 5 And always, night and day, he was in the mountains, and in the tombs, crying, and cutting himself with stones.
Manx: As kinjagh oie as laa v’eh ayns ny sleïtyn, as mastey ny hoaiaghyn, geamagh as dy yiarey Eh hene lesh claghyn.

English: 6 But when he saw Jesus afar off, he ran and worshipped him,
Manx: Agh tra honnick Eh Yeesey foddey ass y raad, roih Eh as hug Eh ooashley da,

English: 7 And cried with a loud voice, and said, What have I to do with thee, Jesus, thou Son of the most high God? I adjure thee by God, that thou torment me not.
Manx: As deïe Eh lesh ard choraa, as dooyrt Eh, Cre’n eïe t’ayd orrym, Yeesey, Vac yn Jee smoo ard? Ta mee cur currym ort, ayns ennym Yee, gyn oo dy my horchaghey.

English: 8 For he said unto him, Come out of the man, thou unclean spirit.
Manx: (Son v’eh er ghra rish, Tar magh ass y dooinney, uss spyrryd neu-ghlen)

English: 9 And he asked him, What is thy name? And he answered, saying, My name is Legion: for we are many.
Manx: As dênee Eh jeh, Cre’n ennym t’ort? As dreggyr Eh, gra, Ta m’ennym Legion: son ta shin ymmodee.

English: 10 And he besought him much that he would not send them away out of the country.
Manx: As ren Eh aghin jeean huggey, gyn Eh dy chur ad ersooyl ass y cheer.

English: 11 Now there was there nigh unto the mountains a great herd of swine feeding.
