Manx: Nish va ayns shen ergerrey da ny sleïtyn, griagh mooar dy vuckyn fo bochillyn.

English: 12 And all the devils besought him, saying, Send us into the swine, that we may enter into them.
Manx: As ghuee ooilley ny drogh-spyrrydyn er, gra, Eiyr shin gys ny muckyn, dy vod mad goll stiagh ayndoo.

English: 13 And forthwith Jesus gave them leave. And the unclean spirits went out, and entered into the swine: and the herd ran violently down a steep place into the sea, (they were about two thousand;) and were choked in the sea.
Manx: As chelleeragh hug Yeesey kied daue. As hie ny spyrrydyn neu-ghlen magh, as hie ad stiagh ayns ny muckyn, as roih yn ghriagh gouyr nyn mullee lesh yn ughtagh gys y cheayn (v’ad mygeayrt daa housane) as v’ad plooghit ayns y cheayn.

English: 14 And they that fed the swine fled, and told it in the city, and in the country. And they went out to see what it was that was done.
Manx: As roih bochillyn ny muckyn roue, as dinsh ad eh ayns yn ard-valley, as er y cheer. As hie ad magh dy akin cre va jeant.

English: 15 And they come to Jesus, and see him that was possessed with the devil, and had the legion, sitting, and clothed, and in his right mind: and they were afraid.
Manx: As haink ad gys Yeesey, as honnick ad eshyn va’n drogh-spyrryd, as y legion er ny ve ayn, ny hoie, as e eaddagh er, as dy mie ayns e cheeal, as ghow ad aggle.

English: 16 And they that saw it told them how it befell to him that was possessed with the devil, and also concerning the swine.
Manx: As dinsh y vooinjer honnick eh daue, kys ve er daghyrt dasyn va’n drogh-spyrryd er ve ayn, as myrgeddin mychione ny muckyn.

English: 17 And they began to pray him to depart out of their coasts.
Manx: As ren ad toshiaght dy ghuee er, Eh dy gholl roish ass ny ardjyn oc.

English: 18 And when he was come into the ship, he that had been possessed with the devil prayed him that he might be with him.
Manx: As tra v’eh er jeet gys y lhong, ren eshyn va’n drogh spyrryd er ve ayn guee er, kied y chur da goll marish.

English: 19 Howbeit Jesus suffered him not, but saith unto him, Go home to thy friends, and tell them how great things the Lord hath done for thee, and hath had compassion on thee.
Manx: Agh cha lig Yeesey da, agh dooyrt Eh rish, Gow thie gys dty vooinjer hene, as insh daue cre ny reddyn mooarey ta’n Chiarn er n’yannoo er dty hon, as dy vel chymmey er ve echey ort.

English: 20 And he departed, and began to publish in Decapolis how great things Jesus had done for him: and all men did marvel.
Manx: As jimmee Eh roish, as ren Eh toshiaght dy hoilshaghey magh ayns Decapolis, cre ny reddyn mooarey va Yeesey er n’yannoo er y hon: as ghow dy chooilley ghooinney yindyss.

English: 21 And when Jesus was passed over again by ship unto the other side, much people gathered unto him: and he was nigh unto the sea.
Manx: As tra va Yeesey er gholl harrish reesht ayns y lhong gys y cheu elley, va earroo mooar dy leih er nyn jaglym cooidjagh huggey, as v’eh ergerrey da’n cheayn.

English: 22 And, behold, there cometh one of the rulers of the synagogue, Jairus by name; and when he saw him, he fell at his feet,
Manx: As cur-my-ner, haink fer jeh fir-reïl ny killagh va enmyssit Jairus, as tra honnick Eh Eh, huit Eh sheese ec e chassyn,

English: 23 And besought him greatly, saying, My little daughter lieth at the point of death: I pray thee, come and lay thy hands on her, that she may be healed; and she shall live.
Manx: As ghuee Eh er dy jeean, gra, Ta m’inneen veg ny lhie raad y vaaish, tar as cur dty laueyn urree, dy vod ee v’er ny lheihys, as bee ee bio.

English: 24 And Jesus went with him; and much people followed him, and thronged him.
Manx: As hie Yeesey marish, as deiyr ymmodee dy leih, as ren ad chionney stiagh er.

English: 25 And a certain woman, which had an issue of blood twelve years,
Manx: As va ben dy row va roih-foalley er ve eck rish daa vleïn jeig.

English: 26 And had suffered many things of many physicians, and had spent all that she had, and was nothing bettered, but rather grew worse,
Manx: As v’ee er hurranse mooarane liorish ymmodee ymmodee lheeghyn, as er vaarail ooilley ny v’eck, as cha row ee veg share, agh ny smoo laik dy ve ny smessey,

English: 27 When she had heard of Jesus, came in the press behind, and touched his garment.
Manx: Tra cheayll ee jeh Yeesey, haink ee ayns y chennid cheu y chooylloo, as venn ee rish e gharmad.

English: 28 For she said, If I may touch but his clothes, I shall be whole.
Manx: Son dooyrt ee, My oddym agh bennaylt rish e eaddagh, bee’m er my laanaghey.

English: 29 And straightway the fountain of her blood was dried up; and she felt in her body that she was healed of that plague.
Manx: As chelleeragh ren farrane yn uill eck chyrmaghey: as dennee ee ayns e corp dy row ee er ny lheihys jeh’n doghan shen.

English: 30 And Jesus, immediately knowing in himself that virtue had gone out of him, turned him about in the press, and said, Who touched my clothes?
Manx: As chelleeragh va fys ec Yeesey cheu-sthie jeh hene, dy row bree er gholl ass, as hyndaa Eh mygeayrt ayns y chennid, as dooyrt Eh, Quoi venn rish m’eaddagh?

English: 31 And his disciples said unto him, Thou seest the multitude thronging thee, and sayest thou, Who touched me?
Manx: As dooyrt y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er rish, T’ow fakin y pobble chionney stiagh ort, as t’ow gra, Quoi venn rhym?

English: 32 And he looked round about to see her that had done this thing.
Manx: As yeeagh Eh mygeayrt dy akin ish v’er n’yannoo shoh.

English: 33 But the woman fearing and trembling, knowing what was done in her, came and fell down before him, and told him all the truth.
Manx: Agh va’n ven agglagh as er-creau, liorish dy row fys eck cre va jeant ayn-jee, as haink ee as huit ee sheese kiongoyrt rish, as dinsh ee da ooilley’n irriney.

English: 34 And he said unto her, Daughter, thy faith hath made thee whole; go in peace, and be whole of thy plague.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh ree, Inneen, ta dty chredjue er dty laanaghey; immee ayns shee, as bee slaane jeh dty ghoghan.

English: 35 While he yet spake, there came from the ruler of the synagogue's house certain which said, Thy daughter is dead: why troublest thou the Master any further?
Manx: Choud as v’eh foast loayrt, haink feallagh veih fer-reil ny killagh, dooyrt rish, Ta dt’inneen marroo, cre slias dhyt yn Mainshtyr y hrublal veg sodjey?

English: 36 As soon as Jesus heard the word that was spoken, he saith unto the ruler of the synagogue, Be not afraid, only believe.
Manx: Tra va Yeesey er chlashtyn yn fockle va loayrit, dooyrt Eh rish fer-reïl ny killagh, Ny gow aggle, ny lomarcan jean credjal.

English: 37 And he suffered no man to follow him, save Peter, and James, and John the brother of James.
Manx: As cha lig Eh da dooinney erbee cheet geiyrt er, cheu-mooie jeh Peddyr, as Jamys, as Ean braar Jamys.

English: 38 And he cometh to the house of the ruler of the synagogue, and seeth the tumult, and them that wept and wailed greatly.
Manx: As haink Eh gys thie fer-reïl ny killagh, as hug Eh tastey da’n yllaghey as yn eamagh oc, as dy row ad keaney as jannoo dobberan mooar.

English: 39 And when he was come in, he saith unto them, Why make ye this ado, and weep? the damsel is not dead, but sleepeth.
Manx: As tra v’eh er jeet stiagh, dooyrt Eh roo, Kys dy vel shiu goaill leid yn yllaghey as y cheayney erriu? cha vel y ven-aeg marroo, agh ny cadley.

English: 40 And they laughed him to scorn. But when he had put them all out, he taketh the father and the mother of the damsel, and them that were with him, and entereth in where the damsel was lying.
Manx: As hie ad son craidey mysh, agh tra v’eh er chur ad ooilley magh, ghow Eh ayr as moir yn ven-aeg, as adsyn va marish, as hie Eh stiagh raad va’n ven-aeg ny lhie.

English: 41 And he took the damsel by the hand, and said unto her, Talitha cumi; which is, being interpreted, Damsel, I say unto thee, arise.
Manx: As ghow Eh yn ven-aeg er laue, as dooyrt eh ree, Talitha cumi, ta shen, dy chur bun er, Ven-aeg (ta mee gra rhyt) irree.

English: 42 And straightway the damsel arose, and walked; for she was of the age of twelve years. And they were astonished with a great astonishment.
Manx: As chelleeragh dirree yn ven-aeg, as hooyl ee; son v’ee daa vleïn jeig dy eash: as v’ad er-skyn towse atchimagh.

English: 43 And he charged them straitly that no man should know it; and commanded that something should be given her to eat.
Manx: As hug Eh currym gyere daue, nagh voghe dooinney erbee fys er: as hug Eh saarey red ennagh dy ve er ny choyrt jee dy ee.
CAB. VI.

English: And he went out from thence, and came into his own country; and his disciples follow him.
Manx: As hie Eh magh veih shen, as haink Eh gys e heer hene, as deiyr y vooinjer va sheer marish er.

English: 2 And when the sabbath day was come, he began to teach in the synagogue: and many hearing him were astonished, saying, From whence hath this man these things? and what wisdom is this which is given unto him, that even such mighty works are wrought by his hands?
Manx: As tra va’n doonaght er jeet ren Eh toshiaght dy ynsaghey ayns y cheeill: as va ymmodee jeusyn va dy chlashtyn Eh atchimagh, gra, Cre woish ta ny reddyn shoh ec y dooinney shoh? as cre’n chreenaght shoh t’er ny choyrt da, dy vel leid ny obbraghyn niartal er nyn obbraghey liorish ny laueyn echey?

English: 3 Is not this the carpenter, the son of Mary, the brother of James, and Joses, and of Juda, and Simon? and are not his sisters here with us? And they were offended at him.
Manx: Nagh nee shoh yn seyr, mac Voirrey, braar Jamys as Jeses [sic: Joses], as Juda as Simon, as nagh vel ny shairaghyn echey ayns shoh mârin? As v’ad jymmoosagh rish.

English: But Jesus, said unto them, A prophet is not without honour, but in his own country, and among his own kin, and in his own house.
Manx: 4 Agh dooyrt Yeesey roo, Cha vel phadeyr fegooish ooashley, agh ayns e heer hene, as mastey e chynney hene, as ayns e hie hene.

English: 5 And he could there do no mighty work, save that he laid his hands upon a few sick folk, and healed them.
Manx: As cha dod Eh mirril erbee y obbraghey ayns shen, cheu-mooie jeh dy dug Eh e laueyn er regyryn dy leih chingey as dy ren Eh ad y lheihys.

English: And he marvelled because of their unbelief. And he went round about the villages, teaching.
Manx: 6. As ghow Eh yindyss jeh’n vee-chredjue oc. As hie Eh mygeayrt ny baljyn beggey oc, gynsaghey.

English: 7 ¶And he called unto him the twelve, and began to send them forth by two and two; and gave them power over unclean spirits;
Manx: As deïe Eh er y daa ostyl yeig huggey, as ren Eh toshiaght dy chur ad magh jees as jees, as hug Eh daue pooar harrish spyrrydyn neu-ghlen,

English: 8 And commanded them that they should take nothing for their journey, save a staff only; no scrip, no bread, no money in their purse:
Manx: As saarey gyn ad dy ghoaill red erbee son nyn yurnah, agh ynrycan lorg: gyn ad dy ghoaill spagey, ny arran, ny argid ayns nyn sporran:

English: 9 But be shod with sandals; and not put on two coats.
Manx: Agh dy chur nyn mraagyn orroo, as gyn ad dy chur orroo daa chooat.

English: 10 And he said unto them, In what place soever ye enter into an house, there abide till ye depart from that place.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Raad erbee dy jed shiu stiagh ayns thie, fuirree-jee ayn derrey aagys shiu yn ynnyd shen.

English: 11 And whosoever shall not receive you, nor hear you, when ye depart thence, shake off the dust under your feet for a testimony against them. Verily I say unto you, It shall be more tolerable for Sodom and Gomorrha in the day of judgment, than for that city.
Manx: As quoi-erbee nagh jean nyn mea y oltaghey, ny geill y choyrt da ny goan eu, tra vees shiu goll reue, crie-jee yn joan ta fo ny cassyn eu, dy ve son feanish nyn oi oc. Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Dy vow Sodom as Gomorrah ny smoo dy foayr ec laa ny briwnys, na yiow yn ard-valley shen.

English: 12 And they went out, and preached that men should repent.
Manx: As hie ad magh, as ren ad preacheil, arrys dy ve er ny ghoaill.

English: 13 And they cast out many devils, and anointed with oil many that were sick, and healed them.
Manx: As deiyr ad magh ymmodee drogh-spyrrydyn, as dooillee ad lesh ooill ymmodee sleih va ching, as ren ad ad y laanaghey.

English: 14 And king Herod heard of him; (for his name was spread abroad:) and he said, That John the Baptist was risen from the dead, and therefore mighty works do shew forth themselves in him.
Manx: As cheayll ree Herod jeh (son va’n goo echey er gholl magh) as dooyrt Eh, Dy row Ean Bashtey er n’irree veih ny merriu, as er-yn-oyr shen dy row mirrillyn er nyn obbraghey liorish.

English: 15 Others said, That it is Elias. And others said, That it is a prophet, or as one of the prophets.
Manx: Dooyrt paart dy leih, Dy nee Elias v’ayn: dooyrt feallagh elley, Dy nee phadeyr v’eh, ny myr annane jeh ny phadeyryn.

English: 16 But when Herod heard thereof, he said, It is John, whom I beheaded: he is risen from the dead.
Manx: Agh tra cheayll Herod jeh, dooyrt Eh, She Ean Bashtey t’ayn, hug mish y kione jeh, t’eh er n’irree veih ny merriu.

English: 17 For Herod himself had sent forth and laid hold upon John, and bound him in prison for Herodias’ sake, his brother Philip's wife: for he had married her.
Manx: Son va Herod hene er chur fys magh, as er ghoaill Ean as er chiangley Eh ayns pryssoon, kyndagh rish Herodias, ben e vraar Philip; son v’eh er phoosey ee.

English: 18 For John had said unto Herod, It is not lawful for thee to have thy brother's wife.
Manx: Son va Ean er ghra rish Herod, Cha vel eh lowit dhyt ben dty vraarey y ve ayd son ben.

English: 19 Therefore Herodias had a quarrel against him, and would have killed him; but she could not:
Manx: Shen-y-fa va Herodias ayns goanlys da, as v’ee shirrey y choyrt Eh gy baase, agh cha dod ee caa y gheddyn.

English: 20 For Herod feared John, knowing that he was a just man and an holy, and observed him; and when he heard him, he did many things, and heard him gladly.
Manx: Son va Herod ayns aggle roish Ean, toiggal dy row Eh ny ghooinney cairagh as crauee, as va sooyll echey er, as tra v’eh dy choyrlaghey Eh, v’eh jannoo ymmodee dy reddyn, as dy chlashtyn Eh dy arryltagh.

English: 21 And when a convenient day was come, that Herod on his birthday made a supper to his lords, high captains, and chief estates of Galilee;
Manx: As tra va laa cooie er jeet, dy ren Herod corrym rish y laa ruggyr eh, Shibber y yannoo, son e hiarnyn, ard chaptanyn, as ny deiney byrjey Galilee:

English: 22 And when the daughter of the said Herodias came in, and danced, and pleased Herod and them that sat with him, the king said unto the damsel, Ask of me whatsoever thou wilt, and I will give it thee.
Manx: As haink inneen Herodias cheddin stiagh, as ren ee donsin, as va Herod as adsyn va marish feer wooiagh jee, as dooyrt y ree rish y ven-aeg, Shir orryms aghin erbee dy naïlt, as giall-ym dhyt eh.

English: 23 And he sware unto her, Whatsoever thou shalt ask of me, I will give it thee, unto the half of my kingdom.
Manx: As loo Eh jee, Cre-erbee hirrys oo orrym, verrym dhyt eh, gys y derrey lieh jeh my reeriaght.

English: 24 And she went forth, and said unto her mother, What shall I ask? And she said, The head of John the Baptist.
Manx: As hiee magh, as dooyrt ee rish e moir, Cre hirrym? As dooyrt ish, Kione Ean Bashtey.

English: 25 And she came in straightway with haste unto the king, and asked, saying, I will that thou give me by and by in a charger the head of John the Baptist.
Manx: As haink ee stiagh chelleeragh lesh siyr gys y ree, as hir ee, gra, Saillym oo dy chur dou nish hene er claare kione Ean Bashtey.

English: 26 And the king was exceeding sorry; yet for his oath's sake, and for their sakes which sat with him, he would not reject her.
Manx: As huit y ree ayns trimshey mooar, ny-yeih er coontey e loo, as y vooinjer va nyn soie marish, cha row Eh booiagh y hobbal ee.

English: 27 And immediately the king sent an executioner, and commanded his head to be brought: and he went and beheaded him in the prison,
Manx: As chelleeragh hug y ree fer jeh ny sidooryn echey, as hug Eh saarey da yn kione y chur lesh: as hie Eh, as hug eh yn kione jeh Ean ayns y phryssoon,

English: 28 And brought his head in a charger, and gave it to the damsel: and the damsel gave it to her mother.
Manx: As hug Eh lesh y kione er claare, as livrey Eh eh gys y ven aeg: as livrey ish eh gys e moir.

English: 29 And when his disciples heard of it, they came and took up his corpse, and laid it in a tomb.
Manx: As tra cheayll yn vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er jeh, haink ad as hrog ad yn corp echey, as doanluck ad eh ayns oaie.

English: 30 And the apostles gathered themselves together unto Jesus, and told him all things, both what they had done, and what they had taught.
Manx: As haink ny ostyllyn cooidjagh gys Yeesey, as dinsh ad da dy chooilley nhee, chammah cre v’ad er n’yannoo, as cre v’ad er n’ynsaghey.

English: 31 And he said unto them, Come ye yourselves apart into a desert place, and rest a while: for there were many coming and going, and they had no leisure so much as to eat.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Tar-jee shiuish er-lheh gys boayl faasagh, as gow-jee tammylt dy nyn aash: son va ymmodee cheet as goll, as cha row caa oc wheesh as dy ee.

English: 32 And they departed into a desert place by ship privately.
Manx: As jimmee ad ayns lhong gys ynnyd faasagh er-lheh.

English: 33 And the people saw them departing, and many knew him, and ran afoot thither out of all cities, and outwent them, and came together unto him.
Manx: As honnick y pobble ad goll roue, as hug ymmodee enney er, as roih ad gys shen rish nyn gosh veih dy chooilley ard-valley, as v’ad ayn roue, as haink ad cooidjagh huggey.

English: 34 And Jesus, when he came out, saw much people, and was moved with compassion toward them, because they were as sheep not having a shepherd: and he began to teach them many things.
Manx: As tra va Yeesey er jeet magh honnick Eh earroo mooar dy leih, as v’eh er ny veiyghey lesh chymmey orroo, er-yn-oyr dy row ad myr kirree fegooish bochilley: as ren Eh toshiaght dy ynsaghey daue ymmodee reddyn.

English: 35 And when the day was now far spent, his disciples came unto him, and said, This is a desert place, and now the time is far passed:
Manx: As tra va’n laa nish foddey baarit, kaink [sic: haink] y vooinjey va sheer geiyrt er huggey, as dooyrt ad, Shoh boayl faasagh, as ta’n traa nish er gholl foddey shiaghey:

English: 36 Send them away, that they may go into the country round about, and into the villages, and buy themselves bread: for they have nothing to eat.
Manx: Lig y raad daue, dy vod ad goll er y cheer mygeayrt, as gys ny baljyn-beggey, dy chionnaghey arran daue hene: son cha vel veg y veaghey oc.

English: 37 He answered and said unto them, Give ye them to eat. And they say unto him, Shall we go and buy two hundred pennyworth of bread, and give them to eat?
Manx: As dreggyr eshyn as dooyrt Eh roo, Cur-jee shiuish bee daue. As dooyrt ad rish, Jemmad dy chionnaghey feagh daa cheead ping dy arran, as bee y chur daue?

English: 38 He saith unto them, How many loaves have ye? go and see. And when they knew, they say, Five, and two fishes.
Manx: Dooyrt Eh roo, Cre-woad bwilleen t’eu? gow-jee as jeeagh-jee. As tra va fys oc, dooyrt ad, Queig, as daa eeast.

English: 39 And he commanded them to make all sit down by companies upon the green grass.
Manx: As hug Eh saarey ad dy chur orroo ooilley soie sheese ayns sheshaghtyn er yn nhaiyr ghlass.

English: 40 And they sat down in ranks, by hundreds, and by fifties.
Manx: As hoie ad sheese ayns roaghyn keead as lieh-cheead ayns roa.

English: 41 And when he had taken the five loaves and the two fishes, he looked up to heaven, and blessed, and brake the loaves, and gave them to his disciples to set before them; and the two fishes divided he among them all.
Manx: As tra v’eh er ghoaill ny queig bwilleenyn as y daa eeast, yeeagh Eh seose gys niau, as vannee Eh, as vrish Eh ny bwilleenyn, as hug Eh ad dauesyn va sheer geiyrt er dy hoiaghey rymboo; as y daa eeast reynn eh nyn mast’ oc ooilley.

English: 42 And they did all eat, and were filled.
Manx: As ren ad ooilley gee, as v’ad er nyn yannoo magh.

English: 43 And they took up twelve baskets full of the fragments, and of the fishes.
Manx: As hrog ad jeh’n fooillagh daag ad as jeh ny heeastyn laane daa vasket jeig.

English: 44 And they that did eat of the loaves were about five thousand men.
Manx: As v’adsyn v’er n’ee jeh ny bwilleenyn, mygeayrt queig thousane dooinney.

English: 45 And straightway he constrained his disciples to get into the ship, and to go to the other side before unto Bethsaida, while he sent away the people.
Manx: As chelleeragh hug Eh er y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er, luingys y ghoaill, as ad dy gholl roish gys y cheu elley gys Bethsaida, choud as v’eh cur y pobble ersooyl.

English: 46 And when he had sent them away, he departed into a mountain to pray.
Manx: As tra v’eh er chur ad ersooyl, hie Eh seose er slieau dy ghoaill padjer.

English: 47 And when even was come, the ship was in the midst of the sea, and he alone on the land.
Manx: As tra va’n fastyr er jeet, va’n lhong ayns main ny marrey, as eshyn ny lomarcan er y thalloo.

English: 48 And he saw them toiling in rowing; for the wind was contrary unto them: and about the fourth watch of the night he cometh unto them, walking upon the sea, and would have passed by them.
Manx: As honnick Eh ad tooileil ayns gymmyrt; (son va’n gheay nyn oi oc) as mygeayrt y chiarroo ghoostey jeh’n oie, haink Eh huc shooyl er y cheayn, as ballish v’er gholl shiaghoo.

English: 49 But when they saw him walking upon the sea, they supposed it had been a spirit, and cried out:
Manx: Agh tra honnick ad Eh shooyl er y cheayn, heïll ad dy nee scaan v’ayn, as deïe ad.

English: 50 For they all saw him, and were troubled. And immediately he talked with them, and saith unto them, Be of good cheer: it is I; be not afraid.
Manx: (Son honnick ad ooilley Eh, as v’ad seaghnit.) As chelleeragh loayr Eh roo, as dooyrt Eh roo, Bee-jee dy yien mie, She mish t’ayn, ny gow-jee aggle.

English: 51 And he went up unto them into the ship; and the wind ceased: and they were sore amazed in themselves beyond measure, and wondered.
Manx: As hie Eh seose ’sy lhong huc, as ghow yn gheay fea: as v’ad feer atchimagh ayndoo hene er-skyn towse, as goaill yindyss.

English: 52 For they considered not the miracle of the loaves: for their heart was hardened.
Manx: Son cha smooinee ad er ny bwilleenyn, son va’n cree oc er ny chreoghey.

English: 53 And when they had passed over, they came into the land of Gennesaret, and drew to the shore.
Manx: As tra v’ad er gholl harrish, haink ad gys cheer Gennesaret, as hayrn ad gys thalloo.

English: 54 And when they were come out of the ship, straightway they knew him,
Manx: As tra v’ad er jeet ass y lhong, chelleeragh hug y sleih enney er,

English: 55 And ran through that whole region round about, and began to carry about in beds those that were sick, where they heard he was.
Manx: As roih ad trooid ooilley’n cheer mygeayrt, as ren ad toshiaght dy chur lhieu ayns lhiabbaghyn adsyn va ching, raad v’ad clashtyn v’eh.

English: 56 And whithersoever he entered, into villages, or cities, or country, they laid the sick in the streets, and besought him that they might touch if it were but the border of his garment: and as many as touched him were made whole.
Manx: As raad erbee dy row Eh goll, gys baljyn-beggey, ny ard-valjyn, ny er y cheer, v’ad cur sleih chingey nyn lhie ayns ny straadjyn, as guee er, ad ny lomarcan dy vennaylt rish oirr e gharmad: as whilleen as venn rish, v’ad er nyn lheiys.
CAB. VII.

English: Then came together unto him the Pharisees, and certain of the scribes, which came from Jerusalem.
Manx: Eisht haink cooidjagh huggey ny Phariseeyn as shiartance jeh ny scruderyn, haink veih Jerusalem.

English: 2 And when they saw some of his disciples eat bread with defiled, that is to say, with unwashen, hands, they found fault.
Manx: As tra honnick ad paart jeusyn va kinjagh mârish gee arran lesh laueyn neu-ghlen (ta shen dy ghra lesh laueyn nagh row ad erreish y niee;) hooar ad foill.

English: 3 For the Pharisees, and all the Jews, except they wash their hands oft, eat not, holding the tradition of the elders.
Manx: Son ny Phariseeyn, as ooilley ny Hewnyn, mannagh vel ad dy mennick niee nyn laueyn, cha vel ad gee, cummal seose oardaghyn y chanstyr.

English: 4 And when they come from the market, except they wash, they eat not. And many other things there be, which they have received to hold, as the washing of cups, and pots, brasen vessels, and of tables.
Manx: As tra t’ad cheet thie veih’n vargey, cha vel ad gee, derrey t’ad neeit. As ta ymmodee dy reddyn elley, t’ad er ghoaill orroo dy reaylley, niee cappanyn as siyn cray, siyn prash, as buird.

English: 5 Then the Pharisees and scribes asked him, Why walk not thy disciples according to the tradition of the elders, but eat bread with unwashen hands?
Manx: Eisht dênee ny Phariseeyn as ny scruderyn jeh, Cre’n-fa nagh vel y vooinjer ta sheer geiyrt orts freaylley oardaghyn y chanstyr, agh t’ad gee arran lesh laueyn nagh vel ad dy niee?

English: 6 He answered and said unto them, Well hath Esaias prophesied of you hypocrites, as it is written, This people honoureth me with their lips, but their heart is far from me.
Manx: Dreggyr eshyn as dooyrt Eh roo, S’mie ren Esaias phadeyrys jiuish, chrauee-oalsey, myr te scruit, Ta’n pobble shoh cur ooashley dou lesh nyn meyllyn, agh ta’n cree oc foddey voym.

English: 7 Howbeit in vain do they worship me, teaching for doctrines the commandments of men.
Manx: Ny-yeih, ayns fardail t’ad cur ooashley dou, gynsaghey son y goo ayms oardaghyn deiney.

English: 8 For laying aside the commandment of God, ye hold the tradition of men, as the washing of pots and cups: and many other such like things ye do.
Manx: Son ta shiu cur dy lhiattee saarey Yee, as freaylley oardaghyn deiney, niee siyn cray as cappanyn: as ymmodee dy reddyn elley dy leid shen ta shiu dy yannoo.

English: 9 And he said unto them, Full well ye reject the commandment of God, that ye may keep your own tradition.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, S’mie ta shiu jannoo saarey Yee gyn vree, dy vod shiu ny oardaghyn eu hene y reaylley.

English: 10 For Moses said, Honour thy father and thy mother; and, Whoso curseth father or mother, let him die the death:
Manx: Son ta Moses er ghra, Cur arrym da dt’ayr as da dty voir: as, Eshyn ta gweeaghyn da ayr ny moir, lig Eh ve kerrit lesh baase.

English: 11 But ye say, If a man shall say to his father or mother, It is Corban, that is to say, a gift, by whatsoever thou mightest be profited by me; he shall be free.
Manx: Agh ta shiuish gra, My jir dooinney rish e ayr ny e voir, She Corban eh, ta shen dy ghra, Yn feaysley shen oddagh uss jerkal rish voym’s, te gioot er ny hebbal da Jee:

English: 12 And ye suffer him no more to do ought for his father or his mother;
Manx: As cha vel shiu lhiggey da red erbee sodjey y yannoo son e ayr ny e voir:

English: 13 Making the word of God of none effect through your tradition, which ye have delivered: and many such like things do ye.
Manx: Jannoo goo Yee gyn vree trooid ny oardaghyn eu, ta shiu er ny livrey: as ymmodee dy leid ny reddyn shoh ta shiu dy yannoo.

English: 14 ¶And when he had called all the people unto him, he said unto them, Hearken unto me every one of you, and understand:
Manx: As tra v’eh er n’eamagh er ooilley yn pobble huggey, dooyrt Eh roo, Eaisht-jee ooilley rhyms, as toig-jee.

English: 15 There is nothing from without a man, that entering into him can defile him: but the things which come out of him, those are they that defile the man.
Manx: Cha vel nhee erbee veih cheu-mooie jeh dooinney, ta goll stiagh ayn oddys Eh y yannoo neu-ghlen: agh ny reddyn ta cheet magh ass, ad shen ta jannoo dooinney neu-ghlen.

English: 16 If any man have ears to hear, let him hear.
Manx: My ta dooinney erbee as cleashyn echey dy chlashtyn, lig da clashtyn.

English: 17 And when he was entered into the house from the people, his disciples asked him concerning the parable.
Manx: As tra v’eh er gholl stiagh ayns y thie veih’n pobble, dênee yn vooinjer va sheer marish jeh mychione y coraa-dorraghey.

English: 18 And he saith unto them, Are ye so without understanding also? Do ye not perceive, that whatsoever thing from without entereth into the man, it cannot defile him;
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Vel shiuish myrgeddin myr shen fegooish tushtey? Nagh vel shiu foast cur tastey, cre-erbee veih cheu-mooie ta goll stiagh ayns y dooinney, nagh vod eh Eh y yannoo neu-ghlen,

English: 19 Because it entereth not into his heart, but into the belly, and goeth out into the draught, purging all meats?
Manx: Er-y-fa nagh vel eh goll stiagh ayns y chree, agh ayns y volg, as goll magh trooid y chorp, glenney dy chooilley veaghey?

English: 20 And he said, That which cometh out of the man, that defileth the man.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Shen ta cheet magh ass y dooinney, ta jannoo yn dooinney neu-ghlen.

English: 21 For from within, out of the heart of men, proceed evil thoughts, adulteries, fornications, murders,
Manx: Son veih cheu-sthie, magh veih creeaghyn deiney, ta cheet drogh smooinaghtyn, brishey-poosey, maarderys, dunverys,

English: 22 Thefts, covetousness, wickedness, deceit, lasciviousness, an evil eye, blasphemy, pride, foolishness:
Manx: Maarlys, saynt, olkys, molteraght, rouanys, drogh hooyl, goan-mollaghtagh, moyrn, ommijys:

English: 23 All these evil things come from within, and defile the man.
Manx: Ta ooilley ny drogh reddyn shoh cheet veih cheu-sthie, as jannoo yn dooinney neu-ghlen.

English: 24 ¶And from thence he arose, and went into the borders of Tyre and Sidon, and entered into an house, and would have no man know it: but he could not be hid.
Manx: As veih shen dirree Eh, as jimmee Eh gys ardjyn Tyre as Sidon, as hie Eh stiagh ayns thie, as cha ballish fys y ve ec dooinney erbee er; agh cha dod Eh ve kellit.

English: 25 For a certain woman, whose young daughter had an unclean spirit, heard of him, and came and fell at his feet:
Manx: Son va ben dy row, va’n inneen aeg eck as spyrryd neu-ghlen ayn-jee, tra cheayll ee jeh, haink ee as huit ee sheese ec e chassyn:

English: 26 The woman was a Greek, a Syrophenician by nation; and she besought him that he would cast forth the devil out of her daughter.
Manx: (Va’n ven ny Greek, ny Syrophenician liorish ashoon) as ghuee ee er, Eh dy hilgey magh yn drogh-spyrryd ass e hinneen.

English: 27 But Jesus said unto her, Let the children first be filled: for it is not meet to take the children’s bread, and to cast it unto the dogs.
Manx: Agh dooyrt Yeesey ree, Lig da’n chloan ve hoshiaght er nyn yannoo magh: son cha vel eh cooie arran y chloan y ghoaill as y hilgey eh gys moddee.

English: 28 And she answered and said unto him, Yes, Lord: yet the dogs under the table eat of the children’s crumbs.
Manx: As dreggyr ish as dooyrt ee rish, Spheer shen, Hiarn: foast ta ny moddee fo’n voayrd gee brooilliagh y chloan.

English: 29 And he said unto her, For this saying go thy way; the devil is gone out of thy daughter.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh ree, Son y raa shoh, immee royd, ta’n drogh-spyrryd er gholl ass dt’inneen.

English: 30 And when she was come to her house, she found the devil gone out, and her daughter laid upon the bed.
Manx: As tra v’ee er jeet gys y thie eck hene, hooar ee e hinneen ny lhie er y lhiabbee, as y drogh-spyrryd er gholl ass-jee.

English: 31 ¶And again, departing from the coasts of Tyre and Sidon, he came unto the sea of Galilee, through the midst of the coasts of Decapolis.
Manx: As hie Eh reesht veih ardjyn Tyre as Sidon, as haink Eh gys faarkey Ghalilee, trooid main ardjyn Decapolis.

English: 32 And they bring unto him one that was deaf, and had an impediment in his speech; and they beseech him to put his hand upon him.
Manx: As hug ad lhieu huggey dooinney va bouyr, as nagh row e ghlaare cheet dy mie lesh: as ghuee ad er Eh dy chur e laue er.

English: 33 And he took him aside from the multitude, and put his fingers into his ears, and he spit, and touched his tongue;
Manx: As ghow Eh Eh dy lhiattee veih’n pobble, as hug Eh e veïr ayns e chleashyn, as hug Eh magh shelley, as venn Eh rish e hengey.

English: 34 And looking up to heaven, he sighed, and saith unto him, Ephphatha, that is, Be opened.
Manx: As yeeagh Eh seose gys niau, as lig Eh osney, as dooyrt Eh rish, Ephphatha, ta shen, Bee foshlit.

English: 35 And straightway his ears were opened, and the string of his tongue was loosed, and he spake plain.
Manx: As chelleeragh va ny cleashyn echey er nyn vosley, as streng e hengey er ny eaysley, as loayr Eh dy plain.

English: 36 And he charged them that they should tell no man: but the more he charged them, so much the more a great deal they published it;
Manx: As hug Eh currym daue gyn ad dy insh shoh da dooinney erbee: agh myr smoo hug Eh currym daue, shen myr smoo foddey ren adsyn y hoilshaghey eh,

English: 37 And were beyond measure astonished, saying, He hath done all things well: he maketh both the deaf to hear, and the dumb to speak.
Manx: As v’ad er-skyn towse atchimagh, gra, T’eh er n’yannoo dy chooilley nhee dy mie: t’eh cur chammah er ny beuyr dy chlashtyn, as ny balloo dy loayrt.
CAB. VIII.

English: In those days the multitude being very great, and having nothing to eat, Jesus called his disciples unto him, and saith unto them,
Manx: Ayns ny laghyn shen va earroo yn pobble feer vooar, as tra nagh row veg y veaghey oc, deïe Yeesey er y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er huggey, as dooyrt Eh roo:

English: 2 I have compassion on the multitude, because they have now been with me three days, and have nothing to eat:
Manx: Ta chymmey aym’s er y pobble, er-yn-oyr dy vel ad er ny ve mârym nish three laa, as nagh vel veg oc dy ee:

English: 3 And if I send them away fasting to their own houses, they will faint by the way: for divers of them came from far.
Manx: As my verrym ad ersooyl nyn drostey gys nyn dhieyn hene, ver ad naardey er y raad: son ta paart jeu er jeet veih foddey.

English: 4 And his disciples answered him, From whence can a man satisfy these men with bread here in the wilderness?
Manx: As dreggyr y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er Eh, Cre woish oddys dooinney ad shoh y yannoo magh lesh arran ayns shoh ayns yn aasagh?

English: 5 And he asked them, How many loaves have ye? And they said, Seven.
Manx: As dênee Eh jeu, Cre-woad bwilleen t’eu? As dooyrt adsyn, Shiaght.

English: 6 And he commanded the people to sit down on the ground: and he took the seven loaves, and gave thanks, and brake, and gave to his disciples to set before them; and they did set them before the people.
Manx: As doardee Eh da’n pobble soie sheese er y thalloo: as ghow Eh ny shiaght bwilleenyn, as hug Eh booise, as vrish Eh, as hug Eh ad dauesyn va sheer geiyrt er dy hoiaghey rhymboo; as hoie ad ad roish y pobble.

English: 7 And they had a few small fishes: and he blessed, and commanded to set them also before them.
Manx: As va beggan dy eeastyn beggey oc: as vannee Eh, as hug Eh saarey dy hoiaghey ad shen myrgeddin rhymboo.

English: 8 So they did eat, and were filled: and they took up of the broken meat that was left seven baskets.
Manx: Myr shen ren ad gee, as v’ad er nyn yannoo magh, as hrog ad jeh’n fooillagh va er-mayrn, laane shiaght baskettyn.

English: And they that had eaten were about four thousand: and he sent them away.
Manx: [9] As v’adsyn ren gee mysh kiare thousaneyn, as hug Eh ad ersooyl.

English: 10 ¶And straightway he entered into a ship with his disciples, and came into the parts of Dalmanutha.
Manx: As chelleeragh hie Eh ayns lhong maroosyn va sheer geiyrt er, as haink Eh gys ardjyn Dalmanutha.

English: 11 And the Pharisees came forth, and began to question with him, seeking of him a sign from heaven, tempting him.
Manx: As haink ny Phariseeyn magh, as ren ad toshiaght dy ênaght questionyn jeh, as dy hirrey er cowrey veih niau, er-chee Eh y violaghey.

English: 12 And he sighed deeply in his spirit, and saith, Why doth this generation seek after a sign? verily I say unto you, There shall no sign be given unto this generation.
Manx: As lig Eh osney hrome ayns e spyrryd, as dooyrt Eh, Cre’n-fa ta’n cheeloghe shoh shirrey cowrey? dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Nagh bee cowrey er ny choyrt da’n cheeloghe shoh.

English: 13 And he left them, and entering into the ship again departed to the other side.
Manx: As daag Eh ad, as ghow Eh luingys reesht, as haink Eh gys y cheu elley.

English: 14 ¶Now the disciples had forgotten to take bread, neither had they in the ship with them more than one loaf.
Manx: Nish v’adsyn va kinjagh geiyrt er er yarrood arran y chur lhieu, as cha row oc ayns y lhong mâroo agh un willeen.

English: 15 And he charged them, saying, Take heed, beware of the leaven of the Pharisees, and of the leaven of Herod.
Manx: As hug Eh currym daue, gra[,] Cur-jee twoaie, gow-jee tastey jeh soorit ny Phariseeyn, as jeh soorit Herod.

English: 16 And they reasoned among themselves, saying, It is because we have no bread.
Manx: As loayr ad eddyr ad hene, gra, Ta shoh er-yn-oyr nagh vel arran ain.

English: 17 And when Jesus knew it, he saith unto them, Why reason ye, because ye have no bread? perceive ye not yet, neither understand? have ye your heart yet hardened?
Manx: As tra va fys ec Yeesey er, dooyrt Eh roo, Cre’n-fa ta shiu imneagh, er-yn-oyr nagh vel arran eu? nagh vel shiu foast cur tastey, ny toiggal? vel y cree eu foast moall ayns tushtey?

English: 18 Having eyes, see ye not? and having ears, hear ye not? and do ye not remember?
Manx: Shiuish ta sooyllyn eu, nagh vel shiu fakin? as cleashyn, nagh vel shiu clashtyn? as nagh vel eh eu ayns cooinaghtyn?

English: 19 When I brake the five loaves among five thousand, how many baskets full of fragments took ye up? They say unto him, Twelve.
Manx: Tra vrish mish ny queig bwilleenyn mastey queig thousaneyn, cre whilleen basket d’ooillagh hrog shiu? Dooyrt ad rish, Daa vasket jeig.

English: 20 And when the seven among four thousand, how many baskets full of fragments took ye up? And they said, Seven.
Manx: As tra vrish mee ny shiaght mastey kiare thousaneyn, cre whilleen basket d’ooillagh hrog shiu? As dooyrt adsyn, Shiaght.

English: 21 And he said unto them, How is it that ye do not understand?
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Kys te nagh vel shiu goaill tushtey?

English: 22 ¶And he cometh to Bethsaida; and they bring a blind man unto him, and besought him to touch him.
Manx: As haink Eh gys Bethsaida, as hug ad lhieu dooinney doal huggey, as ghuee ad er Eh dy vennaylt rish.

English: 23 And he took the blind man by the hand, and led him out of the town; and when he had spit on his eyes, and put his hands upon him, he asked him if he saw ought.
Manx: As ghow Eh yn dooinney doal er laue, as leeid Eh Eh magh ass y valley; as tra v’eh er chur shelley er e hooyllyn, as er chur e laueyn er, dênee Eh jeh row Eh fakin red erbee.

English: 24 And he looked up, and said, I see men as trees, walking.
Manx: As yeeagh Eh seose, as dooyrt Eh, Hee-ym deiney shooyl myr biljyn.

English: 25 After that he put his hands again upon his eyes, and made him look up: and he was restored, and saw every man clearly.
Manx: Ny lurg shen, hug Eh e laueyn reesht er e hooyllyn, as hug Eh er jeeaghyn seose: as hooar Eh e hoilshey, as honnick Eh dy chooilley ghooinney dy plain.

English: 26 And he sent him away to his house, saying, Neither go into the town, nor tell it to any in the town.
Manx: As hug Eh Eh ersooyl gys e hie, gra, Ny gow stiagh ayns y valley, cha-moo inshys oo eh da annane erbee ayns y valley.

English: 27 ¶And Jesus went out, and his disciples, into the towns of Caesarea Philippi: and by the way he asked his disciples, saying unto them, Whom do men say that I am?
Manx: As hie Yeesey as y vooinjer va kinjagh geiyrt er magh gys baljyn Cesarea Philippi: as er y raad dênee Eh jeu, gra, Cre ta deiney dy ghra my my-chiones, quoi mee?

English: 28 And they answered, John the Baptist; but some say, Elias; and others, One of the prophets.
Manx: As dreggyr ad, Ean Bashtey: agh ta paart gra, Elias; as feallagh elley, Annane jeh ny phadeyryn.

English: 29 And he saith unto them, But whom say ye that I am? And Peter answereth and saith unto him, Thou art the Christ.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Agh quoi ta shiuish dy ghra mee? As dreggyr Peddyr as dooyrt Eh rish, Oo yn Creest.

English: 30 And he charged them that they should tell no man of him.
Manx: As hug Eh currym daue, gyn ad dy insh da dooinney erbee quoi v’eh.

English: 31 And he began to teach them, that the Son of man must suffer many things, and be rejected of the elders, and of the chief priests, and scribes, and be killed, and after three days rise again.
Manx: As ren Eh toshiaght dy chur roue, dy row yn Mac dooinney dy hurranse ymmodee dy reddyn, as dy ve beg soit jeh liorish y chanstyr, as ny ard-saggyrtyn as ny scruderyn, as dy ve er ny choyrt gy baase, as kione y tress laa dy irree reesht.

English: 32 And he spake that saying openly. And Peter took him, and began to rebuke him.
Manx: As loayr Eh yn raa shoh dy foshlit. As ghow Peddyr Eh, as ren Eh toshiaght dy chur oghsan da.

English: 33 But when he had turned about and looked on his disciples, he rebuked Peter, saying, Get thee behind me, Satan: for thou savourest not the things that be of God, but the things that be of men.
Manx: Agh tra v’eh er jyndaa mygeayrt, as er yeeaghyn orroosyn va kinjagh marish, hug eshyn oghsan da Peddyr, gra, Ass my enish, Noid-anmey: son cha vel ennaghtyn ayd jeh ny reddyn ta bentyn rish Jee, agh jeh ny reddyn ta bentyn rish deiney.

English: 34 ¶And when he had called the people unto him with his disciples also, he said unto them, Whosoever will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross, and follow me.
Manx: As tra v’eh er n’eamagh er y pobble huggey, marish y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er, dooyrt Eh roo, Quoi-erbee ta booiagh geiyrt orryms, lig da Eh hene y obbal, as e chrosh y hroggal, as geiyrt orrym.

English: 35 For whosoever will save his life shall lose it; but whosoever shall lose his life for my sake and the gospel's, the same shall save it.
Manx: Son quoi-erbee ballish e vioys y hauail, caillee Eh eh; agh quoi-erbee chaillys e vioys er my ghraih’s as graih’n sushtal, sauee Eh eh.

English: 36 For what shall it profit a man, if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own soul?
Manx: Son cre’n vondeish vees ec dooinney, my chosnys Eh yn seihll ooilley, as e annym hene y choall?

English: 37 Or what shall a man give in exchange for his soul?
Manx: Ny cre nee dooinney y choyrt ayns coonrey son e annym?

English: 38 Whosoever therefore shall be ashamed of me and of my words in this adulterous and sinful generation; of him also shall the Son of man be ashamed, when he cometh in the glory of his Father with the holy angels.
Manx: Quoi-erbee er-y-fa shen ghoys nearey roym’s, as roish my ghoan, ayns y cheeloghe oainjyragh as peccoil shoh, roishyn myrgeddin ghoys yn Mac dooinney nearey, tra hig Eh ayns gloyr e Ayrey, as ny ainlyn casherick marish.
CAB. IX.

English: And he said unto them, Verily I say unto you, That there be some of them that stand here, which shall not taste of death, till they have seen the kingdom of God come with power.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Dy vel paart jeusyn ta nyn shassoo ayns shoh, nagh jean blashtyn er y baase, derrey vees ad er vakin reeriaght Yee er jeet lesh pooar.

English: 2 ¶And after six days Jesus taketh with him Peter, and James, and John, and leadeth them up into an high mountain apart by themselves: and he was transfigured before them.
Manx: As ec kione shey laa, ghow Yeesey marish Peddyr, as Jamys, as Ean, as leeid Eh seose gys slieau ard ad hene er-lheh: as va’n cummey echey er ny chaghlaa kiongoyrt roo.

English: 3 And his raiment became shining, exceeding white as snow; so as no fuller on earth can white them.
Manx: As ren y coamrey echey soilshean, as ve feer yial myr y sniaghtey; cha row * walker er y thalloo abyl y yannoo cha gial eh.
*Giallider

English: 4 And there appeared unto them Elias with Moses: and they were talking with Jesus.
Manx: As haink ayns yn enish oc Elias, as Moses: as v’ad taggloo rish Yeesey.

English: 5 And Peter answered and said to Jesus, Master, it is good for us to be here: and let us make three tabernacles; one for thee, and one for Moses, and one for Elias.
Manx: As dreggyr Peddyr as dooyrt Eh rish Yeesey, Vainshtyr, te mie er ny son ainyn dy ve ayns shoh: as lhig dooin three cabbaneyn y yannoo, cabbane er dty hon’s, as cabbane son Moses, as cabbane son Elias.

English: 6 For he wist not what to say; for they were sore afraid.
Manx: Son cha row fys echey cre dy ghra, son v’ad feer agglagh.

English: 7 And there was a cloud that overshadowed them: and a voice came out of the cloud, saying, This is my beloved Son: hear him.
Manx: As ren bodjal scadoo y hilgey harrystoo: as haink coraa ass y vodjal, gra, Shoh my Vac graihagh; eaisht-jee rish.

English: 8 And suddenly, when they had looked round about, they saw no man any more, save Jesus only with themselves.
Manx: As ayns y tullogh, tra v’ad er yeeaghyn mygeayrt, cha vaik ad dooinney erbee ny smoo, cheu-mooie jeh Yeesey ny lomarcan mâroo hene.

English: 9 And as they came down from the mountain, he charged them that they should tell no man what things they had seen, till the Son of man were risen from the dead.
Manx: As myr v’ad cheet neose jeh’n clieau, hug Eh currym daue, gyn ad dy insh da dooinney erbee cre ny reddyn v’ad er vakin, derrey veagh yn Mac dooinney er n’irree veih ny merriu.

English: 10 And they kept that saying with themselves, questioning one with another what the rising from the dead should mean.
Manx: As dreill ad y raa shen oc hene, as v’ad resooney yn derrey yeh rish y jeh elley, cre va’n irree-reesht veih ny merriu dy veanal.

English: 11 ¶And they asked him, saying, Why say the scribes that Elias must first come?
Manx: As dênee ad jeh, gra, Cre’n-oyr ta ny scruderyn gra, dy vel Elias dy heet hoshiaght.

English: 12 And he answered and told them, Elias verily cometh first, and restoreth all things; and how it is written of the Son of man, that he must suffer many things, and be set at nought.
Manx: As dreggyr eshyn as dinsh Eh daue, Dy row Elias dy firrinagh dy heet hoshiaght, as dy lhiassaghey dy chooilley nhee, as kys te scruit mychione yn Mac dooinney, dy row Eh dy hurranse ymmodee dy reddyn as dy ve beg soit jeh.

English: 13 But I say unto you, That Elias is indeed come, and they have done unto him whatsoever they listed, as it is written of him.
Manx: Agh ta mish gra riu, dy vel Elias dy jarroo er jeet, myr te scruit jeh, as dy vel ad er n’yannoo rish cre-erbee baïlloo.

English: 14 ¶And when he came to his disciples, he saw a great multitude about them, and the scribes questioning with them.
Manx: As tra v’eh erjeet gys y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er, honnick Eh chaglym mooar dy leih mygeayrt-y-moo, as ny scruderyn fênaght questionyn jeu.

English: 15 And straightway all the people, when they beheld him, were greatly amazed, and running to him saluted him.
Manx: As chelleeragh ghow ooilley yn pobble, tra honnick ad Eh, laane boggey, as roih ad huggey, cur oltaghey-bea da.

English: 16 And he asked the scribes, What question ye with them?
Manx: As dênee Eh jeh ny scruderyn, Cre ny questionyn va shiu dy ênaght jeu?

English: 17 And one of the multitude answered and said, Master, I have brought unto thee my son, which hath a dumb spirit;
Manx: As dreggyr fer jeh’n cheshaght, as dooyrt Eh, Vainshtyr, Ta mee er chur lhiam my vac hood, ta spyrryd balloo ayn:

English: 18 And wheresoever he taketh him, he teareth him: and he foameth, and gnasheth with his teeth, and pineth away: and I spake to thy disciples that they should cast him out; and they could not.
Manx: As raad erbee dy vel Eh dy ghoaill Eh, t’eh dy heih noon as noall Eh; as t’eh keshal as snaggeraght lesh e eeacklyn, as coall e vree: as loayr mee roosyn ta sheer geiyrt ort, ad dy hilgey ass Eh, as cha dod ad.

English: 19 He answereth him, and saith, O faithless generation, how long shall I be with you? how long shall I suffer you? bring him unto me.
Manx: Dreggyr eshyn, as dooyrt Eh, O heeloghe vee-chredjuagh, caid ta mish dy ve mêriu? caid ta mee dy hurranse diu? cur lhiat Eh hym’s.

English: 20 And they brought him unto him: and when he saw him, straightway the spirit tare him; and he fell on the ground, and wallowed foaming.
Manx: As hug ad lhieu Eh huggey: as tra honnick Eh Eh, chelleeragh chew yn spyrryd noon as noall Eh, as huit Eh er y thalloo, as rowll Eh harrish, keshal.

English: 21 And he asked his father, How long is it ago since this came unto him? And he said, Of a child.
Manx: As dênee Eh jeh’n ayr echey, Caid neayr as haink shoh er? As dooyrt Eh, T’eh er ve myr shoh neayr as v’eh ny liannoo.

English: 22 And ofttimes it hath cast him into the fire, and into the waters, to destroy him: but if thou canst do any thing, have compassion on us, and help us.
Manx: As dy mennick t’eh er hilgey Eh ayns yn aile, as ayns ny hushtaghyn, dy stroie Eh: agh my oddys oo nhee erbee y yannoo, jean chymmey orrin, as cooin lhien.

English: 23 Jesus said unto him, If thou canst believe, all things are possible to him that believeth.
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey rish, My oddys oo credjal, ta dy chooilley nhee possible dasyn ta credjal.

English: 24 And straightway the father of the child cried out, and said with tears, Lord, I believe; help thou mine unbelief.
Manx: As chelleeragh deïe ayr y liannoo, as dooyrt Eh lesh jeir, Hiarn, Ta mee credjal; ymmyrk lesh my vee-chredjue.

English: 25 When Jesus saw that the people came running together, he rebuked the foul spirit, saying unto him, Thou dumb and deaf spirit, I charge thee, come out of him, and enter no more into him.
Manx: Tra honnick Yeesey dy row yn pobble cheet roih cooidjagh, vaggyr Eh er y spyrryd neu-ghlen, as dooyrt Eh rish, U[s]s spyrryd balloo as bouyr, ta mee cur saarey dhyt, Oo dy heet magh ass, as gyn oo dy gholl arragh stiagh ayn.

English: 26 And the spirit cried, and rent him sore, and came out of him: and he was as one dead; insomuch that many said, He is dead.
Manx: As deïe yn spyrryd, as heih Eh noon as noall Eh, as haink Eh magh ass; as v’eh myr dy beagh Eh marroo, ayns wheesh as dy dooyrt ymmodee, T’eh marroo.

English: 27 But Jesus took him by the hand, and lifted him up; and he arose.
Manx: Agh ghow Yeesey Eh er laue, as hrog Eh Eh seose, as dirree Eh.

English: 28 And when he was come into the house, his disciples asked him privately, Why could not we cast him out?
Manx: As tra v’eh er jeet stiagh ayns y thie, dênee adsyn va sheer marish jeh er-lheh, Cre liorish nagh voddagh shinyn y hilgey ass Eh.

English: 29 And he said unto them, This kind can come forth by nothing, but by prayer and fasting.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Cha vel y sorch shoh cheet magh er aght erbee, agh liorish padjer as trostey.

English: 30 ¶And they departed thence, and passed through Galilee; and he would not that any man should know it.
Manx: As jimmee ad veih shen, as hie ad trooid Galilee; as cha ballish fys y ve ec dooinney erbee er.

English: 31 For he taught his disciples, and said unto them, The Son of man is delivered into the hands of men, and they shall kill him; and after that he is killed, he shall rise the third day.
Manx: Son dynsee Eh yn vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er, as dooyrt Eh roo, Ta’n Mac dooinney er ny livrey gys laueyn deiney, as marree ad Eh, as erreish da v’er ny varroo, nee Eh girree reesht yn tress laa.

English: 32 But they understood not that saying, and were afraid to ask him.
Manx: Agh cha hoig ad yn raa shen, as v’ad agglagh dy ênaght jeh.

English: 33 ¶And he came to Capernaum: and being in the house he asked them, What was it that ye disputed among yourselves by the way?
Manx: As haink Eh gys Capernaum, as ayns y thie, dênee Eh jeu, Cre va shen va shiu dy loayrt nyn mast’ eu hene er y raad?

English: 34 But they held their peace: for by the way they had disputed among themselves, who should be the greatest.
Manx: Agh chum ad nyn jengey: Son er y raad v’ad er ve loayrt nyn mast’ oc hene, quoi syrjey veagh.

English: 35 And he sat down, and called the twelve, and saith unto them, If any man desire to be first, the same shall be last of all, and servant of all.
Manx: As hoie Eh sheese, as deïe Eh er y daa ostyl yeig, as dooyrt Eh roo, My ta dooinney erbee geearree dy ve hoshiaght, bee Eh er-jerrey ooilley, as ny harvaant da ooilley.

English: 36 And he took a child, and set him in the midst of them: and when he had taken him in his arms, he said unto them,
Manx: As ghow Eh liannoo, as hoie Eh Eh kiongoyrt roo: as tra v’eh er ghoaill Eh ayns e roiaghyn, dooyrt Eh roo,

English: 37 Whosoever shall receive one of such children in my name, receiveth me: and whosoever shall receive me, receiveth not me, but him that sent me.
Manx: Quoi-erbee nee soiaghey jey [sic: jeh] annane dy leid y chloan shoh, t’eh soiaghey jeem’s: as quoi-erbee nee soiaghey jeem’s, cha vel Eh jannoo soiaghey jeem’s, agh jehsyn t’er my choyrt.

English: 38 ¶And John answered him, saying, Master, we saw one casting out devils in thy name, and he followeth not us: and we forbad him, because he followeth not us.
Manx: As dreggyr Ean Eh, gra, Vainshtyr, honnick shin fer tilgey magh drogh-spyrrydyn ayns dt’ennyms, as cha vel Eh geiyrt orrinyn; as liett shin Eh, er-yn-oyr nagh vel Eh geiyrt orrin.

English: 39 But Jesus said, Forbid him not: for there is no man which shall do a miracle in my name, that can lightly speak evil of me.
Manx: Agh dooyrt Yeesey, Ny liett-jee Eh: son cha vel dooinney erbee oddys mirril y yannoo ayns m’ennyms, oddys dy aashagh loayrt dy holk jee’m.

English: 40 For he that is not against us is on our part.
Manx: Son eshyn nagh vel nyn ’oi, t’eh er nyn baart.

English: 41 For whosoever shall give you a cup of water to drink in my name, because ye belong to Christ, verily I say unto you, he shall not lose his reward.
Manx: Son quoi-erbee ver diu cappan dy ushtey dy iu, ayns m’ennyms, er-yn-oyr dy vel shiu bentyn gys Creest, dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, nagh gaïll Eh e leagh.

English: 42 And whosoever shall offend one of these little ones that believe in me, it is better for him that a millstone were hanged about his neck, and he were cast into the sea.
Manx: As quoi-erbee ver oyr da annane jeh’n vooinjer veggey shoh ta credjal aynyms dy huittym [veih’n Chredjue,] te ny shaare da clagh wyllin dy ve croghit mysh y wannal, as Eh dy ve tilgit ayns y cheayn.

English: 43 And if thy hand offend thee, cut it off: it is better for thee to enter into life maimed, than having two hands to go into hell, into the fire that never shall be quenched:
Manx: As my ta dty laue dy dty hayrn gys yn olk, giare jeed ee: te ny shaare dhyt goll stiagh ayns bea, baccagh, na daa laue y ve ayd, as oo dy gholl gys niurin, gys yn aile nagh bee dy bragh er ny vooghey:

English: 44 Where their worm dieth not, and the fire is not quenched.
Manx: Raad nagh vel y veishteig oc geddyn baase, as cha vel yn aile er ny vooghey.

English: 45 And if thy foot offend thee, cut it off: it is better for thee to enter halt into life, than having two feet to be cast into hell, into the fire that never shall be quenched:
Manx: As my ta dty chass dy dty hayrn gys peccah, giare jeed ee: te ny shaare dhyt goll croobagh stiagh ayns bea, na daa chass y ve ayd, as oo dy ve tilgit ayns niurin, ayns yn aile nagh bee dy bragh er ny vooghey:

English: 46 Where their worm dieth not, and the fire is not quenched.
Manx: Raad nagh vel y veishteig oc geddyn baase, as cha vel yn aile er ny vooghey.

English: 47 And if thine eye offend thee, pluck it out: it is better for thee to enter into the kingdom of God with one eye, than having two eyes to be cast into hell fire:
Manx: As my ta dty hooyll dy dty hayrn gys peccah, pluck assyd ee: te ny share dhyt goll stiagh ayns reeriaght Yee lesh un hooyll, na daa hooyll y ve ayd, as oo dy ve tilgit ayns aile niurin:

English: 48 Where their worm dieth not, and the fire is not quenched.
Manx: Raad nagh vel y veishteig oc geddyn baase, as cha vel yn aile er ny vooghey.

English: 49 For every one shall be salted with fire, and every sacrifice shall be salted with salt.
Manx: Son bee dy chooilley annane jeh nyn leid oc shoh er nyn goyrt mou lesh aile, as dy chooilley oural er ny hailley lesh sollan.

English: 50 Salt is good: but if the salt have lost his saltness, wherewith will ye season it? Have salt in yourselves, and have peace one with another.
Manx: Ta’n sollan mie: agh my ta’n sollan er choall e hailjys, kys hig e vree ayn reesht? Freïll-jee sollan ayndiu hene, as bee-jee ayns shee yn derrey yeh rish y jeh elley.
CAB. X.

English: And he arose from thence, and cometh into the coasts of Judaea by the farther side of Jordan: and the people resort unto him again; and, as he was wont, he taught them again.
Manx: As dirree Eh er veih shen, as haink Eh gys ardjyn Yudea, trooid y cheer v’er cheu elley dy Yordan: as haink y pobble huggey reesht; as myr v’eh cliaghtey, dynsee Eh ad reesht.

English: 2 ¶And the Pharisees came to him, and asked him, Is it lawful for a man to put away his wife? tempting him.
Manx: As haink ny Phariseeyn huggey, as dênee ad jeh, er-chee Eh y violaghey, Vel eh lowal da dooinney scarrey rish e ven?

English: 3 And he answered and said unto them, What did Moses command you?
Manx: As dreggyr eshyn as dooyrt Eh roo, Cre’n saarey hug Moses diu?

English: 4 And they said, Moses suffered to write a bill of divorcement, and to put her away.
Manx: As dooyrt adsyn, Lhow Moses screeuyn scarree y scrieu, as ee y chur ersooyl.

English: 5 And Jesus answered and said unto them, For the hardness of your heart he wrote you this precept.
Manx: As dreggyr eshyn as dooyrt Eh roo, Son creoghys ny creeaghyn eu scrieu Eh diu yn saarey shoh.

English: 6 But from the beginning of the creation God made them male and female.
Manx: Agh er dy hoshiaght y theihll, chroo Jee ad fyrrynagh as bwoirrynagh.

English: 7 For this cause shall a man leave his father and mother, and cleave to his wife;
Manx: Er yn oyr shoh nee dooinney fagail e ayr as e voir, as liannee Eh gys e ven.

English: 8 And they twain shall be one flesh: so then they are no more twain, but one flesh.
Manx: As bee ad ny neesht un eill: myr shen cha vel ad ny sodjey jees, agh un eill.

English: 9 What therefore God hath joined together, let not man put asunder.
Manx: Cre-erbee er-y-fa shen ta Jee er chur cooidjagh, ny lig da dooinney erbee y chur veih my chielley.

English: 10 And in the house his disciples asked him again of the same matter.
Manx: As ayns y thie dênee adsyn va sheer geiyrt er jeh reesht, mychione y chooish cheddin.

English: 11 And he saith unto them, Whosoever shall put away his wife, and marry another, committeth adultery against her.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Quoi-erbee scarrys rish e ven, as phoosys ben elley, t’eh brishey poosey ny hoi eck.

English: 12 And if a woman shall put away her husband, and be married to another, she committeth adultery.
Manx: As my scarrys ben rish e sheshey, as ee dy ve poost rish dooinney elley, t’ee brishey poosey.

English: 13 ¶And they brought young children to him, that he should touch them: and his disciples rebuked those that brought them.
Manx: As hug ad lhieu cloan aegey gys Creest, dy jinnagh Eh bennaylt roo; as hug adsyn va sheer marish oghsan dauesyn hug lhieu ad.

English: 14 But when Jesus saw it, he was much displeased, and said unto them, Suffer the little children to come unto me, and forbid them not: for of such is the kingdom of God.
Manx: Agh tra honnick Yeesey eh, v’eh feer jymmoosagh, as dooyrt Eh roo, Sur-jee cloan aegey dy heet hym’s, as ny jean-jee nyn liettal ad: son jeh nyn leid ta reeriaght Yee.

English: 15 Verily I say unto you, Whosoever shall not receive the kingdom of God as a little child, he shall not enter therein.
Manx: Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Quoi erbee nagh jean goaill reeriaght Yee myr liannoo beg, cha jed Eh stiagh ayn.

English: 16 And he took them up in his arms, put his hands upon them, and blessed them.
Manx: As ghow Eh ad seose ayns e roiaghyn, hug Eh e laueyn orroo, as vannee Eh ad.

English: 17 ¶And when he was gone forth into the way, there came one running, and kneeled to him, and asked him, Good Master, what shall I do that I may inherit eternal life?
Manx: As tra v’eh er gholl magh er y raad, haink fer roih, as hie Eh er e ghlioonyn huggey, as dênee Eh jeh, Vainshtyr vie, Cre neem’s dy vod eiraght y y ve aym ayns y vea veayn?

English: 18 And Jesus said unto him, Why callest thou me good? there is none good but one, that is, God.
Manx: As dooyrt Yeesey rish, Cre’n-fa t’ow genmyss mee mie? cha vel annane erbee mie, agh annane, ta shen dy ghra, Jee.

English: 19 Thou knowest the commandments, Do not commit adultery, Do not kill, Do not steal, Do not bear false witness, Defraud not, Honour thy father and mother.
Manx: Ta toiggal ayd jeh ny annaghyn, Ny jean poosey y vrishey, Ny jean dunverys, Ny jean geid, Ny jean feanish foalsey y ymmyrkey, Ny jean molteraght, Cur arrym da dt’ayr as da dty voir.

English: 20 And he answered and said unto him, Master, all these have I observed from my youth.
Manx: As dreggyr eshyn as dooyrt Eh rish, Vainshtyr, ooilley ny annaghyn shoh ta mee er reaylley veih my aegid.

English: 21 Then Jesus beholding him loved him, and said unto him, One thing thou lackest: go thy way, sell whatsoever thou hast, and give to the poor, and thou shalt have treasure in heaven: and come, take up the cross, and follow me.
Manx: Eisht yeeagh Yeesey er, as hug Eh graih da, as dooyrt Eh rish, Un red ta ort dy yannoo: immee royd, as creck as cur cre-erbee t’ayd da ny boghtyn, as bee berchys ayd ayns niau; as tar, trog y chrosh, as eiyr orryms.

English: 22 And he was sad at that saying, and went away grieved: for he had great possessions.
Manx: As v’eh trimshagh ec y raa shen, as hie Eh ersooyl: son va cummallyn mooarey echey.

English: 23 ¶And Jesus looked round about, and saith unto his disciples, How hardly shall they that have riches enter into the kingdom of God
Manx: As yeeagh Yeesey mygeayrt as dooyrt Eh roosyn va sheer geiyrt er, Cre cha doillee as vees eh dauesyn ta berchys oc goll stiagh ayns reeriaght Yee!

English: 24 And the disciples were astonished at his words. But Jesus answereth again, and saith unto them, Children, how hard is it for them that trust in riches to enter into the kingdom of God
Manx: As ghow adsyn yindyss jeh ny goan echey. Agh dreggyr Yeesey reesht, as dooyrt Eh roo, Chloan, cre cha doillee as te dauesyn ta treishteil ayns berchys, dy gholl stiagh ayns reeriaght Yee!

English: 25 It is easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle, than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of God.
Manx: Te ny sassey da camel goll trooid croae snaidey, na da leid y dooinney berchagh shoh dy goll [sic: gholl] stiagh ayns reeriaght Yee.

English: 26 And they were astonished out of measure, saying among themselves, Who then can be saved?
Manx: As v’ad atchimagh er-skyn towse, gra nyn mast’ oc hene, Quoi eisht oddys v’er ny hauail?

English: 27 And Jesus looking upon them saith, With men it is impossible, but not with God: for with God all things are possible.
Manx: As yeeagh Yeesey orroo, as dooyrt Eh, Da deiney te neu-phossible, agh cha vel eh da Jee: son da Jee ta dy chooilley nhee possible.

English: 28 ¶Then Peter began to say unto him, Lo, we have left all, and have followed thee.
Manx: Eisht ren Peddyr toshiaght dy ghra rish, Cur-my-ner, ta shinyn er dreigeil ooilley, as er n’eiyrt orts.

English: 29 And Jesus answered and said, Verily I say unto you, There is no man that hath left house, or brethren, or sisters, or father, or mother, or wife, or children, or lands, for my sake, and the gospel's,
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Nagh vel dooinney erbee, t’er dreigeil thie, ny braaraghyn, ny shairaghyn, ny ayr, ny moir, ny ben, ny cloan, ny thalloo, er my ghraih’s as graih’n sushtal,

English: 30 But he shall receive an hundredfold now in this time, houses, and brethren, and sisters, and mothers, and children, and lands, with persecutions; and in the world to come eternal life.
Manx: Nagh vow keead-filley nish ayns yn traa shoh, thieyn, as braaraghyn, as shairaghyn, as moiraghyn, as cloan, as thalloo, lesh seaghyn; as ayns y theihll ta ry heet yn vea veayn.

English: 31 But many that are first shall be last; and the last first.
Manx: Agh bee ymmodee jeusyn ta hoshiaght er-jerrey: as jeusyn ta er-jerrey, hoshiaght.

English: 32 ¶And they were in the way going up to Jerusalem; and Jesus went before them: and they were amazed; and as they followed, they were afraid. And he took again the twelve, and began to tell them what things should happen unto him,
Manx: As v’ad er y raad goll seose gys Jerusalem: as hie Yeesey rhymboo; as v’ad atchimagh, as myr v’ad geiyrt er, ghow ad aggle. As ghow Eh yn daa ostyl yeig reesht, as ren Eh toshiaght dy insh daue, cre ny reddyn haghyragh da,

English: 33 Saying, Behold, we go up to Jerusalem; and the Son of man shall be delivered unto the chief priests, and unto the scribes; and they shall condemn him to death, and shall deliver him to the Gentiles:
Manx: Gra, Cur-my-ner, ta shin goll seose gys Jerusalem, as bee yn Mac dooinney er ny livrey gys ny ard-saggyrtyn, as gys ny scruderyn: as nee ad Eh y gheyrey gy baase, as livrey-ee ad Eh hucsyn jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaagh;

English: 34 And they shall mock him, and shall scourge him, and shall spit upon him, and shall kill him: and the third day he shall rise again.
Manx: As craidee ad mysh, as custee ad Eh, as tilgee ad shellaghyn er, as marree ad Eh: as y tress laa nee Eh girree reesht.

English: 35 ¶And James and John, the sons of Zebedee, come unto him, saying, Master, we would that thou shouldest do for us whatsoever we shall desire.
Manx: As haink Jamys as Ean meck Zebedee huggey, gra, Vainshtyr, Baïllin oo dy yannoo er nyn son, cre-erbee nee mad y yeearree.

English: 36 And he said unto them, What would ye that I should do for you?
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Cre baïlliu mee dy yannoo er nyn son?

English: 37 They said unto him, Grant unto us that we may sit, one on thy right hand, and the other on thy left hand, in thy glory.
Manx: Dooyrt adsyn rish, Lhow dooinyn dy hoie, yn derrey yeh er dty laue yesh, as y jeh elley er dty laue chiare, ayns dty ghloyr.

English: 38 But Jesus said unto them, Ye know not what ye ask: can ye drink of the cup that I drink of? and be baptized with the baptism that I am baptized with?
Manx: Agh dooyrt Yeesey roo, Cha s’eu cre ta shiu dy yeearree: vel shiu abyl giu jeh’n cappan ta mish giu jeh? as v’er nyn mashtey lesh y bashtey ta mish bashtit lesh?

English: 39 And they said unto him, We can. And Jesus said unto them, Ye shall indeed drink of the cup that I drink of; and with the baptism that I am baptized withal shall ye be baptized:
Manx: As dooyrt ad rish, Ta shin abyl. As dooyrt Yeesey roo, Iu-ee shiu dy jarroo jeh’n cappan ta mish giu jeh; as bee shiu er nyn mashtey lesh y bashtey ta mish bashtit lesh:

English: 40 But to sit on my right hand and on my left hand is not mine to give; but it shall be given to them for whom it is prepared.
Manx: Agh dy hoie er my laue yesh as er my laue chiare, cha vel shen lhiam’s dy choyrt, agh ynrycan dauesyn er nyn son te kiarit.

English: 41 And when the ten heard it, they began to be much displeased with James and John.
Manx: As tra cheayll yn jeih shoh, ren ad toshiaght dy ve feer jymmoosagh rish Jamys as Ean.

English: 42 But Jesus called them to him, and saith unto them, Ye know that they which are accounted to rule over the Gentiles exercise lordship over them; and their great ones exercise authority upon them.
Manx: Agh deïe Yeesey orroo huggey, as dooyrt Eh roo, Ta fys eu, dy vel adsyn ta soit seose dy reïll harrish ny Ashoonyn-quaagh, gymmyrkey reïll harrystoo, as ta ny deiney mooarey oc gymmyrkey torrity nyn mastey.

English: 43 But so shall it not be among you: but whosoever will be great among you, shall be your minister:
Manx: Agh cha bee eh myr shen nyn mast’ eauish: agh quoi-erbee eauish ballish ve mooar, bee Eh ry hoi shirveish erriu:

English: 44 And whosoever of you will be the chiefest, shall be servant of all.
Manx: As quoi-erbee syrjey ballish y ve nyn mast’ eu, lig Eh ve ny harvaant da ooilley.

English: 45 For even the Son of man came not to be ministered unto, but to minister, and to give his life a ransom for many.
Manx: Son cha daink yn eer Mac dooinney dy ve shirveishit, agh dy hirveish, as dy chur e vioys ny lhiassaghey son ymmodee.

English: 46 ¶And they came to Jericho: and as he went out of Jericho with his disciples and a great number of people, blind Bartimaeus, the son of Timaeus, sat by the highway side begging.
Manx: As haink ad gys Jericho: as myr v’eh goll magh ass Jericho maroosyn va sheer geiyrt er, as marish earroo mooar dy leih, va Bartimeus doal mac Timeus, ny hoie rish liattee yn raad, shirrey jeirk.

English: 47 And when he heard that it was Jesus of Nazareth, he began to cry out, and say, Jesus, thou son of David, have mercy on me.
Manx: As tra cheayll Eh dy nee Yeesey dy Nazareth v’ayn, ren Eh toshiaght dy eamagh as dy ghra, Yeesey Vac Ghavid, jean myghin orrym.

English: 48 And many charged him that he should hold his peace: but he cried the more a great deal, Thou son of David, have mercy on me.
Manx: As hug ymmodee currym da Eh dy chummal e hengey: agh deïe eshyn wheesh shen smoo foddey, Vac Ghavid, jean myghin orrym.

English: 49 And Jesus stood still, and commanded him to be called. And they call the blind man, saying unto him, Be of good comfort, rise; he calleth thee.
Manx: As hass Yeesey, as doardee Eh Eh dy ve eït: as deïe ad er y dooinney doal, gra rish, Bee dy yien mie, irree; t’eh geamagh ort.

English: 50 And he, casting away his garment, rose, and came to Jesus.
Manx: As hilg Eh ersooyl e choamrey, as dirree Eh, as haink Eh gys Yeesey.

English: 51 And Jesus answered and said unto him, What wilt thou that I should do unto thee? The blind man said unto him, Lord, that I might receive my sight.
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey, as dooyrt Eh rish, Cre baïlt mee dy yannoo er dty hon? Dooyrt y dooinney doal rish, Hiarn, dy voddym my hoilshey y gheddyn.

English: 52 And Jesus said unto him, Go thy way; thy faith hath made thee whole. And immediately he received his sight, and followed Jesus in the way.
Manx: As dooyrt Yeesey rish, Immee royd; ta dty chredjue er dy [sic: dty] laanaghey. As chelleeragh hooar Eh e hoilshey, as deiyr Eh er Yeesey er y raad.
CAB. XI.

English: And when they came nigh to Jerusalem, unto Bethphage and Bethany, at the mount of Olives, he sendeth forth two of his disciples,
Manx: As tra v’ad er jeet ergerrey da Jerusalem, gys Bethphage as Bethany ec cronk ny Oliveyn, hug Eh er chaghteraght jees jeusyn va kinjagh geiyrt er,

English: 2 And saith unto them, Go your way into the village over against you: and as soon as ye be entered into it, ye shall find a colt tied, whereon never man sat; loose him, and bring him.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Gow-jee reue gys y balley-beg ta shiu dy akin; as cha leah as vees shiu er gholl stiagh ayn, yiow shiu lhie kainlt, urree nagh ren rieau dooinney markiagh; feayshyl-jee as cur-jee lhieu ee,

English: 3 And if any man say unto you, Why do ye this? say ye that the Lord hath need of him; and straightway he will send him hither.
Manx: As my jir dooinney erbee riu, Cre’n-fa ta shiu jannoo shoh? abbyr-jee dy vel feme ec y Chiarn urree; as chelleeragh nee Eh yn raad y liggey jee.

English: 4 And they went their way, and found the colt tied by the door without in a place where two ways met; and they loose him.
Manx: As hie ad rhymboo, as hooar ad y lhie kianlt er cheu-mooie dy ghorrys, ayns ynnyd va daa raad cheet quaïl y y [sic] chielley: as deayshyl ad ee.

English: 5 And certain of them that stood there said unto them, What do ye, loosing the colt?
Manx: As dooyrt shiartance jeusyn va nyn shassoo ayns shen roo, Kys dy vel shiu feaysley yn lhie?

English: 6 And they said unto them even as Jesus had commanded: and they let them go.
Manx: As dooyrt ad roo myr va Yeesey er n’oardaghey daue, as lig ad y raad daue.

English: 7 And they brought the colt to Jesus, and cast their garments on him; and he sat upon him.
Manx: As hug ad lhieu yn lhie gys Yeesey, as hilg ad ny garmadyn oc urree; as hoie eshyn er y lhie.

English: 8 And many spread their garments in the way: and others cut down branches off the trees, and strawed them in the way.
Manx: As ren ymmodee ny garmadyn oc y skeayley er y raad: as yiare feallagh elley banglaneyn jeh ny biljyn as skeayll ad ad er y raad.

English: 9 And they that went before, and they that followed, cried, saying, Hosanna; Blessed is he that cometh in the name of the Lord:
Manx: As adsyn hie roïsh, as y vooinjer haink ny yei, deïe ad, gra, Hosanna, bannit ta eshyn ta cheet ayns ennym y Chiarn.

English: 10 Blessed be the kingdom of our father David, that cometh in the name of the Lord: Hosanna in the highest.
Manx: Bannit dy row reeriaght yn ayr ain David, ta cheet ayns ennym y Chiarn; Hosanna ayns yn yrjid.

English: 11 And Jesus entered into Jerusalem, and into the temple: and when he had looked round about upon all things, and now the eventide was come, he went out unto Bethany with the twelve.
Manx: As hie Yeesey gys Jerusalem, as hie Eh stiagh ayns y chiamble; as tra v’eh er yeeaghyn mygeayrt er dy chooilley nhee, as nish dy row yn fastyr er jeet, hie Eh magh gys Bethany marish y daa ostyl yeig.

English: 12 ¶And on the morrow, when they were come from Bethany, he was hungry:
Manx: As laa ny vairagh, tra v’ad er jeet veih Bethany, v’eh accryssagh.

English: 13 And seeing a fig tree afar off having leaves, he came, if haply he might find any thing thereon: and when he came to it, he found nothing but leaves; for the time of figs was not yet.
Manx: As honnick Eh billey-figgagh er y raad, as duillagyn er, as haink Eh, dy yeeaghyn daghyragh eh da red erbee y gheddyn er: as tra v’eh er jeet huggey, cha dooar Eh nhee erbee er, agh duillagyn; son cha row earish ny figgyn ayn foast.

English: 14 And Jesus answered and said unto it, No man eat fruit of thee hereafter for ever. And his disciples heard it.
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey, as dooyrt Eh rish, Nar ee dooinney erbee mess jeeds veih shoh magh er son dy bragh. As cheayll yn vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er eh.

English: 15 ¶And they come to Jerusalem: and Jesus went into the temple, and began to cast out them that sold and bought in the temple, and overthrew the tables of the moneychangers, and the seats of them that sold doves;
Manx: As haink ad gys Jerusalem: as hie Yeesey stiagh ayns y chiamble, as ren Eh toshiaght dy eiyrt magh adsyn va creck as kionnaghey ayns y chiamble, as hilg Eh harrish ny buird ocsyn va caghlaa argid, as ny stuill ocsyn va creck calmaneyn;

English: 16 And would not suffer that any man should carry any vessel through the temple.
Manx: As cha lhowagh Eh da dooinney erbee saagh erbee y chur lesh trooid y chiamble.

English: 17 And he taught, saying unto them, Is it not written, My house shall be called of all nations the house of prayer? but ye have made it a den of thieves.
Manx: As dynsee Eh ad, gra, Nagh vel eh scruit, Bee my hie’s enmyssit liorish dy chooilley ashoon thie yn phadjer? agh ta shiuish er n’yannoo eh ny ooig dy vaarlee.

English: 18 And the scribes and chief priests heard it, and sought how they might destroy him: for they feared him, because all the people was astonished at his doctrine.
Manx: As cheayll ny scruderyn as ny ard-saggyrtyn jeh, as v’ad shirrey kys oddagh ad Eh y stroie: son v’ad ayns aggle roish, er-yn-oyr dy row ooilley’n pobble goaill yindyss jeh’n ynsagh echey.

English: 19 And when even was come, he went out of the city.
Manx: As tra va’n fastyr er jeet, hie Eh magh ass yn ard-valley.

English: 20 ¶And in the morning, as they passed by, they saw the fig tree dried up from the roots.
Manx: As ayns y voghrey, myr v’ad goll shiaghey, honnick ad y billey-figgagh dy row eh er greenaghey seose veih ny fraueyn.

English: 21 And Peter calling to remembrance saith unto him, Master, behold, the fig tree which thou cursedst is withered away.
Manx: As hayrn Peddyr Eh hene gys cooinaghtyn, as dooyrt Eh rish, Vainshtyr, cur-my-ner, ta’n billey-figgagh hug uss fo mollaght, er fioghey ersooyl.

English: 22 And Jesus answering saith unto them, Have faith in God.
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh roo, soie-jee nyn gredjue ayns Jee.

English: 23 For verily I say unto you, That whosoever shall say unto this mountain, Be thou removed, and be thou cast into the sea; and shall not doubt in his heart, but shall believe that those things which he saith shall come to pass; he shall have whatsoever he saith.
Manx: Son dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, quoi-erbee jir rish y slieau shoh, Bee er dty scughey, as er dty hilgey ayns y cheayn, as nagh jean dooteïl ayns e chree, agh nee credjal ny reddy[n] t’eh gra hig gy kione, bee cre-erbee t’eh dy ghra echey.

English: 24 Therefore I say unto you, What things soever ye desire, when ye pray, believe that ye receive them, and ye shall have them.
Manx: Shen-y-fa ta mee gra riu, Cre-erbee ny reddyn ta shiu dy yeearree ayns padjer, cred-jee dy vow shiu ad, as bee ad eu.

English: 25 And when ye stand praying, forgive, if ye have ought against any: that your Father also which is in heaven may forgive you your trespasses.
Manx: As tra vees shiu nyn shassoo, dy gholl gys padjer, leih-jee, my ta nhee erbee eu noi dooinney erbee: dy vod yn Ayr eu myrgeddin t’ayns niau nyn loghtyn y leih diuish.

English: 26 But if ye do not forgive, neither will your Father which is in heaven forgive your trespasses.
Manx: Agh mannagh jean shiuish leih, cha jean yn Ayr eu niau t’ayns niau nyn voiljyn y leih diuish.

English: 27 ¶And they come again to Jerusalem: and as he was walking in the temple, there come to him the chief priests, and the scribes, and the elders,
Manx: As haink ad reesht gys Jerusalem: as myr v’eh walkal ayns y chiamble, haink huggey ny ard-saggyrtyn, as ny scruderyn, as y chanstyr,

English: 28 And say unto him, By what authority doest thou these things? and who gave thee this authority to do these things?
Manx: As dooyrt ad rish, Cre’n phooar t’ayds dy yannoo ny reddyn shoh, as quoi hug y phooar shoh dhyt dy yannoo ny reddyn shoh?

English: 29 And Jesus answered and said unto them, I will also ask of you one question, and answer me, and I will tell you by what authority I do these things.
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh roo, Fênyms jiuish myrgeddin un red, as freggyr-jee mee, as inshyms diuish cre’n phooar t’aym dy yannoo ny reddyn shoh.

English: 30 The baptism of John, was it from heaven, or of men? answer me.
Manx: Bashtey Ean, nee veih niau ve, ny veih deiney? freggyr-jee mee.

English: 31 And they reasoned with themselves, saying, If we shall say, From heaven; he will say, Why then did ye not believe him?
Manx: As ren ad resooney roo hene, gra, My jir mad, Veih niau, jir eshyn, Cre’n-oyr eisht nagh ren shiu Eh y credjal [sic: chredjal]?

English: 32 But if we shall say, Of men; they feared the people: for all men counted John, that he was a prophet indeed.
Manx: Agh my jir mad, Veih deiney, v’ad ayns aggle roish y pobble, son va dy chooilley ghooinney jeeaghyn er Ean, dy ve dy jarroo ny adeyr.

English: 33 And they answered and said unto Jesus, We cannot tell. And Jesus answering saith unto them, Neither do I tell you by what authority I do these things.
