Manx: As dreggyr ad as dooyrt ad rish Yeesey, Cha vel shin abyl insh. As dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh roosyn, Cha-moo inshyms diuish cre’n phooar t’aym dy yannoo ny reddyn shoh.
CAB. XII.

English: And he began to speak unto them by parables. A certain man planted a vineyard, and set an hedge about it, and digged a place for the winefat, and built a tower, and let it out to husbandmen, and went into a far country.
Manx: As ren eh toshiaght dy loayrt roo liorish coraaghyn-dorraghey. Va dooinney dy row ren garey-feeney y hoiaghey, as ren Eh cley y mysh, as chleigh Eh ynnyd son y saagh-feeney, as hrog Eh toor, as hoie Eh eh rish fir-hie, as hie Eh gys cheer foddey.

English: 2 And at the season he sent to the husbandmen a servant, that he might receive from the husbandmen of the fruit of the vineyard.
Manx: As ec yn imbagh cooie hug Eh sharvaant gys ny fir-hie, dy voddagh Eh geddyn veih ny fir-hie jeh mess y gharey-feeney.

English: 3 And they caught him, and beat him, and sent him away empty.
Manx: As ghow ad as woail ad Eh, as hug ad Eh ersooyl follym.

English: 4 And again he sent unto them another servant; and at him they cast stones, and wounded him in the head, and sent him away shamefully handled.
Manx: As reesht hug Eh huc sharvaant elley; as ersyn chew ad claghyn, as vrish ad y kione er, as hug ad Eh ersooyl lesh dellal feer scammyltagh.

English: 5 And again he sent another; and him they killed, and many others; beating some, and killing some.
Manx: As reesht hug Eh huc sharvaant elley; as eshyn ren ad y varroo: as ymmodee elley, bwoalley paart, as marroo paart.

English: 6 Having yet therefore one son, his wellbeloved, he sent him also last unto them, saying, They will reverence my son.
Manx: As va echey foast un vac, er v’eh feer ghraihagh er, as hug Eh eshyn myrgeddin ec y jerrey huc, gra, Ver ad arrym da my vac.

English: 7 But those husbandmen said among themselves, This is the heir; come, let us kill him, and the inheritance shall be our's.
Manx: Agh dooyrt ny fir-hie shen nyn mast’ oc hene, Shoh’n eirey; tar-jee as lig dooin Eh y varro [sic: varroo], as bee yn eiraght lhien hene.

English: 8 And they took him, and killed him, and cast him out of the vineyard.
Manx: As ghow ad, as varr ad Eh, as hilg ad Eh magh ass y gharey[-]feeney.

English: 9 What shall therefore the lord of the vineyard do? he will come and destroy the husbandmen, and will give the vineyard unto others.
Manx: Cre nee Chiarn y gharey-feeney er-y-fa shen y yannoo? hig Eh as stroie-ee Eh ny fir-hie, as ver Eh yn garey-feeney da fir-hie elley.

English: 10 And have ye not read this scripture; The stone which the builders rejected is become the head of the corner:
Manx: Nagh vel shiuish er lhaih ayns goo Yee? Ta’n chlagh ren adsyn va troggal y thie y vee-lowal, er jeet dy ve yn ard chlagh chorneilagh.

English: 11 This was the Lord’s doing, and it is marvellous in our eyes?
Manx: Shoh va jannoo yn Chiarn, as te yindyssagh ayns ny sooyllyn ainyn.

English: 12 And they sought to lay hold on him, but feared the people: for they knew that he had spoken the parable against them: and they left him, and went their way.
Manx: As v’ad aignagh dy ghoaill Eh, agh ghow ad aggle roish y pobble; son va fys oc dy row Eh er loayrt yn coraa-dorraghey noi ocsyn: as daag ad Eh, as hie ad rhymboo.

English: 13 ¶And they send unto him certain of the Pharisees and of the Herodians, to catch him in his words.
Manx: As hug ad huggey shiartance jeh ny Phariseeyn, as ny Herodianee, dy hayrn Eh ayns rybbeh liorish e ocklyn.

English: 14 And when they were come, they say unto him, Master, we know that thou art true, and carest for no man: for thou regardest not the person of men, but teachest the way of God in truth: Is it lawful to give tribute to Caesar, or not?
Manx: As tra v’ad er jeet, dooyrt ad rish, Vainshtyr, ta fys ain dy vel oo firrinagh, as nagh vel oo ayns imnea roish dooinney erbee; son cha vel oo soiaghey jeh persoon deiney, agh gynsaghey raad Yee ayns firrinys: Vel eh lowal keesh y choyrt da Cesar, mannagh vel?

English: 15 Shall we give, or shall we not give? But he, knowing their hypocrisy, said unto them, Why tempt ye me? bring me a penny, that I may see it.
Manx: Jean mad coyrt, ny jean mad gyn coyrt? Agh va fys echyssyn er y chraueeaght-foalsey oc, as dooyrt Eh roo, Cre’n-fa ta shiu shirrey dy my ghoaill ayns ribbeh? cur-jee lhieu ping hym, dy vaikym eh.

English: 16 And they brought it. And he saith unto them, Whose is this image and superscription? And they said unto him, Caesar's.
Manx: As hug ad lhieu eh: as dooyrt Eh roo, Quoi gys ta’n jalloo as y screeu shoh bentyn? As dooyrt adsyn rish, gys Cesar.

English: 17 And Jesus answering said unto them, Render to Caesar the things that are Caesar's, and to God the things that are God's. And they marvelled at him.
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey, as dooyrt Eh roo, Eek-jee da Cesar, ny reddyn ta lesh Cesar, as da Jee, ny reddyn ta lesh Jee. As ghow ad yindyss jeh.

English: 18 ¶Then come unto him the Sadducees, which say there is no resurrection; and they asked him, saying,
Manx: Eisht haink huggey ny Sad[d]uceeyn, ta gra nagh vel irree-seose-reesht dy ve ayn; as dênee ad jeh, gra,

English: 19 Master, Moses wrote unto us, If a man’s brother die, and leave his wife behind him, and leave no children, that his brother should take his wife, and raise up seed unto his brother.
Manx: Vainshtyr, Ta Moses er scrieu dooin, My ta braar dooinney geddyn baase, as fagail e ven ny yei, fegooish cloan y aagail, dy vel e vraar dy phoosey’n ven echey, as dy hroggal seose sluight gys e vraar.

English: 20 Now there were seven brethren: and the first took a wife, and dying left no seed.
Manx: Nish va shiaght braaraghyn: as hooar y chied vraar, tra v’eh er phoosey ben, baase fegooish sluight y aagail.

English: 21 And the second took her, and died, neither left he any seed: and the third likewise.
Manx: As ghow yn nah vraar ee, as hooar Eh baase, as cha daag Eh sluight: as y tress myrgeddin.

English: 22 And the seven had her, and left no seed: last of all the woman died also.
Manx: As v’ee ec y chiaght, as cha daag ad sluight: er-jerrey ooilley hooar y ven baase myrgeddin.

English: 23 In the resurrection therefore, when they shall rise, whose wife shall she be of them? for the seven had her to wife.
Manx: Ec yn irree-reesht er-y-fa shen, tra nee ad girree, quoi jeu vees ee echey son ben? son v’ee ny ben da’n chiaght.

English: 24 And Jesus answering said unto them, Do ye not therefore err, because ye know not the scriptures, neither the power of God?
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh roo, Nagh vel shiu er-y-fa shen fo marranys, er-yn-oyr nagh vel toiggal eu jeh goo ny jeh pooar Yee?

English: 25 For when they shall rise from the dead, they neither marry, nor are given in marriage; but are as the angels which are in heaven.
Manx: Son ec yn irree-reesht veih ny merriu, cha vel ad poosey, ny er nyn goyrt ayns poosey: agh t’ad myr ny ainlyn t’ayns niau.

English: 26 And as touching the dead, that they rise: have ye not read in the book of Moses, how in the bush God spake unto him, saying, I am the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob?
Manx: As mychione ny merriu, dy nirree ad; nagh vel shiu er lhaih ayns lioar Voses, kys loayr Jee rish ayns y thammag, gra, Mish Jee Abraham, as Jee Isaac, as Jee Yacob?

English: 27 He is not the God of the dead, but the God of the living: ye therefore do greatly err.
Manx: Cha nee Jee ny merriu Eh, agh Jee ny bio: ta shiu er-y-fa shen fo marranys vooar.

English: 28 ¶And one of the scribes came, and having heard them reasoning together, and perceiving that he had answered them well, asked him, Which is the first commandment of all?
Manx: As haink fer jeh ny scruderyn, as liorish dy row Eh er chlashtyn ad resooney cooidjagh, as er chur tastey dy row Eh er n’ansoor ad dy mie, dênee Eh jeh, Cre’n ard anney ooilley?

English: 29 And Jesus answered him, The first of all the commandments is, Hear, O Israel; The Lord our God is one Lord:
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey Eh, Yn chied anney jeh ooilley ny annaghyn, Clasht, O Israel, Ta’n Chiarn yn Jee ain un Chiarn;

English: 30 And thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind, and with all thy strength: this is the first commandment.
Manx: As ver oo graih da’n Chiarn dty Yee lesh ooilley dty chree, as lesh ooilley dty annym, as lesh ooilley dt’aigney, as lesh ooilley dty niart: shoh’n chied anney.

English: And the second is like, namely this, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself. There is none other commandment greater than these.
Manx: 31. As ta’n nah anney goll rish, ta shen dy ghra, Ver oo graih da dty naboo, myr dhyt hene: cha vel anney erbee elley smoo na ad shoh.

English: 32 And the scribe said unto him, Well, Master, thou hast said the truth: for there is one God; and there is none other but he:
Manx: As dooyrt y scrudere rish, Ta shen dy mie, Vainshtyr, t’ow er loayrt yn irriney: son ta un Jee ayn, as cha vel Jee erbee elley agh Eh.

English: 33 And to love him with all the heart, and with all the understanding, and with all the soul, and with all the strength, and to love his neighbour as himself, is more than all whole burnt offerings and sacrifices.
Manx: As dy ve graihagh er lesh ooilley’n chree, as lesh ooilley’n tushtey, as lesh ooilley’n annym, as lesh ooilley’n niart, as dy ve graihagh er e naboo myr er hene, ta shen ny smoo na ooilley ny slane chebballyn losht as ourallyn.

English: 34 And when Jesus saw that he answered discreetly, he said unto him, Thou art not far from the kingdom of God. And no man after that durst ask him any question.
Manx: As tra honnick Yeesey dy dansoor Eh dy tushtagh, dooyrt Eh rish, Cha vel oo foddey veih reeriaght Yee. As cha by-loys da dooinney erbee ny lurg shen question erbee y ênaght jeh.

English: 35 ¶And Jesus answered and said, while he taught in the temple, How say the scribes that Christ is the son of David?
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh, choud as v’eh gynsaghey ayns y chiamble, Kys ta ny scruderyn gra dy nee Creest mac Ghavid?

English: 36 For David himself said by the Holy Ghost, The Lord said to my Lord, Sit thou on my right hand, till I make thine enemies thy footstool.
Manx: Son ta David Eh hene er ghra liorish y Spyrryd Noo, Dooyrt y Chiarn rish my Hiarn’s, Soie uss er my laue yesh, derrey verrym dty noidjyn son stoyl dty chassyn.

English: 37 David therefore himself calleth him Lord; and whence is he then his son? And the common people heard him gladly.
Manx: Ta David er-y-fa shen Eh hene genmyss Eh ny Hiarn; as kys t’eh eisht yn mac echey? As deaisht yn pobble v’er nyn jaglym cooidjagh rish dy arryltagh.

English: 38 ¶And he said unto them in his doctrine, Beware of the scribes, which love to go in long clothing, and love salutations in the marketplaces,
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo ayns e ynsagh, Cur-jee twoaie jeh ny scruderyn, ta booiagh ve shooyl ayns coamraghyn liaurey, as sleih dy vannaghey daue ayns ny margaghyn,

English: 39 And the chief seats in the synagogues, and the uppermost rooms at feasts:
Manx: As ny ard-stuill y ve oc ayns ny kialteenyn, as ny ard ynnydyn-soie ec cuirraghyn:

English: 40 Which devour widows’ houses, and for a pretence make long prayers: these shall receive greater damnation.
Manx: T’ad cur mow thieyn mraane-treoghe, as liggey orroo dy bee ad foddey ec padjer: ta kerraghey strimmey nyn gouyr oc shoh.

English: 41 ¶And Jesus sat over against the treasury, and beheld how the people cast money into the treasury: and many that were rich cast in much.
Manx: As myr va Yeesey ny hoie liorish kishtey yn stoyr, as cur tastey kys va’n pobble cur argid ayns y stoyr: as ren ymmodee va berchagh cur ayn dy palchey.

English: 42 And there came a certain poor widow, and she threw in two mites, which make a farthing.
Manx: As haink ben voght treoghe dy row, as hilg ee ayn daa vite ta jannoo farling.

English: 43 And he said unto them in his doctrine, Beware of the scribes, which love to go in long clothing, and love salutations in the marketplaces,
Manx: As deïe Eh orroosyn va sheer geiyrt er huggey, as dooyrt Eh roo, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy vel y ven-treoghe voght shoh er chur ny smoo ayns kishtey’n stoyr, na dy chooilley annane t’er choyrt ayn.

English: 44 For all they did cast in of their abundance; but she of her want did cast in all that she had, even all her living.
Manx: Son t’adsyn ooilley er chur ayn ass nyn balchey: agh tie ish ass y ghennid eck er hilgey ayn ooilley ny v’eck, dy jarroo ooilley ny v’eck dy veaghey er.
CAB. XIII.

English: And as he went out of the temple, one of his disciples saith unto him, Master, see what manner of stones and what buildings are here
Manx: As myr v’eh goll magh ass y chiamble, dooyrt fer jeusyn va sheer geiyrt er rish, Vainshtyr, jeeagh cre’n sorch dy chlaghyn, as cre’n vuildal t’ayns shoh.

English: 2 And Jesus answering said unto him, Seest thou these great buildings? there shall not be left one stone upon another, that shall not be thrown down.
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh rish, Vel oo fakin y vuildal vooar shoh? cha bee faagit un chlagh er clagh elley nagh bee tilgit sheese.

English: 3 And as he sat upon the mount of Olives over against the temple, Peter and James and John and Andrew asked him privately,
Manx: As myr v’eh ny hoie er cronck ny Oliveyn, jeeragh er y chiamble, dênee Peddyr as Jamys, as Ean, as Andreays jeh er-lheh,

English: 4 Tell us, when shall these things be? and what shall be the sign when all these things shall be fulfilled?
Manx: Insh dooin, cooin vees ny reddyn shoh? as cre vees y cowrey tra vees dy chooilley nhee jeu shoh er nyn gooilleeney?

English: 5 And Jesus answering them began to say, Take heed lest any man deceive you:
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey ad, as ren Eh toshiaght dy ghra, Cur-jee twoaie nagh moll dooinney erbee shiu.

English: 6 For many shall come in my name, saying, I am Christ; and shall deceive many.
Manx: Son hig ymmodee ayns m’ennym’s, gra, Mish Creest: as nee ad ymmodee y volley.

English: 7 And when ye shall hear of wars and rumours of wars, be ye not troubled: for such things must needs be; but the end shall not be yet.
Manx: As tra chlinnys shiu jeh caggaghyn, as jeh imraaghyn dy chaggaghyn, ny bee-jee seaghnit: son shegin da leid ny reddyn y ve, agh cha bee yn jerrey foast.

English: 8 For nation shall rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom: and there shall be earthquakes in divers places, and there shall be famines and troubles: these are the beginnings of sorrows.
Manx: Son irree ashoon noi ashoon, as reeriaght noi reeriaght: as bee craaghyn-thallooin ayns ymmodee dy ynnydyn, as gennaghyn as seaghyn: ad shoh toshiaght trimshey.

English: 9 But take heed to yourselves: for they shall deliver you up to councils; and in the synagogues ye shall be beaten: and ye shall be brought before rulers and kings for my sake, for a testimony against them.
Manx: Agh cur-jee twoaie diu hene: son livrey-ee ad shiu seose gys coonceïlyn; as ayns ny quaiyllyn vees shiu er nyn mwoalley, as bee shiu er nyn goyrt kiongoyrt rish fir-reïl as reeaghyn er y choontey aym’s, dy ve son feanish nyn oi oc.

English: 10 And the gospel must first be published among all nations.
Manx: As shegin da’n sushtal ve hoshiaght er ny phreacheil mastey dy chooilley ashoon.

English: 11 But when they shall lead you, and deliver you up, take no thought beforehand what ye shall speak, neither do ye premeditate: but whatsoever shall be given you in that hour, that speak ye: for it is not ye that speak, but the Holy Ghost.
Manx: Agh tra nee ad shiu y leeideil as y livrey seose, ny smooinee-jee ro-laue cre nee shiu y loayrt, cha-moo vees shiu imneagh ayns nyn greeaghyn: agh cre-erbee vees er ny choyrt diu ayns yn oor shen, shen loayr-jee; son cha nee shiuish ta loayrt, agh y Spyrryd Noo.

English: 12 Now the brother shall betray the brother to death, and the father the son; and children shall rise up against their parents, and shall cause them to be put to death.
Manx: Nish livrey-ee yn derrey vraar yn braar elley gys baase, as yn ayr y mac: as nee cloan girree seose noi nyn ayr as nyn moir, as eiyree ad ad gys baase.

English: 13 And ye shall be hated of all men for my name’s sake: but he that shall endure unto the end, the same shall be saved.
Manx: As ver dy chooilley ghooinney feoh diu kyndagh rish yn ennym aym’s: agh bee eshyn nee tannaghtyn gys y jerrey er ny hauail.

English: 14 ¶But when ye shall see the abomination of desolation, spoken of by Daniel the prophet, standing where it ought not, (let him that readeth understand,) then let them that be in Judaea flee to the mountains:
Manx: Agh tra hee shiu eajeeid y traartys, ta loayrit jeh liorish Daniel yn phadeyr, ny hassoo raad nagh lhisagh eh, (eshyn ta lhaih, lig da tastey ghoaill) eisht lig dauesyn t’ayns Judea, roih gys ny sleïtyn:

English: 15 And let him that is on the housetop not go down into the house, neither enter therein, to take any thing out of his house:
Manx: As eshyn t’er mullagh y thie, ny lig da cheet neose, ny goll stiagh, dy ghoaill nhee erbee ass e hie.

English: 16 And let him that is in the field not turn back again for to take up his garment.
Manx: As ny lig dasyn t’ayns y vagher chyndaa back, dy chur lesh e gharmad.

English: 17 But woe to them that are with child, and to them that give suck in those days
Manx: Agh smerg dauesyn ta torragh, as dauesyn ta cur keeagh ayns ny laghyn shen.

English: 18 And pray ye that your flight be not in the winter.
Manx: As guee-jee nagh bee yn roih eu er-chea ayns y yeurey.

English: 19 For in those days shall be affliction, such as was not from the beginning of the creation which God created unto this time, neither shall be.
Manx: Son bee seaghyn ayns ny laghyn shen, leid as nagh row er dy hoshiaght y theihll ta Jee er ny chroo, gys yn earish shen, as leid as nagh bee arragh dy bragh.

English: 20 And except that the Lord had shortened those days, no flesh should be saved: but for the elect’s sake, whom he hath chosen, he hath shortened the days.
Manx: As mannagh beagh y Chiarn dy leah er chur kione er ny laghyn shen, cha beagh feill erbee er ny hauail: agh er graih yn chloan reiht, t’eh er ny reih, t’eh er chur er ny laghyn ve dy leah ec kione.

English: 21 And then if any man shall say to you, Lo, here is Christ; or, lo, he is there; believe him not:
Manx: As eisht my jir dooinney erbee riu, Cur-my-ner, ta Creest ayns shoh, ny cur-my-ner, t’eh ayns shid; ny cred-jee Eh.

English: 22 For false Christs and false prophets shall rise, and shall shew signs and wonders, to seduce, if it were possible, even the elect.
Manx: Son nee Creestyn foalsey, as Phadeyryn foalsey girree, as cowraghyn as yindyssyn y hoilshaghey, dy volley, dy beagh eh possible, yn eer chloan reiht.

English: 23 But take ye heed: behold, I have foretold you all things.
Manx: Agh cur-jee twoaie: cur-my-ner, ta mish er n’insh diu dy chooilley nhee ro-laue.

English: 24 ¶But in those days, after that tribulation, the sun shall be darkened, and the moon shall not give her light,
Manx: Agh ayns ny laghyn shen, lurg y seaghyn shen, aasee yn ghrïan dorraghey, as cha der yn aist e soilshey:

English: 25 And the stars of heaven shall fall, and the powers that are in heaven shall be shaken.
Manx: As tuittee rollaagyn yn aer, as bee pooaraghyn yn aer er nyn graa.

English: 26 And then shall they see the Son of man coming in the clouds with great power and glory.
Manx: As eisht hee ad yn Mac dooinney cheet ayns ny bodjallyn, lesh pooar as gloyr vooar.

English: 27 And then shall he send his angels, and shall gather together his elect from the four winds, from the uttermost part of the earth to the uttermost part of heaven.
Manx: As eisht ver Eh magh e ainlyn, as nee Eh e chloan reiht y haglym cooidjagh veih ny kiare geayghyn, veih’n ayrn sodjey ass y raad jeh’n thalloo, gys yn ayrn sodjey jeh’n aer.

English: 28 Now learn a parable of the fig tree; When her branch is yet tender, and putteth forth leaves, ye know that summer is near:
Manx: Nish ynsee-jee coraa-dorraghey jeh’n billey-figgagh: Tra ta’n banglane echey foast oor, as cur magh duillagyn, ta fys eu dy vel y sourey er-gerrey:

English: 29 So ye in like manner, when ye shall see these things come to pass, know that it is nigh, even at the doors.
Manx: Myr shen myrgeddin shiuish, tra hee shiu ny reddyn shoh cheet gy kione, toig-jee dy vel eh er-gerrey, dy jarroo ec ny dorryssyn.

English: 30 Verily I say unto you, that this generation shall not pass, till all these things be done.
Manx: Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, roish my vow yn cheeloghe shoh baase, dy bee dy chooilley nhee jeu shoh jeant.

English: 31 Heaven and earth shall pass away: but my words shall not pass away.
Manx: Nee niau as thalloo cherraghtyn: agh my ghoan’s cha jean cherraghtyn.

English: 23 ¶But of that day and that hour knoweth no man, no, not the angels which are in heaven, neither the Son, but the Father.
Manx: Agh er y laa as yn oor shen, cha vel fys ec dooinney erbee, ny ec ny ainlyn t’ayns niau, ny ec y Mac, agh yn Ayr.

English: 24 Take ye heed, watch and pray: for ye know not when the time is.
Manx: Gow-jee tastey, bee-jee er nyn dwoaie as guee-jee: son cha s’eu cooin ta’n traa.

English: 34 For the Son of Man is as a man taking a far journey, who left his house, and gave authority to his servants, and to every man his work, and commanded the porter to watch.
Manx: Son ta’n Mac dooinney myr dooinney va goll er-troailt, as daag e hie, as hug pooar da e harvaantyn, as da dy chooilley ghooinney e obbyr, as hug Eh saarey da’n porter dy watchal.

English: 35 Watch ye therefore: for ye know not when the master of the house cometh, at even, or at midnight, or at the cockcrowing, or in the morning:
Manx: Bee-jee shiuish er nyn dwoaie er-y-fa shen (son cha s’eu cooin hig mainshtyr y thie; ayns yn astyr, ny ec main-oie, ny ec gerrym y chellee, ny ayns y voghrey)

English: 36 Lest coming suddenly he find you sleeping.
Manx: Er aggle dy jig Eh doaltattym, as dy vow Eh shiu nyn gadley.

English: 37 And what I say unto you I say unto all, Watch.
Manx: As ny ta mee dy ghra riuish, ta mee dy ghra rish ooilley, Jean-jee watchal.
CAB. XIV.

English: After two days was the feast of the passover, and of unleavened bread: and the chief priests and the scribes sought how they might take him by craft, and put him to death.
Manx: Lurg daa laa va feailley ny Caisht as yn arran millish: as va ny ard-saggyrtyn as ny scruderyn shirrey kys oddagh ad Eh y ghoaill dy follit, dy choyrt Eh gy baase.

English: 2 But they said, Not on the feast day, lest there be an uproar of the people.
Manx: Agh dooyrt ad, Cha nee er laa’n eailley, er-aggle dy bee irree-magh ayn mastey yn pobble.

English: 3 ¶And being in Bethany in the house of Simon the leper, as he sat at meat, there came a woman having an alabaster box of ointment of spikenard very precious; and she brake the box, and poured it on his head.
Manx: As myr v’eh ny hoie ec bee, ayns Bethany, ayns thie Simon yn louraane, haink ben as box alabaster dy ooill eck, jeh spikenard feer deyr; as doshil ee yn box, as gheayrt ee eh er y chione echey.

English: 4 And there were some that had indignation within themselves, and said, Why was this waste of the ointment made?
Manx: As va paart va jymmoosagh cheu-sthie jeu hene, gra, Cre’n-fa va’n jummal shoh jeh’n ooill jeant?

English: 5 For it might have been sold for more than three hundred pence, and have been given to the poor. And they murmured against her.
Manx: Son oddagh eh v’er ny ve creckit son ny smoo na three cheead ping, as er ny choyrt da ny boghtyn. As v’ad jymmoosagh ree.

English: 6 And Jesus said, Let her alone; why trouble ye her? she hath wrought a good work on me.
Manx: As dooyrt Yeesey, Faag-jee ee, cre’n-fa ta shiu dy boirey ee? t’ee er n’obbraghey obbyr vie orryms.

English: 7 For ye have the poor with you always, and whensoever ye will ye may do them good: but me ye have not always.
Manx: Son ta ny boghtyn eu kinjagh mêriu, as tra erbee dy naïlliu, foddee shiu mie y yannoo daue: agh mish cha vel eu kinjagh.

English: 8 She hath done what she could: she is come aforehand to anoint my body to the burying.
Manx: T’ee er n’yannoo ny dod ee: t’ee er-jeet ro-laue dy ooillaghey my chorp gouyr my oanluckey.

English: 9 Verily I say unto you, Wheresoever this gospel shall be preached throughout the whole world, this also that she hath done shall be spoken of for a memorial of her.
Manx: Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Raad erbee dy bee yn sushtal shoh er ny phreacheil trooid ooilley’n seihll, bee shoh tie ish er n’yannoo, loayrit jeh son cooinaghtyn jee.

English: 10 ¶And Judas Iscariot, one of the twelve, went unto the chief priests, to betray him unto them.
Manx: As hie Yuaase Iscariot, fer jeh’n daa ostyl yeig, gys ny ard-saggyrtyn, dy vrah Eh huc.

English: 11 And when they heard it, they were glad, and promised to give him money. And he sought how he might conveniently betray him.
Manx: As tra cheayll ad shoh, v’ad booiagh, as yiall ad argid y chur da. As v’eh feeau er traa cooie dy vrah Eh.

English: 12 ¶And the first day of unleavened bread, when they killed the passover, his disciples said unto him, Where wilt thou that we go and prepare that thou mayest eat the passover?
Manx: As er y chied laa jeh’n arran millish, tra v’ad marroo yn Eayn-caisht, dooyrt adsyn va sheer geiyrt er rish, Cre’n raad saïlt shin dy gholl as dy yannoo aarloo, dy vod oo yn Eayn-caisht y ee?

English: 13 And he sendeth forth two of his disciples, and saith unto them, Go ye into the city, and there shall meet you a man bearing a pitcher of water: follow him.
Manx: As hug Eh magh jees jeusyn va sheer marish, as dooyrt Eh roo, Gow-jee gys yn ard-valley, as hig nyn guail dooinney vees saagh-craie dy ushtey echey: eiyr-jee ersyn.

English: 14 And wheresoever he shall go in, say ye to the goodman of the house, The Master saith, Where is the guestchamber, where I shall eat the passover with my disciples?
Manx: As raad erbee dy jed Eh stiagh, abbyr-jee rish far-thie yn thie, Ta’n Mainshtyr gra, Cre vel shamyr ny goaldee, raad nee’m yn Eayn-caisht y ee maroosyn ta sheer mârym?

English: 15 And he will shew you a large upper room furnished and prepared: there make ready for us.
Manx: As jeeagh-ee Eh diu ard-room mooar vees soit magh as jeant aarloo: ayns shen aarlee-jee er nyn son.

English: 16 And his disciples went forth, and came into the city, and found as he had said unto them: and they made ready the passover.
Manx: As hie yn vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er magh, as haink ad gys yn ard-valley, as hooar ad myr v’eh er ghra roo: as daarlee ad yn Eayn-caisht.

English: 17 And in the evening he cometh with the twelve.
Manx: As ayns yn astyr haink Eh marish yn daa ostyl yeig.

English: 18 And as they sat and did eat, Jesus said, Verily I say unto you, One of you which eateth with me shall betray me.
Manx: As myr v’ad nyn soih ec bee, dooyrt Yeesey, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Dy jean annane eauish ta gee mârym mish y vrah.

English: 19 And they began to be sorrowful, and to say unto him one by one, Is it I? and another said, Is it I?
Manx: As ren ad toshiaght dy ve trimshagh, as dy ghra rish annane lurg annane, Nee mish Eh? as dooyrt fer elley, Nee orryms t’ow cheet?

English: 20 And he answered and said unto them, It is one of the twelve, that dippeth with me in the dish.
Manx: As dreggyr Eh, as dooyrt Eh roo, She fer jeh’n daa ostyl yeig Eh, ta cur e laue mârym ayns y chlaare.

English: 21 The Son of man indeed goeth, as it is written of him: but woe to that man by whom the Son of man is betrayed! good were it for that man if he had never been born.
Manx: Ta’n Mac dooinney dy jarroo goll myr te scruit jeh: agh smerg da’n dooinney shen liorish ta’n Mac dooinney er ny vrah; mie veagh eh er ve son y dooinney shen mannagh beagh Eh rieau er-jeet er y theihll.

English: 22 ¶And as they did eat, Jesus took bread, and blessed, and brake it, and gave to them, and said, Take, eat: this is my body.
Manx: As myr v’ad gee, ghow Yeesey arran, as vannee as vrish Eh eh, as hug Eh eh daue, gra, Gow-jee, ee-jee: shoh my chorp.

English: 23 And he took the cup, and when he had given thanks, he gave it to them: and they all drank of it.
Manx: As ghow Eh yn cappan, as tra v’eh er chur booise, hug Eh eh daue: as diu ad ooilley jeh.

English: 24 And he said unto them, This is my blood of the new testament, which is shed for many.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Shoh my uill’s jeh’n conaant noa t’er ny gheayrtey son ymmodee.

English: 25 Verily I say unto you, I will drink no more of the fruit of the vine, until that day that I drink it new in the kingdom of God.
Manx: Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Nagh niu-ym ny smoo jeh mess y villey-feeney, derrey’n laa iu-ym eh ass yn noa ayns reeriaght Yee.

English: 26 ¶And when they had sung an hymn, they went out into the mount of Olives.
Manx: As tra v’ad er ghoaill arrane spyrrydoil, hie ad magh gys cronck ny Oliveyn.

English: 27 And Jesus saith unto them, All ye shall be offended because of me this night: for it is written, I will smite the shepherd, and the sheep shall be scattered.
Manx: As dooyrt Yeesey roo, Failee yn credjue eauish ooilley noght kyndagh rhyms: son te scruit, Bwoaillyms yn bochilley, as bee ny kirree er nyn skeayley.

English: 28 But after that I am risen, I will go before you into Galilee.
Manx: Agh erreish dou v’er n’irree reesht, hem reue gys Galilee.

English: 29 But Peter said unto him, Although all shall be offended, yet will not I.
Manx: Agh dooyrt Peddyr rish, Ga dy vaill credjue dy chooilley annane, foast cha vaill my chredjue’s.

English: 30 And Jesus saith unto him, Verily I say unto thee, That this day, even in this night, before the cock crow twice, thou shalt deny me thrice.
Manx: As dooyrt Yeesey rish, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra rhyt, yn laa jiu, dy jarroo yn oie noght roish my gerr y kellagh daa cheayrt, dy nob uss mish three keayrtyn.

English: 31 But he spake the more vehemently, If I should die with thee, I will not deny thee in any wise. Likewise also said they all.
Manx: Agh loayr eshyn ny s’jeeanney, Dy beïn dy gholl gy baase mârt, cha nobbin oo er aght erbee. As er yn aght cheddin loayr ad ooilley.

English: 32 And they came to a place which was named Gethsemane: and he saith to his disciples, Sit ye here, while I shall pray.
Manx: As haink ad gys ynnyd va enmyssit Gethsemane: as dooyrt Eh rish e ostyllyn, Soie-jee shiuish ayns shoh, choud as hems gys padjer.

English: 33 And he taketh with him Peter and James and John, and began to be sore amazed, and to be very heavy;
Manx: As ghow Eh marish, Peddyr as Jamys as Ean, as ren Eh toshiaght dy ve feer atchimagh as trome-chreeagh,

English: 34 And saith unto them, My soul is exceeding sorrowful unto death: tarry ye here, and watch.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Ta m’annym feer trimshagh gys y baase: fuirree-jee ayns shoh, as jean-jee watchal.

English: 35 And he went forward a little, and fell on the ground, and prayed that, if it were possible, the hour might pass from him.
Manx: As hie Eh red beg er y hoshiaght, as huit Eh er y thalloo, as ghow Eh padjer, my ve possible yn oor shen dy gholl shiaghey.

English: 36 And he said, Abba, Father, all things are possible unto thee; take away this cup from me: nevertheless not what I will, but what thou wilt.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Abba, Ayr, ta dy chooilley nhee possible dhyts, gow ersooyl yn cappan shoh voym: ny-yeih cha nee m’aigney’s, agh dt’aigney’s dy row jeant.

English: 37 And he cometh, and findeth them sleeping, and saith unto Peter, Simon, sleepest thou? couldest not thou watch one hour?
Manx: As haink Eh as hooar Eh ad nyn gadley, as dooyrt Eh rish Peddyr, Simon, vel uss dy [sic: dty] chadley? nagh row abyl watchal mârym un oor?

English: 38 Watch ye and pray, lest ye enter into temptation. The spirit truly is ready, but the flesh is weak.
Manx: Bee-jee er nyn dwoaie, as guee-jee, nagh duit shiu ayns miolagh: ta’n spyrryd eu dy jarroo arryltagh, agh ta’n eill annoon.

English: 39 And again he went away, and prayed, and spake the same words.
Manx: As hie Eh roish reesht, as ghow Eh padjer, as loayr Eh ny goan cheddin.

English: 40 And when he returned, he found them asleep again, (for their eyes were heavy,) neither wist they what to answer him.
Manx: As tra haink Eh back, hooar Eh ad nyn gadley reesht (son va ny sooyllyn oc trome) as cha row fys oc cre’n ansoor dy chur da.

English: 41 And he cometh the third time, and saith unto them, Sleep on now, and take your rest: it is enough, the hour is come; behold, the Son of man is betrayed into the hands of sinners.
Manx: As haink Eh yn tress cheayrt, as dooyrt Eh roo, Caidle-jee nish, as gow-jee nyn vea: te dy liooar, ta’n oor er-jeet; cur-my-ner, ta’n Mac dooinney er ny vrah gys laueyn peccee.

English: 42 Rise up, let us go; lo, he that betrayeth me is at hand.
Manx: Irree-jee erriu, lig dooin goll: cur-my-ner, te [sic: ta] eshyn er gerrey dooin ta dy my vrah.

English: 43 ¶And immediately, while he yet spake, cometh Judas, one of the twelve, and with him a great multitude with swords and staves, from the chief priests and the scribes and the elders.
Manx: As chelleeragh choud as v’eh foast loayrt, haink Yuaase, fer jeh’n daa ostyl yeig, as marish va sheshaght vooar lesh cliwnyn as luirg, veih ny ard-saggyrtyn, as ny scruderyn, as y chanstyr.

English: 44 And he that betrayed him had given them a token, saying, Whomsoever I shall kiss, that same is he; take him, and lead him away safely.
Manx: As hug eshyn v’er vrah Eh cowrey daue, gra, Quoi-erbee verryms paag da, shen Eh; gow-jee Eh, as leeid-jee Eh ersooyl dy sauchey.

English: 45 And as soon as he was come, he goeth straightway to him, and saith, Master, master; and kissed him.
Manx: As cha leah as v’eh er-jeet, hie Eh chelleeragh huggey, as dooyrt Eh, Vainshtyr, vainshtyr; as phaag Eh Eh.

English: 46 ¶And they laid their hands on him, and took him.
Manx: As hug ad nyn laueyn er, as ghow ad Eh.

English: 47 And one of them that stood by drew a sword, and smote a servant of the high priest, and cut off his ear.
Manx: As hayrn fer jeusyn va nyn shassoo marish cliwe, as woail Eh fer-mooinjerey yn ard-saggyrt, as yiare Eh e chleash jeh.

English: 48 And Jesus answered and said unto them, Are ye come out, as against a thief, with swords and with staves to take me?
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey, as dooyrt Eh roo, Vel shiu er jeet magh myr noi maarlagh, lesh cliwnyn as luirg dy my ghoaill?

English: 49 I was daily with you in the temple teaching, and ye took me not: but the scriptures must be fulfilled.
Manx: Va mee mêriu gagh laa ayns y chiamble, gynsaghey, as cha ghow shiu mee: agh shegin da ny scriptyryn v’er nyn gooilleeney.

English: 50 And they all forsook him, and fled.
Manx: As ren ad ooilley Eh y hreigeil as cosney rowe.

English: 51 And there followed him a certain young man, having a linen cloth cast about his naked body; and the young men laid hold on him:
Manx: As deiyr er dooinney aeg dy row va aanrit mysh e chorp rooisht; as haare ny deiney aegey greme er.

English: 52 And he left the linen cloth, and fled from them naked.
Manx: As daag Eh yn aanrit, as chosne Eh vow rooisht.

English: 53 ¶And they led Jesus away to the high priest: and with him were assembled all the chief priests and the elders and the scribes.
Manx: As leeid ad Yeesey ersooyl gys yn ard-saggyrt: as marishyn v’er nyn jaglym cooidjagh ooilley ny ard-saggyrtyn, as y chanstyr, as ny scruderyn.

English: 54 And Peter followed him afar off, even into the palace of the high priest: and he sat with the servants, and warmed himself at the fire.
Manx: As deiyr Peddyr er foddey ny yei, gys eer thie yn ard-saggyrt: as hoie Eh marish ny sharvaantyn, as hiow Eh Eh hene ec yn aile.

English: 55 And the chief priests and all the council sought for witness against Jesus to put him to death; and found none.
Manx: As va ny ard-saggyrtyn, as ooilley’n choonceil shirrey feanishyn noi Yeesey dy chur Eh gy baase; as cha dooar ad veg.

English: 56 For many bare false witness against him, but their witness agreed not together.
Manx: Son dymmyrk ymmodee feanish foalsey noi, agh cha row yn eanish oc lajer dy liooar.

English: 57 And there arose certain, and bare false witness against him, saying,
Manx: As dirree shiartance, as dymmyrk ad feanish foalsey noi, gra,

English: 58 We heard him say, I will destroy this temple that is made with hands, and within three days I will build another made without hands.
Manx: Cheayll shin Eh gra, Lieggyms y chiamble shoh ta jeant lesh laueyn, as cheu-sthie jeh three laa, troggym chiamble elley vees jeant fegooish laueyn.

English: 59 But neither so did their witness agree together.
Manx: Agh myr shen hene cha row yn eanish oc lajer dy liooar.

English: 60 And the high priest stood up in the midst, and asked Jesus, saying, Answerest thou nothing? what is it which these witness against thee?
Manx: As hass yn ard-saggyrt seose ayns y vain oc, as dênee Eh jeh Yeesey, gra, Nagh vel oo cur ansoor erbee? cre shoh t’ad shoh dy hoilshaghey dt’oi?

English: 61 But he held his peace, and answered nothing. Again the high priest asked him, and said unto him, Art thou the Christ, the Son of the Blessed?
Manx: Agh chum Eh e hengey, as cha dansoor Eh veg. Reesht dênee yn ard-saggyrt jeh, as dooyrt Eh rish, Nee uss yn Creest, Mac yn Er-vannit?

English: 62 And Jesus said, I am: and ye shall see the Son of man sitting on the right hand of power, and coming in the clouds of heaven.
Manx: As dooyrt Yeesey, She shen mee: as hee shiuish yn Mac dooinney ny hoie er laue yesh y phooar, as cheet ayns bodjallyn yn aer.

English: 63 Then the high priest rent his clothes, and saith, What need we any further witnesses?
Manx: Eisht raip yn ard-saggyrt e eaddagh, as dooyrt eh, Cre’n feme t’ain er feanishyn erbee sodjey?

English: 64 Ye have heard the blasphemy: what think ye? And they all condemned him to be guilty of death.
Manx: Ta shiu er chlashtyn ny goan-mollaghtagh: cre ta shiu dy smooinaghtyn? As gheyr ad ooilley Eh dy row Eh toilchin dy v’er ny choyrt gy baase.

English: 65 And some began to spit on him, and to cover his face, and to buffet him, and to say unto him, Prophesy: and the servants did strike him with the palms of their hands.
Manx: As ren paart toshiaght dy chew shellaghyn er, as dy choodaghey yn eddin echey, as dy woalley Eh, as dy ghra rish, Jean phadeyrys: as woaill ny sharvaantyn Eh lesh bassyn nyn laueyn.

English: 66 ¶And as Peter was beneath in the palace, there cometh one of the maids of the high priest:
Manx: As myr va Peddyr heese ayns thie yn ard-saggyrt, haink annane jeh ny inneenyn-veyll.

English: 67 And when she saw Peter warming himself, she looked upon him, and said, And thou also wast with Jesus of Nazareth.
Manx: As tra honnick ee Peddyr dy hiow Eh hene, yeeagh ee er, as dooyrt ee, As vow uss marish Yeesey dy Nazareth.

English: 68 But he denied, saying, I know not, neither understand I what thou sayest. And he went out into the porch; and the cock crew.
Manx: Agh dob Eh, gra, Cha vel fys ny toiggal aym, cre t’ow dy ghra. As hie Eh magh ayns y phorch; as gherr y kellagh.

English: 69 And a maid saw him again, and began to say to them that stood by, This is one of them.
Manx: As honnick ben-aeg Eh reesht, as ren ee toshiaght dy ghra roosyn va nyn shassoo liorish, T’eh shoh fer jeu.

English: 70 And he denied it again. And a little after, they that stood by said again to Peter, Surely thou art one of them: for thou art a Galilaean, and thy speech agreeth thereto.
Manx: As dob Eh reesht. As tammylt ny lurg shen, dooyrt y vooinjer va nyn shassoo liorish reesht rish Peddyr, Shickyr she fer jeu oo: son she Galilean oo, as ta dty ghlare dy hoilshaghey eh.

English: 71 But he began to curse and to swear, saying, I know not this man of whom ye speak.
Manx: Agh ren Eh toshiaght dy ghweeaghyn as dy loo, gra, Cha nione dou yn dooinney shoh jeh ta shiu loayrt.

English: 72 And the second time the cock crew. And Peter called to mind the word that Jesus said unto him, Before the cock crow twice, thou shalt deny me thrice. And when he thought thereon, he wept.
Manx: As yn nah cheayrt ren y kellagh gerrym. As hayrn Peddyr gys cooinaghtyn yn fockle va Yeesey er ghra rish, Roish my gerr y kellagh daa cheayrt, obbee uss mish three keayrtyn. As tra smooinee Eh er shen, ren Eh keaney.
CAB. XV.

English: And straightway in the morning the chief priests held a consultation with the elders and scribes and the whole council, and bound Jesus, and carried him away, and delivered him to Pilate.
Manx: As chelleeragh ayns y voghrey hug ny ard-saggyrtyn as y chanstyr as ny scruderyn, as y slane choonceil, nyn goyrle dy cheilley, as chiangle ad Yeesey, as leeid ad Eh ersooyl, as livrey ad Eh gys Pilate.

English: 2 And Pilate asked him, Art thou the King of the Jews? And he answering said unto them, Thou sayest it.
Manx: As dênee Pilate jeh, Nee ree ny Hewnyn oo? As dreggyr eshyn as dooyrt eh rish, Ta mee ny t’ow uss dy ghra.

English: 3 And the chief priests accused him of many things: but he answered nothing.
Manx: As hug ny ard-saggyrtyn ymmodee dy reddyn ny lieh, agh cha dug Eh ansoor erbee daue.

English: 4 And Pilate asked him again, saying, Answerest thou nothing? behold how many things they witness against thee.
Manx: As dênee Pilate jeh reesht, gra, Nagh vel oo cur ansoor erbee? cur-my-ner cre whilleen red as t’ad shoh dy hoilshaghey dt’oi.

English: 5 But Jesus yet answered nothing; so that Pilate marvelled.
Manx: As cha dug Yeesey ansoor erbee da; myr shen dy ghow Pilate yindyss.

English: 6 Now at that feast he released unto them one prisoner, whomsoever they desired.
Manx: Nish ec yn eailley shen v’eh feaysley daue un phryssoonagh, quoi-erbee hirragh ad.

English: 7 And there was one named Barabbas, which lay bound with them that had made insurrection with him, who had committed murder in the insurrection.
Manx: As va fer va enmyssit Barabbas, va ayns geulaghyn maroosyn v’er n’irree magh marish, as v’er n’yannoo dunverys ayns yn irree-magh oc.

English: 8 And the multitude crying aloud began to desire him to do as he had ever done unto them.
Manx: As deïe yn pobble dy ard, as ren ad toshiaght dy ghuee er, Eh dy yannoo myr v’eh rieau cliaghtey y yannoo er nyn son.

English: 9 But Pilate answered them, saying, Will ye that I release unto you the King of the Jews?
Manx: Agh dansoor Pilate ad, gra, Naïlliu mee dy eaysley diu ree ny Hewnyn.

English: 10 For he knew that the chief priests had delivered him for envy.
Manx: (Son va fys echey dy row ny ard-saggyrtyn er livrey seose Eh ayns goanlys.)

English: 11 But the chief priests moved the people, that he should rather release Barabbas unto them.
Manx: Agh ghreinnee ny ard-saggyrtyn yn pobble, Barabbas dy ve yn dooinney yinnagh Eh y eaysley daue.

English: 12 And Pilate answered and said again unto them, What will ye then that I shall do unto him whom ye call the King of the Jews?
Manx: As dreggyr Pilate, as dooyrt Eh reesht roo, Cre baïlliu mee eisht dy yannoo rishyn ta shiu dy enmys ree ny Hewnyn?

English: 13 And they cried out again, Crucify him.
Manx: As deïe ad dy ard reesht, Jean y chrossey Eh.

English: 14 Then Pilate said unto them, Why, what evil hath he done? And they cried out the more exceedingly, Crucify him.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Pilate roo, Cre’n-oyr, cre t’eh er n’yannoo dy holk? As dyllee ad wheesh shen smoo, Jean y chrossey Eh.

English: 15 ¶And so Pilate, willing to content the people, released Barabbas unto them, and delivered Jesus, when he had scourged him, to be crucified.
Manx: As myr shen va Pilate booiagh nyn aigney y choyrt da’n pobble, as deaysle Eh Barabbas daue, agh livrey Eh Yeesey, tra v’eh er chustey Eh, dy ve er ny chrossey.

English: 16 And the soldiers led him away into the hall, called Praetorium; and they call together the whole band.
Manx: As leeid ny sidooryn Eh ersooyl gys y hall va enmyssit Pretorium; as deïe ad er y slane sheshaght cooidjagh.

English: 17 And they clothed him with purple, and platted a crown of thorns, and put it about his head,
Manx: As choamree ad Eh lesh scarleod, as fee ad attey dy ghrineyn, as hug ad eh mygeayrt y chione echey.

English: 18 And began to salute him, Hail, King of the Jews
Manx: As ren ad toshiaght dy oltaghey da, Dy vannee, Ree ny Hewnyn.

English: 19 And they smote him on the head with a reed, and did spit upon him, and bowing their knees worshipped him.
Manx: As woail ad Eh er y chione lesh cuirtliagh, as chew ad shellaghyn er, as chroym ad nyn ghlioonyn kiongoyrt rish, as hug ad ooashley da.

English: 20 And when they had mocked him, they took off the purple from him, and put his own clothes on him, and led him out to crucify him.
Manx: As tra v’ad er chraidey mysh, ghow ad yn scarleod jeh, as hug ad e eaddagh hene er, as leeid ad Eh magh dy chrossey eh.

English: 21 And they compel one Simon a Cyrenian, who passed by, coming out of the country, the father of Alexander and Rufus, to bear his cross.
Manx: As deaginee ad fer va enmyssit Simon Cyrenian va goll shiaghey, cheet ass y cheer, ayr Alexander as Rufus, dy ymmyrkey e chrosh.

English: 22 And they bring him unto the place Golgotha, which is, being interpreted, The place of a skull.
Manx: As hug ad lhieu Eh gys yn ynnyd Golgotha, ta shen, tra ta bun er ny chur er, ynnyd bollag.

English: 23 And they gave him to drink wine mingled with myrrh: but he received it not.
Manx: As hug ad da dy iu, feeyn as myrrhe ny-chione: agh cha ghow Eh eh.

English: 24 And when they had crucified him, they parted his garments, casting lots upon them, what every man should take.
Manx: As tra v’ad er chrossey Eh, reynn ad e gharmadyn, tilgey lottyn orroo, cre yinnagh dy chooilley ghooinney y ghoaill.

English: 25 And it was the third hour, and they crucified him.
Manx: As ve yn tress oor, as ren ad y chrossey Eh.

English: 26 And the superscription of his accusation was written over, THE KING OF THE JEWS.
Manx: As va screeu va cur coontey jeh oyr e vaaish scruit harrish, REE NY HEWNYN.

English: 27 And with him they crucify two thieves; the one on his right hand, and the other on his left.
Manx: As marish ren ad daa vaarlagh y chrossey; yn derrey yeh er e laue yesh, as y jeh elley er e laue chiare.

English: 28 And the scripture was fulfilled, which saith, And he was numbered with the transgressors.
Manx: As va’n scriptyr cooilleenit, ta gra, As v’eh er ny earroo marish ny drogh-yantee.

English: 29 And they that passed by railed on him, wagging their heads, and saying, Ah, thou that destroyest the temple, and buildest it in three days,
Manx: As loayr yn vooinjer va goll shiaghey dy lunagh noi, craa nyn ging, as gra, Ah, uss ta lieggal y chiamble as dy hroggal eh reesht ayns three laa,

English: 30 Save thyself, and come down from the cross.
Manx: Saue oo hene, as tar neose jeh’n chrosh.

English: 31 Likewise also the chief priests mocking said among themselves with the scribes, He saved others; himself he cannot save.
Manx: Myr shen myrgeddin ren ny ard-saggyrtyn craidey, gra nyn mast’ oc hene marish ny scruderyn, Haue Eh feallagh elley, Eh hene cha vel Eh abyl y hauail.

English: 32 Let Christ the King of Israel descend now from the cross, that we may see and believe. And they that were crucified with him reviled him.
Manx: Lig da Creest Ree Israel cheet neose nish jeh’n chrosh, dy vod mad fakin as credjal. As ren adsyn v’er nyn grossey marish, Eh y oltooan.

English: 33 And when the sixth hour was come, there was darkness over the whole land until the ninth hour.
Manx: As tra va’n cheyoo oor er jeet, va dorraghys harrish ooilley’n cheer, gys yn nuyoo oor.

English: 34 And at the ninth hour Jesus cried with a loud voice, saying, Eloi, Eloi, lama sabachthani? which is, being interpreted, My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me?
Manx: As ec yn nuyoo oor deïe Yeesey lesh ard choraa, gra, Eloi, Eloi, lama sabachthani? ta shen, tra ta bun er ny chur er, My Yee, My Yee, My Yee, cre’n-fa t’ow er my hreigeil?

English: 35 And some of them that stood by, when they heard it, said, Behold, he calleth Elias.
Manx: As dooyrt paart jeusyn va nyn shassoo ayns shen, tra cheayll ad shoh, Cur-my-ner, t’eh geamagh er Elias.

English: 36 And one ran and filled a spunge full of vinegar, and put it on a reed, and gave him to drink, saying, Let alone; let us see whether Elias will come to take him down.
Manx: As roih fer, as lhieen Eh spunge laane vinegar, as hug Eh eh er cuirtliagh, as heeyn Eh huggey dy iu, gra, Faag-jee Eh; hee mad jig Elias dy ghoaill neose Eh.

English: 37 And Jesus cried with a loud voice, and gave up the ghost.
Manx: As deïe Yeesey lesh ard choraa, as phaart Eh.

English: 38 And the veil of the temple was rent in twain from the top to the bottom.
Manx: As va’n coodaghey va eddyr y chiamble as yn ynnyd casherick rapit veih my chielley, veih’n vullagh gys y laare.

English: 39 And when the centurion, which stood over against him, saw that he so cried out, and gave up the ghost, he said, Truly this man was the Son of God.
Manx: As tra honnick yn captan-keead va ny hassoo jeeragh er y raad v’eh, dy row Eh myr shen er n’eamagh, as er phaartail, dooyrt Eh, Dy firrinagh she Mac Yee va’n dooinney shoh.

English: 40 There were also women looking on afar off: among whom was Mary Magdalene, and Mary the mother of James the less and of Joses, and Salome;
Manx: Va myrgeddin ymmodee mraane dy akin Eh foddey vow: nyn mast’ ocsyn va Moirrey Malaine, as Moirrey moir Yamys by loo as Joses, as Salome;

English: 41 (Who also, when he was in Galilee, followed him, and ministered unto him;) and many other women which came up with him unto Jerusalem.
Manx: Va myrgeddin tra v’eh ayns Galilee, er n’eiyrt, as er hirveish er; as ymmodee mraane elley v’er jeet seose marish gys Jerusalem.

English: 42 ¶And now when the even was come, because it was the preparation, that is, the day before the sabbath,
Manx: As nish tra va’n fastyr er jeet (er-yn-oyr dy nee traa yn aarlaghey ve, ta shen, yn laa roish y doonaght.)

English: 43 Joseph of Arimathaea, an honourable counsellor, which also waited for the kingdom of God, came, and went in boldly unto Pilate, and craved the body of Jesus.
Manx: Haink Joseph dy Arimathea, fer-coyrlee ooasle, va myrgeddin Eh hene farkiagh son reeriaght Yee, as cha ghow Eh aggle, agh hie Eh stiagh gys Pilate, as ren Eh aghin son corp Yeesey.

English: 44 And Pilate marvelled if he were already dead: and calling unto him the centurion, he asked him whether he had been any while dead.
Manx: As ghow Pilate yindyss my v’eh hannah marroo: as deïe Eh er y captan-keead huggey, as dênee Eh jeh, row Eh er ve foddey marroo?

English: 45 And when he knew it of the centurion, he gave the body to Joseph.
Manx: As tra hooar Eh fys er veih’n captan-keead, hug Eh yn corp da Joseph.

English: 46 And he bought fine linen, and took him down, and wrapped him in the linen, and laid him in a sepulchre which was hewn out of a rock, and rolled a stone unto the door of the sepulchre.
Manx: As chionnee Eh aanrit keyll, as ghow Eh neose Eh, as hoïll Eh Eh ayns yn aanrit, as doanluck Eh Eh ayns oaie va cleyt ayns creg, as rowll Eh clagh er beeall yn oaie.

English: 47 And Mary Magdalene and Mary the mother of Joses beheld where he was laid.
Manx: As honnick Moirrey Malaine as Moirrey moir Joses, c’raad v’eh er ny oanluckey.
CAB. XVI.

English: And when the sabbath was past, Mary Magdalene, and Mary the mother of James, and Salome, had bought sweet spices, that they might come and anoint him.
Manx: As tra va’n doonaght ec kione, va Moirrey Malaine, as Moirrey moir Jamys, as Salome, er chionnaghey spisyn miljey dy voddagh ad cheet dy ooillaghey Eh.

English: 2 And very early in the morning the first day of the week, they came unto the sepulchre at the rising of the sun.
Manx: As dy feer voghey ayns y voghrey, er y chied laa jeh’n chiaghtin, haink ad gys yn oaie ec irree ny greïney.

English: 3 And they said among themselves, Who shall roll us away the stone from the door of the sepulchre?
Manx: As dooyrt ad nyn mast’ oc hene, Quoi rowlys ersooyl yn chlagh jeh beeall yn oaie?

English: 4 And when they looked, they saw that the stone was rolled away: for it was very great.
Manx: (As tra v’ad er yeeaghyn, honnick ad y chlagh rowlit ersooyl) son v’ee feer vooar.

English: 5 And entering into the sepulchre, they saw a young man sitting on the right side, clothed in a long white garment; and they were affrighted.
Manx: As hie ad stiagh ayns yn oaie, as honnick ad dooinney aeg ny hoie er y cheu yesh, coamrit ayns coamrey liauyr gial; as v’ad agglagh.

English: 6 And he saith unto them, Be not affrighted: Ye seek Jesus of Nazareth, which was crucified: he is risen; he is not here: behold the place where they laid him.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Ny gow-jee aggle: ta shiu shirrey Yeesey dy Nazareth, v’er ny chrossey: t’eh er n’irree; cha vel Eh ayns shoh: cur-my-ner shoh’n boayl v’eh oanluckit ayn.

English: 7 But go your way, tell his disciples and Peter that he goeth before you into Galilee: there shall ye see him, as he said unto you.
Manx: Agh gow-jee reue, insh-jee dauesyn va sheer geiyrt er as da Peddyr, dy vel Eh goll reue gys Galilee: ayns shen hee shiu Eh, myr dooyrt Eh riu.

English: 8 And they went out quickly, and fled from the sepulchre; for they trembled and were amazed: neither said they any thing to any man; for they were afraid.
Manx: As hie ad magh dy tappee, as roih ad rowe veih’n oaie; son v’ad er-creau as atchimagh: cha-moo loayr ad veg rish dooinney erbee; son v’ad ayns aggle.

English: 9 ¶Now when Jesus was risen early the first day of the week, he appeared first to Mary Magdalene, out of whom he had cast seven devils.
Manx: Nish tra va Yeesey er n’irree dy moghey, er y chied laa jeh’n chaghtin, hoilshee Eh Eh hene hoshiaght da Moirrey Malaine, ass-jee v’eh er hilgey shiaght drogh-spyrrydyn.

English: 10 And she went and told them that had been with him, as they mourned and wept.
Manx: As hie ish, as dinsh ee yn naight dauesyn v’er ny ve mârish, myr v’ad jannoo dobberan as keaney.

English: 11 And they, when they had heard that he was alive, and had been seen of her, believed not.
Manx: As erreish daue v’er chlashtyn dy row Eh bio, as dy row Eh er ny akin lioree-ish, foast cha ren ad credjal.

English: 12 ¶After that he appeared in another form unto two of them, as they walked, and went into the country.
Manx: Ny lurg shen hoilshee Eh Eh hene ayns cummey elley da jees jeu, myr v’ad walkal, as goll er y cheer.

English: 13 And they went and told it unto the residue: neither believed they them.
Manx: As hie ad as dinsh ad eh da’n chooid elley jeh’n cheshaght: as cha chred ad ad.

English: 14 ¶Afterward he appeared unto the eleven as they sat at meat, and upbraided them with their unbelief and hardness of heart, because they believed not them which had seen him after he was risen.
Manx: Ny lurg shen hoilshee Eh Eh hene da’n un ostyl yeig, myr v’ad nyn soie ec bee, as hooar Eh foill daue son y vee-chredjue as y chreoghys cree oc, er-yn-oyr nagh row ad er chredjal adsyn v’er vakin Eh, erreish da v’er n’irree.

English: 15 And he said unto them, Go ye into all the world, and preach the gospel to every creature.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Gow-jee magh trooid ooilley’n seihll, as jean-jee yn sushtal y phreacheil gys dy chooilley chretoor.

English: 16 He that believeth and is baptized shall be saved; but he that believeth not shall be damned.
Manx: Bee eshyn ta credjal as t’er ny vashtey, er ny hauail; agh bee eshyn nagh vel credjal, er ny gheyrey.

English: 17 And these signs shall follow them that believe; In my name shall they cast out devils; they shall speak with new tongues;
Manx: As eiyree ny cowraghyn shoh orroosyn ta credjal; Ayns m’ennym’s nee ad drogh-spyrrydyn y hilgey magh, loayree ad lesh chengaghyn noa,

English: 18 They shall take up serpents; and if they drink any deadly thing, it shall not hurt them; they shall lay hands on the sick, and they shall recover.
Manx: Troggee ad ard-nieughyn, as my iu-ys ad nhee erbee pushoonagh, cha jean eh skielley daue; ver ad nyn laueyn er sleih chingey, as nee ad cowral.

English: 19 ¶So then after the Lord had spoken unto them, he was received up into heaven, and sat on the right hand of God.
Manx: Myr shen erreish da’n Chiarn v’er loayrt roo, v’eh er ny ghoaill seose gys niau, as hoie Eh er laue yesh Yee.

English: 20 And they went forth, and preached every where, the Lord working with them, and confirming the word with signs following. Amen.
Manx: As hie ad magh, as ren ad preacheil dy chooilley raad, yn Chiarn gobbraghey mâroo; as jannoo yn goo breeoil liorish ny mirrillyn va goll lesh. Amen.
Yn Sushtal scruit liorish yn Noo LUKE.
CAB. I.

English: Forasmuch as many have taken in hand to set forth in order a declaration of those things which are most surely believed among us,
Manx: Son wheesh as dy vel ymmodee er ghoaill ayns laue dy chur coontey cairagh jeh ny reddyn ta dy firrinagh er nyn gredjal nyn mast’ ain.

English: 2 Even as they delivered them unto us, which from the beginning were eyewitnesses, and ministers of the word;
Manx: ’Naght myr ren ad nyn livrey ad dooinyn, va er dyn toshiaght nyn veanishyn sooylley as nyn shirveishee jeh’n ghoo.

English: 3 It seemed good to me also, having had perfect understanding of all things from the very first, to write unto thee in order, most excellent Theophilus,
Manx: Ta mish er vakin eh ymmyrchagh myrgeddin, liorish dy vel toiggal vie er ve aym jeh dy chooilley nhee er dyn eer toshiaght, dy scrieu hoods ayns order, Theophilus smoo ooasle,

English: 4 That thou mightest know the certainty of those things, wherein thou hast been instructed.
Manx: Dy vod fyss y ve ayd er firrinys ny reddyn shen, ayndoo t’ow er ny ve ynsit.

English: 5 There was in the days of Herod, the king of Judaea, a certain priest named Zacharias, of the course of Abia: and his wife was of the daughters of Aaron, and her name was Elisabeth.
Manx: Va ayns laghyn Herod ree Yudea, saggyrt dy row va enmyssit Zacharias, jeh kynney Abia; as va’n ven echey jeh inneenyn Aaron, as yn ennym eck Elizabeth.

English: 6 And they were both righteous before God, walking in all the commandments and ordinances of the Lord blameless.
Manx: As v’ad ny neesht cairagh kiongoyrt rish Jee, gimmeeaght ayns ooilley annaghyn as oardaghyn y Chiarn fegooish oghsan y hoilchin.

English: 7 And they had no child, because that Elisabeth was barren, and they both were now well stricken in years.
Manx: As cha row sluight oc, er-yn-oyr dy row Elizabeth gennish, as v’ad ny neesht er roih dy mie ayns eash.

English: 8 And it came to pass, that while he executed the priest’s office before God in the order of his course,
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, choud as v’eh cooilleeney oik y taggyrt kiongoyrt rish Jee, myr va e choorse erjeet magh,

English: 9 According to the custom of the priest’s office, his lot was to burn incense when he went into the temple of the Lord.
Manx: Cordail rish cliaghtey oik y taggyrt, dy haghyr eh dy ve yn currym echey dy lostey oural millish, tra v’eh goll stiagh ayns chiamble y Chiarn.

English: 10 And the whole multitude of the people were praying without at the time of incense.
Manx: As va’n slane chaglym jeh’n pobble ec padjer er cheu-mooie, ec traa yn oural millish.

English: 11 And there appeared unto him an angel of the Lord standing on the right side of the altar of incense.
Manx: As haink ainle y Chiarn, as hass Eh er y cheu yesh jeh altar yn oural millish.

English: 12 And when Zacharias saw him, he was troubled, and fear fell upon him.
Manx: As tra honnick Zacharias Eh, v’eh seaghnit, as ghow Eh aggle.

English: 13 But the angel said unto him, Fear not, Zacharias: for thy prayer is heard; and thy wife Elisabeth shall bear thee a son, and thou shalt call his name John.
Manx: Agh dooyrt yn ainle rish, Ny gow aggle Zacharias: son ta dty phadjer er ny chlashtyn; as nee yn ven ayd Elizabeth mac y ymmyrkey dhyt, as enmyssee oo yn ennym echey Ean.

English: 14 And thou shalt have joy and gladness; and many shall rejoice at his birth.
Manx: As bee boggey as gennalys ayd, as nee ymmodee boggey y ghoaill tra hig Eh er y teihll.

English: 15 For he shall be great in the sight of the Lord, and shall drink neither wine nor strong drink; and he shall be filled with the Holy Ghost, even from his mother's womb.
Manx: Son bee Eh mooar ayns shilley yn Chiarn, as cha niu Eh feeyn ny jough lajer, as bee Eh lhieent lesh y Spyrryd Noo, veih eer brein e varey.

English: 16 And many of the children of Israel shall he turn to the Lord their God.
Manx: As ymmodee jeh cloan Israel nee Eh y hyndaa gys y Chiarn y Jee oc.

English: 17 And he shall go before him in the spirit and power of Elias, to turn the hearts of the fathers to the children, and the disobedient to the wisdom of the just; to make ready a people prepared for the Lord.
Manx: As hed Eh roish ayns spyrryd as pooar Elias, dy hyndaa creeaghyn ny ayraghyn gys y chloan, as ny mee-viallee gys creenaght yn er-chairagh, dy yannoo aarloo pobble vees kiarit son y Chiarn.

English: 18 And Zacharias said unto the angel, Whereby shall I know this? for I am an old man, and my wife well stricken in years.
Manx: As dooyrt Zacharias rish yn ainle, Cre liorish vees fys ayms er shoh? son ta mee my hen ghooinney, as ta’n ven aym ayns ny shen shen laghyn eck.

English: 19 And the angel answering said unto him, I am Gabriel, that stand in the presence of God; and am sent to speak unto thee, and to shew thee these glad tidings.
Manx: As dreggyr yn ainle, as dooyrt Eh rish, Mish Gabriel ta my hassoo ayns fenish Yee: as ta mee er my choyrt dy loayrt rhyt, as dy hoilshaghey dhyt ny naightyn gerjolagh shoh.

English: 20 And, behold, thou shalt be dumb, and not able to speak, until the day that these things shall be performed, because thou believest not my words, which shall be fulfilled in their season.
Manx: As cur-my-ner bee oo balloo, as cha bee oo abyl loayrt, derrey yn laa vees ny reddyn shoh cooilleenit, er-y-fa nagh vel oo er chredjal my ghoan’s vees er nyn gooilleeney ayns nyn imbagh.

English: 21 And the people waited for Zacharias, and marvelled that he tarried so long in the temple.
Manx: As va’n pobble farkiagh er Zacharias, as goaill yindyss dy row Eh furriaght choud ayns y chiamble.

English: 22 And when he came out, he could not speak unto them: and they perceived that he had seen a vision in the temple: for he beckoned unto them, and remained speechless.
Manx: As tra haink Eh magh, cha row Eh abyl loayrt roo; as dennee ad dy row Eh er vakin ashlish ayns y chiamble: son v’eh jannoo signyn daue, agh cha row e ghlare cheet lesh.

English: 23 And it came to pass, that, as soon as the days of his ministration were accomplished, he departed to his own house.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, cha lea as va laghyn y chirveish echey ec kione, dy jimmee Eh gys e hie hene.

English: 24 And after those days his wife Elisabeth conceived, and hid herself five months, saying,
Manx: As lurg ny laghyn shen ren e ven Elizabeth giennaghtyn, as dollee ee ee hene queig meeghyn, gra,

English: 25 Thus hath the Lord dealt with me in the days wherein he looked on me, to take away my reproach among men.
Manx: Shoh myr ta’n Chiarn er ghellal rhym ayns ny laghyn t’eh er n’yeeaghyn orrym, dy ghoaill ersooyll my scammylt mastey deiney.

English: 26 And in the sixth month the angel Gabriel was sent from God unto a city of Galilee, named Nazareth,
Manx: As ayns y cheyoo vee, va’n ainle Gabriel er ny choyrt veih Jee, gys ard-valley dy Ghalilee, va enmyssit Nazareth,

English: 27 To a virgin espoused to a man whose name was Joseph, of the house of David; and the virgin’s name was Mary.
Manx: Gys moidyn va nasht rish dooinney va enmyssit Joseph, jeh thie Ghavid; as va ennym y voidyn Moirrey.

English: 28 And the angel came in unto her, and said, Hail, thou that art highly favoured, the Lord is with thee: blessed art thou among women.
Manx: As haink yn ainle stiagh as dooyrt Eh ree, Dy vannee dhyts ta ayns foayr mooar, ta’n Chiarn mârt; bannit t’ow mastey mraane.

English: 29 And when she saw him, she was troubled at his saying, and cast in her mind what manner of salutation this should be.
Manx: As tra honnick ee Eh, v’ee seaghnit ayns e haigney kyndagh rish y raa echey, as smooinee ee ayn jee hene cre’n monney dy vannaghey va shoh.

English: 30 And the angel said unto her, Fear not, Mary: for thou hast found favour with God.
Manx: As dooyrt yn ainle ree, Ny gow aggle Moirrey; son t’ow er gheddyn foayr rish Jee.

English: 31 And, behold, thou shalt conceive in thy womb, and bring forth a son, and shalt call his name Jesus.
Manx: As cur my-ner, nee oo giennaghtyn ayns dty vreïn, as mac y ymmyrkey, as enmyssee oo yn ennym echey Yeesey.

English: 32 He shall be great, and shall be called the Son of the Highest: and the Lord God shall give unto him the throne of his father David:
Manx: Bee Eh mooar, as enmyssit Mac yn Er-syrjey; as ver y Chiarn Jee da stoyl-reeoil e ayr David.

English: 33 And he shall reign over the house of Jacob for ever; and of his kingdom there shall be no end.
Manx: As nee Eh reill harrish thie Yacob son dy bragh, as er y reeriaght echey cha bee jerrey erbee.

English: 34 Then said Mary unto the angel, How shall this be, seeing I know not a man?
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Moirrey rish yn ainle, Kys oddys shoh y ve, fakin nagh row veg ec dooinney rhym?

English: 35 And the angel answered and said unto her, The Holy Ghost shall come upon thee, and the power of the Highest shall overshadow thee: therefore also that holy thing which shall be born of thee shall be called the Son of God.
Manx: As dreggyr yn ainle as do[o]yrt Eh ree, Hig yn Spyrryd Noo ort, as nee pooar yn Er-syrjey scadoo y hilgey harryd: shen-y-fa bee yn red casherick shen myrgeddin vees er ny ruggey jeed, enmyssit Mac Yee.

English: 36 And, behold, thy cousin Elisabeth, she hath also conceived a son in her old age: and this is the sixth month with her, who was called barren.
Manx: As cur-my-ner, dty ven-vooinjerey Elizabeth, tie ish myrgeddin er yiennaghtyn mac ayns ny shen laghyn eck: as shoh yn cheyoo vee jee-ish ta enmyssit gennish.

English: 37 For with God nothing shall be impossible.
Manx: Son da Jee cha bee nhee erbee neu-phossible.

English: 38 And Mary said, Behold the handmaid of the Lord; be it unto me according to thy word. And the angel departed from her.
Manx: As dooyrt Moirrey, Cur-my-ner inneeveyl y Chiarn, dy daghyr eh doos cordail rish dty ghoo. As jimmee yn ainle voie.

English: 39 And Mary arose in those days, and went into the hill country with haste, into a city of Juda;
Manx: As dirree Moirrey ayns ny laghyn shen, as hiee gys cheer ny gronck lesh siyr, gys ard-valley dy Yuda,

English: 40 And entered into the house of Zacharias, and saluted Elisabeth.
Manx: As hiee stiagh ayns thie Zacharias as vannee ee da Elizabeth.

English: 41 And it came to pass, that, when Elisabeth heard the salutation of Mary, the babe leaped in her womb; and Elisabeth was filled with the Holy Ghost:
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, tra cheayll Elizabeth bannaghey Moirrey, dy leïme yn oikan ayns e breïn, as va Elizabeth lhieent lesh y Spyrryd Noo.

English: 42 And she spake out with a loud voice, and said, Blessed art thou among women, and blessed is the fruit of thy womb.
Manx: As loayr ee magh lesh ard choraa as dooyrt ee, Bannit t’ow uss mastey mraane, as bannit ta mess dty vreïn.

English: 43 And whence is this to me, that the mother of my Lord should come to me?
Manx: As cre voish ta shoh erjeet hym, dy vel moir my Hiarn erjeet dy my yeeaghyn?

English: 44 For, lo, as soon as the voice of thy salutation sounded in mine ears, the babe leaped in my womb for joy.
Manx: Son cur-my-ner, cha lea as ren coraa yn bannaghey ayd feiyral ayns my chleashyn, leïme yn oikan ayns my vreïn son boggey.

English: 45 And blessed is she that believed: for there shall be a performance of those things which were told her from the Lord.
Manx: As bannit tie ish ta er chredjal: son bee cooilleeney jeh ny reddyn shen v’er ny insh jee liorish y Chiarn.

English: 46 And Mary said, My soul doth magnify the Lord,
Manx: As dooyrt Moirrey, Ta m’annym cur ard-voylley da’n Chiarn.

English: 47 And my spirit hath rejoiced in God my Saviour.
Manx: As ta my spyrryd er ghoaill boggey ayns Jee my Haualtagh.

English: 48 For he hath regarded the low estate of his handmaiden: for, behold, from henceforth all generations shall call me blessed.
Manx: Son t’eh er chur tastey da stayd injil e inneeveyl: son cur-my-ner, maghey shoh nee dy chooilley heeloghe mish y enmyss bannit.

English: 49 For he that is mighty hath done to me great things; and holy is his name.
Manx: Son te eshyn ta niartal er n’yannoo reddyn mooarey er my hon, as casherick yn ennym echey.

English: 50 And his mercy is on them that fear him from generation to generation.
Manx: As ta e vyghin orroosyn ta goaill aggle roish, veih sheeloghe gys sheeloghe.

English: 51 He hath shewed strength with his arm; he hath scattered the proud in the imagination of their hearts.
Manx: T’eh er hoilshaghey niart lesh e roih; t’eh er skeayley yn vooinjer voyrnagh ayns smooinaghtyn nyn greeaghyn.

English: 52 He hath put down the mighty from their seats, and exalted them of low degree.
Manx: T’eh er chur sheese yn vooinjer niartal veih ny stuill oc, as er hoiaghey seose adsyn jeh stayd injill.

English: 53 He hath filled the hungry with good things; and the rich he hath sent empty away.
Manx: T’eh er lhieeney ny accryssee lesh reddyn mie, as ny berchee t’eh er chur follym ersooyl.

English: 54 He hath holpen his servant Israel, in remembrance of his mercy;
Manx: T’eh er chooney lesh e harvaant Israel, ayns cooinaghtyn jeh e vyghin.

English: 55 As he spake to our fathers, to Abraham, and to his seed for ever.
Manx: Myr loayr Eh rish ny ayraghyn ain, rish Abraham as e luight er son dy bragh.

English: 56 And Mary abode with her about three months, and returned to her own house.
Manx: As duirree Moirrey mâree mygeayrt three meeghyn, as haink ee reesht gys e thie hene.

English: 57 Now Elisabeth's full time came that she should be delivered; and she brought forth a son.
Manx: Nish va slane tra Elizabeth erjeet, dy row ee dy ve er ny livrey; as hug ee mac son y teihll.

English: 58 And her neighbours and her cousins heard how the Lord had shewed great mercy upon her; and they rejoiced with her.
Manx: As cheayll ny naboonyn as y sleih mooinjerey eck, kys va’n Chiarn er hoilshaghey ard vyghin jee; as ghow ad boggey mâree.

English: 59 And it came to pass, that on the eighth day they came to circumcise the child; and they called him Zacharias, after the name of his father.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione er y hoghtoo laa dy daink ad dy yiarey chymmylt yn liannoo; as denmyss ad Eh Zacharias, lurg ennym e ayr.

English: 60 And his mother answered and said, Not so; but he shall be called John.
Manx: As dreggyr e voir, as dooyrt ee, Cha nee; agh bee Eh enmyssit Ean.

English: 61 And they said unto her, There is none of thy kindred that is called by this name.
Manx: As dooyrt ad ree, Cha vel veg jeh dty chynney ta’n ennym shen orroo.

English: 62 And they made signs to his father, how he would have him called.
Manx: As ren ad signyn gys e ayr, kys baillish Eh ve enmyssit.

English: 63 And he asked for a writing table, and wrote, saying, His name is John. And they marvelled all.
Manx: As hir Eh boayrd-screeuee, as scrieu Eh, gra, Ta’n ennym echey Ean. As ghow ad ooilley yindyss.

English: 64 And his mouth was opened immediately, and his tongue loosed, and he spake, and praised God.
Manx: As va’n beeal echey er ny osley chelleeragh, as e hengey er ny eaysley, as loayr Eh, as hug Eh moylley da Jee.

English: 65 And fear came on all that dwelt round about them: and all these sayings were noised abroad throughout all the hill country of Judaea.
Manx: As haink aggle orroosyn ooilley va vaghey mygeayrt-y-moo: as va ooilley ny raaghyn shoh er nyn insh magh trooid cheer-cronck Yudea.

English: 66 And all they that heard them laid them up in their hearts, saying, What manner of child shall this be! And the hand of the Lord was with him.
Manx: As ooilley adsyn v’er chlashtyn ad, hasht ad ad ayns nyn greeaghyn, gra, Cre’n monney dy ghooinney vees Eh shoh? as va laue yn Chiarn mârish.

English: And his father Zacharias was filled with the Holy Ghost, and prophesied, saying,
Manx: 67 As va’n ayr echey Zacharias lhieent lesh y Spyrryd Noo, as ren Eh phadeyrys, gra,

English: 68 Blessed be the Lord God of Israel; for he hath visited and redeemed his people,
Manx: Bannit dy row yn Chiarn Jee dy Israel, son t’eh er yeeaghyn er, as er chionnaghey reesht e phobble.

English: 69 And hath raised up an horn of salvation for us in the house of his servant David;
Manx: As t’eh er hroggal seose niart dy haualtys er nyn son, ayns thie e harvaant David;

English: 70 As he spake by the mouth of his holy prophets, which have been since the world began:
Manx: Myr loayr Eh liorish beeal e adeyryn crauee, t’er ny ve er dy hoshiaght y teihll;

English: 71 That we should be saved from our enemies, and from the hand of all that hate us;
Manx: Dy beagh shin er nyn sauail veih nyn noidjyn, as veih’n laue ocsyn ooilley ta dwoaie oc orrin.

English: 72 To perform the mercy promised to our fathers, and to remember his holy covenant;
Manx: Dy chooilleeney yn vyghin va giallit da ny ayraghyn ain, as dy chooinaghtyn er e chonaant casherick:

English: 73 The oath which he sware to our father Abraham,
Manx: Yn breearrey ren Eh gys yn ayr ain Abraham,

English: 74 That he would grant unto us, that we being delivered out of the hand of our enemies might serve him without fear,
Manx: Dy giallagh Eh dooinyn, dy beagh shin er nyn livrey veih laueyn nyn noidjyn, as dy shirveishagh shin Eh fegooish aggle,

English: 75 In holiness and righteousness before him, all the days of our life.
Manx: Ayns craueeaght as cairys kiongoyrt rish, ooilley laghyn nyn mea.

English: 76 And thou, child, shalt be called the prophet of the Highest: for thou shalt go before the face of the Lord to prepare his ways;
Manx: As uss liennoo, bee oo enmyssit phadeyr yn Er-syrjey; son hed oo roish eddin y Chiarn, dy yannoo aarloo e raadjin;

English: 77 To give knowledge of salvation unto his people by the remission of their sins,
Manx: Dy chur tushtey dy haualtys da e phobble, liorish leih nyn beccaghyn,

English: 78 Through the tender mercy of our God; whereby the dayspring from on high hath visited us,
Manx: Trooid myghin meigh yn Jee ain; liorish ta soilshey yn laa veih yn yrjid er jeet dy nyn yeeaghyn,

English: 79 To give light to them that sit in darkness and in the shadow of death, to guide our feet into the way of peace.
Manx: Dy chur soilshey dauesyn ta nyn soie ayns dorraghys as ayns scadoo yn vaish, dy leeideil ny cassyn ain gys raad y chee.

English: 80 And the child grew, and waxed strong in spirit, and was in the deserts till the day of his shewing unto Israel.
Manx: As daase y liannoo, as haink Eh dy ve lajer ayns spyrryd, as v’eh ayns ny faasaghyn, derrey yn laa v’eh er ny hoilshaghey da Israel.
CAB. II.

English: And it came to pass in those days, that there went out a decree from Caesar Augustus that all the world should be taxed.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione ayns ny laghyn shen, dy jagh sarey magh veih Cesar Augustus, ooilley yn seihll dy chur nyn enmyn ayns screeu ry hoi keesh y eeck.

English: 2 (And this taxing was first made when Cyrenius was governor of Syria.)
Manx: (As va’n cheesh shoh hoshiaght er ny hroggal, tra va Cyrenius ny chiannoort er Syria.)

English: 3 And all went to be taxed, every one into his own city.
Manx: As hie ooilley dy chur nyn enmyn sheese, dagh annane gys e ard-valley hene.

English: 4 And Joseph also went up from Galilee, out of the city of Nazareth, into Judaea, unto the city of David, which is called Bethlehem; (because he was of the house and lineage of David:)
Manx: As hie Joseph myrgeddin seose veih Galilee, veih ard-valley Nazareth, gys Judea, gys ard-valley Ghavid, ta enmyssit Bethlehem, (er-y-fa dy row Eh jeh thie as kynney Ghavid)

English: 5 To be taxed with Mary his espoused wife, being great with child.
Manx: Dy chur stiagh e ennym hene as ennym Moirrey yn ven va nasht rish, va trome torragh.

English: 6 And so it was, that, while they were there, the days were accomplished that she should be delivered.
Manx: As shen myr ve, choud as v’ad ayns shen dy row ny laghyn ec kione dy row ee dy ve er ny livrey.

English: 7 And she brought forth her firstborn son, and wrapped him in swaddling clothes, and laid him in a manger; because there was no room for them in the inn.
Manx: As hug ee son y theihll yn chied vac rugg jee, as hoïll ee Eh ayns aanrittyn soïllee, as hug ee Eh ny lhie ayns manjoor, er-y-fa nagh row room er nyn son ayns y thie-oast.

English: 8 And there were in the same country shepherds abiding in the field, keeping watch over their flock by night.
Manx: As va ayns y cheer cheddin bochillyn va cummal ayns ny magheryn, as freaylley watch er ny shioltaneyn oc ayns yn oie.

English: 9 And, lo, the angel of the Lord came upon them, and the glory of the Lord shone round about them: and they were sore afraid.
Manx: As cur-my-ner haink ainle y Chiarn orroo, as ren gloyr y Chiarn soilshean mygeayrt-y-moo; as v’ad feer agglagh.

English: 10 And the angel said unto them, Fear not: for, behold, I bring you good tidings of great joy, which shall be to all people.
Manx: As dooyrt yn ainle roo, Ny gow-jee aggle: son cur-my-ner, ta mish coyrt lhiam hiu naightyn mie dy voggey mooar vees gys dy chooilley phobble.

English: 11 For unto you is born this day in the city of David a Saviour, which is Christ the Lord.
Manx: Son diuish t’er ny ruggey jiu ayns ard-valley Ghavid, Saualtagh, ta shen Creest yn Chiarn.

English: 12 And this shall be a sign unto you; Ye shall find the babe wrapped in swaddling clothes, lying in a manger.
Manx: As bee shoh son cowrey diu; Yiow shiu yn oikan soïllit ayns aanrittyn soïllee, as ny lhie ayns manjoor.

English: 13 And suddenly there was with the angel a multitude of the heavenly host praising God, and saying,
Manx: As ayns y tullogh va marish yn ainle ymmodee jeh’n cheshaght-chaggee flaunyssagh cur moylley da Jee, as gra,

English: 14 Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace, good will toward men.
Manx: Gloyr gys Jee ayns yn yrjid, as er y thalloo shee, aigney-mie gys deiney.

English: 15 And it came to pass, as the angels were gone away from them into heaven, the shepherds said one to another, Let us now go even unto Bethlehem, and see this thing which is come to pass, which the Lord hath made known unto us.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, cha lea as va ny ainlyn er gholl ersooyl vow gys niau, dy dooyrt ny bochillyn yn derrey yeh rish y jeh elley, Lig dooin goll nish derrey Bethlehem, dy akin yn red shoh t’er jeet gy kione, ta’n Chiarn er ny hoilshaghey dooin.

English: 16 And they came with haste, and found Mary, and Joseph, and the babe lying in a manger.
Manx: As haink ad lesh siyr, as hooar ad Moirrey as Joseph, as yn oikan ny lhie ayns manjoor.

English: 17 And when they had seen it, they made known abroad the saying which was told them concerning this child.
Manx: As erreish daue v’er vakin Eh, hoilshee ad magh yn raa va inshit daue mychione y liannoo shoh.

English: 18 And all they that heard it wondered at those things which were told them by the shepherds.
Manx: As ghow dy chooilley annane cheayll eh, yindyss jeh ny reddyn va inshit daue liorish ny bochillyn.

English: 19 But Mary kept all these things, and pondered them in her heart.
Manx: Agh hasht Moirrey ooilley ny raaghyn shoh, as smooinee ee orroo ayns e cree.

English: 20 And the shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God for all the things that they had heard and seen, as it was told unto them.
