Manx: As haink ny bochillyn roue, cur gloyr as moylley da Jee son ooilley ny reddyn v’ad er chlashtyn as er vakin, cordail rish ny va inshit daue.

English: 21 And when eight days were accomplished for the circumcising of the child, his name was called JESUS, which was so named of the angel before he was conceived in the womb.
Manx: As tra va hoght laa ec kione son giarey chymmylt yn liannoo, va’n ennym v’er ny chur er YEESEY, son shen myr v’eh enmyssit liorish yn ainle, roish my row Eh er ny yiennaghtyn ayns y vreïn.

English: 22 And when the days of her purification according to the law of Moses were accomplished, they brought him to Jerusalem, to present him to the Lord;
Manx: As tra va ny laghyn v’oc ry hoi mraane dy ve er nyn ghlenney, cordail rish leih Voses, ec kione, hug ad lhieu Eh gys Jerusalem, dy hebbal Eh gys y Chiarn,

English: 23 (As it is written in the law of the Lord, Every male that openeth the womb shall be called holy to the Lord;)
Manx: (Myr te scruit ayns leih yn Chiarn, Bee dy chooilley yrrynagh ta fosley yn vreïn enmyssit casherick gys y Chiarn)

English: 24 And to offer a sacrifice according to that which is said in the law of the Lord, A pair of turtledoves, or two young pigeons.
Manx: As dy hebbal oural, cordail rish ny t’er ny ghra ayns leih yn Chiarn, Piyr dy chalmaneyn turtle, ny daa chalmane aegey.

English: 25 And, behold, there was a man in Jerusalem, whose name was Simeon; and the same man was just and devout, waiting for the consolation of Israel: and the Holy Ghost was upon him.
Manx: As cur-my-ner va dooinney ayns Jerusalem, va enmyssit Simeon; as va’n dooinney cheddin cairagh as crauee, farkiagh son gerjagh Israel: as va’n Spyrryd Noo er.

English: 26 And it was revealed unto him by the Holy Ghost, that he should not see death, before he had seen the Lord's Christ.
Manx: As ve er ny hoilshaghey da liorish y Spyrryd Noo, nagh vaikagh Eh yn baase, roish my beagh Eh er vakin Creest yn Chiarn.

English: 27 And he came by the Spirit into the temple: and when the parents brought in the child Jesus, to do for him after the custom of the law,
Manx: As haink Eh liorish y spyrryd stiagh ayns y chiamble: as tra va’n ayr as y voir er chur lhieu yn liannoo Yeesey stiagh, dy yannoo er e hon, lurg cliaghtey yn leih;

English: Then took he him up in his arms, and blessed God, and said,
Manx: 28. Eisht ghow Eh seose Eh ayns e roiaghyn, as hug Eh moylley da Jee, as dooyrt Eh,

English: 29 Lord, now lettest thou thy servant depart in peace, according to thy word:
Manx: Hiarn nish t’ow cur kied da dty harvaant paartail ayns shee, cordail rish dty ghoo.

English: 30 For mine eyes have seen thy salvation,
Manx: Son ta my hooyllyn er vakin dty haualtys;

English: 31 Which thou hast prepared before the face of all people;
Manx: T’ow er n’yannoo aarloo kiongoyrt rish dy chooilley phobble;

English: 32 A light to lighten the Gentiles, and the glory of thy people Israel.
Manx: Soilshey dy hoilshaghey ny Ashoonyn quaagh, as gloyr dty phobble Israel.

English: 33 And Joseph and his mother marvelled at those things which were spoken of him.
Manx: As ghow Joseph as e voir yindyss jeh ny reddyn va loayrit liorish.

English: 34 And Simeon blessed them, and said unto Mary his mother, Behold, this child is set for the fall and rising again of many in Israel; and for a sign which shall be spoken against;
Manx: As vannee Simeon ad, as dooyrt Eh rish Moirrey e voir, Cur-my-ner ta’n liannoo shoh soït dy chur sheese as dy hoiaghey seose ymmodee ayns Israel; as son cowrey vees er ny loayrt noi.

English: 35 (Yea, a sword shall pierce through thy own soul also,) that the thoughts of many hearts may be revealed.
Manx: (As nee cliwe toylley trooid dt’annym hene neesht) dy vod smooinaghtyn ymmodee creeaghyn v’er nyn soilshaghey magh.

English: 36 And there was one Anna, a prophetess, the daughter of Phanuel, of the tribe of Aser: she was of a great age, and had lived with an husband seven years from her virginity;
Manx: As va ben va jannoo phadeyrys va enmyssit Anna, inneen Phanuel, jeh sheeloghe Aser; v’ee dy eash vooar, as v’ee er veaghey marish e sheshey shiaght bleeaney neayr as v’ee ny moidyn.

English: 37 And she was a widow of about fourscore and four years, which departed not from the temple, but served God with fastings and prayers night and day.
Manx: As v’ee ny ben-treoghe mysh kiare feed as kiare bleeaney d’eash, as cha row ee fuirriaght veih’n chiamble, agh shirveish Jee lesh trostey as padjeryn oie as laa.

English: 38 And she coming in that instant gave thanks likewise unto the Lord, and spake of him to all them that looked for redemption in Jerusalem.
Manx: As haink ish stiagh ayns yn oor shen, as hug ee booise myrgeddin da’n Chiarn, as loayr ee jeh roosyn ooilley va jeeaghyn son livrey ayns Jerusalem.

English: 39 And when they had performed all things according to the law of the Lord, they returned into Galilee, to their own city Nazareth.
Manx: As tra v’ad er chooilleeney dy chooilley nhee cordail rish leih yn Chiarn, haink ad reesht gys Galilee, gys yn ard-valley oc hene Nazareth.

English: 40 And the child grew, and waxed strong in spirit, filled with wisdom: and the grace of God was upon him.
Manx: As daase y liannoo as haink Eh dy ve lajer ayns Spyrryd, as v’eh lhieent lesh creenaght, as va grayse Yee marish.

English: 41 Now his parents went to Jerusalem every year at the feast of the passover.
Manx: Nish va e ayr as e voir goll seose gys Jerusalem dy chooilley vleïn ec feailley ny caisht.

English: 42 And when he was twelve years old, they went up to Jerusalem after the custom of the feast.
Manx: As tra v’eh daa vleïn jeig dy eash, hie ad seose gys Jerusalem lurg cliaghtey yn eailley.

English: 43 And when they had fulfilled the days, as they returned, the child Jesus tarried behind in Jerusalem; and Joseph and his mother knew not of it.
Manx: As tra va ny laghyn ec kione, as ad goll thie reesht, duirree yn liannoo Yeesey nyn yei ayns Jerusalem, as cha row fys ec Joseph as e voir er.

English: 44 But they, supposing him to have been in the company, went a day's journey; and they sought him among their kinsfolk and acquaintance.
Manx: Agh heill ad dy row Eh ayns y cheshaght, as hie ad jurnah laa; as v’ad briaght er e hon mastey nyn gheiney mooinjerey as nyn ainjys.

English: 45 And when they found him not, they turned back again to Jerusalem, seeking him.
Manx: As tra nagh dooar ad Eh, hie ad reesht gys Jerusalem dy ênaght er e hon.

English: 46 And it came to pass, that after three days they found him in the temple, sitting in the midst of the doctors, both hearing them, and asking them questions.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, lurg three laa dy dooar ad Eh ayns y chiamble, ny hoie mastey ny fir-ynsee, chammah geaishtagh roo, as fênaghtyn questionyn jeu.

English: 47 And all that heard him were astonished at his understanding and answers.
Manx: As ghow ooilley ny va geaishtagh rish yindyss jeh’n toiggal as jeh ny ansooryn echey.

English: 48 And when they saw him, they were amazed: and his mother said unto him, Son, why hast thou thus dealt with us? behold, thy father and I have sought thee sorrowing.
Manx: As tra honnick ad Eh, v’ad atchimagh; as dooyrt e voir rish, Vac, cre’n-fa t’ow er ghellal rooin myr shoh? cur-my ner, ta dt’ ayr as mish er ny ve briaght er dty hon ayns trimshey.

English: 49 And he said unto them, How is it that ye sought me? wist ye not that I must be about my Father's business?
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Kys dy row shiu briaght er my hons? nagh row fys eu dy beign dou y ve mysh obbyr my Ayrey?

English: 50 And they understood not the saying which he spake unto them.
Manx: As cha hoig ad yn raa ren Eh loayrt roo.

English: 51 And he went down with them, and came to Nazareth, and was subject unto them: but his mother kept all these sayings in her heart.
Manx: As hie Eh sheese mâroo, as haink Eh gys Nazareth, as v’eh biallagh daue: as hasht e voir ooilley ny raaghyn shoh ayns e cree.

English: 52 And Jesus increased in wisdom and stature, and in favour with God and man.
Manx: As ren Yeesey bishaghey ayns creenaght as aase, as ayns foayr rish Jee as dooinney.
CAB. III.

English: Now in the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar, Pontius Pilate being governor of Judaea, and Herod being tetrarch of Galilee, and his brother Philip tetrarch of Ituraea and of the region of Trachonitis, and Lysanias the tetrarch of Abilene,
Manx: Nish ayns y wheiggoo vleïn jeig jeh reill Tiberius Cesar, tra va Pontius Pilate ny chiannoort er Judea, as Herod ny hetrarch er Galilee, as e vraar Philip reill ayns Iturea, as cheer Trachonitis, as Lysanias reill ayns Abilene.

English: 2 Annas and Caiaphas being the high priests, the word of God came unto John the son of Zacharias in the wilderness.
Manx: Tra va Annas as Caiaphas nyn ard saggyrtyn, haink goo Yee gys Ean mac Zacharias ayns yn aasagh.

English: 3 And he came into all the country about Jordan, preaching the baptism of repentance for the remission of sins;
Manx: As haink Eh gys ooilley’n cheer mygeayrt Jordan, preacheil bashtey arrys son leih peccaghyn;

English: 4 As it is written in the book of the words of Esaias the prophet, saying, The voice of one crying in the wilderness, Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make his paths straight.
Manx: Myr te scruit ayns lioar goan Esaias yn phadeyr, gra, Coraa fer geamagh ayns yn aasagh, Jean-jee aarloo raad y Chiarn, jean-jee ny cassanyn echey kiart.

English: 5 Every valley shall be filled, and every mountain and hill shall be brought low; and the crooked shall be made straight, and the rough ways shall be made smooth;
Manx: Bee dy chooilley choan er ny lhieeney, as dy chooilley slieau as cronck er nyn injillaghey, as ny ynnydyn cammey er nyn n’yannoo jeeragh, as ny raadjyn garroo er nyn n’yannoo rea.

English: 6 And all flesh shall see the salvation of God.
Manx: As hee dy chooilley eill saualtys Yee.

English: 7 Then said he to the multitude that came forth to be baptized of him, O generation of vipers, who hath warned you to flee from the wrath to come?
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Eh rish y pobble v’er jeet magh huggey dy ve er nyn mashtey, O heeloghe dy ard-nieughyn, quoi ta er chur raaue diu dy hea veih’n chorree ta ry heet?

English: 8 Bring forth therefore fruits worthy of repentance, and begin not to say within yourselves, We have Abraham to our father: for I say unto you, That God is able of these stones to raise up children unto Abraham.
Manx: Ymmyrk-jee magh er-y-fa shen messyn cooie dy arrys, as ny jean-jee toshiaght dy ghra cheu-sthie jiu hene, Ta Abraham ain son nyn ayr: son ta mee gra riu, dy vel Jee abyl jeh ny claghyn shoh cloan y hroggal seose da Abraham.

English: 9 And now also the axe is laid unto the root of the trees: every tree therefore which bringeth not forth good fruit is hewn down, and cast into the fire.
Manx: As nish myrgeddin ta’n teigh er ny choyrt gys fraue ny miljyn: shen-y-fa ta dy chooilley villey nagh vel gymmyrkey magh mess mie, dy ve giarit sheese as tilgit ayns yn aile.

English: 10 And the people asked him, saying, What shall we do then?
Manx: As dênee yn pobble jeh, gra, Cre nee mainyn eisht?

English: 11 He answereth and saith unto them, He that hath two coats, let him impart to him that hath none; and he that hath meat, let him do likewise.
Manx: Dreggyr Eh as dooyrt Eh roo, Eshyn ta daa chooat echey, lig Eh coyrt dasyn nagh vel cooat eddyr echey; as eshyn ta beaghey echey, lig Eh jannoo er yn aght cheddin.

English: 12 Then came also publicans to be baptized, and said unto him, Master, what shall we do?
Manx: Eisht haink myrgeddin ny publicanee dy ve er nyn mashtey, as dooyrt ad rish, Vainshtyr, cre nee mainyn?

English: 13 And he said unto them, Exact no more than that which is appointed you.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Ny trog-jee ny smoo ny t’er ny oardaghey diu.

English: 14 And the soldiers likewise demanded of him, saying, And what shall we do? And he said unto them, Do violence to no man, neither accuse any falsely; and be content with your wages.
Manx: As dênee ny sidooryn myrgeddin jeh, gra, As cre nee mainyn? As dooyrt Eh roo, Ny jean-jee tranlaase er dooinney erbee, ny jean-jee dooinney erbee y phlaint dy aggairagh, as bee-jee booiagh lesh nyn vaill.

English: 15 And as the people were in expectation, and all men mused in their hearts of John, whether he were the Christ, or not;
Manx: As myr va’n pobble ayns imnea, as dy chooilley ghooinney smooinaght ayns nyn greeaghyn mychione Ean, nee Eh va’n Creest mannagh nee;

English: 16 John answered, saying unto them all, I indeed baptize you with water; but one mightier than I cometh, the latchet of whose shoes I am not worthy to unloose: he shall baptize you with the Holy Ghost and with fire:
Manx: Dreggyr Ean as dooyrt Eh roo ooilley, Ta mish dy jarroo bashtey shiu lesh ushtey; agh ta fer spooaral ny mish cheet, kiangley ny braagyn echey cha vel mee feeu dy eaysley: nee eshyn shiu y vashtey lesh y Spyrryd Noo, as lesh aile.

English: 17 Whose fan is in his hand, and he will throughly purge his floor, and will gather the wheat into his garner; but the chaff he will burn with fire unquenchable.
Manx: Ta’n chleayst echey ayns e laue, as nee Eh dy bollagh e laare-arroo y ghlenney, as gowee Eh yn churnaght stiagh ayns e hie-tashtee; agh yn choau nee Eh y lostey lesh aile nagh vod v’er ny vooghey.

English: 18 And many other things in his exhortation preached he unto the people.
Manx: As ymmodee dy reddyn elley ren Eh y choyrlaghey as y phreacheil gys y pobble.

English: 19 But Herod the tetrarch, being reproved by him for Herodias his brother Philip's wife, and for all the evils which Herod had done,
Manx: Agh Herod yn Tetrarch, as oghsan er ny chur da liorish son Herodias ben e vraar Philip, as son ooilley ny huilk va Herod er n’yannoo,

English: 20 Added yet this above all, that he shut up John in prison.
Manx: Ren Eh shoh marish y chooid elley, dy dug Eh Ean ayns pryssoon.

English: 21 Now when all the people were baptized, it came to pass, that Jesus also being baptized, and praying, the heaven was opened,
Manx: Nish tra va ooilley’n pobble er nyn mashtey, haink eh gy kione dy row Yeesey myrgeddin er ny vashtey, as ghow Eh padjer, as va niau er ny osley;

English: 22 And the Holy Ghost descended in a bodily shape like a dove upon him, and a voice came from heaven, which said, Thou art my beloved Son; in thee I am well pleased.
Manx: As haink y Spyrryd Noo neose er, ayns cummey callinagh myr calmane, as haink coraa veih niau, gra, Oo my vac graihagh, jeed ta mee dy mooar soiaghey.

English: 23 And Jesus himself began to be about thirty years of age, being (as was supposed) the son of Joseph, which was the son of Heli,
Manx: As ghow Yeesey Eh hene toshiaght dy ve mysh jeih bleeaney as feed dy eash, as v’eh (jeeaghit dy ve) mac Yoseph, mac Heli,

English: 24 Which was the son of Matthat, which was the son of Levi, which was the son of Melchi, which was the son of Janna, which was the son of Joseph,
Manx: Mac Matthat, mac Levi, mac Melchi, mac Janna, mac Joseph,

English: 25 Which was the son of Mattathias, which was the son of Amos, which was the son of Naum, which was the son of Esli, which was the son of Nagge,
Manx: Mac Mattathias, mac Amos, mac Naum, mac Esli, mac Nagge,

English: 26 Which was the son of Maath, which was the son of Mattathias, which was the son of Semei, which was the son of Joseph, which was the son of Juda,
Manx: Mac Maath, mac Mattathias, mac Semei, mac Joseph, mac Juda,

English: 27 Which was the son of Joanna, which was the son of Rhesa, which was the son of Zorobabel, which was the son of Salathiel, which was the son of Neri,
Manx: Mac Joanna, mac Rhesa, mac Zorobabel, mac Salathiel, mac Neri,

English: 28 Which was the son of Melchi, which was the son of Addi, which was the son of Cosam, which was the son of Elmodam, which was the son of Er,
Manx: Mac Melchi, mac Addi, mac Cosam, mac Elmodam, mac Er,

English: 29 Which was the son of Jose, which was the son of Eliezer, which was the son of Jorim, which was the son of Matthat, which was the son of Levi,
Manx: Mac Jose, mac Eliezer, mac Jorim, mac Matthat, mac Levi,

English: 30 Which was the son of Simeon, which was the son of Juda, which was the son of Joseph, which was the son of Jonan, which was the son of Eliakim,
Manx: Mac Simeon, mac Juda, mac Joseph, mac Jonan, mac Eliakim,

English: 31 Which was the son of Melea, which was the son of Menan, which was the son of Mattatha, which was the son of Nathan, which was the son of David,
Manx: Mac Melea, mac Menan, mac Mattatha, mac Nathan, mac David,

English: 32 Which was the son of Jesse, which was the son of Obed, which was the son of Booz, which was the son of Salmon, which was the son of Naasson,
Manx: Mac Jesse, mac Obed, mac Booz, mac Salmon, mac Naasson,

English: 33 Which was the son of Aminadab, which was the son of Aram, which was the son of Esrom, which was the son of Phares, which was the son of Juda,
Manx: Mac Aminadab, mac Aram, mac Esrom, mac Phares, mac Juda,

English: 34 Which was the son of Jacob, which was the son of Isaac, which was the son of Abraham, which was the son of Thara, which was the son of Nachor,
Manx: Mac Jacob, mac Isaac, mac Abraham, mac Thara, mac Nachor,

English: 35 Which was the son of Saruch, which was the son of Ragau, which was the son of Phalec, which was the son of Heber, which was the son of Sala,
Manx: Mac Saruch, mac Ragau, mac Phalec, mac Heber, mac Sala,

English: 36 Which was the son of Cainan, which was the son of Arphaxad, which was the son of Sem, which was the son of Noe, which was the son of Lamech,
Manx: Mac Cainan, mac Arphaxad, mac Sem, mac Noe, mac Lamech,

English: 37 Which was the son of Mathusala, which was the son of Enoch, which was the son of Jared, which was the son of Maleleel, which was the son of Cainan,
Manx: Mac Mathusala, mac Enoch, mac Jared, mac Maleleel, mac Cainan,

English: 38 Which was the son of Enos, which was the son of Seth, which was the son of Adam, which was the son of God.
Manx: Mac Enos, mac Seth, mac Adam, mac Yee.
CAB. IV.

English: And Jesus being full of the Holy Ghost returned from Jordan, and was led by the Spirit into the wilderness,
Manx: As va Yeesey laane jeh’n Spyrryd Noo as hyndaa Eh veih Jordan, as v’eh er ny leeideil liorish y spyrryd gys yn aasagh,

English: 2 Being forty days tempted of the devil. And in those days he did eat nothing: and when they were ended, he afterward hungered.
Manx: As v’eh da-eed laa er ny violaghey liorish y drogh-spyrryd, as ayns ny laghyn shen, cha die Eh veg; as tra v’ad ec kione, v’eh ny lurg shen accryssagh.

English: 3 And the devil said unto him, If thou be the Son of God, command this stone that it be made bread.
Manx: As dooyrt y drogh-spyrryd rish, My she Mac Yee oo, cur sarey da’n chlagh shoh dy ve jeant ny arran.

English: 4 And Jesus answered him, saying, It is written, That man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word of God.
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey Eh, gra, Te scruit, Nagh nee er arran ny lomarcan nee dooinney beaghey, agh liorish cre-erbee ta Jee dy loayrt.

English: 5 And the devil, taking him up into an high mountain, shewed unto him all the kingdoms of the world in a moment of time.
Manx: As hug y drogh-spyrryd lesh seose Eh gys slieau ard, as yeeagh Eh da ooilley reeriaghtyn y teihll ayns un tullogh.

English: 6 And the devil said unto him, All this power will I give thee, and the glory of them: for that is delivered unto me; and to whomsoever I will I give it.
Manx: As dooyrt y drogh-spyrryd rish, Ooilley yn phooar shoh verryms dhyt, as y ghloyr oc; son ta shen er ny livrey dou, as da quoi-erbee saillym, ta mee dy choyrt eh.

English: 7 If thou therefore wilt worship me, all shall be thine.
Manx: My ver oo er-y-fa shen ooashley dou, bee ooilley lhiats.

English: 8 And Jesus answered and said unto him, Get thee behind me, Satan: for it is written, Thou shalt worship the Lord thy God, and him only shalt thou serve.
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh rish, Gow ass my enish, Noid-anmey: son te scruit, Ver oo ooashley da’n Chiarn dty Yee, as eshyn ny lomarcan nee oo y hirveish.

English: 9 And he brought him to Jerusalem, and set him on a pinnacle of the temple, and said unto him, If thou be the Son of God, cast thyself down from hence:
Manx: As hug Eh lesh Eh gys Jerusalem, as hoie Eh Eh er eer vullagh y chiamble, as dooyrt Eh rish, My she Mac Yee oo, tilg oo hene sheese veih shoh.

English: 10 For it is written, He shall give his angels charge over thee, to keep thee:
Manx: Son te scruit, Ver Eh currym da e ainlyn harryd, dy dty reaylley:

English: 11 And in their hands they shall bear thee up, lest at any time thou dash thy foot against a stone.
Manx: As ayns nyn laueyn nee ad oo y ymmyrkey, er aggle ec traa erbee dy bwoail oo dty chass noi clagh.

English: 12 And Jesus answering said unto him, It is said, Thou shalt not tempt the Lord thy God.
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh rish, Te er ny ghra, Cha jean oo yn Chiarn dty Yee y violaghey.

English: 13 And when the devil had ended all the temptation, he departed from him for a season.
Manx: As tra va’n drogh-spyrryd er chur kione er ooilley’n violagh, daag Eh Eh son y traa shen.

English: 14 ¶And Jesus returned in the power of the Spirit into Galilee: and there went out a fame of him through all the region round about.
Manx: As haink Yeesey reesht ayns pooar y spyrryd gys Galilee: as hie goo magh jeh trooid ooilley’n cheer my-geayrt.

English: 15 And he taught in their synagogues, being glorified of all.
Manx: As dynsee Eh ayns ny kialteenyn oc, as va dy chooilley annane cur ard-voylley da.

English: 16 ¶And he came to Nazareth, where he had been brought up: and, as his custom was, he went into the synagogue on the sabbath day, and stood up for to read.
Manx: As haink Eh gys Nazareth, raad v’eh er ny ve troggit; as hie Eh, myr v’eh cliaghtey, stiagh ayns y cheeill er laa yn doonaght, as hass Eh seose dy lhaih.

English: 17 And there was delivered unto him the book of the prophet Esaias. And when he had opened the book, he found the place where it was written,
Manx: As va lioar y phadeyr Esaias er ny livrey da, as tra v’eh er vosley yn lioar, hooar Eh yn ynnyd raad ve scruit.

English: 18 The Spirit of the Lord is upon me, because he hath anointed me to preach the gospel to the poor; he hath sent me to heal the brokenhearted, to preach deliverance to the captives, and recovering of sight to the blind, to set at liberty them that are bruised,
Manx: Ta spyrryd y Chiarn orryms, er-y-fa dy vel Eh er my ooilliaghey dy phreacheil y sushtal gys ny boghtyn, t’eh er my choyrt dy laanaghey yn vooinjer hrome-chreeagh, dy phreacheil livrey gys ny kappeeyn, as soilshey reesht da ny doail, dy chur nyn reamys dauesyn ta broojit,

English: 19 To preach the acceptable year of the Lord.
Manx: Dy phreacheil blein wooisal y Chiarn.

English: 20 And he closed the book, and he gave it again to the minister, and sat down. And the eyes of all them that were in the synagogue were fastened on him.
Manx: As yeigh Eh yn lioar, as hug Eh ee reesht da’n chirveishagh, as hoie Eh sheese: as yeeagh dy chooilley annane v’ayns y cheeill dy gyere er.

English: 21 And he began to say unto them, This day is this scripture fulfilled in your ears.
Manx: As ren Eh toshiaght dy ghra roo, Jiu ta’n scriptyr shoh cooilleenit ayns ny cleashyn eu.

English: 22 And all bare him witness, and wondered at the gracious words which proceeded out of his mouth. And they said, Is not this Joseph's son?
Manx: As dymmyrk ad ooilley feanish lesh, as ghow ad yindyss jeh ny goan graysoil va cheet magh ass y veeal echey. As dooyrt ad, Nagh nee shoh mac Yoseph?

English: 23 And he said unto them, Ye will surely say unto me this proverb, Physician, heal thyself: whatsoever we have heard done in Capernaum, do also here in thy country.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Jir shiu ayns shickyrys yn chen raa shoh rhym, Lhee, jean oo hene y lheihys: cre-erbee ta shin er chlashtyn va jeant ayns Capernaum, jean myrgeddin ayns shoh ayns dty heer hene.

English: 24 And he said, Verily I say unto you, No prophet is accepted in his own country.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Nagh vel soiagh jeant jeh phadeyr erbee ayns e heer hene.

English: 25 But I tell you of a truth, many widows were in Israel in the days of Elias, when the heaven was shut up three years and six months, when great famine was throughout all the land;
Manx: Agh ta mee ginsh diu ayns firrinys, dy row ymmodee mraane treoghe ayns Israel ayns laghyn Elias, tra va’n aer jeight seose three bleeaney as shey meeghyn, tra va genney vooar trooid ooilley’n cheer:

English: 26 But unto none of them was Elias sent, save unto Sarepta, a city of Sidon, unto a woman that was a widow.
Manx: Agh gys annane oc cha row Elias er ny choyrt, cheu-mooie jeh gys Sarepta ard-valley dy Sidon, gys ben va ny bentreoghe.

English: 27 And many lepers were in Israel in the time of Eliseus the prophet; and none of them was cleansed, saving Naaman the Syrian.
Manx: As va ymmodee louraanee ayns Israel, ayns earish Eliseus yn phadeyr, as cha row annane oc er ny ghlenney, cheu-mooie jeh Naaman yn Syrian.

English: 28 And all they in the synagogue, when they heard these things, were filled with wrath,
Manx: As va ooilley ny v’ayns y cheeill, tra cheayll ad ny goan shoh, lhieent lesh jymmoose,

English: 29 And rose up, and thrust him out of the city, and led him unto the brow of the hill whereon their city was built, that they might cast him down headlong.
Manx: As dirree ad seose, as deiyr ad Eh magh ass yn ard-valley, as leeid ad Eh gys broogh yn chronck (er va’n ard-valley oc troggit) dy voddagh ad Eh y hilgey sheese gouyr y vullee.

English: 30 But he passing through the midst of them went his way,
Manx: Agh hie Eh magh nyn drooid, as jimmee Eh roish:

English: 31 And came down to Capernaum, a city of Galilee, and taught them on the sabbath days.
Manx: As haink Eh neose gys Capernaum, ard-valley dy Ghalilee, as dynsee Eh ad er laghyn y doonaght.

English: 32 And they were astonished at his doctrine: for his word was with power.
Manx: As ghow ad yindyss mooar jeh’n ynsaghey echey: son va e ghoo lesh pooar.

English: 33 ¶And in the synagogue there was a man, which had a spirit of an unclean devil, and cried out with a loud voice,
Manx: As ayns y cheeill va dooinney va spyrryd neu-ghlen ayn, as deie Eh lesh ard choraa,

English: 34 Saying, Let us alone; what have we to do with thee, thou Jesus of Nazareth? art thou come to destroy us? I know thee who thou art; the Holy One of God.
Manx: Gra, Faag shin; cre’n eïe t’ayd orrin uss Yeesey dy Nazareth? vel oo er-jeet dy nyn stroie? ta fys aym quoi oo; yn Fer casherick dy Yee.

English: 35 And Jesus rebuked him, saying, Hold thy peace, and come out of him. And when the devil had thrown him in the midst, he came out of him, and hurt him not.
Manx: As hug Yeesey oghsan da, gra, Cum dty hengey, as tar magh ass. As tra va’n drogh-spyrryd er lhieggal Eh kiongoyrt roo, haink Eh magh ass, as cha ren Eh skielley da.

English: 36 And they were all amazed, and spake among themselves, saying, What a word is this! for with authority and power he commandeth the unclean spirits, and they come out.
Manx: As v’ad ooilley atchimagh, as loayr ad ny mast’ oc hene, gra, Cre’n fockle shoh? son lesh pooar as niart t’eh cur sarey da ny spyrrydyn neu-ghlen, as t’ad cheet magh.

English: 37 And the fame of him went out into every place of the country round about.
Manx: As hie goo magh jeh trooid dy chooilley ard jeh’n cheer mygeayrt.

English: 38 ¶And he arose out of the synagogue, and entered into Simon’s house. And Simon’s wife's mother was taken with a great fever; and they besought him for her.
Manx: As hrog Eh magh ass y cheeill, as hie Eh stiagh ayns thie Simon: as va moir ben Simon feer ching ayns y chiassaghey; as ren ad aghin huggey er e son.

English: 39 And he stood over her, and rebuked the fever; and it left her: and immediately she arose and ministered unto them.
Manx: As hass Eh er e skyn, as hug Eh oghsan da’n chiassaghey, as daag eh ee. As chelleeragh dirree ee seose, as ren ee ad y hirveish.

English: 40 ¶Now when the sun was setting, all they that had any sick with divers diseases brought them unto him; and he laid his hands on every one of them, and healed them.
Manx: Nish ec lhie ny greïney, whilleen as va sleih chingey oc ayns caghlaaghyn dy ghoghanyn, hug ad lhieu ad huggey; as hug Eh e laueyn er dy chooilley annane oc, as ren Eh ad y lheihys.

English: 41 And devils also came out of many, crying out, and saying, Thou art Christ the Son of God. And he rebuking them suffered them not to speak: for they knew that he was Christ.
Manx: As haink drogh-spyrrydyn myrgeddin magh ass ymmodee, geamagh as gra, Oo yn Creest Mac Yee. As hug Eh oghsan, as cha lig Eh daue loayrt; son va fys oc dy nee Eh va’n Creest.

English: 42 And when it was day, he departed and went into a desert place: and the people sought him, and came unto him, and stayed him, that he should not depart from them.
Manx: As tra va’n laa ayn, jimmee Eh roish, as hie Eh gys boall er lheh: as va’n pobble briaght er e hon, as cheet huggey, as chionney er, Eh dy uirriaght mâroo.

English: 43 And he said unto them, I must preach the kingdom of God to other cities also: for therefore am I sent.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, shegin doos reeriaght Yee y phreacheil gys ard-valjyn elley myrgeddin: son er yn oyr shen ta mee er my choyrt.

English: 44 And he preached in the synagogues of Galilee.
Manx: As ren Eh preacheil ayns kialteenyn Ghalilee.
CAB. V.

English: And it came to pass, that, as the people pressed upon him to hear the word of God, he stood by the lake of Gennesaret,
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, myr va’n pobble chionney stiagh er dy chlashtyn goo Yee, dy hass Eh liorish keayn Genesareth,

English: 2 And saw two ships standing by the lake: but the fishermen were gone out of them, and were washing their nets.
Manx: As honnick Eh daa long nyn soie er y traie: agh va ny eeastairyn er gholl ass-doo, as v’ad niee nyn lieenteenyn.

English: 3 And he entered into one of the ships, which was Simon’s, and prayed him that he would thrust out a little from the land. And he sat down, and taught the people out of the ship.
Manx: As hie Eh ayns annane jeh ny longyn va lesh Simon, as ghuee Eh er, Eh dy gholl magh red beg veih’n thalloo: as hoie Eh sheese, as dynsee Eh yn pobble ass y long.

English: 4 Now when he had left speaking, he said unto Simon, Launch out into the deep, and let down your nets for a draught.
Manx: Nish tra v’eh erreish loayrt, dooyrt Eh rish Simon, Gow-jee magh gys y diunit, as lig-jee sheese nyn lieenteenyn dy ghoaill eeast.

English: 5 And Simon answering said unto him, Master, we have toiled all the night, and have taken nothing: nevertheless at thy word I will let down the net.
Manx: As dreggyr Simon as dooyrt Eh rish[,] Vainshtyr, ta shin er hooilleil fud ny hoie, as cha vel shin er ghoaill veg: ny-yeih er dt’ockle’s liggyms sheese y lieen.

English: 6 And when they had this done, they inclosed a great multitude of fishes: and their net brake.
Manx: As tra v’ad er n’yannoo shoh, haare ad earroo mooar dy eeastyn; as ren yn lieen oc brishey.

English: 7 And they beckoned unto their partners, which were in the other ship, that they should come and help them. And they came, and filled both the ships, so that they began to sink.
Manx: As chrie ad er ny sheshaghyn oc va ayns y long elley, ad dy heet dy chooney lhieu. As haink ad, as lhieen ad yn daa long, myr shen dy ren ad toshiaght dy sinkeil.

English: 8 When Simon Peter saw it, he fell down at Jesus’ knees, saying, Depart from me; for I am a sinful man, O Lord.
Manx: Tra honnick Simon Peddyr shoh, huit Eh sheese ec glioonyn Yeesey, gra, Immee voym, son ta mee my ghooinney peccoil, O Hiarn.

English: 9 For he was astonished, and all that were with him, at the draught of the fishes which they had taken:
Manx: Son ghow eshyn, as ooilley ny va mârish yindyss mooar, jeh’n tayrn dy eeastyn v’ad er ghoaill:

English: 10 And so was also James, and John, the sons of Zebedee, which were partners with Simon. And Jesus said unto Simon, Fear not; from henceforth thou shalt catch men.
Manx: As myr shen myrgeddin ren Jamys as Ean meck Zebedee, va nyn barteeassyn marish Simon. As dooyrt Yeesey rish Simon, Ny gow aggle, veih shoh magh nee oo deiney y ghoaill.

English: 11 And when they had brought their ships to land, they forsook all, and followed him.
Manx: As tra v’ad er chur lhieu nyn longyn gys thalloo, hreig ad ooilley, as deiyr ad er.

English: 12 ¶And it came to pass, when he was in a certain city, behold a man full of leprosy: who seeing Jesus fell on his face, and besought him, saying, Lord, if thou wilt, thou canst make me clean.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, tra v’eh ayns ard-valley dy row, cur-my-ner, dooinney laane jeh’n louraanys: as tra honnick Eh Yeesey, huit Eh sheese er e eddin, jannoo aghin huggey as gra, Hiarn, my she dt’aigney eh, foddee oo mish y yannoo glen.

English: 13 And he put forth his hand, and touched him, saying, I will: be thou clean. And immediately the leprosy departed from him.
Manx: As heeyn Eh magh e laue, as venn Eh rish, gra, M’aigneys eh; bee er dty ghlenney. As chelleeragh jimmee yn louraanys veih.

English: 14 And he charged him to tell no man: but go, and shew thyself to the priest, and offer for thy cleansing, according as Moses commanded, for a testimony unto them.
Manx: As hug Eh currym da gyn Eh dy insh da dooinney erbee: agh immee, as soilshee oo hene da’n taggyrt, as cheb son dty ghlenney, ’naght myr ta Moses er harey, dy ve son feanish daue.

English: 15 But so much the more went there a fame abroad of him: and great multitudes came together to hear, and to be healed by him of their infirmities.
Manx: Agh wheesh shen smoo hie taggloo magh jeh: as haink earrooyn mooarey dy leih cooidjagh dy chlashtyn, as dy ve er nyn lheihys liorish jeh nyn aslaïntyn.

English: 16 ¶And he withdrew himself into the wilderness, and prayed.
Manx: Agh hie eshyn Eh hene roish gys yn aasagh, dy ghoaill padjer.

English: 17 And it came to pass on a certain day, as he was teaching, that there were Pharisees and doctors of the law sitting by, which were come out of every town of Galilee, and Judaea, and Jerusalem: and the power of the Lord was present to heal them.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione laa dy row, myr v’eh gynsaghey, dy row Phariseeyn as fir-ynsee jeh’n leih nyn soie liorish, v’er jeet magh ass dy chooilley valley v’ayns Galilee, as Judea, as Jerusalem: as va’n dy Chiarn feer phooral lheihys doghanyn.

English: 18 ¶And, behold, men brought in a bed a man which was taken with a palsy: and they sought means to bring him in, and to lay him before him.
Manx: As cur-my-ner, hug deiney lhieu ayns lhiabbee dooinney va ching jeh’n chingys-cra: as v’ad shirrey y chur lhieu stiagh Eh, dy hoiaghey Eh kiongoyrt rish.

English: 19 And when they could not find by what way they might bring him in because of the multitude, they went upon the housetop, and let him down through the tiling with his couch into the midst before Jesus.
Manx: As tra nagh dod ad er aght erbee y chur lhieu stiagh Eh kyndagh rish y pobble, hie ad seose er mullagh y thie, as lig ad sheese ny hrooid, Eh hene as e lhiabbee, er y laare kiongoyrt rish Yeesey.

English: 20 And when he saw their faith, he said unto him, Man, thy sins are forgiven thee.
Manx: As tra hug Eh tastey da’n chredjue oc, dooyrt Eh rish, Ghooinney, ta dty pheccaghyn er nyn leih dhyt.

English: 21 And the scribes and the Pharisees began to reason, saying, Who is this which speaketh blasphemies? Who can forgive sins, but God alone?
Manx: As ren ny scruderyn as ny Phariseeyn toshiaght dy resooney, gra, Quoi shoh ta loayrt goan mollaghtagh? Quoi oddys peccaghyn y leih, agh Jee ny lomarcan?

English: 22 But when Jesus perceived their thoughts, he answering said unto them, What reason ye in your hearts?
Manx: Agh va fys ec Yeesey er ny smooinaghtyn oc, as dreggyr Eh, as dooyrt Eh roo, Cre er ta shiu resooney ayns nyn greeaghyn?

English: 23 Whether is easier, to say, Thy sins be forgiven thee; or to say, Rise up and walk?
Manx: Quoi sassey dy ghra, Ta dty pheccaghyn er nyn leih dhyt, ny dy ghra, Irree seose as shooill?

English: 24 But that ye may know that the Son of man hath power upon earth to forgive sins, (he said unto the sick of the palsy,) I say unto thee, Arise, and take up thy couch, and go into thine house.
Manx: Agh dy vod fys y ve eu, dy vel pooar ec yn Mac dooinney er y thalloo dy leih peccaghyn (dooyrt Eh rishyn va ching jeh’n chingys-cra) Ta mee gra rhyt, Irree, as trog seose dty lhiabbee, as gow royd gys dty hie.

English: 25 And immediately he rose up before them, and took up that whereon he lay, and departed to his own house, glorifying God.
Manx: As chelleeragh dirree Eh seose kiongoyrt roo, as hrog Eh shen v’eh ny lhie er, as jimmee Eh gys e hie, cur moylley da Jee.

English: 26 And they were all amazed, and they glorified God, and were filled with fear, saying, We have seen strange things to day.
Manx: As ghow ad ooilley lane yindyss, as ren ad Jee y ghloyraghey, as v’ad lhieent lesh aggle, gra, Ta shin er vakin reddyn yindyssagh jiu.

English: 27 ¶And after these things he went forth, and saw a publican, named Levi, sitting at the receipt of custom: and he said unto him, Follow me.
Manx: As ny lurg shoh hie Eh magh, as honnick Eh publican va enmyssit Levi, ny hoie ec boayrd y cheesh: as dooyrt Eh rish, Eiyr orryms.

English: 28 And he left all, rose up, and followed him.
Manx: As daag Eh ooilley as dirree Eh seose, as deiyr Eh er.

English: 29 And Levi made him a great feast in his own house: and there was a great company of publicans and of others that sat down with them.
Manx: As ren Levi aarlaghey mooar er e hon ayns e hie hene: as va sheshaght vooar dy phublicanee as dy eallagh elley hoie sheese mâroo.

English: 30 But their scribes and Pharisees murmured against his disciples, saying, Why do ye eat and drink with publicans and sinners?
Manx: Agh va ny scruderyn oc as ny Phariseeyn jymmoosagh roosyn va sheer geiyrt er, gra, Cre’n-fa ta shiu gee as giu marish publicanee as peccee?

English: 31 And Jesus answering said unto them, They that are whole need not a physician; but they that are sick.
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh roo, Cha vel feme ocsyn t’a [sic: ta] slaane er y lhee: agh ec sleih chingey.

English: 32 I came not to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance.
Manx: Cha daink mish dy eamagh er y vooinjer chairagh, agh er peccee gys arrys.

English: 33 ¶And they said unto him, Why do the disciples of John fast often, and make prayers, and likewise the disciples of the Pharisees; but thine eat and drink?
Manx: As dooyrt ad roo, Cre’n-fa t’adsyn ta Ean er n’ynsaghey trostey dy mennick, as jannoo padjeryn, as myrgeddin yn vooinjer ta ny Phariseeyn er n’ynsaghey; agh t’adsyn ta geiyrt orts gee as giu?

English: 34 And he said unto them, Can ye make the children of the bridechamber fast, while the bridegroom is with them?
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Vod shiu cur er ny caarjyn ta marish dooinney’n phoosee ayns e hiamyr trostey, choud as ta dooinney’n phoosee mâroo?

English: 35 But the days will come, when the bridegroom shall be taken away from them, and then shall they fast in those days.
Manx: Agh hig ny laghyn, tra vees dooinney’n phoosee er ny ghoaill ersooyl vow, as eisht nee ad trostey ayns ny laghyn shen.

English: 36 ¶And he spake also a parable unto them; No man putteth a piece of a new garment upon an old; if otherwise, then both the new maketh a rent, and the piece that was taken out of the new agreeth not with the old.
Manx: As loayr Eh myrgeddin coraa-dorraghey roo, Cha vel dooinney erbee cur peesh dy eaddagh noa er shen gharmad: er nonney, ta chammah yn noa rapey y laane lesh, as cha vel yn pheesh va goit ass yn noa coardail rish y shen.

English: 37 And no man putteth new wine into old bottles; else the new wine will burst the bottles, and be spilled, and the bottles shall perish.
Manx: As cha vel dooinney erbee cur feeyn noa ayns shnn voteilyn*; er nonney brishee yn feeyn noa ny boteïlyn, as bee eh deayrtit, as bee ny boteïlyn dy choayll er.
* Liare

English: 38 But new wine must be put into new bottles; and both are preserved.
Manx: Agh shegin da feeyn noa v’er ny chur ayns boteïlyn noa; as t’ad ny neesht sauchey.

English: 39 No man also having drunk old wine straightway desireth new: for he saith, The old is better.
Manx: Cha-moo ta dooinney erbee, erreish da v’er n’iu shen feeyn, chelleeragh shirrey feeyn noa: son t’eh gra, Ta’n shen ny share.
CAB. VI.

English: And it came to pass on the second sabbath after the first, that he went through the corn fields; and his disciples plucked the ears of corn, and did eat, rubbing them in their hands.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione er y chied doonaght lurg yn nah laa jeh’n chaisht, dy row Eh goll shiaghey arroo: as ren y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er jeeasyn y phluckey, as nyn ee ad, erreish daue nyn rubbey ad ayns nyn laueyn.

English: 2 And certain of the Pharisees said unto them, Why do ye that which is not lawful to do on the sabbath days?
Manx: As dooyrt shiartance jeh ny Phariseeyn roo, Cre’n-fa ta shiu jannoo shen nagh vel lowit dy ve jeant er laghyn y doonaght?

English: 3 And Jesus answering them said, Have ye not read so much as this, what David did, when himself was an hungred, and they which were with him;
Manx: As dreggyr eshyn ad, gra, Nagh vel shiu er lhaih wheesh shoh, cre ren David, tra v’eh hene as e heshaght accryssagh:

English: 4 How he went into the house of God, and did take and eat the shewbread, and gave also to them that were with him; which it is not lawful to eat but for the priests alone?
Manx: Kys hie Eh stiagh ayns thie Yee, as ghow Eh as die Eh yn arran casherick, as hug Eh eh myrgeddin dauesyn va mârish, ga nagh row eh lowit dy ve eeit, agh liorish ny saggyrtyn ny lomarcan?

English: 5 And he said unto them, That the Son of man is Lord also of the sabbath.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Dy row yn Mac dooinney ny Hiarn myrgeddin er y doonaght.

English: 6 And it came to pass also on another sabbath, that he entered into the synagogue and taught: and there was a man whose right hand was withered.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione er doonaght elley, dy jagh Eh stiagh ayns y cheeill, as dy dynsee Eh: as va dooinney ayns shen va’n laue yesh echey er shyrgaghey.

English: 7 And the scribes and Pharisees watched him, whether he would heal on the sabbath day; that they might find an accusation against him.
Manx: As hug ny scruderyn as ny Phariseeyn tastey da, dy yeeaghyn jinnagh Eh Eh y lheihys er laa’n doonaght: dy voddagh oyr y ve oc dy loayrt noi.

English: 8 But he knew their thoughts, and said to the man which had the withered hand, Rise up, and stand forth in the midst. And he arose and stood forth.
Manx: Agh va fys echyssyn er ny smooinaghtyn oc, as dooyrt Eh rish y dooinney va’n laue echey er shyrgaghey, Irree seose as shass magh er y laare. As dirree Eh, as hass Eh magh.

English: 9 Then said Jesus unto them, I will ask you one thing; Is it lawful on the sabbath days to do good, or to do evil? to save life, or to destroy it?
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Yeesey roo, Fênyms un red jiuish, Vel eh lowit er laghyn y doonaght dy yannoo mie, ny dy yannoo dy holk? dy hauail bioys, ny dy stroie eh?

English: 10 And looking round about upon them all, he said unto the man, Stretch forth thy hand. And he did so: and his hand was restored whole as the other.
Manx: As yeeagh Eh mygeayrt orroo ooilley, as dooyrt Eh rish y dooinney, Sheeyn magh dty laue. As ren Eh shen; as va’n laue echey er ny lheihys myr y laue elley.

English: 11 And they were filled with madness; and communed one with another what they might do to Jesus.
Manx: As daase ad feer elgyssagh; as loayr ad eddyr ad hene cre oddagh ad y yannoo rish Yeesey.

English: 12 And it came to pass in those days, that he went out into a mountain to pray, and continued all night in prayer to God.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione ayns ny laghyn shen, dy jagh Eh seose er slieau dy ghoaill padjer, as dy ren Eh tannaghtyn fud ny hoie guee gys Jee.

English: 13 ¶And when it was day, he called unto him his disciples: and of them he chose twelve, whom also he named apostles;
Manx: As tra va’n laa ayn, deïe Eh er y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er huggey: as jeusyn reih Eh ghaa-yeig, denmyss Eh myrgeddin nyn Ostyllyn:

English: 14 Simon, (whom he also named Peter,) and Andrew his brother, James and John, Philip and Bartholomew,
Manx: Simon (ren Eh myrgeddin y enmyss Peddyr) as Andreays e vraar, Jamys as Ean, Philip as Parlane,

English: 15 Matthew and Thomas, James the son of Alphaeus, and Simon called Zelotes,
Manx: Mian as Thomase, Jamys mac Alpheus, as Simon va enmyssit Zelotes,

English: 16 And Judas the brother of James, and Judas Iscariot, which also was the traitor.
Manx: As Judas braar Jamys, as Yuase Iscariot, va myrgeddin yn traitoor.

English: 17 ¶And he came down with them, and stood in the plain, and the company of his disciples, and a great multitude of people out of all Judaea and Jerusalem, and from the sea coast of Tyre and Sidon, which came to hear him, and to be healed of their diseases;
Manx: As haink Eh neose mâroo, as hass Eh er y thalloo kiart, as va marish yn cheshaght jeusyn va sheer geiyrt er, as earroo mooar dy leih veih ooilley Judea as Jerusalem, as veih ardjyn ny marrey Tyre as Sidon, haink dy eaishtagh rish, as dy ve er nyn lheihys jeh nyn ghoghanyn;

English: 18 And they that were vexed with unclean spirits: and they were healed.
Manx: As adsyn va spyrrydyn neu-ghlen ayndoo; as v’ad er nyn lheihys.

English: 19 And the whole multitude sought to touch him: for there went virtue out of him, and healed them all.
Manx: As va’n slane chaglym shirrey bennalt rish: son va bree goll magh ass, va dyn lheihys ad ooilley.

English: 20 ¶And he lifted up his eyes on his disciples, and said, Blessed be ye poor: for yours is the kingdom of God.
Manx: As hrog Eh seose e hooyllyn er y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er, as dooyrt Eh, Bannit ta shiuish voghtyn: son lhieuish reeriaght Yee.

English: 21 Blessed are ye that hunger now: for ye shall be filled. Blessed are ye that weep now: for ye shall laugh.
Manx: Bannit ta shiuish ta accryssagh nish: son bee shiu er nyn yannoo magh. Bannit ta shiuish ta nish jannoo dobberan: son nee shiu garaghtee.

English: 22 Blessed are ye, when men shall hate you, and when they shall separate you from their company, and shall reproach you, and cast out your name as evil, for the Son of man’s sake.
Manx: Bannit ta shiuish, tra ta deiney cur feoh diu, as tra nee ad nyn scarrey shiu vow, as nyn oltooaney shiu, as nyn ennym y hilgey magh myr olk, er coontey’n Mac dooinney.

English: 23 Rejoice ye in that day, and leap for joy: for, behold, your reward is great in heaven: for in the like manner did their fathers unto the prophets.
Manx: Bee-jee gennal ayns y laa shen, as leïme-jee son boggey: son cur-my-ner, ta’n leagh eu mooar ayns niau: son er yn aght cheddin ren ny ayraghyn oc rish ny phadeyryn.

English: 24 But woe unto you that are rich! for ye have received your consolation.
Manx: Agh smerg diuish ta berchagh: son ta shiu er gheddyn nyn gherjagh.

English: 25 Woe unto you that are full! for ye shall hunger. Woe unto you that laugh now! for ye shall mourn and weep.
Manx: Smerg diuish ta laane: son bee shiu accryssagh. Smerg diuish ta garaghtee nish: son nee shiu dobberan as keaney.

English: 26 Woe unto you, when all men shall speak well of you! for so did their fathers to the false prophets.
Manx: Smerg diuish tra nee dy chooilley ghooinney loayrt dy mie jiu: son shen myr ren ny ayraghyn oc jeh ny phadeyryn foalsey.

English: 27 ¶But I say unto you which hear, Love your enemies, do good to them which hate you,
Manx: Agh ta mish gra riuish ta clashtyn, Bee-jee graihagh er nyn noidyn, jean-jee mie dauesyn ta cur feoh diu:

English: 28 Bless them that curse you, and pray for them which despitefully use you.
Manx: Bannee-jee adsyn ta guee mollaght diu, as gow-jee padjer er nyn son ocsyn ta cur seaghyn erriu.

English: 29 And unto him that smiteth thee on the one cheek offer also the other; and him that taketh away thy cloak forbid not to take thy coat also.
Manx: As huggeysyn woaillys oo er y derrey lieckan, chyndaa myrgeddin yn lieckan elley: as eshyn ghoys ersooyl dty chloagey, ny bee noi dty chooat y liggey lesh myrgeddin.

English: 30 Give to every man that asketh of thee; and of him that taketh away thy goods ask them not again.
Manx: Cur da dy chooilley ghooinney ta jannoo aghin hood; as jehsyn ta goaill woid, ny trog dty chooid reesht.

English: 31 And as ye would that men should do to you, do ye also to them likewise.
Manx: As myr balliuish deiney dy yannoo riuish, jean-jee shiuish myrgeddin roosyn.

English: 32 For if ye love them which love you, what thank have ye? for sinners also love those that love them.
Manx: Son my ta shiu soilshaghey graih dauesyn ta graihagh erriuish, cre’n booise ta nyn gouyr? son ta peccee myrgeddin graihagh er y vooinjer ta cur graih daue.

English: 33 And if ye do good to them which do good to you, what thank have ye? for sinners also do even the same.
Manx: As my ta shiu jannoo mie dauesyn ta jannoo mie diuish, cre’n booise ta nyn gouyr? son ta peccee myrgeddin jannoo yn leid cheddin[.]

English: 34 And if ye lend to them of whom ye hope to receive, what thank have ye? for sinners also lend to sinners, to receive as much again.
Manx: As my ta shiu geeasaght dauesyn vow ta shiu treishteil dy gheddyn reesht, cre’n booise t’eu? son ta peccee myrgeddin geeasaght da peccee; dy gheddyn wheesh reesht.

English: 35 But love ye your enemies, and do good, and lend, hoping for nothing again; and your reward shall be great, and ye shall be the children of the Highest: for he is kind unto the unthankful and to the evil.
Manx: Agh cur-jee graih da nyn noidjyn, as jean-jee mie, as eeasee-jee, fegooish jerkal rish veg y gheddyn reesht: as bee yn leagh eu mooar, as bee shiu nyn gloan da’n Er-syrjey: son t’eh dooie da’n vooinjer neu-wooisal as da’n mee-chrauee.

English: 36 Be ye therefore merciful, as your Father also is merciful.
Manx: Bee-jee er-y-fa shen myghinagh, myr ta’n Ayr eu myrgeddin myghinagh.

English: 37 Judge not, and ye shall not be judged: condemn not, and ye shall not be condemned: forgive, and ye shall be forgiven:
Manx: Ny jean-jee briwnyss, as cha bee shiu er nyn mriwnyss: ny jean-jee deyrey, as cha bee shiu er nyn gheyrey: leih-jee, as yiow shiu leih:

English: 38 Give, and it shall be given unto you; good measure, pressed down, and shaken together, and running over, shall men give into your bosom. For with the same measure that ye mete withal it shall be measured to you again.
Manx: Jean-jee coyrt, as bee eh er ny choyrt diu; towse mie, jingit sheese, as criht cooidjagh, as roih harrish, ver deiney diu gys nyn oghrish. Son lesh y towse cheddin ta shiu towse, bee eh er ny howse diu reesht.

English: 39 And he spake a parable unto them, Can the blind lead the blind? shall they not both fall into the ditch?
Manx: As loayr Eh coraa-dorraghey roo, Vod y doal shooyll kione y doal? nagh duit ad ny neesht ayns y jeeg?

English: 40 The disciple is not above his master: but every one that is perfect shall be as his master.
Manx: Cha vel y scoyllar erskyn e vainshtyr: agh bee dy chooilley annane ta ynsit dy fondagh, myr e vainshtyr.

English: 41 And why beholdest thou the mote that is in thy brother's eye, but perceivest not the beam that is in thine own eye?
Manx: As cre’n-fa t’ow cronnaghey yn brenneein t’ayns sooyl dty vraar, agh cha vel oo gennaghtyn yn beam t’ayns dty hooyl hene?

English: 42 Either how canst thou say to thy brother, Brother, let me pull out the mote that is in thine eye, when thou thyself beholdest not the beam that is in thine own eye? Thou hypocrite, cast out first the beam out of thine own eye, and then shalt thou see clearly to pull out the mote that is in thy brother's eye.
Manx: Ny kys oddys oo gra rish dty vraar, Vraar, lig dou yn brenneein y ghoaill ass dty hooyl’s, tra nagh vel oo goaill ayd hene dy vel beam ayns dty hooyl hene? Er-crauee-oalsey, tilg hoshiaght yn beam ass dty hooyl hene, eisht bee soilshey ayd dy ghoaill yn brenneein ass sooyl dty vraarey.

English: 43 For a good tree bringeth not forth corrupt fruit; neither doth a corrupt tree bring forth good fruit.
Manx: Son cha vel billey mie tilgey drogh vess: ny drogh villey tilgey mess mie.

English: 44 For every tree is known by his own fruit. For of thorns men do not gather figs, nor of a bramble bush gather they grapes.
Manx: Son ta enney er ny choyrt er dy chooilley villey liorish e vess: son cha vel mess y villey-figgagh er ny heiy jeh drineyn, ny mess y villey-feeney jeh thammag-ghress.

English: 45 A good man out of the good treasure of his heart bringeth forth that which is good; and an evil man out of the evil treasure of his heart bringeth forth that which is evil: for of the abundance of the heart his mouth speaketh.
Manx: Ta dooinney mie ass stoyr mie yn chree echey, cur magh shen ny ta mie: as drogh ghooinney ass drogh stoyr e chree, cur magh shen ny ta olk: son magh veih stoyr y chree ta’n beeal loayrt.

English: 46 ¶And why call ye me, Lord, Lord, and do not the things which I say?
Manx: As cre’n-fa ta shiu genmyss mee, Hiarn, Hiarn, fegooish jannoo ny reddyn ta mee dy ghra?

English: 47 Whosoever cometh to me, and heareth my sayings, and doeth them, I will shew you to whom he is like:
Manx: Quoi-erbee ta cheet hym’s, ta clashtyn my ghoan, as jannoo ymmyd mie jeu, jeeaghyms diu quoi rish t’eh goll.

English: 48 He is like a man which built an house, and digged deep, and laid the foundation on a rock: and when the flood arose, the stream beat vehemently upon that house, and could not shake it: for it was founded upon a rock.
Manx: T’eh goll-rish dooinney ren thie y hroggal, as chley dy dowin, as hoie yn undin er creg: as tra dhatt yn ushtey, cheau yn thooilley er y thie shen, as cha dod eh y chraa eh; er-yn-oyr dy row yn undin echey er creg.

English: 49 But he that heareth, and doeth not, is like a man that without a foundation built an house upon the earth; against which the stream did beat vehemently, and immediately it fell; and the ruin of that house was great.
Manx: Agh eshyn ta clashtyn as nagh vel jannoo ymmyd mie jeh, t’eh goll-rish dooinney, ren fegooish undin thie y hroggal er yn ooir, as ren y thooilley ceau, as chelleeragh huit eh, as mooar va toyrt-mow yn thie shen.
CAB. VII.

English: Now when he had ended all his sayings in the audience of the people, he entered into Capernaum.
Manx: Nish tra v’eh erreish ooilley ny goan shoh y loayrt ayns clashtyn yn pobble, hie Eh stiagh ayns Capernaum.

English: 2 And a certain centurion’s servant, who was dear unto him, was sick, and ready to die.
Manx: As va captan-keead dy row va fer-mooinjerey echey, bynney lesh dy mie, as v’eh ching, as raad y vaaïsh.

English: 3 And when he heard of Jesus, he sent unto him the elders of the Jews, beseeching him that he would come and heal his servant.
Manx: As tra cheayll Eh jeh Yeesey, hug Eh huggey shanstyr ny Hewnyn, guee er Eh dy heet dy laanaghey e er-mooinjerey.

English: 4 And when they came to Jesus, they besought him instantly, saying, That he was worthy for whom he should do this:
Manx: As tra v’ad er jeet gys Yeesey, ren ad aghin huggey dy jeean, gra, Dy row eshyn feeu v’eh dy yannoo shoh er y hon:

English: 5 For he loveth our nation, and he hath built us a synagogue.
Manx: Son t’eh graihagh er yn ashoon ain, as t’eh er hroggal keeill dooin.

English: 6 Then Jesus went with them. And when he was now not far from the house, the centurion sent friends to him, saying unto him, Lord, trouble not thyself: for I am not worthy that thou shouldest enter under my roof:
Manx: Eisht hie Yeesey mâroo. As tra v’eh er jeet er-gerrey da’n thie, hug y captan-keead caarjyn huggey, gra rish, Hiarn, ny gow yn trubble ort hene, son cha vel mish feeu oo dy heet stiagh fo my chlea.

English: 7 Wherefore neither thought I myself worthy to come unto thee: but say in a word, and my servant shall be healed.
Manx: As er-yn-oyr shen cha yeeagh mee orrym pene dy ve feeu dy heet hood: agh loayr y fockle, as bee my er-mooinjerey er ny laanaghey.

English: 8 For I also am a man set under authority, having under me soldiers, and I say unto one, Go, and he goeth; and to another, Come, and he cometh; and to my servant, Do this, and he doeth it.
Manx: Son ta mish mee hene my ghooinney ta fo pooar, as ta sidooryn aym foym, as ta mee gra rish shoh, Immee, as t’eh goll: as rish fer elley, Tarr, as t’eh cheet: as rish my harvaant, Jean shoh, as t’eh dy yannoo eh.

English: 9 When Jesus heard these things, he marvelled at him, and turned him about, and said unto the people that followed him, I say unto you, I have not found so great faith, no, not in Israel.
Manx: Tra cheayll Yeesey ny reddyn shoh, ghow Eh yindyss, as hyndaa Eh mygeayrt, as dooyrt Eh rish y pobble va geiyrt er, Ta mee gra riu, Leid y credjue lajer shoh, cha vel mee er gheddyn ayns Israel hene.

English: 10 And they that were sent, returning to the house, found the servant whole that had been sick.
Manx: As haink adsyn hie er y chaghteragh reesht gys y thie, as hooar ad dy mie ayns e lhaint yn fer-mooinjerey va er ny ve ching.

English: 11 ¶And it came to pass the day after, that he went into a city called Nain; and many of his disciples went with him, and much people.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione yn laa er-giyn, dy jagh Eh gys ard-valley va enmyssit Nain; as hie ymmodee jeusyn va sheer geiyrt er marish, as ymmodee dy leih.

English: 12 Now when he came nigh to the gate of the city, behold, there was a dead man carried out, the only son of his mother, and she was a widow: and much people of the city was with her.
Manx: Nish tra haink Eh er-gerrey da giat yn ard-valley, cur-my-ner, va sleih cur lhieu magh dooinney marroo, va ny ynrycan mac da e voir, as vie ish ny ben-treoghe: as va ymmodee jeh sleih yn ard-valley mâree.

English: 13 And when the Lord saw her, he had compassion on her, and said unto her, Weep not.
Manx: As tra honnick y Chiarn ee, va chymmey echey urree, as dooyrt eh ree, Ny jean keaney.

English: 14 And he came and touched the bier: and they that bare him stood still. And he said, Young man, I say unto thee, Arise.
Manx: As haink Eh, as venn Eh rish y carbyd, (as hass adsyn va fo) as dooyrt Eh, Ghooinney aeg, ta mee gra rhyt, Irree.

English: 15 And he that was dead sat up, and began to speak. And he delivered him to his mother.
Manx: As hoie yn dooinney marroo seose, as ren Eh toshiaght dy loayrt: as livrey Eh Eh gys e voir.

English: 16 And there came a fear on all: and they glorified God, saying, That a great prophet is risen up among us; and, That God hath visited his people.
Manx: As haink aggle orroo ooilley: hug ad moylley da Jee, gra, Dy vel phadeyr mooar er n’irree seose nyn mast’ ain; as, Dy vel Jee er yeeaghyn er e phobble.

English: 17 And this rumour of him went forth throughout all Judaea, and throughout all the region round about.
Manx: As hie yn naight shoh magh mychione echey trooid ooilley Judea, as trooid ooilley’n cheer mygeayrt.

English: 18 And the disciples of John shewed him of all these things.
Manx: As hug adsyn va sheer geiyrt er Ean coontey da jeh ooilley ny reddyn shoh.

English: 19 ¶And John calling unto him two of his disciples sent them to Jesus, saying, Art thou he that should come? or look we for another?
Manx: As deïe Ean er jees jeusyn v’er ny ve sheer marish, as hug Eh ad er chaghteragh gys Yeesey, gra, Nee uss Eh * va dy heet, ny vel shin dy yeeaghyn son fer elley?
* Yn Messias.

English: 20 When the men were come unto him, they said, John Baptist hath sent us unto thee, saying, Art thou he that should come? or look we for another?
Manx: Tra va ny deiney er jeet huggey, dooyrt ad, Ta Ean Bashtey er nyn goyrt shin dy ênaght jeed, Nee uss Eh * va ry hoi cheet, ny vel shin dy yeeaghyn son fer elley?
* Yn Messias.

English: 21 And in that same hour he cured many of their infirmities and plagues, and of evil spirits; and unto many that were blind he gave sight.
Manx: As ayns yn oor cheddin v’eh lheihys ymmodee jeh ny aslaïntyn as ny doghanyn, as ny drogh-spyrrydyn oc, as da ymmodee va doal v’eh coyrt soilshey.

English: 22 Then Jesus answering said unto them, Go your way, and tell John what things ye have seen and heard; how that the blind see, the lame walk, the lepers are cleansed, the deaf hear, the dead are raised, to the poor the gospel is preached.
Manx: Eisht dreggyr Yeesey, as dooyrt Eh roo, Immee-jee reue, as insh-jee da Ean cre ny reddyn ta shiu er vakin as er chlashtyn, kys dy vel ny doail geddyn nyn soilshey, ny croobee shooyll, ny louraanee er nyn ghlenney, ny beuyr clashtyn, ny merriu er nyn mioghey, as y sushtal er ny phreacheil da ny boghtyn.

English: 23 And blessed is he, whosoever shall not be offended in me.
Manx: As bannit ta eshyn nagh gow oyr dy huittym ersooyl [veih’n Chredjue] er y choontey aym’s.

English: 24 ¶And when the messengers of John were departed, he began to speak unto the people concerning John, What went ye out into the wilderness for to see? A reed shaken with the wind?
Manx: As tra va chaghteryn Ean er gholl roue, ren Eh toshiaght dy ghra rish y pobble mychione Ean, cre hie shiu magh gys yn aasagh dy akin? Cuirtlagh criht lesh y gheay?

English: 25 But what went ye out for to see? A man clothed in soft raiment? Behold, they which are gorgeously apparelled, and live delicately, are in kings’ courts.
Manx: Agh cre hie shiu magh dy akin? Dooinney coamrit ayns sheedey? Cur-my-ner, t’adsyn ta ceau sheedey, as beaghey dy seyr, ayns thieyn reeaghyn.

English: 26 But what went ye out for to see? A prophet? Yea, I say unto you, and much more than a prophet.
Manx: Agh cre hie shiu magh dy akin? Phadeyr? dy jarroo, ta mee gra riu, as fer syrjey na phadeyr.

English: 27 This is he, of whom it is written, Behold, I send my messenger before thy face, which shall prepare thy way before thee.
Manx: Shoh Eh jeh te scruit, cur-my-ner, ta mee cur my haghter magh royd, dy yannoo aarloo dty raad er dty hon.

English: 28 For I say unto you, Among those that are born of women there is not a greater prophet than John the Baptist: but he that is least in the kingdom of God is greater than he.
Manx: Son ta mee gra riu, Nyn mastey ocsyn t’er nyn ruggey jeh mraane, cha vel phadeyr syrjey na Ean Bashtey: agh ta’n fer sloo t’ayns reeriaght Yee ny syrjey na eshyn.

English: 29 And all the people that heard him, and the publicans, justified God, being baptized with the baptism of John.
Manx: As ren ooilley’n pobble cheayll Eh, as ny publicanee Jee y heyrey, as v’ad er nyn mashtey lesh bashtey Ean.

English: 30 But the Pharisees and lawyers rejected the counsel of God against themselves, being not baptized of him.
Manx: Agh ren ny Phariseeyn as ny fir-ynsee jeh’n leigh beg y hoiaghey jeh coyrle Yee nyn oi oc hene, as cha row ad er nyn mashtey liorish.

English: 31 ¶And the Lord said, Whereunto then shall I liken the men of this generation? and to what are they like?
Manx: As dooyrt y Chiarn, Cre gys nee’m deiney yn cheeloghe shoh y hoyllaghey? as cre rish t’ad goll.

English: 32 They are like unto children sitting in the marketplace, and calling one to another, and saying, We have piped unto you, and ye have not danced; we have mourned to you, and ye have not wept.
Manx: T’ad goll-rish cloan, ta nyn soie ayns ny margaghyn, geamagh yn derrey yeh da’n jeh elley, as gra, Ta shin er n’yannoo bingys diu, as cha vel shiu er ghonsin: ta shin er n’yannoo kiaull hrimshagh diu, as cha vel shiu er cheaney.

English: 33 For John the Baptist came neither eating bread nor drinking wine; and ye say, He hath a devil.
Manx: Son cha daink Ean Bashtey gee arran, ny giu feeyn; as ta shiu gra, Ta drogh-spyrryd echey.

English: 34 The Son of man is come eating and drinking; and ye say, Behold a gluttonous man, and a winebibber, a friend of publicans and sinners
Manx: Ta’n Mac dooinney er jeet gee as giu; as ta shiu gra, Cur-my-ner dooinney jollyssagh, as iuder-feeney, carrey dy phublicanee as dy pheccee.

English: 35 But wisdom is justified of all her children.
Manx: Agh ta creenaght er ny heyrey liorish ooilley e cloan.

English: 36 ¶And one of the Pharisees desired him that he would eat with him. And he went into the Pharisee's house, and sat down to meat.
Manx: As chuir fer jeh ny Phariseeyn Eh gys bee mârish. As hie Eh stiagh ayns thie yn Pharisee, as hoie Eh sheese gys bee.

English: 37 And, behold, a woman in the city, which was a sinner, when she knew that Jesus sat at meat in the Pharisee’s house, brought an alabaster box of ointment,
Manx: As cur-my-ner, va ben ayns yn ard-valley, va ny drogh-yantagh, tra va fys eck dy row Yeesey ny hoie ec bee ayns thie yn Pharisee, hug ee lheie box-alabaster dy ooill,

English: 38 And stood at his feet behind him weeping, and began to wash his feet with tears, and did wipe them with the hairs of her head, and kissed his feet, and anointed them with the ointment.
Manx: As hass ee ec e chassyn cheu e chooylloo keaney, as ren ee toshiaght dy niee e chassyn lesh jeïr, as rub ee ad lesh folt e king, as phaag ee e chassyn, as ren ee ad y ooillaghey lesh yn ooill.

English: 39 Now when the Pharisee which had bidden him saw it, he spake within himself, saying, This man, if he were a prophet, would have known who and what manner of woman this is that toucheth him: for she is a sinner.
Manx: Nish yn Pharisee ren y chuirrey Eh, tra honnick Eh shoh, loayr Eh cheu-sthie jeh hene, gra, Veagh fys er ve ec y dooinney shoh, dy beagh Eh ny adeyr, quoi, as cre’n monney dy ven ee shoh, ta bennaylt rish: son t’ee ny drogh-yantagh.

English: 40 And Jesus answering said unto him, Simon, I have somewhat to say unto thee. And he saith, Master, say on.
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey, as dooyrt Eh rish, Simon, ta red aym’s dy ghra rhyt. As dooyrt Eh, Loayr, Vainshtyr.

English: 41 There was a certain creditor which had two debtors: the one owed five hundred pence, and the other fifty.
Manx: Va dooinney dy row, va jees ayns lhiastynys da: va’n derrey yeh lhiastyn queig cheead ping, as y jeh elley jeih pingyn as da-eed.

English: 42 And when they had nothing to pay, he frankly forgave them both. Tell me therefore, which of them will love him most?
Manx: As tra nagh row oc dy eeck, leih Eh daue ny neesht dy arryltagh. Insh dou eisht, quoi oc s’graihee vees er?

English: 43 Simon answered and said, I suppose that he, to whom he forgave most. And he said unto him, Thou hast rightly judged.
Manx: Dreggyr Simon as dooyrt Eh, Ta mee dy smooinaghtyn dy nee eshyn, da smoo ren Eh leih. As dooyrt Eh rish, T’ow er vriwnys dy cairagh.

English: 44 And he turned to the woman, and said unto Simon, Seest thou this woman? I entered into thine house, thou gavest me no water for my feet: but she hath washed my feet with tears, and wiped them with the hairs of her head.
Manx: As hyndaa Eh gys y ven, as dooyrt Eh rish Simon, Vel oo cur tastey da’n ven shoh? Hie mee stiagh ayns dty hie’s, as cha dug oo dou ushtey son my chassyn: agh tie ish er niee my chassyn lesh jeïr, as er rubbey ad lesh folt e king.

English: 45 Thou gavest me no kiss: but this woman since the time I came in hath not ceased to kiss my feet.
Manx: Cha dug uss paag dou: agh ta’n ven shoh, er dyn traa haink mee stiagh, er ve kinjagh paagey my chassyn.

English: 46 My head with oil thou didst not anoint: but this woman hath anointed my feet with ointment.
Manx: My chione lesh ooill cha ren oo y ooillaghey: agh ta’n ven shoh er n’ooillaghey my chassyn lesh ooill.

English: 47 Wherefore I say unto thee, Her sins, which are many, are forgiven; for she loved much: but to whom little is forgiven, the same loveth little.
Manx: Shen-y-fa ta mee gra rhyt, Ta ny peccaghyn eck, ta ymmodee, er nyn leih: son v’ee feer ghraihagh: agh eshyn ta beggan er ny leih da, cha vel y fer cheddin soilshaghey agh beggan graih.

English: 48 And he said unto her, Thy sins are forgiven.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh ree, Ta dty pheccaghyn er nyn leih.

English: 49 And they that sat at meat with him began to say within themselves, Who is this that forgiveth sins also?
Manx: As ren y vooinjer va nyn soie ec bee marish, toshiaght dy ghra cheu-sthie jeu hene, Quoi Eh shoh ta myrgeddin leih peccaghyn?

English: 50 And he said to the woman, Thy faith hath saved thee; go in peace.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish y ven, Ta dty chredjue er dty hauail; immee ayns shee.
CAB. VIII.

English: And it came to pass afterward, that he went throughout every city and village, preaching and shewing the glad tidings of the kingdom of God: and the twelve were with him,
Manx: As haink eh gy kione ny lurg shen, dy jagh Eh trooid dy chooilley valley, mooar as beg, preacheil as soilshaghey naightyn gerjolagh reeriaght Yee: as va’n daa ostyl yeig marish;

English: 2 And certain women, which had been healed of evil spirits and infirmities, Mary called Magdalene, out of whom went seven devils,
Manx: As shiartance dy vraane, v’er nyn lheihys jeh drogh-spyrrydyn, as aslaïntyn, Moirrey va enmyssit Malaine, ass-jee hie shiaght drogh-spyrrydyn,

English: 3 And Joanna the wife of Chuza Herod's steward, and Susanna, and many others, which ministered unto him of their substance.
Manx: As Joanna ben Chusa stiurt Herod, as Susanna, as ymmodee elley, v’er hirveish er jeh nyn gooid.

English: 4 ¶And when much people were gathered together, and were come to him out of every city, he spake by a parable:
Manx: As tra va earroo mooar dy leih er nyn jaglym cooidjagh, as er jeet huggey ass dy chooilley ard-valley; loayr Eh liorish coraa-dorraghey:

English: 5 A sower went out to sow his seed: and as he sowed, some fell by the way side; and it was trodden down, and the fowls of the air devoured it.
Manx: Hie corryder magh dy chuirr e rass: as myr v’eh cuirr, huit paart rish oirr y raad, as ve stampit sheese, as die eeanlee yn aer eh.

English: 6 And some fell upon a rock; and as soon as it was sprung up, it withered away, because it lacked moisture.
Manx: As huit paart er creg, as cha leah as ve er n’aase seose, hie eh naardey, er-yn-oyr dy row eh laccal soo.

English: 7 And some fell among thorns; and the thorns sprang up with it, and choked it.
Manx: As huit paart mastey drineyn, as daase ny drineyn seose marish, as hoght ad eh.

English: 8 And other fell on good ground, and sprang up, and bare fruit an hundredfold. And when he had said these things, he cried, He that hath ears to hear, let him hear.
Manx: As huit cooid elley jeh ayns thalloo mie as daase eh seose, as dymmyrk eh mess keead-filley. As tra v’eh er ghra shoh, deïe Eh, Eshyn ta cleashyn echey dy chlashtyn, lig da clashtyn.

English: 9 And his disciples asked him, saying, What might this parable be?
Manx: As dênee yn vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er jeh, gra, Cre oddagh y coraa-dorraghey shoh y ve?

English: 10 And he said, Unto you it is given to know the mysteries of the kingdom of God: but to others in parables; that seeing they might not see, and hearing they might not understand.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Diuish te er ny choyrt dy hoiggal folliaghtyn reeriaght Yee; agh da feallagh elley ayns coraaghyn-dorraghey: fakin nagh voddagh ad fakin, as clashtyn nagh voddagh ad toiggal.

English: 11 Now the parable is this: The seed is the word of God.
Manx: Nish y coraa-dorraghey she shoh eh: Yn rass goo Yee.

English: 12 Those by the way side are they that hear; then cometh the devil, and taketh away the word out of their hearts, lest they should believe and be saved.
Manx: Shen rish oirr y raad, yn vooinjer ta clashtyn: eisht ta’n drogh-spyrryd cheet, as goaill ersooyl yn goo ass ny creeaghyn oc, er aggle dy jeanagh ad credjal, as dy beagh ad er nyn sauail.

English: 13 They on the rock are they, which, when they hear, receive the word with joy; and these have no root, which for a while believe, and in time of temptation fall away.
Manx: Adsyn er y chreg, yn vooinjer, tra t’ad er chlashtyn, ta goaill y goo lesh boggey; as cha vel fraue oc shoh, son tammylt t’ad credjal, agh ayns earish miolagh ta nyn gredjue failleil.

English: 14 And that which fell among thorns are they, which, when they have heard, go forth, and are choked with cares and riches and pleasures of this life, and bring no fruit to perfection.
Manx: As shen huit mastey drineyn, yn vooinjer, tra t’ad er chlashtyn, ta goll magh as ta thoghtit lesh kiarrail as berchys, as pleasallyn y vea shoh, as cha vel ad gymmyrkey magh mess.

English: 15 But that on the good ground are they, which in an honest and good heart, having heard the word, keep it, and bring forth fruit with patience.
Manx: Agh shen er y thalloo mie, yn vooinjer, ta lesh creeaghyn onneragh as mie, er chlashtyn yn goo, as ta dy reaylley oc eh, as cur magh mess dy surransagh.

English: 16 ¶No man, when he hath lighted a candle, covereth it with a vessel, or putteth it under a bed; but setteth it on a candlestick, that they which enter in may see the light.
Manx: Cha vel dooinney erbee, tra t’eh er voddey kainle, dy choodaghey ee lesh saagh, ny dy choyrt ee fo lhiabbee: agh soiaghey ee ayns kainlere, dy vod adsyn ta cheet stiagh yn soilshey y akin.

English: 17 For nothing is secret, that shall not be made manifest; neither any thing hid, that shall not be known and come abroad.
Manx: Son cha vel nhee erbee follit, nagh jig gys soilshey: ny nhee erbee kellit, nagh bee fys er, as nagh jig magh.

English: 18 Take heed therefore how ye hear: for whosoever hath, to him shall be given; and whosoever hath not, from him shall be taken even that which he seemeth to have.
Manx: Cur-jee twoaie er-y-fa shen kys ta shiu clashtyn: son quoi-erbee ta echey, dasyn vees er ny choyrt; as quoi-erbee nagh vel echey, veihsyn vees er ny ghoaill shen hene ny ta smooinit dy ve echey.

English: 19 ¶Then came to him his mother and his brethren, and could not come at him for the press.
Manx: Eisht haink huggey e voir as e vraaraghyn, as cha dad ad cheet n’aare, kyndagh rish y chennid.

English: 20 And it was told him by certain which said, Thy mother and thy brethren stand without, desiring to see thee.
Manx: As va shoh er ny insh da, lioroosyn dooyrt, Ta dty voir as dty vraaraghyn nyn shassoo mooie, as booiagh oo y akin.

English: 21 And he answered and said unto them, My mother and my brethren are these which hear the word of God, and do it.
Manx: As dreggyr Eh, as dooyrt Eh roo, My voir as my vraaraghyn ad shoh ta clashtyn goo Yee, as ta dy yannoo eh.

English: 22 ¶Now it came to pass on a certain day, that he went into a ship with his disciples: and he said unto them, Let us go over unto the other side of the lake. And they launched forth.
Manx: Nish haink eh gy kione, er laa dy row, dy jagh Eh ayns lhong marish y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er: as dooyrt Eh roo, Lig dooin goll harrish gys y cheu elley jeh’n ushtey. As hie ad magh son y cheayn.

English: 23 But as they sailed he fell asleep: and there came down a storm of wind on the lake; and they were filled with water, and were in jeopardy.
Manx: Agh myr v’ad shiaulley, huit Eh ny chadley: as dirree sterrym mooar dy gheay er y cheayn, as haink lane ushtey stiagh, as v’ad ayns dangere.

English: 24 And they came to him, and awoke him, saying, Master, master, we perish. Then he arose, and rebuked the wind and the raging of the water: and they ceased, and there was a calm.
Manx: As haink ad huggey as ghooisht ad Eh, gra, Vainshtyr, vainshtyr, bee mad callit. Eisht dirree Eh, as smaghtee Eh yn gheay as y sterrym v’ayns yn ushtey: as ghow ad fea, as va kuiney ayn.

English: 25 And he said unto them, Where is your faith? And they being afraid wondered, saying one to another, What manner of man is this! for he commandeth even the winds and water, and they obey him.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Cre vel y credjue eu? As v’ad agglagh, as ghow ad yindyss, gra yn derrey yeh rish y jeh elley, Cre’n monney dy ghooinney Eh shoh? son t’eh cur saarey da ny eer geayghyn as yn ushtey, as t’ad cur biallys da.

English: 26 ¶And they arrived at the country of the Gadarenes, which is over against Galilee.
Manx: As haink ad gys cheer ny Gadarenee, ta jeeragh er Galilee.

English: 27 And when he went forth to land, there met him out of the city a certain man, which had devils long time, and ware no clothes, neither abode in any house, but in the tombs.
Manx: As tra v’eh er gholl er thalloo, haink ny whail ass yn ard-valley, dooinney dy row va drogh-spyrrydyn er ve ayn ry foddey, as cha row Eh ceau eaddagh, ny fuirriaght ayns thie erbee, agh mastey ny hoaiaghyn.

English: 28 When he saw Jesus, he cried out, and fell down before him, and with a loud voice said, What have I to do with thee, Jesus, thou Son of God most high? I beseech thee, torment me not.
Manx: Tra honnick Eh Yeesey, deïe Eh, as huit Eh sheese kiongoyrt rish, as dooyrt Eh lesh ard choraa, Cre’n eïe t’ayd orrym, Yeesey, Vac yn Jee smoo ard? Gueeym ort ny jean m’y horchaghey.

English: 29 (For he had commanded the unclean spirit to come out of the man. For oftentimes it had caught him: and he was kept bound with chains and in fetters; and he brake the bands, and was driven of the devil into the wilderness.)
Manx: (Sôn v’eh er haarey yn spyrryd neu-ghlen dy heet magh ass y dooinney. Son ve dy mennick er hoiaghey er: as v’eh freilt kainlt lesh geulaghyn, as ayns yiarnyn; as vrish Eh ny geulaghyn, as v’eh er ny ve eiyrit liorish y drogh-spyrryd gys yn aasagh.)

English: 30 And Jesus asked him, saying, What is thy name? And he said, Legion: because many devils were entered into him.
Manx: As dênee Yeesey jeh, gra, Cre’n ennym t’ort? As dooyrt Eh, Legion: er-yn-oyr dy row ymmodee drogh-spyrrydyn er gholl stiagh ayn.

English: 31 And they besought him that he would not command them to go out into the deep.
Manx: As ghuee ad er gyn Eh dy oardaghey daue goll sheese gys y diunit.

English: 32 And there was there an herd of many swine feeding on the mountain: and they besought him that he would suffer them to enter into them. And he suffered them.
Manx: As va griagh mooar dy vuckyn fo bochillyn er y clieau: as ghuee ad er, Eh dy chur kied daue goll stiagh ayndoo. As hug Eh kied daue.

English: 33 Then went the devils out of the man, and entered into the swine: and the herd ran violently down a steep place into the lake, and were choked.
Manx: Eisht hie ny drogh-spyrrydyn ass y dooinney, as hie ad stiagh ayns ny muckyn: as roih yn ghriagh gouyr nyn mullee lesh yn ughtagh gys y cheayn, as v’ad plooghit.

English: 34 When they that fed them saw what was done, they fled, and went and told it in the city and in the country.
Manx: Tra honnick ny bochillyn cre va jeant, roih ad rowe, as hie ad as dinsh ad eh ayns yn ard-valley, as er y cheer.

English: 35 Then they went out to see what was done; and came to Jesus, and found the man, out of whom the devils were departed, sitting at the feet of Jesus, clothed, and in his right mind: and they were afraid.
Manx: Eisht hie ad magh dy yeeaghyn cre va jeant; as haink ad gys Yeesey, as hooar ad y dooinney, ass va ny drogh spyrrydyn er gholl, ny hoie ec cassyn Yeesey, as e eaddagh er, as v’eh dy mie ayns e cheeal: as ghow ad aggle.

English: 36 They also which saw it told them by what means he that was possessed of the devils was healed.
Manx: Dinsh myrgeddin yn vooinjer honnick eh daue, cre’n aght v’eshyn va ny drogh-spyrrydyn er ny ve ayn, er ny lheihys.

English: 37 Then the whole multitude of the country of the Gadarenes round about besought him to depart from them; for they were taken with great fear: and he went up into the ship, and returned back again.
Manx: Eisht ren y slane chaglym jeh cheer ny Gadarenee mygeayrt, guee er Eh dy gholl roish vow; son va aggle mooar er duittym orroo: as hie Eh seose ayns y lhong as hyndaa Eh back reesht.
