English: 38 Now the man out of whom the devils were departed besought him that he might be with him: but Jesus sent him away, saying,
Manx: Nish va’n dooinney ass va ny drogh-spyrrydyn er gholl geearree dy ve marish: agh hug Yeesey Eh ersooyl, gra,

English: 39 Return to thine own house, and shew how great things God hath done unto thee. And he went his way, and published throughout the whole city how great things Jesus had done unto him.
Manx: Gow royd gys dty hie hene, as soilshee cre ny reddyn mooarey ta Jee er n’yannoo er dty hon. As hie Eh roish, as dinsh Eh magh trooid ooilley’n ard-valley, cre ny reddyn mooarey va Yeesey er n’yannoo er e hon.

English: 40 And it came to pass, that, when Jesus was returned, the people gladly received him: for they were all waiting for him.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, tra va Yeesey er jeet back, dy ren y pobble e vea y oltaghey: son v’ad ooilley feeau er.

English: 41 ¶And, behold, there came a man named Jairus, and he was a ruler of the synagogue: and he fell down at Jesus’ feet, and besought him that he would come into his house:
Manx: As cur-my-ner, haink dooinney va enmyssit Jairus, as v’eh ny er-reïl jeh’n cheeill: as huit Eh sheese ec cassyn Yeesey, as ghuee Eh er, Eh dy heet stiagh ayns e hie:

English: 42 For he had one only daughter, about twelve years of age, and she lay a dying. But as he went the people thronged him.
Manx: Son va un ynrycan inneen echey, va mysh daa vleïn jeig dy eash, as v’ee raad y vaaish. (Agh myr v’eh goll, va’n pobble cheet chion er.

English: 43 ¶And a woman having an issue of blood twelve years, which had spent all her living upon physicians, neither could be healed of any,
Manx: As va ben va roih-foalley er ny ve eck rish daa vleïn jeig, v’er vaarail ooilley e beaghey er lheeghyn, as cha dod annane oc ee y lheihys,

English: 44 Came behind him, and touched the border of his garment: and immediately her issue of blood stanched.
Manx: Haink ee shoh cheu y chooylloo, as venn ee rish oirr e gharmad: as chelleeragh hyrmee yn roih-foalley eck.

English: 45 And Jesus said, Who touched me? When all denied, Peter and they that were with him said, Master, the multitude throng thee and press thee, and sayest thou, Who touched me?
Manx: As dooyrt Yeesey, Quoi venn rhym? Tra ren ooilley gobbal, dooyrt Peddyr, as adsyn va marish, Vainshtyr, ta’n pobble cheet chion ort, as dy dty yingey, as t’ow uss gra, Quoi venn rhym?

English: 46 And Jesus said, Somebody hath touched me: for I perceive that virtue is gone out of me.
Manx: As dooyrt Yeesey, Ta peccagh ennagh er vennaylt rhym: son ta mee gennaghtyn dy vel bree er gholl ass-ym.

English: 47 And when the woman saw that she was not hid, she came trembling, and falling down before him, she declared unto him before all the people for what cause she had touched him, and how she was healed immediately.
Manx: As tra honnick y ven dy row ee cronnit, haink ee er-creau, as huit ee sheese ec e chassyn, as hoilshee ee da kiongoyrt rish ooilley’n pobble, cre’n oyr v’eck dy vennaylt rish, as kys v’ee er ny lheihys chelleeragh.

English: 48 And he said unto her, Daughter, be of good comfort: thy faith hath made thee whole; go in peace.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh ree, Inneen, bee dy yien mie; ta dty chredjue er dty laanaghey: immee ayns shee.)

English: 49 ¶While he yet spake, there cometh one from the ruler of the synagogue's house, saying to him, Thy daughter is dead; trouble not the Master.
Manx: Choud as v’eh foast loayrt, haink fer veih thie fer-reïl ny killagh, gra rish, Ta dt’inneen marroo; ny cur trubble da’n Mainshtyr.

English: 50 But when Jesus heard it, he answered him, saying, Fear not: believe only, and she shall be made whole.
Manx: Agh tra cheayll Yeesey shoh, dreggyr Eh Eh, gra, Ny gow aggle: ny lomarcan jean credjal, as yiow ee e slaint.

English: 51 And when he came into the house, he suffered no man to go in, save Peter, and James, and John, and the father and the mother of the maiden.
Manx: As tra v’eh er jeet stiagh ayns y thie, cha lig Eh da dooinney erbee goll stiagh, cheu-mooie jeh Peddyr, as Jamys, as Ean, as ayr as moir y ven-aeg.

English: 52 And all wept, and bewailed her: but he said, Weep not; she is not dead, but sleepeth.
Manx: As v’ad ooilley keaney, as jannoo dobberan er e son: agh dooyrt eshyn, Ny jean-jee keaney; cha vel ee marroo, agh ny cadley.

English: 53 And they laughed him to scorn, knowing that she was dead.
Manx: As ren ad gannidys er; son va fys oc dy row ee marroo.

English: 54 And he put them all out, and took her by the hand, and called, saying, Maid, arise.
Manx: As hug Eh ad ooilley magh, as ghow Eh ee er laue, as deïe Eh, gra, Ven-aeg, irree seose.

English: 55 And her spirit came again, and she arose straightway: and he commanded to give her meat.
Manx: As haink y spyrryd eck reesht, as dirree ee chelleeragh: as hug Eh saarey bee y chur jee.

English: 56 And her parents were astonished: but he charged them that they should tell no man what was done.
Manx: As ghow yn ayr as y voir eck yindyss mooar: agh hug Eh currym daue gyn ad dy insh da dooinney erbee cre va jeant.
CAB. IX.

English: Then he called his twelve disciples together, and gave them power and authority over all devils, and to cure diseases.
Manx: Eisht deïe Eh er y daa ostyl yeig cooidjagh, as hug Eh daue pooar as reill harrish dy chooilley ghrogh-spyrryd, as dy lheihys doghanyn.

English: 2 And he sent them to preach the kingdom of God, and to heal the sick.
Manx: As hug Eh ad magh dy phreacheil reeriaght Yee, as dy laanaghey sleih chingey.

English: 3 And he said unto them, Take nothing for your journey, neither staves, nor scrip, neither bread, neither money; neither have two coats apiece.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Ny cur-jee lhieu red erbee son nyn yurnah, cha-moo luirg, ny spagey, ny arran, ny argid; as ny lig da daa chooat y pheesh y ve eu.

English: 4 And whatsoever house ye enter into, there abide, and thence depart.
Manx: As thie erbee dy jed shiu stiagh ayn, fuirree-jee ayns shen, as veih shen gow-jee reue.

English: 5 And whosoever will not receive you, when ye go out of that city, shake off the very dust from your feet for a testimony against them.
Manx: As quoi-erbee nagh jean soiagh jiu, tra aagys shiu yn ard-valley shen, crie-jee yn eer joan jeh ny cassyn eu, dy ve son feanish nyn oi oc.

English: 6 And they departed, and went through the towns, preaching the gospel, and healing every where.
Manx: As hie ad magh, as jimmee ad trooid ny baljyn, preacheil yn sushtal, as lheihys dy chooilley raad.

English: 7 ¶Now Herod the tetrarch heard of all that was done by him: and he was perplexed, because that it was said of some, that John was risen from the dead;
Manx: Nish va Herod yn tetrarch er chlashtyn jeh ooilley ny v’er ny yannoo liorish: as v’eh seaghnit, er-y-fa dy row paart gra, dy row Ean er n’irree veih ny merriu:

English: 8 And of some, that Elias had appeared; and of others, that one of the old prophets was risen again.
Manx: As paart, dy row Elias er jeet kionfenish: as feallagh elley, dy row annane jeh ny shen adeyryn er n’irree reesht.

English: 9 And Herod said, John have I beheaded: but who is this, of whom I hear such things? And he desired to see him.
Manx: As dooyrt Herod, Jeh Ean ren mish yn chione y ghoaill; agh quoi Eh shoh jeh ta mee clashtyn leid ny reddyn? As v’eh booiagh Eh y akin.

English: 10 ¶And the apostles, when they were returned, told him all that they had done. And he took them, and went aside privately into a desert place belonging to the city called Bethsaida.
Manx: As dinsh ny ostyllyn da, tra v’ad er jeet back, ooilley ny v’ad er n’yannoo. As ghow Eh ad, as hie Eh dy liattee gys boayl er-lheh ayns yn aasagh, va bentyn gys ard-valley va enmyssit Bethsaida.

English: 11 And the people, when they knew it, followed him: and he received them, and spake unto them of the kingdom of God, and healed them that had need of healing.
Manx: As tra hooar y pobble fys er, deiyr ad er: as hug Eh oltaghey-bea daue, as loayr Eh roo jeh reeriaght Yee, as laanee Eh adsyn va feme slaanaghey.

English: 12 And when the day began to wear away, then came the twelve, and said unto him, Send the multitude away, that they may go into the towns and country round about, and lodge, and get victuals: for we are here in a desert place.
Manx: As tra va’n laa faggys ceaut, haink yn daa ostyl yeig as dooyrt ad rish, Cur y pobble ersooyl, dy vod ad goll roue gys ny baljyn as er y cheer mygeayrt, dy gheddyn aaght as beaghey: son ta shin ayns shoh ayns boayl faasagh.

English: 13 But he said unto them, Give ye them to eat. And they said, We have no more but five loaves and two fishes; except we should go and buy meat for all this people.
Manx: Agh dooyrt Eh roo, Cur-jee shiuish bee daue. As dooyrt ad, Cha vel ain agh queig bwilleenyn as daa eeast; mannagh jemmad dy chionnaghey bee son ooilley’n pobble shoh.

English: 14 For they were about five thousand men. And he said to his disciples, Make them sit down by fifties in a company.
Manx: Son v’ad mysh queig thousane dooinney. As dooyrt Eh rish y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er, Cur-jee orroo soie sheese, jeih as da-eed ayns sheshaght.

English: 15 And they did so, and made them all sit down.
Manx: As ren ad shen, as hug ad orroo ooilley soie sheese.

English: 16 Then he took the five loaves and the two fishes, and looking up to heaven, he blessed them, and brake, and gave to the disciples to set before the multitude.
Manx: Eisht ghow Eh ny queig bwilleenyn as y daa eeast, as yeeagh Eh seose gys niau, as vannee Eh, as vrish Eh, as hug Eh ad dauesyn va sheer marish dy hoiaghey roish y pobble.

English: 17 And they did eat, and were all filled: and there was taken up of fragments that remained to them twelve baskets.
Manx: As ren ad ooilley gee, as v’ad er nyn yannoo magh: as hrog ad jeh’n fooillagh daag ad, laane daa vasket jeig.

English: 18 ¶And it came to pass, as he was alone praying, his disciples were with him: and he asked them, saying, Whom say the people that I am?
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, myr v’eh ayns ynnyd er-lheh ec padjer, dy row yn vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er marish: as dênee Eh jeu, gra, Cre ta’n pobble dy ghra my mychione’s, quoi mee?

English: 19 They answering said, John the Baptist; but some say, Elias; and others say, that one of the old prophets is risen again.
Manx: Dreggyr adsyn, as dooyrt ad, Ean Bashtey: agh ta paart gra, Elias: as paart elley, dy vel annane jeh ny shen adeyryn er n’irree reesht.

English: 20 He said unto them, But whom say ye that I am? Peter answering said, The Christ of God.
Manx: Dooyrt eshyn roo, Agh quoi ta shiuish dy ghra mee? Dreggyr Peddyr as dooyrt Eh, Creest Mac Yee.

English: 21 And he straitly charged them, and commanded them to tell no man that thing;
Manx: As hug Eh currym as saarey gyere daue, gyn ad insh shen da dooinney erbee,

English: 22 Saying, The Son of man must suffer many things, and be rejected of the elders and chief priests and scribes, and be slain, and be raised the third day.
Manx: Gra, Shegin da’n Mac dooinney ymmodee dy reddyn y hurranse, as ve beg soit jeh liorish y chanstyr, as ny ard-saggyrtyn, as ny scruderyn, as ve er ny varroo, as girree reesht yn tress laa.

English: 23 ¶And he said to them all, If any man will come after me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross daily, and follow me.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo ooilley, My ta dooinney erbee booiagh geiyrt orryms, lig da Eh hene y obbal, as e chrosh y hroggal gagh laa, as geiyrt orrym.

English: 24 For whosoever will save his life shall lose it: but whosoever will lose his life for my sake, the same shall save it.
Manx: Son quoi-erbee ballish e vioys y hauail, caillee Eh eh: agh quoi-erbee chaillys e vioys er my ghraih’s, sauee Eh shoh eh.

English: 25 For what is a man advantaged, if he gain the whole world, and lose himself, or be cast away?
Manx: Son cre’n vondeish t’ec dooinney, my chosnys Eh yn seihll ooilley, as Eh hene dy ve caillit, ny ceaut ersooyl?

English: 26 For whosoever shall be ashamed of me and of my words, of him shall the Son of man be ashamed, when he shall come in his own glory, and in his Father's, and of the holy angels.
Manx: Son quoi-erbee ghoys nearey roym’s, as roish my ghoan, roishyn nee yn Mac dooinney nearey y ghoaill, tra hig Eh ayns e ghloyr hene, as gloyr e Ayrey, as ny ainlyn casherick.

English: 27 But I tell you of a truth, there be some standing here, which shall not taste of death, till they see the kingdom of God.
Manx: Agh ta mee ginsh diu ayns firrinys, dy vel paart nyn shassoo ayns shoh nagh jean blashtyn er y baase, derrey hee ad reeriaght Yee.

English: 28 ¶And it came to pass about an eight days after these sayings, he took Peter and John and James, and went up into a mountain to pray.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione mygeayrt hoght laa lurg ny raaghyn shoh, dy ghow Eh marish, Peddyr as Ean as Jamys, as dy jagh Eh seose er slieau dy ghoaill padjer.

English: 29 And as he prayed, the fashion of his countenance was altered, and his raiment was white and glistering.
Manx: As myr v’eh guee, va cummey yn eddin echey er ny chaghlaa, as va’n coamrey echey gial as sollys.

English: 30 And, behold, there talked with him two men, which were Moses and Elias:
Manx: As cur-my-ner, va daa ghooinney taggloo rish, ta shen dy ghra Moses as Elias:

English: 31 Who appeared in glory, and spake of his decease which he should accomplish at Jerusalem.
Manx: Haink kionfenish ayns gloyr, as ren loayrt jeh e vaase, as ny v’eh dy hurranse ec Jerusalem.

English: 32 But Peter and they that were with him were heavy with sleep: and when they were awake, they saw his glory, and the two men that stood with him.
Manx: Agh haink cadley trome er Peddyr as orroosyn va marish: as tra v’ad er ghoostey, honnick ad yn ghloyr echey, as y daa ghooinney va nyn shassoo marish.

English: 33 And it came to pass, as they departed from him, Peter said unto Jesus, Master, it is good for us to be here: and let us make three tabernacles; one for thee, and one for Moses, and one for Elias: not knowing what he said.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, myr v’ad goll dy aagail Eh, dy dooyrt Peddyr rish Yeesey, Vainshtyr, te mie er ny son ainyn dy ve ayns shoh; as lig dooin three cabbaneyn y yannoo, cabbane er dty hon’s, as cabbane son Moses, as cabbane son Elias: cha row fys echey cre v’eh dy ghra.

English: 34 While he thus spake, there came a cloud, and overshadowed them: and they feared as they entered into the cloud.
Manx: Choud as v’eh loayrt ny goan shoh, haink bodjal ren scadoo y hilgey harrystoo: as ghow ad aggle, myr va’n bodjal cheet ’moo.

English: 35 And there came a voice out of the cloud, saying, This is my beloved Son: hear him.
Manx: As haink coraa ass y vodjal, gra, Shoh my Vac graihagh; eaisht-jee rish.

English: 36 And when the voice was past, Jesus was found alone. And they kept it close, and told no man in those days any of those things which they had seen.
Manx: As lurg y choraa, va Yeesey er ny gheddyn ny lomarcan: as dreill ad shoh oc hene, as cha dinsh ad da dooinney erbee ayns ny laghyn shen, veg jeh ny reddyn v’ad er vakin.

English: 37 ¶And it came to pass, that on the next day, when they were come down from the hill, much people met him.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione yn nah laa, tra v’ad er jeet neose jeh’n clieau, dy daink ymmodee ny whail.

English: 38 And, behold, a man of the company cried out, saying, Master, I beseech thee, look upon my son: for he is mine only child.
Manx: As cur-my-ner, deïe dooinney jeh’n cheshaght, gra, Vainshtyr, ta mee guee ort jeeagh er my vac, son she my ynrycan liannoo Eh.

English: 39 And, lo, a spirit taketh him, and he suddenly crieth out; and it teareth him that he foameth again, and bruising him hardly departeth from him.
Manx: As cur-my-ner, ta spyrryd dy ghoaill Eh, as ayns y tullogh t’eh geamagh, as t’eh dy heih noon as noall Eh derrey t’eh keshal, as er egin t’eh cheet huggey hene, erreish da y vroo Eh.

English: 40 And I besought thy disciples to cast him out; and they could not.
Manx: As ghuee mee orroosyn ta sheer geiyrt ort ad dy hilgey ass Eh, as cha row ad abyl.

English: 41 And Jesus answering said, O faithless and perverse generation, how long shall I be with you, and suffer you? Bring thy son hither.
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey, gra, O heeloghe vee-chredjuagh as roonagh, caid ta mish dy ve mêriu, as dy hurranse diu? Cur lhiat dty vac ayns shoh?

English: 42 And as he was yet a coming, the devil threw him down, and tare him. And Jesus rebuked the unclean spirit, and healed the child, and delivered him again to his father.
Manx: As choud as v’eh foast cheet, chew yn drogh-spyrryd sheese, as heih Eh noon as noall Eh: agh Yeesey oghsan da’n spyrryd neu-ghlen, as laanee Eh yn liannoo, as livrey Eh Eh reesht gys e ayr.

English: 43 ¶And they were all amazed at the mighty power of God. But while they wondered every one at all things which Jesus did, he said unto his disciples,
Manx: As ghow ad ooilley yindyss mooar jeh pooar niartal Yee: Agh choud as va dy chooilley annane ayns ard imnea mychione dagh nhee va Yeesey er n’yannoo, dooyrt Eh rish y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er,

English: 44 Let these sayings sink down into your ears: for the Son of man shall be delivered into the hands of men.
Manx: Lig da ny raaghyn shoh v’er nyn glashtyn dy gyere lieriu: son bee yn Mac dooinney er ny livrey gys laueyn deiney.

English: 45 But they understood not this saying, and it was hid from them, that they perceived it not: and they feared to ask him of that saying.
Manx: Agh cha hoig ad y raa shoh, as ve kellit vow, nagh dug ad tastey da: as va aggle orroo fênaght jeh mychione yn raa shen.

English: 46 ¶Then there arose a reasoning among them, which of them should be greatest.
Manx: Eisht hie ad dy resooney eddyr ad hene, quoi oc syrjey veagh.

English: 47 And Jesus, perceiving the thought of their heart, took a child, and set him by him,
Manx: As hoig Yeesey smooinaghtyn y chree oc, as ghow Eh liannoo, as hoie Eh Eh liorish.

English: 48 And said unto them, Whosoever shall receive this child in my name receiveth me: and whosoever shall receive me receiveth him that sent me: for he that is least among you all, the same shall be great.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Quoi-erbee nee soiaghey jeh’n liannoo shoh ayns m’ennym’s, t’eh jannoo soiagh jeem’s: as quoi-erbee nee soiaghey jeem’s, t’eh soiaghey jehsyn t’er my choyrt: son eshyn sloo ta nyn mast’ eu ooilley, bee yn fer cheddin mooar.

English: 49 ¶And John answered and said, Master, we saw one casting out devils in thy name; and we forbad him, because he followeth not with us.
Manx: As dreggyr Ean as dooyrt Eh, Vainshtyr, honnick shin fer tilgey magh drogh-spyrrydyn ayns dt’ennym’s; as liett shin Eh, er-yn-oyr nagh vel Eh geiyrt orts mârinyn.

English: 50 And Jesus said unto him, Forbid him not: for he that is not against us is for us.
Manx: As dooyrt Yeesey rish, Ny liett-jee Eh: son, eshyn nagh vel nyn ’oi, t’eh lhien.

English: 51 ¶And it came to pass, when the time was come that he should be received up, he stedfastly set his face to go to Jerusalem,
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, myr va’n traa er jeet dy row Eh dy ve goit seose, dy ghow Eh dy shickyr ayns laue, goll seose, myr va e eddin soit, gys Jerusalem.

English: 52 And sent messengers before his face: and they went, and entered into a village of the Samaritans, to make ready for him.
Manx: As hug Eh chaghteryn magh roish: as jimmee ad roue, as hie ad stiagh ayns balley-beg jeh ny Samaritanee dy yannoo aarloo er e hon.

English: 53 And they did not receive him, because his face was as though he would go to Jerusalem.
Manx: Agh cha dug adsyn oltaghey-bea da, er-yn-oyr dy row Eh goll er e hoshiaght gys Jerusalem.

English: 54 And when his disciples James and John saw this, they said, Lord, wilt thou that we command fire to come down from heaven, and consume them, even as Elias did?
Manx: As tra honnick ny ostyllyn echey Jamys as Ean shoh, dooyrt ad, Hiarn, naïlt shin dy haarey aile dy heet neose veih niau, dy choyrt ad mow, myr ren Elias?

English: 55 But he turned, and rebuked them, and said, Ye know not what manner of spirit ye are of.
Manx: Agh hyndaa Eh, as hug Eh oghsan daue, gra, Cha s’eu cre’n monney dy spyrryd ta shiu jeh.

English: 56 For the Son of man is not come to destroy men’s lives, but to save them. And they went to another village.
Manx: Son cha vel yn Mac dooinney er jeet dy stroie bioys deiney, agh dy nyn sauail. As hie ad roue gys balley-beg elley.

English: 57 ¶And it came to pass, that, as they went in the way, a certain man said unto him, Lord, I will follow thee whithersoever thou goest.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, myr v’ad goll er y raad, dy dooyrt dooinney dy row rish, Hiarn, Eiyryms ort raad erbee dy jeu.

English: 58 And Jesus said unto him, Foxes have holes, and birds of the air have nests; but the Son of man hath not where to lay his head.
Manx: As dooyrt Yeesey rish, Ta tuill ec ny shynnee, as idd ec eeanlee yn aer, agh ec yn Mac dooinney cha vel boayl dy chur e chione ayn.

English: 59 And he said unto another, Follow me. But he said, Lord, suffer me first to go and bury my father.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish fer elley, Eiyr orrym: Agh dooyrt eshyn, Hiarn, cur kied dou hoshiaght goll thie dy oanluckey my ayr.

English: 60 Jesus said unto him, Let the dead bury their dead: but go thou and preach the kingdom of God.
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey rish, Lig da ny merriu nyn merriu y oanluckey; agh gow uss royd as jean reeriaght Yee y phreacheil.

English: 61 And another also said, Lord, I will follow thee; but let me first go bid them farewell, which are at home at my house.
Manx: As dooyrt fer elley myrgeddin rish, Hiarn, Eiyryms ort: agh cur kied dou hoshiaght bannaght y aagail ec y vooinjer t’ec my hie.

English: 62 And Jesus said unto him, No man, having put his hand to the plough, and looking back, is fit for the kingdom of God.
Manx: As dooyrt Yeesey rish, Cha vel dooinney erbee t’er chur e laue gys y cheeaght, as ta jeeaghyn back, fit son reeriaght Yee.
CAB. X.

English: After these things the Lord appointed other seventy also, and sent them two and two before his face into every city and place, whither he himself would come.
Manx: Ny lurg shoh, hug y Chiarn ayns pooar three-feed as jeih elley, as hug Eh ad magh jees as jees roish hene, gys dy chooilley ard-valley as ynnyd, raad v’eh hene dy heet.

English: 2 Therefore said he unto them, The harvest truly is great, but the labourers are few: pray ye therefore the Lord of the harvest, that he would send forth labourers into his harvest.
Manx: Shen-y-fa dooyrt Eh roo, Ta’n fouyr dy jarroo mooar, agh ta ny labreeyn beggan: guee-jee shiuish er-y-fa shen er Chiarn y fouyr, Eh dy chur magh labreeyn gys y fouyr echey.

English: 3 Go your ways: behold, I send you forth as lambs among wolves.
Manx: Immee-jee reue: cur-my-ner, ta mish dyn goyrt shiu magh myr eayin mastey moddee-oaldey.

English: 4 Carry neither purse, nor scrip, nor shoes: and salute no man by the way.
Manx: Ny cur-jee lhieu sporran, ny spagey, ny braagyn: as ny ceau-jee nyn draa ayns goll dy yeeaghyn dooinney erbee er y raad.

English: 5 And into whatsoever house ye enter, first say, Peace be to this house.
Manx: As thie erbee dy jed shiu stiagh ayn, abbyr-jee hoshiaght, Shee dy row gys y thie shoh.

English: 6 And if the son of peace be there, your peace shall rest upon it: if not, it shall turn to you again.
Manx: As my vees mac yn chee ayns shen, nee yn shee eauish tannaghtyn ayn: mannagh vel, chyndaa-ee eh hiu reesht.

English: 7 And in the same house remain, eating and drinking such things as they give: for the labourer is worthy of his hire. Go not from house to house.
Manx: As ayns y thie cheddin fuirree-jee, gee as giu leid as nee ad y choyrt: son ta’n labree feeu e ail. Ny gow-jee veih thie dy thie.

English: 8 And into whatsoever city ye enter, and they receive you, eat such things as are set before you:
Manx: As ard-valley erbee dy jed shiu stiagh ayn, as ad dy oltaghey nyn mea, ee-jee leid as vees soit reue.

English: 9 And heal the sick that are therein, and say unto them, The kingdom of God is come nigh unto you.
Manx: As slaanee-jee yn sleih chingey t’ayn, as abbyr-jee roo, Ta reeriaght Yee er jeet er-gerrey diu.

English: 10 But into whatsoever city ye enter, and they receive you not, go your ways out into the streets of the same, and say,
Manx: Agh ard-valley erbee dy jed shiu stiagh ayn, as gyn ad dy oltaghey nyn mea, gow-jee reue magh ayns ny straadjyn oc, as abbyr-jee,

English: 11 Even the very dust of your city, which cleaveth on us, we do wipe off against you: notwithstanding be ye sure of this, that the kingdom of God is come nigh unto you.
Manx: Eer joan yn ard-valley eu, ta lhiantyn hooin, ta shin dy rubbey jin nyn ’oi eu: ny-yeih, bee-jee shickyr jeh shoh, dy vel reeriaght Yee er jeet er-gerrey diu.

English: 12 But I say unto you, that it shall be more tolerable in that day for Sodom, than for that city.
Manx: Agh ta mish gra riu, dy vow Sodom ny smoo dy foayr ec y laa shen, na yiow yn ard-valley shen.

English: 13 Woe unto thee, Chorazin! woe unto thee, Bethsaida! for if the mighty works had been done in Tyre and Sidon, which have been done in you, they had a great while ago repented, sitting in sackcloth and ashes.
Manx: Smerg dhyts Chorazin, smerg dhyts Vethsaida: son dy beagh ny obbraghyn yindyssagh er ve jeant ayns Tyre as Sidon, t’er ny ve jeant ayn-diuish, veagh ad er ghoaill arrys foddey er dy henney ayns aanrit sack as leoai.

English: 14 But it shall be more tolerable for Tyre and Sidon at the judgment, than for you.
Manx: Agh bee kerraghey s’eddrymmee er ny choyrt er Tyre as Sidon ec y vriwnys, na vees er ny choyrt erriuish.

English: 15 And thou, Capernaum, which art exalted to heaven, shalt be thrust down to hell.
Manx: As uss Capernaum, ta dt’ooashley roshtin gys niau, bee oo er dty hilgey sheese gys niurin.

English: 16 He that heareth you heareth me; and he that despiseth you despiseth me; and he that despiseth me despiseth him that sent me.
Manx: Eshyn eaishtys riuish, t’eh geaishtagh rhym’s: as eshyn ta soiaghey beg jiuish, t’eh soiaghey beg jeem’s: as eshyn ta soiaghey beg jeem’s, t’eh soiaghey beg jehsyn ta er my choyrt.

English: 17 ¶And the seventy returned again with joy, saying, Lord, even the devils are subject unto us through thy name.
Manx: As haink y three-feed as jeih back reesht lesh boggey, gra, Hiarn, ta ny eer drogh-spyrrydyn biallagh dooin, trooid dt’ennym’s.

English: 18 And he said unto them, I beheld Satan as lightning fall from heaven.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Honnick mee Noid ny hanmey, myr tendeil, tuittym veih niau.

English: 19 Behold, I give unto you power to tread on serpents and scorpions, and over all the power of the enemy: and nothing shall by any means hurt you.
Manx: Cur-my-ner, Ta mish coyrt diu pooar dy stampey er ard-nieughyn as scorpionee, as er ooilley pooar yn noid; as cha jean nhee erbee er aght erbee, shiu y ghortaghey.

English: 20 Notwithstanding in this rejoice not, that the spirits are subject unto you; but rather rejoice, because your names are written in heaven.
Manx: Ny-yeih ayns shoh ny gow-jee boggey, dy vel ny spyrrydyn biallagh diu: agh gow-jee boggey smoo, dy vel ny hen’myn eu scruit ayns niau.

English: 21 ¶In that hour Jesus rejoiced in spirit, and said, I thank thee, O Father, Lord of heaven and earth, that thou hast hid these things from the wise and prudent, and hast revealed them unto babes: even so, Father; for so it seemed good in thy sight.
Manx: Ayns yn oor cheddin ghow Yeesey boggey ayns e spyrryd, as dooyrt Eh, Ta mee cur booise dhyt, O Ayr, Hiarn niau as thalloo, dy vel oo er chieltyn ny reddyn shoh vowsyn ta creeney as tushtagh, as dy vel oo er hoilshaghey ad da oikanyn: shen dy jarroo myr te, Ayr, son shen myr ve mie ayns dty hilley’s.

English: 22 All things are delivered to me of my Father: and no man knoweth who the Son is, but the Father; and who the Father is, but the Son, and he to whom the Son will reveal him.
Manx: Ta dy chooilley nhee er ny livrey dooys liorish my Ayr: as cha vel fyss ec annane erbee quoi yn Mac, agh yn Ayr; ny quoi yn Ayr, agh y Mac, as eshyn da nee yn Mac Eh y hoilshaghey.

English: 23 ¶And he turned him unto his disciples, and said privately, Blessed are the eyes which see the things that ye see:
Manx: As hyndaa Eh gys y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er, as dooyrt Eh er-lheh, Bannit ta ny sooyllyn ta fakin ny reddyn ta shiuish dy akin.

English: 24 For I tell you, that many prophets and kings have desired to see those things which ye see, and have not seen them; and to hear those things which ye hear, and have not heard them.
Manx: Son ta mee ginsh diu, dy vel ymmodee phadeyryn as reeaghyn er ve aignagh dy akin ny reddyn shen ta shiuish er vakin, as cha vel ad er vakin ad; as dy chlashtyn ny reddyn ta shiuish dy chlashtyn, as cha vel ad er chlashtyn ad.

English: 25 ¶And, behold, a certain lawyer stood up, and tempted him, saying, Master, what shall I do to inherit eternal life?
Manx: As cur-my-ner, hass fer-ynsee dy row jeh’n leigh seose, er-chee y violaghey Eh, gra, Vainshtyr, cre-neem’s dy vod eiraght y ve aym ayns y vea veayn?

English: 26 He said unto him, What is written in the law? how readest thou?
Manx: Dooyrt eshyn rish, Cre ta scruit ayns y leigh? kys t’ow lhaih?

English: 27 And he answering said, Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy strength, and with all thy mind; and thy neighbour as thyself.
Manx: As dreggyr eshyn as dooyrt Eh, Ver oo graih da’n Chiarn dty Yee lesh ooilley dty chree, as lesh ooilley dt’annym, as lesh ooilley dty niart, as lesh ooilley dt’aigney; as da dty naboo myr dhyt hene.

English: 28 And he said unto him, Thou hast answered right: this do, and thou shalt live.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish, T’ow er n’ansoor dy mie: jean shoh, as yiow yn vea.

English: 29 But he, willing to justify himself, said unto Jesus, And who is my neighbour?
Manx: Agh v’eshyn booiagh Eh hene y heyrey, as dooyrt Eh rish Yeesey, As quoi my naboo?

English: 30 And Jesus answering said, A certain man went down from Jerusalem to Jericho, and fell among thieves, which stripped him of his raiment, and wounded him, and departed, leaving him half dead.
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey, gra, Hie dooinney dy row sheese veih Jerusalem gys Jericho, as huit Eh mastey maarlee, rooisht e choamrey jeh, as woaill Eh, as hie ad rhymboo, erreish daue v’er vaagail Eh lieh-varroo.

English: 31 And by chance there came down a certain priest that way: and when he saw him, he passed by on the other side.
Manx: As trooid taghyrt haink saggyrt dy row sheese y raad shen; as tra honnick Eh Eh, hie Eh shaghey er y derrey hiew jeh.

English: 32 And likewise a Levite, when he was at the place, came and looked on him, and passed by on the other side.
Manx: As myrgeddin Levite, tra v’eh ec yn ynnyd, haink Eh as yeeagh Eh er, as hie Eh shaghey er y cheu elley.

English: 33 But a certain Samaritan, as he journeyed, came where he was: and when he saw him, he had compassion on him,
Manx: Agh haink Samaritan dy row, myr v’eh er e yurnah, raad v’eh: as tra honnick Eh Eh, va chymmey echey er.

English: 34 And went to him, and bound up his wounds, pouring in oil and wine, and set him on his own beast, and brought him to an inn, and took care of him.
Manx: As hie Eh huggey, as chiangle Eh seose ny lottyn echey, deayrtey ayn-doo ooill as feeyn, as hoie Eh Eh er e vaagh hene, as hug Eh lesh Eh gys thie-oast, as ghow Eh kiarrail jeh.

English: 35 And on the morrow when he departed, he took out two pence, and gave them to the host, and said unto him, Take care of him; and whatsoever thou spendest more, when I come again, I will repay thee.
Manx: As laa ny vairagh tra v’eh goll roish, hayrn Eh, as hug Eh daa phing da’n far-thie, as dooyrt Eh rish, Bee kiarralagh jeh; as cre-erbee smoo vaarys oo, eeckym dhyt eh, tra higgym reesht.

English: 36 Which now of these three, thinkest thou, was neighbour unto him that fell among the thieves?
Manx: Quoi nish jeu shoh nyn droor, t’ow uss dy smooinaghtyn, va ny naboo dasyn huit mastey ny maarlee?

English: 37 And he said, He that shewed mercy on him. Then said Jesus unto him, Go, and do thou likewise.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish, Eshyn ren myghin y hoilshaghey er. Eisht dooyrt Yeesey rish, Immee, as jean uss er yn aght cheddin.

English: 38 ¶Now it came to pass, as they went, that he entered into a certain village: and a certain woman named Martha received him into her house.
Manx: Nish haink eh gy kione, myr v’ad goll, dy jagh ad stiagh ayns balley-beg dy row: as ren ben dy row, va enmyssit Martha, e vea y oltaghey gys y thie eck.

English: 39 And she had a sister called Mary, which also sat at Jesus’ feet, and heard his word.
Manx: As va shuyr eck enmyssit Moirrey, hoie myrgeddin ec cassyn Yeesey, clashtyn e ghoo.

English: 40 But Martha was cumbered about much serving, and came to him, and said, Lord, dost thou not care that my sister hath left me to serve alone? bid her therefore that she help me.
Manx: Agh va Martha tooillit lesh y phreïsh vooar v’urree, as haink ee huggey, as dooyrt ee, Hiarn, vel eh gys dt’aigney dy vel my huyr er n’aagail y currym orryms my lomarcan? abbyr ree er-y-fa shen, ee dy chooney lhiam.

English: 41 And Jesus answered and said unto her, Martha, Martha, thou art careful and troubled about many things:
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey, as dooyrt Eh ree, Martha, Martha, t’ow seaghnit ayns dt’aigney, as ta ymmodee reddyn dy dty voirey:

English: 42 But one thing is needful: and Mary hath chosen that good part, which shall not be taken away from her.
Manx: Agh un red ta ymmyrchagh. As ta Moirrey er reih yn ayrn vie shen, nagh bee er ny ghoaill ersooyl voiee.
CAB. XI.

English: And it came to pass, that, as he was praying in a certain place, when he ceased, one of his disciples said unto him, Lord, teach us to pray, as John also taught his disciples.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, myr v’eh ec padjer ayns ynnyd dy row, tra daag Eh jeh, dy dooyrt fer jeusyn va sheer geiyrt er rish, Hiarn, ynsee dooinyn dy ghoaill padjer, myr dynsee Ean myrgeddin da’n vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er.

English: 2 And he said unto them, When ye pray, say, Our Father which art in heaven, Hallowed be thy name. Thy kingdom come. Thy will be done, as in heaven, so in earth.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Tra ghoys shiu padjer, abbyr-jee, Ayr ain t’ayns niau, Casherick dy row dt’ennym. Dy jig dty reeriaght. Dt’aigney dy row jeant er y thalloo, myr te ayns niau.

English: 3 Give us day by day our daily bread.
Manx: Cur dooin laa lurg laa nyn arran gagh laa.

English: 4 And forgive us our sins; for we also forgive every one that is indebted to us. And lead us not into temptation; but deliver us from evil.
Manx: As leih dooin nyn beccaghyn; son ta shinyn myrgeddin leih da dy chooilley annane ta ayns lhiastynys dooin. As ny leeid shin ayns miolagh, agh livrey shin veih olk.

English: 5 And he said unto them, Which of you shall have a friend, and shall go unto him at midnight, and say unto him, Friend, lend me three loaves;
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Quoi eauish vees carrey echey, as hed huggey ec main-oie, as jir rish, Charrey, eeasee dou three bwilleenyn;

English: 6 For a friend of mine in his journey is come to me, and I have nothing to set before him?
Manx: Son ta dooinney-mooinjerey dou va er e yurnah er jeet hym, as cha vel monney aym dy hoiaghey roish:

English: 7 And he from within shall answer and say, Trouble me not: the door is now shut, and my children are with me in bed; I cannot rise and give thee.
Manx: As freggyr-ee eshyn veih cheu-sthie, gra, Ny boir mee: ta’n dorrys nish jeight, as ta my chloan ’sy lhiabbee mârym; cha voddym girree dy chur dhyt.

English: 8 I say unto you, Though he will not rise and give him, because he is his friend, yet because of his importunity he will rise and give him as many as he needeth.
Manx: Ta mee gra riu, Ga nagh nirree Eh dy chur da, er coontey dy nee e charrey eh: ny-yeih kyndagh rish y jeeanid echey, irree Eh as ver Eh da whilleen as vees Eh ny eme.

English: 9 And I say unto you, Ask, and it shall be given you; seek, and ye shall find; knock, and it shall be opened unto you.
Manx: As ta mish gra riuish, Yeearree-jee, as yiow shiu: shir-jee, as nee shiu feddyn: bee-jee aignagh fosley gheddyn, as bee eh er ny osley diu.

English: 10 For every one that asketh receiveth; and he that seeketh findeth; and to him that knocketh it shall be opened.
Manx: Son ta dy chooilley annane ta geearree, geddyn: as y fer ta shirrey, feddyn: as eshyn ta aignagh fosley gheddyn, bee eh er ny osley da.

English: 11 If a son shall ask bread of any of you that is a father, will he give him a stone? or if he ask a fish, will he for a fish give him a serpent?
Manx: My nee mac arran y hirrey er annane eauish ta ny ayr, der Eh clagh da? ny my hirrys Eh eeast, jean Eh ayns ynnyd eeast ard-nieu y chur da?

English: 12 Or if he shall ask an egg, will he offer him a scorpion?
Manx: Ny my hirrys Eh ooh, jeb Eh scorpion da?

English: 13 If ye then, being evil, know how to give good gifts unto your children: how much more shall your heavenly Father give the Holy Spirit to them that ask him?
Manx: My ta toiggal er-y-fa shen eauish, ta olk, kys dy choyrt giootyn mie da nyn gloan; cre woad smoo nee’n Ayr flaunyssagh eu yn Spyrryd Noo y choyrt dauesyn ta jannoo aghin huggey?

English: 14 ¶And he was casting out a devil, and it was dumb. And it came to pass, when the devil was gone out, the dumb spake; and the people wondered.
Manx: As v’eh tilgey magh drogh-spyrryd, as v’eh balloo. As haink eh gy kione, tra va’n drogh-spyrryd er gholl ass, dy loayr y balloo: as ghow yn pobble yindyss.

English: 15 But some of them said, He casteth out devils through Beelzebub the chief of the devils.
Manx: Agh dooyrt paart jeu, She liorish Beelzebub, yn ard drogh-spyrryd, t’eh tilgey magh drogh-spyrrydyn.

English: 16 And others, tempting him, sought of him a sign from heaven.
Manx: As va feallagh elley miolaghey, as shirrey er cowrey veih niau.

English: 17 But he, knowing their thoughts, said unto them, Every kingdom divided against itself is brought to desolation; and a house divided against a house falleth.
Manx: Agh va fys echyssyn er ny smooinaghtyn oc, as dooyrt Eh roo, Ta dy chooilley reeriaght ta girree ny oi hene, er ny choyrt mow: as thie ta ny oi hene, tuittym.

English: 18 If Satan also be divided against himself, how shall his kingdom stand? because ye say that I cast out devils through Beelzebub.
Manx: As my ta’n Jouyl girree magh ny oi hene, kys nee yn reeriaght echey shassoo? er-y-fa dy vel shiu gra, dy nee liorish Beelzebub ta mish tilgey magh drogh-spyrrydyn.

English: 19 And if I by Beelzebub cast out devils, by whom do your sons cast them out? therefore shall they be your judges.
Manx: As my ta mish liorish Beelzebub tilgey magh drogh-spyrrydyn, quoi liorish ta ny meck eu hene dyn dilgey ad magh? adsyn er-y-fa shen vees ny briwnyn eu.

English: 20 But if I with the finger of God cast out devils, no doubt the kingdom of God is come upon you.
Manx: Agh my ta mish lesh mair Yee tilgey magh drogh-spyrrydyn, fegooish dooyt ta reeriaght Yee er jeet erriu.

English: 21 When a strong man armed keepeth his palace, his goods are in peace:
Manx: Tra ta dooinney lajer, ta eïlley er, jeeaghyn da e e hie, ta e chooid sauchey.

English: 22 But when a stronger than he shall come upon him, and overcome him, he taketh from him all his armour wherein he trusted, and divideth his spoils.
Manx: Agh tra ta fer stroshey na Eh soiaghey er, as geddyn yn varriaght, t’eh goaill veih ooilley e eïlley huggey v’eh treishteil, as t’eh reynn e chooid.

English: 23 He that is not with me is against me: and he that gathereth not with me scattereth.
Manx: Eshyn nagh vel lhiam, t’eh m’oi; as eshyn nagh vel chymsaghey mârym, t’eh skeayley.

English: 24 When the unclean spirit is gone out of a man, he walketh through dry places, seeking rest; and finding none, he saith, I will return unto my house whence I came out.
Manx: Tra ta’n spyrryd neu-ghlen er gholl ass dooinney, t’eh shooyl trooid ynnydyn chyrmey, shirrey fea: as tra nagh vel Eh dy gheddyn eh, t’eh gra, Chyndaa-ym gys my hie, ass haink mee.

English: 25 And when he cometh, he findeth it swept and garnished.
Manx: As tra t’eh cheet, t’eh dy gheddyn eh sceabit as soit magh dy stooamey.

English: 26 Then goeth he, and taketh to him seven other spirits more wicked than himself; and they enter in, and dwell there: and the last state of that man is worse than the first.
Manx: Eisht t’eh goll as cur lesh marish shiaght spyrrydyn elley, ny smessey na Eh hene, as t’ad goll stiagh as vaghey ayns shen: as ta’n jerrey ny smessey da’n dooinney shen na’n toshiaght.

English: 27 ¶And it came to pass, as he spake these things, a certain woman of the company lifted up her voice, and said unto him, Blessed is the womb that bare thee, and the paps which thou hast sucked.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, myr v’eh loayrt ny goan shoh, dy hrog ben dy row jeh’n cheshaght e coraa seose, as dy dooyrt ee rish, Bannit ta’n vreïn dymmyrk oo, as ny keeaghyn t’ow er ny yiole.

English: 28 But he said, Yea rather, blessed are they that hear the word of God, and keep it.
Manx: Agh dooyrt eshyn, Bannit dy jarroo t’adsyn ta clashtyn goo Yee, as jannoo ymmyd jeh.

English: 29 ¶And when the people were gathered thick together, he began to say, This is an evil generation: they seek a sign; and there shall no sign be given it, but the sign of Jonas the prophet.
Manx: As tra va’n pobble er nyn jaglym dy choo cooidjagh, ren Eh toshiaght dy ghra, Shoh drogh heeloghe: t’ad shirrey cowrey, as cha bee cowrey er ny choyrt daue, agh cowrey yn phadeyr Jonas.

English: 30 For as Jonas was a sign unto the Ninevites, so shall also the Son of man be to this generation.
Manx: Son myr va Jonas ny chowrey da ny Nineviteyn, myr shen myrgeddin vees yn Mac dooinney da’n cheeloghe shoh.

English: 31 The queen of the south shall rise up in the judgment with the men of this generation, and condemn them: for she came from the utmost parts of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon; and, behold, a greater than Solomon is here.
Manx: Nee ben-reïn y jass girree seose ayns briwnys noi deiney yn cheeloghe shoh, as ad y gheyrey: son haink ish veih ny ardjyn sodjey er y thalloo dy eaishtagh rish creenaght Solomon; as cur-my-ner, ta fer syrjey na Solomon ayns shoh.

English: 32 The men of Nineve shall rise up in the judgment with this generation, and shall condemn it: for they repented at the preaching of Jonas; and, behold, a greater than Jonas is here.
Manx: Nee deiney Nineveh girree seose ayns briwnys, as y cheeloghe shoh y gheyrey: son ghow adsyn arrys ec preacheil Jonas; as cur-my-ner, ta fer syrjey na Jonas ayns shoh.

English: 33 No man, when he hath lighted a candle, putteth it in a secret place, neither under a bushel, but on a candlestick, that they which come in may see the light.
Manx: Cha vel dooinney erbee, tra t’eh er voddey kainle, dy choyrt ee ayns ynnyd follit, ny fo saagh; agh ayns kainlere, dy vod adsyn ta cheet stiagh yn soilshey y akin.

English: 34 The light of the body is the eye: therefore when thine eye is single, thy whole body also is full of light; but when thine eye is evil, thy body also is full of darkness.
Manx: Yn tooyl ta cur soilshey da’n chorp: shen-y-fa tra ta dty hooyl fegooish foill, ta soilshey ec ooilley dty chorp: agh tra ta foil ayns dty hooyl, ta dty chorp myrgeddin ayns dorraghys.

English: 35 Take heed therefore that the light which is in thee be not darkness.
Manx: Cur twoaie er-y-fa shen nagh nee dorraghys yn soilshey ta aynyd.

English: 36 If thy whole body therefore be full of light, having no part dark, the whole shall be full of light, as when the bright shining of a candle doth give thee light.
Manx: My ta soilshey er-y-fa shen ec ooilley dty chorp, fegooish ayrn erbee dy ve ayns dorraghys, bee oo ooilley ayns soilshey, myr t’ow, tra ta soilshey sollys ayd veih kainle.

English: 37 ¶And as he spake, a certain Pharisee besought him to dine with him: and he went in, and sat down to meat.
Manx: As myr v’eh loayrt, chuir Pharisee dy row Eh gys jinnair marish: as hie Eh stiagh, as hoie Eh sheese gys bee.

English: 38 And when the Pharisee saw it, he marvelled that he had not first washed before dinner.
Manx: As tra honnick yn Pharisee shoh, ghow Eh yindyss nagh ren Eh Eh hene y niee roish jinnair.

English: 39 And the Lord said unto him, Now do ye Pharisees make clean the outside of the cup and the platter; but your inward part is full of ravening and wickedness.
Manx: As dooyrt y Chiarn rish, Nish ta shiuish Phariseeyn glenney yn cappan as y claare er cheu-mooie: agh ta’n cheu-sthie eu laane dy hranlaase as dy olkys.

English: 40 Ye fools, did not he that made that which is without make that which is within also?
Manx: Gheiney vee-cheealagh, nagh nee eshyn ren y cheu-mooie, ren y cheu-sthie myrgeddin?

English: 41 But rather give alms of such things as ye have; and, behold, all things are clean unto you.
Manx: Agh cur-jee leid as t’eu da ny boghtyn: as cur-my-ner, bee dy chooilley nhee glen diu.

English: 42 But woe unto you, Pharisees! for ye tithe mint and rue and all manner of herbs, and pass over judgment and the love of God: these ought ye to have done, and not to leave the other undone.
Manx: Agh smerg diuish Phariseeyn: son ta shiu geeck jaghee jeh myndey, rue, as dy chooilley sorch dy lossyreeyn, as cha vel shiu cooilleeney briwnys as graih Yee: ad shoh lhisagh shiu v’er n’yannoo, fegooish y chooid elley y aagail gyn jannoo.

English: 43 Woe unto you, Pharisees! for ye love the uppermost seats in the synagogues, and greetings in the markets.
Manx: Smerg diuish Phariseeyn: son shynney lhieu ny ard-stuill ayns ny kialteenyn, as sleih dy vannaghey diu ayns ny margaghyn.

English: 44 Woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! for ye are as graves which appear not, and the men that walk over them are not aware of them.
Manx: Smerg diu scruderyn as Phariseeyn, chrauee-oalsey: son ta shiu goll-rish oaiaghyn nagh vel er nyn vakin, as ny deiney ta shooyl harrystoo, cha vel fys oc dy vel ad ayn.

English: 45 ¶Then answered one of the lawyers, and said unto him, Master, thus saying thou reproachest us also.
Manx: Eisht dreggyr fer jeh fir-ynsee yn leigh, as dooyrt Eh rish, Vainshtyr, liorish shen y ghra, t’ow cur scammylt dooinyn myrgeddin.

English: 46 And he said, Woe unto you also, ye lawyers! for ye lade men with burdens grievous to be borne, and ye yourselves touch not the burdens with one of your fingers.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Smerg diuish neesht fir-ynsee yn leigh: son ta shiu laadey deiney lesh erraghyn doillee dy ve er nyn ymmyrkey, as cha vel shiu hene bennaylt rish ny erraghyn lesh annane jeh ny meïr eu.

English: 47 Woe unto you! for ye build the sepulchres of the prophets, and your fathers killed them.
Manx: Smerg diu: son ta shiu troggal oaiaghyn ny phadeyryn, as ny ayraghyn eu ren y varroo ad.

English: 48 Truly ye bear witness that ye allow the deeds of your fathers: for they indeed killed them, and ye build their sepulchres.
Manx: Dy firrinagh ta shiu gymmyrkey feanish dy vel shiu lowal jeh jannoo ny ayraghyn eu: son ren adsyn dy jarroo y varroo ad, as ta shiuish troggal ny oaiaghyn oc.

English: 49 Therefore also said the wisdom of God, I will send them prophets and apostles, and some of them they shall slay and persecute:
Manx: As shoh yn oyr ta creenaght Yee er ghra, Verrym huc phadeyryn as ostyllyn, as paart jeu nee ad y varroo, as tranlaase y yannoo orroo:

English: 50 That the blood of all the prophets, which was shed from the foundation of the world, may be required of this generation;
Manx: Dy vod fuill ooilley ny phadeyryn, v’er ny gheayrtey er dy hoshiaght y theihll, ve er ny chooilleeney er y cheeloghe shoh;

English: 51 From the blood of Abel unto the blood of Zacharias which perished between the altar and the temple: verily I say unto you, It shall be required of this generation.
Manx: Veih fuill Abel gys fuill Zacharias, ren cherraghtyn eddyr yn altar as y chiamble: dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy bee eh er ny chooilleeney er y cheeloghe shoh.

English: 52 Woe unto you, lawyers! for ye have taken away the key of knowledge: ye entered not in yourselves, and them that were entering in ye hindered.
Manx: Smerg diu fir-ynsee yn leigh: son ta shiu er ghoaill ersooyl ogher yn ysseree: cha jagh shiu stiagh shiu hene, as adsyn va goll stiagh, ren shiu y liettal.

English: 53 And as he said these things unto them, the scribes and the Pharisees began to urge him vehemently, and to provoke him to speak of many things:
Manx: As tra v’eh er ghra ny reddyn shoh roo, ren ny scruderyn as ny Phariseeyn toshiaght dy eaginaghey, as dy ghreinnaghey Eh dy loayrt jeh ymmodee reddyn:

English: 54 Laying wait for him, and seeking to catch something out of his mouth, that they might accuse him.
Manx: Soiaghey ribbaghyn er e hon, as shirrey red ennagh y hayrtyn ass e veeal, dy voddagh oyr y ve oc dy phlaint er.
CAB. XII.
CAB. XII.

English: In the mean time, when there were gathered together an innumerable multitude of people, insomuch that they trode one upon another, he began to say unto his disciples first of all, Beware ye of the leaven of the Pharisees, which is hypocrisy.
Manx: Nish tra va ymmodee er-skyn earroo dy leih er nyn jaglym cooidjagh, ayns wheesh as dy stamp ad yn derrey yeh er yn jeh elley, ren Eh toshiaght dy ghra rish y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er hoshiaght ooilley, Cur-jee twoaie jeh soorit ny Phariseeyn, she craueeaght oalsey eh.

English: 2 For there is nothing covered, that shall not be revealed; neither hid, that shall not be known.
Manx: Son cha vel nhee erbee follit nagh jig gys soilshey ; ny kellit, nagh jig magh.

English: 3 Therefore whatsoever ye have spoken in darkness shall be heard in the light; and that which ye have spoken in the ear in closets shall be proclaimed upon the housetops.
Manx: Shen-y-fa cre-erbee ta shiuish er loayrt ayns y dorraghys, bee eh er ny chlashtyn ayns y toilshey : as shen ta shiu er livrey ayns sonnishyn ayns shamyryn, bee eh er ny ockley magh er mullagh ny thieyn.

English: 4 And I say unto you my friends, Be not afraid of them that kill the body, and after that have no more that they can do.
Manx: As ta mee gra riuish, my chaarjyn, Ny bee-jee agglagh rouesyn varrys y corp, as ny lurg shen nagh vel arragh oc oddys ad y yannoo.

English: 5 But I will forewarn you whom ye shall fear: Fear him, which after he hath killed hath power to cast into hell; yea, I say unto you, Fear him.
Manx: Agh soilshee-yms diu quoi roish ghoys shiu aggle : Gow-jee aggle roishyn, echey ta pooar, erreish da v’er varroo, dy hilgey ayns niurin ; shen ta mish dy ghra riu, Gow-jee aggle roishyn.

English: 6 Are not five sparrows sold for two farthings, and not one of them is forgotten before God?
Manx: Nagh vel queig sperriu er nyn greck son daa farling, as cha vel annane oc jarroodit kiongoyrt rish Jee?

English: 7 But even the very hairs of your head are all numbered. Fear not therefore: ye are of more value than many sparrows.
Manx: Agh ta eer renaigyn nyn ghing ooilley er nyn earroo. Ny gow-jee aggle er-y-fa shen : ta ny smoo dy ve soit jiuish, na jeh ymmodee sperriu.

English: 8 Also I say unto you, Whosoever shall confess me before men, him shall the Son of man also confess before the angels of God:
Manx: Myrgeddin ta mee gra riu, Quoi-erbee ghoys rhym’s kiongoyrt rish deiney, nee yn Mac dooinney myrgeddin goaill rishyn kiongoyrt rish ainlyn Yee.

English: 9 But he that denieth me before men shall be denied before the angels of God.
Manx: Agh bee eshyn obbys mish kiongoyrt rish deiney, er ny obbal kiongoyrt ainlyn Yee.

English: 10 And whosoever shall speak a word against the Son of man, it shall be forgiven him: but unto him that blasphemeth against the Holy Ghost it shall not be forgiven.
Manx: As quoi-erbee loayrys fockle noi yn Mac dooinney, bee eh er ny leih da : agh dasyn ta loayrt goan-mollaghtagh noi yn Spyrryd Noo, cha bee eh er ny leih.

English: 11 And when they bring you unto the synagogues, and unto magistrates, and powers, take ye no thought how or what thing ye shall answer, or what ye shall say:
Manx: As tra ver ad lhieu shiu gys ny quaiyllyn, as gys fir-reïl as pooaraghyn, ny bee-jee imneagh kys ny cre nee shiu y reggyrt, ny cre nee shiu y ghra :

English: 12 For the Holy Ghost shall teach you in the same hour what ye ought to say.
Manx: Son ynsee yn Spyrryd Noo diu, ayns yn oor cheddin cre lhisagh shiu y ghra.

English: 13 ¶And one of the company said unto him, Master, speak to my brother, that he divide the inheritance with me.
Manx: As dooyrt fer jeh’n cheshaght rish, Vainshtyr, loayr rish my vraar Eh dy reynn yn eiraght rhym?

English: 14 And he said unto him, Man, who made me a judge or a divider over you?
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish, Ghooinney, quoi t’er my hoiaghey’s seose dy vriwnys, ny dy reynn nyn mast’ eu?

English: 15 And he said unto them, Take heed, and beware of covetousness: for a man’s life consisteth not in the abundance of the things which he possesseth.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, gow-jee tastey, as cur-jee twoaie jeh saynt : son cha vel dooinney er ny reaylley bio liorish palchey mooar e chooid.

English: 16 And he spake a parable unto them, saying, The ground of a certain rich man brought forth plentifully:
Manx: As loayr Eh coraa-dorraghey roo, gra, Ren thalloo dooinney berchagh dy row mess y chur magh dy palchey.

English: 17 And he thought within himself, saying, What shall I do, because I have no room where to bestow my fruits?
Manx: As smooinee Eh rish hene, gra, Cre nee’m, tra nagh vel boayl aym dy hashtey seose my vess ayn?

English: 19 And he said, This will I do: I will pull down my barns, and build greater; and there will I bestow all my fruits and my goods.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Shoh nee’m y yannoo: Lieggym my hoaltyn, as troggym soaltyn smoo ; as ayns shen nee’m ooilley my vess as my chooid y hashtey.

English: 19 And I will say to my soul, Soul, thou hast much goods laid up for many years; take thine ease, eat, drink, and be merry.
Manx: As jirrrym rish m’annym, Annym, ta ymmodee cooid ayd tashtit seose son ymmodee bleeantyn ; gow dt’aash, ee, iu, as bee gennal.

English: 20 But God said unto him, Thou fool, this night thy soul shall be required of thee: then whose shall those things be, which thou hast provided?
Manx: Agh dooyrt Jee rish, Uss ommydan, yn oie noght vees dt’annym er ny ghoaill woid : quoi lesh eisht vees ny reddyn shen t’ow uss er hilgey nyn gouyr?

English: 21 So is he that layeth up treasure for himself, and is not rich toward God.
Manx: Myr shoh ta eshyn ta tashtey seose berchys er e hon hene, as nagh vel berchagh fenish Jee.

English: 22 ¶And he said unto his disciples, Therefore I say unto you, Take no thought for your life, what ye shall eat; neither for the body, what ye shall put on.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er, Shen-y-fa ta mish gra riuish, Ny bee-jee imneagh son nyn mea, cre nee shiu y ee ; ny son nyn girp, cre ver shiu miu.

English: 23 The life is more than meat, and the body is more than raiment.
Manx: Ta’n vea ny smoo dy ve soit jeh na beaghey, as y corp na coamrey.

English: 24 Consider the ravens: for they neither sow nor reap; which neither have storehouse nor barn; and God feedeth them: how much more are ye better than the fowls?
Manx: Smooinee-jee er ny fee : son cha vel ad cuirr, ny buinn; cha vel thie-stoyr ny soalt oc, as ta Jee dyn meag[h]ey ad : As nagh vel shiuish foddey share na ny eeanlee?

English: 25 And which of you with taking thought can add to his stature one cubit?
Manx: Quoi eauish liorish ve imneagh oddys un chraue-roih y chur dys yn aase echey?

English: 26 If ye then be not able to do that thing which is least, why take ye thought for the rest?
Manx: Mannagh vel shiuish abyl eisht yn red sloo y yannoo, cre’n-fa ta shiu imneagh son y chooid elley?

English: 27 Consider the lilies how they grow: they toil not, they spin not; and yet I say unto you, that Solomon in all his glory was not arrayed like one of these.
Manx: Gow-jee eu hene kys ta ny lilleeyn gaase ; cha vel ad laboraght, cha vel ad sneeu : as foast ta mee gra riu, nagh row Solomon ayns ooilley e ghloyr er ny choamrey myr annane jeu shoh.

English: 28 If then God so clothe the grass, which is to day in the field, and to morrow is cast into the oven; how much more will he clothe you, O ye of little faith?
Manx: My ta Jee eisht myr shoh coamrey’n faiyr, ta jiu ’sy vagher, as mairagh ceaut stiagh ayns yn oghe : nagh jean Eh foddey smoo er nyn son eauish, O gheiney faase-chredjuagh?

English: 29 And seek not ye what ye shall eat, or what ye shall drink, neither be ye of doubtful mind.
Manx: As ny shir-jee cre ee-ys, ny cre iu-ys shiu, as ny bee-jee roa imneagh.

English: 30 For all these things do the nations of the world seek after: and your Father knoweth that ye have need of these things.
Manx: Son ooilley ny reddyn shoh ta ashoonyn y theihll briaght er nyn son : as ta fys ec yn Ayr eu dy vel feme eu er ny reddyn shoh.

English: 31 ¶But rather seek ye the kingdom of God; and all these things shall be added unto you.
Manx: Agh shir-jee hoshiaght reeriaght Yee, as bee shiu jeant magh lesh ooilley ny reddyn shoh.

English: 32 Fear not, little flock; for it is your Father’s good pleasure to give you the kingdom.
Manx: Ny gow-jee aggle, hioltane veg ; son she aigney mie nyn Ayr eh, dy chur diu yn reeriaght.

English: 33 Sell that ye have, and give alms; provide yourselves bags which wax not old, a treasure in the heavens that faileth not, where no thief approacheth, neither moth corrupteth.
Manx: Creck-jee, as cur-jee ny t’eu da ny boghtyn : kiare-jee er ny son eu hene sporranyn nagh naase shen, berchys ayns ny niaughyn nagh vel failleil, raad nagh vel y maarlagh cheet er-gerrey, ny’n lhemeen cur mow.

English: 34 For where your treasure is, there will your heart be also.
Manx: Son raad vees nyn stoyr, ayns shen vees y cree eu myrgeddin.

English: 35 Let your loins be girded about, and your lights burning;
Manx: Lhig da ny meeghyn eu ve soïllit, as ny kainlyn eu foddit ;

English: 36 And ye yourselves like unto men that wait for their lord, when he will return from the wedding; that when he cometh and knocketh, they may open unto him immediately.
Manx: As shiu hene goll-rish deiney ta farkiagh son cheet thie nyn Jiarn veih’n vannish, ec y cheet echey tra nee Eh cronckal dy vod ad fosley da chelleeragh.

English: 37 Blessed are those servants, whom the lord when he cometh shall find watching: verily I say unto you, that he shall gird himself, and make them to sit down to meat, and will come forth and serve them.
Manx: Bannit ta ny sharvaantyn shen yiow yn Chiarn er nyn dwoaie ec y cheet echey : dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, dy gainle Eh e gharmad mysh, as dy der Eh orroo soie sheese gys bee, as dy jig Eh magh dy hirveish orroo.

English: 38 And if he shall come in the second watch, or come in the third watch, and find them so, blessed are those servants.
Manx: As my hig Eh ayns yn nah ghoostey, ny my hig Eh ayns y tress ghoostey, as ad y gheddyn myr shen, bannit ta ny sharvaantyn shen.

English: 39 And this know, that if the goodman of the house had known what hour the thief would come, he would have watched, and not have suffered his house to be broken through.
Manx: As shoh toig-jee, dy beagh fys er ve ec mainshtyr y thie cre’n oor veagh y maarlaght er jeet, veagh Eh er ve er e arrey, as cha beagh Eh er lhiggey da e hie v’er ny vrishey stiagh.

English: 40 Be ye therefore ready also: for the Son of man cometh at an hour when ye think not.
Manx: Bee-jee shiuish myrgeddin er-y-fa shen aarloo : son hig yn Mac dooinney ec oor nagh vel shiu smooinaghtyn er.

English: 41 ¶Then Peter said unto him, Lord, speakest thou this parable unto us, or even to all?
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Peddyr rish, Hiarn, nee rooinyn t’ow loayrt yn coraa dorraghey shoh, ny myrgeddin rish dy chooilley annane?

English: 42 And the Lord said, Who then is that faithful and wise steward, whom his lord shall make ruler over his household, to give them their portion of meat in due season?
Manx: As dooyrt y Chiarn, Quoi eisht yn stiurt firrinagh as creeney shen nee e hiarn y yannoo ny er-reil er lught e hie, dy howse magh nyn meaghey daue ayns traa cooie?

English: 43 Blessed is that servant, whom his lord when he cometh shall find so doing.
Manx: Bannit ta’n charvaant shen, yiow e hiarn jannoo myr shen, ec y cheet echey.

English: 44 Of a truth I say unto you, that he will make him ruler over all that he hath.
Manx: Ayns firrinys ta mee gra riu, dy livrey Eh gys y churrymechey ooilley e chooid.

English: 45 But and if that servant say in his heart, My lord delayeth his coming; and shall begin to beat the menservants and maidens, and to eat and drink, and to be drunken;
Manx: Agh my nee yn charvaant shen gra ayns e chree, Ta my hiarn lhiggey-shaghey yn cheet echey; as toshiaght y yannoo dy woalley ny fir-vooinjerey, as ny inneenyn-veyll, as dy ee as dy iu, as dy ve er-meshtey :

English: 46 The lord of that servant will come in a day when he looketh not for him, and at an hour when he is not aware, and will cut him in sunder, and will appoint him his portion with the unbelievers.
Manx: Hig chiarn y charvaant shen ec laa nagh bee Eh jeeaghyn er e hon, as ayns oor nagh bee eh twoaiagh jeh, as giaree Eh Eh veih my chielley, as pointee Eh e chronney marish y vooinjer vee-chredjuagh.

English: 47 And that servant, which knew his lord's will, and prepared not himself, neither did according to his will, shall be beaten with many stripes.
Manx: As y charvaant shen va toiggal aigney e hiarn, as nagh dooar Eh hene aarloo, as nagh ren cordail rish e aigney, mooar vees y kerraghey echey.

English: 48 But he that knew not, and did commit things worthy of stripes, shall be beaten with few stripes. For unto whomsoever much is given, of him shall be much required: and to whom men have committed much, of him they will ask the more.
Manx: Agh eshyn nagh row toiggal, as ren reddyn y yannoo va toilchin kerraghey, cha bee yn kerraghey echey mooar. Son da quoi-erbee ta mooarane er ny choyrt, ersyn vees mooarane er ny hirrey : as eshyn ta lane er ny chur gys e churrym, ersyn smoo vees dy choyrt.

English: 49 I am come to send fire on the earth; and what will I, if it be already kindled?
Manx: Haink mish dy chur aile er y thalloo, as cre baillym, my te hannah er lossey?

English: 50 But I have a baptism to be baptized with; and how am I straitened till it be accomplished
Manx: Agh ta bashtey ayms dy ve er my vashtey lesh, as cre cha neu-aashagh as ta mee, derrey vees eh cooilleenit?

English: 51 Suppose ye that I am come to give peace on earth? I tell you, Nay; but rather division:
Manx: Vel shiu smooinaghtyn dy daink mish dy chur shee er y thalloo? Cha nee shee, ta mee gra riu hug mee lhiam, agh streeu.

English: 52 For from henceforth there shall be five in one house divided, three against two, and two against three.
Manx: Son veih shoh magh bee queig ayns un thie noi ry hoi, three noi jees, as jees noi three.

English: 53 The father shall be divided against the son, and the son against the father; the mother against the daughter, and the daughter against the mother; the mother in law against her daughter in law, and the daughter in law against her mother in law.
Manx: Bee yn ayr noi yn mac, as y mac noi yn ayr; yn voir noi yn inneen, as yn inneen noi yn voir ; yn voir ’sy leigh, noi e ben-chlewn, as y ven-chlewn noi e moir ’sy leigh.

English: 54 ¶And he said also to the people, When ye see a cloud rise out of the west, straightway ye say, There cometh a shower; and so it is.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh myrgeddin rish y pobble, Tra ta shiu fakin bodjal girree ass y sheear, chelleeragh ta shiu gra, Ta frass cheet; as shen myr te.

English: 55 And when ye see the south wind blow, ye say, There will be heat; and it cometh to pass.
Manx: As tra ta’n gheay-jass sheidey, ta shiu gra, Bee chiass ayn, as te cheet gy kione.

English: 56 Ye hypocrites, ye can discern the face of the sky and of the earth; but how is it that ye do not discern this time?
Manx: Chrauee-oalsey, ta shiu abyl tastey y choyrt da neeal yn aer as y thalloo : agh kys nagh vel shiu cur tastey da’n earish shoh?

English: 57 Yea, and why even of yourselves judge ye not what is right?
Manx: Dy jarroo, as cre’n-oyr myrgeddin nagh vel shiu jiu hene briwnys shen ny ta cairagh?

English: 58 ¶When thou goest with thine adversary to the magistrate, as thou art in the way, give diligence that thou mayest be delivered from him; lest he hale thee to the judge, and the judge deliver thee to the officer, and the officer cast thee into prison.
Manx: Tra t’ow goll marishyn ta streeu rhyt fenish yn fer-reïl, jean ny oddys oo er y raad dy gheddyn rea rish ; er aggle dy dayrn Eh lesh oo gys y vriw, as dy livrey yn briw huggeysyn ta goaill kerraghey, as dy dilg Eh shen oo ayns pryssoon.

English: 59 I tell thee, thou shalt not depart thence, till thou hast paid the very last mite.
Manx: Ta mee ginsh dhyt, nagh jeu magh ass shen derrey vees oo erreish yn mite sodjey magh y eeck
CAB. XIII.

English: There were present at that season some that told him of the Galilaeans, whose blood Pilate had mingled with their sacrifices.
Manx: Va kionfenish ec y traa shen, paart dinsh da mychione ny Galileanee, yn uill oc va Pilate er gheayrtey kione ny ourallyn oc.

English: 2 And Jesus answering said unto them, Suppose ye that these Galilaeans were sinners above all the Galilaeans, because they suffered such things?
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh roo, Vel shiu sheiltyn dy row ny Galileanee shoh nyn beccee erskyn ooilley ny Galileanee, er-y-fa dy duillee ad lheid y baase?

English: 3 I tell you, Nay: but, except ye repent, ye shall all likewise perish.
Manx: Ta mee ginsh diu, Nagh row : agh mannagh gow shiuish arrys, nee shiu ooilley myrgeddin cherraghtyn.

English: 4 Or those eighteen, upon whom the tower in Siloam fell, and slew them, think ye that they were sinners above all men that dwelt in Jerusalem?
Manx: Ny yn hoght-jeig shen, orroo ren yn toor ayns Siloam tuittym, as ad y varroo, vel shiu smooinaghtyn dy row ad nyn beccee erskyn ooilley ny deiney va vaghey ec Jerusalem?

English: 5 I tell you, Nay: but, except ye repent, ye shall all likewise perish.
Manx: Ta mee ginsh diu, Nagh row : agh mannagh gow shiuish arrys, nee shiu ooilley myrgeddin cherraghtyn.

English: 5 ¶He spake also this parable; A certain man had a fig tree planted in his vineyard; and he came and sought fruit thereon, and found none.
Manx: Loayr Eh myrgeddin yn coraa-dorraghey shoh : va dooinney dy row va billey-figgagh echey soit ayns e gharey-feeney, as haink Eh dy yeeaghyn row mess er, as cha dooar Eh veg.

English: 7 Then said he unto the dresser of his vineyard, Behold, these three years I come seeking fruit on this fig tree, and find none: cut it down; why cumbereth it the ground?
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Eh rishyn va currym y gharey-feeney er, Cur-my-ner, ny three bleeaney shoh ta mee er jeet dy yeeaghyn voïn mess er y villey figgagh shoh, as cha vel mee geddyn veg : giare sheese eh, cre’n vondeish ta jeh’n thalloo choud as te ayn?

English: 8 And he answering said unto him, Lord, let it alone this year also, till I shall dig about it, and dung it:
Manx: As dreggyr eshyn as dooyrt Eh rish, Hiarn, lig da shassoo bleïn elley, derrey neem’s reurey mygeayrt y mysh, as y eoyllaghey eh.

English: 9 And if it bear fruit, well: and if not, then after that thou shalt cut it down.
Manx: As my nee eh mess y ymmyrkey, smie shen : as mannagh jean, foddee oo ny lurg shen y yiarey sheese eh.

English: 10 And he was teaching in one of the synagogues on the sabbath.
Manx: As v’eh gynsaghey ayns annane jeh ny kialteenyn er y doonaght.

English: 11 ¶And, behold, there was a woman which had a spirit of infirmity eighteen years, and was bowed together, and could in no wise lift up herself.
Manx: As cur-my-ner, va ben va spyrryd dy ghoghan er ve eck rish hoght bleeaney jeig, as v’ee crybbit dy cheiley, as cha dod ee er aght erbee ee hene y yeeraghey.

English: 12 And when Jesus saw her, he called her to him, and said unto her, Woman, thou art loosed from thine infirmity.
Manx: As tra honnick Yeesey ee, deïe Eh urree huggey, as dooyrt Eh ree, Ven, t’ow er d[t]y eaysley veih dty ghoghan.

English: 13 And he laid his hands on her: and immediately she was made straight, and glorified God.
Manx: As hug Eh e laueyn urree ; as chelleeragh v’ee er ny yannoo jeeragh, as hug ee gloyr da Jee.

English: 14 And the ruler of the synagogue answered with indignation, because that Jesus had healed on the sabbath day, and said unto the people, There are six days in which men ought to work: in them therefore come and be healed, and not on the sabbath day.
Manx: As dreggyr fer-reïl ny killagh lesh jymmoose, er-yn-oyr dy row Yeesey er lheihys er laa yn doonaght, as dooyrt Eh rish y pobble, Ta shey laa ayn ry hoi gobbraghey : er ny laghyn shen er-y-fa shen tar-jee dy ve er nyn lheihys, as cha nee er laa’n doonaght.

English: 15 The Lord then answered him, and said, Thou hypocrite, doth not each one of you on the sabbath loose his ox or his ass from the stall, and lead him away to watering?
Manx: Eisht dreggyr yn Chiarn Eh, gra, Er-crauee-oalsey, nagh vel dagh annane eauish er y doonaght feaysley e ghow ny e assyl veih’n vanjoor, as dy chur lhieu magh dy ushtaghey eh?

English: 16 And ought not this woman, being a daughter of Abraham, whom Satan hath bound, lo, these eighteen years, be loosed from this bond on the sabbath day?
Manx: As nagh lhisagh y ven shoh ta ny hinneen da Abraham, ee ta’n Noid-anmey er chiangley, cur-my-ner ny hoght bleeaney jeig shoh, ve er ny eaysley veih yn vondiaght shoh er laa’n doonaght?

English: 17 And when he had said these things, all his adversaries were ashamed: and all the people rejoiced for all the glorious things that were done by him.
Manx: As tra v’eh er loayrt ny goan shoh, ghow ooilley e noidyn nearey : agh ooilley yn pobble ren boggey ghoaill son ooilley ny reddyn gloyroil va jeant liorish.

English: 18 ¶Then said he, Unto what is the kingdom of God like? and whereunto shall I resemble it?
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Eh, Cre rish ta reeriaght Yee goll? as cre gys nee’m y hoyllaghey eh?

English: 19 It is like a grain of mustard seed, which a man took, and cast into his garden; and it grew, and waxed a great tree; and the fowls of the air lodged in the branches of it.
Manx: Te goll-rish greine dy rass mustard, ren dooinney y ghoaill, as y hilgey ayns e gharey, as daase eh, as haink eh dy ve ny villey vooar : as ren eeanlee yn aer fastee y ghoaill ayns ny banglaneyn echey.

English: 20 And again he said, Whereunto shall I liken the kingdom of God?
Manx: As reesht dooyrt Eh, Cre gys nee’m reeriaght Yee y hoyllaghey?

English: 21 It is like leaven, which a woman took and hid in three measures of meal, till the whole was leavened.
Manx: Te goll-rish soorit, ren ben y ghoaill as y ollaghey ayns three towseyn dy veinn, derrey ve ooilley soor.

English: 22 And he went through the cities and villages, teaching, and journeying toward Jerusalem.
Manx: As hie Eh magh trooid ny ard-valjyn as ny baljyn-beggey, gynsaghey as goll er e hoshiaght gys Jerusalem.

English: 23 Then said one unto him, Lord, are there few that be saved? And he said unto them,
Manx: Eisht dooyrt fer rish, Hiarn, nee beggan ta er nyn sauail? As dooyrt eh roo.

English: 24 ¶Strive to enter in at the strait gate: for many, I say unto you, will seek to enter in, and shall not be able.
Manx: Streeu-jee dy gholl stiagh er y yiat coon : son ymmodee, ta mee gra riu, hirrys goll stiagh, as nagh bee abyl.

English: 25 When once the master of the house is risen up, and hath shut to the door, and ye begin to stand without, and to knock at the door, saying, Lord, Lord, open unto us; and he shall answer and say unto you, I know you not whence ye are:
Manx: Un cheayrt dy bee mainshtyr y thie er n’irree, as y dorrys er ny yeigh, as dy jean shiuish toshiaght dy hassoo er cheu-mooie, as dy chronckal ec y dorrys, gra, Hiarn, Hiarn, foshil dooin ; as freggyr-ee eshyn as jir Eh riu, Cha vel mee goaill riu, cre voish ta shiu :

English: 26 Then shall ye begin to say, We have eaten and drunk in thy presence, and thou hast taught in our streets.
Manx: Eisht nee shiu toshiaght dy ghra, Ta shin er n’ee as er n’iu ayns dt’enish, as t’ow er n’ynsaghey ayns ny straadjyn ain.

English: 27 But he shall say, I tell you, I know you not whence ye are; depart from me, all ye workers of iniquity.
Manx: Agh jir eshyn, Ta mee ginsh diu, nagh vel mee goaill riu, cre voish ta shiu ; immee-jee voym ooilley shiuish ghrogh-yantee.

English: 28 There shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth, when ye shall see Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob, and all the prophets, in the kingdom of God, and you yourselves thrust out.
Manx: Ayns shen vees keaney as snaggeraght feeacklyn, tra hee shiu Abraham, as Isaac as Jacob as ooilley ny phadeyryn ayns reeriaght Yee, as shiu hene tilgit magh.

English: 29 And they shall come from the east, and from the west, and from the north, and from the south, and shall sit down in the kingdom of God.
Manx: As hig ad veih’n niar, as veih yn neear, as veih yn twoaie as veih yn jass, as soie-ee ad sheese ayns reeriaght-Yee.

English: 30 And, behold, there are last which shall be first, and there are first which shall be last.
Manx: As cur-my-ner, ta er-jerrey vees hoshiaght, as ta hoshiaght vees er-jerrey.

English: 31 ¶The same day there came certain of the Pharisees, saying unto him, Get thee out, and depart hence: for Herod will kill thee.
Manx: Yn laa cheddin, haink shiartance jeh ny Phariseeyn, as dooyrt ad rish, Fow ersooyl, as immee royd veih shoh ; son ta Herod ayns aigney oo y varroo.

English: 32 And he said unto them, Go ye, and tell that fox, Behold, I cast out devils, and I do cures to day and to morrow, and the third day I shall be perfected.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Gow-jee shiuish, as insh-jee da’n shynnagh shen, Cur-my-ner, ta mee geiyrt magh drogh-spyrrydyn, as lheihys doghanyn jiu as mairagh, as y tress laa bee my obbyr ec kione.

English: 33 Nevertheless I must walk to day, and to morrow, and the day following: for it cannot be that a prophet perish out of Jerusalem.
Manx: Ny-yeih, Shegin dou shooyl jiu as mairagh, as y laa er-giyn : son cha vel eh lowal phadeyr dy ve er ny stroïe ass Jerusalem.

English: 34 O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, which killest the prophets, and stonest them that are sent unto thee; how often would I have gathered thy children together, as a hen doth gather her brood under her wings, and ye would not
Manx: O Yerusalem, Yerusalem, ta marroo ny phadeyryn, as dyn glaghey adsyn t’er nyn goyrt er chaghteraght hood : cre cha mennick as va mish booiagh v’er haglym dty chloan cooidjagh, myr ta kiark goaill stiagh e hein fo my skainyn, cha nee yn aigney eu ve!

English: 35 Behold, your house is left unto you desolate: and verily I say unto you, Ye shall not see me, until the time come when ye shall say, Blessed is he that cometh in the name of the Lord.
Manx: Cur-my-ner, ta’n thie eu faagit diu treigit : As dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, nagh vaik shiu mish, derrey hig yn earish tra jir shiu, Bannit ta eshyn ta cheet ayns ennym y Chiarn.
CAB. XIV.

English: And it came to pass, as he went into the house of one of the chief Pharisees to eat bread on the sabbath day, that they watched him.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, tra v’eh er gholl stiagh ayns thie annane jeh ny ard Phariseeyn dy ee arran er y doonaght, dy dug ad tastey da.

English: 2 And, behold, there was a certain man before him which had the dropsy.
Manx: As cur-my-ner, va dooinney ayns yn enish echey, va’n dropsy er.

English: 3 And Jesus answering spake unto the lawyers and Pharisees, saying, Is it lawful to heal on the sabbath day?
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey, as loayr Eh rish fir-ynsee yn leigh as rish ny Phariseeyn, gra, Vel eh lowal dy lheihys er laa’n doonaght?

English: 4 And they held their peace. And he took him, and healed him, and let him go;
Manx: As chum ad nyn jengey. As ghow Eh as laanee Eh Eh, as lig Eh yn raad da :

English: 5 And answered them, saying, Which of you shall have an ass or an ox fallen into a pit, and will not straightway pull him out on the sabbath day?
Manx: As dreggyr Eh ad, gra, Quoi eu vees dow ny assyl echey er huittym ayns jeeg, nagh jean chelleeragh y hayrn ass eh er y doonaght?

English: 6 And they could not answer him again to these things.
Manx: As cha row ad abyl ansoor erbee y chur da gys ny goan shoh.

English: 7 ¶And he put forth a parable to those which were bidden, when he marked how they chose out the chief rooms; saying unto them.
Manx: As loayr Eh coraa-dorraghey roosyn va cuirt, tra hug Eh tastey kys v’ad reih ny stuill byrjey ; gra roo.

English: 8 When thou art bidden of any man to a wedding, sit not down in the highest room; lest a more honourable man than thou be bidden of him;
Manx: Tra t’ow cuirt liorish dooinney erbee gys bannish, ny soie sheese er y stoyl syrjey ; er aggle dy bee dooinney s’ooasle na uss er ny chuirrey liorish ;

English: 9 And he that bade thee and him come and say to thee, Give this man place; and thou begin with shame to take the lowest room.
Manx: As dy jig eshyn ren shiu ny neesht y chuirrey, as dy jir Eh rhyt, Cur raad da’n dooinney shoh ; as dy jean oo toshiaght lesh nearey dy ghoaill y stoyl s’inshilley.

English: 10 But when thou art bidden, go and sit down in the lowest room; that when he that bade thee cometh, he may say unto thee, Friend, go up higher: then shalt thou have worship in the presence of them that sit at meat with thee.
Manx: Agh tra vees oo cuirt, gow as soie sheese er y stoyl s’inshilley ; tra hig eshyn ren d[t]y chuirrey, dy vod Eh gra rhyt, Charrey, gow seose ny syrjey : eisht bee ooashley ayd ayns yn enish ocsyn ta nyn soie ec bee mârt.

English: 11 For whosoever exalteth himself shall be abased; and he that humbleth himself shall be exalted.
Manx: Son quoi-erbee ta dy hoiaghey Eh hene seose, bee Eh er ny injillaghey ; as eshyn ta dy injillaghey Eh hene, bee Eh er ny hoiaghey seose.

English: 12 ¶Then said he also to him that bade him, When thou makest a dinner or a supper, call not thy friends, nor thy brethren, neither thy kinsmen, nor thy rich neighbours; lest they also bid thee again, and a recompence be made thee.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Eh rishyn ren y chuirrey Eh, Tra t’ow jannoo jinnair ny shibber, ny cuir dty chaarjyn, ny dty vraaraghyn, ny dty gheiney-mooinjerey, ny dty naboonyn berchagh ; er-aggle dy jean adsyn oo y chuirrey reesht, as dy bee lhiassaghey er ny yannoo dhyt.

English: 13 But when thou makest a feast, call the poor, the maimed, the lame, the blind:
Manx: Agh tra t’ow jannoo cuirraghyn, eïe er ny boghtyn, ny baccee, ny croobee, as ny doail :

English: 14 And thou shalt be blessed; for they cannot recompense thee: for thou shalt be recompensed at the resurrection of the just.
Manx: As bee oo bannit ; son cha vod adsyn cooilleeney chur dhyt : son bee oo cooilleenit ec irree-reesht y chloan chairagh.

English: 15 ¶And when one of them that sat at meat with him heard these things, he said unto him, Blessed is he that shall eat bread in the kingdom of God.
Manx: As tra cheayll fer jeusyn va nyn soie ec bee marish ny goan shoh, dooyrt Eh rish, Bannit ta eshyn nee arran y ee ayns reeriaght Yee.

English: 16 Then said he unto him, A certain man made a great supper, and bade many:
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Eh rish, Ren dooinney dy row shibber vooar, as chuir Eh ymmodee :

English: 17 And sent his servant at supper time to say to them that were bidden, Come; for all things are now ready.
Manx: As hug Eh magh e harvaant ec traa shibberagh dy ghra roosyn va cuirt, Tar-jee, son ta dy chooilley nhee nish aarloo.
