English: 18 And they all with one consent began to make excuse. The first said unto him, I have bought a piece of ground, and I must needs go and see it: I pray thee have me excused.
Manx: As ren ad ooilley toshiaght lesh un aigney dy yannoo leshtallyn. Dooyrt y chied er, Ta mee er chionnaghey peesh dy halloo, as shegin dou goll dy yeeaghyn er : Guee-ym ort, jean my leshtal y ghoaill.

English: 19 And another said, I have bought five yoke of oxen, and I go to prove them: I pray thee have me excused.
Manx: As dooyrt fer elley, Ta mee er chionnaghey queig chubbil dy ghew, as ta mee goll dy hrial ad : Ta mee guee ort, jean my leshtal’s y ghoaill.

English: 20 And another said, I have married a wife, and therefore I cannot come.
Manx: As dooyrt fer elley, Ta mee er phoosey ben, as er-y-fa shen cha voddym cheet.

English: 21 So that servant came, and shewed his lord these things. Then the master of the house being angry said to his servant, Go out quickly into the streets and lanes of the city, and bring in hither the poor, and the maimed, and the halt, and the blind.
Manx: Myr shen haink y charvaant shen, as hoilshee Eh da e hiarn ny reddyn shoh. Eisht va mainshtyr y thie jymmoosagh, as dooyrt Eh rish e harvaant, Gow magh dy tappee gys straadjyn as raadjyn yn ard-valley, as cur lhiat stiagh ayns shoh ny boghtyn, as ny baccee, as ny croobee, as ny doail.

English: 22 And the servant said, Lord, it is done as thou hast commanded, and yet there is room.
Manx: As dooyrt y charvaant, Hiarn, te jeant myr t’ow er ny harey, as foast ta room.

English: 23 And the lord said unto the servant, Go out into the highways and hedges, and compel them to come in, that my house may be filled.
Manx: As dooyrt y chiarn rish y charvaant, Gow magh gys ny raadjyn mooarey as ny cloiy, as eaginee ad dy heet stiagh, dy vod my hie ve jeant magh.

English: 24 For I say unto you, That none of those men which were bidden shall taste of my supper.
Manx: Son ta mee gra riu, nagh jean annane jeh ny deiney va cuirt, blashtyn jeh my hibber.

English: 25 ¶And there went great multitudes with him: and he turned, and said unto them,
Manx: As hie earrooyn mooarey dy leih marish : as hyndaa Eh, as dooyrt Eh roo.

English: 26 If any man come to me, and hate not his father, and mother, and wife, and children, and brethren, and sisters, yea, and his own life also, he cannot be my disciple.
Manx: My hig dooinney erbee hym’s, as gyn feoh y ve echey er e ayr, as e voir, as e ven as e chloan, as e vraaraghyn, as e hairaghyn, dy jarroo, as er e vioys hene, cha vod Eh dy firrinagh gynsaghey voym’s.

English: 27 And whosoever doth not bear his cross, and come after me, cannot be my disciple.
Manx: As quoi-erbee nagh vel gymmyrkey e chrosh, as cheet geiyrt orryms, cha vod Eh dy firrinagh gynsaghey voym’s.

English: 28 ¶For which of you, intending to build a tower, sitteth not down first, and counteth the cost, whether he have sufficient to finish it?
Manx: Quoi eauish ta kiarrail toor y hroggal, nagh vel soie sheese hoshiaght, as tilgey seose y cost, dy yeeagheyn bee echey ny nee magh eh?

English: 29 Lest haply, after he hath laid the foundation, and is not able to finish it, all that behold it begin to mock him,
Manx: Er aggle erreish da yn undin y hoiaghey, as nagh vel Eh abyl y yannoo magh eh, dy jean ooilley ny hee eh, toshiaght dy chraidey mysh.

English: 30 Saying, This man began to build, and was not able to finish.
Manx: Gra, Ren y dooinney shoh toshiaght dy vuildal, as cha row Eh abyl kione y chur er e obbyr.

English: 31 Or what king, going to make war against another king, sitteth not down first, and consulteth whether he be able with ten thousand to meet him that cometh against him with twenty thousand?
Manx: Ny cre’n ree ragh dy yannoo caggey noi ree elley, nagh soiagh sheese hoshiaght dy ghoaill coyrle, beagh Eh abyl lesh jeih thousaneyn goll magh ny whail echyssyn harragh noi lesh feed thousane?

English: 32 Or else, while the other is yet a great way off, he sendeth an ambassage, and desireth conditions of peace.
Manx: Er nonney, choud as ta’n ree elley foddey veih, t’eh cur chaghteraght huggey, as shirrey y hayrn Eh gys shee.

English: 33 So likewise, whosoever he be of you that forsaketh not all that he hath, he cannot be my disciple.
Manx: Myr shen myrgeddin quoi-erbee Eh nyn mast’ eauish, nagh dreig ooilley ny t’echey, cha vod Eh dy firrinagh geiyrt orryms.

English: 34 Salt is good: but if the salt have lost his savour, wherewith shall it be seasoned?
Manx: Ta Sollan mie : agh, my ta’n sollan er choall e vlass, kys hig e vree ayn reesht?

English: 35 It is neither fit for the land, nor yet for the dunghill; but men cast it out. He that hath ears to hear, let him hear.
Manx: Cha vel ymmyd ayn son y thalloo, ny foast son y torran ; agh ta deiney dy cheau magh eh. Eshyn ta cleayshyn echey dy chlashtyn, lig da clashtyn.
CAB. XV.

English: Then drew near unto him all the publicans and sinners for to hear him.
Manx: Eisht haink er-gerrey da ooilley ny publicanee as ny peccee dy eaishtagh rish.

English: 2 And the Pharisees and scribes murmured, saying, This man receiveth sinners, and eateth with them.
Manx: As va ny Phariseeyn as ny scruderyn jymmoosagh, gra, Ta’n dooinney shoh goaill peccee huggey, as gee mâroo.

English: 3 ¶And he spake this parable unto them, saying,
Manx: As loayr Eh yn coraa-dorraghey shoh roo, gra,

English: 4 What man of you, having an hundred sheep, if he lose one of them, doth not leave the ninety and nine in the wilderness, and go after that which is lost, until he find it?
Manx: Quoi yn dooinney nyn mast’ eauish ta keead keyrrey echey, as my t’eh coall annane oc, nagh vel Eh faagail yn chiare-feed as yn nuyh-jeig ayns yn aasagh, as goll dy hirrey yn cheyrrey ta caillit, derrey t’eh dy gheddyn ee?

English: 5 And when he hath found it, he layeth it on his shoulders, rejoicing.
Manx: As tra t’eh er gheddyn ee, t’eh dy choyrt ee er e gheayltyn, goaill boggey.

English: 6 And when he cometh home, he calleth together his friends and neighbours, saying unto them, Rejoice with me; for I have found my sheep which was lost.
Manx: As tra t’eh cheet thie, t’eh geamagh er e chaarjyn as e naboonyn cooidjagh, as gra roo, Gow-jee boggey mârym, son ta mee er gheddyn my cheyrrey va caillit.

English: 7 I say unto you, that likewise joy shall be in heaven over one sinner that repenteth, more than over ninety and nine just persons, which need no repentance.
Manx: Ta mee gra riu, dy bee boggey myrgeddin ayns niau, harrish un pheccagh ta goaill arrys, ny smoo na harrish kiare-feed as nuyh persoonyn jeig cairagh, nagh vel feme arrys.

English: 8 ¶Either what woman having ten pieces of silver, if she lose one piece, doth not light a candle, and sweep the house, and seek diligently till she find it?
Manx: Ny cre’n ven ta jeih peeshyn dy argid eck, as ee dy choall un pheesh, nagh vel ee foddey kainle, as sceabey yn thie, as shirrey dy kiarralagh, derrey t’ee dy gheddyn eh?

English: 9 And when she hath found it, she calleth her friends and her neighbours together, saying, Rejoice with me; for I have found the piece which I had lost.
Manx: As tra t’ee er gheddyn eh, t’ee geamagh er e caarjyn as e naboonyn cooidjagh, gra, Gow-jee boggey mârym, son ta mee er gheddyn yn pheesh ren mee y choall.

English: 10 Likewise, I say unto you, there is joy in the presence of the angels of God over one sinner that repenteth.
Manx: Myrgeddin ta mee gra riu, dy vel boggey ayns fenish ainlyn Yee harrish un pheccagh ta goaill arrys.

English: 11 ¶And he said, A certain man had two sons:
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Va daa vac ec dooinney dy row :

English: 12 And the younger of them said to his father, Father, give me the portion of goods that falleth to me. And he divided unto them his living.
Manx: As dooyrt y fer saa rish e ayr, Ayr, cur dooys yn ayrn dy chooid ta my chouyr. As reynn Eh e veaghey orroo.

English: 13 And not many days after the younger son gathered all together, and took his journey into a far country, and there wasted his substance with riotous living.
Manx: As laghyn ny lurg shen, hymsee yn mac saa ooilley cooidjagh, as ghow Eh jurnah gys cheer foddey, as ayns shen hug Eh jummal er e chooid liorish rouyr stroie.

English: 14 And when he had spent all, there arose a mighty famine in that land; and he began to be in want.
Manx: As tra va ooilley baarit echey, dirree genney vooar ayns y cheer shen ; as ren Eh toshiaght dy ve ayns feme.

English: 15 And he went and joined himself to a citizen of that country; and he sent him into his fields to feed swine.
Manx: As hie Eh as daill Eh Eh hene rish fer jeh fir-vaghee yn cheer shen ; as hug eshyn Eh magh gys ny magheryn echey dy ve son bochilley muck.

English: 16 And he would fain have filled his belly with the husks that the swine did eat: and no man gave unto him.
Manx: As by houyr lesh e volg y lhieeney lesh ny bleaystyn va ny muckyn dy ee : as cha row dooinney erbee ry hoi cur da.

English: 17 And when he came to himself, he said, How many hired servants of my father’s have bread enough and to spare, and I perish with hunger
Manx: As tra v’eh er jeet huggey hene, dooyrt Eh, Nagh nimmey sharvaant failt t’ec my ayr ta nyn saie arran oc, as ta mish goll mow laccal beaghey!

English: 18 I will arise and go to my father, and will say unto him, Father, I have sinned against heaven, and before thee,
Manx: Irree-ym, as hem roym gys my ayr, as jir-ym rish, Ayr, ta mee er n’yannoo peccah noi niau, as kiongoyrt rhyts.

English: 19 And am no more worthy to be called thy son: make me as one of thy hired servants.
Manx: As cha vel mee ny sodjey feeu dy ve enmyssit dty vac : dell rhym myr rish fer jeh dty harvaantyn failt.

English: 20 And he arose, and came to his father. But when he was yet a great way off, his father saw him, and had compassion, and ran, and fell on his neck, and kissed him.
Manx: As hrog Eh er, as haink Eh gys e ayr. Agh tra v’eh foast foddey veih, honnick e ayr Eh, as va chymmey echey er, as roih Eh, as haar Eh e roihaghyn mysh e wannal, as phaag Eh Eh.

English: 21 And the son said unto him, Father, I have sinned against heaven, and in thy sight, and am no more worthy to be called thy son.
Manx: As dooyrt y mac rish, Ayr, ta mee er n’yannoo peccah noi niau, as ayns dty hilley’s, as cha vel mee ny sodjey feeu dy ve enmyssit dty vac.

English: 22 But the father said to his servants, Bring forth the best robe, and put it on him; and put a ring on his hand, and shoes on his feet:
Manx: Agh dooyrt yn ayr rish e harvaantyn, Cur-jee lhieu magh yn coamrey share, as cur-jee er eh, as cur-jee faainey er e laue, as braagyn er e chassyn.

English: 23 And bring hither the fatted calf, and kill it; and let us eat, and be merry:
Manx: As cur-jee lhieu ayns shoh yn lheiy beiyht, as mar-jee eh ; as lig dooin gee as ve gennal.

English: 24 For this my son was dead, and is alive again; he was lost, and is found. And they began to be merry.
Manx: Son va my vac shoh marroo, as t’eh bio reesht ; v’eh caillit, as t’eh er ny gheddyn. As ren ad toshiaght dy ve gennal.

English: 25 Now his elder son was in the field: and as he came and drew nigh to the house, he heard musick and dancing.
Manx: Nish va’n mac shinney ayns y vagher : as tra haink Eh er-gerrey da’n thie, cheayll Eh Kiaull as donsin.

English: 26 And he called one of the servants, and asked what these things meant.
Manx: As deïe Eh er annane jeh ny guillin, as dênee Eh cre son va shoh.

English: 27 And he said unto him, Thy brother is come; and thy father hath killed the fatted calf, because he hath received him safe and sound.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish, Ta dty vraar er jeet ; as ta dt’ayr er varroo yn lheiy beiyht, er-yn-oyr dy vel Eh er jeet thie huggey sauchey.

English: And he was angry, and would not go in: therefore came his father out, and intreated him.
Manx: 28. As va farg er, as cha row Eh booiagh goll stiagh : shen-y-fa haink Eh ayr magh, as chuir Eh Eh.

English: 29 And he answering said to his father, Lo, these many years do I serve thee, neither transgressed I at any time thy commandment: and yet thou never gavest me a kid, that I might make merry with my friends:
Manx: As dreggyr eshyn, as dooyrt Eh rish e ayr, Cur-my-ner, ta mish rish whilleen blein shen ayns dty hirveish, as cha ren mee rieau noi dt’aigney, as foast cha dug oo dou rieau mannan dou, dy voddin ve gennal marish my gheiney-mooinjerey :

English: 30 But as soon as this thy son was come, which hath devoured thy living with harlots, thou hast killed for him the fatted calf.
Manx: Agh cha leah as v’eh shoh dty vac er jeet, ta er vaarail dty chooid er streebaghyn, t’ow er varroo er e hon yn lheiy beiyht.

English: 31 And he said unto him, Son, thou art ever with me, and all that I have is thine.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish, Vac, t’ow er ny ve kinjagh mârym, as lhiat ooilley ny t’aym.

English: 32 It was meet that we should make merry, and be glad: for this thy brother was dead, and is alive again; and was lost, and is found.
Manx: Ve cooie dooin ve gennal, as boggey y ghoaill : son v’eh shoh dty vraar marroo, as t’eh bio reesht ; v’eh caillit, as t’eh er ny gheddyn.
CAB. XVI.

English: And he said also unto his disciples, There was a certain rich man, which had a steward; and the same was accused unto him that he had wasted his goods.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh myrgeddin rish y vooinjer va sheer marish, Va dooinney berchagh dy row as stiurt echey ; as v’eh er ny phlaint huggey dy row Eh er yummal e chooid.

English: 2 And he called him, and said unto him, How is it that I hear this of thee? give an account of thy stewardship; for thou mayest be no longer steward.
Manx: As deïe Eh er, as dooyrt Eh rish, Kys dy vel mee clashtyn shoh jeed? cur coontey jeh dty stiurtys : son cha vod oo ve ny sodjey dty stiurt.

English: 3 Then the steward said within himself, What shall I do? for my lord taketh away from me the stewardship: I cannot dig; to beg I am ashamed.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt y stiurt rish hene, Cre nee’m? son ta my hiarn goaill y stiurtys voym : cha voddym gobbraghey lesh my chiebbey, as ta nearey orrym goll dy hooyl ny dhieyn.

English: 4 I am resolved what to do, that, when I am put out of the stewardship, they may receive me into their houses.
Manx: Ta fys aym cre nee’m, tra vee-ym er my choyrt ass y stiurtys, dy vod my vea ve oltit gys ny thieyn oc.

English: 5 So he called every one of his lord’s debtors unto him, and said unto the first, How much owest thou unto my lord?
Manx: Myr shen deïe Eh er dy chooilley annane v’ayns lhiastynys da e hiarn, as dooyrt Eh rish y chied er, Cre-woad t’ow uss dy lhiastyn dy my hiarn?

English: 6 And he said, An hundred measures of oil. And he said unto him, Take thy bill, and sit down quickly, and write fifty.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Keead towse dy ooill. As dooyrt Eh rish, Gow dty screeuyn, soie sheese dy tappee, as scrieu jeih as da-eed.

English: 7 Then said he to another, And how much owest thou? And he said, An hundred measures of wheat. And he said unto him, Take thy bill, and write fourscore.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish fer elley, As cre-woad t’ow uss dy lhiastyn? As dooyrt Eh, Keead towse dy churnaght. As dooyrt Eh rish, Gow dty screeuyn, as scrieu kiare-feed.

English: 8 And the lord commended the unjust steward, because he had done wisely: for the children of this world are in their generation wiser than the children of light.
Manx: As voyll y chiarn y stiurt neu-chairagh, er-y-fa dy row Eh er n’yannoo dy creeney : son ta cloan y theihll shoh ayns nyn sheeloghe ny s’creeney na cloan y toilshey.

English: 9 And I say unto you, Make to yourselves friends of the mammon of unrighteousness; that, when ye fail, they may receive you into everlasting habitations.
Manx: As ta mee gra riu, Jean-jee diu hene caarjyn liorish yn mammon molteragh ; tra nee shiu failleil, dy vod ad shiu y ghoaill stiagh gys ny ynnydyn-vaghee dy bragh farraghtyn.

English: 10 He that is faithful in that which is least is faithful also in much: and he that is unjust in the least is unjust also in much.
Manx: Eshyn ta ynrick ayns yn red s’fardaalee, t’eh ynrick myrgeddin ayns mooarane : as eshyn ta neu-charragh ayns y red s’fardalee, t’eh neu-chairagh myrgeddin ayns mooarane.

English: 11 If therefore ye have not been faithful in the unrighteous mammon, who will commit to your trust the true riches?
Manx: Mannagh vel shiu er-y-fa shen er ve ynrick ayns y mammon molteragh, quoi livrey-ys diu yn verchys firrinagh?

English: 12 And if ye have not been faithful in that which is another man’s, who shall give you that which is your own?
Manx: As mannagh vel shiu er ve firrinagh ayns ny ta lesh dooinney elley, quoi ver diu ny vees lhieu hene?

English: 13 ¶No servant can serve two masters: for either he will hate the one, and love the other; or else he will hold to the one, and despise the other. Ye cannot serve God and mammon.
Manx: Cha vod sharvaant erbee daa vainshter y hirveish : son edyr ver Eh feoh da’n derrey yeh, as graih da’n jeh elley ; er nonney cummee Eh gys y derrey yeh, as soie-ee Eh beg jeh’n jeh elley. Cha vod shiu Jee as mammon y hirveish.

English: 14 And the Pharisees also, who were covetous, heard all these things: and they derided him.
Manx: As cheayll ny Phariseeyn myrgeddin va sayntoilagh, ooilley ny reddyn shoh : as ren ad gannidys er.

English: 15 And he said unto them, Ye are they which justify yourselves before men; but God knoweth your hearts: for that which is highly esteemed among men is abomination in the sight of God.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Shiuish yn vooinjer ta dy heyrey shiu hene kiongoyrt rish deiney ; agh ta fys ec Jee er ny creeaghyn eu : son ta shen ta dy mooar soit jeh mastey deiney, feohdoil ayns shilley Yee.

English: 16 The law and the prophets were until John: since that time the kingdom of God is preached, and every man presseth into it.
Manx: Va’n leigh as ny phadeyryn derrey Ean: er dyn traa shen, ta reeriaght Yee er ny phreacheil, as ta dy chooilley ghooinney chionney stiagh huggey.

English: 17 And it is easier for heaven and earth to pass, than one tittle of the law to fail.
Manx: Agh t’eh ny sassey da’n aer as da’n thalloo dy hierraghtyn, na da un tittle jeh’n leigh dy ailleil.

English: 18 Whosoever putteth away his wife, and marrieth another, committeth adultery: and whosoever marrieth her that is put away from her husband committeth adultery.
Manx: Quoi-erbee scarrys rish e ven, as phoosys ben elley, t’eh brishey poosey : as quoi-erbee phoosys ish ta scarrit veih e sheshey, t’eh brishey poosey.

English: 19 ¶There was a certain rich man, which was clothed in purple and fine linen, and fared sumptuously every day:
Manx: Va dooinney berchagh dy row va coamrit ayns gorrym-jiarg, as aanrit keyll, as jeant magh lesh gien mie dy chooilley laa.

English: 20 And there was a certain beggar named Lazarus, which was laid at his gate, full of sores,
Manx: As va dooinney boght dy row va enmyssit Lazarus, va ny lhie ec y yiat echey, laane dy hingyn,

English: 21 And desiring to be fed with the crumbs which fell from the rich man’s table: moreover the dogs came and licked his sores.
Manx: As geearree dy ve jeant magh lesh y vrooilliagh va tuittym jeh boayrd y dooinney verchagh : agh haink ny eer moddee as sliee ad ny chingyn echey.

English: 22 And it came to pass, that the beggar died, and was carried by the angels into Abraham’s bosom: the rich man also died, and was buried;
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, dy dooar y dooinney boght baase, as dy dug dy ainlyn lhieu Eh gys oghrish Abraham : hooar y dooinney berchagh myrgeddin baase, as v’eh er ny oanluckey.

English: 23 And in hell he lift up his eyes, being in torments, and seeth Abraham afar off, and Lazarus in his bosom.
Manx: As ayns niurin, raad v’eh er ny horchaghey, hrog Eh seose Eh hooyllyn, as honnick Eh Abraham foddey veih, as Lazarus ayns e oghrish.

English: 24 And he cried and said, Father Abraham, have mercy on me, and send Lazarus, that he may dip the tip of his finger in water, and cool my tongue; for I am tormented in this flame.
Manx: As deïe Eh, as dooyrt Eh, Ayr Abraham, jean myghin orrym, as cur Lazarus, dy vod Eh baare e vair y hummey ayns ushtey, as my hengey y eayraghey ; son ta mee er my horchaghey ayns y lossey shoh.

English: 25 But Abraham said, Son, remember that thou in thy lifetime receivedst thy good things, and likewise Lazarus evil things: but now he is comforted, and thou art tormented.
Manx: Agh dooyrt Abraham, Vac, cooinee ayns earish dty vea dy ren uss dty reddyn mie y ghoaill, as myrgeddin Lazarus reddyn sie : agh nish t’eshyn er ny gherjaghey, as t’ow uss er d[t]y horchaghey.

English: 26 And beside all this, between us and you there is a great gulf fixed: so that they which would pass from hence to you cannot; neither can they pass to us, that would come from thence.
Manx: As marish shoh ooilley, ta eddyr shinyn as shiuish diunid vooar soit : myr shen adsyn ta aignagh dy gholl veih shoh hiuish, cha vel ad abyl ; chamoo oddys adsyn cheet hooinyn, ta aignagh dy heet veih shen.

English: 27 Then he said, I pray thee therefore, father, that thou wouldest send him to my father’s house:
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Eh, Ta mee guee ort er-y-fa shen, ayr, dy chur Eh gys thie my ayr :

English: 28 For I have five brethren; that he may testify unto them, lest they also come into this place of torment.
Manx: Son ta queig braaraghyn aym ; dy vod Eh feanish y ymmyrkey daue, er son nagh jig adsyn myrgeddin gys y boayl shoh dy horchagh.

English: 29 Abraham saith unto him, They have Moses and the prophets; let them hear them.
Manx: Dooyrt Abraham rish, Ta Moses as ny phadeyryn oc ; lig daue geill y chur dauesyn.

English: 30 And he said, Nay, father Abraham: but if one went unto them from the dead, they will repent.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Cha nee, O ayr Abraham : agh dy ragh fer veih ny merriu huc, ghoghe ad arrys.

English: 31 And he said unto him, If they hear not Moses and the prophets, neither will they be persuaded, though one rose from the dead.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish, Mannagh der ad geill da Moses as ny phadeyryn, cha greidagh ad, ga dy nirragh fer veih ny merriu.
CAB. XVII.

English: Then said he unto the disciples, It is impossible but that offences will come: but woe unto him, through whom they come
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Eh rish y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er, Cha vod eh ve nagh bee oyryn peccah ayn : agh smerg dasyn liorish ta sleih er nyn dayrn gys peccah.

English: 2 It were better for him that a millstone were hanged about his neck, and he cast into the sea, than that he should offend one of these little ones.
Manx: Veagh eh ny baare da dy beagh clagh-wyllin er ve croghit mysh e wannal, as Eh dy ve tilgit ayns y cheayn, na Eh dy hayrn gys peccah annane jeh’n vooinjer veggey shoh.

English: 3 ¶Take heed to yourselves: If thy brother trespass against thee, rebuke him; and if he repent, forgive him.
Manx: Cur-jee twoaie diu hene : My nee dty vraar aggair dhyt, cur oghsan da ; as my ghoys Eh arrys, leih da.

English: 4 And if he trespass against thee seven times in a day, and seven times in a day turn again to thee, saying, I repent; thou shalt forgive him.
Manx: As my nee Eh peccah dt’oi shiaght keayrtyn ’sy laa, as shiaght keayrtyn ’sy laa chyndaa reesht hood as gra, Ta mee goaill arrys ; leih-ee oo da.

English: 5 ¶And the apostles said unto the Lord, Increase our faith.
Manx: As dooyrt ny ostyllyn rish y Chiarn, Bishee yn credjue ainyn.

English: 6 And the Lord said, If ye had faith as a grain of mustard seed, ye might say unto this sycamine tree, Be thou plucked up by the root, and be thou planted in the sea; and it should obey you.
Manx: As dooyrt y Chiarn, Dy beagh credjue eu myr greine dy rass mustard, oddagh shiu gra rish y billey-sycamine shoh, Bee er dty hayrn ass ny fraueyn, as bee er d[t]y hoiaghey ayns y cheayn ; as yinnagh eh biallys diu.

English: 7 But which of you, having a servant plowing or feeding cattle, will say unto him by and by, when he is come from the field, Go and sit down to meat?
Manx: Agh quoi eu ta sharvaant echey traaue, ny cur bee da’n ollagh, jir rish chelleeragh, tra vees Eh er jeet veih’n vagher, Immee as soie gys y voayrd?

English: 8 And will not rather say unto him, Make ready wherewith I may sup, and gird thyself, and serve me, till I have eaten and drunken; and afterward thou shalt eat and drink?
Manx: As nagh jir hoshiaght rish, Fow aarloo dy voddyms my hibber y gheddyn, as kaingle dty gharmad mood, as shirveish orryms, derrey vee’m erreish gee as giu, as ny lurg shen nee uss gee as giu?

English: 9 Doth he thank that servant because he did the things that were commanded him? I trow not.
Manx: Vel booise er da’n charvaant shen, er-yn-oyr dy ren Eh ny reddyn v’er ny haarey da? Cha vel mee smooinaghtyn dy vel.

English: 10 So likewise ye, when ye shall have done all those things which are commanded you, say, We are unprofitable servants: we have done that which was our duty to do.
Manx: Myr shen myrgeddin shiuish, tra vees shiu er n’yannoo ooilley ny t’er ny haarey diu, abbyr-jee, She sharvaantyn neu-vondeishagh shin: ta shiu [sic: shin] er n’yannoo ynrycan ny va orrin dy yannoo.

English: 11 ¶And it came to pass, as he went to Jerusalem, that he passed through the midst of Samaria and Galilee.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, myr v’eh er e yurnah gys Jerusalem, dy jimmee Eh trooid main Samaria as Galilee.

English: 12 And as he entered into a certain village, there met him ten men that were lepers, which stood afar off:
Manx: As myr v’eh goll stiagh ayns balley-beg dy row, haink ny whail jeih deiney va nyn louraanee, as hass ad foddey veih ;

English: 13 And they lifted up their voices, and said, Jesus, Master, have mercy on us.
Manx: As hrog ad seose nyn goraaghyn, as dooyrt ad, Yeesey, Vainshtyr, jean myghin orrin.

English: 14 And when he saw them, he said unto them, Go shew yourselves unto the priests. And it came to pass, that, as they went, they were cleansed.
Manx: As tra v’eh er yeeaghyn orroo, dooyrt Eh roo, Immee-jee as jeeagh-jee shiu hene da ny saggyrtyn. As haink eh gy kione, myr v’ad goll, dy row ad er nyn ghlenney.

English: 15 And one of them, when he saw that he was healed, turned back, and with a loud voice glorified God,
Manx: As hyndaa fer jeu back, tra honnick Eh dy row Eh er ny laanaghey, as lesh ard choraa hug Eh moylley da Jee,

English: 16 And fell down on his face at his feet, giving him thanks: and he was a Samaritan.
Manx: As huit Eh sheese er e eddin ec ny cassyn echey, cur booise da : as v’eh ny Samaritan.

English: 17 And Jesus answering said, Were there not ten cleansed? but where are the nine?
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey, gra, Nagh row jeih er nyn ghlenney? agh cre vel yn nuy?

English: 18 There are not found that returned to give glory to God, save this stranger.
Manx: Cha vel er nyn gheddyn t’er jyndaa dy chur gloyr da Jee, agh my lomarcan yn joarree shoh.

English: 19 And he said unto him, Arise, go thy way: thy faith hath made thee whole.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish, Irree, immee royd ; ta dty chredjue er d[t]y laanaghey.

English: 20 ¶And when he was demanded of the Pharisees, when the kingdom of God should come, he answered them and said, The kingdom of God cometh not with observation:
Manx: As tra v’eh fênit jeh liorish ny Phariseeyn, cre’n traa harragh reeriaght Yee ; dreggyr Eh ad, gra, Cha jig reeriaght Yee lesh stayd chronnal.

English: 21 Neither shall they say, Lo here! or, lo there! for, behold, the kingdom of God is within you.
Manx: Cha-moo jir ad, Jeeagh ayns shoh, ny jeeagh ayns shid : son cur-my-ner, ta reeriaght Yee cheu-sthie jiu.

English: 22 And he said unto the disciples, The days will come, when ye shall desire to see one of the days of the Son of man, and ye shall not see it.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er, Hig ny laghyn tra vees shiu aignagh dy akin annane jeh laghyn yn Mac dooinney, as cha vaik shiu eh.

English: 23 And they shall say to you, See here; or, see there: go not after them, nor follow them.
Manx: As jir ad riu, Jeeagh ayns shoh, ny jeeagh ayns shid : ny roih-jee geiyrt, as ny eiyr-jee orroo.

English: 24 For as the lightning, that lighteneth out of the one part under heaven, shineth unto the other part under heaven; so shall also the Son of man be in his day.
Manx: Son myr ta’n tendeil ta soilshean veih yn derrey ard fo’n aer, cur soilshey da’n ard elley fo’n aer : myr shen myrgeddin vees yn Mac dooinney ayns y laa echey.

English: 25 But first must he suffer many things, and be rejected of this generation.
Manx: Agh hoshiaght shegin da ymmodee reddyn y hurranse, as ve beg soit jeh liorish y cheeloghe shoh.

English: 26 And as it was in the days of Noe, so shall it be also in the days of the Son of man.
Manx: As myr ve ayns laghyn Noe, myr shen vees eh myrgeddin ayns laghyn yn Mac dooinney.

English: 27 They did eat, they drank, they married wives, they were given in marriage, until the day that Noe entered into the ark, and the flood came, and destroyed them all.
Manx: V’ad gee, v’ad giu, v’ad poosey, v’ad er nyn goyrt ayns poosey, derrey yn laa hie Noe stiagh ayns yn arg : as haink y thooilley, as vaiy eh ad ooilley.

English: 28 Likewise also as it was in the days of Lot; they did eat, they drank, they bought, they sold, they planted, they builded;
Manx: As er yn un aght as ve ayns laghyn Lot, v’ad gee, v’ad giu, v’ad kionnaghey, v’ad creck, v’ad soiaghey biljyn, v’ad troggal [t]hieyn :

English: 29 But the same day that Lot went out of Sodom it rained fire and brimstone from heaven, and destroyed them all.
Manx: Agh er y laa hie Lot magh ass Sodom, haink neose aile as brymstone veih niau, as ren eh ad ooilley y stroie :

English: 30 Even thus shall it be in the day when the Son of man is revealed.
Manx: Er yn aght shoh vees eh er y laa vees yn Mac dooinney er ny hoilshaghey.

English: 31 In that day, he which shall be upon the housetop, and his stuff in the house, let him not come down to take it away: and he that is in the field, let him likewise not return back.
Manx: Ayns y laa shen, eshyn vees er mullagh y thie, as y stoo-thie echey sthie, ny lig da cheet neose dy chur lesh eh : as eshyn ta ayns y vagher, ny lig dasyn myrgeddin chyndaa back.

English: 32 Remember Lot’s wife.
Manx: Cooinee-jee er ben Lot.

English: 33 Whosoever shall seek to save his life shall lose it; and whosoever shall lose his life shall preserve it.
Manx: Quoi-erbee ta hirrys e vioys y hauail, caillee Eh eh : as quoi-erbee nee e vioys y choall, sauee Eh eh.

English: 34 I tell you, in that night there shall be two men in one bed; the one shall be taken, and the other shall be left.
Manx: Ta mee ginsh diu, ayns yn oie shen dy bee daa ghooinney ayns un lhiabbee ; as bee yn derrey yeh goit, as y jeh elley faagit.

English: 35 Two women shall be grinding together; the one shall be taken, and the other left.
Manx: Bee daa ven blieh cooidjagh ; bee yn derrey yeh goit, as y jeh elley faagit.

English: 36 Two men shall be in the field; the one shall be taken, and the other left.
Manx: Bee daa ghooinney ayns y vagher ; bee yn derrey yeh goit, as y jeh elley faagit.

English: 37 And they answered and said unto him, Where, Lord? And he said unto them, Wheresoever the body is, thither will the eagles be gathered together.
Manx: As dreggyr ad, as dooyrt ad rish, C’raad, Hiarn? As dooyrt eshyn roo, Raad erbee dy bee yn corp, ayns shen vees ny urlee er nyn jaglym cooidjagh.
CAB. XVIII.

English: And he spake a parable unto them to this end, that men ought always to pray, and not to faint;
Manx: As loayr Eh coraa dorraghey roo, dy lhisagh deiney kinjagh padjer y ghoaill, as nagh lhisagh ad ve lhiastey ;

English: 2 Saying, There was in a city a judge, which feared not God, neither regarded man:
Manx: Gra, Va ayns ard-valley dy row briw nagh row ayns aggle roish Jee, ny cur geill da dooinney.

English: 3 And there was a widow in that city; and she came unto him, saying, Avenge me of mine adversary.
Manx: As va ben-treoghe ayns yn ard-valley shen, haink huggey, gra, Cur cairys dou oi my noid.

English: 4 And he would not for a while: but afterward he said within himself, Though I fear not God, nor regard man;
Manx: As cha row Eh booiagh son earish : agh ny lurg shen dooyrt Eh rish hene, Ga nagh vel mee goaill aggle roish Jee, ny cur geill da dooinney ;

English: 5 Yet because this widow troubleth me, I will avenge her, lest by her continual coming she weary me.
Manx: Ny-yeih er-y-fa dy vel y ven-treoghe shoh dy my voirey, verrym cairys jee, er aggle dy jean ee deïnagh jee’m, liorish ve kinjagh cheet my raad.

English: 6 And the Lord said, Hear what the unjust judge saith.
Manx: As dooyrt y Chiarn, Clasht-jee cre ta’n briw neu-chairagh dy ghra.

English: 7 And shall not God avenge his own elect, which cry day and night unto him, though he bear long with them?
Manx: As nagh jean Jee cooilleeney ayns lieh e chloan reiht hene, ta geamagh huggey oie as laa, ga t’eh foddey er lhiggey-shiaghey?

English: 8 I tell you that he will avenge them speedily. Nevertheless when the Son of man cometh, shall he find faith on the earth?
Manx: Ta mee ginsh diu dy gooilleen Eh er nyn son oc dy tappee. Ny-yeih, tra hig yn Mac dooinney, vow Eh credjue er y thalloo?

English: 9 And he spake this parable unto certain which trusted in themselves that they were righteous, and despised others:
Manx: As loayr Eh yn coraa-dorraghey shoh rish shiartance va treishteil ayndoo hene dy row ad cairagh, agh soiaghey beg jeh feallagh elley :

English: 10 Two men went up into the temple to pray; the one a Pharisee, and the other a publican.
Manx: Hie daa ghooinney seose gys y chiamble dy ghoaill padjer ; va’n derrey yeh ny Pharisee, as y jeh elley ny phublican.

English: 11 The Pharisee stood and prayed thus with himself, God, I thank thee, that I am not as other men are, extortioners, unjust, adulterers, or even as this publican.
Manx: Hass y Pharisee as ghow Eh padjer myr shoh rish hene, Yee, ta mee cur booise dhyt, nagh vel mish myr deiney elley, tranlaasee, neu-chairagh, brishey-poosey, ny foast myr y publican shoh.

English: 12 I fast twice in the week, I give tithes of all that I possess.
Manx: Ta mee trostey daa cheayrt ’sy chaghtin, ta mee cur jaghee jeh ooilley ny t’ayns my chummal.

English: 13 And the publican, standing afar off, would not lift up so much as his eyes unto heaven, but smote upon his breast, saying, God be merciful to me a sinner.
Manx: As hass y publican foddey veih, as cha ballish wheesh as e hooillyn y hroggal seose gys niau, agh woaill Eh er e chleeau, gra, Dy row Jee myghinagh dooys ta my ghrogh-yantagh.

English: 14 I tell you, this man went down to his house justified rather than the other : for every one that exalteth himself shall be abased; and he that humbleth himself shall be exalted.
Manx: Ta mee ginsh diu, dy jagh y dooinney shoh sheese gys e hie er ny heyrey ny smoo na’n jeh elley : son bee dy chooilley annane ta dy hoiaghey Eh hene seose, er ny injillaghey ; as bee eshyn ta dy injillaghey Eh hene, er ny hoiaghey seose.

English: 15 And they brought unto him also infants, that he would touch them: but when his disciples saw it, they rebuked them.
Manx: As hug ad myrgeddin lhieu oikanyn huggey, dy jinnagh Eh bennaylt roo : agh tra honnick yn vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er eh, hug ad oghsan daue.

English: 16 But Jesus called them unto him, and said, Suffer little children to come unto me, and forbid them not: for of such is the kingdom of God.
Manx: Agh deïe Yeesey orroo huggey, as dooyrt Eh, Sur-jee cloan aegey dy heet hyms, as ny jean-jee nyn lhiettal ad : son jeh nyn leid ta reeriaght Yee.

English: 17 Verily I say unto you, Whosoever shall not receive the kingdom of God as a little child shall in no wise enter therein.
Manx: Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Quoi-erbee nagh jean goaill reeriaght Yee myr liannoo beg, cha jed Eh er aght erbee stiagh ayn.

English: 18 And a certain ruler asked him, saying, Good Master, what shall I do to inherit eternal life?
Manx: As dênee fer-reill dy row jeh, gra, Vainshtyr vie, cre neem’s dy vod eiraght y ve aym ayns y vea veayn?

English: 19 And Jesus said unto him, Why callest thou me good? none is good, save one, that is, God.
Manx: As dooyrt Yeesey rish, Cre’n-fa t’ow genmyss mee mie? cha vel annane erbee mie, agh annane, ta shen dy ghra, Jee.

English: 20 Thou knowest the commandments, Do not commit adultery, Do not kill, Do not steal, Do not bear false witness, Honour thy father and thy mother.
Manx: Ta toiggal ayd jeh ny annaghyn, Ny jean poosey y vrishey, Ny jean dunverys, Ny jean geid, Ny jean feanish foalsey y ymmyrkey, Cur arrym da dt’ayr as da dty voir.

English: 21 And he said, All these have I kept from my youth up.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Ooilley shoh ta mee er vreaylley veih my aegid.

English: 22 Now when Jesus heard these things, he said unto him, Yet lackest thou one thing: sell all that thou hast, and distribute unto the poor, and thou shalt have treasure in heaven: and come, follow me.
Manx: Nish tra cheayll Yeesey shoh, dooyrt Eh rish, Ta foast un red ort dy yannoo : creck as reynn ooilley ny t’ayd er ny boghtyn, as bee berchys ayd ayns niau : as tar, as eiyr orryms.

English: 23 And when he heard this, he was very sorrowful: for he was very rich.
Manx: As tra cheayll Eh shoh, daase Eh feer trimshagh, son v’eh feer verchagh.

English: 24 And when Jesus saw that he was very sorrowful, he said, How hardly shall they that have riches enter into the kingdom of God
Manx: As tra honnick Yeesey dy row Eh feer trimshagh, dooyrt Eh, Cre cha doillee as vees eh dauesyn ta berchys oc, goll stiagh ayns reeriaght Yee!

English: 25 For it is easier for a camel to go through a needle’s eye, than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of God.
Manx: Son te ny sassey da camel goll trooid croae snaidey, na da dooinney berchagh dy gholl stiagh ayns reeriaght Yee.

English: 26 And they that heard it said, Who then can be saved?
Manx: As dooyrt adsyn cheayll eh, Quoi eisht oddys v’er ny hauail?

English: 27 And he said, The things which are impossible with men are possible with God.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Ta ny reddyn shoh neu-phossible da deiney, agh t’ad possible da Jee.

English: 28 Then Peter said, Lo, we have left all, and followed thee.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Peddyr, Cur-my-ner, ta shinyn er dreigeil ooilley, as er n’eiyrt orts.

English: 29 And he said unto them, Verily I say unto you, There is no man that hath left house, or parents, or brethren, or wife, or children, for the kingdom of God’s sake,
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Nagh vel dooinney erbee t’er dreigeil thie, ny ayr as moir, ny braaraghyn, ny ben, ny cloan, er graih reeriaght Yee,

English: 30 Who shall not receive manifold more in this present time, and in the world to come life everlasting.
Manx: Nagh vow ymmodee fillaghyn smoo ’sy traa t’ayn nish, as ayns y theihll ta ry heet yn vea veayn.

English: 31 ¶Then he took unto him the twelve, and said unto them, Behold, we go up to Jerusalem, and all things that are written by the prophets concerning the Son of man shall be accomplished.
Manx: Eisht ghow Eh huggey yn daa ostyl yeig, as dooyrt Eh roo, Cur-my-ner ta shin goll seose gys Jerusalem, as bee dy chooilley nhee ta scruit liorish ny phadeyryn, mychione yn Mac dooinney, cooilleenit.

English: 32 For he shall be delivered unto the Gentiles, and shall be mocked, and spitefully entreated, and spitted on:
Manx: Son bee Eh er ny livrey hucsyn jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaagh, as nee ad craidey mysh, as bee Eh dellit dy roonagh rish, as shellaghyn ceaut er ;

English: 33 And they shall scourge him, and put him to death: and the third day he shall rise again.
Manx: As custee ad Eh, as ver ad Eh gy baase ; as y tress laa nee Eh girree reesht.

English: 34 And they understood none of these things: and this saying was hid from them, neither knew they the things which were spoken.
Manx: As cha hoig ad veg jeh ny reddyn shoh : va’n raa shoh kellit vow, cha-moo va fys oc er ny reddyn va loayrit.

English: 35 ¶And it came to pass, that as he was come nigh unto Jericho, a certain blind man sat by the way side begging:
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, tra v’eh er jeet er-gerrey da Jericho, dy row dooinney doal dy row ny hoie rish liattee yn raad, shirrey jeirk.

English: 36 And hearing the multitude pass by, he asked what it meant.
Manx: As tra cheayll Eh yn pobble goll shiaghey, dênee Eh cre v’ayn.

English: 37 And they told him, that Jesus of Nazareth passeth by.
Manx: As dinsh ad da, dy row Yeesey dy Nazaaeth [sic] goll shiaghey.

English: 38 And he cried, saying, Jesus, thou son of David, have mercy on me.
Manx: As deïe Eh, gra, Yeesey, vac Ghavid, jean myghin orrym.

English: 39 And they which went before rebuked him, that he should hold his peace: but he cried so much the more, Thou son of David, have mercy on me.
Manx: As hug y vooinjer hie roish oghsan da, son dy jinnagh Eh e hengey y chummal : agh deïe eshyn wheesh shen smoo, Vac Ghavid, jean myghin orrym.

English: 40 And Jesus stood, and commanded him to be brought unto him: and when he was come near, he asked him,
Manx: As hass Yeesey, as hug Eh saarey Eh dy ve er ny choyrt lesh huggey : as tra v’eh er jeet er-gerrey, dênee Eh jeh,

English: 41 Saying, What wilt thou that I shall do unto thee? And he said, Lord, that I may receive my sight.
Manx: Gra, Cre baïlt mee dy yannoo er dty hon? As dooyrt Eh, Hiarn, dy voddym my hoilshey y gheddyn.

English: 42 And Jesus said unto him, Receive thy sight: thy faith hath saved thee.
Manx: As dooyrt Yeesey rish, Gow dty hoilshey : ta dty chredjue er dty hauail.

English: 43 And immediately he received his sight, and followed him, glorifying God: and all the people, when they saw it, gave praise unto God.
Manx: As chelleeragh hooar Eh e hoilshey, as deiyr Eh er, cur gloyr da Jee ; as ooilley yn pobble, tra honnick ad eh, hug ad moylley da Jee.
CAB. XIX.

English: And Jesus entered and passed through Jericho.
Manx: As hie Yeesey stiagh, as jimmee Eh trooid Jericho.

English: 2 And, behold, there was a man named Zacchaeus, which was the chief among the publicans, and he was rich.
Manx: As cur-my-ner, va dooinney va enmyssit Zaccheus, va’n dooinney byrjey va mastey ny publicanee, as v’eh berchagh.

English: 3 And he sought to see Jesus who he was; and could not for the press, because he was little of stature.
Manx: As v’eh shirrey Yeesey y akin quoi v’eh, as cha dod Eh kyndagh rish y pobble, son v’eh jeh aase beg.

English: 4 And he ran before, and climbed up into a sycomore tree to see him: for he was to pass that way.
Manx: As roih Eh roish, as hie Eh seose er billey-sycamore dy gheddyn shilley jeh ; son v’eh dy gholl shiaghey yn raad shen.

English: 5 And when Jesus came to the place, he looked up, and saw him, and said unto him, Zacchaeus, make haste, and come down; for to day I must abide at thy house.
Manx: As tra va Yeesey er jeet gys yn ynnyd, yeeagh Eh seose, as honnick Eh Eh, as dooyrt Eh rish, Zaccheus, jean siyr, as tar neose ; son jiu ta mish dy ve ec dty hie.

English: 6 And he made haste, and came down, and received him joyfully.
Manx: As ren Eh siyr, as haink Eh neose, as doltee Eh e vea gys e hie lesh boggey.

English: 7 And when they saw it, they all murmured, saying, That he was gone to be guest with a man that is a sinner.
Manx: As tra honnick ad shoh, v’ad ooilley jymmoosagh, gra, Dy row Eh er gholl stiagh dy ee as dy iu marish dooinney dy ghrogh vea.

English: 8 And Zacchaeus stood, and said unto the Lord: Behold, Lord, the half of my goods I give to the poor; and if I have taken any thing from any man by false accusation, I restore him fourfold.
Manx: As hass Zaccheus, as dooyrt Eh rish y Chiarn, Cur-my-ner, Hiarn, yn derrey lieh jeh my chooid ta mee dy choyrt da ny boghtyn : as my ta mee er ghoaill red erbee dy molteragh veih dooinney erbee, ta mee cur lhiassaghey da kiare-filley.

English: And Jesus said unto him, This day is salvation come to this house, forsomuch as he also is a son of Abraham.
Manx: 9. As dooyrt Yeesey rish, Jiu ta saualtys er jeet gys y thie shoh, ayns wheesh as dy vel eshyn myrgeddin ny vac da Abraham.

English: For the Son of man is come to seek and to save that which was lost.
Manx: 10. Son ta’n Mac dooinney er jeet dy hirrey as dy hauail shen ny va caillit.

English: 11 And as they heard these things, he added and spake a parable, because he was nigh to Jerusalem, and because they thought that the kingdom of God should immediately appear.
Manx: As erreish daue shoh y chlashtyn, hie Eh ny sodjey er e hoshiaght, as loayr Eh coraa-dorraghey, er-y-fa dy row Eh er-gerrey da Jerusalem, as liorish dy row ad smooinaghtyn dy row reeriaght Yee dy chelleeragh dy ve er ny hoilshaghey :

English: 12 He said therefore, A certain nobleman went into a far country to receive for himself a kingdom, and to return.
Manx: Dooyrt Eh er-y-fa shen, Hie dooinney ooasle dy row gys cheer foddey, dy gheddyn er e hon hene reeriaght, as dy heet back reesht.

English: 13 And he called his ten servants, and delivered them ten pounds, and said unto them, Occupy till I come.
Manx: As deïe Eh er ny jeih sharvaantyn echey, as livrey Eh daue jeih puint, as dooyrt Eh roo, Jean-jee dellal derrey higgym.

English: 14 But his citizens hated him, and sent a message after him, saying, We will not have this man to reign over us.
Manx: Agh hug fir-vaghee yn un ard-valley rish feoh da, as hug ad chaghteraght geiyrt er, gra, Cha naillin yn dooinney shoh dy reill harrin.

English: 15 And it came to pass, that when he was returned, having received the kingdom, then he commanded these servants to be called unto him, to whom he had given the money, that he might know how much every man had gained by trading.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, tra v’eh er jeet back, erreish da yn reeriaght y gheddyn, dy dug Eh saarey ny sharvaantyn shoh dy ve eit huggey, daue v’eh er choyrt yn argid, dy voddagh fys ve echey, cre-woad va dy chooilley ghooinney er chosney liorish dellal.

English: 16 Then came the first, saying, Lord, thy pound hath gained ten pounds.
Manx: Eisht haink y chied er, gra, Hiarn, ta dty phunt er chosney jeih puint.

English: 17 And he said unto him, Well, thou good servant: because thou hast been faithful in a very little, have thou authority over ten cities.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish, Smie shen, harvaant vie : er-yn-oyr dy vel oo er ny ve firrinagh ayns red feer fardalagh, ta’n reill dy ve ayd er jeih ard-valjyn.

English: 18 And the second came, saying, Lord, thy pound hath gained five pounds.
Manx: As haink yn nah er, gra, Hiarn, ta dty phunt er chosney queig puint.

English: 19 And he said likewise to him, Be thou also over five cities.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh myrgeddin rishyn, Ta reill dy ve ayds neesht er queig ard-valjyn.

English: 20 And another came, saying, Lord, behold, here is thy pound, which I have kept laid up in a napkin:
Manx: As haink fer elley, gra, Hiarn, cur-my-ner, shoh dty phunt, t’er ny ve ayms tashtit ayns naptin :

English: 21 For I feared thee, because thou art an austere man: thou takest up that thou layedst not down, and reapest that thou didst not sow.
Manx: Son va mee ayns aggle royd, er-y-fa dy nee dooinney oo ta creoi dy ghellal rhyt : t’ow troggal shen nagh dug oo sheese, as buinn yn red nagh chuirr oo.

English: 22 And he saith unto him, Out of thine own mouth will I judge thee, thou wicked servant. Thou knewest that I was an austere man, taking up that I laid not down, and reaping that I did not sow:
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish, Ass dty veeal hene nee’m oo y vriwnys, ghrogh harvaant. Va fys ayd dy row mee dooinney creoi dy ve dellit rish, troggal shen nagh dug mee sheese, as buinn yn red nagh chuirr mee :

English: 23 Wherefore then gavest not thou my money into the bank, that at my coming I might have required mine own with usury?
Manx: Cre’n-fa nagh dug oo my argid raad t’ad jannoo vondeish liorish argid y yeeasaght, ec y cheet aym, dy voddin v’er droggal my chooid hene lesh bishaghey.

English: 24 And he said unto them that stood by, Take from him the pound, and give it to him that hath ten pounds.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roosyn va nyn shassoo liorish, Gow-jee veih yn punt, as cur-jee eh dasyn ta jeih puint echey.

English: 25 (And they said unto him, Lord, he hath ten pounds.)
Manx: (As dooyrt ad rish, Hiarn, ta jeih puint echey.)

English: 26 For I say unto you, That unto every one which hath shall be given; and from him that hath not, even that he hath shall be taken away from him.
Manx: Son ta mee gra riu, Da dy chooilley annane ta echey, vees er ny choyrt : as eshyn nagh vel echey, bee shen hene ny ta echey er ny ghoaill ersooyl veih.

English: 27 But those mine enemies, which would not that I should reign over them, bring hither, and slay them before me.
Manx: Agh my noidyn shen nagh row booiagh mish dy reill harrystoo, cur lhiat ad ayns shoh, as cur ad gy baase kiongoyrt rhym.

English: 28 ¶And when he had thus spoken, he went before, ascending up to Jerusalem.
Manx: As tra v’eh er ghra shoh, hie Eh rhymboo, myr v’ad goll seose gys Jerusalem.

English: 29 And it came to pass, when he was come nigh to Bethphage and Bethany, at the mount called the mount of Olives, he sent two of his disciples,
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, tra v’ad er jeet er-gerrey da Bethphage as Bethany, ec y chronck va enmyssit cronck ny Oliveyn, dy dug Eh jees jeh’n vooinjer va sheer marish er chaghteraght,

English: 30 Saying, Go ye into the village over against you; in the which at your entering ye shall find a colt tied, whereon yet never man sat: loose him, and bring him hither.
Manx: Gra, Gow-jee gys y balley-beg ta shiu dy akin ; as cha leah as vees shiu er gholl stiagh ayn, yiow shiu lhie kainlt, urree nagh ren rieau dooinney markiagh : feayshyl-jee as cur cur-jee lhieu ee ayns shoh.

English: 31 And if any man ask you, Why do ye loose him? thus shall ye say unto him, Because the Lord hath need of him.
Manx: As my ênys dooinney erbee jiu, Cre’n fa ta shiu dy eaysley ee? shoh myr nee shiu gra rish, Er-y-fa dy vel feme ec y Chiarn urree.

English: 32 And they that were sent went their way, and found even as he had said unto them.
Manx: As hie adsyn v’er nyn goyrt, rhymboo, hooar ad eh myr v’eh er ghra roo.

English: 33 And as they were loosing the colt, the owners thereof said unto them, Why loose ye the colt?
Manx: As myr v’ad feaysley yn lhie, dooyrt y vooinjer by liesh ee roo, Cre’n-fa ta shiu feaysley yn lhie?

English: 34 And they said, The Lord hath need of him.
Manx: As dooyrt adsyn, Ta feme ec y Chiarn urree.

English: 35 And they brought him to Jesus: and they cast their garments upon the colt, and they set Jesus thereon.
Manx: As hug ad lhieu ee gys Yeesey : as hug ad nyn eaddagh er y lhie, as hug ad Yeesey ny hoie er yn eaddagh.

English: 36 And as he went, they spread their clothes in the way.
Manx: As myr v’eh goll, skeayl ad nyn gharmadyn er y raad.

English: 37 And when he was come nigh, even now at the descent of the mount of Olives, the whole multitude of the disciples began to rejoice and praise God with a loud voice for all the mighty works that they had seen;
Manx: As tra v’eh er jeet er-gerrey, liorish dy row Eh er y raad sheese veih cronck ny Oliveyn, ren y slane sheshaght jeh’n vooinjer va sheer marish toshiaght dy ghoaill boggey, as dy chur moylley da Jee lesh ard choraa, son ooilley ny obbraghyn pooaral v’ad er ny akin,

English: 38 Saying, Blessed be the King that cometh in the name of the Lord: peace in heaven, and glory in the highest.
Manx: Gra, Bannit dy row yn Ree ta cheet ayns ennym y Chiarn : shee ayns niau, as gloyr ayns yn yrjid.

English: 39 And some of the Pharisees from among the multitude said unto him, Master, rebuke thy disciples.
Manx: As dooyrt paart jeh ny Phariseeyn rish veih mastey’n pobble, Vainshtyr, cur oghsan da’n vooinjer ta sheer geiyrt ort.

English: 40 And he answered and said unto them, I tell you that, if these should hold their peace, the stones would immediately cry out.
Manx: As dreggyr eshyn, as dooyrt Eh roo, Ta mee ginsh diu, my chummagh ad shoh nyn jengey, dy jinnagh ny claghyn chelleeragh geamagh.

English: 41 ¶And when he was come near, he beheld the city, and wept over it,
Manx: As tra v’eh er jeet er-gerrey, yeeagh Eh er yn ard-valley, as cheayn Eh er e son,

English: 42 Saying, If thou hadst known, even thou, at least in this thy day, the things which belong unto thy peace! but now they are hid from thine eyes.
Manx: Gra, Dy beagh toiggal er ve ayds, dy jarroo ayds, ayns dty laa shoh hene, jeh ny reddyn ta bentyn rish dty hee! agh nish t’ad follit veih dty hooyllyn.

English: 43 For the days shall come upon thee, that thine enemies shall cast a trench about thee, and compass thee round, and keep thee in on every side,
Manx: Son hig ny laghyn ort, tra nee dty noidjyn jeeg y yannoo mood, as soie-ee ad ad hene mygeayrt, as cruinnee ad oo stiagh er dy chooilley hiew.

English: 44 And shall lay thee even with the ground, and thy children within thee; and they shall not leave in thee one stone upon another; because thou knewest not the time of thy visitation.
Manx: As lieggee ad oo kiart rish y thalloo, as dty chloan cheu-sthie jeed ; as cha vaag ad aynyd un chlagh er clagh elley: er-y-fa nagh dug oo tastey da’n earish haink mish dy dty yeeaghyn.

English: 45 And he went into the temple, and began to cast out them that sold therein, and them that bought;
Manx: As hie Eh stiagh ayns y chiamble, as ren Eh toshiaght dy eiyrt magh yn vooinjer va creck as kionnaghey ayn,

English: 46 Saying unto them, It is written, My house is the house of prayer: but ye have made it a den of thieves.
Manx: Gra roo, Te scruit, My hie’s thie yn phadjer : agh ta shiuish er n’yannoo eh ny ooig dy vaarlee.

English: 47 And he taught daily in the temple. But the chief priests and the scribes and the chief of the people sought to destroy him,
Manx: As dynsee Eh gagh laa ayns y chiamble. Agh va ny ard-saggyrtyn, as ny scruderyn, as leeideilee yn pobble shirrey Eh y stroie,

English: 48 And could not find what they might do: for all the people were very attentive to hear him.
Manx: As cha row fys oc cre yinnagh ad : son va ooilley’n pobble as ny aignaghyn oc soit dy eaishtagh rish.
CAB. XX.

English: And it came to pass, that on one of those days, as he taught the people in the temple, and preached the gospel, the chief priests and the scribes came upon him with the elders,
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, er annane jeh ny laghyn shen, myr v’eh gynsaghey yn pobble ayns y chiamble as preacheil y sushtal, dy ren ny ard-saggyrtyn, as ny scruderyn soiaghey er, marish y chanstyr,

English: 2 And spake unto him, saying, Tell us, by what authority doest thou these things? or who is he that gave thee this authority?
Manx: As loayr ad rish, gra, Insh dooin, Cre’n phooar t’ayd dy yannoo ry [sic: ny] reddyn shoh? ny quoi Eh hug y phooar shoh dhyt?

English: 3 And he answered and said unto them, I will also ask you one thing; and answer me:
Manx: As dreggyr eshyn as dooyrt Eh roo, Fênyms jiuish myrgeddin un red; as freggyr-jee mee :

English: 4 The baptism of John, was it from heaven, or of men?
Manx: Bashtey Ean, nee veih niau ve, ny veih deiney?

English: 5 And they reasoned with themselves, saying, If we shall say, From heaven; he will say, Why then believed ye him not?
Manx: As loayr ad nyn mast’ oc hene, gra, My jir mad, Veih niau ; jir eshyn, Cre’n-fa eisht nagh chred shiu eh?

English: 6 But and if we say, Of men; all the people will stone us: for they be persuaded that John was a prophet.
Manx: Agh my jir mad, Veih deiney ; nee ooilley’n pobble nyn glaghey shin ; son t’ad dy shickyr credjal Ean dy ve ny adeyr.

English: 7 And they answered, that they could not tell whence it was.
Manx: As dreggyr ad, nagh row ad abyl insh cre voish v’eh.

English: 8 And Jesus said unto them, Neither tell I you by what authority I do these things.
Manx: As dooyrt Yeesey roo, Cha-moo inshyms diuish cre’n phooar t’aym dy yannoo ny reddyn shoh.

English: 9 Then began he to speak to the people this parable; A certain man planted a vineyard, and let it forth to husbandmen, and went into a far country for a long time.
Manx: Eisht ren Eh toshiaght dy loayrt rish y pobble yn coraa-dorraghey shoh: Va dooinney dy row ren garey-feeney y hoiaghey, as hoie Eh eh rish fir-hie, as hie Eh gys cheer foddey son choud shen dy hraa.

English: 10 And at the season he sent a servant to the husbandmen, that they should give him of the fruit of the vineyard: but the husbandmen beat him, and sent him away empty.
Manx: As ec yn imbagh, hug Eh fer-mooinjerey gys ny fir-hie, dy voddagh ad coyrt da jeh mess y gharey-feeney : agh woaill ny fir-hie Eh, as hug ad Eh ersooyl follym.

English: 11 And again he sent another servant: and they beat him also, and entreated him shamefully, and sent him away empty.
Manx: As reesht hug Eh fer-mooinjerey elley ; as woaill ad eshyn myrgeddin, as ghell ad dy scammyltagh rish, as hug ad Eh ersooyl follym.

English: 12 And again he sent a third: and they wounded him also, and cast him out.
Manx: As reesht hug Eh yn tress ; as vroo ad eshyn myrgeddin, as deiyr ad Eh ersooyl.

English: 13 Then said the lord of the vineyard, What shall I do? I will send my beloved son: it may be they will reverence him when they see him.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt chiarn y gharey-feeney, Cre nee’m? Verrym huc my vac graihagh : foddee dy der ad arrym da tra hee ad Eh.

English: 14 But when the husbandmen saw him, they reasoned among themselves, saying, This is the heir: come, let us kill him, that the inheritance may be ours.
Manx: Agh tra honnick ny fir-hie Eh, loayr ad eddyr ad hene, gra, Shoh’n eirey : tar-jee, lig dooin Eh y varroo, dy vod yn eiraght ve lhien hene.

English: 15 So they cast him out of the vineyard, and killed him. What therefore shall the lord of the vineyard do unto them?
Manx: Myr shen cheau ad Eh magh ass y gharey-feeney, as varr ad Eh. Cre nee chiarn y gharey-feeney er-y-fa shen roo?

English: 16 He shall come and destroy these husbandmen, and shall give the vineyard to others. And when they heard it, they said, God forbid.
Manx: Hig Eh as stroie-ee Eh ny fir-hie shoh, as ver Eh yn garey-feeney da feallagh elley. As tra cheayll ad shen, dooyrt ad, Nar lig eh Jee.

English: 17 And he beheld them, and said, What is this then that is written, The stone which the builders rejected, the same is become the head of the corner?
Manx: As yeeagh Eh orroo, as dooyrt Eh, Cre shoh eisht ta scruit, Ta’n chlagh ren adsyn va troggal y thie y vee-lowal, er jeet dy ve yn ard chlagh chorneilagh?

English: 18 Whosoever shall fall upon that stone shall be broken; but on whomsoever it shall fall, it will grind him to powder.
Manx: Quoi-erbee huittys er y chlagh shen, bee Eh er ny vroo : agh quoi-erbee huittys y chlagh shen er, nee ee cha meen as joan jeh.

English: 19 ¶And the chief priests and the scribes the same hour sought to lay hands on him; and they feared the people: for they perceived that he had spoken this parable against them.
Manx: As va ny ard-saggyrtyn as ny scruderyn ayns yn oor cheddin shirrey Eh y ghoaill ; agh ghow ad aggle roish y pobble : son dennee ad dy row Eh er loayrt yn coraa-dorraghey shoh noi ocsyn.

English: 20 And they watched him, and sent forth spies, which should feign themselves just men, that they might take hold of his words, that so they might deliver him unto the power and authority of the governor.
Manx: As va sooyl oc er, as hug ad magh feallagh va ry hoi y hayrn Eh ayns ribbeh liorish e ghoan, as v’ad dy lhiggey orroo dy nee deiney cairagh v’ad, dy voddagh ad Eh y hayrtyn ayns e ghlare, as myr shen Eh y livrey gys pooar as reill y chiannoort.

English: 21 And they asked him, saying, Master, we know that thou sayest and teachest rightly, neither acceptest thou the person of any, but teachest the way of God truly:
Manx: As dênee ad jeh, gra, Vainshtyr, ta fys ain dy vel oo loayrt as gynsaghey dy cairagh ; cha-moo t’ow soiaghey jeh persoonyn, agh gynsaghey raad Yee dy firrinagh

English: 22 Is it lawful for us to give tribute unto Caesar, or no?
Manx: Vel eh lowal dooin keesh y eeck da Cesar, mannagh vel?

English: 23 But he perceived their craftiness, and said unto them, Why tempt ye me?
Manx: Agh dennee Eh yn foalsaght oc, as dooyrt Eh roo, Cre’n-fa ta shiu shirrey da my ghoaill ayns ribbeh?

English: 24 Shew me a penny. Whose image and superscription hath it? They answered and said, Caesar’s.
Manx: Jeeagh-jee dou ping : quoi gys ta’n jalloo as y screeu t’er bentyn? Dreggyr ad as dooyrt ad, gys Cesar.

English: 25 And he said unto them, Render therefore unto Caesar the things which be Caesar’s, and unto God the things which be God’s.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Eeck-jee er-y-fa shen da Cesar ny reddyn ta lesh Cesar ; as da Jee ny reddyn ta lesh Jee.

English: 26 And they could not take hold of his words before the people: and they marvelled at his answer, and held their peace.
Manx: As cha row ad abyl Eh y ghoaill ayns ribbeh liorish e ghoan kiongoyrt rish y pobble : as ghow ad yindyss jeh’n ansoor echey, as chum ad nyn jengey.

English: 27 ¶Then came to him certain of the Sadducees, which deny that there is any resurrection; and they asked him,
Manx: Eisht haink huggey shiartance jeh ny Saduceeyn (ta gobbal yn irree-seose-reesht dy ve ayn) as dênee ad jeh,

English: 28 Saying, Master, Moses wrote unto us, If any man’s brother die, having a wife, and he die without children, that his brother should take his wife, and raise up seed unto his brother.
Manx: Gra, Vainshtyr, ta Moses er scrieu dooin, My ta braar dooinney erbee geddyn baase, as ben echey, as Eh dy gheddyn baase fegooish chloan, dy vel e vraar dy phoosey’n ven echey, as dy hroggal seose sluight gys e vraar.

English: 29 There were therefore seven brethren: and the first took a wife, and died without children.
Manx: Va er-y-fa shen shiaght braaraghyn : as hooar y chied vraar, tra v’eh er phoosey ben, baase fegooish cloan.

English: 30 And the second took her to wife, and he died childless.
Manx: As ghow yn nah vraar ee son ben, as hooar eshyn baase dyn chloan.

English: 31 And the third took her; and in like manner the seven also: and they left no children, and died.
Manx: As ghow yn tress ee ; as er yn aght cheddin yn chiaght. As cha daag ad cloan, as hooar ad baase.

English: 32 Last of all the woman died also.
Manx: Er-jerrey ooilley hooar y ven baase myrgeddin.

English: 33 Therefore in the resurrection whose wife of them is she? for seven had her to wife.
Manx: Ec yn irree-reesht er-y-fa shen, quoi jeu vees ee echey son ben? son v’ee ny ben da’n chiaght.

English: 34 And Jesus answering said unto them, The children of this world marry, and are given in marriage:
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh roo, Ta cloan y theihll shoh poosey, as er nyn goyrt ayns poosey :

English: 35 But they which shall be accounted worthy to obtain that world, and the resurrection from the dead, neither marry, nor are given in marriage:
Manx: Agh adsyn vees coontit feeu jeh’n theihll shen, as jeh’n irree-reesht veih ny merriu, cha vel ad poosey, ny er nyn goyrt ayns poosey.

English: 36 Neither can they die any more: for they are equal unto the angels; and are the children of God, being the children of the resurrection.
Manx: Cha-moo oddys ad baase y gheddyn arragh ; son t’ad corrym rish ny ainlyn, as nyn gloan dy Yee, liorish dy nee cloan yn irree-seose-reesht ad.

English: 37 Now that the dead are raised, even Moses shewed at the bush, when he calleth the Lord the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.
Manx: Nish dy nirree ny merriu, hoilshee Moses hene ec y thammag, tra t’eh genmyss y Chiarn, Jee Abraham, as Jee Isaac, as Jee Yacob.

English: 38 For he is not a God of the dead, but of the living: for all live unto him.
Manx: Son cha nee Jee ny merriu Eh, agh Jee ny bio : son ta ooilley bio huggeysyn.

English: 39 ¶Then certain of the scribes answering said, Master, thou hast well said.
Manx: Eisht dreggyr shiartance jeh ny scruderyn, as dooyrt ad, Vainshtyr, t’ow er ghra dy mie.

English: 40 And after that they durst not ask him any question at all.
Manx: As ny lurg shen, cha by-loys daue question erbee sodjey y ênaght jeh.

English: 41 And he said unto them, How say they that Christ is David’s son?
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Kys t’ad gra dy nee Creest mac Ghavid?

English: 42 And David himself saith in the book of Psalms, The Lord said unto my Lord, Sit thou on my right hand,
Manx: As dy vel David Eh hene ayns lioar ny psalmyn gra, Dooyrt y Chiarn rish my Hiarn’s, Soie uss er my laue yesh,

English: 43 Till I make thine enemies thy footstool.
Manx: Derrey verrym dty noidyn son stoyl fo dty chassyn.

English: 44 David therefore calleth him Lord, how is he then his son?
Manx: Ta David er-y-fa shen genmyss Eh ny Hiarn, kys t’eh eisht yn mac echey?

English: 45 ¶Then in the audience of all the people he said unto his disciples,
Manx: Eisht ayns clashtyn ooilley yn pobble, dooyrt Eh rish y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er,

English: 46 Beware of the scribes, which desire to walk in long robes, and love greetings in the markets, and the highest seats in the synagogues, and the chief rooms at feasts;
Manx: Cur-jee twoaie jeh ny scruderyn, ta booiagh ve shooyl ayns coamraghyn liaurey, as shynney lhieu sleih dy vannaghey daue ayns ny margaghyn, as ny stuill syrjey y ve oc, ayns kialteenyn, as ny ard ynnydyn-soie ec cuirraghyn :

English: 47 Which devour widows’ houses, and for a shew make long prayers: the same shall receive greater damnation.
Manx: T’ad cur mow thieyn mraane-treoghe, as lhiggey orroo dy bee ad foddey ec padjer : ta kerraghey strimmey nyn gouyr oc shoh.
CAB. XXI.

English: And he looked up, and saw the rich men casting their gifts into the treasury.
Manx: As yeeagh Eh seose, as honnick Eh ny deiney berchagh tilgey ny giootyn oc ayns kishtey yn stoyr.

English: 2 And he saw also a certain poor widow casting in thither two mites.
Manx: As honnick Eh myrgeddin ben voght treoghe dy row, tilgey ayn daa vite.

English: 3 And he said, Of a truth I say unto you, that this poor widow hath cast in more than they all:
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Ayns firrinys ta mee gra riu, dy vel y ven voght treoghe shoh er hilgey ayn ny smoo na t’ad ooilley.

English: 4 For all these have of their abundance cast in unto the offerings of God: but she of her penury hath cast in all the living that she had.
Manx: Son t’ad shoh ooilley ass nyn balchey er chur gys ourallyn Yee : agh tie ish ass y ghennid eck er hilgey ayn ooilley ny v’eck dy veaghey er.

English: 5 ¶And as some spake of the temple, how it was adorned with goodly stones and gifts, he said,
Manx: As myr va paart loayrt jeh’n chiamble, kys ve er ny hoiaghey magh lesh claghyn aalin, as giootyn, dooyrt Eh,

English: 6 As for these things which ye behold, the days will come, in the which there shall not be left one stone upon another, that shall not be thrown down.
Manx: Son ny reddyn shoh ta shiu dy akin, hig ny laghyn, tra nagh bee faagit un chlagh er clagh elley nagh bee tilgit sheese.

English: 7 And they asked him, saying, Master, but when shall these things be? and what sign will there be when these things shall come to pass?
Manx: As dênee ad jeh, gra, Vainshtyr, agh cooin vees ny reddyn shoh? as cre’n cowrey vees tra hig ny reddyn shoh gy kione?

English: 8 And he said, Take heed that ye be not deceived: for many shall come in my name, saying, I am Christ; and the time draweth near: go ye not therefore after them.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Cur-jee twoaie nagh bee shiu er nyn molley : son hig ymmodee ayns m’ennym’s, gra, Mish Creest ; as ta’n traa tayrn er-gerrey : ny gow-jee shiuish er-y-fa shen geiyrt orroo.

English: 9 But when ye shall hear of wars and commotions, be not terrified: for these things must first come to pass; but the end is not by and by.
Manx: Agh tra chlinnys shiu jeh caggaghyn as irree-magh, ny bee aggle erriu : son shegin da ny reddyn shoh hoshiaght cheet gy kione, agh cha bee yn jerrey foast.

English: 10 Then said he unto them, Nation shall rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom:
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Eh roo, Nee ashoon girree noi ashoon, as reeriaght noi reeriaght.

English: 11 And great earthquakes shall be in divers places, and famines, and pestilences; and fearful sights and great signs shall there be from heaven.
Manx: As bee craaghyn-thallooin mooar ayns ymmodee ynnydyn, as gennaghyn, as crampyn, as shillaghyn agglagh, as bee cowraghyn mooarey veih niau.

English: 12 But before all these, they shall lay their hands on you, and persecute you, delivering you up to the synagogues, and into prisons, being brought before kings and rulers for my name’s sake.
Manx: Agh roish ooilley shoh, ver ad nyn laueyn erriu, as nee ad tranlaase y yannoo erriu, as shiu y livrey seose gys quaiyllyn, as gys pryssoonyn, as bee shiu er nyn goyrt fenish reeaghyn as fir-reïl er coontey yn ennym aym’s.

English: 13 And it shall turn to you for a testimony.
Manx: As myr shoh taghyrt dy ve son feanish diu.

English: 14 Settle it therefore in your hearts, not to meditate before what ye shall answer:
Manx: Soie-jee eh er-y-fa shen ayns nyn greeaghyn, gyn shiu dy smooinaghtyn ro-laue, cre nee shiu y reggyrt.

English: 15 For I will give you a mouth and wisdom, which all your adversaries shall not be able to gainsay nor resist.
Manx: Son verryms diu beeal as creenaght, nagh bee ooilley nyn noidjyn abyl loayrt ny shassoo noi.

English: 16 And ye shall be betrayed both by parents, and brethren, and kinsfolks, and friends; and some of you shall they cause to be put to death.
Manx: As bee shiu er nyn mrah chammah liorish ayraghyn as moiraghyn, as braaraghyn, as deiney mooinjerey, as caarjyn ; as ver ad er paart eu ve er nyn goyrt gy baase.

English: 17 And ye shall be hated of all men for my name’s sake.
Manx: As ver dy chooilley ghooinney feoh diu kyndagh rish yn ennym aym’s.

English: 18 But there shall not an hair of your head perish.
Manx: Agh cha jed renaig jeh’n chione eu mow.

English: 19 In your patience possess ye your souls.
Manx: Liorish y surranse eu freillee shiu sauchey nyn anmeenyn.

English: 20 And when ye shall see Jerusalem compassed with armies, then know that the desolation thereof is nigh.
Manx: As tra hee shiu sheshaghtyn-caggee mygeayrt Jerusalem, eisht toig-jee dy vel y traartys echey er-gerrey.

English: 21 Then let them which are in Judaea flee to the mountains; and let them which are in the midst of it depart out; and let not them that are in the countries enter thereinto.
Manx: Eisht lig dauesyn ta ayns Judea, roih gys ny sleïtyn ; as lig dauesyn ta sthie ayns main ny cheerey, goll rowe ass ; as ny lig dauesyn ta mooie er y cheer goll back reesht.

English: 22 For these be the days of vengeance, that all things which are written may be fulfilled.
Manx: Son ad shoh laghyn y chooilleeney, dy vod dy chooilley nhee ta scruit ve jeant mie.

English: 23 But woe unto them that are with child, and to them that give suck, in those days! for there shall be great distress in the land, and wrath upon this people.
Manx: Agh smerg dauesyn ta torragh, as dauesyn ta cur keeagh ayns ny laghyn shen : son bee trimshey mooar ayns y cheer, as corree noi yn pobble shoh.

English: 24 And they shall fall by the edge of the sword, and shall be led away captive into all nations: and Jerusalem shall be trodden down of the Gentiles, until the times of the Gentiles be fulfilled.
Manx: As tuittee ad er foyr y chliwe, as bee ad er nyn ghoaill ersooyl nyn gappeeyn gys dy chooilley ashoon : as bee Jerusalem er ny stampey sheese lioroosyn jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaagh, derrey vees earishyn ny Ashoonyn-quaagh er nyn gooilleeney.

English: 25 And there shall be signs in the sun, and in the moon, and in the stars; and upon the earth distress of nations, with perplexity; the sea and the waves roaring;
Manx: As bee cowraghyn ayns y ghrian, as ayns yn aist, as ayns ny rollaagyn ; as er y thalloo seaghyn ashoonyn, as angaish ; yn faarkey, as ny tonnyn echey feiyral ;

English: 26 Men’s hearts failing them for fear, and for looking after those things which are coming on the earth: for the powers of heaven shall be shaken.
Manx: Creeaghyn deiney dyn vailleil ad lesh aggle, as lesh jeeaghyn jeih ny reddyn shen ta cheet er y thalloo : son bee pooaraghyn yn aer er nyn graa.

English: 27 And then shall they see the Son of man coming in a cloud with power and great glory.
Manx: As eisht hee ad yn Mac dooinney cheet ayns bodjal lesh pooar as gloyr vooar.

English: 28 And when these things begin to come to pass, then look up, and lift up your heads; for your redemption draweth nigh.
Manx: As tra nee ny reddyn shoh toshiaght dy heet gy kione, eisht jeeagh-jee seose, as trog-jee seose nyn ghing ; son ta’n livrey eu tayrn er-gerrey.

English: 29 And he spake to them a parable; Behold the fig tree, and all the trees;
Manx: As loayr Eh roo coraa-dorraghey, Cur-jee my-ner yn billey-figgagh as ooilley ny biljyn ;

English: 30 When they now shoot forth, ye see and know of your own selves that summer is now nigh at hand.
Manx: Tra t’ad nish cur magh duillagyn, ta shiu fakin as toiggal jiu hene, dy vel y sourey er-gerrey.

English: 31 So likewise ye, when ye see these things come to pass, know ye that the kingdom of God is nigh at hand.
Manx: Myr shen myrgeddin shiuish, tra hee shiu ny reddyn shoh cheet gy kione, toig-jee dy vel reeriaght Yee er-gerrey.

English: 32 Verily I say unto you, This generation shall not pass away, till all be fulfilled.
Manx: Dy firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Roish my vow yn cheeloghe shoh baase, dy bee ooilley cooilleenit.

English: 33 Heaven and earth shall pass away: but my words shall not pass away.
Manx: Nee niau as thalloo cherraghtyn, agh my ghoan’s cha jean cherraghtyn.

English: 34 ¶And take heed to yourselves, lest at any time your hearts be overcharged with surfeiting, and drunkenness, and cares of this life, and so that day come upon you unawares.
Manx: As cur-jee twoaie diu hene, er aggle ec traa erbee dy bee ny creeaghyn eu rouyr laadit lesh jooid as meshtyrys, as kiarrail y vea shoh, as myr shen yn laa shen dy heet erriu gyn yss.

English: 35 For as a snare shall it come on all them that dwell on the face of the whole earth.
Manx: Son myr ribbeh hig eh er orroosyn ooilley ta vaghey er eaghtyr ooilley’n thalloo.

English: 36 Watch ye therefore, and pray always, that ye may be accounted worthy to escape all these things that shall come to pass, and to stand before the Son of man.
Manx: Bee-jee er nyn dwoaie er-y-fa shen, as guee-jee kinjagh, dy vod shiu ve coontit feeu dy scapail ooilley ny reddyn shoh hig gy kione, as dy hassoo kiongoyrt rish yn Mac dooinney.

English: 37 And in the day time he was teaching in the temple; and at night he went out, and abode in the mount that is called the mount of Olives.
Manx: As ayns y laa v’eh gynsaghey ayns y chiamble, as ec yn oie goll magh, as goaill aaght ec y chronck ta enmyssit cronck ny Oliveyn.

English: 38 And all the people came early in the morning to him in the temple, for to hear him.
Manx: As va ooilley’n pobble cheet huggey dy moghey gys y chiamble, dy eaishtagh rish.
CAB. XXII.

English: Now the feast of unleavened bread drew nigh, which is called the Passover.
Manx: Nish va feailley yn arran millish tayrn er-gerrey, ta enmyssit y Chaisht.

English: 2 And the chief priests and scribes sought how they might kill him; for they feared the people.
Manx: As va ny ard-saggyrtyn as ny scruderyn shirrey cre’n aght oddagh ad Eh y choyrt gy baase ; son v’ad ayns aggle roish y pobble.

English: 3 ¶Then entered Satan into Judas surnamed Iscariot, being of the number of the twelve.
Manx: Eisht hie yn drogh-spyrryd stiagh ayns Yuaase va slennooit Iscariot, va jeh earroo yn daa ostyl yeig.

English: 4 And he went his way, and communed with the chief priests and captains, how he might betray him unto them.
Manx: As hie Eh roish, as loayr Eh rish ny ard-saggyrtyn as ny captanyn, mychione Eh y vrah daue.

English: 5 And they were glad, and covenanted to give him money.
Manx: As ghow adsyn boggey, as ren ad conaant dy chur argid da.

English: 6 And he promised, and sought opportunity to betray him unto them in the absence of the multitude.
Manx: As hug Eh gialdyn, as ve’h [sic: v’eh] shirrey caa dy vrah eh tra nagh beagh y pobble marish.

English: 7 ¶Then came the day of unleavened bread, when the passover must be killed.
Manx: Eisht haink laa yn arran millish, tra va’n Eayn-caisht dy ve er ny varroo.

English: 8 And he sent Peter and John, saying, Go and prepare us the passover, that we may eat.
Manx: As hug Eh magh Peddyr as Ean, gra, Immee-jee, as aarlee-jee yn Eayn-caisht, dy vod mad gee.

English: 9 And they said unto him, Where wilt thou that we prepare?
Manx: As dooyrt ad rish, C’raad saïlt shin dy yannoo aarloo?

English: 10 And he said unto them, Behold, when ye are entered into the city, there shall a man meet you, bearing a pitcher of water; follow him into the house where he entereth in.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Cur-my-ner, tra vees shiu er gholl stiagh ayns yn ard-valley, hig dooinney nyn guail vees saagh-craie dy ushtey echey ; eiyr-jee er gys y thie hed Eh stiagh ayn.

English: 11 And ye shall say unto the goodman of the house, The Master saith unto thee, Where is the guestchamber, where I shall eat the passover with my disciples?
Manx: As abbyr-jee rish y far-thie yn thie, Ta’n Mainshtyr gra rhyt, Cre vel shamyr ny goaldee, raad nee’m yn Eayn-caisht y ee maroosyn ta sheer geiyrt orrym?

English: 12 And he shall shew you a large upper room furnished: there make ready.
Manx: As jeeaghee Eh diu ard-room mooar vees soit magh : ayns shen jean-jee aarloo.

English: 13 And they went, and found as he had said unto them: and they made ready the passover.
Manx: As hie ad as hooar ad myr v’eh er ghra roo : as daarlee ad yn Eayn-caisht.

English: 14 And when the hour was come, he sat down, and the twelve apostles with him.
Manx: As tra va’n oor er jeet hoie eh sheese as y daa ostyl yeig marish.

English: 15 And he said unto them, With desire I have desired to eat this passover with you before I suffer:
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Lesh yeearree jeean ta mee er ve aignagh yn Eayn-caisht shoh y ee mêriu roish my jean-ym surranse.

English: 16 For I say unto you, I will not any more eat thereof, until it be fulfilled in the kingdom of God.
Manx: Son ta mee gra riu, Nagh nee-ym maghey shoh jeh, derrey vees eh cooilleenit ayns reeriaght Yee.

English: 17 And he took the cup, and gave thanks, and said, Take this, and divide it among yourselves:
Manx: As ghow Eh yn cappan, as hug Eh booise, as dooyrt Eh, Gow-jee shoh, as reynn-jee eh ny mast’ eu hene.

English: 18 For I say unto you, I will not drink of the fruit of the vine, until the kingdom of God shall come.
Manx: Son ta mee gra riu, Nagh niu-ym jeh mess y villey-feeney, derrey hig reeriaght Yee.

English: 19 ¶And he took bread, and gave thanks, and brake it, and gave unto them, saying, This is my body which is given for you: this do in remembrance of me.
Manx: As ghow Eh arran, as hug Eh booise, as vrish Eh eh, as hug Eh eh daue, gra, Shoh my chorp t’er ny choyrt er nyn son eu : shoh jean-jee ayns cooinaghtyn jeem’s.

English: 20 Likewise also the cup after supper, saying, This cup is the new testament in my blood, which is shed for you.
Manx: As er yn aght cheddin yn cappan lurg shibber, gra, Yn cappan shoh yn conaant noa ayns my uill’s, t’er ny gheayrtey er nyn son eu.

English: 21 ¶But, behold, the hand of him that betrayeth me is with me on the table.
Manx: Agh cur-my-ner, ta’n laue echyssyn ta dy my vrah, mârym er y voayrd.

English: 22 And truly the Son of man goeth, as it was determined: but woe unto that man by whom he is betrayed
Manx: As dy firrinagh ta’n Mac dooinney goll myr ve er ny oardaghey : agh smerg da’n dooinney shen liorish t’eh er ny vrah.

English: 23 And they began to enquire among themselves, which of them it was that should do this thing.
Manx: As ren ad toshiaght dy vriaght nyn mast’ oc hene, quoi oc yinnagh shoh y yannoo.
