English: 24 ¶And there was also a strife among them, which of them should be accounted the greatest.
Manx: Nish va streeu myrgeddin nyn mast’ oc, quoi jeu syrjey veagh coontit.

English: 25 And he said unto them, The kings of the Gentiles exercise lordship over them; and they that exercise authority upon them are called benefactors.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Ta reeaghyn ny Ashoonyn-quaagh gymmyrkey reill harrystoo ; as t’adsyn t’ayns pooar nyn mastey, enmyssit deiney ooasle.

English: 26 But ye shall not be so: but he that is greatest among you, let him be as the younger; and he that is chief, as he that doth serve.
Manx: Agh cha bee shiuish myr shen : agh quoi-erbee syrjey ta nyn mast’ eu, lig Eh ve myr y fer-saa ; as eshyn ta goaill y raad, myr y fer ta shirveish.

English: 27 For whether is greater, he that sitteth at meat, or he that serveth? is not he that sitteth at meat? but I am among you as he that serveth.
Manx: Son quoi syrjey, eshyn ta ny hoie ec bee, ny’n fer ta shirveish? nagh nee eshyn ta ny hoie ec bee? agh ta mish nyn mast’ eu myr y fer ta shirveish.

English: 28 Ye are they which have continued with me in my temptations.
Manx: She shiuish t’er hannaghtyn mârym ayns my violaghyn.

English: 29 And I appoint unto you a kingdom, as my Father hath appointed unto me;
Manx: As ta mee pointeil diu reeriaght, myr ta my Ayr er phointeil dooys :

English: 30 That ye may eat and drink at my table in my kingdom, and sit on thrones judging the twelve tribes of Israel.
Manx: Dy vod shiu gee as giu ec my voayrd ayns my reeriaght, as soie er stuill-reeoil, briwnys daa heeloghe yeig Israel.

English: 31 ¶And the Lord said, Simon, Simon, behold, Satan hath desired to have you, that he may sift you as wheat:
Manx: As dooyrt y Chiarn, Simon, Simon, cur-my-ner, ta’n Noid-anmey er yeearree shiuish y ve echey, dy chreearey shiu myr curnaght :

English: 32 But I have prayed for thee, that thy faith fail not: and when thou art converted, strengthen thy brethren.
Manx: Agh ta mish er ghuee er dty hon’s, nagh jean dty chredjue failleil ; as tra vees oo er jyndaa, niartee dty vraaraghyn.

English: 33 And he said unto him, Lord, I am ready to go with thee, both into prison, and to death.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish, Hiarn, ta mish aarloo dy gholl mârt chammah gys pryssoon, as gys baase.

English: 34 And he said, I tell thee, Peter, the cock shall not crow this day, before that thou shalt thrice deny that thou knowest me.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Ta mee ginsh dhyt, Pheddyr, roish my gerr y kellagh jiu, dy nob uss three keayrtyn dy nione dhyt mee.

English: 35 And he said unto them, When I sent you without purse, and scrip, and shoes, lacked ye any thing? And they said, Nothing.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Tra hug mee shiu magh fegooish sporran, as spagey, as braagyn, row nhee erbee dy laccal erriu? As dooyrt ad, Cha row nhee erbee.

English: 36 Then said he unto them, But now, he that hath a purse, let him take it, and likewise his scrip: and he that hath no sword, let him sell his garment, and buy one.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Eh roo, Agh nish eshyn ta sporran echey, lig da y ghoaill eh, as myrgeddin e spagey : as eshyn nagh vel cliwe echey, lig Eh e gharmad y chreck, as cliwe y chionnaghey.

English: 37 For I say unto you, that this that is written must yet be accomplished in me, And he was reckoned among the transgressors: for the things concerning me have an end.
Manx: Son ta mee gra riu, Dy negin da shoh ny ta scruit, ve foast cooilleenit aynyms, As v’eh er ny earroo marish ny drogh-yantee : son ta jerrey er ny reddyn ta my my-chiones.

English: 38 And they said, Lord, behold, here are two swords. And he said unto them, It is enough.
Manx: As dooyrt ad, Hiarn, cur-my-ner ta daa chliwe ayns shoh, As dooyrt Eh roo, Te dy liooar.

English: 39 ¶And he came out, and went, as he was wont, to the mount of Olives; and his disciples also followed him.
Manx: As haink Eh magh, as hie Eh, myr v’eh cliaghtey, gys cronk ny Oliveyn ; as deiyr ny ostyllyn myrgeddin er.

English: 40 And when he was at the place, he said unto them, Pray that ye enter not into temptation.
Manx: As tra v’eh ec yn ynnyd, dooyrt Eh roo, Guee-jee, nagh duit shiu ayns miolagh.

English: 41 And he was withdrawn from them about a stone’s cast, and kneeled down, and prayed,
Manx: As hie Eh vow, mysh choud as hilgagh fer clagh, as huit Eh er e ghlioonyn, as ghuee Eh,

English: 42 Saying, Father, if thou be willing, remove this cup from me: nevertheless not my will, but thine, be done.
Manx: Gra, Ayr, my she dty aigney eh, scugh yn cappan shoh voym : ny-yeih cha nee m’aigney’s, agh dt’aigney’s dy row jeant.

English: 43 And there appeared an angel unto him from heaven, strengthening him.
Manx: As haink huggey ainle veih niau, dy niartaghey Eh,

English: 44 And being in an agony he prayed more earnestly: and his sweat was as it were great drops of blood falling down to the ground.
Manx: As v’eh ayns angaish vooar, as ghow Eh padjer ny s’jeeanney : as va’n ollish echey myr bineyn mooarey foalley tuittym gys y thalloo.

English: 45 And when he rose up from prayer, and was come to his disciples, he found them sleeping for sorrow,
Manx: As tra v’eh er n’irree veih padjer, as er jeet gys e ostyllyn, hooar Eh ad nyn gadley lesh trimshey,

English: 46 And said unto them, Why sleep ye? rise and pray, lest ye enter into temptation.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Cre’n-fa ta shiu cadley? irree-jee as guee-jee, nagh duit shiu ayns miolagh.

English: 47 ¶And while he yet spake, behold a multitude, and he that was called Judas, one of the twelve, went before them, and drew near unto Jesus to kiss him.
Manx: As choud as v’eh foast loayrt, cur-my-ner, haink sheshaght vooar, as eshyn va enmyssit Yuaase, fer jeh’n daa ostyl yeig, shooyl rhymboo, as hayrn Eh er-gerrey da Yeesey dy chur paag da.

English: 48 But Jesus said unto him, Judas, betrayest thou the Son of man with a kiss?
Manx: Agh dooyrt Yeesey rish, Yuaase, vel oo brah Mac dooinney lesh paag?

English: 49 When they which were about him saw what would follow, they said unto him, Lord, shall we smite with the sword?
Manx: Tra honnick adsyn va mygeayrt y mysh cre va ry heet, dooyrt ad rish, Hiarn, bwoail mayd lesh y chliwe?

English: 50 ¶And one of them smote the servant of the high priest, and cut off his right ear.
Manx: As woaill fer jeu fer-mooinjerey yn ard-saggyrt, as yiare Eh yn chleash yesh jeh.

English: 51 And Jesus answered and said, Suffer ye thus far. And he touched his ear, and healed him.
Manx: As dreggyr Yeesey, as dooyrt Eh, Slioar shoh hene. As venn Eh rish e chleash, as laanee Eh eh.

English: 52 Then Jesus said unto the chief priests, and captains of the temple, and the elders, which were come to him, Be ye come out, as against a thief, with swords and staves?
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Yeesey rish ny ard-saggyrtyn as captanyn y chiamble, as y chanstyr v’er jeet magh huggey, Vel shiu er jeet magh, myr noi maarlagh, lesh cliwnyn as luirg?

English: 53 When I was daily with you in the temple, ye stretched forth no hands against me: but this is your hour, and the power of darkness.
Manx: Tra va mee mêriu gagh laa ayns y chiamble, cha heeyn shiu magh nyn laueyn m’oi : agh shoh yn oor eu, as pooar y dorraghys.

English: 54 ¶Then took they him, and led him, and brought him into the high priest’s house. And Peter followed afar off.
Manx: Eisht ghow ad Eh, as leeid ad as hug ad lhieu Eh gys thie yn ard-saggyrt. As deiyr Peddyr er foddey ny yei.

English: 55 And when they had kindled a fire in the midst of the hall, and were set down together, Peter sat down among them.
Manx: As tra v’ad er voddey aile ayns main y hall, as er hoie sheese cooidjagh, hoie Peddyr sheese nyn mast’ oc.

English: 56 But a certain maid beheld him as he sat by the fire, and earnestly looked upon him, and said, This man was also with him.
Manx: Agh hug ben-aeg dy row tastey da, myr v’eh ny hoie ec yn aile, as yeeagh ee dy gyere er, as dooyrt ee, V’eh shoh myrgeddin marish.

English: 57 And he denied him, saying, Woman, I know him not.
Manx: As dob Eh, gra, Ven, cha vel enney aym er.

English: 58 And after a little while another saw him, and said, Thou art also of them. And Peter said, Man, I am not.
Manx: As tammylt ny lurg shen, honnick fer elley Eh, as dooyrt Eh, She fer jeu myrgeddin uss. As dooyrt Peddyr, Ghooinney, cha nee.

English: 59 And about the space of one hour after another confidently affirmed, saying, Of a truth this fellow also was with him: for he is a Galilaean.
Manx: As mysh oor ny lurg shen, hass fer elley er dy creoi, gra, Ayns firrinys v’eh shoh myrgeddin marish ; son she Galilean eh.

English: 60 And Peter said, Man, I know not what thou sayest. And immediately, while he yet spake, the cock crew.
Manx: As dooyrt Peddyr, Ghooinney, cha vel fys aym cre t’ow dy ghra. As chelleeragh, choud as v’eh foast loayrt, gherr y kellagh.

English: 61 And the Lord turned, and looked upon Peter. And Peter remembered the word of the Lord, how he had said unto him, Before the cock crow, thou shalt deny me thrice.
Manx: As hyndaa yn Chiarn, as yeeagh Eh er Peddyr; as chooinee Peddyr er y fockle va’n Chiarn er ghra rish, Roish my gerr y kellagh, nee uss mish y obbal three keayrtyn.

English: 62 And Peter went out, and wept bitterly.
Manx: As hie Peddyr magh, as cheayn Eh dy sharroo.

English: 63 ¶And the men that held Jesus mocked him, and smote him.
Manx: As ren ny deiney va cummal Yeesey craidey mysh, [as] y woalley Eh.

English: 64 And when they had blindfolded him, they struck him on the face, and asked him, saying, Prophesy, who is it that smote thee?
Manx: As tra v’ad er choodaghey ny sooyllyn echey, woaill ad Eh er yn eddin, as dênee ad jeh, gra, Jean phadeyrys, quoi ta dy dty woalley?

English: 65 And many other things blasphemously spake they against him.
Manx: As ymmodee reddyn elley loayr ad dy mollaghtagh noi.

English: 66 ¶And as soon as it was day, the elders of the people and the chief priests and the scribes came together, and led him into their council, saying,
Manx: As cha leah as va’n laa ayn, haink shanstyr yn pobble, as ny ard-saggyrtyn as ny scruderyn cooidjagh, as hug ad lhieu Eh gys y choonceil oc.

English: 67 Art thou the Christ? tell us. And he said unto them, If I tell you, ye will not believe:
Manx: Gra, Nee oo yn Creest? insh dooin. As dooyrt Eh roo, My inshym diu, cha jean shiu credjal.

English: 68 And if I also ask you, ye will not answer me, nor let me go.
Manx: As my neem’s myrgeddin shiuish y qhuestional, cha jean shiu my reggyrt, ny’n raad y lhiggey dou.

English: 69 Hereafter shall the Son of man sit on the right hand of the power of God.
Manx: Ny lurg shoh nee yn Mac dooinney soie er laue yesh pooar Yee.

English: 70 Then said they all, Art thou then the Son of God? And he said unto them, Ye say that I am.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt ad ooilley, Nee oo eisht Mac Yee? As dooyrt Eh roo, Ta shiuish gra dy nee.

English: 71 And they said, What need we any further witness? for we ourselves have heard of his own mouth.
Manx: As dooyrt ad, Cre’n feme sodjey t’ain er feanishyn? son ta shin hene er chlashtyn veih’n veeall echey.
CAB. XXIII.

English: And the whole multitude of them arose, and led him unto Pilate.
Manx: As dirree yn slane sheshaght jeu, as leeid ad Eh gys Pilate.

English: 2 And they began to accuse him, saying, We found this fellow perverting the nation, and forbidding to give tribute to Caesar, saying that he himself is Christ a King.
Manx: As ren ad toshiaght dy loayrt noi, gra, Hooar shin Eh shoh cur yn ashoon ain er shaghryn, as lhiettal sleih veih keesh y choyrt da Cesar, gra, Dy nee Eh hene Creest yn ree.

English: 3 And Pilate asked him, saying, Art thou the King of the Jews? And he answered him and said, Thou sayest it.
Manx: As dênee Pilate jeh, gra, Nee ree ny Hewnyn oo? As dreggyr Eh as dooyrt Eh, T’ow uss dy ghra eh.

English: 4 Then said Pilate to the chief priests and to the people, I find no fault in this man.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Pilate rish ny ard-saggyrtyn as rish y pobble, Cha vel mish er gheddyn foill erbee ayns y dooinney shoh.

English: 5 And they were the more fierce, saying, He stirreth up the people, teaching throughout all Jewry, beginning from Galilee to this place.
Manx: As loayr ad ny s’jymmo[o]see, gra, T’eh boirey yn pobble, gynsaghey trooid ooilley Judea, goaill toshiaght veih Galilee derrey shoh.

English: 6 When Pilate heard of Galilee, he asked whether the man were a Galilaean.
Manx: Tra cheayll Pilate jeh Galilee, dênee Eh nee Galilean va’n dooinney.

English: 7 And as soon as he knew that he belonged unto Herod’s jurisdiction, he sent him to Herod, who himself also was at Jerusalem at that time.
Manx: As cha leah as hooar Eh fys dy nee gys reill Herod v’eh bentyn, hug Eh Eh gys Herod, va myrgeddin Eh hene ec Jerusalem ec y traa shen.

English: 8 ¶And when Herod saw Jesus, he was exceeding glad: for he was desirous to see him of a long season, because he had heard many things of him; and he hoped to have seen some miracle done by him.
Manx: As tra honnick Herod Yeesey, v’eh feer wooiagh : son v’eh aignagh ry foddey dy akin Eh, er-yn-oyr dy row Eh er chlashtyn ymmodee reddyn jeh ; as dy row Eh treishteil dy akin mirril ennagh jeant liorish.

English: 9 Then he questioned with him in many words; but he answered him nothing.
Manx: Eisht dênee Eh ymmodee questionyn jeh ; agh cha dug Eh ansoor erbee da.

English: 10 And the chief priests and scribes stood and vehemently accused him.
Manx: As hass ny ard-saggyrtyn as ny scruderyn as loayr ad dy elgyssagh noi.

English: 11 And Herod with his men of war set him at nought, and mocked him, and arrayed him in a gorgeous robe, and sent him again to Pilate.
Manx: As ren Herod as e gheiney-caggee beg y hoiaghey jeh, as chraid ad mysh, as choamree ad Eh lesh coamrey gloyroil, as hug ad Eh reesht gys Pilate.

English: 12 ¶And the same day Pilate and Herod were made friends together: for before they were at enmity between themselves.
Manx: As y laa cheddin va coardail er ny yannoo eddyr Pilate as Herod ; son roie v’ad ayns noidys yn derrey yeh gys y jeh elley.

English: 13 ¶And Pilate, when he had called together the chief priests and the rulers and the people,
Manx: As deïe Pilate er ny ard-saggyrtyn cooidjagh, as er ny fir-reil as y pobble,

English: 14 Said unto them, Ye have brought this man unto me, as one that perverteth the people: and, behold, I, having examined him before you, have found no fault in this man touching those things whereof ye accuse him:
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Ta shiu er chur lhieu yn dooinney shoh hym’s, myr fer ta cur y pobble er shaghryn : as cur-my-ner, ta mish er veysht Eh kiongoyrt riu, as cha vel mee er gheddyn foill erbee ayns y dooinney shoh, mychione ny reddyn ta shiuish cur ny lieh ;

English: 15 No, nor yet Herod: for I sent you to him; and, lo, nothing worthy of death is done unto him.
Manx: Cha-moo ta Herod : son hug mee shiu huggeysyn, as cur-my-ner, cha vel nhee erbee ta toilchin baase er ny yannoo liorish.

English: 16 I will therefore chastise him, and release him.
Manx: Smaghtee-ym er-y-fa shen Eh, as liggym y raad da.

English: 17 (For of necessity he must release one unto them at the feast.)
Manx: Son beign da fer y eaysley daue ec yn eailley.

English: 18 And they cried out all at once, saying, Away with this man, and release unto us Barabbas:
Manx: As deïe ooilley’n cheshaght, gra, Ersooyl lesh y dooinney shoh, as feaysle dooin Barabbas :

English: 19 (Who for a certain sedition made in the city, and for murder, was cast into prison.)
Manx: (Va son irree-magh dy row, va jeant ayns yn ard-valley, as son dunverys tilgit ayns pryssoon.)

English: 20 Pilate therefore, willing to release Jesus, spake again to them.
Manx: Va Pilate er-y-fa shen booiagh feaysley choyrt da Yeesey, as loayr Eh reesht roo.

English: 21 But they cried, saying, Crucify him, crucify him.
Manx: Agh deïe adsyn, gra, Jean y chrossey Eh, Jean y chrossey Eh.

English: 22 And he said unto them the third time, Why, what evil hath he done? I have found no cause of death in him: I will therefore chastise him, and let him go.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo yn tress cheayrt, Cre’n oill t’eh er ny yannoo? cha vel mish er gheddyn oyr erbee baaish ayn : Smaghtee-ym Eh er-y-fa shen, as liggym y raad da.

English: 23 And they were instant with loud voices, requiring that he might be crucified. And the voices of them and of the chief priests prevailed.
Manx: As loayr ad ny s’jeeanney lesh ard choraaghyn, geearree Eh dy ve er ny chrossey : as ren y coraa ocsyn as coraa ny ard-saggyrtyn raad y ghoaill.

English: 24 And Pilate gave sentence that it should be as they required.
Manx: As hug Pilate briwnys cordail rish nyn yeearree.

English: 25 And he released unto them him that for sedition and murder was cast into prison, whom they had desired; but he delivered Jesus to their will.
Manx: As deaysle Eh daue, eshyn va son irree-magh as dunverys tilgit ayns pryssoon, Eh v’ad er n’yannoo aghin er e hon ; agh livrey Eh Yeesey gys nyn aigney.

English: 26 And as they led him away, they laid hold upon one Simon, a Cyrenian, coming out of the country, and on him they laid the cross, that he might bear it after Jesus.
Manx: As myr v’ad dy chur lhieu Eh, haare ad greme er Simon Cyrenian dy row, va cheet ass y cheer, as ersyn hug ad y chrosh, dy ymmyrkey eh geiyrt er Yeesey.

English: 27 ¶And there followed him a great company of people, and of women, which also bewailed and lamented him.
Manx: As deiyr er earroo mooar dy leïh, as dy vraane, va myrgeddin keayney as jannoo dobberan er e hon.

English: 28 But Jesus turning unto them said, Daughters of Jerusalem, weep not for me, but weep for yourselves, and for your children.
Manx: Agh hyndaa Yeesey huc, as dooyrt Eh, Inneenyn Yerusalem, ny keayn-jee er my hon’s, agh keayn-jee er nyn son hene, as son nyn gloan.

English: 29 For, behold, the days are coming, in the which they shall say, Blessed are the barren, and the wombs that never bare, and the paps which never gave suck.
Manx: Son cur-my-ner, ta ny laghyn cheet, tra jir ad, Bannit ta ny mraane gennish, as ny breïnyn nagh ren gymmyrkey, as ny keeaghyn nagh dug bainney.

English: 30 Then shall they begin to say to the mountains, Fall on us; and to the hills, Cover us.
Manx: Eisht nee ad toshiaght dy ghra rish ny sleïtyn, Tuit-jee orrin ; as rish ny cruinck, Coodee-jee shin.

English: 31 For if they do these things in a green tree, what shall be done in the dry?
Manx: Son my t’ad jannoo ny reddyn shoh rish y billey oor, cre vees er ny yannoo rish y billey creen?

English: 32 And there were also two other, malefactors, led with him to be put to death.
Manx: As va myrgeddin daa ghrogh-yantagh elley er nyn leeideil magh marish, dy ve er nyn goyrt gy baase.

English: 33 And when they were come to the place, which is called Calvary, there they crucified him, and the malefactors, one on the right hand, and the other on the left.
Manx: As tra v’ad er jeet gys yn ynnyd ta enmyssit Calvary, ayns shen ren ad eshyn y chrossey, as ny drogh-yantee ; yn derrey yeh er y laue yesh, as y jeh elley er y laue chiare.

English: 34 ¶Then said Jesus, Father, forgive them; for they know not what they do. And they parted his raiment, and cast lots.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Yeesey, Ayr, leih daue ; son cha s’oc cre t’ad dy yannoo. As reynn ad e choamrey, as hilg ad lottyn.

English: 35 And the people stood beholding. And the rulers also with them derided him, saying, He saved others; let him save himself, if he be Christ, the chosen of God.
Manx: As va’n pobble nyn shassoo jeeaghyn er : as mâroo ren ny fir-reïl myrgeddin gannidys er, as gra, Haue Eh feallagh elley ; lig da Eh-hene y hauail my she Creest reiht Yee Eh.

English: 36 And the soldiers also mocked him, coming to him, and offering him vinegar,
Manx: As va ny sidooryn myrgeddin craidey mysh, cheet huggey, as chebbal da vinegar,

English: 37 And saying, If thou be the king of the Jews, save thyself.
Manx: As gra, My she ree ny Hewnyn oo, saue oo hene.

English: 38 And a superscription also was written over him in letters of Greek, and Latin, and Hebrew, THIS IS THE KING OF THE JEWS.
Manx: As va’n screeu shoh myrgeddin soit er-skyn e chione, ayns letteryn dy Ghreek, as dy Latin, as dy Hebrew, SHOH REE NY HEWNYN.

English: 39 ¶And one of the malefactors which were hanged railed on him, saying, If thou be Christ, save thyself and us.
Manx: As ren fer jeh ny drogh-yantee v’er nyn groghey loayrt dy lunagh noi, gra, My she oo yn Creest, saue oo hene as shinyn.

English: 40 But the other answering rebuked him, saying, Dost not thou fear God, seeing thou art in the same condemnation?
Manx: Agh dreggyr y jeh elley, cur oghsan da, as gra, Nagh vel aggle ort roish Jee, fakin dy vel uss fo’n vriwnys cheddin?

English: 41 And we indeed justly; for we receive the due reward of our deeds: but this man hath done nothing amiss.
Manx: As shinyn dy jarroo dy cairagh ; son ta shin er gheddyn toilchinys cooie yn jannoo ain : agh cha vel y dooinney shoh er n’yannoo aggair erbee.

English: 42 And he said unto Jesus, Lord, remember me when thou comest into thy kingdom.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish Yeesey, Hiarn, cooinee orryms tra hig oo gys dty reeriaght.

English: 43 And Jesus said unto him, Verily I say unto thee, To day shalt thou be with me in paradise.
Manx: As dooyrt Yeesey rish, Dy firrinagh ta mee gra rhyt, Dy bee uss mâryms jiu ayns paradise.

English: 44 And it was about the sixth hour, and there was a darkness over all the earth until the ninth hour.
Manx: As ve mysh y cheyoo oor, as va dorraghys harrish ooilley yn cheer gys yn nuyhoo oor.

English: 45 And the sun was darkened, and the veil of the temple was rent in the midst.
Manx: As va’n ghrian dorraghey, as y coodaghey va eddyr y chiamble as yn ynnyd casherick ve rapit veih my chielley.

English: 46 ¶And when Jesus had cried with a loud voice, he said, Father, into thy hands I commend my spirit: and having said thus, he gave up the ghost.
Manx: As tra va Yeesey er n’eamagh lesh ard-choraa, dooyrt Eh, Ayr, gys dty laueyn ta mish chymney my spyrryd : as tra v’eh er ghra shoh, phaart Eh.

English: 47 Now when the centurion saw what was done, he glorified God, saying, Certainly this was a righteous man.
Manx: Nish tra honnick y captan-keead cre va er jeet gy kione, hug Eh moylley da Jee, gra, Ayns firrinys v’eh shoh ny ghooinney cairagh.

English: 48 And all the people that came together to that sight, beholding the things which were done, smote their breasts, and returned.
Manx: As ooilley yn pobble v’er jeet cooidjagh gys y shilley shen, hug ad my-ner ny reddyn va jeant, as woaill ad nyn gleeau, as haink ad rhymboo.

English: 49 And all his acquaintance, and the women that followed him from Galilee, stood afar off, beholding these things.
Manx: As ooilley’n sleih ainjyssagh echey, as ny mraane deiyr er veih Galilee, hass ad foddey veih cur ny reddyn shoh my-ner.

English: 50 ¶And, behold, there was a man named Joseph, a counsellor; and he was a good man, and a just:
Manx: As cur-my-ner va dooinney va enmyssit Joseph, va ny er-coyrlee, as ny ghooinney mie as cairagh :

English: 51 (The same had not consented to the counsel and deed of them;) he was of Arimathaea, a city of the Jews: who also himself waited for the kingdom of God.
Manx: (Cha row ayrn erbee ec Eh shoh ayns y choyrle ny’n jannoo oc) v’eh veih Arimathea, ard-valley jeh ny Hewnyn, (va myrgeddin Eh hene farkiaght son reeriaght Yee.)

English: 52 This man went unto Pilate, and begged the body of Jesus.
Manx: Hie Eh shoh gys Pilate, as deearree Eh corp Yeesey.

English: 53 And he took it down, and wrapped it in linen, and laid it in a sepulchre that was hewn in stone, wherein never man before was laid.
Manx: As ghow Eh neose eh, as hoïll Eh eh ayns aanrit, as doanluck Eh eh ayns oaie va cleyt ayns creg, ayn nagh row rieau dooinney oanluckit roie.

English: 54 And that day was the preparation, and the sabbath drew on.
Manx: As y laa shen va laa’n aarlaghey, as va’n doonaght tayrn er-gerrey.

English: 55 And the women also, which came with him from Galilee, followed after, and beheld the sepulchre, and how his body was laid.
Manx: As hie ny mraane myrgeddin haink marish veih Galilee geiyrt er y corp, as honnick ad yn oaie, as kys va’n corp er ny oanluckey.

English: 56 And they returned, and prepared spices and ointments; and rested the sabbath day according to the commandment.
Manx: As haink ad rhymboo, as hooar ad aarloo spisyn as ooillyn ; as ghow ad fea er laa’n doonaght cordail rish yn anney.
CAB. XXIV.

English: Now upon the first day of the week, very early in the morning, they came unto the sepulchre, bringing the spices which they had prepared, and certain others with them.
Manx: Nish er y chied laa jeh’n chaghtin, feer voghey ayns y voghrey, haink ad gys yn oaie, cur lhieu ny spisyn v’ad er gheddyn aarloo, as va mraane elley mâroo.

English: 2 And they found the stone rolled away from the sepulchre.
Manx: As hooar ad y chlagh rowlit ersooyl jeh’n oaie.

English: 3 And they entered in, and found not the body of the Lord Jesus.
Manx: As hie ad stiagh, as cha dooar ad corp y Chiarn Yeesey.

English: 4 And it came to pass, as they were much perplexed thereabout, behold, two men stood by them in shining garments:
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, tra v’ad ayns imnea mooar son shoh, cur-my-ner, hass daa ghooinney lioroo ayns coamraghyn sollys.

English: 5 And as they were afraid, and bowed down their faces to the earth, they said unto them, Why seek ye the living among the dead?
Manx: As myr v’ad agglagh, as croymmey sheese nyn eddinyn gys y thalloo, dooyrt ad roo, Cre’n-fa ta shiu shirrey yn vio mastey ny merriu?

English: 6 He is not here, but is risen: remember how he spake unto you when he was yet in Galilee,
Manx: Cha vel Eh ayns shoh, agh er n’irree : cooinee-jee cre loayr Eh riu tra v’eh ayns Galilee,

English: 7 Saying, The Son of man must be delivered into the hands of sinful men, and be crucified, and the third day rise again.
Manx: Gra, Shegin da’n Mac dooinney v’er ny livrey gys laueyn deiney peccoil, as ve er ny chrossey, as y tress laa girree reesht.

English: 8 And they remembered his words,
Manx: As chooinee ad er e ghoan,

English: 9 And returned from the sepulchre, and told all these things unto the eleven, and to all the rest.
Manx: As haink ad back veih yn oaie, as dinsh ad ooilley shoh da’n un ostyl yeig, as da ooilley’n vooinjer elley.

English: 10 It was Mary Magdalene and Joanna, and Mary the mother of James, and other women that were with them, which told these things unto the apostles.
Manx: She Moirrey Malaine, as Joanna as Moirrey moir Yamys, as mraane elley va mâroo, dinsh ny reddyn shoh da ny ostyllyn.

English: 11 And their words seemed to them as idle tales, and they believed them not.
Manx: As ghow ad y ghlare oc myr taggloo ommijagh, as cha dug ad geill daue.

English: 12 Then arose Peter, and ran unto the sepulchre; and stooping down, he beheld the linen clothes laid by themselves, and departed, wondering in himself at that which was come to pass.
Manx: Eisht dirree Peddyr as roih Eh gys yn oaie, as chroym Eh sheese, as honnick Eh ny haanrityn nyn lhie er-lheh, as jimmee Eh roish, goaill yindyss ec ny va er daghyrt.

English: 13 ¶And, behold, two of them went that same day to a village called Emmaus, which was from Jerusalem about threescore furlongs.
Manx: As cur-my-ner hie jees jeu yn laa cheddin gys balley va enmyssit Emmaus, va mysh shiaght veeilley as lieh veeilley veih Jerusalem.

English: 14 And they talked together of all these things which had happened.
Manx: As va taggloo oc eddyr ad mychione dy chooilley nhee va er daghyrt.

English: 15 And it came to pass, that, while they communed together and reasoned, Jesus himself drew near, and went with them.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, choud as v’ad taggloo as resooney ry cheiley, dy daink Yeesey hene er-gerrey, as dy jagh Eh mâroo.

English: 16 But their eyes were holden that they should not know him.
Manx: As va ny sooyllyn oc lhiettit nagh dug ad enney er.

English: 17 And he said unto them, What manner of communications are these that ye have one to another, as ye walk, and are sad?
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, cre ny naightyn shoh ta shiu dy insh yn derrey yeh da’n jeh elley, myr ta shiu shooyl dy trimshagh er y raad?

English: 18 And the one of them, whose name was Cleopas, answering said unto him, Art thou only a stranger in Jerusalem, and hast not known the things which are come to pass there in these days?
Manx: As dreggyr fer jeu, va’n ennym echey Cleopas, as dooyrt Eh rish, Vel uss d[t]y lomarcan dty yoarree ayns Jerusalem, as nagh vel fys ayd er ny reddyn t’ayns shen er jeet gy kione er ny laghyn shoh?

English: 19 And he said unto them, What things? And they said unto him, Concerning Jesus of Nazareth, which was a prophet mighty in deed and word before God and all the people:
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Cre ny reddyn? As dooyrt adsyn rish, Mychione Yeesey dy Nazareth, va ny adeyr, as pooaral ayns jannoo as goo, kiongoyrt rish Jee, as ooilley’n pobble :

English: 20 And how the chief priests and our rulers delivered him to be condemned to death, and have crucified him.
Manx: As kys ren ny ard-saggyrtyn as ny fir-reïl ain y livrey Eh dy ve er ny gheyrey gys baase, as t’ad er ny chrossey Eh.

English: 21 But we trusted that it had been he which should have redeemed Israel: and beside all this, to day is the third day since these things were done.
Manx: Agh va shinyn treishteil dy nee eshyn veagh er chur livrey da Israel : as marish shoh ooilley, jiu yn tress laa neayr as hie ny reddyn shoh er jannoo.

English: 22 Yea, and certain women also of our company made us astonished, which were early at the sepulchre;
Manx: Myrgeddin va shiartance dy vraane jeh’n cheshaght ain, hug orrin lane yindyss y ghoaill, liorish dy row ad dy moghey ec yn oaie :

English: 23 And when they found not his body, they came, saying, that they had also seen a vision of angels, which said that he was alive.
Manx: As tra nagh dooar ad yn corp echey, haink ad as dooyrt ad, dy row ad er vakin ashlish dy ainlyn, dinsh daue dy row Eh bio.

English: 24 And certain of them which were with us went to the sepulchre, and found it even so as the women had said: but him they saw not.
Manx: As hie shiartance jeusyn va mârinyn gys yn oaie, as hooar ad eh er yn eer aght myr va ny mraane er ghra ; agh eshyn cha vaik ad.

English: 25 Then he said unto them, O fools, and slow of heart to believe all that the prophets have spoken:
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Eh roo, O gheiney mee-hushtagh, as moall ayns cree dy chredjal ooilley ny ta ny phadeyryn er loayrt!

English: 26 Ought not Christ to have suffered these things, and to enter into his glory?
Manx: Nagh beign da Creest ny reddyn shoh y hurranse as goll stiagh ayns e ghloyr?

English: 27 And beginning at Moses and all the prophets, he expounded unto them in all the scriptures the things concerning himself.
Manx: As goaill toshiaght ec Moses, as ooilley ny phadeyryn, hug Eh tushtey daue ayns ooilley ny scriptyryn jeh ny reddyn va bentyn rish hene.

English: 28 And they drew nigh unto the village, whither they went: and he made as though he would have gone further.
Manx: As haink ad er-gerrey da’n balley, raad v’ad goll : as lig Eh er dy ragh Eh ny-sodjey.

English: 29 But they constrained him, saying, Abide with us: for it is toward evening, and the day is far spent. And he went in to tarry with them.
Manx: Agh lhie ad er, gra, Fuirree mârin, son ta’n fastyr faggys ayn, as ayrn vie jeh’n laa ceaut. As hie Eh stiagh dy uirriaght mâroo.

English: 30 And it came to pass, as he sat at meat with them, he took bread, and blessed it, and brake, and gave to them.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, myr v’eh ny hoie ec bee mâroo, dy ghow Eh arran, as vannee Eh, as vrish Eh, as heeyn Eh huc eh.

English: 31 And their eyes were opened, and they knew him; and he vanished out of their sight.
Manx: As va ny sooyllyn oc er nyn vosley, as hug ad enney er ; as hie Eh ersooyl ass nyn shilley.

English: 32 And they said one to another, Did not our heart burn within us, while he talked with us by the way, and while he opened to us the scriptures?
Manx: As dooyrt y derrey yeh jeu rish y jeh elley, Nagh row ny creeaghyn ain lossey cheu-sthie jin, choud as v’eh taggloo rooin er y raad, as choud as v’eh fosley dooin ny scriptyryn?

English: 33 And they rose up the same hour, and returned to Jerusalem, and found the eleven gathered together, and them that were with them,
Manx: As dirree ad seose yn oor cheddin, as haink ad back gys Jerusalem, as hooar ad yn un ostyl yeig er nyn jaglym cooidjagh, as adsyn va mâroo,

English: 34 Saying, The Lord is risen indeed, and hath appeared to Simon.
Manx: Gra, Ta’n Chiarn er n’irree dy jarroo, as v’eh er ny akin liorish Simon.

English: 35 And they told what things were done in the way, and how he was known of them in breaking of bread.
Manx: As dinsh ad cre ny reddyn va jeant er y raad, as kys hug ad enney er, tra v’eh brishey arran.

English: 36 ¶And as they thus spake, Jesus himself stood in the midst of them, and saith unto them, Peace be unto you.
Manx: As myr v’ad myr shoh loayrt, hass Yeesey hene ayns y vain oc, as dooyrt Eh roo, Shee dy row hiu.

English: 37 But they were terrified and affrighted, and supposed that they had seen a spirit.
Manx: Agh v’ad seaghnit ayns nyn aigney as agglit, as heill ad dy nee scaan v’ad dy akin.

English: 38 And he said unto them, Why are ye troubled? and why do thoughts arise in your hearts?
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Cre’n-fa ta shiu seaghnit, as cre’n-fa ta smooinaghtyn er n’irree ayns nyn greeaghyn?

English: 39 Behold my hands and my feet, that it is I myself: handle me, and see; for a spirit hath not flesh and bones, as ye see me have.
Manx: Jeeagh-jee er my laueyn as my chassyn, dy nee mish mee hene t’ayn : loaghtee-jee mee, as jeeagh-jee, son cha vel feill as craueyn ec scaan, myr hee shiu aym’s.

English: 40 And when he had thus spoken, he shewed them his hands and his feet.
Manx: As tra v’eh er ghra shoh, yeeagh Eh daue e laueyn as e chassyn.

English: 41 And while they yet believed not for joy, and wondered, he said unto them, Have ye have any meat?
Manx: As choud as nagh row ad foast credjal, kyndagh rish y boggey oc, agh goaill yindyss, dooyrt Eh roo, Vel veg y veaghey eu ayns shoh?

English: 42 And they gave him a piece of a broiled fish, and of an honeycomb.
Manx: As hug ad da peesh dy eeast roast as dy khere-volley.

English: 43 And he took it, and did eat before them.
Manx: As ghow Eh, as die Eh kiongoyrt roo.

English: 44 And he said unto them, These are the words which I spake unto you, while I was yet with you, that all things must be fulfilled, which were written in the law of Moses, and in the prophets, and in the psalms, concerning me.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Shoh ny goan loayr mish riu, choud as va mee foast mêriu, dy beign da dy chooilley nhee ve cooilleenit va scruit ayns leigh Voses, as ayns ny phadeyryn, as ayns ny psalmyn my-mychione’s.

English: 45 Then opened he their understanding, that they might understand the scriptures,
Manx: Eisht doshil Eh yn tushtey oc, dy voddagh ad ny scriptyryn, y hoiggal,

English: 46 And said unto them, Thus it is written, and thus it behoved Christ to suffer, and to rise from the dead the third day:
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Shoh myr te scruit, as shoh myr ve kiarit da Creest dy hurranse, as dy irree yn tress laa veih ny merriu :

English: 47 And that repentance and remission of sins should be preached in his name among all nations, beginning at Jerusalem.
Manx: As arrys as leih peccaghyn dy ve er nyn breacheil ayns yn ennym echey, mastey dy chooilley ashoon, goaill toshiaght ec Jerusalem.

English: 48 And ye are witnesses of these things.
Manx: As ta shiuish nyn veanishyn jeh ny reddyn shoh.

English: 49 ¶And, behold, I send the promise of my Father upon you: but tarry ye in the city of Jerusalem, until ye be endued with power from on high.
Manx: As cur-my-ner, Verryms hiu gialdyn my Ayr : agh fuirree-jee ayns ard-valley Yerusalem, derrey vees shiu coamrit lesh pooar veih’n yrjid.

English: 50 ¶And he led them out as far as to Bethany, and he lifted up his hands, and blessed them.
Manx: As leeid Eh ad magh choud as gys Bethany : as hrog Eh seose e laueyn as vannee Eh ad.

English: 51 And it came to pass, while he blessed them, he was parted from them, and carried up into heaven.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, choud as v’eh dyn mannaghey ad, dy row Eh er ny scarrey vow, as er ny hroggal seose gys niau.

English: 52 And they worshipped him, and returned to Jerusalem with great joy:
Manx: As hug ad ooashley da, as hyndaa ad gys Jerusalem lesh boggey mooar :

English: 53 And were continually in the temple, praising and blessing God. Amen.
Manx: As v’ad kinjagh ayns y chiamble, cur moylley as gloyr da Jee. Amen
Yn Sushtal scruit liorish yn Noo EAN.
CAB. I.

English: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.
Manx: Ayns y toshiaght va’n Goo, as va’n Goo marish Jee, as va’n Goo ny Yee.

English: The same was in the beginning with God.
Manx: 2. Va’n Goo cheddin ayns y toshiaght marish Jee.

English: 3 All things were made by him ; and without him was not any thing made that was made.
Manx: Va dy chooilley nhee er ny yannoo liorish ; as n’egooish cha row nhee erbee er ny yannoo va jeant.

English: 4 In him was life ; and the life was the light of men.
Manx: Aynsyn va bea, as va’n vea soilshey deiney.

English: 5 And the light shineth in darkness ; and the darkness comprehended it not.
Manx: As ren y soilshey soilshean ayns y dorraghys, as y dorraghys cha ren tastey ghoaill jeh.

English: 6 ¶There was a man sent from God, whose name was John.
Manx: Va dooinney er ny choyrt veih Jee va enmyssit Ean.

English: 7 The same came for a witness, to bear witness of the Light, that all men through him might believe.
Manx: Haink Eh shoh son feanish, dy ymmyrkey feanish jeh’n toilshey, liorishyn dy voddagh dy chooilley ghooinney credjal.

English: 8 He was not that Light, but was sent to bear witness of that Light.
Manx: Cha nee Eh va’n soilshey shen, agh v’eh er ny choyrt dy ymmyrkey feanish jeh’n toilshey shen.

English: 9 That was the true Light, which lighteth every man that cometh into the world.
Manx: Shen va’n soilshey firrinagh, ta soilshean er dy chooilley ghooinney ta cheet stiagh ayns y theihll.

English: 10 He was in the world, and the world was made by him, and the world knew him not.
Manx: V’eh ayns y theihll, as va’n seihll er ny yannoo liorish, as y seihll cha dug enney er.

English: 11 He came unto his own, and his own received him not.
Manx: Haink Eh gys ny va lesh hene, as cha ren e vooinjer hene soiaghey jeh.

English: 12 But as many as received him, to them gave he power to become the sons of God, even to them that believe on his name :
Manx: Agh da whilleen as ren soiaghey jeh, hug Eh pooar dy heet dy ve nyn meck dy Yee, liorish credjal ayns yn ennym echey :

English: 13 Which were born, not of blood, nor of the will of the flesh, nor of the will of man, but of God.
Manx: Dauesyn ruggyr, cha nee jeh fuill, ny jeh aigney ny foalley, ny jeh aigney dooinney, agh jeh Jee.

English: 14 And the Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us, (and we beheld his glory, the glory as of the only begotten of the Father,) full of grace and truth.
Manx: As va’n Goo er ny yannoo ny eill, as ren Eh vaghey nyn mast’ ain (as hug shin my-ner yn ghloyr echey, yn ghloyr myr jeh’n ynrycan Mac er ny gheddyn jeh’n Ayr) laane dy ghrayse as dy irrinys.

English: 15 ¶John bare witness of him, and cried, saying, This was he of whom I spake, He that cometh after me is preferred before me : for he was before me.
Manx: Dymmyrk Ean feanish jeh, as deïe Eh, gra, Shoh Eh jeh ren mish loayrt, Te eshyn ta cheet my yei er ny hoiaghey roym ; son v’eh roym.

English: 16 And of his fulness have all we received, and grace for grace.
Manx: As jeh’n slane towse echey ta shin ooilley er gheddy[n], as grayse son grayse.

English: 17 For the law was given by Moses, but grace and truth came by Jesus Christ.
Manx: Son va’n leigh er ny choyrt liorish Moses, agh haink grayse as firrinys liorish Yeesey Creest.

English: 18 No man hath seen God at any time, the only begotten Son, which is in the bosom of the Father, he hath declared him.
Manx: Cha vel annane erbee er vakin Jee ec traa erbee ; yn ynrycan Mac v’er ny gheddyn, ta ayns oghrish yn Ayr, eshyn t’er ny hoilshaghey Eh.

English: 19 ¶And this is the record of John, when the Jews sent priests and Levites from Jerusalem to ask him, Who art thou?
Manx: As shoh feanish Ean, tra hug ny Hewnyn saggyrtyn as Leviteyn veih Jerusalem dy ênaght jeh, Quoi oo?

English: 20 And he confessed, and denied not ; but confessed, I am not the Christ.
Manx: As ghow Eh rish, as cha dob Eh ; agh ghow Eh rish, Cha nee mish yn Creest.

English: 21 And they asked him, What then? Art thou Elias? And he saith, I am not. Art thou that prophet? And he answered, No.
Manx: As dênee ad jeh, Cre eisht? Nee oo Elias? As dooyrt eshyn, Cha nee. Nee oo yn phadeyr shen? As dansoor Eh, Cha nee.

English: 22 Then said they unto him, Who art thou? that we may give an answer to them that sent us. What sayest thou of thyself?
Manx: Eisht dooyrt ad rish, Quoi oo? dy vod mad ansoor y choyrt da’n vooinjer t’er nyn goyrt shin : Cre t’ow dy ghra my dty chione hene?

English: 23 He said, I am the voice of one crying in the wilderness, Make straight the way of the Lord, as said the prophet Esaias.
Manx: Dooyrt Eh, Mish coraa fer geamagh ayns yn aasagh, Jean-jee raad y Chiarn kiart, myr dooyrt y phadeyr Esaias.

English: 24 And they which were sent were of the Pharisees.
Manx: As adsyn v’er nyn goyrt, v’ad jeh ny Phariseeyn.

English: 25 And they asked him, and said unto him, Why baptizest thou then, if thou be not that Christ, nor Elias, neither that prophet?
Manx: As dênee ad jeh, as dooyrt ad rish, Cre’n-fa t’ow bashtey eisht, mannagh nee oo yn Creest, ny Elias, ny’n phadeyr shen?

English: 26 John answered them, saying, I baptize with water : but there standeth one among you, whom ye know not ;
Manx: Dreggyr Ean ad, gra, Ta mish bashtey lesh ushtey : agh ta fer ny hassoo nyn mast’ eu, nagh vel enney eu er ;

English: 27 He it is, who coming after me is preferred before me, whose shoe’s latchet I am not worthy to unloose.
Manx: Eshyn Eh ta cheet my yei, agh t’er ny hoiaghey roym, kiangley ny braagyn echey cha vel mish feeu dy eaysley.

English: 28 These things were done in Bethabara beyond Jordan, where John was baptizing.
Manx: Va ny reddyn shoh jeant ayns Bethabara er cheu elley jeh Jordan, raad va Ean bashtey.

English: 29 ¶The next day John seeth Jesus coming unto him, and saith, Behold the Lamb of God, which taketh away the sin of the world.
Manx: Yn nah laa honnick Ean Yeesey cheet huggey, as dooyrt Eh, Cur-my-ner Eayn Yee, ta goaill ersooyl peccah yn seihll.

English: 30 This is he of whom I said, After me cometh a man which is preferred before me : for he was before me.
Manx: Shoh Eh ta mish er loayrt jeh, My yei ta dooinney cheet, t’er ny hoiaghey roym ; son v’eh roym.

English: 31 And I knew him not : but that he should be made manifest to Israel, therefore am I come baptizing with water.
Manx: As cha row enney aym’s er : agh dy voddagh Eh ve soilshit da Israel, er-yn-oyr shen haink mish bashtey lesh ushtey.

English: 32 And John bare record, saying, I saw the Spirit descending from heaven like a dove, and it abode upon him.
Manx: As dymmyrk Ean feanish, gra, Honnick mee yn Spyrryd cheet neose veih niau myr calmane, as soie er.

English: 33 And I knew him not : but he that sent me to baptize with water, the same said unto me, Upon whom thou shalt see the Spirit descending, and remaining on him, the same is he which baptizeth with the Holy Ghost.
Manx: As cha dug mish enney er : agh eshyn ren mish y choyrt dy vashtey lesh ushtey, dooyrt Eh shen rhym, Er-syn hee oo yn Spyrryd cheet neose as soie, shen Eh ta bashtey lesh y Spyrryd Noo.

English: 34 And I saw, and bare record that this is the Son of God.
Manx: As honnick mee, as dymmyrk mee feanish, dy nee shoh Mac Yee.

English: 35 ¶Again the next day after John stood, and two of his disciples ;
Manx: Yn nah laa reesht va Ean ny hassoo, as jees jeusyn va sheer geiyrt er :

English: 36 And looking upon Jesus as he walked, he saith, Behold the Lamb of God
Manx: As yeeagh Eh er Yeesey, myr v’eh shooyl, as dooyrt Eh, Cur-my-ner Eayn Yee.

English: 37 And the two disciples heard him speak, and they followed Jesus.
Manx: As cheayll y jees va sheer marish Eh loayrt, as deiyr ad er Yeesey.

English: 38 Then Jesus turned, and saw them following, and saith unto them, What seek ye? They said unto him, Rabbi, (which is to say, being interpreted, Master,) where dwellest thou?
Manx: Eisht hyndaa Yeesey, as honnick Eh ad geiyrt er, as dooyrt Eh roo, Cre ta shiu dy hirrey? Dooyrt adsyn rish, Rabbi (ta shen dy ghra, tra ta bun er ny chur er, Vainshtyr) c’raad t’ow vaghey?

English: 39 He saith unto them, Come and see. They came and saw where he dwelt, and abode with him that day : for it was about the tenth hour.
Manx: Dooyrt Eh roo, Tar-jee as jeeagh-jee. Haink ad as honnick ad c’raad v’eh vaghey, as duirree ad marish yn laa shen : son ve mysh y jeihoo oor.

English: 40 One of the two which heard John speak, and followed him, was Andrew, Simon Peter’s brother.
Manx: Fer jeh’n jees cheayll Ean loayrt, as deiyr er, va Andreays, braar Simon Peddyr.

English: 41 He first findeth his own brother Simon, and saith unto him, We have found the Messias, which is, being interpreted, the Christ.
Manx: Hooar eshyn hoshiaght e vraar hene Simon, as dooyrt Eh rish, Ta shin er gheddyn yn Messias, ta shen, tra ta bun er ny chur er, yn Creest.

English: 42 And he brought him to Jesus. And when Jesus beheld him, he said, Thou art Simon the son of Jona : thou shalt be called Cephas, which is by interpretation, A stone.
Manx: As hug Eh lesh Eh gys Yeesey. As tra honnick Yeesey Eh, dooyrt Eh, Uss Simon mac Jona : bee oo enmyssit Cephas, liorish ta dy ve er ny hoiggal, clagh.

English: 43 ¶The day following Jesus would go forth into Galilee, and findeth Philip, and saith unto him, Follow me.
Manx: Yn laa er-giyn she aigney Yeesey ve dy gholl magh gys Galilee, as hooar Eh Philip, as dooyrt Eh rish, Eiyr orrym.

English: 44 Now Philip was of Bethsaida, the city of Andrew and Peter.
Manx: Nish va Philip ass Bethsaida, ard-valley Andreays as Peddyr.

English: 45 Philip findeth Nathanael, and saith unto him, We have found him, of whom Moses in the law, and the prophets, did write, Jesus of Nazareth, the son of Joseph.
Manx: Hooar Philip magh Nathanael, as dooyrt Eh rish, Ta shin er gheddyn eshyn, jeh ren Moses ayns y leigh, as ny phadeyryn scrieu, Yeesey dy Nazareth, mac Yoseph.

English: 46 And Nathanael said unto him, Can there any good thing come out of Nazareth? Philip saith unto him, Come and see.
Manx: As dooyrt Nathanael rish, Vod nhee erbee mie cheet magh ass Nazareth? Dooyrt Philip rish, Tar royd as hee oo.

English: 47 Jesus saw Nathanael coming to him, and saith of him, Behold an Israelite indeed, in whom is no guile
Manx: Honnick Yeesey Nathanael cheet huggey, as dooyrt Eh mychione echey, Cur-my-ner Israelite dy jarroo, ayn nagh vel molteraght erbee.

English: 48 Nathanael saith unto him, Whence knowest thou me? Jesus answered and said unto him, Before that Philip called thee, when thou wast under the fig tree, I saw thee.
Manx: Dooyrt Nathanael rish, Cre-woish ta enney ayd orryms? Dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh rish, Roish my deïe Philip ort, tra v’ow fo’n villey-figgagh, honnick mee oo.

English: 49 Nathanael answered and saith unto him, Rabbi, thou art the Son of God ; thou art the King of Israel.
Manx: Dreggyr Nathanael as dooyrt Eh rish, Rabbi, oo Mac Yee, oo ree Israel.

English: 50 Jesus answered and said unto him, Because I said unto thee, I saw thee under the fig tree, believest thou? thou shalt see greater things than these.
Manx: Dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh rish, Er-y-fa dy dooyrt mee rhyt, dy vaik mee oo fo’n billey-figgagh, vel oo credjal? hee oo reddyn smoo na shoh.

English: 51 And he saith unto him, Verily, verily, I say unto you, Hereafter ye shall see heaven open, and the angels of God ascending and descending upon the Son of man.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish, Dy firrinagh firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Ny lurg shoh hee shiu niau foshlit, as ainlyn Yee goll seose as cheet neose er y Mac dooinney.
CAB. II.

English: And the third day there was a marriage in Cana of Galilee ; and the mother of Jesus was there :
Manx: As er y tress laa va poosey ayns Cana dy Ghalilee ; as va moir Yeesey ayns shen.

English: 2 And both Jesus was called, and his disciples, to the marriage.
Manx: As va chammah Yeesey cuirt, as y vooinjer va sheer marish, gys y vannish.

English: 3 And when they wanted wine, the mother of Jesus saith unto him, They have no wine.
Manx: As tra v’ad laccal feeyn, dooyrt moir Yeesey rish, Cha vel feeyn oc.

English: 4 Jesus saith unto her, Woman, what have I to do with thee? mine hour is not yet come.
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey ree, Ven, cre’n eïe t’ayd orrym? cha vel my oor foast er jeet.

English: 5 His mother saith unto the servants, Whatsoever he saith unto you, do it.
Manx: Dooyrt e voir rish ny sharvaantyn, Jean-jee shiuish cre-erbee jir Eh riu.

English: 6 And there were set there six waterpots of stone, after the manner of the purifying of the Jews, containing two or three firkins apiece.
Manx: As va soit ayns shen shey siyn cloaie ry hoi ushtey, lurg aght niee ny Hewnyn, cummal ghaa ny three dy firkinyn y pheesh.

English: 7 Jesus saith unto them, Fill the waterpots with water. And they filled them up to the brim.
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey roo, Lhieen-jee ny siyn lesh ushtey. As lhieen ad ad seose gys y veeal.

English: 8 And he saith unto them, Draw out now, and bear unto the governor of the feast. And they bare it.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Tayrn-jee nish, as cur-jee lhieu gys fer-reïl y yien. As hug ad lhieu eh.

English: 9 When the ruler of the feast had tasted the water that was made wine, and knew not whence it was : (but the servants which drew the water knew ;) the governor of the feast called the bridegroom,
Manx: Tra va fer-reïl y yien er vlashtyn er yn ushtey va jeant ny eeyn, as nagh row fys echey cre-woish ve (agh va fys ec ny sharvaantyn va tayrn yn ushtey) deïe fer-reïl y yien er y dooinney-phoosee,

English: 10 And saith unto him, Every man at the beginning doth set forth good wine ; and when men have well drunk, then that which is worse : but thou hast kept the good wine until now.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rish, Ta dy chooilley g[h]ooinney ec y toshiaght cur magh feeyn mie ; as tra ta deiney er n’iu dy mie, eisht feeyn smessey : agh tow uss er vrealley yn feeyn mie derrey nish.

English: 11 This beginning of miracles did Jesus in Cana of Galilee, and manifested forth his glory ; and his disciples believed on him.
Manx: Yn toshiaght shoh dy virrilyn ren Yeesey ayns Cana dy Ghalilee, as hoilshee Eh magh e ghloyr ; as ren y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er credjal ayn.

English: 12 ¶After this he went down to Capernaum, he, and his mother, and his brethren, and his disciples : and they continued there not many days.
Manx: Ny lurg shen, hie Eh hene, as e voir, as e vraaraghyn, as y vooinjer va sheer marish sheese gys Capernaum ; as cha nimmey laa duirree ad ayns shen.

English: 13 And the Jews’ passover was at hand, and Jesus went up to Jerusalem.
Manx: As va Caisht ny Hewnyn er-gerrey, as hie Yeesey seose gys Jerusalem,

English: 14 And found in the temple those that sold oxen and sheep and doves, and the changers of money sitting :
Manx: As hooar Eh ayns y chiamble feallagh va creck deu, as kirree, as calmaneyn, as y vooinjer va caghlaa argid nyn soie :

English: 15 And when he had made a scourge of small cords, he drove them all out of the temple, and the sheep, and the oxen ; and poured out the changers’ money, and overthrew the tables ;
Manx: As tra v’eh er n’yannoo kip dy choyrdyn keylley, deiyr Eh ad ooilley ass y chiamble, as ny kirree, as ny deu ; as spreiy Eh magh yn argid ocsyn va caghlaa, as hilg Eh harrish ny buird ;

English: 16 And said unto them that sold doves, Take these things hence ; make not my Father’s house an house of merchandise.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roosyn va creck calmaneyn, Cur-jee lhieu ny reddyn shoh ass shoh ; ny jean-jee thie my Ayrey ny hie dy verchantys.

English: 17 And his disciples remembered that it was written, The zeal of thine house hath eaten me up.
Manx: As chooinee yn vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er dy row eh scruit, Ta graih jeean dty hie er my chur mow.

English: 18 ¶Then answered the Jews and said unto him, What sign shewest thou unto us, seeing that thou doest these things?
Manx: Eisht dreggyr ny Hewnyn, as dooyrt ad rish, Cre’n cowrey t’ow dy yeeaghyn dooin, fakin dy vel oo jannoo ny reddyn shoh?

English: 19 Jesus answered and said unto them, Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up.
Manx: Dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh roo, Lieg-jee yn chiamble shoh, as troggyms eh reesht ayns three laa.

English: 20 Then said the Jews, Forty and six years was this temple in building, and wilt thou rear it up in three days?
Manx: Eisht dooyrt ny Hewnyn, Shey bleeaney as da-eed va’n chiamble shoh dy hroggal, as drog uss eh ayns three laa?

English: 21 But he spake of the temple of his body.
Manx: Agh mychione chiamble e chorp hene loayr eshyn.

English: 22 When therefore he was risen from the dead, his disciples remembered that he had said this unto them ; and they believed the scripture, and the word which Jesus had said.
Manx: Shen-y-fa tra v’eh er n’irree veih ny merriu, chooinee yn vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er dy row Eh er ghra shoh roo : as chred ad yn scriptyr, as y ghlare va Yeesey er loayrt.

English: 23 ¶Now when he was in Jerusalem at the passover, in the feast day, many believed in his name, when they saw the miracles which he did.
Manx: Nish tra v’eh ec Jerusalem ec y Chaisht, rish earish yn eailley, ren ymmodee credjal ayns yn ennym echey, tra honnick ad ny mirrillyn v’eh er dy yannoo.

English: 24 But Jesus did not commit himself unto them, because he knew all men,
Manx: Agh cha hreisht Yeesey Eh hene orroo, er-yn-oyr dy row enney echey er dy chooilley ghooinney,

English: 25 And needed not that any should testify of man : for he knew what was in man.
Manx: As nagh row feme echey er annane erbee dy ymmyrkey feanish jeh dooinney : son va fys echey cre va ayns dooinney.
CAB. III.

English: There was a man of the Pharisees, named Nicodemus, a ruler of the Jews :
Manx: Va dooinney jeh ny Phariseeyn va enmyssit Nicodemus, fer-reïl jeh ny Hewnyn :

English: 2 The same came to Jesus by night, and said unto him, Rabbi, we know that thou art a teacher come from God : for no man can do these miracles that thou doest, except God be with him.
Manx: Haink Eh shoh gys Yeesey ayns yn oie, as dooyrt Eh rish, Rabbi, ta fys ain dy nee fer-ynsee oo as t’er jeet veih Jee : son cha vod dooinney erbee ny mirrillyn shen y yannoo tow uss dy yannoo, mannagh bee Jee marish.

English: 3 Jesus answered and said unto him, Verily, verily, I say unto thee, Except a man be born again, he cannot see the kingdom of God.
Manx: Dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh rish, Dy firrinagh firrinagh ta mee gra rhyt, Mannagh bee dooinney er ny ruggey reesht, cha vod Eh reeriaght Yee y akin.

English: 4 Nicodemus saith unto him, How can a man be born when he is old? can he enter the second time into his mother’s womb, and be born?
Manx: Dooyrt Nicodemus rish, Kys oddys dooinney v’er ny ruggey tra t’eh shen? vod Eh goll stiagh yn nah cheayrt ayns breïn e vayrey, as cheet er y theihll?

English: 5 Jesus answered, Verily, verily, I say unto thee, Except a man be born of water and of the Spirit, he cannot enter into the kingdom of God.
Manx: Dreggyr Yeesey, Dy firrinagh firrinagh ta mee gra rhyt, Mannagh bee dooinney er ny ruggey jeh ushtey as jeh’n Spyrryd, cha vod Eh goll stiagh ayns reeriaght Yee.

English: 6 That which is born of the flesh is flesh ; and that which is born of the Spirit is spirit.
Manx: Shen t’er ny ruggey jeh’n eill, she feill eh ; as shen t’er ny ruggey jeh’n Spyrryd, she spyrryd eh.

English: 7 Marvel not that I said unto thee, Ye must be born again.
Manx: Ny gow yindyss dy dooyrt mee rhyt, Shegin diu v’er nyn ruggey reesht.

English: 8 The wind bloweth where it listeth, and thou hearest the sound thereof, but canst not tell whence it cometh, and whither it goeth : so is every one that is born of the Spirit.
Manx: Ta’n gheay sheidey raad saill ee, as t’ow clashtyn y feiyr eck, agh cha s’ayd cre-woish t’ee cheet, ny cre’n raad t’ee goll : myr shen ta dy chooilley annane t’er ny ruggey jeh’n Spyrryd.

English: 9 Nicodemus answered and said unto him, How can these things be?
Manx: Dreggyr Nicodemus as dooyrt Eh rish, Kys oddys ny reddyn shoh y ve?

English: 10 Jesus answered and said unto him, Art thou a master of Israel, and knowest not these things?
Manx: Dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh rish, Vel uss dy [sic: dty] vainshtyr ayns Israel, as nagh vel fys ayd er ny reddyn shoh?

English: 11 Verily, verily, I say unto thee, We speak that we do know, and testify that we have seen ; and ye receive not our witness.
Manx: Dy firrinagh firrinagh ta mee gra riu, Ta shin loayrt shen ta fys ain er, as gymmyrkey feanish jeh ny ta shin er vakin ; as cha vel shiu soiaghey jeh’n eanish ain.

English: 12 If I have told you earthly things, and ye believe not, how shall ye believe, if I tell you of heavenly things?
Manx: My ta mish er loayrt reddyn thallooinagh riu, as nagh vel shiu dy my chredjal, kys nee shiu my chredjal my loayr-ym reddyn flaunyssagh riu?

English: 13 And no man hath ascended up to heaven, but he that came down from heaven, even the Son of man which is in heaven.
Manx: As cha vel dooinney erbee er gholl seose gys niau, agh eshyn haink neose veih niau, yn Mac dooinney ta ayns niau.

English: 14 ¶And as Moses lifted up the serpent in the wilderness, even so must the Son of man be lifted up :
Manx: As myr ren Moses yn ard-nieu y hroggal seose ayns yn aasagh, myr shen shegin da’n Mac dooinney v’er ny hroggal seose :

English: 15 That whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have eternal life.
Manx: Son nagh jean quoi-erbee ta credjal ayn cherraghtyn, agh dy bee yn vea ta dy bragh farraghtyn echey.

English: 16 ¶For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have everlasting life.
Manx: Son myr shen hug Jee graih da’n seihll, dy dug Eh e ynrycan Vac v’er ny gheddyn, son nagh jinnagh quoi-erbee chredagh ayn cherraghtyn, agh dy beagh yn vea ta dy bragh farraghtyn echey.

English: 17 For God sent not his Son into the world to condemn the world ; but that the world through him might be saved.
Manx: Son cha dug Jee e vac gys y theihll, dy gheyrey’n seihll ; agh dy voddagh y seihll liorishyn v’er ny hauail.

English: 18 ¶He that believeth on him is not condemned : but he that believeth not is condemned already, because he hath not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God.
Manx: Eshyn ta credjal ayn, cha vel Eh er ny gheyrey : agh eshyn nagh vel credjal ayn, t’eh er ny gheyrey hannah, er-yn-oyr nagh vel Eh er chredjal ayns ennym yn ynrycan Mac v’er ny gheddyn dy Yee.

English: 19 And this is the condemnation, that light is come into the world, and men loved darkness rather than light, because their deeds were evil.
Manx: As shoh yn vriwnys, dy vel soilshey er jeet gys y theihll, as dy row deiney ny s’graihee er y dorraghys na er y toilshey, er-y-fa dy row nyn obbraghyn olk.

English: 20 For every one that doeth evil hateth the light, neither cometh to the light, lest his deeds should be reproved.
Manx: Son ta dy chooilley annane ta jannoo dy holk, cur feoh da’n toilshey, cha-moo t’eh cheet gys y toilshey, son nagh jig brah er ny obbraghyn echey.

English: 21 But he that doeth truth cometh to the light, that his deeds may be made manifest, that they are wrought in God.
Manx: Agh eshyn ta jannoo firrinys, t’eh cheet gys y toilshey, dy vod e obbraghyn v’er nyn soilshaghey magh, dy vel ad er nyn obbraghey ayns Jee.

English: 22 ¶After these things came Jesus and his disciples into the land of Judaea ; and there he tarried with them, and baptized.
Manx: Ny lurg shoh haink Yeesey as y vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er gys cheer Yudea, as duirree Eh ayns shen mâroo, as ren Eh bashtey.

English: 23 And John also was baptizing in Aenon near to Salim, because there was much water there : and they came, and were baptized.
Manx: As va Ean myrgeddin bashtey ayns Enon, er-gerrey da Salim, er-y-fa dy row lane ushtey ayns shen : as haink ad as v’ad er nyn mashtey.

English: 24 For John was not yet cast into prison.
Manx: Son cha row Ean foast tilgit ayns pryssoon.

English: 25 ¶Then there arose a question between some of John’s disciples and the Jews about purifying.
Manx: Eisht dirree question eddyr paart jeh’n vooinjer va sheer geiyrt Ean as ny Hewnyn, mychione glenney.

English: 26 And they came unto John, and said unto him, Rabbi, he that was with thee beyond Jordan, to whom thou barest witness, behold, the same baptizeth, and all men come to him.
Manx: As haink ad gys Ean, as dooyrt ad rish Rabbi, eshyn va mârt er cheu elley dy Yordan, da ren oo feanish y ymmyrkey, cur-my-ner, te eshyn bashtey, as ta dy chooilley ghooinney cheet huggey.

English: 27 John answered and said, A man can receive nothing, except it be given him from heaven.
Manx: Dreggyr Ean as dooyrt Eh, Cha vod dooinney nhee erbee y ghoaill, mannagh bee eh er ny choyrt da veih niau.

English: 28 Ye yourselves bear me witness, that I said, I am not the Christ, but that I am sent before him.
Manx: Ren shiuish shiu hene feanish y ymmyrkey lhiam, dy dooyrt mee, Cha nee mish yn Creest, agh dy vel mee er my choyrt roish.

English: 29 He that hath the bride is the bridegroom : but the friend of the bridegroom, which standeth and heareth him, rejoiceth greatly because of the bridegroom’s voice : this my joy therefore is fulfilled.
Manx: Eshyn dooinney’n phoosee ta ben y phoosee echey : agh ta carrey dooinney’n phoosee, ta ny hassoo as geaishtagh rish, goaill boggey mooar kyndagh rish coraa yn dooinney-phoosee : ta shoh my voggey’s er-y-fa shen jeant magh.

English: 30 He must increase, but I must decrease.
Manx: Shegin dasyn bishaghey, agh shegin dooys parail.

English: 31 He that cometh from above is above all : he that is of the earth is earthly, and speaketh of the earth : he that cometh from heaven is above all.
Manx: Eshyn ta cheet veih’n yrjid, t’eh erskyn ooilley : eshyn ta jeh’n thalloo, t’eh thallooinagh, as loayrt jeh’n thalloo : eshyn ta cheet veih niau, t’eh erskyn ooilley.

English: 32 And what he hath seen and heard, that he testifieth ; and no man receiveth his testimony.
Manx: As y red t’eh er vakin as er chlashtyn, shen t’eh gymmyrkey feanish jeh ; as cha vel dooinney erbee soiaghey jeh’n eanish echey.

English: 33 He that hath received his testimony hath set to his seal that God is true.
Manx: Eshyn t’er n’yannoo soiagh jeh’n eanish echey, t’eh er chur y seal echey huggey, dy vel Jee firrinagh.

English: 34 For he whom God hath sent speaketh the words of God : for God giveth not the Spirit by measure unto him.
Manx: Son te eshyn ta Jee er ny choyrt, loayrt goan Yee : son cha nee liorish towse ta Jee cur y Spyrryd da.

English: 35 The Father loveth the Son, and hath given all things into his hand.
Manx: Ta’n Ayr graihagh er y Mac, as t’eh er chur dy chooilley nhee ayns y laue echey.

English: 36 He that believeth on the Son hath everlasting life : and he that believeth not the Son shall not see life ; but the wrath of God abideth on him.
Manx: Eshyn ta credjal ayns y Mac, ta’n vea ta dy bragh farraghtyn echey : as eshyn nagh vel credjal yn Mac, cha vaik Eh yn vea, agh nee corree Yee tannaghtyn er.
CAB. IV.

English: When therefore the Lord knew how the Pharisees had heard that Jesus made and baptized more disciples than John,
Manx: Tra va fys ec y Chiarn er-y-fa shen, kys va ny Phariseeyn er chlashtyn dy row Yeesey jannoo as bashtey ny sliee va geiyrt ersyn na va er Ean,

English: 2 (Though Jesus himself baptized not, but his disciples,)
Manx: (Ga nagh row Yeesey hene bashtey, agh yn vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er)

English: 3 He left Judaea, and departed again into Galilee.
Manx: Daag Eh Judea, as jimmee Eh reesht gys Galilee.

English: 4 And he must needs go through Samaria.
Manx: As beign da goll trooid Samaria.

English: 5 Then cometh he to a city of Samaria, which is called Sychar, near to the parcel of ground that Jacob gave to his son Joseph.
Manx: Eisht haink Eh gys ard-valley dy Samaria, ta enmyssit Sychar, er-gerrey da’n pheesh dy halloo hug Jacob da e vac Joseph.

English: 6 Now Jacob’s well was there. Jesus therefore, being wearied with his journey, sat thus on the well : and it was about the sixth hour.
Manx: Nish va chibbyr Yacob ayns shen. Va Yeesey er-y-fa shen cuirt rish e yurnah, as myr shen hoie Eh liorish y chibbyr : as ve mysh y cheyoo oor.

English: 7 There cometh a woman of Samaria to draw water : Jesus saith unto her, Give me to drink.
Manx: Haink ben dy Samaria dy hayrn ushtey : dooyrt Yeesey ree, Cur dooys dy iu.

English: 8 (For his disciples were gone away unto the city to buy meat.)
Manx: Son va’n vooinjer va sheer marish er gholl gys y valley dy chionnaghey beaghey.

English: 9 Then saith the woman of Samaria unto him, How is it that thou, being a Jew, askest drink of me, which am a woman of Samaria? for the Jews have no dealings with the Samaritans.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt y ven dy Samaria rish, Kys dy vel uss, ta dy [sic: dty] Hew, shirrey jough orryms, ta my ven dy Samaria? son cha vel ny Hewnyn dellal rish ny Samaritanee.

English: 10 Jesus answered and said unto her, If thou knewest the gift of God, and who it is that saith to thee, Give me to drink ; thou wouldest have asked of him, and he would have given thee living water.
Manx: Dreggyr Yeesey, as dooyrt Eh ree, Dy beagh fys ayds er gioot Yee, as quoi Eh ta gra rhyt, Cur dooys dy iu? veagh oo er hirrey ersyn, as veagh Eh er chur dhyt ushtey bio.

English: 11 The woman saith unto him, Sir, thou hast nothing to draw with, and the well is deep : from whence then hast thou that living water?
Manx: Dooyrt y ven rish, Vainshtyr, cha vel red erbee ayd dy hayrn lesh, as ta’n chibbyr dowin : cre voish eisht ta’n ushtey bio shen ayd?

English: 12 Art thou greater than our father Jacob, which gave us the well, and drank thereof himself, and his children, and his cattle?
Manx: Vel uss ny syrjey na nyn ayr Jacob, hug dooin y chibbyr, as diu jee Eh hene, as e chloan, as y maase echey?

English: 13 Jesus answered and said unto her, Whosoever drinketh of this water shall thirst again :
Manx: Dreggyr Yeesey as dooyrt Eh ree, Quoi-erbee iu-ys jeh’n ushtey shoh bee Eh paagh reesht :

English: 14 But whosoever drinketh of the water that I shall give him shall never thirst ; but the water that I shall give him shall be in him a well of water springing up into everlasting life.
Manx: Agh quoi-erbee iu-ys jeh’n ushtey verryms da, cha bee Eh dy bragh paagh : agh bee yn ushtey verrym da ny farrane ushtey ayn nee geill gys y vea ta dy bragh farraghtyn.

English: 15 The woman saith unto him, Sir, give me this water, that I thirst not, neither come hither to draw.
Manx: Dooyrt y ven rish, Vainshtyr, cur dooys yn ushtey shoh, son nagh bee’m paagh, as nagh jiggym ayns shoh dy hayrn.

English: 16 Jesus saith unto her, Go, call thy husband, and come hither.
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey ree, Immee as eïe er dty heshey, as tar ayns shoh.

English: 17 The woman answered and said, I have no husband. Jesus said unto her, Thou hast well said, I have no husband :
Manx: Dreggyr y ven as dooyrt ee, Cha vel sheshey aym. Dooyrt Yeesey ree, T’ow er ghra dy mie, Cha vel sheshey aym :

English: 18 For thou hast had five husbands ; and he whom thou now hast is not thy husband : in that saidst thou truly.
Manx: Son ta queig deiney er ny ve ayd, as eshyn t’ayd nish, cha nee dty heshey Eh : ayns shen t’ow er ghra yn irriney.

English: 19 The woman saith unto him, Sir, I perceive that thou art a prophet.
Manx: Dooyrt y ven rish, Vainshtyr, ta mee cur tastey dy nee phadeyr oo.

English: 20 Our fathers worshipped in this mountain ; and ye say, that in Jerusalem is the place where men ought to worship.
Manx: Ren ny ayraghyn ain ooashley choyrt er y slieau shoh ; as ta shiuish gra, dy nee ayns Jerusalem ta’n boayl raad lhisagh sleih ooashley choyrt.

English: 21 Jesus saith unto her, Woman, believe me, the hour cometh, when ye shall neither in this mountain, nor yet at Jerusalem, worship the Father.
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey ree, Ven, cred mish, ta’n oor cheet tra nagh jean shiu er y clieau shoh, ny foast ec Jerusalem ooashley choyrt da’n Ayr.

English: 22 Ye worship ye know not what : we know what we worship : for salvation is of the Jews.
Manx: Ta shiuish cur ooashley da, cha s’eu cre : ta fys ainyn cre ta shin cur ooashley da ; son ta saualtys jeh ny Hewnyn.

English: 23 But the hour cometh, and now is, when the true worshippers shall worship the Father in spirit and in truth : for the Father seeketh such to worship him.
Manx: Agh ta’n oor cheet, as nish ayn, tra nee adsyn ta cur ooashley dy firrinagh ooashley choyrt da’n Ayr ayns spyrryd as ayns firrinys : son ta’n Ayr shirrey nyn leid oc shoh dy chur ooashley da.

English: 24 God is a Spirit : and they that worship him must worship him in spirit and in truth.
Manx: Ta Jee ny Spyrryd, as adsyn ta cur ooashley da, shegin daue ooashley choyrt ayns spyrryd as ayns firrinys.

English: 25 The woman saith unto him, I know that Messias cometh, which is called Christ : when he is come, he will tell us all things.
Manx: Dooyrt y ven rish, Ta fys aym dy vel Messias cheet ta enmyssit Creest : tra hig eshyn, inshee Eh dooin dy chooilley nhee.

English: 26 Jesus saith unto her, I that speak unto thee am he.
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey ree, She mish ta loayrt rhyt Eh.

English: 27 ¶And upon this came his disciples, and marvelled that he talked with the woman : yet no man said, What seekest thou? or, Why talkest thou with her?
Manx: As er shen haink yn vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er, as ghow ad yindyss dy row Eh taggloo rish y ven : foast cha dooyrt dooinney erbee, Cre t’ow dy hirrey? ny, Cre’n-fa t’ow taggloo ree?

English: 28 The woman then left her waterpot, and went her way into the city, and saith to the men,
Manx: Daag yn ven eisht yn saagh ushtey eck, as hiee rhimbee gys y valley, as dooyrt ee rish ny deiney,

English: 29 Come, see a man, which told me all things that ever I did : is not this the Christ?
Manx: Tar-jee dy akin dooinney t’er n’insh dou ooilley ny ren mee rieau : nagh nee shoh yn Creest?

English: 30 Then they went out of the city, and came unto him.
Manx: Eisht hie ad magh ass y valley as haink ad huggey.

English: 31 ¶In the mean while his disciples prayed him, saying, Master, eat.
Manx: Ayns y traa shen ghuee yn vooinjer va sheer marish er, gra, Vainshtyr, ee bee.

English: 32 But he said unto them, I have meat to eat that ye know not of.
Manx: Agh dooyrt eshyn roo, Ta bee ayms dy ee nagh vel fys eauish er.

English: 33 Therefore said the disciples one to another, Hath any man brought him ought to eat?
Manx: Shen-y-fa dooyrt yn vooinjer va sheer geiyrt er yn derrey yeh rish y jeh elley, Vel dooinney erbee er chur lesh nhee erbee huggey dy ee?

English: 34 Jesus saith unto them, My meat is to do the will of him that sent me, and to finish his work.
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey roo, Yn beaghey ayms eh dy yannoo yn aigney echyssyn t’er my choyrt, as dy chooilleeney yn obbyr echey.

English: 35 Say not ye, There are yet four months, and then cometh harvest? behold, I say unto you, Lift up your eyes, and look on the fields ; for they are white already to harvest.
Manx: Nagh vel shiu gra, dy vel kiare meeghyn foast, as eisht ta’n fouyr cheet? cur-my-ner, ta mish gra riu, Trog-jee seose nyn sooyllyn, as jeeagh-jee er ny magheryn ; son t’ad baane hannah son y fouyr.

English: 36 And he that reapeth receiveth wages, and gathereth fruit unto life eternal : that both he that soweth and he that reapeth may rejoice together.
Manx: As ta’n beaynee geddyn faill, as chaglym mess gys y vea veayn : dy vod chammah yn corryder as y beaynee boggey y ghoaill cooidjagh.

English: 37 And herein is that saying true, One soweth, and another reapeth.
Manx: As ayns shoh ta’n raa shen firrinagh, Ta fer cuirr, as fer elley buinn.

English: 38 I sent you to reap that whereon ye bestowed no labour : other men laboured, and ye are entered into their labours.
Manx: Hug mish shiu magh dy vuinn yn red nagh ren shiu y laboragh : ta deiney elley er laboragh, as ta shiuish er gholl stiagh er y laboraght oc.

English: 39 ¶And many of the Samaritans of that city believed on him for the saying of the woman, which testified, He told me all that ever I did.
Manx: As ren ymmodee jeh Samaritanee yn ard-valley shen credjal ayn, kyndagh rish raa yn ven, ren feanish y ymmyrkey, Dinsh Eh dou ooilley ny ren mee rieau.

English: 40 So when the Samaritans were come unto him, they besought him that he would tarry with them : and he abode there two days.
Manx: Myr shen tra va ny Samaritanee er jeet huggey, ghuee ad er, Eh dy uirriaght mâroo : as duirree Eh ayns shen daa laa.

English: 41 And many more believed because of his own word ;
Manx: As ren ymmodee elley credjal ayn kyndagh rish e ghlare hene ;

English: 42 And said unto the woman, Now we believe, not because of thy saying : for we have heard him ourselves, and know that this is indeed the Christ, the Saviour of the world.
Manx: As dooyrt ad rish y ven, Nish ta shin credjal, cha nee son y raa ayds : son ta shin hene er chlashtyn Eh, as ta fys ain, dy nee shoh dy jarroo yn Creest, Saualtagh y theihll.

English: 43 ¶Now after two days he departed thence, and went into Galilee.
Manx: Nish lurg daa laa jimmee Eh veih shen, as hie Eh roish gys Galilee :

English: 44 For Jesus himself testified, that a prophet hath no honour in his own country.
Manx: Son ren Yeesey hene feanish y ymmyrkey, nagh vel ooashley ec phadeyr ayns e heer hene.

English: 45 Then when he was come into Galilee, the Galilaeans received him, having seen all the things that he did at Jerusalem at the feast : for they also went unto the feast.
Manx: Tra v’eh eisht er jeet gys Galilee, hug ny Galileanee oltaghey-bea da, liorish dy row ad er vakin ooilley ny ren Eh ec Jerusalem, ec yn eailley : son v’adsyn er ve ec y eailley.

English: 46 So Jesus came again into Cana of Galilee, where he made the water wine. And there was a certain nobleman, whose son was sick at Capernaum.
Manx: Myr shen haink Yeesey reesht gys Cana ayns Galilee, raad v’eh er n’yannoo yn ushtey ny eeyn. As va chiarn dy row, va’n mac echey ching ec Capernaum.

English: 47 When he heard that Jesus was come out of Judaea into Galilee, he went unto him, and besought him that he would come down, and heal his son : for he was at the point of death.
Manx: Tra cheayll Eh dy row Yeesey er jeet veih Judea gys Galilee, hie Eh huggey, as ghuee Eh er, Eh dy heet neose dy lheihys e vac : son v’eh raad y vaaish.

English: 48 Then said Jesus unto him, Except ye see signs and wonders, ye will not believe.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Yeesey rish, Mannagh vaik shiu cowraghyn as yindyssyn, cha jean shiu credjal.

English: 49 The nobleman saith unto him, Sir, come down ere my child die.
Manx: Dooyrt y chiarn rish, Vainshtyr, tar neose roish my vow my liannoo baase.

English: 50 Jesus saith unto him, Go thy way ; thy son liveth. And the man believed the word that Jesus had spoken unto him, and he went his way.
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey rish, Immee royd ; ta dty vac bio. As chred y dooinney yn fockle va Yeesey er loayrt rish, as hie Eh roish.

English: 51 And as he was now going down, his servants met him, and told him, saying, Thy son liveth.
Manx: As tra v’eh nish goll sheese, haink ny sharvaantyn echey ny whaill, as dinsh ad da, gra, Ta dty vac bio.

English: 52 Then enquired he of them the hour when he began to amend. And they said unto him, Yesterday at the seventh hour the fever left him.
Manx: Eisht dênee Eh jeu cre’n oor ren Eh toshiaght dy ve ny share : as dooyrt ad rish, Jea ec y chiaghtoo oor daag y chiassaghey Eh.

English: 53 So the father knew that it was at the same hour, in the which Jesus said unto him, Thy son liveth : and himself believed, and his whole house.
Manx: Myr shen va fys ec yn ayr dy nee ayns yn oor cheddin va Yeesey er ghra rish, Ta dty vac bio ; as ren Eh hene credjal as ooilley e hie.

English: 54 This is again the second miracle that Jesus did, when he was come out of Judaea into Galilee.
Manx: Shoh reesht yn nah virril ren Yeesey, tra v’eh er jeet veih Judea gys Galilee.
CAB. V.

English: After this there was a feast of the Jews ; and Jesus went up to Jerusalem.
Manx: Ny lurg shoh va feailley ny Hewnyn ayn, as hie Yeesey seose gys Jerusalem.

English: 2 Now there is at Jerusalem by the sheep market a pool, which is called in the Hebrew tongue Bethesda, having five porches.
Manx: Nish ta ec Jerusalem liorish giat ny geyrragh, poyll, ta enmyssit ayns y ghlare Hebrew Bethesda, ta queig porchyn er.

English: 3 In these lay a great multitude of impotent folk, of blind, halt, withered, waiting for the moving of the water.
Manx: Ayndoo shoh va nyn lhie ymmodee dy leih dourinagh, jeusyn va doal, jeh ny baccee, jeusyn va ayrn erbee jeh nyn gorp er shirgaghey, as v’ad feeau er gleashaght yn ushtey.

English: 4 For an angel went down at a certain season into the pool, and troubled the water : whosoever then first after the troubling of the water stepped in was made whole of whatsoever disease he had.
Manx: Son va ainle goll sheese ec leid y traa shen ayns yn ushtey, as seiy yn ushtey : quoi-erbee eisht va hoshiaght goll sheese lurg seiy yn ushtey, v’eh er ny laanaghey jeh doghan erbee dy row er.

English: 5 And a certain man was there, which had an infirmity thirty and eight years.
Manx: As va ayns shen dooinney dy row, va doghan er ve er rish hoght bleeaney jeig as feed.

English: 6 When Jesus saw him lie, and knew that he had been now a long time in that case, he saith unto him, Wilt thou be made whole?
Manx: Tra honnick Yeesey Eh ny lhie, as fys echey dy row Eh er ve myr shen ry foddey dy earish, dooyrt Eh rish, Nailt ve er dy [sic: dty] laanaghey?

English: 7 The impotent man answered him, Sir, I have no man, when the water is troubled, to put me into the pool : but while I am coming, another steppeth down before me.
Manx: Dreggyr yn annooinagh Eh, Vainshtyr, cha vel dooinney erbee aym, tra ta’n ushtey er ny heiy, dy my chur sheese ayns y phoyll : agh choud as ta mee cheet, ta fer elley goll sheese roym.

English: 8 Jesus saith unto him, Rise, take up thy bed, and walk.
Manx: Dooyrt Yeesey rish, Irree, trog dty lhiabbee as jean shooyl.

English: 9 And immediately the man was made whole, and took up his bed, and walked : and on the same day was the sabbath.
Manx: As chelleeragh va’n dooinney er ny lheihys, as hrog Eh e lhiabbee, as huill Eh : as er y laa shen va’n doonaght.

English: 10 ¶The Jews therefore said unto him that was cured, It is the sabbath day : it is not lawful for thee to carry thy bed.
Manx: Dooyrt ny Hewnyn er-y-fa shen rishyn v’er ny lheihys, She laa’n doonaght t’ayn ; cha vel eh lowal dhyt dty lhiabbee y chur lhiat.

English: 11 He answered them, He that made me whole, the same said unto me, Take up thy bed, and walk.
Manx: Dreggyr eshyn ad, Eshyn ren my laanaghey, dooyrt Eh shen rhym, Trog dty lhiabbee as shooill.

English: 12 Then asked they him, What man is that which said unto thee, Take up thy bed, and walk?
Manx: Eisht dênee ad jeh, Quoi yn dooinney shen dooyrt rhyt, Trog dty lhiabbe[e] as shooill?

English: 13 And he that was healed wist not who it was : for Jesus had conveyed himself away, a multitude being in that place.
