Manx: As tra v’eh slane da-eed bleïn dy eash, haink eh ayns y chree echey dy gholl dy yeeaghyn e vraaraghyn cloan Israel.

English: 24 And seeing one of them suffer wrong, he defended him, and avenged him that was oppressed, and smote the Egyptian :
Manx: As fakin fer jeu geddyn aggair, ghow Eh e phaart, as ghow Eh cooilleen er e hon son y tranlaase va jeant, as varr Eh yn Egyptian :

English: 25 For he supposed his brethren would have understood how that God by his hand would deliver them : but they understood not.
Manx: Son v’eh smooinaghtyn dy beagh e vraaraghyn er hoiggal, kys dy jinnagh Jee liorish y laue echyssyn nyn livrey ad ; agh cha hoig ad Eh.

English: 26 And the next day he shewed himself unto them as they strove, and would have set them at one again, saying, Sirs, ye are brethren ; why do ye wrong one to another?
Manx: As yn nah laa haink Eh huscyn v’er duittym magh, as v’eh booiagh nyn dayrn ad gys cordail, gra, Gheiney, she braaraghyn shiu ; cre’n-fa ta shiu jannoo aggair yn derrey yeh da’n jeh elley?

English: 27 But he that did his neighbour wrong thrust him away, saying, Who made thee a ruler and a judge over us?
Manx: Agh hug eshyn va jannoo aggair da e naboo eddin da, gra, Quoi hug uss ayns pooar dy ve d[t]y er-reïl as d[t]y vriw harrin?

English: 28 Wilt thou kill me, as thou diddest the Egyptian yesterday?
Manx: Bailt mish y varroo, myr varr oo yn Egyptian jea?

English: 29 Then fled Moses at this saying, and was a stranger in the land of Madian, where he begat two sons.
Manx: Eisht hie Moses er-chea ec y raa shen, as v’eh ny yoarree ayns thalloo Madian, raad hooar Eh daa vac.

English: 30 And when forty years were expired, there appeared to him in the wilderness of mount Sina an angel of the Lord in a flame of fire in a bush.
Manx: As tra va da-eed blein ec kione, haink huggey ayns faasagh cronck Sina, ainle y Chiarn ayns lossey dy aile ayns thammag.

English: 31 When Moses saw it, he wondered at the sight : and as he drew near to behold it, the voice of the Lord came unto him,
Manx: Tra honnick Moses eh, ghow Eh yindyss jeh’n shilley : as myr v’eh tayrn er-gerrey dy chur tastey da, haink coraa’n Chiarn huggey,

English: 32 Saying, I am the God of thy fathers, the God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob. Then Moses trembled, and durst not behold.
Manx: Gra, Mish Jee dty ayraghyn, Jee Abraham, as Jee Isaac, as Jee Yacob. Eisht va Moses er-creau, as cha by loys da jeeaghyn.

English: 33 Then said the Lord to him, Put off thy shoes from thy feet : for the place where thou standest is holy ground.
Manx: Agh dooyrt y Chiarn rish, Cur dty vraagyn jeh dty chassyn : son y boayl t’ow dy hassoo er she grunt casherick eh.

English: 34 I have seen, I have seen the affliction of my people which is in Egypt, and I have heard their groaning, and am come down to deliver them. And now come, I will send thee into Egypt.
Manx: Ta mee er vakin, ta mee er vakin seaghyn my phobble ta ayns Egypt, as er chlashtyn ny osnaghyn oc, as ta mee er jeet neose dy livrey ad. As nish tarr, verryms oo er chaghteraght gys Egypt.

English: 35 This Moses whom they refused, saying, Who made thee a ruler and a judge? the same did God send to be a ruler and a deliverer by the hand of the angel which appeared to him in the bush.
Manx: Moses shoh ren adsyn y obbal, gra, Quoi hug oo ayns pooar dy ve d[t]y er-reïl as d[t]y vriw? Eh shoh ren Jee y choyrt dy ve ny er-reïl as dy choyrt livrey liorish laueyn yn ainle honnick Eh ayns y thammag.

English: 36 He brought them out, after that he had shewed wonders and signs in the land of Egypt, and in the Red sea, and in the wilderness forty years.
Manx: Hug Eh lesh ad magh, erreish da v’er hoilshaghey yindyssyn as cowraghyn ayns thalloo Egypt, as ayns y faarkey jiarg, as ayns yn aasagh da-eed blein.

English: 37 This is that Moses, which said unto the children of Israel, A prophet shall the Lord your God raise up unto you of your brethren, like unto me ; him shall ye hear.
Manx: Shoh va’n Moses dooyrt rish cloan Israel, Phadeyr nee yn Chiarn yn Jee eu y hroggal seose diu jeh ny braaraghyn eu, casley rhyms ; dasyn ver shiu geill.

English: 38 This is he, that was in the church in the wilderness with the angel which spake to him in the mount Sina, and with our fathers : who received the lively oracles to give unto us :
Manx: Shoh Eh va ayns yn agglish ayns yn aasagh, marish yn ainle ren loayrt rish er cronck Sina, as marish ny ayraghyn ain : Eh hooar goan y vea dy choyrt ad dooinyn.

English: 39 To whom our fathers would not obey, but thrust him from them, and in their hearts turned back again into Egypt,
Manx: Da cha row ny ayraghyn ain booiagh ve biallagh, agh yioold ad rish, as ayns ny creeaghyn oc hyndaa ad back reesht gys Egypt,

English: 40 Saying unto Aaron, Make us gods to go before us : for as for this Moses, which brought us out of the land of Egypt, we wot not what is become of him.
Manx: Gra rish Aaron, Jean dooinyn Jeeaghyn hed roïn : son Moses shoh hug lesh shin magh ass thalloo Egypt, cha s’ain cre’n erree t’er jeet er.

English: 41 And they made a calf in those days, and offered sacrifice unto the idol, and rejoiced in the works of their own hands.
Manx: As ren ad lheiy ayns ny laghyn shen, as heb ad oural da’n jalloo, as ghow ad boggey ayns obbraghyn nyn laueyn hene.

English: 42 Then God turned, and gave them up to worship the host of heaven ; as it is written in the book of the prophets, O ye house of Israel, have ye offered to me slain beasts and sacrifices by the space of forty years in the wilderness?
Manx: Eisht hyndaa Jee, as livrey Eh ad seose dy chur ooashley da * sheshaght-chaggee flaunys ; myr te scruit ayns lioar ny Phadeyryn, O hie Israel, vel shiu er hebbal dooys beiyn marroo as ourallyn, da-eed blein ayns yn aasagh?
*Yn Ghrian, yn Aist as ny Rollaageyn.

English: 43 Yea, ye took up the tabernacle of Moloch, and the star of your god Remphan, figures which ye made to worship them : and I will carry you away beyond Babylon.
Manx: As ta shiu er hroggal cabbane-agglish Moloch, as rollaage yn Jee eu Remphan, co-chaslyssyn ren shiu y yannoo dy chur ooashley daue : as verryms lhiam shiu ersooyl gys y cheu elley jeh Babylon.

English: 44 Our fathers had the tabernacle of witness in the wilderness, as he had appointed, speaking unto Moses, that he should make it according to the fashion that he had seen.
Manx: Va cabbane-agglish yn eanish ec ny ayraghyn ain ayns yn aasagh, myr v’eh er n’oardaghey, gra rish Moses, Eh dy yannoo eh lurg y samplere v’eh er ny akin.

English: 45 Which also our fathers that came after brought in with Jesus into the possession of the Gentiles, whom God drave out before the face of our fathers, unto the days of David ;
Manx: As hug ny ayraghyn ain, haink ny yei, lhieu stiagh eh marish Joshua, gys cheer ny Ashoonyn-quaagh, deiyr Jee magh veih fenish ny ayraghyn ain, gys laghyn David ;

English: 46 Who found favour before God, and desired to find a tabernacle for the God of Jacob.
Manx: Quoi hooar foayr ayns shilley Yee, as va shirrey ynnyd-vaghee y gheddyn son Jee Yacob.

English: 47 But Solomon built him an house.
Manx: Agh Solomon hrog thie da.

English: 48 Howbeit the most High dwelleth not in temples made with hands ; as saith the prophet,
Manx: Ny-yeih cha vel y Jee smoo ard vaghey ayns chiambyllyn ta troggit lesh laueyn ; myr ta’n phadeyr gra,

English: 49 Heaven is my throne, and earth is my footstool : what house will ye build me? saith the Lord : or what is the place of my rest?
Manx: Niau my stoyl-reeoil, as y thalloo yn stoyl ta fo my chassyn : cre’n thie hroggys shiu dooys? ta’n Chiarn gra : ny cre vel ynnyd yn fea aym?

English: 50 Hath not my hand made all these things?
Manx: Nagh nee my laue’s ren dy chooilley nhee jeu shoh?

English: 51 ¶Ye stiffnecked and uncircumcised in heart and ears, ye do always resist the Holy Ghost : as your fathers did, so do ye.
Manx: Chreoi-wannallagh as nagh vel er nyn yiarey-chymmylt ayns cree as cleashyn, ta shiu kinjagh shassoo magh noi yn Spyrryd Noo : myr va ny ayraghyn eu, myr shen ta shiuish.

English: 52 Which of the prophets have not your fathers persecuted? and they have slain them which shewed before of the coming of the Just One ; of whom ye have been now the betrayers and murderers :
Manx: Quoi jeh ny phadeyryn nagh ren ny ayraghyn eu tranlaase er? as t’ad er varroo adsyn hoilshee ro-laue jeh cheet yn Fer-cairagh, Eh ta shiuish nish er vrah as er ghunverys :

English: 53 Who have received the law by the disposition of angels, and have not kept it.
Manx: Hooar shiu yn leigh liorish shirveish ainlyn, agh cha dreill shiu eh.

English: 54 ¶When they heard these things, they were cut to the heart, and they gnashed on him with their teeth.
Manx: Tra cheayll ad ny goan shoh, v’ad guint gys y chree, as slieeu ad nyn veeacklyn er.

English: 55 But he, being full of the Holy Ghost, looked up stedfastly into heaven, and saw the glory of God, and Jesus standing on the right hand of God,
Manx: Agh v’eshyn laane jeh’n Spyrryd Noo, as yeeagh Eh seose dy gyere gys niau, as honnick Eh gloyr Yee, as Yeesey ny hassoo er laue yesh Yee,

English: 56 And said, Behold, I see the heavens opened, and the Son of man standing on the right hand of God.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Cur-my-ner, hee-ym ny niaughyn foshlit, as yn Mac dooinney ny hassoo er laue yesh Yee.

English: 57 Then they cried out with a loud voice, and stopped their ears, and ran upon him with one accord,
Manx: Eisht deïe ad lesh ard choraa, as stap ad nyn gleashyn, as roih ad stiagh er lesh un aigney,

English: 58 And cast him out of the city, and stoned him : and the witnesses laid down their clothes at a young man’s feet, whose name was Saul.
Manx: As hilg ad Eh magh ass yn ard-valley, as chlagh ad Eh : as hug ny feanishyn nyn eaddagh ny lhie ec cassyn dooinney aeg, va enmyssit Saul.

English: 59 And they stoned Stephen, calling upon God, and saying, Lord Jesus, receive my spirit.
Manx: As chlagh ad Steaon, geamagh er Jee, as gra, Hiarn Yeesey, gow my spyrryd.

English: 60 And he kneeled down, and cried with a loud voice, Lord, lay not this sin to their charge. And when he had said this, he fell asleep.
Manx: As ghlioon Eh sheese, as deïe Eh lesh ard choraa, Hiarn, ny cur y peccah shoh nyn lieh. As tra v’eh er ghra shoh, huit Eh ny chadley.
CAB. VIII.

English: And Saul was consenting unto his death. And at that time there was a great persecution against the church which was at Jerusalem ; and they were all scattered abroad throughout the regions of Judaea and Samaria, except the apostles.
Manx: As va aigney Saul lhieu ayns y choyrt Eh gy baase. As ec y traa shen va tranlaase mooar er ny yannoo er yn agglish va ec Jerusalem ; as v’ad ooilley er nyn skeayley magh trooid cheeraghyn Yudea as Samaria, cheu-mooie jeh ny ostyllyn.

English: 2 And devout men carried Stephen to his burial, and made great lamentation over him.
Manx: As hrog deiney crauee lhieu Steaon dy oanluckey Eh, as v’ad feer trimshagh er e skyn.

English: 3 As for Saul, he made havock of the church, entering into every house, and haling men and women committed them to prison.
Manx: Agh hug Saul mow yn agglish, goll stiagh ayns thieyn, as tayrn magh deiney as mraane, as dyn dilgey ad ayns pryssoon.

English: 4 Therefore they that were scattered abroad went every where preaching the word.
Manx: Shen-y-fa hie yn vooinjer v’er nyn skeayley magh, trooid ymmodee ardjyn, preacheil y goo.

English: 5 Then Philip went down to the city of Samaria, and preached Christ unto them.
Manx: Agh hie Philip sheese gys ard-valley Samaria, as ren Eh Creest y phreacheil daue.

English: 6 And the people with one accord gave heed unto those things which Philip spake, hearing and seeing the miracles which he did.
Manx: As hug yn pobble geill lesh un aigney da ny reddyn va Philip dy loayrt, clashtyn as fakin ny mirrilyn v’eh dy yannoo.

English: 7 For unclean spirits, crying with loud voice, came out of many that were possessed with them : and many taken with palsies, and that were lame, were healed.
Manx: Son va spyrrydyn neu-ghlen, geamagh lesh ard choraa, cheet magh ass ymmodee v’ad ayndoo ; as va ymmodee va’n chingys-craa orroo, as va croobagh, er nyn lheihys.

English: 8 And there was great joy in that city.
Manx: As va boggey mooar ayns yn ard-valley shen.

English: 9 But there was a certain man, called Simon, which beforetime in the same city used sorcery, and bewitched the people of Samaria, giving out that himself was some great one :
Manx: Agh va dooinney dy row va enmyssit Simon, boallagh ayns yn ard-valley cheddin ve cur rish obbeeyn, as cur shaghrynys er pbble Samaria, jannoo dooinney mooar jeh hene.

English: 10 To whom they all gave heed, from the least to the greatest, saying, This man is the great power of God.
Manx: Da shoh v’ad ooilley cur tastey, beg as mooar, gra, Yn dooinney shoh pooar vooar Yee.

English: 11 And to him they had regard, because that of long time he had bewitched them with sorceries.
Manx: As v’ad ayns imnea roïsh, er-y-fa dy row Eh ry foddey er chur ad er-shaghryn lesh ny obbeeyn echey.

English: 12 But when they believed Philip preaching the things concerning the kingdom of God, and the name of Jesus Christ, they were baptized, both men and women.
Manx: Agh tra v’ad er chredjal Philip, preacheil ny reddyn va bentyn rish reeriaght Yee, as ennym Yeesey Creest, v’ad er nyn mashtey chammah deiney as mraane.

English: 13 Then Simon himself believed also : and when he was baptized, he continued with Philip, and wondered, beholding the miracles and signs which were done.
Manx: As va Simon hene er hyndaa gys y chredjue : as tra v’eh er ny vashtey, duirree Eh marish Philip, goaill yindyss, as cur tastey da ny mirrilyn as ny cowraghyn v’er nyn obbraghey.

English: 14 Now when the apostles which were at Jerusalem heard that Samaria had received the word of God, they sent unto them Peter and John :
Manx: Nish tra va ny ostyllyn va ec Jerusalem er chlashtyn dy row Samaria er ghoaill goo Yee, hug ad huc Peddyr as Ean.

English: 15 Who, when they were come down, prayed for them, that they might receive the Holy Ghost :
Manx: As tra v’ad er jeet neose, ghuee ad er nyn son dy voddagh ad y Spyrryd Noo y gheddyn.

English: 16 (For as yet he was fallen upon none of them : only they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.)
Manx: (Son cha row Eh foast er duittym er veg jeu : agh v’ad ynrycan er nyn mashtey ayns ennym y Chiarn Yeesey. )

English: 17 Then laid they their hands on them, and they received the Holy Ghost.
Manx: Eisht hug ad nyn laueyn orroo, as hooar ad y Spyrryd Noo.

English: 18 And when Simon saw that through laying on of the apostles’ hands the Holy Ghost was given, he offered them money,
Manx: As tra honnick Simon dy row yn Spyrryd Noo er ny choyrt liorish laueyn ny ostyllyn y chur orroo, heb Eh daue argid,

English: 19 Saying, Give me also this power, that on whomsoever I lay hands, he may receive the Holy Ghost.
Manx: Gra, Cur-jee dooys neesht yn phooar shoh, quoi-erbee verrym my laueyn er, dy vod Eh yn Spyrryd Noo y gheddyn.

English: 20 But Peter said unto him, Thy money perish with thee, because thou hast thought that the gift of God may be purchased with money.
Manx: Agh dooyrt Peddyr rish, Dy jean dt’argid cherraghtyn mârt hene, er-y-fa dy vel oo er smooinaghtyn dy vod gioot Yee ve kionnit lesh argid.

English: 21 Thou hast neither part nor lot in this matter : for thy heart is not right in the sight of God.
Manx: Cha vel part ny ayrn ayd ayns y chirveish shoh : son cha vel dty chree firrinagh ayns shilley Yee.

English: 22 Repent therefore of this thy wickedness, and pray God, if perhaps the thought of thine heart may be forgiven thee.
Manx: Gow arrys er-y-fa shen jeh dt’olkys, as guee gys Jee, dy yeeaghyn bee smooinaghtyn dty chree er ny lheih dhyt.

English: 23 For I perceive that thou art in the gall of bitterness, and in the bond of iniquity.
Manx: Son hee-ym dy vel oo ayns y ghall dy herridys as fo geuley dy vee-chraueeaght.

English: 24 Then answered Simon, and said, Pray ye to the Lord for me, that none of these things which ye have spoken come upon me.
Manx: Eisht dreggyr Simon, as dooyrt Eh, Guee-jee shiuish gys y Chiarn er my hon, nagh jig veg jeh ny reddyn ta shiuish er loayrt, orrym.

English: 25 And they, when they had testified and preached the word of the Lord, returned to Jerusalem, and preached the gospel in many villages of the Samaritans.
Manx: As tra v’ad er n’ymmyrkey feanish as er phreacheil goo yn Chiarn, hie ad back gys Jerusalem, as ren ad y sushtal y phreacheil ayns ymmodee jeh baljyn ny Samaritanee.

English: 26 And the angel of the Lord spake unto Philip, saying, Arise, and go toward the south unto the way that goeth down from Jerusalem unto Gaza, which is desert.
Manx: As loayr ainle y Chiarn rish Philip, gra, Irree, as gow gys y jass, gys y raad ta goll sheese veih Jerusalem gys Gaza, ta enmyssit faasagh.

English: 27 And he arose and went : and, behold, a man of Ethiopia, an eunuch of great authority under Candace queen of the Ethiopians, who had the charge of all her treasure, and had come to Jerusalem for to worship,
Manx: As dirree Eh as jimmee Eh roish : as cur-my-ner, va dooinney gennish veih Ethiopia, v’ayns pooar vooar fo Candace ben-reïn ny Ethiopianee, fo’n churrym echey va ooilley yn verchys eck, er jeet gys Jerusalem dy chur ooashley da Jee.

English: 29 Was returning, and sitting in his chariot read Esaias the prophet.
Manx: [sic: 28] As v’eh er y raad back, as ny hoie ayns e ainagh, lhaih Esaias yn phadeyr.

English: 29 Then the Spirit said unto Philip, Go near, and join thyself to this chariot.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt y Spyrryd rish Philip, Gow seose, as cur oo hene ayns sheshaght yn ainagh shoh.

English: 30 And Philip ran thither to him, and heard him read the prophet Esaias, and said, Understandest thou what thou readest?
Manx: As roih Philip huggey, as cheayll Eh Eh lhaih yn phadeyr Esaias, as dooyrt Eh, Vel oo toiggal cre t’ow dy lhaih?

English: 31 And he said, How can I, except some man should guide me? And he desired Philip that he would come up and sit with him.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Kys oddym, mannagh bee fer ennagh aym dy chur roym? As hir Eh er Philip Eh dy heet seose dy hoie mârish.

English: 32 The place of the scripture which he read was this, He was led as a sheep to the slaughter ; and like a lamb dumb before his shearer, so opened he not his mouth :
Manx: Yn ayrn jeh’n scriptyr v’eh dy lhaih, she shoh ve, V’eh er ny leeideil myr keyrrey gys y vaase, as myr ta eayn balloo kiongoyrt rishyn ta dy lomyrt eh, myr shen cha doshil eshyn e veeal :

English: 33 In his humiliation his judgment was taken away : and who shall declare his generation? for his life is taken from the earth.
Manx: As ayns e injillid v’eh livreit veih yn vriwnys v’eh fo : as quoi nee yn veayntys echey y hoilshaghey? son va e vioys goit ersooyl veih’n thalloo.

English: 34 And the eunuch answered Philip, and said, I pray thee, of whom speaketh the prophet this? of himself, or of some other man?
Manx: As dansoor y dooinney gennish Philip, as dooyrt Eh, Guee-ym ort, quoi jeh ta’n phadeyr loayrt shoh, jeh hene, ny jeh dooinney ennagh elley?

English: 35 Then Philip opened his mouth, and began at the same scripture, and preached unto him Jesus.
Manx: Eisht doshil Philip e veeal, as ghow Eh toshiaght ec y scriptyr cheddin, as ren Eh Yeesey y phreacheil da.

English: 36 And as they went on their way, they came unto a certain water : and the eunuch said, See, here is water ; what doth hinder me to be baptized?
Manx: As myr v’ad goll er y raad, haink ad gys ushtey dy row : as dooyrt y dooinney gennish, Jeeagh shoh ushtey ; cre ta dy my lhiettal’s dy ve er ny vashtey?

English: 37 And Philip said, If thou believest with all thine heart, thou mayest. And he answered and said, I believe that Jesus Christ is the Son of God.
Manx: As dooyrt Philip, My t’ow credjal lesh ooilley dty chree, foddee oo. As dreggyr eshyn as dooyrt Eh, Ta mee credjal dy nee Yeesey Creest Mac Yee.

English: 38 And he commanded the chariot to stand still : and they went down both into the water, both Philip and the eunuch ; and he baptized him.
Manx: As hug Eh saarey yn ainagh dy hassoo : as hie ad ny neesht sheese ayns yn ushtey, chammah Philip as y dooinney gennish ; as vasht Eh Eh.

English: 39 And when they were come up out of the water, the Spirit of the Lord caught away Philip, that the eunuch saw him no more : and he went on his way rejoicing.
Manx: As tra v’ad er jeet seose as yn ushtey, hrog Spyrryd y Chiarn lesh Philip ersooyl nagh vaik y dooinney gennish Eh arragh : as hie Eh er y raad goaill boggey.

English: 40 But Philip was found at Azotus : and passing through he preached in all the cities, till he came to Caesarea.
Manx: Agh va Philip er ny gheddyn ec Azotus : as jimmee Eh trooid, as ren Eh yn sushtal y phreacheil ayns dy chooilley ard-valley, derrey haink Eh gys Cesarea.
CAB. IX.

English: And Saul, yet breathing out threatenings and slaughter against the disciples of the Lord, went unto the high priest,
Manx: As va Saul foast sheidey magh baggyrtyn as toyrt-mow noi ocsyn v’er chredjal ayns y Chiarn, as jimmee Eh gys yn ard-saggyrt,

English: 2 And desired of him letters to Damascus to the synagogues, that if he found any of this way, whether they were men or women, he might bring them bound unto Jerusalem.
Manx: As hir Eh er screeuyn gys Damascus gys ny fir-reïl, my yioghe Eh veg jeh’n raad shen, edyr ad ’ve deiney ny mraane, dy voddagh Eh chur lesh ad kainlt gys Jerusalem.

English: 3 And as he journeyed, he came near Damascus : and suddenly there shined round about him a light from heaven :
Manx: As myr v’eh er e yurnah, haink Eh er-gerrey da Damascus : as doaltattym ren soilshey veih niau soilshean mygeayrt y mysh.

English: 4 And he fell to the earth, and heard a voice saying unto him, Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?
Manx: As huit Eh gys y thalloo, as cheayll Eh coraa gra rish, Saul, Saul, cre’n-fa t’ow jannoo tranlaase orrym?

English: 5 And he said, Who art thou, Lord? And the Lord said, I am Jesus whom thou persecutest : it is hard for thee to kick against the pricks.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Quoi oo Hiarn? As dooyrt y Chiarn, Mish Yeesey t’ow jannoo tranlaase er : Te doillee dhyt dy vrebbal noi ny jilg.

English: 6 And he trembling and astonished said, Lord, what wilt thou have me to do? And the Lord said unto him, Arise, and go into the city, and it shall be told thee what thou must do.
Manx: As v’eh er-creau as atchimagh, as dooyrt Eh, Hiarn, cre baïlt mee dy yannoo? As dooyrt y Chiarn rish, Irree, as gow gys yn ard-valley, as bee eh inshit dhyt cre shegin dhyt y yannoo.

English: 7 And the men which journeyed with him stood speechless, hearing a voice, but seeing no man.
Manx: As hass ny deiney va er nyn yurnah mârish as nyn dappey vow, son cheayl ad coraa, agh cha vaik ad dooinney erbee.

English: 8 And Saul arose from the earth ; and when his eyes were opened, he saw no man : but they led him by the hand, and brought him into Damascus.
Manx: As dirree Saul veih’n thalloo ; as tra va e hooyllyn er nyn vosley, cha vaik Eh dooinney erbee : agh leeid ad Eh er y laue, as hug ad lhieu Eh gys Damascus.

English: 9 And he was three days without sight, and neither did eat nor drink.
Manx: As v’eh three laa fegooish soilshey, as cha ren Eh gee ny giu.

English: 10 ¶And there was a certain disciple at Damascus, named Ananias ; and to him said the Lord in a vision, Ananias. And he said, Behold, I am here, Lord.
Manx: As va dooinney dy row ec Damascus enmyssit Ananias, v’er jyndaa gys y chredjue, as rishyn dooyrt y Chiarn ayns ashlish, Ananias. As dooyrt Eh, Cur-my ner, ta mee ayns shoh, Hiarn.

English: 11 And the Lord said unto him, Arise, and go into the street which is called Straight, and enquire in the house of Judas for one called Saul, of Tarsus : for, behold, he prayeth,
Manx: As dooyrt y Chiarn rish, Irree, as gow gys y traaid ta enmyssit y traaid Yeeragh, as jean briaght ayns thie Judas, son fer ta enmyssit Saul jeh Tarsus : son cur-my-ner, t’eh ec padjer.

English: 12 And hath seen in a vision a man named Ananias coming in, and putting his hand on him, that he might receive his sight.
Manx: As t’eh er vakin ayns ashlish dooinney enmyssit Ananias cheet stiagh, as cur e laue er, dy vod Eh e hoilshey y gheddyn.

English: 13 Then Ananias answered, Lord, I have heard by many of this man, how much evil he hath done to thy saints at Jerusalem :
Manx: Eisht dansoor Ananias, Hiarn, ta mee er chlashtyn veih fer ny gha jeh’n dooinney shoh, dy mooar yn aggair t’eh er n’yannoo da dty nooghyn’s ec Jerusalem :

English: 14 And here he hath authority from the chief priests to bind all that call on thy name.
Manx: As ayns shoh ta pooar echey veih ny ard-saggyrtyn, dy chiangley ooilley ny ta geamagh er dt’ennym’s.

English: 15 But the Lord said unto him, Go thy way : for he is a chosen vessel unto me, to bear my name before the Gentiles, and kings, and the children of Israel :
Manx: Agh dooyrt y Chiarn rish, Immee royd : son t’eh ny haagh reiht dooys, dy ymmyrkey my ennym kiongoyrt rish ny Ashoonyn-quaagh, as reeaghyn, as cloan Israel.

English: 16 For I will shew him how great things he must suffer for my name’s sake.
Manx: Son soilshee-yms da, cre ny reddyn mooarey shegin da y hurranse son m’ennym’s.

English: 17 And Ananias went his way, and entered into the house ; and putting his hands on him said, Brother Saul, the Lord, even Jesus, that appeared unto thee in the way as thou camest, hath sent me, that thou mightest receive thy sight, and be filled with the Holy Ghost.
Manx: As jimmee Ananias roish, as hie Eh stiagh ayns y thie ; as hug Eh e laueyn er, as dooyrt Eh, Vraar Saul, ta’n Chiarn (ta shen dy ghra, Yeesey honnick oo er y raad myr haink oo) er my choyrt’s, dy voddagh oo dty hoilshey y gheddyn, as ve lhieent lesh y Spyrryd Noo.

English: 18 And immediately there fell from his eyes as it had been scales : and he received sight forthwith, and arose, and was baptized.
Manx: As chelleeragh huit veih ny sooyllyn echey myr dy beagh eh scaailey ; as hooar Eh ec y traa cheddin e hoilshey, as dirree Eh, as v’eh er ny vashtey.

English: 19 And when he had received meat, he was strengthened. Then was Saul certain days with the disciples which were at Damascus.
Manx: As tra v’eh er ghoaill beaghey, v’eh er [n]y niartaghey. Eisht duirree Saul shiartance dy laghyn maroosyn v’er jyndaa gys y chredjue ec Damascus.

English: 20 And straightway he preached Christ in the synagogues, that he is the Son of God.
Manx: As chelleeragh ren Eh Creest y phreacheil ayns ny kialteenyn, dy nee Mac Yee Eh.

English: 21 But all that heard him were amazed, and said ; Is not this he that destroyed them which called on this name in Jerusalem, and came hither for that intent, that he might bring them bound unto the chief priests?
Manx: Agh ghow ooilley ny va dy chlashtyn Eh yindyss mooar, as dooyrt ad, Nagh nee shoh Eh va dyn eiyrt gys baase adsyn va geamagh er yn ennym shoh ayns Jerusalem, as nagh daink Eh er y chee shen, dy voddagh Eh nyn goyrt lesh ad kainlt gys ny ard-saggyrtyn?

English: 22 But Saul increased the more in strength, and confounded the Jews which dwelt at Damascus, proving that this is very Christ.
Manx: Agh daase Saul ny s’dunnallee dy chooilley laa, as cha row ny Hewnyn va vaghey ec Damascus abyl loayrt n’oi, tra v’eh jannoo mie jeh dy nee shoh yn Creest firrinagh.

English: 23 ¶And after that many days were fulfilled, the Jews took counsel to kill him :
Manx: As tra va ymmodee dy laghyn ec kione, hug ny Hewnyn nyn goyrle dy cheïley dy varroo Eh :

English: 24 But their laying await was known of Saul. And they watched the gates day and night to kill him.
Manx: Agh hooar Saul fys er y drogh aigney v’ad ayn da : as v’ad watchal ec ny giattyn laa as oie dy varroo Eh.

English: 25 Then the disciples took him by night, and let him down by the wall in a basket.
Manx: Eisht ghow adsyn v’er jyndaa gys y chredjue Eh ayns yn oie, as lig ad Eh sheese rish y voall ayns basket.

English: 26 And when Saul was come to Jerusalem, he assayed to join himself to the disciples : but they were all afraid of him, and believed not that he was a disciple.
Manx: As tra va Saul er jeet gys Jerusalem v’eh booiagh lhiantyn hucsyn v’er jyndaa gys y chredjue, agh v’ad ooilley ayns aggle roïsh, as cha row ad credjal dy row Eh jeh’n chredjue oc.

English: 27 But Barnabas took him, and brought him to the apostles, and declared unto them how he had seen the Lord in the way, and that he had spoken to him, and how he had preached boldly at Damascus in the name of Jesus.
Manx: Agh ghow Barnabas Eh, as hug Eh lesh Eh gys ny ostyllyn, as hoilshee Eh daue, kys v’eh er vakin yn Chiarn er y raad, as dy row Eh er loayrt rish, as kys v’eh er preacheil dy dunnal as dy foshlit ec Damascus ayns ennym Yeesey.

English: 28 And he was with them coming in and going out at Jerusalem.
Manx: As v’eh mâroo ayns y cheet stiagh as y goll magh oc ec Jerusalem.

English: 29 And he spake boldly in the name of the Lord Jesus, and disputed against the Grecians : but they went about to slay him.
Manx: As loayr Eh dy foshlit as lesh dunnalys ayns ennym y Chiarn Yeesey, as ren Eh hene as ny Grecianee resooney noi ry hoi : agh ghow adsyn ayns laue dy marragh ad Eh.

English: 30 Which when the brethren knew, they brought him down to Caesarea, and sent him forth to Tarsus.
Manx: Agh tra hoig ny braaraghyn shoh, hug ad lhieu Eh sheese gys Cesarea, as hug ad Eh magh gys Tarsus.

English: 31 Then had the churches rest throughout all Judaea and Galilee and Samaria, and were edified ; and walking in the fear of the Lord, and in the comfort of the Holy Ghost, were multiplied.
Manx: Eisht hooar yn agglish fea trooid ooilley Judea, as Galilee, as Samaria, as haink ee dy mie er e toshiaght, as liorish dy huïll ee ayns gerjagh yn Spyrryd Noo, v’ee er ny bishaghey.

English: 32 ¶And it came to pass, as Peter passed throughout all quarters, he came down also to the saints which dwelt at Lydda.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione tra va Peddyr er gholl harrish ooilley ny ardjyn, dy daink Eh neose myrgeddin gys ny nooghyn va vaghey ec Lydda.

English: 33 And there he found a certain man named Aeneas, which had kept his bed eight years, and was sick of the palsy.
Manx: As ayns shen hooar Eh dooinney dy row va enmyssit Eneas, v’er chummal e lhiabbee rish hoght bleeaney, as va’n chingys-craa er.

English: 34 And Peter said unto him, Aeneas, Jesus Christ maketh thee whole : arise, and make thy bed. And he arose immediately.
Manx: As dooyrt Peddyr rish, Eneas, ta Yeesey Creest dy dty laanaghey : irree, as jean dty lhiabbee. As dirree Eh chelleeragh.

English: 35 And all that dwelt at Lydda and Saron saw him, and turned to the Lord.
Manx: As honnick ooilley fir-vaghee Lydda as Saron Eh, as hyndaa ad gys y Chiarn.

English: 36 ¶Now there was at Joppa a certain disciple named Tabitha, which by interpretation is called Dorcas : this woman was full of good works and almsdeeds which she did.
Manx: Nish va ec Joppa ben dy row jeh’n chredjue yiarragh ad Tabitha ree, va ayns glare elley enmyssit Dorcas : va’n ven shoh er n’yannoo ymmodee obbraghyn mie, as er chur lane da ny boghtyn.

English: 37 And it came to pass in those days, that she was sick, and died : whom when they had washed, they laid her in an upper chamber.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione ayns ny laghyn shen, dy row ee ching, as dy dooar ee baase : as tra v’ad er y niee ee, hug ad ee ny lhie er lout.

English: 28 And forasmuch as Lydda was nigh to Joppa, and the disciples had heard that Peter was there, they sent unto him two men, desiring him that he would not delay to come to them.
Manx: As son wheesh as dy row Lydda er-gerrey da Joppa, as dy row adsyn jeh’n chredjue er chlashtyn dy row Peddyr ayns shen, hug ad huggey daa ghooinney, dy ghuee er Eh dy ghoaill y trubble dy heet huc.

English: 39 Then Peter arose and went with them. When he was come, they brought him into the upper chamber : and all the widows stood by him weeping, and shewing the coats and garments which Dorcas made, while she was with them.
Manx: Eisht dirree Peddyr, as hie Eh mâroo. Tra v’eh er jeet, hug ad lhieu Eh seose er y lout : as hass ooilley ny mraane-treoghe liorish keaney, as jeeaghyn da ny cooatyn as ny garmadyn va Dorcas er n’yannoo, choud as v’ee er-mayrn.

English: 40 But Peter put them all forth, and kneeled down, and prayed ; and turning him to the body said, Tabitha, arise. And she opened her eyes : and when she saw Peter, she sat up.
Manx: Ag[h] hug Peddyr ad ooilley magh, as ghlioon Eh sheese, as ghow Eh padjer, as hyndaa Eh gys y corp, as dooyrt Eh, Tabitha, irree seose. As doshil ee e sooyllyn : as tra honnick ee Peddyr, hoie ee seose.

English: 41 And he gave her his hand, and lifted her up, and when he had called the saints and widows, presented her alive.
Manx: As ghow Eh ee er y laue, as hrog Eh ee seose : as tra v’eh er n’eamagh er ny nooghyn as ny mraane-treoghe, hoie Eh ee kiongoyrt roo bio.

English: 42 And it was known throughout all Joppa ; and many believed in the Lord.
Manx: As va shoh er ny hoilshaghey magh trooid ooilley Joppa ; as ren ymmodee credjal ayns y Chiarn.

English: 43 And it came to pass, that he tarried many days in Joppa with one Simon a tanner.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, dy duirree Eh ymmodee dy laghyn ayns Joppa marish tanner dy row va enmyssit Simon.
CAB. X.

English: There was a certain man in Caesarea called Cornelius, a centurion of the band called the Italian band,
Manx: Va dooinney dy row ayns Cesarea, enmyssit Cornelius, va ny chaptan-keead er y cheshaght va enmyssit yn cheshaght Italian ;

English: 2 A devout man, and one that feared God with all his house, which gave much alms to the people, and prayed to God alway.
Manx: Dooinney crauee, va beaghey ayns aggle Yee, Eh hene as ooilley e hie, as v’eh cur ymmodee jeirkyn da’n pobble, as guee gys Jee kinjagh.

English: 3 He saw in a vision evidently about the ninth hour of the day an angel of God coming in to him, and saying unto him, Cornelius.
Manx: Honnick Eh shoh ayns ashlish dy plain, mysh yn nuyoo oor jeh’n laa, ainle dy Yee cheet stiagh huggey, as gra rish, Cornelius.

English: 4 And when he looked on him, he was afraid, and said, What is it, Lord? And he said unto him, Thy prayers and thine alms are come up for a memorial before God.
Manx: As tra yeeagh Eh seose er, v’eh agglagh, as dooyrt Eh, Cre shoh Hiarn? As dooyrt Eh rish, Ta ny padjeryn as ny jeirkyn ayd er jeet seose son cooinaghtyn kiongoyrt rish Jee.

English: And now send men to Joppa, and call for one Simon, whose surname is Peter :
Manx: 5. As nish cur deiney gys Joppa, dy eamagh er Simon ta slennooit Peddyr :

English: 6 He lodgeth with one Simon a tanner, whose house is by the sea side : he shall tell thee what thou oughtest to do.
Manx: T’eh goaill aaght marish Simon yn tanner, ta’n thie echey rish oirr ny marrey : inshee eshyn dhyt cre lhisagh oo y yannoo.

English: 7 And when the angel which spake unto Cornelius was departed, he called two of his household servants, and a devout soldier of them that waited on him continually ;
Manx: As tra va’n ainle loayr rish Cornelius er gholl roish, deïe Eh er jees jeh ny fir-vooinjerey echey, as er sidoor crauee jeusyn va tendeil er kinjagh :

English: 8 And when he had declared all these things unto them, he sent them to Joppa.
Manx: As tra v’eh er hoilshaghey dy chooilley nhee jeu shoh daue, hug Eh ad gys Joppa.

English: 19 ¶On the morrow, as they went on their journey, and drew nigh unto the city, Peter went up upon the housetop to pray about the sixth hour :
Manx: Laa ny vairagh myr v’ad goll er nyn yurnah, as tayrn er-gerrey da’n ard-valley, hie Peddyr seose er mullagh y thie gys padjer, mysh y cheyoo oor.

English: 10 And he became very hungry, and would have eaten : but while they made ready, he fell into a trance,
Manx: As daase Eh feer accryssagh, as v’eh booiagh v’er n’ee : agh choud as v’ad jannoo aarloo er e hon, huit Eh my-nealloo,

English: 11 And saw heaven opened, and a certain vessel descending upon him, as it had been a great sheet knit at the four corners, and let down to the earth :
Manx: As honnick Eh niau er ny osley, as saagh dy row cheet neose huggey, myr dy beagh eh brelleein vooar, kainlt ec ny kiare binn, as lhiggit sheese er y thalloo :

English: 12 Wherein were all manner of fourfooted beasts of the earth, and wild beasts, and creeping things, and fowls of the air.
Manx: Ayn va dy chooilley vonney dy veiyn kiare-cassagh y thallooin, dy veiyn feïe, as reddyn ta snauee er y thalloo, as eeanlee yn aer.

English: 13 And there came a voice to him, Rise, Peter ; kill, and eat.
Manx: As haink coraa huggey, Irree, Pheddyr ; marr, as ee,

English: 14 But Peter said, Not so, Lord ; for I have never eaten any thing that is common or unclean.
Manx: Agh dooyrt Peddyr, Foddey dy row shen voym, Hiarn ; son cha vel mish rieau er n’ee nhee erbee dy vel cadjin ny neu-ghlen.

English: 15 And the voice spake unto him again the second time, What God hath cleansed, that call not thou common.
Manx: As loayr y coraa rish reesht yn nah cheayrt, Shen ta Jee er ny ghlenney, ny enmyss uss cadjin.

English: 16 This was done thrice : and the vessel was received up again into heaven.
Manx: Va shoh jeant three keayrtyn : as va’n saagh goit seose reesht gys niau.

English: 17 Now while Peter doubted in himself what this vision which he had seen should mean, behold, the men which were sent from Cornelius had made enquiry for Simon’s house, and stood before the gate,
Manx: Nish choud as va Peddyr ayns imnea ayn hene, cre va meanal yn ashlish v’eh er vakin ; cur-my-ner, va ny chaghteryn haink veih Cornelius er gheddyn magh thie Simon liorish briaght, as v’ad nyn shassoo ec y dorrys,

English: 18 And called, and asked whether Simon, which was surnamed Peter, were lodged there.
Manx: As deïe ad, as dênee ad row Simon va slennooit Peddyr goaill aaght ayns shen.

English: 19 ¶While Peter thought on the vision, the Spirit said unto him, Behold, three men seek thee.
Manx: Choud as va Peddyr smooinaghtyn er yn ashlish, dooyrt y Spyrryd rish, Cur-my-ner, ta three deiney fênaght er dty hon.

English: 20 Arise therefore, and get thee down, and go with them, doubting nothing : for I have sent them.
Manx: Irree er-y-fa shen, as gow sheese, as gow mâroo, as ny bee faittagh : son ta mish er nyn goyrt ad.

English: 21 Then Peter went down to the men which were sent unto him from Cornelius ; and said, Behold, I am he whom ye seek : what is the cause wherefore ye are come?
Manx: Eisht hie Peddyr sheese gys ny chaghteryn haink huggey veih Cornelius ; as dooyrt Eh, Cur-my-ner, Mish Eh ta shiu dy hirrey : cre’n-oyr v’eu er-y-fa shen dy heet??

English: 22 And they said, Cornelius the centurion, a just man, and one that feareth God, and of good report among all the nation of the Jews, was warned from God by an holy angel to send for thee into his house, and to hear words of thee.
Manx: As dooyrt adsyn, Cornelius yn captan-keead, dooinney cairagh, as ta beaghey ayns aggle Yee, as echey ta goo mie mastey ooilley ashoon ny Hewnyn, er gheddyn raaue veih Jee liorish ainle casherick, dy chur fys orts gys e hie, dy eaishtagh rish dty ghoan.

English: 23 Then called he them in, and lodged them. And on the morrow Peter went away with them, and certain brethren from Joppa accompanied him.
Manx: Eisht deïe Eh orroo stiagh, as hooar Eh aaght daue. As laa ny vairagh hie Peddyr mâroo, as hie myrgeddin shiartance jeh ny braaraghyn mârish veih Joppa.

English: 24 And the morrow after they entered into Caesarea. And Cornelius waited for them, and he had called together his kinsmen and near friends.
Manx: As yn laa er-giyn haink ad gys Cesarea : as va Cornelius feeau er y cheet oc, as v’eh er n’eamagh er e gheiney-mooinjerey cooidjagh, as e reih caarjyn.

English: 25 And as Peter was coming in, Cornelius met him, and fell down at his feet, and worshipped him.
Manx: As tra va Peddyr cheet stiagh, hie Cornelius ny whail, as huit Eh sheese ec e chassyn, as hug Eh ooashley da.

English: 26 But Peter took him up, saying, Stand up ; I myself also am a man.
Manx: Agh hrog Peddyr seose Eh, gra, Shass seose ; ta mish mee hene myrgeddin my ghooinney.

English: 27 And as he talked with him, he went in, and found many that were come together.
Manx: As myr v’eh loayrt rish, hie Eh stiagh, as hooar Eh ymmodee er nyn jaglym cooidjagh.

English: 28 And he said unto them, Ye know how that it is an unlawful thing for a man that is a Jew to keep company, or come unto one of another nation ; but God hath shewed me that I should not call any man common or unclean.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Ta fys eu dy nee red neu-lowal eh da dooinney ta ny Hew, dy reaylley sheshaght rish, ny dy heet gys annane erbee jeh ashoon elley : agh ta Jee er hoilshaghey dooys, nagh lhisin jeeaghyn er dooinney erbee dy ve cadjin ny neu-ghlen.

English: 29 Therefore came I unto you without gainsaying, as soon as I was sent for : I ask therefore for what intent ye have sent for me?
Manx: As she shoh va’n oyr haink mee hiu dy arryltagh, cha leah as hug shiu fys orrym : baïllym er-y-fa shen shiu dy insh dou cre son hug oyr shiu fys orrym.

English: 30 And Cornelius said, Four days ago I was fasting until this hour ; and at the ninth hour I prayed in my house, and, behold, a man stood before me in bright clothing,
Manx: As dooyrt Cornelius, Kiare laa er dy henney va mish my hrostey gys yn oor shoh, ac [sic: as] ec yn nuyoo oor ghow mee padjer ayns my hie, as cur-my-ner, hass dooinney kiongoyrt rhym ayns coamrey sollys,

English: 31 And said, Cornelius, thy prayer is heard, and thine alms are had in remembrance in the sight of God.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Cornelius, ta dty phadjer er ny chlashtyn, as dty yeirkyn freilt ayns cooinaghtyn ayns shilley Yee.

English: 32 Send therefore to Joppa, and call hither Simon, whose surname is Peter ; he is lodged in the house of one Simon a tanner by the sea side : who, when he cometh, shall speak unto thee.
Manx: Cur fys er-y-fa shen gys Joppa, dy eamagh er Simon ta slennooit Peddyr ; t’eh goaill aaght ayns thie Simon yn tanner, rish oirr ny marrey : as tra hig Eh, loayree Eh rhyt.

English: 33 Immediately therefore I sent to thee ; and thou hast well done that thou art come. Now therefore are we all here present before God, to hear all things that are commanded thee of God.
Manx: Chelleeragh er-y-fa shen hug mee fys ort ; as t’ow er n’yannoo dy mie dy vel oo er jeet. Nish er-y-fa shen ta shin ooilley ayns shoh kionfenish, kiongoyrt rish Jee, dy eaishtagh rish dy chooilley nhee ta Jee er n’oardaghey dhyt.

English: 34 ¶Then Peter opened his mouth, and said, Of a truth I perceive that God is no respecter of persons :
Manx: Eisht doshil Peddyr e veeal, as dooyrt Eh, Ayns firrinys ta mee cur tastey nagh vel Jee soiaghey jeh persoonyn :

English: 35 But in every nation he that feareth him, and worketh righteousness, is accepted with him.
Manx: Agh ayns dy chooilley ashoon, eshyn ta goaill aggle roïsh, as gobbraghey cairys, t’eh goit gys foayr liorish.

English: 36 The word which God sent unto the children of Israel, preaching peace by Jesus Christ : (he is Lord of all :)
Manx: Yn goo hug Jee gys cloan Israel, preacheil shee liorish Yeesey Creest (eshyn y Chiarn ain ooilley)

English: 37 That word, I say, ye know, which was published throughout all Judaea, and began from Galilee, after the baptism which John preached ;
Manx: Yn goo shen (ta mee gra) ta fys eauish dy row eh er ny hoilshaghey magh trooid ooilley Judea, as dy ghow eh toshiaght veih Galilee, lurg y bashtey ren Ean y phreacheil ;

English: 38 How God anointed Jesus of Nazareth with the Holy Ghost and with power : who went about doing good, and healing all that were oppressed of the devil ; for God was with him.
Manx: Kys dy ren Jee Yeesey dy Nazareth y ooillaghey lesh y Spyrryd Noo, as lesh pooar ; hie Eh mygeayrt jannoo mie ; as slaanaghey ooilley ny va’n drogh spyrryd er heaghnaghey : son va Jee mârish.

English: 39 And we are witnesses of all things which he did both in the land of the Jews, and in Jerusalem ; whom they slew and hanged on a tree :
Manx: As ta shinyn nyn veanishyn jeh dy chooilley nhee ren Eh chammah ayns cheer ny Hewnyn, as ayns Jerusalem ; as dy ren ad Eh y varroo as y croghey er billey :

English: 40 Him God raised up the third day, and shewed him openly ;
Manx: Eshyn ta Jee er hroggal seose yn tress laa, as er hoilshaghey Eh dy foshlit,

English: 42 Not to all the people, but unto witnesses chosen before God, even to us, who did eat and drink with him after he rose from the dead.
Manx: [sic: 41] Cha nee da ooilley yn pobble, agh da feanishyn va reiht ro-laue liorish Jee, dy jarroo dooinyn ren gee as giu marish, erreish da v’er n’irree veih ny merriu.

English: 42 And he commanded us to preach unto the people, and to testify that it is he which was ordained of God to be the Judge of quick and dead.
Manx: As hug Eh saarey dooin dy phreacheil gys y pobble, as dy ymmyrkey feanish dy nee eshyn, liorish oardagh Yee, ta dy ve briw ny bio as ny merriu.

English: 43 To him give all the prophets witness, that through his name whosoever believeth in him shall receive remission of sins.
Manx: Leshyn ta ooilley ny phadeyryn gymmyrkey feanish, trooid yn ennym echey, quoi-erbee chreddys ayn, dy vow Eh feaysley peccaghyn.

English: 44 ¶While Peter yet spake these words, the Holy Ghost fell on all them which heard the word.
Manx: Choud as va Peddyr loayrt ny goan shoh, huit y Spyrryd Noo orroosyn ooilley va clashtyn y goo.

English: 45 And they of the circumcision which believed were astonished, as many as came with Peter, because that on the Gentiles also was poured out the gift of the Holy Ghost.
Manx: As ghow adsyn jeh’n yiarey-chymmylt va er chredjal, yindyss mooar, whilleen as haink marish Peddyr, er-y-fa orroosyn jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaagh myrgeddin dy row gioot y Spyrryd Noo er ny gheayrtey magh.

English: 46 For they heard them speak with tongues, and magnify God. Then answered Peter,
Manx: Son cheayll ad ad loayrt lesh chengaghyn, as cur ard-voylley da Jee. Eisht dreggyr Peddyr,

English: 47 Can any man forbid water, that these should not be baptized, which have received the Holy Ghost as well as we?
Manx: Vod dooinney erbee ushtey y lhiettal, nagh bee ad shoh er nyn mashtey, ta er gheddyn y Spyrryd Noo, chammah as shinyn?

English: 48 And he commanded them to be baptized in the name of the Lord. Then prayed they him to tarry certain days.
Manx: As hug Eh saarey ad dy ve er nyn mashtey ayns ennym y Chiarn. Eisht ghuee ad er dy uirriaght shiartance dy laghyn.
CAB. XI.

English: And the apostles and brethren that were in Judaea heard that the Gentiles had also received the word of God.
Manx: As cheayll ny ostyllyn as ny braaraghyn va ayns Judea, dy row adsyn jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaagh er ghoaill orroo goo Yee.

English: 2 And when Peter was come up to Jerusalem, they that were of the circumcision contended with him,
Manx: As tra va Peddyr er jeet seose gys Jerusalem, hooar braaraghyn y yiarey-chymmylt foill da,

English: 3 Saying, Thou wentest in to men uncircumcised, and didst eat with them.
Manx: Gra, Hie oo stiagh gys deiney nagh row er nyn yiarey chymmylt, as ren oo gee mâroo.

English: 4 But Peter rehearsed the matter from the beginning, and expounded it by order unto them, saying,
Manx: Agh hoilshee Peddyr kys ve veih yn toshiaght, as hoie Eh eh ayns order rhymboo, gra,

English: 5 I was in the city of Joppa praying : and in a trance I saw a vision, A certain vessel descend, as it had been a great sheet, let down from heaven by four corners ; and it came even to me :
Manx: Va mish ec padjer ayns ard-valley Joppa ; as huit mee my-nealloo, as honnick mee ayns ashlish, saagh dy row cheet neose, myr dy beagh eh brelleein vooar, lhiggit neose veih niau er ny kiare binn ; as haink eh hym’s.

English: 6 Upon the which when I had fastened mine eyes, I considered, and saw fourfooted beasts of the earth, and wild beasts, and creeping things, and fowls of the air.
Manx: As tra va mee er yeeaghyn dy gyere er, as er ghoaill tastey, honnick mee beiyn kiare-chassagh y thallooin, as beiyn feïe, as reddyn ta snaaue er y thalloo, as eeanlee yn aer.

English: 7 And I heard a voice saying unto me, Arise, Peter ; slay and eat.
Manx: As cheayll mee coraa gra rhym, Irree, Pheddyr ; marr as ee.

English: 8 But I said, Not so, Lord : for nothing common or unclean hath at any time entered into my mouth.
Manx: Agh dooyrt mish, Foddey dy row shen voym, Hiarn : son cha vel nhee erbee dy vel cadjin ny neu-ghlen ec traa erbee er gholl stiagh ayns my veeal.

English: 9 But the voice answered me again from heaven, What God hath cleansed, that call not thou common.
Manx: Agh dreggyr y coraa mee reesht veih niau, Shen ta Jee er ny ghlenney, ny enmyss uss cadjin.

English: 10 And this was done three times : and all were drawn up again into heaven.
Manx: As va shoh jeant three keayrtyn : as va ooilley tayrnit seose reesht gys niau.

English: 11 And, behold, immediately there were three men already come unto the house where I was, sent from Caesarea unto me.
Manx: As cur-my-ner, ayns y traa, va three deiney hannah er jeet gys y thie raad va mee, v’er nyn goyrt hym veih Cesarea.

English: 12 And the Spirit bade me go with them, nothing doubting. Moreover these six brethren accompanied me, and we entered into the man’s house :
Manx: As doardee yn Spyrryd dou goll mâroo, as nagh by lhias dou aggle y ghoaill. As hie ny shey braaraghyn shoh ry heshaght mârym, as hie shin stiagh ayns thie yn dooinney :

English: 13 And he shewed us how he had seen an angel in his house, which stood and said unto him, Send men to Joppa, and call for Simon, whose surname is Peter ;
Manx: As hoilshee Eh dooin, kys v’eh er vakin ainle ayns e hie, hass as dooyrt rish, Cur deiney gys Joppa dy eamagh er Simon ta slennooit Peddyr :

English: 14 Who shall tell thee words, whereby thou and all thy house shall be saved.
Manx: Eh nee goan y livrey dhyt, lioroo oddys oo hene as ooilley dty hie ve er nyn sauail.

English: 15 And as I began to speak, the Holy Ghost fell on them, as on us at the beginning.
Manx: As tra ren mee toshiaght dy loayrt, huit y Spyrryd Noo orroo, myr huit Eh orrinyn ec y toshiaght.

English: 16 Then remembered I the word of the Lord, how that he said, John indeed baptized with water ; but ye shall be baptized with the Holy Ghost.
Manx: Eisht chooinee mee er goo yn Chiarn, kys dooyrt Eh, Ren Ean dy jarroo bashtey lesh ushtey ; agh bee shiuish er nyn mashtey lesh y Spyrryd Noo.

English: 17 Forasmuch then as God gave them the like gift as he did unto us, who believed on the Lord Jesus Christ ; what was I, that I could withstand God?
Manx: My hug Jee eisht dauesyn yn un yioot hug Eh dooinyn v’er chredjal ayns y Chiarn Yeesey Creest, cre’n phooar v’aym’s dy hassoo noi Jee?

English: 18 When they heard these things, they held their peace, and glorified God, saying, Then hath God also to the Gentiles granted repentance unto life.
Manx: Tra cheayll ad shoh, chum ad nyn jengey, as hug ad gloyr da Jee, gra, Eisht ta Jee er yialdyn da ny eer Ashoonyn-quaagh arrys gys bea.

English: 19 ¶Now they which were scattered abroad upon the persecution that arose about Stephen travelled as far as Phenice, and Cyprus, and Antioch, preaching the word to none but unto the Jews only.
Manx: Nish va’n vooinjer v’er nyn skeayley magh, kyndagh rish y tranlaase va jeant er coontey Steaon, er droailt choud as Phenice, as Cyprus, as Antioch, as cha ren ad yn goo y phreacheil da annane erbee agh ynrycan da ny Hewnyn.

English: 20 And some of them were men of Cyprus and Cyrene, which, when they were come to Antioch, spake unto the Grecians, preaching the Lord Jesus.
Manx: As va paart jeu deiney veih Cyprus as Cyrene, as tra v’ad er jeet gys Antioch loayr ad roosyn jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaagh, preacheil yn Chiarn Yeesey.

English: 21 And the hand of the Lord was with them : and a great number believed, and turned unto the Lord.
Manx: As va laue yn Chiarn lhieu : as ren earroo mooar dy leih credjal, as chyndaa gys y Chiarn.

English: 22 ¶Then tidings of these things came unto the ears of the church which was in Jerusalem : and they sent forth Barnabas, that he should go as far as Antioch.
Manx: Eisht haink naightyn jeh ny reddyn shoh gys clashtyn yn agglish va ec Jerusalem : as hug ad magh Barnabas derrey Antioch.

English: 23 Who, when he came, and had seen the grace of God, was glad, and exhorted them all, that with purpose of heart they would cleave unto the Lord.
Manx: As tra v’eh er jeet as er vakin grayse Yee, ghow Eh boggey, as choyrlee Eh ad ooilley, lesh shickyrys cree ad dy lhiantyn gys y Chiarn.

English: 24 For he was a good man, and full of the Holy Ghost and of faith : and much people was added unto the Lord.
Manx: Son v’eh ny ghooinney mie, as laane jeh’n Spyrryd Noo, as jeh credjue ; as ren ymmodee dy leih chyndaa gys y Chiarn.

English: 25 Then departed Barnabas to Tarsus, for to seek Saul :
Manx: Eisht jimmee Barnabas gys Tarsus dy hirrey Saul. As tra v’eh er gheddyn Eh, hug Eh lesh Eh gys Antioch.

English: 26 And when he had found him, he brought him unto Antioch. And it came to pass, that a whole year they assembled themselves with the church, and taught much people. And the disciples were called Christians first in Antioch.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, dy duirree ad choud as bleïn ayns shen ayns sheshaght ny hagglish, as dy dynsee ad ymmodee dy leih ; as v’adsyn v’er jyndaa gys y chredjue enmyssit Creesteenyn hoshiaght ayns Antioch.

English: 27 ¶And in these days came prophets from Jerusalem unto Antioch.
Manx: As ayns ny laghyn shen haink phadeyryn veih Jerusalem gys Antioch.

English: 28 And there stood up one of them named Agabus, and signified by the Spirit that there should be great dearth throughout all the world : which came to pass in the days of Claudius Caesar.
Manx: As hass seose fer jeu enmyssit Agabus, as hoilshee Eh liorish y Spyrryd, dy beagh genney vooar trooid ooilley yn theihll ; red haink gy kione ayns laghyn Claudius Cesar.

English: 29 Then the disciples, every man according to his ability, determined to send relief unto the brethren which dwelt in Judaea :
Manx: Eisht ghow adsyn v’er jyndaa gys y chredjue ayns laue, dy chooilley ghooinney lurg e phooar, dy chur cooney gys ny braaraghyn va vaghey ayns Judea.

English: 30 Which also they did, and sent it to the elders by the hands of Barnabas and Saul.
Manx: As ren ad shen neesht, as hug ad eh gys y chanstyr liorish laueyn Barnabas as Saul.
CAB. XII.

English: Now about that time Herod the king stretched forth his hands to vex certain of the church.
Manx: Nish mysh y traa shen heeyn Herod yn ree magh e laueyn dy yannoo tranlaase er shiartance jeh’n agglish.

English: 2 And he killed James the brother of John with the sword.
Manx: As varr Eh Jamys braar Ean lesh y chliwe.

English: 3 And because he saw it pleased the Jews, he proceeded further to take Peter also. (Then were the days of unleavened bread.)
Manx: As er-y-fa dy dug Eh tastey dy row shoh booiys ny Hewnyn, hie Eh ny sodjey er e hoshiaght dy ghoaill Peddyr neesht. (Shen y traa va laghyn yn arran millish ayn.)

English: 4 And when he had apprehended him, he put him in prison, and delivered him to four quaternions of soldiers to keep him ; intending after Easter to bring him forth to the people.
Manx: As tra v’eh er ghoaill Eh, hug Eh Eh ayns pryssoon, as livrey Eh Eh gys shey sidooryn jeig dy reaylley Eh, kiarrail lurg y Chaisht dy chur lesh Eh magh gys y pobble.

English: 5 Peter therefore was kept in prison : but prayer was made without ceasing of the church unto God for him.
Manx: Va Peddyr er-y-fa shen freilt ayns pryssoon ; agh va padjer er ny yannoo kinjagh gys Jee er e hon.

English: 6 And when Herod would have brought him forth, the same night Peter was sleeping between two soldiers, bound with two chains : and the keepers before the door kept the prison.
Manx: As tra baillish Herod v’er choyrt lesh magh Eh, yn oie cheddin va Peddyr ny chadley eddyr daa hidoor kianlt lesh daa yeuley ; as va feallagh soit ec y dorrys dy watchal y phryssoon.

English: 7 And, behold, the angel of the Lord came upon him, and a light shined in the prison : and he smote Peter on the side, and raised him up, saying, Arise up quickly. And his chains fell off from his hands.
Manx: As cur-my-ner, haink ainle y Chiarn huggey, as ren soilshey soilshean ayns y phryssoon : as woaill Eh Peddyr er y lhiattee, as ghooisht Eh Eh, gra, Irree seose dy tappee. As huit ny geulaghyn jeh ny laueyn echey.

English: 8 And the angel said unto him, Gird thyself, and bind on thy sandals. And so he did. And he saith unto him, Cast thy garment about thee, and follow me.
Manx: As dooyrt yn ainle rish, Cur dty chryss ort as kiangle ort dty vraagyn : As ren Eh shen. As dooyrt Eh rish, Cur dty gharmad mood, as eiyr orryms.

English: 9 And he went out, and followed him ; and wist not that it was true which was done by the angel ; but thought he saw a vision.
Manx: As hie Eh magh as deiyr Eh er, as cha row fys echey dy row ny va’n ainle er n’yannoo firrinagh ; agh heill Eh dy nee ashlish v’eh dy akin.

English: 10 When they were past the first and the second ward, they came unto the iron gate that leadeth unto the city ; which opened to them of his own accord : and they went out, and passed on through one street ; and forthwith the angel departed from him.
Manx: Tra v’ad er gholl shiaghey yn chied as yn nah ghard, haink ad gys y giat yiarn ta leeideil gys yn ard-valley, as doshil eh daue jeh hene : as hie ad magh as jimmee ad trooid un straaid, as chelleeragh daag yn ainle Eh.

English: 11 And when Peter was come to himself, he said, Now I know of a surety, that the Lord hath sent his angel, and hath delivered me out of the hand of Herod, and from all the expectation of the people of the Jews.
Manx: As tra va Peddyr er jeet huggey hene, dooyrt Eh, Nish ta fys aym ayns shickyrys dy vel y Chiarn er choyrt e ainle dy my livrey veih laue Herod, as veih ooilley ny va kiarit my chouyr liorish pobble ny Hewnyn.

English: 12 And when he had considered the thing, he came to the house of Mary the mother of John, whose surname was Mark ; where many were gathered together praying.
Manx: As tra v’eh er smooinaghtyn er hene, haink Eh gys thie Moirrey moir Ean, va slennooit Mark, raad va ymmodee er nyn jaglym cooidjagh, ec padjer.

English: 13 And as Peter knocked at the door of the gate, a damsel came to hearken, named Rhoda.
Manx: As tra va Peddyr er chronckal ec dorryss y yiat, haink ben-aeg va enmyssit Rhoda dy ênaght quoi v’ayn.

English: 14 And when she knew Peter’s voice, she opened not the gate for gladness, but ran in, and told how Peter stood before the gate.
Manx: As tra hug ee enney er coraa Pheddyr, cha doshil ee yn giat son boggey, agh roih ee stiagh as dinsh ee daue dy row Peddyr ny hassoo ec y yiat.

English: 15 And they said unto her, Thou art mad. But she constantly affirmed that it was even so. Then said they, It is his angel.
Manx: Dooyrt adsyn ree, T’ow ass dty cheeal. Agh hass ish er kinjagh dy nee Eh v’ayn. Eisht dooyrt ad, She yn ainle echey t’ayn.

English: 16 But Peter continued knocking : and when they had opened the door, and saw him, they were astonished.
Manx: Agh chum Peddyr cronckal ec y dorrys : as tra v’ad er vosley da, as er vakin dy nee Eh v’ayn, ghow ad lane yindyss.

English: 17 But he, beckoning unto them with the hand to hold their peace, declared unto them how the Lord had brought him out of the prison. And he said, Go shew these things unto James, and to the brethren. And he departed, and went into another place.
Manx: Agh chrie eshyn e laue orroo ad dy chummal nyn jengey, as hoilshee Eh daue kys va’n Chiarn er chur lesh Eh ass y phryssoon. As dooyrt Eh, Insh-jee ny reddyn shoh da Jamys, as da ny braaraghyn. As jimmee Eh roish, as hie Eh gys ynnyd elley.

English: 18 Now as soon as it was day, there was no small stir among the soldiers, what was become of Peter.
Manx: Nish cha leah as va’n laa ayn, va streeu mooar mastey ny sidooryn cre’n erree v’er jeet er Peddyr.

English: 19 And when Herod had sought for him, and found him not, he examined the keepers, and commanded that they should be put to death. And he went down from Judaea to Caesarea, and there abode.
Manx: As tra va Herod dy hirrey magh Eh, as nagh row Eh ry gheddyn, deaysht Eh yn vooinjer va currym y phryssoon orroo, as doardee Eh ad dy ve er nyn goyrt gy baase. As hie Eh sheese veih Judea gys Cesarea, as duirree Eh ayns shen.

English: 20 ¶And Herod was highly displeased with them of Tyre and Sidon : but they came with one accord to him, and, having made Blastus the king’s chamberlain their friend, desired peace ; because their country was nourished by the king’s country.
Manx: As va Herod treeal goll dy ghaggey rish ny Tyrianee as ny Sidonianee : agh haink ad lesh un aigney huggey, as hooar ad stiagh rish Blastus, er va currym y chamyr va’n Ree lhie ayn, as hir ad shee ; er coontey dy row yn cheer oc cummit seose liorish cheer y Ree.

English: 21 And upon a set day Herod, arrayed in royal apparel, sat upon his throne, and made an oration unto them.
Manx: As laa dy row, hug Herod er e choamrey reeoil, as hoie Eh er e stoyl-reeoil, as loayr Eh myr dy beagh Eh jannoo sharmane daue.

English: 22 And the people gave a shout, saying, It is the voice of a god, and not of a man.
Manx: As dyllee yn pobble, She coraa Yee t’ayn, as cha nee coraa dooinney.

English: 23 And immediately the angel of the Lord smote him, because he gave not God the glory : and he was eaten of worms, and gave up the ghost.
Manx: As chelleeragh woaill ainle y Chiarn Eh, er-y-fa nagh dug Eh yn gloyr da Jee : as diee beishteigyn Eh, as hooar Eh baase.

English: 24 ¶But the word of God grew and multiplied.
Manx: Agh ren goo Yee bishaghey as mooadaghey.

English: 25 And Barnabas and Saul returned from Jerusalem, when they had fulfilled their ministry, and took with them John, whose surname was Mark.
Manx: As haink Barnabas as Saul back veih Jerusalem, tra v’ad er chooilleeney yn chirveish oc, as hug ad lhieu mâroo Ean va slennooit Mark.
CAB. XIII.

English: Now there were in the church that was at Antioch certain prophets and teachers ; as Barnabas, and Simeon that was called Niger, and Lucius of Cyrene, and Manaen, which had been brought up with Herod the tetrarch, and Saul.
Manx: Nish va ayns yn agglish va ec Antioch, shiartance dy adeyryn as dy ir-ynsee ; myr Barnabas as Simeon, va enmyssit Niger, as Lucius yn Cyrenean, as Manaen va troggit marish Herod yn tetrarch, as Saul.

English: 2 As they ministered to the Lord, and fasted, the Holy Ghost said, Separate me Barnabas and Saul for the work whereunto I have called them.
Manx: Roo shoh va tendeil er shirveish y Chiarn as trostey, dooyrt y Spyrryd Noo, Soie-jee dooys er-lheh Barnabas as Saul, son yn obbyr huggey ta mee er n’eamagh ad.

English: 3 And when they had fasted and prayed, and laid their hands on them, they sent them away.
Manx: As tra v’ad er hrostey as er ghoaill padjer, as er chur nyn laueyn orroo, hug ad ad ersooyl.

English: 4 ¶So they, being sent forth by the Holy Ghost, departed unto Seleucia ; and from thence they sailed to Cyprus.
Manx: Myr shen jimmee adsyn v’er nyn goyrt magh liorish y Spyrryd Noo, gys Seleucia ; as veih shen hiauill ad gys Cyprus.

English: 5 And when they were at Salamis, they preached the word of God in the synagogues of the Jews : and they had also John to their minister.
Manx: As tra haink ad gys Salamis, ren ad goo Yee y phreacheil ayns kialteenyn ny Hewnyn : as va Ean oc foue son shirveishagh.

English: 6 And when they had gone through the isle unto Paphos, they found a certain sorcerer, a false prophet, a Jew, whose name was Barjesus :
Manx: As tra v’ad er gholl trooid yn Ellan gys Paphos, hooar ad ayns shen fer-obbee dy row, phadeyr-foalsey, Hew va enmyssit Barjesus :

English: 7 Which was with the deputy of the country, Sergius Paulus, a prudent man ; who called for Barnabas and Saul, and desired to hear the word of God.
Manx: Va marish kiannoort ny cheerey, Sergius Paulus, dooinney dy hushtey mie : hug Eh shoh fys er Barnabas as Saul, geearree goo Yee y chlashtyn.

English: 8 But Elymas the sorcerer (for so is his name by interpretation) withstood them, seeking to turn away the deputy from the faith.
Manx: Agh hass Elymas yn fer-obbee (son shen meanal yn ennym echey) nyn oi oc, shirrey yn kiannoort y reaylley veih chyndaa gys y chredjue.

English: 9 Then Saul, (who also is called Paul,) filled with the Holy Ghost, set his eyes on him.
Manx: Agh yeeagh Saul (ta myrgeddin enmyssit Paul) myr v’eh lhieent lesh y Spyrryd Noo, dy feer yhere [sic] er,

English: 10 And said, O full of all subtilty and all mischief, thou child of the devil, thou enemy of all righteousness, wilt thou not cease to pervert the right ways of the Lord?
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, O uss ta laane jeh dy chooilley volterys as dy olkys, vac y Jouyl, noid dy chooilley chairys, nagh scuir uss veih shaghrynys y chur er sleih huïllagh ayns raadjyn cairagh y Chiarn?

English: 11 And now, behold, the hand of the Lord is upon thee, and thou shalt be blind, not seeing the sun for a season. And immediately there fell on him a mist and a darkness ; and he went about seeking some to lead him by the hand.
Manx: As nish cur-my-ner, ta laue yn Chiarn ort, as bee oo doal, cha vaik oo yn ghrian son earish. As chelleeragh huit kay as dorraghys er ; as hie Eh mygeayrt shirrey feallagh huïllagh ny chione.

English: 12 Then the deputy, when he saw what was done, believed, being astonished at the doctrine of the Lord.
Manx: Tra honnick yn kiannoort eisht cre va er daghyrt, ren Eh credjal, as ghow Eh yindyss mooar jeh goo yn Chiarn.

English: 13 Now when Paul and his company loosed from Paphos, they came to Perga in Pamphylia : and John departing from them returned to Jerusalem.
Manx: Nish tra va Paul as e heshaght er hiaulley veih Paphos, haink ad gys Perga ayns Pamphylia : as daag Ean ad, as hie Eh back gys Jerusalem.

English: 14 ¶But when they departed from Perga, they came to Antioch in Pisidia, and went into the synagogue on the sabbath day, and sat down.
Manx: Agh tra v’ad er gholl veih Perga, haink ad gys Antioch ayns Pisidia, as hie ad stiagh ayns y cheeill er laa yn doonaght, as hoie ad sheese.

English: 15 And after the reading of the law and the prophets the rulers of the synagogue sent unto them, saying, Ye men and brethren, if ye have any word of exhortation for the people, say on.
Manx: As lurg lhaih yn leigh as ny phadeyryn, hug fir-reïl ny killagh fys huc, gra, Gheiney as vraaraghyn, my ta fockle erbee dy choyrle eu dy chur da’n pobble, loayr-jee.

English: 16 Then Paul stood up, and beckoning with his hand said, Men of Israel, and ye that fear God, give audience.
Manx: Eisht hass Paul seose, as chrie Eh e laue orroo, as dooyrt Eh, Gheiney Israel, as shiuish ta goaill aggle roish Jee, eaisht-jee.

English: 17 The God of this people of Israel chose our fathers, and exalted the people when they dwelt as strangers in the land of Egypt, and with an high arm brought he them out of it.
Manx: Ren Jee yn pobble shoh Israel ny ayraghyn ain y reih, as yn pobble y hoiaghey seose tra v’ad er nyn yoarreeaght ayns cheer Egypt, as lesh laue niartal hug Eh lesh ad magh ass Egypt.

English: 18 And about the time of forty years suffered he their manners in the wilderness.
Manx: As mysh da-eed blein dy hraa hrog Eh ad ayns yn aasagh, myr ta bondyr troggal liannoo.

English: 19 And when he had destroyed seven nations in the land of Chanaan, he divided their land to them by lot.
Manx: As tra v’eh er stroie shiaght ashoonyn ayns cheer Chanaan, reynn Eh yn thalloo oc orroo liorish lottyn.

English: 20 And after that he gave unto them judges about the space of four hundred and fifty years, until Samuel the prophet.
Manx: As ny lurg shen hug Eh daue briwnyn, mysh kiare cheead as jeih bleeaney as daeed, derrey Samuel yn phadeyr.

English: 21 And afterward they desired a king : and God gave unto them Saul the son of Cis, a man of the tribe of Benjamin, by the space of forty years.
Manx: As ny lurg shen deearree ad Ree : as hug Jee daue Saul mac Cis, dooinney jeh sheeloghe Benjamin, son da-eed blein.

English: 22 And when he had removed him, he raised up unto them David to be their king ; to whom also he gave their testimony, and said, I have found David the son of Jesse, a man after mine own heart, which shall fulfil all my will.
Manx: As tra v’eh er scughey eshyn, hoie eh David seose dy ve ny Ree daue ; gymmyrkey feanish lesh myrgeddin as gra, Ta mee er gheddyn magh David mac Jesse, dooinney lurg my chree hene, nee cooilleeney ooilley my aigney.

English: 23 Of this man’s seed hath God according to his promise raised unto Israel a Saviour, Jesus :
Manx: Jeh sluight y dooinney shoh ta Jee, cordail rish e yialdyn, er hroggal seose da Israel Saualtagh Yeesey :

English: 24 When John had first preached before his coming the baptism of repentance to all the people of Israel.
Manx: Erreish da Ean v’er phreacheil, tra v’eshyn aarloo dy heet, bashtey arrys da ooilley pobble Israel.

English: 25 And as John fulfilled his course, he said, Whom think ye that I am? I am not he. But, behold, there cometh one after me, whose shoes of his feet I am not worthy to loose.
Manx: As myr va Ean cooilleeney e hirveish, dooyrt Eh, Quoi, ta shiu dy smooinaghtyn mish? Cha nee mish Eh. Agh cur-my-ner, ta fer cheet my yei, braagyn e chassyn cha vel mee feeu dy eaysley.

English: 26 Men and brethren, children of the stock of Abraham, and whosoever among you feareth God, to you is the word of this salvation sent.
Manx: Gheiney as vraaraghyn, cloan sheeloghe Abraham, as quoi-erbee ta nyn mast’ eauish goaill aggle roish Jee, hiuish ta goo yn taualtys shoh er ny choyrt.

English: 27 For they that dwell at Jerusalem, and their rulers, because they knew him not, nor yet the voices of the prophets which are read every sabbath day, they have fulfilled them in condemning him.
Manx: Son adsyn ta vaghey ec Jerusalem, as ny fir-reïl oc, son nagh hoie ad jehsyn, ny foast jeh coraaghyn ny phadeyryn t’er nyn lhaih dy chooilley ghoonaght, t’ad er chooilleeney ad shen ayns eshyn y gheyrey.

English: 28 And though they found no cause of death in him, yet desired they Pilate that he should be slain.
Manx: As ga nagh dooar ad oyr erbee baaish ayn, ny-yeih ghuee ad er Pilate e vioys y ghoaill.

English: 29 And when they had fulfilled all that was written of him, they took him down from the tree, and laid him in a sepulchre.
Manx: As tra v’ad er chooilleeney ooilley ny va scruit jeh, ghow ad Eh neose jeh’n villey, as doanluc ad Eh ayns oaie.

English: 30 But God raised him from the dead :
Manx: Agh hrog Jee seose Eh veih ny merriu :

English: 31 And he was seen many days of them which came up with him from Galilee to Jerusalem, who are his witnesses unto the people.
Manx: As v’eh er ny akin ymmodee dy laghyn lioroosyn haink seose mârish veih Galilee gys Jerusalem, quoi va ny feanishyn echey da’n pobble.

English: 32 And we declare unto you glad tidings, how that the promise which was made unto the fathers,
Manx: As ta shinyn soilshaghey diu naightyn gerjoilagh ; yn gialdyn va jeant da ny ayraghyn,

English: 33 God hath fulfilled the same unto us their children, in that he hath raised up Jesus again ; as it is also written in the second psalm, Thou art my Son, this day have I begotten thee.
Manx: Kys dy vel Jee er chooilleeney eh dooinyn yn chloan oc, ayns dy vel Eh er hroggal seose Yeesey reesht ; myr te myrgeddin scruit ayns yn nah psalm, Oo my vac, jiu ta mee er dty gheddyn.

English: 34 And as concerning that he raised him up from the dead, now no more to return to corruption, he said on this wise, I will give you the sure mercies of David.
Manx: As mychione dy hrog Eh Eh seose veih ny merriu, as nagh row Eh arragh dy hyndaa gys loauys, dooyrt Eh er yn aght shoh, Verryms diu myghinyn shickyr Ghavid.

English: 35 Wherefore he saith also in another psalm, Thou shalt not suffer thine Holy One to see corruption.
Manx: Shen-y-fa t’eh gra myrgeddin ayns psalm elley, Cha lig oo da dty Er-casherick loauys y akin.

English: 36 For David, after he had served his own generation by the will of God, fell on sleep, and was laid unto his fathers, and saw corruption :
Manx: Son erreish da David ayns e eash hene v’er hirveish aigney Yee, huit Eh ny chadley, as v’eh er ny oanluckey marish e ayraghyn, as honnick Eh loauys :

English: 37 But he, whom God raised again, saw no corruption.
Manx: Agh eshyn hrog Jee seose reesht, cha vaik Eh loauys.

English: 38 ¶Be it known unto you therefore, men and brethren, that through this man is preached unto you the forgiveness of sins :
Manx: Toig-jee shiuish er-y-fa shen, gheiney as vraaraghyn, dy nee ny hrooidsyn ta leih peccaghyn er ny phreacheil diu :

English: 39 And by him all that believe are justified from all things, from which ye could not be justified by the law of Moses.
Manx: As liorishyn ta ooilley ny ta credjal er ny heyrey veih dy chooilley nhee, vow nagh voddagh shiu v’er ny heyrey liorish leigh Voses.

English: 40 Beware therefore, lest that come upon you, which is spoken of in the prophets ;
Manx: Cur-jee twoaie er-y-fa shen, nagh jig shen ny ta loayrit liorish ny phadeyryn erriu,

English: 41 Behold, ye despisers, and wonder, and perish : for I work a work in your days, a work which ye shall in no wise believe, though a man declare it unto you.
Manx: Cur-jee my-ner, shiuish ta soiaghey beg, as gow-jee yindyss jeh’n toyrt-mow eu : son ta mish gobbraghey obbyr ayns ny laghyn eauish, obbyr nagh jean shiu er aght erbee y chredjal, dy beagh eh er ny hoilshaghey diu.

English: 42 And when the Jews were gone out of the synagogue, the Gentiles besought that these words might be preached to them the next sabbath.
Manx: As tra va ny Hewnyn er gholl as y cheeill, ghuee adsyn jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaagh dy beagh ny goan shoh er ny phreacheil daue yn nah ghoonaght.

English: 43 Now when the congregation was broken up, many of the Jews and religious proselytes followed Paul and Barnabas : who, speaking to them, persuaded them to continue in the grace of God.
Manx: As erreish da sleih ny killagh v’er skeayley, deiyr ymmodee jeh ny Hewnyn, as jeh ny proselyteyn crauee er Paul as Barnabas ; as loayr ad roo, as choyrlee ad ad dy hannaghtyn ayns grayse Yee.

English: 44 ¶And the next sabbath day came almost the whole city together to hear the word of God.
Manx: As yn nah ghoonaght haink faggys yn slane ard-valley cooidjagh dy chlashtyn goo Yee.

English: 45 But when the Jews saw the multitudes, they were filled with envy, and spake against those things which were spoken by Paul, contradicting and blaspheming.
Manx: Agh tra honnick ny Hewnyn leid y chaglym dy leih, daase ad feer jymmoosagh, as loayr ad noi ny reddyn va Paul dy livrey, cur eddin da, loayrt goan-mollaghtagh.

English: 46 Then Paul and Barnabas waxed bold, and said, It was necessary that the word of God should first have been spoken to you : but seeing ye put it from you, and judge yourselves unworthy of everlasting life, lo, we turn to the Gentiles.
Manx: Eisht daase Paul as Barnabas dunnal, as dooyrt ad, Ve ymmyrchagh goo Yee dy ve hoshiaght er ny phreacheil diuish : agh fakin dy vel shiu cur cooyl rish, as briwnys shiu hene neu-feeu jeh’n vea veayn, cur-my-ner, ta shinyn chyndaa gys ny Ashoonyn-quaagh.

English: 47 For so hath the Lord commanded us, saying, I have set thee to be a light of the Gentiles, that thou shouldest be for salvation unto the ends of the earth.
Manx: Son shen myr ta’n Chiarn er chur saarey dooin, gra, Ta mee er hoiaghey oo seose dy ve dty hoilshey da ny Ashoonyn-quaagh, as dy ve son saualtys gys ny ardjyn sodjey er y thalloo.

English: 48 And when the Gentiles heard this, they were glad, and glorified the word of the Lord : and as many as were ordained to eternal life believed.
Manx: As tra cheayll adsyn jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaagh shoh, ghow ad boggey, as ren ad goo yn Chiarn y ghloyraghey : as hyndaa whilleen gys y chredjue as va feeu as aarloo son y vea veayn.

English: 49 And the word of the Lord was published throughout all the region.
Manx: As va goo yn Chiarn er ny hoilshaghey magh trooid ooilley yn cheer.

English: 50 But the Jews stirred up the devout and honourable women, and the chief men of the city, and raised persecution against Paul and Barnabas, and expelled them out of their coasts.
Manx: Agh ghreinnee ny Hewnyn ny mraane seyrey va jeh’n chredjue oc, as deiney mooarey yn ard-valley nyn oi oc, as dirree ad seose noi Paul as Barnabas, as deiyr ad ad ass ny ardjyn oc.

English: 51 But they shook off the dust of their feet against them, and came unto Iconium.
Manx: Agh chrie adsyn yn joan jeh nyn gassyn nyn oi oc, as haink ad gys Iconium.

English: 52 And the disciples were filled with joy, and with the Holy Ghost.
Manx: As v’adsyn v’er jyndaa gys y chredjue lhieent lesh boggey as y Spyrryd Noo.
CAB. XIV.

English: And it came to pass in Iconium, that they went both together into the synagogue of the Jews, and so spake, that a great multitude both of the Jews and also of the Greeks believed.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione ayns Iconium, dy jagh ad ny neesht cooidjagh stiagh ayns keeill ny Hewnyn, as dy loayr ad myr shen dy ren earroo mooar chammah jeh ny Hewnyn as jeusyn jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaagh credjal.

English: 2 But the unbelieving Jews stirred up the Gentiles, and made their minds evil affected against the brethren.
Manx: Agh hug ny Hewnyn nagh hyndaa gys y chredjue adsyn jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaagh er nyn doshiaght, as phushoon ad ny aignaghyn oc noi ny braaraghyn.

English: 3 Long time therefore abode they speaking boldly in the Lord, which gave testimony unto the word of his grace, and granted signs and wonders to be done by their hands.
Manx: Ry foddey dy earish er-y-fa shen duirree ad ayns shen loayrt dy foshlit as dy dunnal ayns y Chiarn, ren feanish y ymmyrkey gys goo e ghrayse hene, as yiall cowraghyn as yindyssyn dy ve jeant liorish ny laueyn oc.

English: 4 But the multitude of the city was divided : and part held with the Jews, and part with the apostles.
Manx: Agh va sleih yn ard-valley noi ry hoi : as va ayrn jeu goaill paart ny Hewnyn, as ayrn elley paart ny ostyllyn.

English: 5 And when there was an assault made both of the Gentiles, and also of the Jews with their rulers, to use them despitefully, and to stone them,
Manx: As tra va chammah adsyn jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaagh, as myrgeddin ny Hewnyn, marish ny fir-reïl oc, soit er drogh ghellal y chur daue, as nyn glaghey ad,

English: 6 They were ware of it, and fled unto Lystra and Derbe, cities of Lycaonia, and unto the region that lieth round about :
Manx: Hooar adsyn fys er, as chosne ad rowe gys Lystra as Derbe, ard-valjyn dy Lycaonia, as gys y cheer mygeayrt :

English: 7 And there they preached the gospel.
Manx: As ayns shen ren ad y sushtal y phreacheil.

English: 8 ¶And there sat a certain man at Lystra, impotent in his feet, being a cripple from his mother’s womb, who never had walked :
Manx: As va ny hoie ec Lystra dooinney dy row, va annoon ayns e chassyn, v’er ny ve croobagh veih breïn e vayrey, cha ren Eh rieau shooyl.

English: 9 The same heard Paul speak : who stedfastly beholding him, and perceiving that he had faith to be healed,
Manx: Cheayll Eh shoh Paul loayrt ; as yeeagh Paul dy gyere er, as dennee Eh dy row credjue echey dy ve er ny lheihys,

English: 10 Said with a loud voice, Stand upright on thy feet. And he leaped and walked.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh lesh ard choraa, Shass seose dy jeeragh er dty chassyn. As leïme Eh, as huïll eh.

English: 11 And when the people saw what Paul had done, they lifted up their voices, saying in the speech of Lycaonia, The gods are come down to us in the likeness of men.
