Manx: As tra honnick y pobble cre va Paul er n’yannoo, hrog ad seose nyn goraaghyn, gra ayns glare Lycaonia, Ta ny Jeeaghyn er jeet neose hooin ayns cummey deiney.

English: 12 And they called Barnabas, Jupiter ; and Paul, Mercurius, because he was the chief speaker.
Manx: As denmys ad Barnabas Jupiter, as Paul Mercury, er-y-fa dy nee Eh smoo va loayrt.

English: 13 Then the priest of Jupiter, which was before their city, brought oxen and garlands unto the gates, and would have done sacrifice with the people.
Manx: Eisht hug saggyrt Jupiter, va cheu-mooie jeh’n ard-valley, lesh dew as lossyreeyn gys ny giattyn, as baillish v’er hebbal oural marish y pobble.

English: 14 Which when the apostles, Barnabas and Paul, heard of, they rent their clothes, and ran in among the people, crying out,
Manx: Agh tra cheayll ny ostyllyn, Barnabas as Paul jeh, raip ad nyn eaddagh, as roih ad stiagh mastey’n pobble, geamagh,

English: 15 And saying, Sirs, why do ye these things? We also are men of like passions with you, and preach unto you that ye should turn from these vanities unto the living God, which made heaven, and earth, and the sea, and all things that are therein :
Manx: As gra, Gheiney, cre’n-fa ta shiu jannoo ny reddyn shoh? Cha vel shinyn agh deiney ta ny annooinidyn cheddin ain as ta eauish, as ta shin preacheil diu, shiu dy hyndaa veih ny fardailyn shoh gys y Jee bio, chroo niau as thalloo, as y faarkey as dy chooilley nhee t’ayndoo :

English: 16 Who in times past suffered all nations to walk in their own ways.
Manx: As ayns ny eashyn t’er gholl shiaghey, lig da ooilley ny Ashoonyn-quaagh shooyl ayns nyn raaidyn hene.

English: 17 Nevertheless he left not himself without witness, in that he did good, and gave us rain from heaven, and fruitful seasons, filling our hearts with food and gladness.
Manx: Ny-yeih cha daag Eh Eh hene fegooish feanish, ayns dy ren Eh mie, as dy dug Eh dooin fliaghey veih niau, as imbaghyn messoil, lhieeney ny creeaghyn ain lesh beaghey as gennalys.

English: 19 And with these sayings scarce restrained they the people, that they had not done sacrifice unto them.
Manx: [sic: 18] As lesh ny raaghyn shoh, scoan ren ad y pobble y lhiettal veih oural y hebbal daue.

English: 19 ¶And there came thither certain Jews from Antioch and Iconium, who persuaded the people, and having stoned Paul, drew him out of the city, supposing he had been dead.
Manx: As haink shiartance dy Hewnyn veih Antioch as Iconium, as chleaynee ad y pobble, as ren ad Paul y chlaghey as y hayrn magh ass yn ard-valley, sheiltyn dy row eh marroo.

English: 20 Howbeit, as the disciples stood round about him, he rose up, and came into the city : and the next day he departed with Barnabas to Derbe.
Manx: Ny-yeih myr v’adsyn va jeh’n chredjue nyn shassoo mygeayrt y mysh, dirree Eh seose as haink Eh stiagh ayns yn ard-valley : as yn nah laa hie Eh marish Barnabas gys Derbe.

English: 21 And when they had preached the gospel to that city, and had taught many, they returned again to Lystra, and to Iconium, and Antioch,
Manx: As tra v’ad er phreacheil y sushtal gys yn ard-valley shen, as er n’ynsaghey ymmodee, haink ad reesht gys Lystra, as gys Iconium as Antioch,

English: 22 Confirming the souls of the disciples, and exhorting them to continue in the faith, and that we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God.
Manx: Niartaghey anmeenyn ny Creesteenyn, as coyrlaghey ad dy hannaghtyn ayns y chredjue, as dy nhegin dooin trooid ymmodee seaghyn goll stiagh ayns reeriaght Yee.

English: 23 And when they had ordained them elders in every church, and had prayed with fasting, they commended them to the Lord, on whom they believed.
Manx: As tra v’ad er hoiaghey er-lheh shirveishee ayns dy chooilley cheeill, as er ghoaill padjer lesh trostey, ren ad y hymney ad gys y Chiarn, ayn v’ad er chredjal.

English: 24 And after they had passed throughout Pisidia, they came to Pamphylia.
Manx: As tra v’ad er gholl harrish ooilley Pisidia, haink ad gys Pamphylia.

English: 25 And when they had preached the word in Perga, they went down into Attalia :
Manx: As erreish daue v’er phreacheil y goo ayns Perga, hie ad sheese gys Attalia :

English: 26 And thence sailed to Antioch, from whence they had been recommended to the grace of God for the work which they fulfilled.
Manx: As veih shen ghow ad luingys gys Antioch, voish v’ad er ny ve chymnit gys grayse Yee, son yn obbyr ren ad y chooilleeney.

English: 27 And when they were come, and had gathered the church together, they rehearsed all that God had done with them, and how he had opened the door of faith unto the Gentiles.
Manx: As tra v’ad er jeet, as er n’eamagh er yn agglish cooidjagh, hug ad coontey daue jeh ooilley ny va Jee er n’yannoo roo, as kys v’eh er vosley dorrys y chredjue da ny Ashoonyn-quaagh.

English: 28 And there they abode long time with the disciples.
Manx: As duirree ad ry foddey dy earish ayns shen, maroosyn v’er jyndaa gys y chredjue.
CAB. XV.

English: And certain men which came down from Judea taught the brethren, and said, Except ye be circumcised after the manner of Moses, ye cannot be saved.
Manx: As dynsee shiartance dy gheiney haink neose veih Judea ny braaraghyn, gra, Mannagh bee shiu er nyn yiarey chymmylt lurg aght Voses, cha vod shiu v’er nyn sauail.

English: 2 When therefore Paul and Barnabas had no small dissension and disputation with them, they determined that Paul and Barnabas, and certain other of them, should go up to Jerusalem unto the apostles and elders about this question.
Manx: Tra va streeu er-y-fa shen as resooney nagh nee beggan er ve ec Paul as Barnabas roo, ghow ad ayns laue dy ragh Paul as Barnabas, as shiartance elley mâroo, seose gys Jerusalem gys ny ostyllyn as y chanstyr mychione y question shoh.

English: 3 And being brought on their way by the church, they passed through Phenice and Samaria, declaring the conversion of the Gentiles : and they caused great joy unto all the brethren.
Manx: As hie yn agglish magh mâroo dy chur ad er nyn doshiaght er nyn yurnah, as jimmee ad trooid Phenice as Samaria, soilshaghey chyndaa ny Ashoonyn-quaagh gys y chredjue : as va shoh oyr boggey mooar da ooilley ny braaraghyn.

English: 4 And when they were come to Jerusalem, they were received of the church, and of the apostles and elders, and they declared all things that God had done with them.
Manx: As tra v’ad er jeet gys Jerusalem, hooar ad oltaghey bea veih’n agglish, as veih ny ostylyn as y chanstyr, as hug ad coontey jeh dy chooilley nhee va Jee er n’yannoo roo.

English: 15 But there rose up certain of the sect of the Pharisees which believed, saying, That it was needful to circumcise them, and to command them to keep the law of Moses.
Manx: As dirree seose shiartance jeh ny Phariseeyn v’er jyndaa gys y chredjue, as dooyrt ad, Dy row eh ymmyrchagh ad y yiarey chymmylt, as saarey chur daue ad dy reaylley leigh Voses.

English: 6 ¶And the apostles and elders came together for to consider of this matter.
Manx: As haink ny ostyllyn as y chanstyr cooidjagh dy reaghey yn chooish shoh.

English: 7 And when there had been much disputing, Peter rose up, and said unto them, Men and brethren, ye know how that a good while ago God made choice among us, that the Gentiles by my mouth should hear the word of the gospel, and believe.
Manx: As erreish daue v’er ve foddey resooney, dirree Peddyr seose, as dooyrt Eh roo, Gheiney as vraaraghyn, ta fys eu foddey er dy henney, dy ren Jee reih y yannoo nyn mast’ ain, dy row ny Ashoonyn-quaagh veih my veeal’s dy chlashtyn goo yn sushtal, as dy chredjal.

English: 8 And God, which knoweth the hearts, bare them witness, giving them the Holy Ghost, even as he did unto us ;
Manx: Agh dymmyrk Jee, echey ta fys cre t’ayns ny creeaghyn, feanish lhieu, as hug Eh daue yn Spyrryd Noo, myr hug Eh dooinyn.

English: 9 And put no difference between us and them, purifying their hearts by faith.
Manx: As cha dug Eh scarrey erbee eddyr adsyn as shinyn, glenney ny creeaghyn oc liorish credjue.

English: 10 Now therefore why tempt ye God, to put a yoke upon the neck of the disciples, which neither our fathers nor we were able to bear?
Manx: Kys er-y-fa shen dy vel shiu nish brasnaghey Jee, liorish quing y choyrt er y wannal ocsyn ta jeh’n chredjue, nagh row ny ayraghyn ain ny shin hene abyl y ymmyrkey?

English: 11 But we believe that through the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ we shall be saved, even as they.
Manx: Agh ta shin credjal trooid grayse nyn Jiarn Yeesey Creest, dy bee mad er nyn sauail, er yn un aght as vees adsyn.

English: 12 ¶Then all the multitude kept silence, and gave audience to Barnabas and Paul, declaring what miracles and wonders God had wrought among the Gentiles by them.
Manx: Eisht va ooilley yn cheshaght nyn dost, as deaisht ad rish Barnabas as Paul soilshaghey cre ny mirrillyn as ny yindyssyn va Jee er n’obbraghey mastey ny Ashoonyn-quaagh lioroosyn.

English: 13 ¶And after they had held their peace, James answered, saying, Men and brethren, hearken unto me :
Manx: As erreish daue v’er chummal nyn jengey, dreggyr Jamys, gra, Gheiney as vraaraghyn, eaisht-jee rhym’s.

English: 14 Simeon hath declared how God at the first did visit the Gentiles, to take out of them a people for his name.
Manx: Ta Simeon er hoilshaghey kys ren Jee ec y toshiaght jeeaghyn er ny Ashoonyn-quaagh, dy ghoaill assdoo pobble son yn ennym echey.

English: 15 And to this agree the words of the prophets ; as it is written,
Manx: As rish shoh ta cordail goan ny phadeyryn ; myr te scruit,

English: 16 After this I will return, and will build again the tabernacle of David, which is fallen down ; and I will build again the ruins thereof, and I will set it up :
Manx: Ny lurg shoh higgyms reesht, as troggym as yn noa cabbane-agglish Ghavid, ta er duittym ; as troggym eh reesht erreish da v’er gholl naardey, as soie-ym eh seose :

English: 17 That the residue of men might seek after the Lord, and all the Gentiles, upon whom my name is called, saith the Lord, who doeth all these things.
Manx: Dy vod y Chiarn v’er ny hirrey magh liorish y chooid elley jeh ny deiney, as liorish ooilley ny Ashoonyn-quaagh, orroo ta my ennym er ny enmyss, ta’n Chiarn gra, ta jannoo dy chooilley nhee jeu shoh.

English: 18 Known unto God are all his works from the beginning of the world.
Manx: Ec Jee ta fys er ooilley e obbraghyn hene, er dy hoshiaght y theihll.

English: 19 Wherefore my sentence is, that we trouble not them, which from among the Gentiles are turned to God :
Manx: Shen-y-fa my vriwnys’s eh, gyn shin dy heaghnaghey adsyn ta veih mastey ny Ashoonyn-quaagh er jyndaa gys Jee :

English: 20 But that we write unto them, that they abstain from pollutions of idols, and from fornication, and from things strangled, and from blood.
Manx: Agh shin dy scrieu huc, ad dy reaylley ad hene veih broïd jallooyn, as veih maarderys, as veih reddyn toghtit, as veih fuill.

English: 21 For Moses of old time hath in every city them that preach him, being read in the synagogues every sabbath day.
Manx: Son ta ec Moses er dyn chen earish, ayns dy chooilley ard-valley adsyn ta dy phreacheil Eh, as t’eh er ny lhaih ayns ny kialteenyn dy chooilley ghoonaght.

English: 22 Then pleased it the apostles and elders with the whole church, to send chosen men of their own company to Antioch with Paul and Barnabas ; namely, Judas surnamed Barsabas and Silas, chief men among the brethren :
Manx: Eisht yeeagh ny ostyllyn as y chanstyr, as y slane agglish er dy ve ymmyrchagh, dy chur deiney reiht jeh’n cheshaght oc hene gys Antioch, marish Paul as Barnabas, ta shen dy ghra, Judas slennooit Barsabas, as Silas, ard deiney mastey ny braaraghyn :

English: 23 And they wrote letters by them after this manner ; The apostles and elders and brethren send greeting unto the brethren which are of the Gentiles in Antioch and Syria and Cilicia.
Manx: As scrieu ad screeuyn lhieu er yn aght shoh, Ta ny ostyllyn, as y chanstyr, as ny braaraghyn cur bannaght gys ny braaraghyn ta jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaagh ayns Antioch, as Syria as Cilicia.

English: 24 Forasmuch as we have heard, that certain which went out from us have troubled you with words, subverting your souls, saying, Ye must be circumcised, and keep the law : to whom we gave no such commandment :
Manx: Son wheesh as dy vel shin er chlashtyn, dy vel shiartance hie magh voinyn er ny heaghnaghey shiu lesh goan, seih nyn anmeenyn, as gra, dy nhegin diu v’er nyn yiarey chymmylt, as y leigh y reaylley ; daue cha dug shinyn leid y saarey :

English: 25 It seemed good unto us, being assembled with one accord, to send chosen men unto you with our beloved Barnabas and Paul,
Manx: Ta shinyn, ta lesh un aigney er nyn jaglym cooidjagh, er vakin eh fit, dy chur deiney reiht hiuish, marish nyn mraaraghyn graihagh Barnabas as Paul ;

English: 26 Men that have hazarded their lives for the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.
Manx: Deiney veagh er scarrey rish nyn mioys son ennym nyn Jiarn Yeesey Creest.

English: 27 We have sent therefore Judas and Silas, who shall also tell you the same things by mouth.
Manx: Ta shin er-y-fa shen er chur hiu Judas as Silas, nee ny reddyn cheddin y insh diu.

English: 28 For it seemed good to the Holy Ghost, and to us, to lay upon you no greater burden than these necessary things ;
Manx: Son te er ny akin fit liorish yn Spyrryd Noo, as liorinyn, gyn errey smoo y chur erriu na ny reddyn ymmyrchagh shoh ;

English: 29 That ye abstain from meats offered to idols, and from blood, and from things strangled, and from fornication : from which if ye keep yourselves, ye shall do well. Fare ye well.
Manx: Shiu dy reaylley shiu hene veih beeghyn va chebbit gys jallooyn, as veih fuill, as veih reddyn toghtit, as veih maarderys : vow shoh my reaillys shiu shiu hene, nee shiu dy mie. Shee dy row hiu.

English: 30 So when they were dismissed, they came to Antioch : and when they had gathered the multitude together, they delivered the epistle :
Manx: Myr shen tra v’ad er lhiggey yn raad daue, haink ad gys Antioch : as cha leah as va’n cheshaght er nyn jaglym cooidjagh, livrey ad ny screeuyn.

English: 31 Which when they had read, they rejoiced for the consolation.
Manx: As lhaih ad ee lesh boggey as gerjagh mooar.

English: 32 And Judas and Silas, being prophets also themselves, exhorted the brethren with many words, and confirmed them.
Manx: As myr va Judas as Silas nyn vadeyryn ad hene, choyrlee ad ny braaraghyn lesh ymmodee goan, as hickyree ad ad ayns nyn gredjue.

English: 33 And after they had tarried there a space, they were let go in peace from the brethren unto the apostles.
Manx: As erreish daue v’er vuirriaght ayns shen son earish, lig ny braaraghyn y raad daue gys ny ostyllyn ayns shee.

English: 34 Notwithstanding it pleased Silas to abide there still.
Manx: Ny-yeih she aigney Silas ve dy uirriaght ayns shen.

English: 35 Paul also and Barnabas continued in Antioch, teaching and preaching the word of the Lord, with many others also.
Manx: Duirree Paul myrgeddin as Barnabas ayns Antioch, gynsaghey as preacheil goo yn Chiarn, marish ymmodee elley.

English: 36 ¶And some days after Paul said unto Barnabas, Let us go again and visit our brethren in every city where we have preached the word of the Lord, and see how they do.
Manx: As laghyn ny lurg shen dooyrt Paul rish Barnabas, Lig dooin goll reesht dy yeeaghyn nyn mraaraghyn ayns dy chooilley ard-valley, raad ta shin er phreacheil goo yn Chiarn, dy yeeaghyn kys t’ad.

English: 37 And Barnabas determined to take with them John, whose surname was Mark.
Manx: As va Barnabas booiagh Ean y chur lhieu mâroo, va slennooit Mark.

English: 38 But Paul thought not good to take him with them, who departed from them from Pamphylia, and went not with them to the work.
Manx: Agh dob Paul nagh ragh Eh mâroo, son dy daag Eh ad ec Pamphylia, as nagh jagh Eh mâroo gys yn obbyr.

English: 39 And the contention was so sharp between them, that they departed asunder one from the other : and so Barnabas took Mark, and sailed unto Cyprus ;
Manx: As dirree leid y streeu shen eddyr ad, dy scarr ad ry cheïley : as hug Barnabas lesh Mark, as ghow Eh luingys gys Cyprus.

English: 40 And Paul chose Silas, and departed, being recommended by the brethren unto the grace of God.
Manx: As reih Paul Silas, as jimmee Eh roish, erreish da v’er ny hymney gys grayse Yee liorish ny braaraghyn.

English: 41 And he went through Syria and Cilicia, confirming the churches.
Manx: As huïll Eh trooid Syria as Cilicia, niartaghey ny kialteenyn ayns nyn gredjue.
CAB. XVI.

English: Then came he to Derbe and Lystra : and, behold, a certain disciple was there, named Timotheus, the son of a certain woman, which was a Jewess, and believed ; but his father was a Greek :
Manx: Eisht haink Eh gys Derbe as Lystra : as cur-my-ner, va dooinney dy row jeh’n chredjue ayns shen, va enmyssit Timothy, mac ben dy row v’er ve ny Hew, as ren chyndaa gys y chredjue ; agh va’n ayr echey jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaagh :

English: 2 Which was well reported of by the brethren that were at Lystra and Iconium.
Manx: Va goo-mie ec Timothy shoh veih ny braaraghyn va ec Lystra as Iconium.

English: 3 Him would Paul have to go forth with him ; and took and circumcised him because of the Jews which were in those quarters : for they knew all that his father was a Greek.
Manx: As eshyn ballish Paul dy gholl magh mârish ; as ghow Eh as ren Eh Eh y yiarey chymmylt, kyndagh rish ny Hewnyn v’ayns ny ardjyn shen : son va fys oc ooilley dy row e ayr jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaagh.

English: 4 And as they went through the cities, they delivered them the decrees for to keep, that were ordained of the apostles and elders which were at Jerusalem.
Manx: As myr v’ad goll trooid ny ard-valjyn livrey ad daue ny oardaghyn dy reaylley v’er nyn goyrt magh liorish ny ostyllyn as y chanstyr va ec Jerusalem.

English: 5 And so were the churches established in the faith, and increased in number daily.
Manx: As shen myr va ny kialteenyn er nyn niartaghey ayns y chredjue, as er nyn mishaghey ayns earroo gagh laa.

English: 6 Now when they had gone throughout Phrygia and the region of Galatia, and were forbidden of the Holy Ghost to preach the word in Asia,
Manx: Nish tra v’ad er gholl trooid Phrygia, as cheer Galatia, hug y Spyrryd Noo currym daue gyn ad dy phreacheil y goo ayns Asia,

English: 7 After they were come to Mysia, they assayed to go into Bithynia : but the Spirit suffered them not.
Manx: As erreish daue v’er jeet gys Mysia, heb ad dy gholl er nyn doshiaght gys Bithynia : agh cha lig y Spyrryd daue.

English: 8 And they passing by Mysia came down to Troas.
Manx: Myr shen hie ad shiaghey Mysia, as haink ad neose gys Troas.

English: 9 And a vision appeared to Paul in the night ; There stood a man of Macedonia, and prayed him, saying, Come over into Macedonia, and help us.
Manx: As honnick Paul ashlish ayns yn oie ; Hass dooinney jeh Macedonia liorish, as ghuee Eh er, gra, Tarr noon gys Macedonia, as cooin lhien.

English: 10 And after he had seen the vision, immediately we endeavoured to go into Macedonia, assuredly gathering that the Lord had called us for to preach the gospel unto them.
Manx: As erreish da v’er vakin yn ashlish ghow shin ayns laue chelleeragh dy ragh shin gys Macedonia, goaill ain hene ayns shickyrys dy row yn Chiarn er n’eamagh orrin dy phreacheil y sushtal daue.

English: 11 Therefore loosing from Troas, we came with a straight course to Samothracia, and the next day to Neapolis ;
Manx: Shen-y-fa ghow deashil shin veih Troas, as haink shin lesh coorse jeeragh gys Samothracia, as yn nah laa gys Neapolis ;

English: 12 And from thence to Philippi, which is the chief city of that part of Macedonia, and a colony : and we were in that city abiding certain days.
Manx: As veih shen gys Philippi, yn ard-valley by voo v’ayns yn ayrn shen jeh Macedonia, as bentyn gys y Raue : as duirree shin ayns yn ard-valley shen shiartance dy laghyn.

English: 13 And on the sabbath we went out of the city by a river side, where prayer was wont to be made ; and we sat down, and spake unto the women which resorted thither.
Manx: As er laa’n doonaght hie shin magh ass y valley, gys boayl va lowit son padjer, rish oirr ny hawin ; as hoie shin sheese, as loayr shin rish ny mraane v’er nyn jaglym cooidjagh.

English: 14 ¶And a certain woman named Lydia, a seller of purple, of the city of Thyatira, which worshipped God, heard us : whose heart the Lord opened, that she attended unto the things which were spoken of Paul.
Manx: As va ben dy row enmyssit Lydia, va jeh ard-valley Thyatira, as creck gorrym-jiarg, v’ee shoh cur ooashley da Jee, as deaisht ee rooin : as doshil yn Chiarn y cree eck, dy dug ee geill da ny va Paul dy loayrt.

English: 15 And when she was baptized, and her household, she besought us, saying, If ye have judged me to be faithful to the Lord, come into my house, and abide there. And she constrained us.
Manx: As tra v’ee hene as lught e thie er nyn mashtey, ghuee ee orrin, gra, My ta shiu er vriwnys mish dy ve firrinagh gys y Chiarn, tarr-jee stiagh as fuirree-jee ayns my hie. As cha goghe ee obbal voïn.

English: 16 ¶And it came to pass, as we went to prayer, a certain damsel possessed with a spirit of divination met us, which brought her masters much gain by soothsaying :
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, myr va shin goll gys y boayl va lowit son padjer, dy daink ben-aeg dy row nyn guail, ayn-jee va spyrryd dy aishnagh, as v’ee cur ymmodee cosney da ny mainshtyryn eck, liorish ny reddyn v’ee dy insh :

English: 17 The same followed Paul and us, and cried, saying, These men are the servants of the most high God, which shew unto us the way of salvation.
Manx: Deiyr ee shoh er Paul as orrinyn, geamagh as gra, Ny deiney shoh sharvaantyn y Jee smoo ard, ta soilshaghey dooin raad y taualtys.

English: 18 And this did she many days. But Paul, being grieved, turned and said to the spirit, I command thee in the name of Jesus Christ to come out of her. And he came out the same hour.
Manx: As shoh ren ee ry ymmodee dy laghyn. Agh va Paul jymmoosagh, as hyndaa Eh, as dooyrt Eh rish y spyrryd, Ta mee cur currym ort ayns ennym Yeesey Creest oo dy heet magh ass-jee. As haink eh magh yn oor cheddin.

English: 19 ¶And when her masters saw that the hope of their gains was gone, they caught Paul and Silas, and drew them into the marketplace unto the rulers,
Manx: As tra honnick ny mainshtyryn eck nagh row ad dy yerkal rish arragh dy chosney lioree, haare ad Paul as Silas, as hayrn ad ad gys y whaiyl, fenish fir-reïl yn ard-valley,

English: 20 And brought them to the magistrates, saying, These men, being Jews, do exceedingly trouble our city,
Manx: Eisht hug ad lhieu ad gys ny fir-reïl va veih’n Raue, gra, Ta ny deiney shoh er ghoostey ymmodee anvea ayns yn ard-valley ain, liorish dy nee Hewnyn ad,

English: 21 And teach customs, which are not lawful for us to receive, neither to observe, being Romans.
Manx: As dy vel ad cur magh oardaghyn nagh vel lowit dooinyn, ta bentyn gys y Raue, dy ghoaill orrin, ny dy reaylley.

English: 22 And the multitude rose up together against them : and the magistrates rent off their clothes, and commanded to beat them.
Manx: As dirree yn pobble magh nyn oi : as raip ny fir-reïl nyn eaddagh, as hug ad saarey ad dy ve er nyn mwoalley lesh slattyn.

English: 23 And when they had laid many stripes upon them, they cast them into prison, charging the jailor to keep them safely :
Manx: As tra v’ad er chur ymmodee buillaghyn daue, hilg ad ad ayns pryssoon, as hug ad saarey dasyn va currym y phryssoon er, Eh dy reaylley ad dy sauchey ;

English: 24 Who, having received such a charge, thrust them into the inner prison, and made their feet fast in the stocks.
Manx: Quoi, liorish dy row leid y saarey er ny chur da, hilg ad ayns y phryssoon bodjey stiagh, as hug ny cassyn oc dy shickyr ayns ny stockyn.

English: 25 ¶And at midnight Paul and Silas prayed, and sang praises unto God : and the prisoners heard them.
Manx: Agh ec main-oie ghow Paul as Silas padjer as arraneyn moyllee gys Jee : as cheayll ny pryssoonee ad.

English: 26 And suddenly there was a great earthquake, so that the foundations of the prison were shaken : and immediately all the doors were opened, and every one’s bands were loosed.
Manx: As ayns y tullogh va craa mooar thallooin ayn, myr shen dy row undinyn y phryssoon er nyn graa : as chelleeragh va ooilley ny dorryssyn er nyn vosley, as kianglaghyn dy chooilley annane er nyn veaysley.

English: 27 And the keeper of the prison awaking out of his sleep, and seeing the prison doors open, he drew out his sword, and would have killed himself, supposing that the prisoners had been fled.
Manx: As ghooisht eshyn va currym y phryssoon er ass e chadley, as tra honnick Eh dorryssyn y phryssoon foshlit, hayrn Eh e chliwe, as ballish v’er varroo Eh hene, goaill ayns laue dy row ny pryssoonee er chosney rowe.

English: 28 But Paul cried with a loud voice, saying, Do thyself no harm : for we are all here.
Manx: Agh deïe Paul lesh ard choraa, gra, Ny jean aggair erbee dhyt hene ; son ta shin ooilley ayns shoh.

English: 29 Then he called for a light, and sprang in, and came trembling, and fell down before Paul and Silas,
Manx: Eisht deïe Eh son soilshey, as hie Eh stiagh, as huit Eh sheese er-creau kiongoyrt rish Paul as Silas ;

English: 30 And brought them out, and said, Sirs, what must I do to be saved?
Manx: As hug Eh lesh ad magh, as dooyrt Eh, Gheiney mie, cre shegin dooys y yannoo dy voddym v’er my hauail?

English: 31 And they said, Believe on the Lord Jesus Christ, and thou shalt be saved, and thy house.
Manx: As dooyrt ad, Cred ayns y Chiarn Yeesey Creest, as bee oo hene as dty hie er nyn sauail.

English: 32 And they spake unto him the word of the Lord, and to all that were in his house.
Manx: As loayr ad goo yn Chiarn rishyn, as rish ooilley ny va ayns e hie.

English: 33 And he took them the same hour of the night, and washed their stripes ; and was baptized, he and all his, straightway.
Manx: As ghow Eh ad yn oor cheddin jeh’n oie, as niee Eh ny lottyn oc ; as v’eh hene as ooilley lught e hie er nyn mashtey chelleeragh.

English: 34 And when he had brought them into his house, he set meat before them, and rejoiced, believing in God with all his house.
Manx: As tra v’eh er chur lesh ad stiagh ayns e hie, hoie Eh bee rhumboo, as ghow Eh hene as ooilley e hie boggey, as chred ad ayns Jee.

English: 35 And when it was day, the magistrates sent the serjeants, saying, Let those men go.
Manx: As tra va’n laa ayn, hug ny fir-reïl ny fir-oik va foue, gra, Lig ny deiney shen magh.

English: 36 And the keeper of the prison told this saying to Paul, The magistrates have sent to let you go : now therefore depart, and go in peace.
Manx: As dinsh eshyn va currym y phryssoon yn raa shoh da Paul, Ta ny fir-reïl er chur fys dy lhiggey yn raad diu : gow-jee nish er-y-fa shen magh, as immee-jee reue ayns shee.

English: 37 But Paul said unto them, They have beaten us openly uncondemned, being Romans, and have cast us into prison ; and now do they thrust us out privily? nay verily ; but let them come themselves and fetch us out.
Manx: Agh dooyrt Paul roo, T’ad er nyn mwoalley shinyn, ta bentyn gys y Raue, dy foshlit as fegooish v’er nyn mriwnys, as er hilgey shin ayns pryssoon ; as vel ad nish dyn eiyrt shin magh dy follit? cha bee eh myr shen ayns firrinys ; agh lig daue hene cheet as shin y chur lhieu magh.

English: 38 And the serjeants told these words unto the magistrates : and they feared, when they heard that they were Romans.
Manx: As dinsh ny fir-oik ny reddyn shoh da ny fir-reïl : as ghow ad aggle tra cheayll ad dy row ad bentyn gys y Raue.

English: 39 And they came and besought them, and brought them out, and desired them to depart out of the city.
Manx: As haink ad lesh aghin huc, as hug ad lhieu magh ad, as ghuee ad orroo ad dy gholl rowe ass yn ard-valley.

English: 40 And they went out of the prison, and entered into the house of Lydia : and when they had seen the brethren, they comforted them, and departed.
Manx: As tra v’adsyn er jeet ass y phryssoon, hie ad stiagh ayns thie Lydia : as erreish daue v’er vakin ny braaraghyn, ren ad y gherjaghey ad, as jimmee ad roue.
CAB. XVII.

English: Now when they had passed through Amphipolis and Apollonia, they came to Thessalonica, where was a synagogue of the Jews :
Manx: Nish tra v’ad er gholl trooid Amphipolis as Apollonia, haink ad gys Thessalonica, raad va keeill ec ny Hewnyn.

English: 2 And Paul, as his manner was, went in unto them, and three sabbath days reasoned with them out of the scriptures,
Manx: As hie Paul, myr va’n cliaghtey echey stiagh huc, as son three doonaghtyn ren Eh resooney roo ass ny scriptyryn,

English: 3 Opening and alleging, that Christ must needs have suffered, and risen again from the dead ; and that this Jesus, whom I preach unto you, is Christ.
Manx: Cur tushtey daue as soiaghey roue dy beign da Cresst v’er hurranse, as v’er n’irree veih ny merriu : as dy nee Yeesey shoh ta mish dy phreacheil diu, yn Creest.

English: 4 And some of them believed, and consorted with Paul and Silas ; and of the devout Greeks a great multitude, and of the chief women not a few.
Manx: As ren paart jeu credjal, as lhiantyn gys Paul as Silas : as shen ren earroo mooar jeh ny Greekyn crauee, as myrgeddin jeh ny ard vraane.

English: 5 ¶But the Jews which believed not, moved with envy, took unto them certain lewd fellows of the baser sort, and gathered a company, and set all the city on an uproar, and assaulted the house of Jason, and sought to bring them out to the people.
Manx: Agh hie ny Hewnyn nagh hyndaa gys y chredjue son troo moo, as ghow ad huc shiartance dy ghrogh gheiney as dy vee-reiltee ; as tra va chaglym mooar jeu oc, voiyr ad ooilley yn ard-valley, as hie ad stiagh er niart ayns thie Jason, shirrey ad y choyrt lhieu magh gys y pobble.

English: 6 And when they found them not, they drew Jason and certain brethren unto the rulers of the city, crying, These that have turned the world upside down are come hither also ;
Manx: As tra nagh dooar ad ad, hayrn ad lhieu Jason as shiartance jeh ny braaraghyn gys fir-reïl yn ard-valley, geamagh, T’ad shoh t’er hyndaa yn seihll bun rish skyn er jeet ayns shoh neesht ;

English: 7 Whom Jason hath received : and these all do contrary to the decrees of Caesar, saying that there is another king, one Jesus.
Manx: As ta Jason er chur oltaghey bea daue : as t’ad shoh ooilley jannoo noi oardaghyn Cesar, gra dy vel ree elley ayn, enmyssit Yeesey.

English: 8 And they troubled the people and the rulers of the city, when they heard these things.
Manx: As va ooilley yn pobble as fir-reïl yn ard-valley ayns imnea mooar, tra cheayll ad ny reddyn shoh.

English: 9 And when they had taken security of Jason, and of the other, they let them go.
Manx: As tra v’ad er ghoaill raanteenyn son Jason as y vooinjer elley, lhig ad y raad daue.

English: 10 ¶And the brethren immediately sent away Paul and Silas by night unto Berea : who coming thither went into the synagogue of the Jews.
Manx: As hug ny braaraghyn ersooyl chelleeragh Paul as Silas ayns yn oie gys Berea : as tra v’ad er jeet gys shen, hie ad stiagh ayns keeill ny Hewnyn.

English: 17 These were more noble than those in Thessalonica, in that they received the word with all readiness of mind, and searched the scriptures daily, whether those things were so.
Manx: V’ad shoh ny s’fudee na ny Thessalonianee, ayns dy deaisht ad rish y goo lesh dy chooilley arryltys aigney, as hir ad magh ny scriptyryn gagh laa, nee shen myr va ny reddyn shen.

English: 12 Therefore many of them believed ; also of honourable women which were Greeks, and of men, not a few.
Manx: Shen-y-fa ren ymmodee jeu credjal : as myrgeddin dy vraane ooasle va nyn Greekyn, as dy gheiney.

English: 13 But when the Jews of Thessalonica had knowledge that the word of God was preached of Paul at Berea, they came thither also, and stirred up the people.
Manx: Agh tra hooar Hewnyn Thessalonica fys dy row Paul er phreacheil goo Yee ec Berea, haink ad derrey shen, as ghreinnee ad yn pobble n’oi.

English: 14 And then immediately the brethren sent away Paul to go as it were to the sea : but Silas and Timotheus abode there still.
Manx: Er shen hug ny braaraghyn Paul chelleeragh, myr dy beagh Eh dy gholl son y cheayin : agh duirree Silas as Timothy ayns shen.

English: 15 And they that conducted Paul brought him unto Athens : and receiving a commandment unto Silas and Timotheus for to come to him with all speed, they departed.
Manx: As hug y vooinjer hie marish Paul lhieu Eh gys Athens : as erreish daue v’er gheddyn saarey gys Silas as Timothy dy heet huggey lesh dy chooilley hiyr, jimmee ad rowe.

English: 16 ¶Now while Paul waited for them at Athens, his spirit was stirred in him, when he saw the city wholly given to idolatry.
Manx: Nish choud as va Paul farkiaght son y cheet oc ec Athens, v’eh seaghnit ayns e aigney, tra honnick Eh ooilley yn ard-valley laane jallooyn.

English: 17 Therefore disputed he in the synagogue with the Jews, and with the devout persons, and in the market daily with them that met with him.
Manx: Shen-y-fa ren Eh resooney ayns y cheeill rish ny Hewnyn, as rish ny deiney crauee, as ayns y vargey gagh laa roosyn va cheet ny raad.

English: 18 Then certain philosophers of the Epicureans, and of the Stoicks, encountered him. And some said, What will this babbler say? other some, He seemeth to be a setter forth of strange gods : because he preached unto them Jesus, and the resurrection.
Manx: Eisht hoie shiartance jeh fir-ynsee ny Epicureanee as ny Stoickyn er : as dooyrt paart jeu, Cre ballish shoh ta goaill wheesh dy haggloo er y ghra? Dooyrt feallagh elley, T’eh jeeaghyn myr dy beagh Eh loayrt jeh Jee’ghyn noa ; er-yn-oyr dy row Eh preacheil daue Yeesey, as yn irree-seose-reesht.

English: 19 And they took him, and brought him unto Areopagus, saying, May we know what this new doctrine, whereof thou speakest, is?
Manx: As ghow ad, as hug ad lhieu Eh gys Areopagus, gra, Vod mad fys y gheddyn cre’n ynsagh noa shoh tow uss dy chur magh?

English: 20 For thou bringest certain strange things to our ears : we would know therefore what these things mean.
Manx: Son t’ow feiyral shiartance dy reddyn yindyssagh ayns ny cleashyn ain : baillin er-y-fa shen fys y gheddyn cre er t’ow cheet liorish ny reddyn shoh?

English: 21 (For all the Athenians and strangers which were there spent their time in nothing else, but either to tell, or to hear some new thing.)
Manx: (Son cha row ooilley ny Athenianee as ny joarreeyn v’ayns shen, baarail nyn draa ayns nhee erbee, agh edyr dy insh, ny dy chlashtyn red ennagh noa.)

English: 22 ¶Then Paul stood in the midst of Mars’ hill, and said, Ye men of Athens, I perceive that in all things ye are too superstitious.
Manx: Eisht hass Paul seose ayns main Areopagus, as dooyrt Eh, Gheiney Athens, Heeym dy vel er dy chooilley aght rouyr fardail ayns y chraueeaght eu.

English: 23 For as I passed by, and beheld your devotions, I found an altar with this inscription, TO THE UNKNOWN GOD. Whom therefore ye ignorantly worship, him declare I unto you.
Manx: Son myr va mee goll shiaghey, as goaill tastey jeh’n ooashley eu, hooar mee altar va’n raa shoh scruit er, GYS Y JEE NAGH VEL TUSHTEY AIN JEH. She eshyn er-y-fa shen ta shiu dy mee-hushtagh cur ooashley da, ta mish dy hoilshaghey diu.

English: 24 God that made the world and all things therein, seeing that he is Lord of heaven and earth, dwelleth not in temples made with hands ;
Manx: Jee ren y seihll, as dy chooilley nhee t’ayn y chroo, fakin dy nee Chiarn niau as thalloo Eh, cha vel Eh vaghey ayns chiambyllyn ta troggit lesh laueyn :

English: 25 Neither is worshipped with men’s hands, as though he needed any thing, seeing he giveth to all life, and breath, and all things ;
Manx: Cha-moo ta ooashley er ny chur da lesh laueyn deiney, myr dy beagh feme echey er nhee erbee, fakin dy vel Eh coyrt da ooilley bioys, as ennal, as dy chooilley nhee ;

English: 26 And hath made of one blood all nations of men for to dwell on all the face of the earth, and hath determined the times before appointed, and the bounds of their habitation ;
Manx: As dy hrog Eh seose jeh’n un uill ooilley ashoonyn sheelnaue, dy chur orroo vaghey er ooilley eaghtyr y thallooin, as dy vel Eh er n’oardaghey ny earishyn v’eh roie er ny hoiaghy, as ardjyn ny ynnydyn-vaghee oc :

English: 27 That they should seek the Lord, if haply they might feel after him, and find him, though he be not far from every one of us :
Manx: Dy voddagh ad y Chiarn y hirrey, my haghyragh daue briaght er e hon, as y gheddyn magh Eh, ga nagh vel Eh foddey veih dy chooilley annane ain :

English: 28 For in him we live, and move, and have our being ; as certain also of your own poets have said, For we are also his offspring.
Manx: Son aynsyn ta shin bio, as gleashaght, as beaghey ; myr ta paart jeh ny poetyn eu hene er ghra, Son she jehsyn myrgeddin haink shin.

English: 29 Forasmuch then as we are the offspring of God, we ought not to think that the Godhead is like unto gold, or silver, or stone, graven by art and man’s device.
Manx: Son wheesh eisht as dy nee jeh Jee haink shin, cha lhisagh shin smooinaghtyn dy vel y Dooghys-Jee goll-rish aihr, ny argid, ny clagh obbyrit lesh keeal as shleie dooinney.

English: 30 And the times of this ignorance God winked at ; but now commandeth all men every where to repent :
Manx: As son earishyn y vee-hushtey shoh, cha ghow Jee kerraghey ; agh nish t’eh cur saarey da dy chooilley ghooinney ayns dy chooilley ynnyd arrys y ghoaill :

English: 31 Because he hath appointed a day, in the which he will judge the world in righteousness by that man whom he hath ordained ; whereof he hath given assurance unto all men, in that he hath raised him from the dead.
Manx: Er-y-fa dy vel Eh er hoiaghey laa ry hoi yn seihll y vriwnys ayns cairys, liorish y dooinney shen t’eh er ny phointeil ; as jeh shoh t’eh er chur shickyrys da dy chooilley ghooinney, ayns dy vel Eh er hroggal Eh veih ny merriu.

English: 32 ¶And when they heard of the resurrection of the dead, some mocked : and others said, We will hear thee again of this matter.
Manx: As tra cheayll ad jeh irree-seose-reesht ny merriu, ren paart craidey : as dooyrt cooid elley jeu, Eaishtee mad rhyt keayrt elley mychione shen.

English: 33 So Paul departed from among them.
Manx: Myr shen jimmee Paul veih nyn mast’ oc.

English: 34 Howbeit certain men clave unto him, and believed : among the which was Dionysius the Areopagite, and a woman named Damaris, and others with them.
Manx: Ny-yeih ren shiartance dy gheiney lhiantyn huggey, as credjal : nyn mast’ ocsyn va Dionysius yn Areopagite, as ben va enmyssit Damaris, as feallagh elley mâroo.
CAB. XVIII.

English: After these things Paul departed from Athens, and came to Corinth ;
Manx: Ny lurg shoh jimmee Paul veih Athens, as haink eh gys Corinth :

English: 2 And found a certain Jew named Aquila, born in Pontus, lately come from Italy, with his wife Priscilla ; (because that Claudius had commanded all Jews to depart from Rome :) and came unto them.
Manx: As hooar Eh Hew dy row va enmyssit Aquila, ruggyr ayns Pontus, va er ny laghyn shen er jeet veih Italy, as e ven Priscilla mârish (er-y-fa dy row Claudius er haarey ooilley ny Hewnyn dy gholl ass y Raue) as haink Eh huc.

English: 3 And because he was of the same craft, he abode with them, and wrought : for by their occupation they were tentmakers.
Manx: As er-yn-oyr dy row Eh jeh’n un cheird roo, duirree Eh as dobbree Eh mâroo (son jannoo-cabbaneyn va’n cheird oc)

English: 4 And he reasoned in the synagogue every sabbath, and persuaded the Jews and the Greeks.
Manx: As v’eh resooney ayns y cheeill dy chooilley ghoonaght, as coyrlaghey ny Hewnyn as ny Greekyn.

English: 5 And when Silas and Timotheus were come from Macedonia, Paul was pressed in the spirit, and testified to the Jews that Jesus was Christ.
Manx: As tra va Silas as Timothy er jeet veih Macedonia, daase Paul jeean ayns spyrryd, as dymmyrk Eh feanish gys ny Hewnyn dy nee Yeesey va yn Creest.

English: 6 And when they opposed themselves, and blasphemed, he shook his raiment, and said unto them, Your blood be upon your own heads ; I am clean ; from henceforth I will go unto the Gentiles.
Manx: Agh tra v’ad er hoiaghey ad hene n’oi, as er loayrt goan mollaghtagh, chrie Eh e choamrey, as dooyrt Eh roo, Yn uill eu dy row er ny king eu hene ; Ta mish neu-chyndagh : veih shoh magh hem roym gys ny Ashoonyn-quaagh.

English: 7 ¶And he departed thence, and entered into a certain man’s house, named Justus, one that worshipped God, whose house joined hard to the synagogue.
Manx: As jimmee Eh veih shen, as hie Eh stiagh ayns thie dooinney dy row va cur ooashley da Jee, va enmyssit Justus, va’n thie echey er-gerrey da’n cheeill.

English: 8 And Crispus, the chief ruler of the synagogue, believed on the Lord with all his house ; and many of the Corinthians hearing believed, and were baptized.
Manx: As ren Crispus ard fer-reïl ny killagh, credjal ayns y Chiarn, as ooilley e hie : as va ymmodee jeh ny Corinthianee ren clashtyn as credjal, er nyn mashtey.

English: 9 Then spake the Lord to Paul in the night by a vision, Be not afraid, but speak, and hold not thy peace :
Manx: Eisht loayr y Chiarn ayns ashlish rish Paul ayns yn oie, Ny gow aggle, agh loayr, as ny cum dty hengey :

English: 10 For I am with thee, and no man shall set on thee to hurt thee : for I have much people in this city.
Manx: Son ta mish mârt, as cha soie dooinney erbee ort dy yannoo aggair dhyt : son ta sleih dy mie aym’s ayns yn ard-valley shoh.

English: 11 And he continued there a year and six months, teaching the word of God among them.
Manx: As duirree Eh ayns shen three bleeaney as lieh vlein, gynsaghey goo Yee nyn mast’ oc.

English: 12 ¶And when Gallio was the deputy of Achaia, the Jews made insurrection with one accord against Paul, and brought him to the judgment seat,
Manx: As tra va Gallio reill ayns Achaia, ren ny Hewnyn girree magh lesh un aigney noi Paul, as hug ad lhieu Eh gys stoyl y vriwnys,

English: 13 Saying, This fellow persuadeth men to worship God contrary to the law.
Manx: Gra, T’eh shoh coyrlaghey sleih dy chur ooashley da Jee noi yn leigh.

English: 14 And when Paul was now about to open his mouth, Gallio said unto the Jews, If it were a matter of wrong or wicked lewdness, O ye Jews, reason would that I should bear with you :
Manx: As tra va Paul goll dy osley e veeal, dooyrt Gallio rish ny Hewnyn, Dy beagh eh cooish dy aggair, ny dy ghrogh yannoo, veagh eh resoonagh, O Ewnyn, mee dy ymmyrkey lhieu :

English: 15 But if it be a question of words and names, and of your law, look ye to it ; for I will be no judge of such matters.
Manx: Agh my she streeu eh son focklyn as en’myn, as mychione y leigh eu, jeeagh-jee hene da ; son cha beem’s my vriw ayns leid ny cooishyn.

English: 16 And he drave them from the judgment seat.
Manx: As deiyr Eh ad veih stoyl y vriwnys.

English: 17 Then all the Greeks took Sosthenes, the chief ruler of the synagogue, and beat him before the judgment seat. And Gallio cared for none of those things.
Manx: Eisht ghow ooilley ny Greekyn Sosthenes, ard fer-reïl ny killagh, as woail ad Eh kiongoyrt rish stoyl y vriwnys : as cha dug Gallio veg y yeill da ny reddyn shen.

English: 18 ¶And Paul after this tarried there yet a good while, and then took his leave of the brethren, and sailed thence into Syria, and with him Priscilla and Aquila ; having shorn his head in Cenchrea : for he had a vow.
Manx: As duirree Paul ayns shen ymmodee dy laghyn, as eisht daag Eh bannaght ec ny braaraghyn, as hiauil Eh veih shen gys Syria, as mârish va Priscilla as Aquila, v’er vaarey e chione ec Cenchrea ; son v’eh fo breearrey.

English: 19 And he came to Ephesus, and left them there : but he himself entered into the synagogue, and reasoned with the Jews.
Manx: As haink Eh gys Ephesus, as daag Eh adsyn ayns shen : agh hie Eh hene stiagh ayns y cheeill, as resoon Eh rish ny Hewnyn.

English: 20 When they desired him to tarry longer time with them, he consented not ;
Manx: Tra v’ad geearree Eh dy uirriaght ny sodjey mâroo, cha neaishtagh Eh roo :

English: 21 But bade them farewell, saying, I must by all means keep this feast that cometh in Jerusalem : but I will return again unto you, if God will. And he sailed from Ephesus.
Manx: Agh daag Eh bannaght oc, gra, Shegin dooys er dy chooilley chor yn feailley shoh ta cheet stiagh y reaylley ec Jerusalem : agh higgym back reesht hiuish, lesh cooney Yee. As hiauil Eh veih Ephesus.

English: 22 And when he had landed at Caesarea, and gone up, and saluted the church, he went down to Antioch.
Manx: As tra v’eh er jeet er thalloo ec Cesarea, as er gholl seose, as er vannaghey da’n agglish, hie Eh sheese gys Antioch.

English: 23 And after he had spent some time there, he departed, and went over all the country of Galatia and Phrygia in order, strengthening all the disciples.
Manx: As erreish da v’er vuirriaght choud shen dy hraa ayns shen, jimmee Eh roish, as hie Eh harrish cheer Galatia as Phrygia ayns order, niartaghey ooilley ny Creesteenyn ayns nyn gredjue.

English: 24 ¶And a certain Jew named Apollos, born at Alexandria, an eloquent man, and mighty in the scriptures, came to Ephesus.
Manx: As haink Hew dy row gys Ephesus, va enmyssit Apollos, ruggyr ec Alexandria, dooinney dy hengey mie, as jeh tushtey fondagh ayns ny scriptyryn.

English: 25 This man was instructed in the way of the Lord ; and being fervent in the spirit, he spake and taught diligently the things of the Lord, knowing only the baptism of John.
Manx: Va’n dooinney shoh er ny ynsaghey ayns raad y Chiarn ; as lesh jeeanid ayns y spyrryd loayr Eh as dynsee Eh dy kiarralagh ny reddyn va bentyn rish y Chiarn, toiggal ynrycan bashtey Ean.

English: 26 And he began to speak boldly in the synagogue : whom when Aquila and Priscilla had heard, they took him unto them, and expounded unto him the way of God more perfectly.
Manx: As ren Eh toshiaght dy loayrt dy foshlit as lesh dunnalys ayns y cheeill. Agh tra va Aquila as Priscilla er chlashtyn Eh, hug ad lhieu Eh, as hug ad tushtey s’fondee da jeh raad Yee.

English: 27 And when he was disposed to pass into Achaia, the brethren wrote, exhorting the disciples to receive him : who, when he was come, helped them much which had believed through grace :
Manx: As tra v’eh aignagh dy ghoaill jurnah gys Achaia, scrieu ny braaraghyn, as choyrlee ad ny Creesteenyn dy oltaghey e vea : as erreish da v’er jeet, hug Eh dy mie er nyn doshiaght adsyn v’er chredjal trooid grayse.

English: 28 For he mightily convinced the Jews, and that publickly, shewing by the scriptures that Jesus was Christ.
Manx: Son resoon Eh dy pooaral rish ny Hewnyn, kiongoyrt rish y pobble, soilshaghey liorish ny scriptyryn, dy nee Yeesey va’n Creest.
CAB. XIX.

English: And it came to pass, that, while Apollos was at Corinth, Paul having passed through the upper coasts came to Ephesus : and finding certain disciples,
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, choud as va Apollos ec Corinth, dy jagh Paul trooid ny ardjyn syrjey, derrey haink Eh gys Ephesus : as hooar Eh shiartance jeusyn va jeh’n chredjue.

English: 2 He said unto them, Have ye received the Holy Ghost since ye believed? And they said unto him, We have not so much as heard whether there be any Holy Ghost.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Dooar shiu yn Spyrryd Noo neayr as ren shiu credjal? Dooyrt adsyn rish, Cha vel shin wheesh as er chlashtyn vel Spyrryd Noo ayn.

English: 3 And he said unto them, Unto what then were ye baptized? And they said, Unto John’s baptism.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Cre gys eisht va shiu er nyn mashtey? Dooyrt adsyn, Gys bashtey Ean.

English: 4 Then said Paul, John verily baptized with the baptism of repentance, saying unto the people, that they should believe on him which should come after him, that is, on Christ Jesus.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Paul, Vaisht Ean dy firrinagh lesh bashtey arrys, gra rish y pobble, Ad dy chredjal aynsyn harragh ny yei, ta shen, ayns Creest Yeesey.

English: 5 When they heard this, they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.
Manx: Tra cheayll ad shen, v’ad er nyn mashtey ayns ennym y Chiarn Yeesey.

English: 6 And when Paul had laid his hands upon them, the Holy Ghost came on them ; and they spake with tongues, and prophesied.
Manx: As tra va Paul er chur e laueyn orroo, haink y Spyrryd Noo orroo ; as loayr ad lesh chengaghyn, as ren ad phadeyrys.

English: 7 And all the men were about twelve.
Manx: As va ooilley ny deiney mysh ghaa yeig.

English: 8 And he went into the synagogue, and spake boldly for the space of three months, disputing and persuading the things concerning the kingdom of God.
Manx: As hie Eh stiagh ayns y cheeill, as loayr Eh foshlit as lesh dunnalys choud as three meeghyn, resooney as coyrlaghey ny reddyn va bentyn rish reeriaght Yee.

English: 9 But when divers were hardened, and believed not, but spake evil of that way before the multitude, he departed from them, and separated the disciples, disputing daily in the school of one Tyrannus.
Manx: Agh tra ren shiartance jeu creoghey, as ayns ynnyd chyndaa gys y chredjue, loayrt dy holk jeh’n raad shen kiongoyrt rish y pobble, hug Eh cooyl roo, as tra v’eh er scarrey adsyn v’er chredjal vow, dynsee Eh ad gagh laa ayns schoill fer va enmyssit Tyrannus.

English: 10 And this continued by the space of two years ; so that all they which dwelt in Asia heard the word of the Lord Jesus, both Jews and Greeks.
Manx: As shoh chum Eh jannoo choud as daa vlein ; myr shen dy ren ooilley fir-vaghee Asia clashtyn goo yn Chiarn Yeesey ; chammah ny Hewnyn as adsyn jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaagh.

English: 11 And God wrought special miracles by the hands of Paul :
Manx: As mooar va ny mirrillyn ren Jee y obbraghey liorish laueyn Paul :

English: 12 So that from his body were brought unto the sick handkerchiefs or aprons, and the diseases departed from them, and the evil spirits went out of them.
Manx: Myr shen dy dug ad lhieu veih’n chorp echey gys sleih chingey, bussellyn as apronyn, as hooar ad rea rish ny doghanyn oc, as hie ny drogh spyrrydyn magh assdoo.

English: 13 ¶Then certain of the vagabond Jews, exorcists, took upon them to call over them which had evil spirits the name of the Lord Jesus, saying, We adjure you by Jesus whom Paul preacheth.
Manx: Eisht ren shiartance jeh ny Hewnyn va goll mygeayrt tilgey magh drogh-spyrrydyn, goaill orroo dy eamagh harrish y vooinjer va drogh spyrrydyn ayndoo, ennym y Chiarn Yeesey, gra, Ta shin cur currym erriu liorish Yeesey ta Paul dy phreacheil.

English: 14 And there were seven sons of one Sceva, a Jew, and chief of the priests, which did so.
Manx: As va shiaght meck da Sceva, Hew, ard saggyrt ren shen.

English: 15 And the evil spirit answered and said, Jesus I know, and Paul I know ; but who are ye?
Manx: As dreggyr y drogh spyrryd as dooyrt eh, Yeesey shione dou, as Paul ta enney aym er ; agh quoi shiuish?

English: 16 And the man in whom the evil spirit was leaped on them, and overcame them, and prevailed against them, so that they fled out of that house naked and wounded.
Manx: As leïme y dooinney ayn va’n drogh spyrryd orroo, as hooar Eh yn varriaght as laue yn eaghtyr harrystoo, myr shen dy chosne ad rowe ass y thie shen rooisht as broojit.

English: 17 And this was known to all the Jews and Greeks also dwelling at Ephesus ; and fear fell on them all, and the name of the Lord Jesus was magnified.
Manx: As hooar ooilley ny Hewnyn, as adsyn jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaagh va vaghey ec Ephesus fys er shoh ; as haink aggle orroo ooilley, as va ard-voylley er ny choyrt da ennym y Chiarn Yeesey.

English: 18 And many that believed came, and confessed, and shewed their deeds.
Manx: As haink ymmodee jeusyn v’er chredjal, as ghow ad rish, as hoilshee ad magh nyn obbraghyn.

English: 19 Many of them also which used curious arts brought their books together, and burned them before all men : and they counted the price of them, and found it fifty thousand pieces of silver.
Manx: Ren ymmodee myrgeddin jeusyn va cur rish obbeeyn, nyn lhioaryn y chur lhieu cooidjagh, as losht ad ad kiongoyrt rish dy chooilley ghooinney : as hilg ad seose y phrice oc, as hooar ad eh dy ve jeih thousaneyn as da-eed dy pheeshyn dy argid.

English: 20 So mightily grew the word of God and prevailed.
Manx: Cha breeoil shen ren goo Yee bishaghey as raad y ghoaill.

English: 21 ¶After these things were ended, Paul purposed in the spirit, when he had passed through Macedonia and Achaia, to go to Jerusalem, saying, After I have been there, I must also see Rome.
Manx: Tra va ny reddyn shoh ec kione, chiare Paul ayns y spyrryd, tra veagh Eh er gholl trooid Macedonia as Achaia, dy ragh Eh gys Jerusalem, gra, Erreish dou ve ayns shen, shegin dou myrgeddin yn Raue y akin.

English: 22 So he sent into Macedonia two of them that ministered unto him, Timotheus and Erastus ; but he himself stayed in Asia for a season.
Manx: Myr shen hug Eh gys Macedonia jees jeh ny shirveishee echey, Timothy as Erastus ; agh duirree Eh hene ayns Asia son earish.

English: 23 And the same time there arose no small stir about that way.
Manx: As ec y traa cheddin va boirey nagh nee beggan mychione y raad shen.

English: 24 For a certain man named Demetrius, a silversmith, which made silver shrines for Diana, brought no small gain unto the craftsmen ;
Manx: Son va gaue-argid dy row, va enmyssit Demetrius, va jannoo chambyllyn argid son Diana, as cur cosney nagh nee beggan gys ny fir-chyrjey ;

English: 25 Whom he called together with the workmen of like occupation, and said, Sirs, ye know that by this craft we have our wealth.
Manx: Roo shoh, tra v’eh er n’eamagh orroo cooidjagh marish ny obbreeyn va bentyn rish y cheird cheddin, dooyrt Eh, Gheiney mie, ta fys eu dy nee liorish y cheird shoh ta nyn merchys ain :

English: 26 Moreover ye see and hear, that not alone at Ephesus, but almost throughout all Asia, this Paul hath persuaded and turned away much people, saying that they be no gods, which are made with hands :
Manx: As ta shiu fakin as clashtyn, dy vel Paul shoh, cha nee ynrycan ec Ephesus, agh faggys trooid ooilley Asia, er choyrlaghey as er hayrn ersooyl ymmodee dy leih, gra, nagh nee Jee’ghyn ad ta jeant lesh laueyn :

English: 27 So that not only this our craft is in danger to be set at nought ; but also that the temple of the great goddess Diana should be despised, and her magnificence should be destroyed, whom all Asia and the world worshippeth.
Manx: Myr shen dy vel, cha nee ny lomarcan yn cheird shoh ain ayns dangere dy ve mee-lowit ; agh myrgeddin chiamble yn ven-jee mooar Diana dy ve beg soit jeh, as yn ard-ooashley eck dy ve er ny stroie, jee ta ooilley Asia, as y seihll cur ooashley.

English: 28 And when they heard these sayings, they were full of wrath, and cried out, saying, Great is Diana of the Ephesians.
Manx: Tra cheayll ad shoh, daase ad feer jymmoosagh, as deïe ad, gra, Mooar ta Diana ny Ephesianee.

English: 29 And the whole city was filled with confusion : and having caught Gaius and Aristarchus, men of Macedonia, Paul’s companions in travel, they rushed with one accord into the theatre.
Manx: As va ooilley yn ard-valley bun rish skyn : as erreish daue v’er ghoaill Gaius as Aristarchus, Macedonianee, sheshaghyn Paul ayns y troailt echey, ying ad lesh un aigney stiagh ayns y theater.

English: 30 And when Paul would have entered in unto the people, the disciples suffered him not.
Manx: As tra va Paul aignagh dy gholl stiagh gys y pobble, cha lig adsyn va jeh’n chredjue da.

English: 31 And certain of the chief of Asia, which were his friends, sent unto him, desiring him that he would not adventure himself into the theatre.
Manx: As hug shiartance jeh deiney mooarey Asia, va ny caarjyn echey, fys huggey, geearree gyn Eh dy hreishteil Eh hene ayns y theater.

English: 32 Some therefore cried one thing, and some another : for the assembly was confused : and the more part knew not wherefore they were come together.
Manx: Deïe paart er-y-fa shen un red, as paart red elley : son va’n chaglym bun rish skyn, as cha row fys ec yn ayrn smoo jeu cre’n-fa v’ad er nyn jaglym cooidjagh.

English: 33 And they drew Alexander out of the multitude, the Jews putting him forward. And Alexander beckoned with the hand, and would have made his defence unto the people.
Manx: As hayrn ad Alexander magh ass y cheshaght, as deiyr ny Hewnyn roue Eh. As chrie Alexander lesh e laue, as ballish v’er loayrt ass e lieh hene rish y pobble.

English: 34 But when they knew that he was a Jew, all with one voice about the space of two hours cried out, Great is Diana of the Ephesians.
Manx: Agh tra hooar ad fys dy nee Hew v’eh, deïe ad ooilley lesh un choraa choud as daa oor, Mooar ta Diana ny Ephesianee.

English: 35 And when the townclerk had appeased the people, he said, Ye men of Ephesus, what man is there that knoweth not how that the city of the Ephesians is a worshipper of the great goddess Diana, and of the image which fell down from Jupiter?
Manx: As tra va cleragh y valley er chur y pobble gys fea, dooyrt Eh, Gheiney Ephesus, quoi’n dooinney nagh vel fys echey dy vel ard-valley ny Ephesianee cur ooashley da’n ven-jee mooar Diana, as da’n jalloo huit neose veih Jupiter?

English: 36 Seeing then that these things cannot be spoken against, ye ought to be quiet, and to do nothing rashly.
Manx: Fakin eisht nagh vod ny reddyn shoh ve loayrit noi, lhisagh shiu ve fea-agh, as gyn nhee erbee y yannoo er vullagh ching.

English: 37 For ye have brought hither these men, which are neither robbers of churches, nor yet blasphemers of your goddess.
Manx: Son ta shiu er chur lhieu ayns shoh ny deiney shoh, nagh vel nyn roosteyryn jeh kialteenyn, ny foast er loayrt goan-mollaghtagh noi yn ven-jee eu.

English: 38 Wherefore if Demetrius, and the craftsmen which are with him, have a matter against any man, the law is open, and there are deputies : let them implead one another.
Manx: Shen-y-fa my ta ec Demetrius, as ny fir-chyrjey ta mârish, playnt noi dooinney erbee, ta ny quaiyllyn nyn soie, as briwnyn ayndoo, ry hoi reaghey chur daue.

English: 39 But if ye enquire any thing concerning other matters, it shall be determined in a lawful assembly.
Manx: Agh my ta nhee erbee elley eu dy hirrey magh, foddee shiu rick y gheddyn ayn ayns chaglym cooidjagh lowal.

English: 40 For we are in danger to be called in question for this day’s uproar, there being no cause whereby we may give an account of this concourse.
Manx: Son ta shin ayns dangere dy bee irree-magh er ny choyrt nyn lieh son ny ta jeant jiu ; liorish nagh vel oyr erbee ain dy chur stiagh, dy chur resoon son leid y meeiteil sleih.

English: 41 And when he had thus spoken, he dismissed the assembly.
Manx: As tra v’eh er ghra shoh, lig Eh yn raad da’n pobble.
CAB. XX.

English: And after the uproar was ceased, Paul called unto him the disciples, and embraced them, and departed for to go into Macedonia.
Manx: As erreish da’n irree-magh shoh ve ec fea, deïe Paul orroosyn v’er chredjal huggey, as daag Eh bannaght oc, as jimmee Eh roish dy gholl gys Macedonia

English: 2 And when he had gone over those parts, and had given them much exhortation, he came into Greece,
Manx: As tra v’eh er gholl harrish ny ardjyn shen, as er chur ymmodee coyrlyn daue, haink Eh gys Greece,

English: 3 And there abode three months. And when the Jews laid wait for him, as he was about to sail into Syria, he purposed to return through Macedonia.
Manx: As duirree Eh ayns shen three meeghyn : as tra va ny Hewnyn kiarrail y ghoaill Eh, myr v’eh goll dy ghoaill luingys gys Syria, ghow Eh ayns laue dy darragh Eh back trooid Macedonia.

English: 4 And there accompanied him into Asia Sopater of Berea ; and of the Thessalonians, Aristarchus and Secundus ; and Gaius of Derbe, and Timotheus ; and of Asia, Tychicus and Trophimus.
Manx: As hie ayns sheshaght mârish gys Asia, Sopater Verea ; as jeh ny Thessalonianee, Aristarchus as Secundus ; as Gaius veih Derbe, as Timothy ; as veih Asia, Tychicus as Trophimus.

English: 5 These going before tarried for us at Troas.
Manx: Hie ad shoh roïn, as duirree ad er nyn son ec Troas.

English: 6 And we sailed away from Philippi after the days of unleavened bread, and came unto them to Troas in five days ; where we abode seven days.
Manx: As hiauil shin veih Philippi, lurg laghyn yn arran millish, as haink shin huc gys Troas ayns queig laa, as duirree shin ayns shen shiaght laa.

English: 7 And upon the first day of the week, when the disciples came together to break bread, Paul preached unto them, ready to depart on the morrow ; and continued his speech until midnight.
Manx: As er y chied laa jeh’n chaghtin, tra va shin er jeet cooidjagh dy vrishey arran, ren Paul preacheil daue, as myr v’eh dy gholl roish laa ny vairagh, chum Eh loayrt derrey main-oie.

English: 8 And there were many lights in the upper chamber, where they were gathered together.
Manx: As va ymmodee kainlyn foddit er y lout, raad v’ad er nyn jaglym cooidjagh.

English: 9 And there sat in a window a certain young man named Eutychus, being fallen into a deep sleep : and as Paul was long preaching, he sunk down with sleep, and fell down from the third loft, and was taken up dead.
Manx: As va dooinney aeg dy row, va enmyssit Eutychus, ny hoie ayns uinniag, as huit Eh ny chadley dy trome : as myr va Paul foddey preacheil, skyr Eh sheese ayns e chadley, as huit Eh neose jeh’n tress lout, as v’eh er ny hroggal marroo.

English: 10 And Paul went down, and fell on him, and embracing him said, Trouble not yourselves ; for his life is in him.
Manx: Agh hie Paul sheese, as huit Eh er, as ghow Eh Eh ayns e roihaghyn, gra, Ny bee-jee ayns imnea erbee ; son ta e vioys ayn.

English: 11 When he therefore was come up again, and had broken bread, and eaten, and talked a long while, even till break of day, so he departed.
Manx: Tra v’eh er-y-fa shen er jeet seose reesht, as er vrishey arran, as er n’ee, as er daggloo foddey, dys eer brishey yn laa, jimmee Eh roish.

English: 12 And they brought the young man alive, and were not a little comforted.
Manx: As hug ad lhieu yn dooinney aeg bio, as va gerjagh oc nagh nee beggan.

English: 13 ¶And we went before to ship, and sailed unto Assos, there intending to take in Paul : for so had he appointed, minding himself to go afoot.
Manx: As hie shin roishyn gys y lhong, as hiauil shin gys Assos, kiarrail Paul y ghoaill stiagh ayns shen : son shen myr v’eh er n’oardaghey, liorish dy row Eh aignagh dy gholl ry chosh.

English: 14 And when he met with us at Assos, we took him in, and came to Mitylene.
Manx: As tra veet Eh rooin ec Assos, ghow shin stiagh Eh, as haink shin gys Mitylene.

English: 15 And we sailed thence, and came the next day over against Chios ; and the next day we arrived at Samos, and tarried at Trogyllium ; and the next day we came to Miletus.
Manx: As hiauil shin veih shen, as haink shin yn nah laa jeeragh er Chios ; as yn laa er-giyn chosne shin gys Samos, as duirree shin ec Trogyllium ; as yn laa ny lurg shen haink shin gys Miletus.

English: 16 For Paul had determined to sail by Ephesus, because he would not spend the time in Asia : for he hasted, if it were possible for him, to be at Jerusalem the day of Pentecost.
Manx: Son va Paul kiarit dy hiauley shaghey Ephesus, er-y-fa nagh row Eh booiagh yn traa y vaarail ayns Asia : son v’eh jannoo wheesh dy hiyr as va possible dy ve ec Jerusalem laa ny Kingeesh.

English: 17 ¶And from Miletus he sent to Ephesus, and called the elders of the church.
Manx: As veih Miletus, hug Eh fys gys Ephesus, as deïe Eh er shanstyr ny hagglish.

English: 18 And when they were come to him, he said unto them, Ye know, from the first day that I came into Asia, after what manner I have been with you at all seasons,
Manx: As tra v’ad er jeet huggey, dooyrt Eh roo, Ta fys eu, er dyn chied laa haink mish gys Asia, cre’n aght ta mee er ve mêriu ec dy chooilley earish,

English: 19 Serving the Lord with all humility of mind, and with many tears, and temptations, which befell me by the lying in wait of the Jews :
Manx: Shirveish y Chiarn lesh dy chooilley injillid aigney, as lesh ymmodee jeïr, as miolaghyn haink my raad, liorish ny ribbaghyn hoie ny Hewnyn er my hon :

English: 20 And how I kept back nothing that was profitable unto you, but have shewed you, and have taught you publickly, and from house to house,
Manx: As kys nagh dreill mee back nhee erbee veagh vondeishagh diuish, agh hoilshee mee diu, as dynsee mee shiu dy foshlit, as veih thie dy thie,

English: 21 Testifying both to the Jews, and also to the Greeks, repentance toward God, and faith toward our Lord Jesus Christ.
Manx: Gymmyrkey feanish, chammah gys ny Hewnyn, as myrgeddin hucsyn jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaagh, jeh arrys gys Jee, as credjue gys nyn Jiarn Yeesey Creest.

English: 22 And now, behold, I go bound in the spirit unto Jerusalem, not knowing the things that shall befall me there :
Manx: As nish cur-my-ner, Ta mee goll kainlt ayns y spyrryd gys Jerusalem, fegooish fys y ve aym er ny reddyn nee taghyrt dou ayns shen :

English: 23 Save that the Holy Ghost witnesseth in every city, saying that bonds and afflictions abide me.
Manx: Agh dy vel y Spyrryd Noo gymmyrkey feanish ayns dagh ard-valley, gra, dy vel bondiaght as seaghyn my chouyr.

English: 24 But none of these things move me, neither count I my life dear unto myself, so that I might finish my course with joy, and the ministry, which I have received of the Lord Jesus, to testify the gospel of the grace of God.
Manx: Agh cha vel veg jeh ny reddyn shoh dy my agglaghey, cha-moo ta mee soiaghey jeh my vioys, my oddym my choorse y chooilleeney lesh boggey, as y chirveish ta mee er ny gheddyn veih’n Chiarn Yeesey, dy ymmyrkey feanish gys sushtal grayse Yee.

English: 25 And now, behold, I know that ye all, among whom I have gone preaching the kingdom of God, shall see my face no more.
Manx: As nish cur-my-ner, ta fys aym nagh jean shiuish ooilley, nyn mast’ eu ta mee er ve shooyl preacheil reeriaght Yee, my eddin y akin ny smoo.

English: 26 Wherefore I take you to record this day, that I am pure from the blood of all men.
Manx: Shen-y-fa ta mee goaill shiu son feanishyn jiu, dy vel mee neu-chyndagh jeh fuill dy chooilley ghooinney :

English: 27 For I have not shunned to declare unto you all the counsel of God.
Manx: Son cha vel mee er ve lhiastey dy hoilshaghey diu ooilley coyrle Yee.

English: 28 ¶Take heed therefore unto yourselves, and to all the flock, over the which the Holy Ghost hath made you overseers, to feed the church of God, which he hath purchased with his own blood.
Manx: Cur-jee twoaie er-y-fa shen diu hene, as da ooilley yn chioltane harrystoo ta’n Spyrryd Noo er n’yannoo shiu nyn aspickyn, dy veaghey agglish Yee, t’eh er ny chionnaghey lesh e uill hene.

English: 29 For I know this, that after my departing shall grievous wolves enter in among you, not sparing the flock.
Manx: Son ta fys aym, erreish dooys goll roym, dy jig moddee-oaldey jollyssagh stiagh nyn mast’ eu, nagh gow accan jeh’n chioltane.

English: 30 Also of your own selves shall men arise, speaking perverse things, to draw away disciples after them.
Manx: Myrgeddin nyn mast’ eu hene nee deiney girree seose, as loayrt reddyn nagh lhisagh ad, dy violaghey feallagh dy eiyrt orroo.

English: 31 Therefore watch, and remember, that by the space of three years I ceased not to warn every one night and day with tears.
Manx: Bee-jee er-y-fa shen er nyn dwoaie, as cooinee-jee rish three bleeaney dy vel mee er ve kinjagh oie as laa cur raaue da dy chooilley annane eu lesh jeïr.

English: 32 And now, brethren, I commend you to God, and to the word of his grace, which is able to build you up, and to give you an inheritance among all them which are sanctified.
Manx: As nish, vraaraghyn, Ta mish chymney shiu gys Jee, as gys goo e ghrayse, ta abyl nyn droggal shiu seose, as eiraght y chur diu nyn mastey ocsyn ooilley ta er nyn gasherickey.

English: 33 I have coveted no man’s silver, or gold, or apparel.
Manx: Cha vel mee er chur saynt da argid, ny aihr, ny cooid ghooinney erbee.

English: 34 Yea, ye yourselves know, that these hands have ministered unto my necessities, and to them that were with me.
Manx: Dy jarroo ta fys eu hene, dy nee ny laueyn shoh ren shirveish er my ymmyrch, as orroosyn va mârym.

English: 35 I have shewed you all things, how that so labouring ye ought to support the weak, and to remember the words of the Lord Jesus, how he said, It is more blessed to give than to receive.
Manx: Ta mee er hoilshaghey diu dy chooilley nhee, kys liorish myr shen laboraght, dy lhisagh shiu kemmyrk y choyrt da ny hannooinee ; as cooinaghtyn er goan y Chiarn Yeesey, kys dooyrt Eh, Te bannaght smoo dy choyrt na dy ghoaill.

English: 36 ¶And when he had thus spoken, he kneeled down, and prayed with them all.
Manx: As tra v’eh er ghra shoh, ghlioon Eh sheese, as ghow Eh padjer mâroo ooilley.

English: 37 And they all wept sore, and fell on Paul’s neck, and kissed him,
Manx: As cheayn ad ooilley dy treih, lhie er mwannal Phaul as dy phaagey Eh,

English: 38 Sorrowing most of all for the words which he spake, that they should see his face no more. And they accompanied him unto the ship.
Manx: As jannoo yn trimshey smoo ooilley, son ny goan loayr Eh, nagh vaikagh ad yn eddin echey ny smoo. As hie ad ayns sheshaght mârish gys y lhong.
CAB. XXI.

English: And it came to pass, that after we were gotten from them, and had launched, we came with a straight course unto Coos, and the day following unto Rhodes, and from thence unto Patara :
Manx: As haink eh gy-kione, tra va shin er gheddyn vow, as dy jagh shin magh son y cheayin, as dy daink shin lesh coorse jeeragh gys Coos, as yn laa er-giyn gys Rhodes, as veih shen gys Patara.

English: 2 And finding a ship sailing over unto Phenicia, we went aboard, and set forth.
Manx: As hooar shin lhong va goll er-shiaulley gys Phenicia, hie shin er-board, as hie shin magh.

English: 3 Now when we had discovered Cyprus, we left it on the left hand, and sailed into Syria, and landed at Tyre : for there the ship was to unlade her burden.
Manx: Nish tra chronnee shin Cyprus, daag shin eh er y laue chiare, as hiauil shin gys Syria, as haink shin er thalloo ec Tyre : son ayns shen va’n lhong dy olmaghey yn lught eck.

English: 4 And finding disciples, we tarried there seven days : who said to Paul through the Spirit, that he should not go up to Jerusalem.
Manx: As hooar shin feallagh jeh’n chredjue, as duirree shin mâroo shiaght laa : as loayr ad rish Paul trooid y Spyrryd, gyn Eh dy gholl seose gys Jerusalem.

English: 5 And when we had accomplished those days, we departed and went our way ; and they all brought us on our way, with wives and children, till we were out of the city : and we kneeled down on the shore, and prayed.
Manx: As tra va ny laghyn ec kione, jimmee shin roïn, as hie shin er nyn raad ; as hie ad ooilley magh mârin dy chur shin er nyn doshiaght er nyn yurnah, marish mraane as cloan, derrey va shin mooie ass y valley : as ghlioon shin sheese er y traie, as ghow shin padjer.

English: 6 And when we had taken our leave one of another, we took ship ; and they returned home again.
Manx: As tra va shin er ghoaill nyn gied yn derrey yeh jeh’n jeh elley, ghow shin luingys ; as hyndaa adsyn back reesht.

English: 7 And when we had finished our course from Tyre, we came to Ptolemais, and saluted the brethren, and abode with them one day.
Manx: As tra va shin er roih yn coorse ain veih Tyre, haink shin gys Ptolemais, as vannee shin da ny braaraghyn, as duirree shin mâroo un laa.

English: 8 And the next day we that were of Paul’s company departed, and came unto Caesarea : and we entered into the house of Philip the evangelist, which was one of the seven ; and abode with him.
Manx: As yn nah laa, jimmee shinyn va jeh sheshaght Phaul roïn, as haink shin gys Cæsarea ; as hie shin stiagh ayns thie Philip yn sushtallagh (va fer jeh’n chiaght) as duirree shin mârish.

English: 9 And the same man had four daughters, virgins, which did prophesy.
Manx: As va kiare inneenyn ec y dooinney cheddin, moidynyn, va jannoo phadeyrys.

English: 10 And as we tarried there many days, there came down from Judaea a certain prophet, named Agabus.
Manx: As duirree shin ayns shen ymmodee dy laghyn, as haink neose veih Judea phadeyr dy row va enmyssit Agabus.

English: 11 And when he was come unto us, he took Paul’s girdle, and bound his own hands and feet, and said, Thus saith the Holy Ghost, So shall the Jews at Jerusalem bind the man that owneth this girdle, and shall deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles.
Manx: As tra haink Eh hooin, ghow Eh cryss Phaul, as chiangle Eh e laueyn as e chassyn hene, as dooyrt Eh, Shoh myr ta’n Spyrryd Noo gra, Er yn aght shoh nee ny Hewnyn yn dooinney slesh yn cryss shoh y chiangley ec Jerusalem, as Eh y livrey gys laueyn ny Ashoonyn-quaagh.

English: 12 And when we heard these things, both we, and they of that place, besought him not to go up to Jerusalem.
Manx: As erreish dooin shoh y chlashtyn, ghuee chammah shinyn as adsyn jeh’n ynnyd shen er, gyn Eh dy gholl seose gys Jerusalem.

English: 13 Then Paul answered, What mean ye to weep and to break mine heart? for I am ready not to be bound only, but also to die at Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus.
Manx: Eisht dreggyr Paul, Cre er ta shiu cheet, dy ve myr shoh keayney, as brishey my chree? son ta mee aarloo, cha nee ynrycan dy ve er my choyrt ayns geulaghyn, agh dy hurranse baase ec Jerusalem son ennym y Chiarn Yeesey.

English: 14 And when he would not be persuaded, we ceased, saying, The will of the Lord be done.
Manx: As tra nagh gogh Eh coyrle, ghow shin fea, gra, Aigney yn Chiarn dy row jeant.

English: 15 And after those days we took up our carriages, and went up to Jerusalem.
Manx: As lurg ny laghyn shen, hug shin cooidjagh ny v’ain dy chur lhein, as hie shih seose gys Jerusalem.

English: 16 There went with us also certain of the disciples of Caesarea, and brought with them one Mnason of Cyprus, an old disciple, with whom we should lodge.
Manx: Hie mârin myrgeddin paart jeusyn v’ayns Cesarea v’er chredjal, as hug ad lhieu shin gys fer yiarragh ad Mnason rish, veih Cyprus, va ry foddey er jyndaa gys y chredjue, mârishyn dy voddagh shin aaght y ghoaill.

English: 17 And when we were come to Jerusalem, the brethren received us gladly.
Manx: As tra va shin er jeet gys Jerusalem, doltee ny braaraghyn nyn mea dy arryltagh.

English: 18 And the day following Paul went in with us unto James ; and all the elders were present.
Manx: As yn laa er-giyn hie Paul stiagh mârin gys Jamys ; as va ooilley yn chanstyr kionfenish.

English: 19 And when he had saluted them, he declared particularly what things God had wrought among the Gentiles by his ministry.
Manx: As tra v’eh er vannaghey daue, hoilshee Eh lurg y chielley ny reddyn va Jee er n’obbraghey mastey ny Ashoonyn-quaagh liorish y chirveish echyssyn.

English: 20 And when they heard it, they glorified the Lord, and said unto him, Thou seest, brother, how many thousands of Jews there are which believe ; and they are all zealous of the law :
Manx: As tra cheayll ad shen, hug ad moylley da’n Chiarn, as dooyrt ad rish, T’ow fakin, vraar, cre whilleen thousane jeh ny Hewnyn t’er ghoaill yn credjue orroo ; as ta graih jeean oc ooilley son y leigh.

English: 21 And they are informed of thee, that thou teachest all the Jews which are among the Gentiles to forsake Moses, saying that they ought not to circumcise their children, neither to walk after the customs.
Manx: As te inshit daue my dty chione’s, dy vel oo gynsaghey ooilley ny Hewnyn ta mastey ny Ashoonyn-quaagh, dy hreigeil Moses, gra, nagh lhisagh ad nyn gloan y yiarey chymmylt, ny nyn mea y leeideil liorish ny oardaghyn.

English: 22 What is it therefore? the multitude must needs come together : for they will hear that thou art come.
Manx: Cre nee oo eisht? Hig y pobble cooidjagh : son clinnee ad dy vel oo er jeet.

English: 23 Do therefore this that we say to thee : We have four men which have a vow on them ;
Manx: Jean er-y-fa shen ny jir mainyn rhyt : ta kiare deiney ain ta fo breearrey ;

English: 24 Them take, and purify thyself with them, and be at charges with them, that they may shave their heads : and all may know that those things, whereof they were informed concerning thee, are nothing ; but that thou thyself also walkest orderly, and keepest the law.
Manx: Ad shen gow, as glen oo hene mâroo, as cur oo hene gys cost er nyn son, dy vod ad nyn ghing y shaval : as dy vod fys y ve ec dy chooilley annane, nagh vel ny reddyn va inshit daue my dty chione’s firrinagh, agh dy vel oo hene leeideil dty vea lurg ny oardaghyn, as freaylley yn leigh.

English: 25 As touching the Gentiles which believe, we have written and concluded that they observe no such thing, save only that they keep themselves from things offered to idols, and from blood, and from strangled, and from fornication.
Manx: As mychione adsyn jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaagh t’er chredjal, ta shinyn er scrieu as er vriwnys, gyn ad dy ghoaill leid y red orroo, agh ynrycan ad dy reaylley ad hene veih reddyn va chebbit gys jallooyn, as veih fuill, as veih reddyn toghtit, as veih maarderys.

English: 26 Then Paul took the men, and the next day purifying himself with them entered into the temple, to signify the accomplishment of the days of purification, until that an offering should be offered for every one of them.
Manx: Eisht ghow Paul ny deiney, as yn nah laa ghlen Eh Eh hene mâroo, as hie Eh stiagh ayns y chiamble, dy hoilshaghey, tra veagh laghyn y ghlenney ec kione, dy row oural dy ve chebbit son dy chooilley annane oc.

English: 27 And when the seven days were almost ended, the Jews which were of Asia, when they saw him in the temple, stirred up all the people, and laid hands on him,
Manx: As tra va ny shiaght laa faggys ec kione, ghreinnee ny Hewnyn va veih Asia ooilley yn pobble, tra honnick ad Eh ayns y chiamble, as hug ad nyn laueyn er,

English: 28 Crying out, Men of Israel, help : This is the man, that teacheth all men every where against the people, and the law, and this place : and further brought Greeks also into the temple, and hath polluted this holy place.
Manx: Geamagh, Gheiney Israel, cooin-jee lhien : shoh’n dooinney ta gynsaghey dy chooilley ghooinney, ayns dy chooilley ynnyd noi yn pobble, as y leigh, as y boayl shoh ; as ny sodjey na shen, t’eh er chur lesh deiney jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaagh stiagh ayns y chiamble, as er villey yn ynnyd casherick shoh.

English: 29 (For they had seen before with him in the city Trophimus an Ephesian, whom they supposed that Paul had brought into the temple.)
Manx: (Son v’ad roie er vakin mârish ayns yn ard-valley, Trophimus, Ephesian, as heïll ad dy row Paul er chur lesh Eh stiagh ayns y chiamble.)

English: 30 And all the city was moved, and the people ran together : and they took Paul, and drew him out of the temple : and forthwith the doors were shut.
Manx: As va ooilley yn ard-valley neu-aashagh, as roih yn pobble cooidjagh : as ghow ad Paul, as hayrn ad Eh magh ass y chiamble ; as chelleeragh va ny dorryssyn er nyn yeigh.

English: 31 And as they went about to kill him, tidings came unto the chief captain of the band, that all Jerusalem was in an uproar.
Manx: As myr v’ad goll dy varroo Eh, haink skeeal gys ard chaptan y cheshaght, dy row ooilley Jerusalem bun rish skyn.

English: 32 Who immediately took soldiers and centurions, and ran down unto them : and when they saw the chief captain and the soldiers, they left beating of Paul.
Manx: As ghow Eh chelleeragh sidooryn as captanyn-keead, as roie Eh sheese huc : as tra honnick ad yn ard chaptan as ny sidooryn, scuir ad veih bwoalley Paul.
