English: 33 Then the chief captain came near, and took him, and commanded him to be bound with two chains ; and demanded who he was, and what he had done.
Manx: Eisht haink yn ard chaptan er-gerrey, as ghow Eh Eh, as doardee Eh Eh dy ve kainlt lesh daa yeuley ; as dênee Eh quoi v’eh, as cre v’eh er n’yannoo.

English: 34 And some cried one thing, some another, among the multitude : and when he could not know the certainty for the tumult, he commanded him to be carried into the castle.
Manx: As deïe paart un red, as paart red elley mastey’n pobble : as tra nagh dod Eh shickyrys y gheddyn kyndagh rish y voirrainys, doardee Eh Eh dy ve er ny chur stiagh ayns y chashtal.

English: 35 And when he came upon the stairs, so it was, that he was borne of the soldiers for the violence of the people.
Manx: As tra v’eh er ny greeshyn, hrog ny sidooryn lhieu Eh, kyndagh rish dewlys y phobble.

English: 36 For the multitude of the people followed after, crying, Away with him.
Manx: Son roih yn slane chaglym jeh’n pobble geiyrt er, geamagh, Ersooyl lesh.

English: 37 And as Paul was to be led into the castle, he said unto the chief captain, May I speak unto thee? Who said, Canst thou speak Greek?
Manx: As myr va Paul dy gholl stiagh ayns y chashtal, dooyrt Eh rish yn ard chaptan, Voym kied loayrt rhyt? Dooyrt eshyn, Vod oo Greek y loayrt?

English: 38 Art not thou that Egyptian, which before these days madest an uproar, and leddest out into the wilderness four thousand men that were murderers?
Manx: Nagh nee uss yn Egyptian shen, ren roish ny laghyn shoh irree-magh y yannoo, as leeid magh gys yn aasagh, kiare thousane dooinney, va nyn ghunveryn?

English: 39 But Paul said, I am a man which am a Jew of Tarsus, a city in Cilicia, a citizen of no mean city : and, I beseech thee, suffer me to speak unto the people.
Manx: Agh dooyrt Paul, Ta mish my ghooinney ta my Hew, veih Tarsus, ard-valley ayns Cilicia, balley jeh ennym mooar ; as ta mee guee ort kied y chur dou loayrt rish y pobble.

English: 40 And when he had given him licence, Paul stood on the stairs, and beckoned with the hand unto the people. And when there was made a great silence, he spake unto them in the Hebrew tongue, saying,
Manx: As tra v’eh er chur kied da, hass Paul er ny greeshyn, as chrie Eh e laue er y pobble : as tra huit ad feer fea-agh, loayr Eh roo ayns glare ny Hebrewyn, gra.
CAB. XXII.

English: Men, brethren, and fathers, hear ye my defence which I make now unto you.
Manx: Gheiney, vraaraghyn, as ayraghyn, clasht-jee rish ny t’ayms dy ghra ayns my lieh hene.

English: 2 (And when they heard that he spake in the Hebrew tongue to them, they kept the more silence : and he saith,)
Manx: (As tra cheayll ad Eh loayrt ayns glare ny Hebrewnyn roo, v’ad ny s’feaee : as dooyrt Eh)

English: 3 I am verily a man which am a Jew, born in Tarsus, a city in Cilicia, yet brought up in this city at the feet of Gamaliel, and taught according to the perfect manner of the law of the fathers, and was zealous toward God, as ye all are this day.
Manx: Ta mish dy firrinagh my ghooinney ta my Hew, ruggyr ayns Tarsus, ard-valley ayns Cilicia, agh va mee troggit ayns yn ard-valley shoh, ec cassyn Gamaliel, as ynsit lurg aght s’gyerey jeh leigh ny ayraghyn, as va graih jeean aym gys Jee, myr t’eauish ooilley jiu.

English: 4 And I persecuted this way unto the death, binding and delivering into prisons both men and women.
Manx: As ren mee tranlaase er y raad shoh gys y baase, kiangley as livrey gys pryssoonyn, chammah deiney as mraane.

English: 5 As also the high priest doth bear me witness, and all the estate of the elders : from whom also I received letters unto the brethren, and went to Damascus, to bring them which were there bound unto Jerusalem, for to be punished.
Manx: Myr ta’n ard-saggyrt hene gymmyrkey feanish lhiam, as ooilley yn chanstyr : vow hooar mee myrgeddin screeuyn gys ny braaraghyn, as hie mee gys Damascus, dy chur lhiam adsyn v’ayns shen, kainlt gys Jerusalem, dy ve er nyn gerraghey.

English: 6 And it came to pass, that, as I made my journey, and was come nigh unto Damascus about noon, suddenly there shone from heaven a great light round about me.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, myr va mee er my yurnah, tra haink mee er-gerrey da Damascus mysh y vun-laa, dy hoilshean doaltattym veih niau soilshey mooar mygeayrt y moo’m.

English: 7 And I fell unto the ground, and heard a voice saying unto me, Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?
Manx: As huit mee er y thalloo, as cheayll mee coraa, gra rhym, Saul, Saul, cre’n-fa t’ow jannoo tranlaase orrym?

English: 8 And I answered, Who art thou, Lord? And he said unto me, I am Jesus of Nazareth, whom thou persecutest.
Manx: As dreggyr mish, Quoi oo, Hiarn? As dooyrt Eh rhym, Mish Yeesey dy Nazareth t’ow jannoo tranlaase er.

English: 9 And they that were with me saw indeed the light, and were afraid ; but they heard not the voice of him that spake to me.
Manx: As honnick adsyn va mârym yn soilshey dy jarroo, as v’ad agglagh ; agh cha geayll ad yn coraa echyssyn va loayrt rhym.

English: 10 And I said, What shall I do, Lord? And the Lord said unto me, Arise, and go into Damascus ; and there it shall be told thee of all things which are appointed for thee to do.
Manx: As dooyrt mish, Cre nee’m, Hiarn? As dooyrt y Chiarn rhym, Irree, as gow gys Damascus, as ayns shen vees inshit dhyt mychione dy chooilley nhee ta oardrit dhyt dy yannoo.

English: 11 And when I could not see for the glory of that light, being led by the hand of them that were with me, I came into Damascus.
Manx: As tra nagh dod mee fakin son gloyr y toilshey shen, hug y vooinjer va mârym lhieu mee er y laue, as haink mee gys Damascus.

English: 12 And one Ananias, a devout man according to the law, having a good report of all the Jews which dwelt there,
Manx: As haink hym fer dy row yiarragh ad Ananias rish, dooinney crauee cordail rish y leigh, echey va goo mie veih ooilley ny Hewnyn va vaghey ayns shen,

English: 13 Came unto me, and stood, and said unto me, Brother Saul, receive thy sight. And the same hour I looked up upon him.
Manx: As hass Eh as dooyrt Eh rhym, Vraar Saul, gow dty hoilshey. As ’syn oor cheddin yeeagh mee seose er.

English: 14 And he said, The God of our fathers hath chosen thee, that thou shouldest know his will, and see that Just One, and shouldest hear the voice of his mouth.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Ta Jee ny ayraghyn ain er dty reih’s, dy voddagh fys y ve ayd er yn aigney echey, as dy voddagh oo yn Fer-cairagh shen y akin, as clashtyn coraa e veeal.

English: 15 For thou shalt be his witness unto all men of what thou hast seen and heard.
Manx: Son bee oo d[t]y eanish da dy chooilley ghooinney, jeh ny t’ow er vakin as er chlashtyn.

English: 16 And now why tarriest thou? arise, and be baptized, and wash away thy sins, calling on the name of the Lord.
Manx: As nish cre’n-oyr t’ow lhiggey shiaghey? irree as bee er dty vashtey, as niee ersooyl dty pheccaghyn, geamagh er ennym y Chiarn.

English: 17 And it came to pass, that, when I was come again to Jerusalem, even while I prayed in the temple, I was in a trance ;
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, tra va mee er jeet reesht gys Jerusalem, dy jarroo choud as va mee ec padjer ayns y chiamble, dy huit mee my-nealloo ;

English: 18 And saw him saying unto me, Make haste, and get thee quickly out of Jerusalem : for they will not receive thy testimony concerning me.
Manx: As honnick mee Eh, gra rhym, Jean siyr, as gow royd dy tappee ass Jerusalem : son cha soie ad jeh’n eanish ayd my mychione’s.

English: 19 And I said, Lord, they know that I imprisoned and beat in every synagogue them that believed on thee :
Manx: As dooyrt mish, Hiarn, ta fys oc dy ren mish pryssooney as bwoalley ayns dy chooilley cheeill adsyn va credjal aynyd.

English: 20 And when the blood of thy martyr Stephen was shed, I also was standing by, and consenting unto his death, and kept the raiment of them that slew him.
Manx: As tra va fuill dt’eanish Steaon duillee baase dy gheayrtey, va mee my hassoo liorish, as va m’aigney lhieu ayns y choyrt Eh gy baase, as yeeagh mee da’n eaddagh ocsyn va dy varroo Eh.

English: 21 And he said unto me, Depart : for I will send thee far hence unto the Gentiles.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh rhym, Immee royd : son verryms oo er chaghteraght foddey veih shoh gys ny Ashoonyn-quaagh.

English: 22 And they gave him audience unto this word, and then lifted up their voices, and said, Away with such a fellow from the earth : for it is not fit that he should live.
Manx: As deaisht ad rish gys y fockle shoh, as eisht hrog ad seose nyn goraaghyn, as dooyrt ad, Ersooyl lesh leid yn er shoh jeh’n thalloo : son cha vel eh cooie Eh dy ve bio.

English: 23 And as they cried out, and cast off their clothes, and threw dust into the air,
Manx: As myr v’ad gyllaghey, as ceau jeu nyn eaddagh, as cur joan ’syn aer,

English: 24 The chief captain commanded him to be brought into the castle, and bade that he should be examined by scourging ; that he might know wherefore they cried so against him.
Manx: Hug yn ard chaptan saarey Eh dy ve er ny chur stiagh ayns y chashtal, goardaghey Eh dy ve feayshtit liorish custey ; dy voddagh Eh fys y gheddyn cre’n-fa v’ad gyllaghey myr shen n’oi.

English: 25 And as they bound him with thongs, Paul said unto the centurion that stood by, Is it lawful for you to scourge a man that is a Roman, and uncondemned?
Manx: As myr v’ad dy chiangley Eh lesh yeeallyn, dooyrt Paul rish y captan-keead va ny hassoo liorish, Vel eh lowit diuish dy chustey dooinney ta bentyn rish y Raue, as nagh vel er ny gheyrey?

English: 26 When the centurion heard that, he went and told the chief captain, saying, Take heed what thou doest : for this man is a Roman.
Manx: Tra cheayll yn captan-keead shen, hie Eh as dinsh Eh eh da’n ard chaptan, gra, Cur tastey cre t’ow dy yannoo ; son ta’n dooinney shoh bentyn rish y Raue.

English: 27 Then the chief captain came, and said unto him, Tell me, art thou a Roman? He said, Yea.
Manx: Eisht haink yn ard chaptan, as dooyrt Eh rish, Insh dou, vel uss bentyn rish y Raue? Dooyrt eshyn, Ta mee.

English: 28 And the chief captain answered, With a great sum obtained I this freedom. And Paul said, But I was free born.
Manx: Dreggyr yn ard chaptan, Lesh sim mooar dy argid hooar mish yn seyrsnaght shen. As dooyrt Paul, Agh ruggyr mish seyr.

English: 29 Then straightway they departed from him which should have examined him : and the chief captain also was afraid, after he knew that he was a Roman, and because he had bound him.
Manx: Eisht jimmee adsyn chelleeragh veih lhisagh v’er veaysht Eh, as ghow yn ard chaptan hene aggle tra va fys echey dy row Eh bentyn rish y Raue, as er-y-fa dy row Eh er chiangley Eh.

English: 30 On the morrow, because he would have known the certainty wherefore he was accused of the Jews, he loosed him from his bands, and commanded the chief priests and all their council to appear, and brought Paul down, and set him before them.
Manx: Laa ny vairagh, er-yn-oyr dy row Eh aignagh fys y ve echey, ayns shickyrys cre va ny Hewnyn dy choyrt ny lieh, deayshil Eh Eh veih e yeulaghyn, as hug Eh saarey ny ard-saggyrtyn as ooilley yn choonceïl oc dy heet kionfenish, as hug Eh lesh Paul sheese, as hoie Eh Eh kiongoyrt roo.
CAB. XXIII.

English: And Paul, earnestly beholding the council, said, Men and brethren, I have lived in all good conscience before God until this day.
Manx: As yeeagh Paul dy gyere er y choonceïl as dooyrt Eh, Gheiney as vraaraghyn, Ta mee er hirveish Jee ayns dy chooilley chooinsheanse vie, gys y laa t’ayn jiu.

English: 2 And the high priest Ananias commanded them that stood by him to smite him on the mouth.
Manx: As hug Ananias yn ard-saggyrt saarey dauesyn va nyn shassoo liorish, dy woalley Eh er y veeal.

English: 3 Then said Paul unto him, God shall smite thee, thou whited wall : for sittest thou to judge me after the law, and commandest me to be smitten contrary to the law?
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Paul rish, Nee Jee uss y woalley, voal yiallit : son vel uss d[t]y hoie dy my vriwnys’s lurg y leigh, as cur saarey mee dy ve bwoailt noi yn leigh.

English: 4 And they that stood by said, Revilest thou God’s high priest?
Manx: As dooyrt y vooinjer va nyn shassoo liorish rish, Vel uss loayrt dy scammyltagh noi ard-saggyrt Yee?

English: 5 Then said Paul, I wist not, brethren, that he was the high priest : for it is written, Thou shalt not speak evil of the ruler of thy people.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Paul, Cha row fys aym, vraaraghyn, dy nee yn ard-saggyrt v’eh : son te scruit, Cha loayr oo dy holk jeh fer-reïl dty phobble.

English: 6 But when Paul perceived that the one part were Sadducees, and the other Pharisees, he cried out in the council, Men and brethren, I am a Pharisee, the son of a Pharisee : of the hope and resurrection of the dead I am called in question.
Manx: Agh tra dennee Paul dy row yn derrey ayrn jeu nyn Sadduceeyn, as yn ayrn elley nyn Phariseeyn, deïe Eh ayns y choonceïl, Gheiney as vraaraghyn, Ta mee my Pharisee, my Vac da Pharisee : son treishteil as irree seose-reesht ny merriu ta mee eït gys coontey.

English: 7 And when he had so said, there arose a dissension between the Pharisees and the Sadducees : and the multitude was divided.
Manx: As tra v’eh er ghra shoh, dirree streeu eddyr ny Phariseeyn as ny Sadduceeyn, as va’n chaglym noi ry hoi.

English: 8 For the Sadducees say that there is no resurrection, neither angel, nor spirit : but the Pharisees confess both.
Manx: Son ta ny Sadduceeyn gra nagh vel irree-seose-reesht ayn, ny ainle ny spyrryd ; agh ta ny Phariseeyn goaill roo ny neesht.

English: 9 And there arose a great cry : and the scribes that were of the Pharisees’ part arose, and strove, saying, We find no evil in this man : but if a spirit or an angel hath spoken to him, let us not fight against God.
Manx: As va argane mooar er ny ghoostey : as dirree ny scruderyn va er paart ny Phariseeyn, as streeu ad, gra, Cha vel shinyn er geddyn foill erbee ayns y dooinney shoh : agh my ta spyrryd ny ainle er loayrt rish, ny lig dooin caggey noi Jee.

English: 10 And when there arose a great dissension, the chief captain, fearing lest Paul should have been pulled in pieces of them, commanded the soldiers to go down, and to take him by force from among them, and to bring him into the castle.
Manx: As myr va’n streeu mooadaghey va’n ard chaptan agglagh dy raipagh ad Paul ayns peeshyn, as doardee Eh sidooryn dy gholl sheese, as dy ghoaill Eh er niart veih nyn mast’ oc, as dy chur lhieu Eh stiagh ayns y chashtal.

English: 11 And the night following the Lord stood by him, and said, Be of good cheer, Paul : for as thou hast testified of me in Jerusalem, so must thou bear witness also at Rome.
Manx: As yn oie er-giyn hass y Chiarn liorish, as dooyrt Eh, Bee dy yien mie, Phaul : son myr t’ow er n’ymmyrkey feanish jeem’s ayns Jerusalem, myr shen myrgeddin shegin dhyt feanish y ymmyrkey ec y Raue.

English: 12 And when it was day, certain of the Jews banded together, and bound themselves under a curse, saying that they would neither eat nor drink till they had killed Paul.
Manx: As tra va’n laa ayn, hiaggyl shiartance jeh ny Hewnyn cooidjagh, as chiangle ad ad hene fo mollaght, gra nagh nee-agh ad as nagh niu-agh ad derrey veagh ad er varroo Paul.

English: 13 And they were more than forty which had made this conspiracy.
Manx: As va ny smoo na da-eed jeu ayns y drogh-choyrlaghey shoh.

English: 14 And they came to the chief priests and elders, and said, We have bound ourselves under a great curse, that we will eat nothing until we have slain Paul.
Manx: As haink ad gys ny ard-saggyrtyn as y chanstyr, as dooyrt ad, Ta shin er chiangley shin hene fo mollaght mooar, nagh nee mad veg derrey vees shin er varroo Paul.

English: 15 Now therefore ye with the council signify to the chief captain that he bring him down unto you to morrow, as though ye would enquire something more perfectly concerning him : and we, or ever he come near, are ready to kill him.
Manx: Nish er-y-fa shen jean-jee shiuish as y choonceïl fys y chur gys yn ard chaptan, Eh dy chur lesh Eh hiu mairagh, myr dy beagh red ennagh eu dy gheddyn toiggal sodjeh jeh mychione echey : as bee mainyn aarloo, roish my jig Eh nyn vaar, dy varroo Eh.

English: 16 And when Paul’s sister’s son heard of their lying in wait, he went and entered into the castle, and told Paul.
Manx: As tra cheayll mac shayrey Phaul jeh ny croutyn oc, jimmee Eh roish, as hie Eh stiagh ayns y chashtal, as dinsh Eh ooilley da Paul.

English: 17 Then Paul called one of the centurions unto him, and said, Bring this young man unto the chief captain : for he hath a certain thing to tell him.
Manx: Eisht deïe Paul er annane jeh ny captanyn-keead huggey, as dooyrt Eh, Cur lhiat yn dooinney aeg shoh ys yn ard chaptan ; son ta red ennagh echey dy insh da.

English: 18 So he took him, and brought him to the chief captain, and said, Paul the prisoner called me unto him, and prayed me to bring this young man unto thee, who hath something to say unto thee.
Manx: Myr shen ghow Eh Eh, as hug Eh lesh Eh gys yn ard chaptan, as dooyrt Eh, Deïe Paul yn pryssoonagh orrym huggey, as ghuee Eh orrym mee dy chur lhiam yn dooinney aeg shoh hoods, son dy vel red ennagh echey dy ghra rhyt.

English: 19 Then the chief captain took him by the hand, and went with him aside privately, and asked him, What is that thou hast to tell me?
Manx: Eisht ghow yn ard-chaptan Eh er y laue, as hie Eh mârish dy lhiattee gys boayl er-lheh, as dênee Eh jeh, Cre shen t’ayd dy insh dooys?

English: 20 And he said, The Jews have agreed to desire thee that thou wouldest bring down Paul to morrow into the council, as though they would enquire somewhat of him more perfectly.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh, Ta ny Hewnyn er chordail dy hirrey orts, oo dy chur Paul sheese mairagh gys y choonceïl, myr dy beagh red ennagh oc dy gheddyn toiggal sodjeh jeh veih.

English: 21 But do not thou yield unto them : for there lie in wait for him of them more than forty men, which have bound themselves with an oath, that they will neither eat nor drink till they have killed him : and now are they ready, looking for a promise from thee.
Manx: Agh ny jean uss er y raa oc : son ta aarloo dy ghoaill Eh er-skyn da-eed dooinney jeu, t’er chiangley ad hene fo mollaght, nagh jean ad gee ny giu derrey vees ad er varroo Eh : as nish t’ad aarloo, jerkal rish gialdyn y gheddyn voids.

English: 22 So the chief captain then let the young man depart, and charged him, See thou tell no man that thou hast shewed these things to me.
Manx: Myr shen lig yn ard chaptan yn raad da’n dooinney aeg, as hug Eh currym da, Jeeagh nagh ninsh oo da dooinney erbee dy vel oo er hoilshaghey ny reddyn shoh dooys.

English: 23 And he called unto him two centurions, saying, Make ready two hundred soldiers to go to Caesarea, and horsemen threescore and ten, and spearmen two hundred, at the third hour of the night ;
Manx: As deïe Eh er daa chaptan-keead huggey, gra, Fow-jee aarloo da[a] cheead sidoor dy gholl gys Cesarea, as markee three-feed as jeih, as deiney-shleigh daa cheead, ec y tress oor jeh’n oie.

English: 24 And provide them beasts, that they may set Paul on, and bring him safe unto Felix the governor.
Manx: As kiare-jee beiyn daue, dy vod Paul markiagh, as dy vod ad y chur lhieu Eh dy sauchey gys y kiannoort Felix.

English: 25 And he wrote a letter after this manner :
Manx: As scrieu Eh screeuyn er yn aght shoh :

English: 26 Claudius Lysias unto the most excellent governor Felix sendeth greeting.
Manx: Bea as slaynt veih Claudius Lysias, gys y kiannoort smoo ooasle Felix.

English: 27 This man was taken of the Jews, and should have been killed of them : then came I with an army, and rescued him, having understood that he was a Roman.
Manx: Va’n dooinney shoh goit ec ny Hewnyn, as veagh ad er choyrt Eh gys baase : agh haink mish lesh sheshaght dy hidooryn, as haue mee Eh vow, tra hoig mee dy row Eh bentyn rish y Raue.

English: 28 And when I would have known the cause wherefore they accused him, I brought him forth into their council :
Manx: As liorish dy row mee booiagh fys y gheddyn er yn oyr v’oc dy phlaynt er, hug mee lhiam Eh fenish y choonceil oc :

English: 29 Whom I perceived to be accused of questions of their law, but to have nothing laid to his charge worthy of death or of bonds.
Manx: As dennee mee dy row Eh eït, gys coontey mychione questionyn jeh’n leigh oc hene ; agh nagh row nhee erbee er ny chur gys e lieh toilchin baase ny geulaghyn.

English: 30 And when it was told me how that the Jews laid wait for the man, I sent straightway to thee, and gave commandment to his accusers also to say before thee what they had against him. Farewell.
Manx: As tra ve inshit dou dy row ny Hewnyn ayns drogh-choyrlaghey noi bioys y dooinney, hug mee fys chelleeragh hoods, as doardee mee yn vooinjer va loart n’oi, dy ghra kiongoyrt rhyts ny va oc dy ghra n’oi. Shee dy row mârt.

English: 31 Then the soldiers, as it was commanded them, took Paul, and brought him by night to Antipatris.
Manx: Eisht ghow ny sidooryn Paul myr v’ad oardrit, as hug ad lhieu Eh ayns yn oie gys Antipatris.

English: 32 On the morrow they left the horsemen to go with him, and returned to the castle :
Manx: Laa ny vairagh daag ad ny markee dy gholl mârish, as hie ad back gys y chashtal.

English: 33 Who, when they came to Caesarea and delivered the epistle to the governor, presented Paul also before him.
Manx: As tra haink ny markee gys Cesarea, livrey ad ny screeuyn gys y chiannoort, as hoie ad Paul myrgeddin kiongoyrt rish.

English: 34 And when the governor had read the letter, he asked of what province he was. And when he understood that he was of Cilicia ;
Manx: As tra va’n kiannoort er lhaih ny screeuyn, dênee Eh cre’n cheer v’eh jeh. As tra hoig Eh dy nee veih Cilicia v’eh ;

English: 35 I will hear thee, said he, when thine accusers are also come. And he commanded him to be kept in Herod’s judgment hall.
Manx: Verrym clashtyn dhyt, dooyrt eshyn, tra vees y vooinjer ta loayrt dt’oi er jeet. As hug Eh saarey Eh dy ve freilt ayns hall-briwnys Herod.
CAB. XXIV.

English: And after five days Ananias the high priest descended with the elders, and with a certain orator named Tertullus, who informed the governor against Paul.
Manx: As ec kione queig laa, hie Ananias yn ard-saggyrt sheese marish y chanstyr, as ard phleadere dy row va enmyssit Tertullus, dy chur eddin da Paul fenish y chiannoort.

English: 2 And when he was called forth, Tertullus began to accuse him, saying, Seeing that by thee we enjoy great quietness, and that very worthy deeds are done unto this nation by thy providence,
Manx: As tra v’eh eït magh, ren Tertullus toshiaght dy loayrt n’oi, gra, Fakin dy vel fea mooar ain liorts, as dy vel ymmodee dy reddyn jeant son y chooid share son yn ashoon shoh fo dty reill’s,

English: 3 We accept it always, and in all places, most noble Felix, with all thankfulness.
Manx: Ta shin ec dy chooilley earish, as ayns dy chooilley ynnyd, goaill rish, Felix smoo ooasle, lesh dy chooilley vooise.

English: 4 Notwithstanding, that I be not further tedious unto thee, I pray thee that thou wouldest hear us of thy clemency a few words.
Manx: Agh son nagh goym rouyr jeh’n traa ayd seose, ta mee guee ort oo dy ve cha foayroil as dy eishtagh tammylt rhym :

English: 5 For we have found this man a pestilent fellow, and a mover of sedition among all the Jews throughout the world, and a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes :
Manx: Ta shin er gheddyn yn dooinney shoh er-skyn towse boiragh, t’eh er chur ooilley ny Hewnyn trooid y theihll fo my chielley, as er ve ny ard-leeideilagh mastey ny Nazarenee, ayns y shaghrynys oc ayns credjue :

English: 6 Who also hath gone about to profane the temple : whom we took, and would have judged according to our law.
Manx: T’eh myrgeddin er ghoaill er yn chiamble y hollaghey : as ghow shinyn Eh, as baillin v’er vriwnys Eh cordail rish y leigh ain.

English: 7 But the chief captain Lysias came upon us, and with great violence took him away out of our hands,
Manx: Agh haink yn ard chaptan Lysias orrin, as ghow Eh Eh er eer niart ass nyn laueyn,

English: 8 Commanding his accusers to come unto thee : by examining of whom thyself mayest take knowledge of all these things, whereof we accuse him.
Manx: As hug Eh saarey da’n vooinjer va loayrt n’oi dy heet ayns yn enish ayds : as tra vees oo er nyn veaysht ad, bee toiggal ayd jeh dy chooilley nhee ta shinyn dy choyrt ny lieh.

English: 9 And the Jews also assented, saying that these things were so.
Manx: As va ny Hewnyn er yn un ghlare rish, gra, dy nee shen myr va’n chooish.

English: 10 Then Paul, after that the governor had beckoned unto him to speak, answered, Forasmuch as I know that thou hast been of many years a judge unto this nation, I do the more cheerfully answer for myself :
Manx: Eisht dreggyr Paul, tra va’n kiannoort er chra e laue er dy loayrt, Son wheesh as dy vel fys aym dy vel uss er ve rish ymmodee dy vleeantyn dty vriw da’n ashoon shoh, ta mee ny s’aggindee dy ansoor er my hon hene ;

English: 11 Because that thou mayest understand, that there are yet but twelve days since I went up to Jerusalem for to worship.
Manx: Er-y-fa dy vod oo toiggal y ghoaill, nagh vel agh daa laa yeig foast neayr as hie mee seose dy chur ooashley ec Jerusalem.

English: 12 And they neither found me in the temple disputing with any man, neither raising up the people, neither in the synagogues, nor in the city :
Manx: As cha dooar ad mee ayns y chiamble resooney rish dooinney erbee, ny greinnaghey yn pobble gys irree-magh, edyr ayns ny kialteenyn, ny ayns yn ard-valley :

English: 13 Neither can they prove the things whereof they now accuse me.
Manx: Cha-moo t’ad abyl ny reddyn t’ad dy choyrt my lieh y phrowal.

English: 14 But this I confess unto thee, that after the way which they call heresy, so worship I the God of my fathers, believing all things which are written in the law and in the prophets :
Manx: Agh shoh ta mee goaill-rish dhyt, lurg yn aght t’adsyn genmys shaghrynys veih yn chredjue, dy nee shen myr ta mish cur ooashley da Jee my ayraghyn, credjal dagh nhee ta scruit ayns y leigh as ny phadeyryn :

English: 15 And have hope toward God, which they themselves also allow, that there shall be a resurrection of the dead, both of the just and unjust.
Manx: As ta treishteil aym gys Jee, red t’ad hene myrgeddin dy lowal, dy bee irree-seose-reesht jeh ny merriu ayn, chammah jeh cairagh as neu-chairagh.

English: 16 And herein do I exercise myself, to have always a conscience void to offence toward God, and toward men.
Manx: As er-yn-oyr shoh ta mee er my chliaghtey hene, cooinsheanse gyn loght y ve aym kinjagh gys Jee as gys deiney.

English: 17 Now after many years I came to bring alms to my nation, and offerings.
Manx: Nish lurg ymmodee dy vleeantyn, haink mee dy chur lhiam jeirk gys my ashoon hene, as ourallyn.

English: 18 Whereupon certain Jews from Asia found me purified in the temple, neither with multitude, nor with tumult.
Manx: Er shoh hooar shiartance dy Hewnyn veih Asia mee er my ghlenney ayns y chiamble, agh cha nee lesh chymsaghey sleih, ny boirrainys :

English: 19 Who ought to have been here before thee, and object, if they had ought against me.
Manx: As lhisagh ad ve ayns shoh dy loayrt m’oi, my va red erbee oc dy choyrt my lieh.

English: 20 Or else let these same here say, if they have found any evil doing in me, while I stood before the council,
Manx: Er nonney lig daue shoh hene loayrt, my hooar ad mee-chairys erbee aynym, tra hass mee kiongoyrt y choonceïl ;

English: 21 Except it be for this one voice, that I cried standing among them, Touching the resurrection of the dead I am called in question by you this day.
Manx: Mannagh vel mee son yn un choraa shoh hug mee magh tra hass mee nyn mast’ oc, Mychione irree-seose-reesht ny merriu ta mee eït gys coontey lieriu jiu.

English: 22 And when Felix heard these things, having more perfect knowledge of that way, he deferred them, and said, When Lysias the chief captain shall come down, I will know the uttermost of your matter.
Manx: Tra cheayll Felix shoh, hug Eh ad shiaghey, liorish dy row toiggal sodjey echey jeh’n raad shen, as dooyrt Eh, Tra hig Lysias yn ard chaptan neose, yoyms fys er bun y chooish eu.

English: 23 And he commanded a centurion to keep Paul, and to let him have liberty, and that he should forbid none of his acquaintance to minister or come unto him.
Manx: As doardee Eh captan-keead dy yeeaghyn da Paul, as e remys y ve echey, as nagh lhiettagh Eh veg jeh’n ainjys echey dy hirveish dy hirveish, ny dy heet huggey.

English: 24 And after certain days, when Felix came with his wife Drusilla, which was a Jewess, he sent for Paul, and heard him concerning the faith in Christ.
Manx: As lurg shiartance dy laghyn, haink Felix as e ven Drusilla, va ny Hew, as hug Eh fys er Paul, as deaisht Eh rish mychione y credjue ayns Creest.

English: 25 And as he reasoned of righteousness, temperance, and judgment to come, Felix trembled, and answered, Go thy way for this time ; when I have a convenient season, I will call for thee.
Manx: As myr v’eh loayrt mychione cairys, sheeltys, as y vriwnys va ry heet, chrie Felix, as dansoor Eh, Immee royd nish ; tra vees traa cooie aym, verrrym fys ort.

English: 26 He hoped also that money should have been given him of Paul, that he might loose him : wherefore he sent for him the oftener, and communed with him.
Manx: V’eh treishteil myrgeddin dy beagh Paul er chur argid da, son feaysley chur da ; shen-y-fa v’eh cur fys er ny s’menkey dy loayrt rish.

English: 27 ¶But after two years Porcius Festus came into Felix’ room : and Felix, willing to shew the Jews a pleasure, left Paul bound.
Manx: Agh ec kione daa vlein, haink Porcius Festus ayns ynnyd Felix : as liorish dy row Felix booiagh ny Hewnyn y wooiys, daag Eh Paul ny phryssoonagh.
CAB. XXV.

English: Now when Festus was come into the province, after three days he ascended from Caesarea to Jerusalem.
Manx: Nish tra va Festus er jeet gys y cheer, ec kione three laa hie Eh seose veih Cesarea gys Jerusalem.

English: 2 Then the high priest and the chief of the Jews informed him against Paul, and besought him,
Manx: Eisht hug yn ard-saggyrt, as leedeilee ny Hewnyn coontey da jeh Paul, as ren ad aghin huggey,

English: 3 And desired favour against him, that he would send for him to Jerusalem, laying wait in the way to kill him.
Manx: As ghuee ad er yn foayr shoh y yeeaghyn daue n’oi, Eh dy chur fys er gys Jerusalem, son dy row ad soit er e vioys y ghoaill er y raad.

English: 4 But Festus answered, that Paul should be kept at Caesarea, and that he himself would depart shortly thither.
Manx: Agh dreggyr Festus, dy beagh Paul freilt ec Cesarea, as dy ragh Eh hene ayns shen dy gerrit.

English: 5 Let them therefore, said he, which among you are able, go down with me, and accuse this man, if there be any wickedness in him.
Manx: Lig dauesyn er-y-fa shen ta er y hon nyn mast’ eu, dooyrt eshyn, goll sheese mâryms, as cur noi yn dooinney shoh foill erbee dy vel ayn.

English: 6 And when he had tarried among them more than ten days, he went down unto Caesarea ; and the next day sitting on the judgment seat commanded Paul to be brought.
Manx: As tra v’eh er vuirriaght nyn mast’ oc erskyn jeih laa, hie Eh sheese gys Cesarea ; as laa ny vairagh hoie Eh er stoyl y vriwnys, as hug Eh saarey Paul y chur ayns yn enish echey.

English: 7 And when he was come, the Jews which came down from Jerusalem stood round about, and laid many and grievous complaints against Paul, which they could not prove.
Manx: As tra v’eh er jeet, hass ny Hewnyn haink veih Jerusalem mygeayrt, as hug ad ymmodee foiljyn eajee dys lieh Phaul, nagh row ad abyl y yannoo mie ;

English: 8 While he answered for himself, Neither against the law of the Jews, neither against the temple, nor yet against Caesar, have I offended any thing at all.
Manx: Eshyn ayns y traa gra er e hon hene, Nagh row Eh noi leigh ny Hewnyn, ny noi yn chiamble, ny foast noi Cesar, er ve foiljagh ayns nhee erbee.

English: 9 But Festus, willing to do the Jews a pleasure, answered Paul, and said, Wilt thou go up to Jerusalem, and there be judged of these things before me?
Manx: Agh dansoor Festus, liorish dy row Eh booiagh ny Hewnyn y wooiys, as dooyrt Eh rish Paul, Vel oo booiagh goll seose gys Jerusalem, ayns shen dy ve er dty vriwnys son ny reddyn shoh kiongoyrt rhym’s?

English: 10 Then said Paul, I stand at Caesar’s judgment seat, where I ought to be judged : to the Jews have I done no wrong, as thou very well knowest.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Paul, Ta mee my hassoo ec stoyl-briwnys Cesar, raad te cooie dou dy ve briwnyssit : da ny Hewnyn cha vel mee er n’yannoo aggair erbee, myr t’ow toiggal dy feer vie.

English: 11 For if I be an offender, or have committed any thing worthy of death, I refuse not to die : but if there be none of these things whereof these accuse me, no man may deliver me unto them. I appeal unto Caesar.
Manx: Son my ta mee my ghrogh-yantagh, ny my ta mee er n’yannoo nhee erbee dy hoilchin baase, cha vel mee gobbal baase y hurranse : agh mannagh vel veg jeh ny reddyn shoh firrinagh t’ad shoh dy choyrt my lieh, cha vod dooinney erbee mish y livrey seose huc. Ta mee peallal gys Cesar.

English: 12 Then Festus, when he had conferred with the council, answered, Hast thou appealed unto Caesar? unto Caesar shalt thou go.
Manx: Eisht loayr Festus rish y choonceïl, as dooyrt Eh, Vel oo er pheallal gys Cesar? gys Cesar heu.

English: 13 And after certain days king Agrippa and Bernice came unto Caesarea to salute Festus.
Manx: As ec kione shiartance dy laghyn, haink ree Agrippa as Bernice gys Cesarea dy yeeaghyn Festus.

English: 14 And when they had been there many days, Festus declared Paul’s cause unto the king, saying, There is a certain man left in bonds by Felix :
Manx: As erreish daue v’er ve ayns shen ymmodee dy laghyn, hoilshee Festus cooish Phaul da’n ree, gra, Ta dooinney ayns shoh va faagit ny phryssoonagh liorish Felix :

English: 15 About whom, when I was at Jerusalem, the chief priests and the elders of the Jews informed me, desiring to have judgment against him.
Manx: Mychione echey, tra va mee ec Jerusalem, ren ny ard-saggyrtyn as shanstyr ny Hewnyn aghin hym, geearree Eh dy ve briwnyssit.

English: 16 To whom I answered, It is not the manner of the Romans to deliver any man to die, before that he which is accused have the accusers face to face, and have licence to answer for himself concerning the crime laid against him.
Manx: Dansoor mish ad, Nagh nee cliaghtey yn vooinjer va bentyn rish y Raue ve dy livrey dooinney erbee seose gys baase, derrey veagh y fer veagh er ny chassid, as adsyn veagh dy chassid Eh noi ry hoi, as kied echey loayrt er e hon hene mychione yn oill veagh er ny choyrt ny lieh.

English: 17 Therefore, when they were come hither, without any delay on the morrow I sat on the judgment seat, and commanded the man to be brought forth.
Manx: Shen-y-fa tra v’ad er jeet ayns shoh, fegooish lhiggey-shiaghey hoie mee laa ny vairagh er stoyl y vriwnys, as doardee mee yn dooinney y chur kionfenish.

English: 18 Against whom when the accusers stood up, they brought none accusation of such things as I supposed :
Manx: N’oi, tra va’n vooinjer va dy phlaiynt Eh er hassoo seose, cha dug ad nhee erbee dys e lieh jeh ny reddyn va mish dy smooinaghtyn :

English: 19 But had certain questions against him of their own superstition, and of one Jesus, which was dead, whom Paul affirmed to be alive.
Manx: Agh va shiartance dy whestionyn oc n’oi, mychione y rouyr fardail v’ayns y chraueeaght oc, as mychione fer va enmyssit Yeesey va marroo, agh hickyree Paul dy row Eh bio.

English: 20 And because I doubted of such manner of questions, I asked him whether he would go to Jerusalem, and there be judged of these matters.
Manx: Er-yn-oyr dy row mee ayns imnea mychione leid ny questionyn, dênee mee jeh row Eh booiagh goll seose gys Jerusalem, ayns shen dy ve briwnyssit son ny reddyn shoh.

English: 21 But when Paul had appealed to be reserved unto the hearing of Augustus, I commanded him to be kept till I might send him to Caesar.
Manx: Agh tra va Paul er pheallal dy ve freilt gys clashtyn Augustus, hug mee saarey Eh dy v’er ny reaylley derrey oddin Eh y choyrt gys Cesar.

English: 22 Then Agrippa said unto Festus, I would also hear the man myself. To morrow, said he, thou shalt hear him.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Agrippa rish Festus, v’ein’s mee hene booiagh yn dooinney y chlashtyn. Mairagh, dooyrt eshyn, nee oo clashtyn Eh.

English: 23 And on the morrow, when Agrippa was come, and Bernice, with great pomp, and was entered into the place of hearing, with the chief captains, and principal men of the city, at Festus’ commandment Paul was brought forth.
Manx: As laa ny vairagh, tra va Agrippa er jeet, as Bernice ayns stayd vooar, as er gholl stiagh ayns thie ny quaylagh, marish ny ard chaptanyn, as ard deiney yn ard-valley, ec saarey Festus va Paul er ny choyrt kionfenish.

English: 24 And Festus said, King Agrippa, and all men which are here present with us, ye see this man, about whom all the multitude of the Jews have dealt with me, both at Jerusalem, and also here, crying that he ought not to live any longer.
Manx: As dooyrt Festus, Ree Agrippa, as dy chooilley ghooinney t’ayns shoh kionfenish mârin, hee shiu yn dooinney shoh, mychione ta ooilley ny Hewnyn er phlaynt hyms, chammah ec Jerusalem as ayns shoh, geamagh nagh lhisagh Eh ve ny sodjey bio.

English: 25 But when I found that he had committed nothing worthy of death, and that he himself hath appealed to Augustus, I have determined to send him.
Manx: Agh tra hooar mish magh nagh row Eh er n’yannoo nhee erbee dy hoilchin baase, as dy row Eh hene er pheallal gys Augustus, ta mee kiarit dy choyrt Eh.

English: 26 Of whom I have no certain thing to write unto my lord. Wherefore I have brought him forth before you, and specially before thee, O king Agrippa, that, after examination had, I might have somewhat to write.
Manx: As er-y-fa nagh vel shickyrys aym jeh nhee erbee oddym y scrieu gys my hiarn, ta mee er choyrt lhiam Eh magh kiongoyrt riu, agh er-skyn ooilley kiongoyrt rhyts, Ree Agrippa, erreish da ve feayshtit, dy vod red ennagh ve aym dy scrieu.

English: 27 For it seemeth to me unreasonable to send a prisoner, and not withal to signify the crimes laid against him.
Manx: Son va mee smooinaghtyn dy row eh red neu-resoonagh pryssoonagh y choyrt, as gyn ny foiljyn v’er ny chur gys e lieh y hoilshaghey.
CAB. XXVI.

English: Then Agrippa said unto Paul, Thou art permitted to speak for thyself. Then Paul stretched forth the hand, and answered for himself :
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Agrippa rish Paul, Ta kied ayd loayrt er dty hon hene. Eisht heeyn Paul magh e laue, as dansoor Eh er e hon hene,

English: 2 I think myself happy, king Agrippa, because I shall answer for myself this day before thee touching all the things whereof I am accused of the Jews :
Manx: Ta mee jeeaghyn er myr bannaght, Ree Agrippa, er-y-fa dy vel mee dy ansoor er my hon hene jiu kiongoyrt rhyts, mychione ooilley ny reddyn ta ny Hewnyn dy chur my lieh :

English: 3 Especially because I know thee to be expert in all customs and questions which are among the Jews : wherefore I beseech thee to hear me patiently.
Manx: Er-skyn ooilley, er-y-fa dy vel toiggal ayd jeh dy chooilley chliaghtey as question ta mastey ny Hewnyn : shen-y-fa ta mee guee ort, oo dy eaishtagh rhym dy surransagh.

English: 4 My manner of life from my youth, which was at the first among mine own nation at Jerusalem, know all the Jews ;
Manx: My ymmyrkey-bea veih my aegid, va hoshiaght mastey my ashoon hene ec Jerusalem, ta fys ec ooilley ny Hewnyn er,

English: 5 Which knew me from the beginning, if they would testify, that after the most straitest sect of our religion I lived a Pharisee.
Manx: Va enney oc orrym er dyn toshiaght, (dy jinnagh ad feanish y ymmyrkey) kys lurg yn aght s’gyerey jeh’n chredjue ain, ren mee baeghey my Pharisee.

English: 6 And now I stand and am judged for the hope of the promise made of God, unto our fathers :
Manx: As nish ta mee my hassoo, as er my vriwnys son treishteil y gialdyn ren Jee da ny ayraghyn ain :

English: 7 Unto which promise our twelve tribes, instantly serving God day and night, hope to come. For which hope’s sake, king Agrippa, I am accused of the Jews.
Manx: Gys y gialdyn cheddin ta’n daa heeloghe yeig ain, ta shirveish Jee oie as laa, treishteil dy heet, as er coontey yn treishteil shoh, Ree Agrippa, ta mee er my chassid liorish ny Hewnyn.

English: 8 Why should it be thought a thing incredible with you, that God should raise the dead?
Manx: Cre’n-fa te smooinit lieriuish red nagh vel dy ve creddit, Jee dy vioghey ny merriu?

English: 9 I verily thought with myself, that I ought to do many things contrary to the name of Jesus of Nazareth.
Manx: Ghow mish dy jarroo aym pene dy lhisin ymmodee dy reddyn y yannoo noi ennym Yeesey dy Nazareth.

English: 10 Which thing I also did in Jerusalem : and many of the saints did I shut up in prison, having received authority from the chief priests ; and when they were put to death, I gave my voice against them.
Manx: As shen ren mee neesht ayns Jerusalem : as ymmodee jeh ny nooghyn yeigh mee ayns pryssoon, erreish dou v’er gheddyn pooar veih ny ard-saggyrtyn ; as tra v’ad er nyn goyrt gy baase, hug mee my choraa nyn oi oc.

English: 11 And I punished them oft in every synagogue, and compelled them to blaspheme ; and being exceedingly mad against them, I persecuted them even unto strange cities.
Manx: As cherree mee ad dy mennick ayns dy chooilley cheeill, as deaginee mee ad dy loayrt goan-mollaghtagh ; as va mee ass towse elgyssagh nyn oi oc, as ren mee tranlaase orroo gys eer ard-valjyn joarree.

English: 12 Whereupon as I went to Damascus with authority and commission from the chief priests,
Manx: Er shoh tra hie mee gys Damascus lesh pooar as barrantys veih ny ard-saggyrtyn ;

English: 13 At midday, O king, I saw in the way a light from heaven, above the brightness of the sun, shining round about me and them which journeyed with me.
Manx: Ec mun-laa, O ree, honnick mee er y raad soilshey veih niau erskyn sollyssit y ghrian, soilshean mygeayrt y moo’ms, as y vooinjer v’er nyn yurnah mârym.

English: 14 And when we were all fallen to the earth, I heard a voice speaking unto me, and saying in the Hebrew tongue, Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me? it is hard for thee to kick against the pricks.
Manx: As tra va shin ooilley er duittym gys y thalloo, cheayll mee coraa loayrt rhym, as gra ayns glare ny Hebrewyn, Saul, Saul, cre’n-fa t’ow jannoo tranlaase orrym? Te doillee dhyt dy vrebbal noi ny jilg.

English: 15 And I said, Who art thou, Lord? And he said, I am Jesus whom thou persecutest.
Manx: As dooyrt mish, Quoi oo, Hiarn? As dooyrt Eh, Mish Yeesey t’ow jannoo tranlaase er.

English: 16 But rise, and stand upon thy feet : for I have appeared unto thee for this purpose, to make thee a minister and a witness both of these things which thou hast seen, and of those things in the which I will appear unto thee ;
Manx: Agh irree, as shass er dty chassyn : son ta mish er hoilshaghey mee hene dhyt er yn oyr shoh, dy yannoo oo d[t]y hirveishagh as d[t]y eanish, chammah jeh ny reddyn t’ow er vakin, as jeh ny reddyn ayndoo nee’m mee hene y hoilshaghey dhyt ;

English: 17 Delivering thee from the people, and from the Gentiles, unto whom now I send thee,
Manx: Fendeil oo veih yn pobble, as vowsyn jeh ny Ashoonyn-quaagh, huc ta mee nish dy dty choyrt.

English: 18 To open their eyes, and to turn them from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan unto God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins, and inheritance among them which are sanctified by faith that is in me.
Manx: Dy osley nyn sooyllyn, as dy hyndaa ad veih dorraghys gys soilshey, as veih pooar Noid-ny-hanmey gys Jee, dy vod ad leih peccaghyn y gheddyn, as eiraght nyn mast’ ocsyn t’er nyn gasherickey liorish y credjue ta aynyms.

English: 19 Whereupon, O king Agrippa, I was not disobedient unto the heavenly vision :
Manx: Er shoh, Ree Agrippa, cha row mee mee-viallagh gys yn ashlish flaunyssagh :

English: 20 But shewed first unto them of Damascus, and at Jerusalem, and throughout all the coasts of Judaea, and then to the Gentiles, that they should repent and turn to God, and do works meet for repentance.
Manx: Agh hoilshee mee hoshiaght dauesyn v’ayns Damascus, as ec Jerusalem, as trooid ooilley cheer Yudea, as eisht da ny Ashoonyn-quaagh, ad dy ghoaill arrys as dy hyndaa gys Jee, as obbraghyn y yannoo cooie son arrys.

English: 21 For these causes the Jews caught me in the temple, and went about to kill me.
Manx: Son ny oyryn shoh haare ny Hewnyn mee ayns y chiamble, as ghow ad ayns laue my varroo.

English: 22 Having therefore obtained help of God, I continue unto this day, witnessing both to small and great, saying none other things than those which the prophets and Moses did say should come :
Manx: Lesh y cooney er-y-fa shen hooar mee veih Jee, ta mee er-mayrn gys y laa t’ayn jiu, gymmyrkey feanish chammah gys beg as mooar, fegooish nhee erbee sodjey y ghra na dooyrt ny phadeyryn as Moses harragh gy kione :

English: 23 That Christ should suffer, and that he should be the first that should rise from the dead, and should shew light unto the people, and to the Gentiles.
Manx: Dy row Creest dy hurranse, as dy nee Eh veagh y chied er irragh veih ny merriu, as dy jinnagh Eh soilshey y hoilshaghey da’n pobble, as gys ny Ashoonyn-quaagh.

English: 24 And as he thus spake for himself, Festus said with a loud voice, Paul, thou art beside thyself ; much learning doth make thee mad.
Manx: As myr v’eh myr shoh loayrt er e hon hene, dooyrt Festus lesh ard choraa, T’ow ass dty cheeal, Phaul : ta’n ynsagh mooar dy chur oo er-shaghryn.

English: 25 But he said, I am not mad, most noble Festus ; but speak forth the words of truth and soberness.
Manx: Agh dooyrt eshyn, Cha vel mish ass my cheeal, Festus smoo ooasle ; agh ta mee loayrt magh goan dy irriney as dy heeltys.

English: 26 For the king knoweth of these things, before whom also I speak freely : for I am persuaded that none of these things are hidden from him ; for this thing was not done in a corner.
Manx: Son ta fys ec y ree er ny reddyn shoh, kiongoyrt rish er-y-fa shen ta mee loayrt dy arryltagh : son ta mee credjal nagh vel veg jeh ny reddyn shoh kellit veih ; son cha row shoh jeant ayns corneil.

English: 27 King Agrippa, believest thou the prophets? I know that thou believest.
Manx: Ree Agrippa, vel oo credjal ny phadeyryn? ta fys aym dy vel oo credjal.

English: 28 Then Agrippa said unto Paul, Almost thou persuadest me to be a Christian.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Agrippa rish Paul, T’ow faggys er my hayrn dy ve my Chreestee.

English: 29 And Paul said, I would to God, that not only thou, but also all that hear me this day, were both almost, and altogether such as I am, except these bonds.
Manx: As dooyrt Paul, Yee dy beagh, cha nee ynrycan uss, agh myrgeddin ooilley ny ta dy my chlashtyn jiu, chammah faggys as ooilley cooidjagh leid as ta mish, cheu-mooie jeh ny geulaghyn shoh.

English: 30 And when he had thus spoken, the king rose up, and the governor, and Bernice, and they that sat with them :
Manx: As tra v’eh er ghra shoh, dirree yn ree, as y kiannoort, as Bernice, as adsyn va nyn soie mâroo ;

English: 31 And when they were gone aside, they talked between themselves, saying, This man doeth nothing worthy of death or of bonds.
Manx: As hie ad dy lhiattee, as loayr ad eddyr ad hene, gra, Cha vel y dooinney shoh jannoo nhee erbee ta toilchin baase ny bondiaght.

English: 32 Then said Agrippa unto Festus, This man might have been set at liberty, if he had not appealed unto Caesar.
Manx: Eisht dooyrt Agrippa rish Festus, Oddagh feaysley ve ec y dooinney shoh, erbey dy ren Eh peallal gys Cesar.
CAB. XXVII.

English: And when it was determined that we should sail into Italy, they delivered Paul and certain other prisoners unto one named Julius, a centurion of Augustus’ band.
Manx: As tra ve kiarit dy row shin dy ghoaill luingys gys Italy, livrey ad Paul as shiartance dy phryssoonee elley, gys fer va enmyssit Julius captan-keead v’ayns sheshaght Augustus.

English: 2 And entering into a ship of Adramyttium, we launched, meaning to sail by the coasts of Asia ; one Aristarchus, a Macedonian of Thessalonica, being with us.
Manx: As hie shin ayns lhong veih Adramyttium, hie shin magh son y cheayin, kiarrail shiauley shiaghey coastyn Asia, as va Aristarchus, Macedonian veih Thessalonica mârin.

English: 3 And the next day we touched at Sidon. And Julius courteously entreated Paul, and gave him liberty to go unto his friends to refresh himself.
Manx: As yn nah laa haink shin gys Sidon : as ghell Julius dy dooie rish Paul, cur kied da goll mastey e gheiney mooinjerey dy voddagh kiarrail ve goit jeh.

English: 4 And when we had launched from thence, we sailed under Cyprus, because the winds were contrary.
Manx: As tra va shin er gholl magh veih shen, hiauil shin fo Cyprus, er-y-fa dy row yn gheay nyn oi.

English: 5 And when we had sailed over the sea of Cilicia and Pamphylia, we came to Myra, a city of Lycia.
Manx: As tra va shin er hiauley harrish keayn Cilicia as Pamphylia, haink shin gys Myra ard-valley ayns Lycia.

English: 6 And there the centurion found a ship of Alexandria sailing into Italy ; and he put us therein.
Manx: As ayns shen hooar y captain-keead lhong ass Alexandria v’er y veyge eck gys Italy ; as hug Eh shin er-board.

English: 7 And when we had sailed slowly many days, and scarce were come over against Cnidus, the wind not suffering us, we sailed under Crete, over against Salmone ;
Manx: As tra va shin er hiauley dy moal ymmodee dy laghyn, as dy goan va shin er jeet jeeragh er Cnidus, son nagh row yn gheay lhien, hiauil shin fo Crete, magh veih Salmone :

English: 8 And, hardly passing it, came unto a place which is called The fair havens ; nigh whereunto was the city of Lasea.
Manx: As scoan va shin er gholl shiaghey, tra haink shin gys ynnyd ta enmyssit, Ny purtyn aalin, er-gerrey da ard-valley Lasea.

English: 9 Now when much time was spent, and when sailing was now dangerous, because the fast was now already past, Paul admonished them,
Manx: Nish tra va mooarane traa baarit, as dy row shiauley nish dangeragh, er-yn-oyr dy row earish yn trostey nish er gholl shiaghey, choyrlee Paul ad,

English: 10 And said unto them, Sirs, I perceive that this voyage will be with hurt and much damage, not only of the lading and ship, but also of our lives.
Manx: As dooyrt Eh roo, Gheiney mie, ta mee cur tastey dy bee yn veyge shoh lesh skielley as coayl mooar, cha nee ynrycan jeh’n lught as y lhong, agh myrgeddin gys nyn mioys.

English: 11 Nevertheless the centurion believed the master and the owner of the ship, more than those things which were spoken by Paul.
Manx: Ny-yeih chred yn captan-keead mainshtyr as pilot ny luingey, ny smoo na ny reddyn va Paul dy loayrt.

English: 12 And because the haven was not commodious to winter in, the more part advised to depart thence also, if by any means they might attain to Phenice, and there to winter ; which is an haven of Crete, and lieth toward the south west and north west.
Manx: As er-y-fa nagh row eh purt mie dy ve ayn car y yeuree, choyrlee yn ayrn smoo jeh’n cheshaght ad dy gholl rowe veih shen, my oddagh ad er aght erbee cosney gys Phenice, dy voddagh ad yn geurey y chur shiaghey ayns shen ; she purt t’ayns Crete eh, as te lhie gys yn neear-ass as yn neear-hwoai.

English: 13 And when the south wind blew softly, supposing that they had obtained their purpose, loosing thence, they sailed close by Crete.
Manx: As er-y-fa dy row geay-jass as cuiney ayn, heill ad dy beagh nyn earree oc, as deayshil ad veih shen, as hiauil ad close shiaghey Crete.

English: 14 But not long after there arose against it a tempestuous wind, called Euroclydon.
Manx: Agh my daink ny voddey dirree geay sterrymagh nyn oi oc, va enmyssit Yn gheay niar-hwoai.

English: 15 And when the ship was caught, and could not bear up into the wind, we let her drive.
Manx: As tra nagh rowe yn lhong cosney, as nagh dod ee cummal seose gys y gheay, lhig shin jee tuittym lesh.

English: 16 And running under a certain island which is called Clauda, we had much work to come by the boat :
Manx: As roih shin fo ellan dy row, ta enmyssit Clauda, as va lane obbyr ain dy ghoaill stiagh yn baatey :

English: 17 Which when they had taken up, they used helps, undergirding the ship ; and, fearing lest they should fall into the quicksands, strake sail, and so were driven.
Manx: Agh tra v’ee goit seose oc, ren ad ymmyd jeh saasyn, hoïll ad y lhong fo lesh cablyn ; as er aggle dy duittagh ad ayns geinnagh vio, ghow ad yn shiaul neose, as myr shen lhig ad y raad jee.

English: 18 And we being exceedingly tossed with a tempest, the next day they lightened the ship ;
Manx: As erreish dooin ve eiyrit er-skyn towse noon as noal lesh y doyrrin, yn nah laa deddrymmee ad y lhong :

English: 19 And the third day we cast out with our own hands the tackling of the ship.
Manx: As yn tress laa hug shin magh lesh nyn laueyn hene greie ny luingey.

English: 20 And when neither sun nor stars in many days appeared, and no small tempest lay on us, all hope that we should be saved was then taken away.
Manx: As tra nagh daink grian ny aist rish ayns ymmodee dy laghyn, as dy row shin fo sterrym nagh nee beggan, cha row shin ny sodjey jerkal rish dy v’er nyn sauail.

English: 21 But after long abstinence Paul stood forth in the midst of them, and said, Sirs, ye should have hearkened unto me, and not have loosed from Crete, and to have gained this harm and loss.
Manx: As erreish daue v’er ve foddey nyn drostey, hass Paul magh nyn mast’ oc, as dooyrt Eh, Lhisagh shiu, gheiney mie, v’er n’eaishtagh rhyms, as gyn v’er veaysley veih Crete, dy gheddyn yn skielley as y coayl shoh.

English: 22 And now I exhort you to be of good cheer : for there shall be no loss of any man’s life among you, but of the ship.
Manx: As nish ta mee coyrlaghey shiu dy ve ayns gien mie, son cha bee coayl jeh bioys dooinney erbee nyn mast’ eu, agh jeh’n lhong.

English: 23 For there stood by me this night the angel of God, whose I am, and whom I serve,
Manx: Son hass lioryms noght ainle Yee, quoi slesh mee, as Eh ta mee dy hirveish,

English: 24 Saying, Fear not, Paul ; thou must be brought before Caesar : and, lo, God hath given thee all them that sail with thee.
Manx: Gra, Ny gow aggle, Phaul ; shegin dhyt shassoo kiongoyrt rish Cesar : as cur-my ner, ta Jee er chur dhyt ooilley adsyn ta shiauley mârt.

English: 25 Wherefore, sirs, be of good cheer : for I believe God, that it shall be even as it was told me.
Manx: Shen-y-fa, Gheiney mie, cum-jee seose nyn gree : son ta mee credjal Jee, dy bee eh myr te inshit dou.

English: 26 Howbeit we must be cast upon a certain island.
Manx: Ny yeih shegin dooin ve ceaut stiagh er ellan.

English: 27 But when the fourteenth night was come, as we were driven up and down in Adria, about midnight the shipmen deemed that they drew near to some country ;
Manx: Agh tra va’n chiarroo oie yeig er jeet, myr va shin eiyrit noon as noal ayns keayn Adria, mysh y vain-oie heill ny marreeyn dy row ad tayrn er-gerrey da cheer ennagh :

English: 28 And sounded, and found it twenty fathoms : and when they had gone a little further, they sounded again, and found it fifteen fathoms.
Manx: As cheau ad magh yn leoaie, as dennee ad dy row feed feiy oc : as tra v’ad er gholl red beg sodjey, hug ad magh yn leoaie reesht, as hooar ad eh queig feiyn jeig.

English: 29 Then fearing lest we should have fallen upon rocks, they cast four anchors out of the stern, and wished for the day.
Manx: Eisht er aggle dy roiagh ad er creggyn, hilg ad kiare akeryn magh ec y stiurey, as ghow ad foddiaght son y laa.

English: 30 And as the shipmen were about to flee out of the ship, when they had let down the boat into the sea, under colour as though they would have cast anchors out of the foreship,
Manx: As myr va ny marreeyn mysh cosney ass y lhong, tra v’ad er lhiggey yn baatey sheese er y cheayn, myr dy beagh ad goll dy hilgey akeryn magh ec toshiaght ny luingey,

English: 31 Paul said to the centurion and to the soldiers, Except these abide in the ship, ye cannot be saved.
Manx: Dooyrt Paul rish y captan-keead as rish ny sidooryn, Mannagh vuirree ad shoh ayns y lhong, cha vod shiu v’er nyn sauail.

English: 32 Then the soldiers cut off the ropes of the boat, and let her fall off.
Manx: Eish[t] yiare ny sidooryn teddyn y vaatey, as lhig ad y raad jee.

English: 33 And while the day was coming on, Paul besought them all to take meat, saying, This day is the fourteenth day that ye have tarried and continued fasting, having taken nothing.
Manx: As myr va’n laa soilshaghey, choyrlee Paul ad ooilley dy ghoaill beaghey, gra, Ta shiu jiu er chur shiaghey yn chiarroo laa yeig, as er chummal nyn drostey, fegooish nhee erbee y ghoaill.

English: 34 Wherefore I pray you to take some meat : for this is for your health : for there shall not an hair fall from the head of any of you.
Manx: Shen-y-fa my choyrle’s eh shiu dy ghoaill beaghey ; son te son y slaynt eu : son cha duit renaig jeh kione annane eu.

English: 35 And when he had thus spoken, he took bread, and gave thanks to God in presence of them all : and when he had broken it, he began to eat.
Manx: As tra v’eh er ghra shoh, ghow Eh arran, as hug eh booise da Jee, ayns yn enish oc ooilley, as vrish Eh eh, as ren Eh toshiaght dy ee.

English: 36 Then were they all of good cheer, and they also took some meat.
Manx: Eisht v’ad ooilley ayns cree mie, as myrgeddin ghow ad beaghey.

English: 37 And we were in all in the ship two hundred threescore and sixteen souls.
Manx: As va shin ayns ooilley ayns y lhong, daa cheead, three feed as shey anmeenyn jeig.

English: 38 And when they had eaten enough, they lightened the ship, and cast out the wheat into the sea.
Manx: As tra v’ad er n’ee dy liooar, deddrymmee ad y lhong, as hilg ad y churnaght magh ayns y cheayn.

English: 39 And when it was day, they knew not the land : but they discovered a certain creek with a shore, into the which they were minded, if it were possible, to thrust in the ship.
Manx: As tra va’n laa ayn, cha dug ad enney er y thalloo : agh chronnee ad giuag dy row, as er y traie echey, v’ad aignagh, my ve possible, yn lhong y roie stiagh.

English: 40 And when they had taken up the anchors, they committed themselves unto the sea, and loosed the rudder bands, and hoised up the mainsail to the wind, and made toward shore.
Manx: As hrog ad ny akeryn, as daag ad ad hene gys y cheayn, as deayshil ad bondaghyn y stiurey, as hug ad yn shiaul main gys y gheay, as ren ad gys y traie.

English: 41 And falling into a place where two seas met, they ran the ship aground ; and the forepart stuck fast, and remained unmoveable, but the hinder part was broken with the violence of the waves.
Manx: As huit ad ayns boayl raad va daa fairkey cheet quail y chielley, as roih ad y lhong er thalloo ; as va’n toshiaght eck soit cha shickyr, nagh row ee scughey, agh va’n jerrey eck brisht lesh niart ny tonnyn.

English: 42 And the soldiers’ counsel was to kill the prisoners, lest any of them should swim out, and escape.
Manx: As coyrle ny sidooryn ve dy varroo ny pryssoonee, er aggle dy snaauagh veg jeu magh, as dy gosnagh ad rowe.

English: 43 But the centurion, willing to save Paul, kept them from their purpose ; and commanded that they which could swim should cast themselves first into the sea, and get to land :
Manx: Agh va’n captan-keead booiagh Paul y hauail, as lhiett Eh ad veih shen y yannoo, as doardee Eh adsyn oddagh snaaue, ad dy hilgey ad hene hoshiaght ayns y cheayn, as ad dy hayrtyn gys y thalloo :

English: 44 And the rest, some on boards, and some on broken pieces of the ship. And so it came to pass, that they escaped all safe to land.
Manx: As y chooid elley, paart er buird, as paart er peeshyn jeh’n lhong : as myr shen haink eh gy kione, dy dooar ad ooilley dy sauchey gys thalloo.
CAB. XXVIII.

English: And when they were escaped, then they knew that the island was called Melita.
Manx: As erreish daue v’er geddyn dy sauchey er thalloo, eisht va fys oc dy row yn ellan enmyssit Melita.

English: 2 And the barbarous people shewed us no little kindness : for they kindled a fire, and received us every one, because of the present rain, and because of the cold.
Manx: As va ny barbarianee feer dooie dooin ; son dod ad aile, as ghow ad dy chooilley annane ain stiagh kyndagh rish y fliaghey v’ayn, as kyndagh rish y feayraght.

English: 3 And when Paul had gathered a bundle of sticks, and laid them on the fire, there came a viper out of the heat, and fastened on his hand.
Manx: As heih Paul kionnan dy vrasnagyn, as hug Eh ad er yn aile, as haink ard-nieu as y chiass, as leïme eh er e laue.

English: 4 And when the barbarians saw the venomous beast hang on his hand, they said among themselves, No doubt this man is a murderer, whom, though he hath escaped the sea, yet vengeance suffereth not to live.
Manx: As tra honnick ny barbarianee yn cretoor pooshoonagh croghey rish e laue, dooyrt ad nyn mast’ oc hene, Fegooish dooyt ta’n dooinney shoh ny ghunver, cha lhig kerraghey Yee da ve bio, ga t’eh er scapail y keayn.

English: 5 And he shook off the beast into the fire, and felt no harm.
Manx: As chrie Eh yn ard-nieu jeh’n laue echey ayns yn aile, as cha dennee Eh skielley erbee.

English: 6 Howbeit they looked when he should have swollen, or fallen down dead suddenly : but after they had looked a great while, and saw no harm come to him, they changed their minds, and said that he was a god.
Manx: Agh ghow adsyn oc hene dy beagh Eh er n’att, ny er duittym sheese marroo doaltattym ; agh tra v’ad foddey er n’yeeaghyn, as nagh vaik ad aggair erbee er jeet er, haink ad gys smooinaghtyn elley, as dooyrt ad dy nee Jee v’eh.

English: 7 In the same quarters were possessions of the chief man of the island, whose name was Publius ; who received us, and lodged us three days courteously.
Manx: Ayns ny ardjyn shen va thieyn as thalloo lesh kiannoort ny hellan, va enmyssit Publius, veih hooar shin oltaghey-bea, as aaght ry three laa dy gennal.

English: 8 And it came to pass, that the father of Publius lay sick of a fever and of a bloody flux : to whom Paul entered in, and prayed, and laid his hands on him, and healed him.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione, dy row ayr Publius ny lhie dy ching ayns y chiassaghey, as ayns giarey folley : as hie Paul stiagh huggey, as ghow Eh padjer, as hug Eh e laueyn er, as laanee Eh Eh.

English: 9 So when this was done, others also, which had diseases in the island, came, and were healed :
Manx: As erreish da v’er n’yannoo shoh, haink feallagh elley neesht va doghanyn oc ayns yn ellan, as v’ad er nyn lheihys :

English: 10 Who also honoured us with many honours ; and when we departed, they laded us with such things as were necessary.
Manx: As hug ad ymmodee leaghyn onnoroïl dooin, as tra va shin goll roïn, laad ad shin lesh leid ny reddyn as veagh ymmyrchagh.

English: 11 And after three months we departed in a ship of Alexandria, which had wintered in the isle, whose sign was Castor and Pollux.
Manx: As lurg three meeghyn, hiauil shin ayns lhong dy Alexandria v’er ve car y yeuree ayns yn ellan, yn cowrey eck va Castor as Pollux.

English: 12 And landing at Syracuse, we tarried there three days.
Manx: As haink shin er thalloo ec Syracuse, duirree shin ayns shen three laa.

English: 13 And from thence we fetched a compass, and came to Rhegium : and after one day the south wind blew, and we came the next day to Puteoli :
Manx: As veih shen hiauil shin mygeayrt, as haink shin gys Rhegium : as ec kione un laa heid y gheay ec y jass ; as yn nah laa haink shin gys Puteoli :

English: 14 Where we found brethren, and were desired to tarry with them seven days : and so we went toward Rome.
Manx: Ayns shen hooar shin braaraghyn, as va aghin jeant hooin shin dy uirriaght mâroo shiaght laa : as shen myr hie shin gys y Raue.

English: 15 And from thence, when the brethren heard of us, they came to meet us as far as Appii forum, and The three taverns : whom when Paul saw, he thanked God, and took courage.
Manx: As veih shen, tra cheayll ny braaraghyn jin, haink ad magh nyn guail choud as Appii forum, as choud as ny Three ard-thieyn oast : as tra honnick Paul ad, hug Eh booise da Jee, as ghow Eh dunnalys.

English: 16 And when we came to Rome, the centurion delivered the prisoners to the captain of the guard : but Paul was suffered to dwell by himself with a soldier that kept him.
Manx: As tra haink shin gys y Raue, livrey yn captan-keead ny pryssoonee gys captan y ghard : agh ve lowit da Paul thie y ve echey da hene, marish sidoor va dy yeeaghyn da.

English: 17 And it came to pass, that after three days Paul called the chief of the Jews together : and when they were come together, he said unto them, Men and brethren, though I have committed nothing against the people, or customs of our fathers, yet was I delivered prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans.
Manx: As haink eh gy kione lurg three laa, dy deïe Paul er ny ard Hewnyn cooidjagh. As tra v’ad er jeet huggey, dooyrt Eh roo, Gheiney as vraaraghyn, ga nagh vel mee er n’yannoo nhee erbee noi yn pobble, ny cliaghtaghyn ny ayraghyn ain, foast va mee er my livrey seose my phryssoonagh veih Jerusalem gys laueyn y vooinjer ta bentyn rish y Raue.

English: 18 Who, when they had examined me, would have let me go, because there was no cause of death in me.
Manx: As tra v’ad shoh er my eaysht, v’ad booiagh yn raad y lhiggey dou, er-y-fa nagh row oyr erbee baaish aynym.

English: 19 But when the Jews spake against it, I was constrained to appeal unto Caesar ; not that I had ought to accuse my nation of.
Manx: Agh tra loayr ny Hewnyn m’oi, va mee eaginit dy pheallal gys Cesar ; cha nee son dy row playnt erbee aym dy yannoo er my ashoon.

English: 20 For this cause therefore have I called for you, to see you, and to speak with you : because that for the hope of Israel I am bound with this chain.
Manx: Er-yn-oyr shoh er-y-fa shen ta mee er chur fys erriuish, dy akin shiu, as dy loayrt riu : er-y-fa son treishteil Israel dy vel mee kainlt lesh y geuley shoh.

English: 21 And they said unto him, We neither received letters out of Judaea concerning thee, neither any of the brethren that came shewed or spake any harm of thee.
Manx: As dooyrt ad rish, Cha dooar shinyn screeuyn veih Judea my dty chione, cha-moo ren veg jeh ny braaraghyn t’er jeet soilshaghey ny loayrt red erbee dy holk jeed.

English: 22 But we desire to hear of thee what thou thinkest : for as concerning this sect, we know that every where it is spoken against.
Manx: Agh ta shin booiagh clashtyn voids, cre t’ow dy smooinaghtyn : son mychione y shaghrynys shoh veih’n chredjue, ta fys ain dy vel eh ayns dy chooilley ynnyd loayrit noi.

English: 23 And when they had appointed him a day, there came many to him into his lodging ; to whom he expounded and testified the kingdom of God, persuading them concerning Jesus, both out of the law of Moses, and out of the prophets, from morning till evening.
Manx: As tra v’ad er hoiaghey laa da, haink ymmodee huggey gys e hie ; as hug Eh tushtey daue, as dymmyrk Eh feanish jeh reeriaght Yee, coyrlaghey ad mychione Yeesey, chammah ass leigh Voses, as veih ny phadeyryn, veih moghrey derrey fastyr.

English: 24 And some believed the things which were spoken, and some believed not.
Manx: As va paart jeu chred ny reddyn va loayrit, as paart elley nagh ren credjal.

English: 25 And when they agreed not among themselves, they departed, after that Paul had spoken one word, Well spake the Holy Ghost by Esaias the prophet unto our fathers,
Manx: As tra nagh chord ad nyn mast’ oc hene, jimmee ad rowe, erreish da Paul v’er loayrt un ockle, S’mie loayr yn Spyrryd Noo liorish Esaias yn phadeyr rish ny ayraghyn ain.

English: 26 Saying, Go unto this people, and say, Hearing ye shall hear, and shall not understand ; and seeing ye shall see, and not perceive :
Manx: Gra, Gow royd gys y pobble shoh as abbyr, Liorish clashtyn, nee shiu clashtyn, agh cha doig shiu : as lesh fakin, nee shiu fakin, agh cha gronnee shiu.

English: 27 For the heart of this people is waxed gross, and their ears are dull of hearing, and their eyes have they closed ; lest they should see with their eyes, and hear with their ears, and understand with their heart, and should be converted, and I should heal them.
Manx: Son ta cree yn phobble shoh er n’aase roauyr, as ta ny cleashyn oc moal dy chlashtyn, as nyn sooyllyn  t’ad er n’yeigh ; er aggle dy jinnagh ad fakin lesh nyn sooyllyn, as clashtyn lesh nyn gleashyn, as toiggal lesh nyn greeaghyn, as dy beagh ad er nyn jyndaa, as dy jinnin ad y lheihys.

English: 28 Be it known therefore unto you, that the salvation of God is sent unto the Gentiles, and that they will hear it.
Manx: Lig da fys y ve eauish er-y-fa shen, dy vel saualtys Yee er ny choyrt gys ny Ashoonyn-quaagh, as dy neaisht ad rish.

English: 29 And when he had said these words, the Jews departed, and had great reasoning among themselves.
Manx: As tra v’eh er loayrt ny goan shoh, jimmee ny Hewnyn rowe, as va mooarane resooney nyn mast’ oc hene.

English: 30 And Paul dwelt two whole years in his own hired house, and received all that came in unto him,
Manx: As chum Paul ry daa vlein cooidjagh ayns e hie maallee hene, goaill stiagh dy chooilley annane va cheet huggey ;

English: 31 Preaching the kingdom of God, and teaching those things which concern the Lord Jesus Christ, with all confidence, no man forbidding him.
Manx: Preacheil daue reeriaght Yee, as gynsaghey ny reddyn va bentyn rish y Chiarn Yeesey Creest, lesh dunnalys, as fegooish ve er ny lhiettal.
Jerrey Jannoo ny Ostyllyn.
